HEADLINE: Advice From the Trenches

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle; Louis Uchitelle reports on economics for The New York Times.

 BODY:

MOVING MOUNTAINS
Lessons in Leadership and Logistics
From the Gulf War.
By William G. Pagonis
with Jeffrey L. Cruikshank.
Illustrated. 248 pp. Boston:
Harvard Business School Press.
$24.95. 
 HAVING kept American forces well supplied during the Persian Gulf war, Lieut. Gen. William G. Pagonis now offers corporate America lessons in innovative management. "Moving Mountains: Lessons in Leadership and Logistics From the Gulf War" is not a modest book. General Pagonis maintains that, in effect, his achievements as the leader of a huge Army logistics team rank him among the nation's more imaginative and effective top executives.
Military memoirs, in his view, are no longer the preserve of combat commanders like General Grant or General Eisenhower or, most recently, General Schwarzkopf. Supplying military expeditions in the post-cold war era is also heroic, he believes, and the Army's performance in the gulf is evidence that America is supreme in that field. "Our logistical successes in the gulf war," General Pagonis writes, "suggest to me that our colleagues in the private sector may now get some good guidance from us." In the 19th century European generals came to this country to learn something about moving and supplying large, complicated forces by observing P. T. Barnum's maneuvers with his vast circus. Now American industry, the general suggests, should look not only to Japan and Germany for lessons in efficiency, but also to the United States Army.
That would be quite a spinoff victory from the gulf war, if it were true. But while General Pagonis is clearly an effective executive, his management precepts are already known to corporate America, or should be. More than a decade of self-analysis and self-criticism for having lost the industrial lead to Japan and Germany has produced a huge volume of literature on how to manage workers, reorganize and inspire them, and how to keep strategic goals simple and flexible.
"Moving Mountains," written with Jeffrey L. Cruickshank, a communications consultant, is a bracing review of these lessons, even offering an original management tool: 3-by-5 cards, each with a handwritten message, that General Pagonis and his corps used by the thousands to keep information flowing rapidly. But such management agility is now standard in corporate America, and "Moving Mountains" is far from being a breakthrough book.
Disconcertingly, General Pagonis shifts back and forth from memoir to management textbook, with the latter occupying two-thirds of the book. The memoir is more vivid, anecdotal and instructive. For months William (Gus) Pagonis was billed in the news media as the logistics genius who, as head of the Army's 22d Support Command, had fed, housed and equipped more than half a million American troops on short notice. As he notes, moving that large a force and all its equipment was like moving the whole state of Alaska and everything in it around the globe and then keeping it going. How did he do it? General Pagonis offers a broad outline, but starves his readers for detail.
One lesson comes through loud and clear. Saudi Arabia turned out to be a well-equipped and friendly staging area for a war. When the general arrived with a skeleton staff, he rented Saudi buses to transport the thousands of troops piling up on airport tarmacs without a clue about what to do next. And he secured 10,000 Bedouin tents to help house them.
The greatest feat, getting so many Americans and so much ammunition and equipment from the United States to Saudi Arabia in a few weeks, is not the subject of this book, and that is disappointing. Others managed this aspect of the operation; the general and his men -- a corporate work force, so to speak, that reached 50,000 people -- handled the distribution within Saudi Arabia.
And for all their organizational skills, they might have failed if the Saudis had not made available deep-water ports with excellent docks and huge warehouses, fresh food and thousands of trucks and buses that were rented, each with a driver, from the Philippines, Korea, Turkey or Bangladesh. The same war, staged from a much less friendly country like Jordan or Syria, might not have made the 51-year-old General Pagonis such a management hero.
MOVING tanks hundreds of miles to the front line, for example, was a major problem. Under their own steam, the tanks would have torn up the asphalt highways or burned too much fuel and created too many maintenance problems. General Pagonis urgently needed big transport trucks, and the Army had only 112 in Saudi Arabia. "We were able to assemble a fleet of nearly 1,300 H.E.T.'s [heavy equipment transporters] and tractor trailers, most of which came equipped with experienced third-country national drivers," the general reports. And on to the next problem.
Zahir Mastri, a friend of King Fahd, solved General Pagonis's fresh-food problem. As the general tells the story in an amusing section of the book, troops waiting months in the desert for the war to start required a diet that went beyond dry Army rations, and Mr. Mastri's company, Astra Foods, operated the largest covered farm in the world. Soon Astra Foods and the Pagonis team had mess halls everywhere as well as mobile fast-food canteens, with King Fahd paying most of the bill. King Fahd, the good Arab host, had sent Mr. Mastri to the Americans.
A successful company, of course, is not only efficient but profitable. The gulf war's urgency saved General Pagonis from budget constraints, and the Army's buying power was a magnet not only for Saudi merchants but also for suppliers in neighboring countries. "Word spread like wildfire that the American military was paying in Saudi riyals -- a desirable currency -- and that payment was made every two weeks," General Pagonis writes. "Since the Saudi Government was in the habit of paying its vendors only once or twice a year, we were suddenly the favorite clients on the block."
And in the end it is that buying power that makes Army executives, even those as skilled as General Pagonis, less than credible as management gurus.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 31; Column 2; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 2355 words

HEADLINE: Impressionist Master

BYLINE: By William Grimes; William Grimes is a culture reporter for The New York Times.

 BODY:
Out on the campaign trail, the voters are getting a double dose of the character and trust issue, the family-values issue, the come-clean-on-the-draft issue. But on stage at Stand-Up NY, a brick-walled comedy club, a familiar-sounding figure is getting right down to bedrock, lambasting Bill Clinton's economic program. "I call it Elvis economics," says the shrill and insistent voice of George Bush, "a reckless policy of excessive spending that causes the Government to get fatter and fatter until one day the economy just falls off the toilet and dies."
The line is funny, but not, by itself, hysterical. What has the audience doubled over are the voice and the mannerisms, the grin that wanders up the right side of the face, the hectoring tone that slides right into a whine, the short intakes of breath after every third word to buy precious time in the desperate struggle to hold syntax together. It is a trulyPresidential performance, one that Jim Morris, a political humorist who specializes in impressions, has refined for a dozen years now. 
 The ridicule is bipartisan. Suddenly, Bill Clinton, his voice hoarse and slightly weepy, is fielding questions about his draft record. "If you're going to go back into someone's past, then you must view their actions in the light of that time, not what they look like 23 years later, when I'm 46 and running for President of the United States," Morris says, all earnest appeal, a little like a televangelist soliciting love offerings. "Twenty-three years ago I wore a Nehru jacket, but today I'm not running for Prime Minister of India."
Campaign '92 has been tough enough for Bush and Clinton. For Morris it has been hell. Consider the problem. Ross Perot was in, out and then in again. At one point, the Democratic pack included, besides Clinton, Paul Tsongas, Douglas Wilder, Jerry Brown, Bob Kerrey, Tom Harkin. Each with a distinct voice and manner. Each a potential winner. Each a mammoth homework assignment for Morris.
"It's a very nervous time, because I'm thinking, 'Will I have a career next year?' " says Morris, sitting in the Frank Sinatra Room of the Friars Club in midtown Manhattan the day after his appearance at Stand-Up NY. "This time around I was thinking, 'Cuomo, I don't know how I'm going to do him.' His waffling drove me crazy, because for me to work up an impression takes hours and hours."
Morris, 35 years old, is dark-haired and slim. He stands 6 feet 2 inches, the same height as the President, which helps when it comes to projecting the loose, gangling Bush. Offstage, he is quite shy and soft-spoken, and high-strung. He is a chronic worrier. Things are going well now. A resident of Los Angeles, he has appeared on "The Tonight Show," "Comic Relief" and "Larry King Live." On CNN's "Crossfire" he has withstood fierce questioning as all three candidates. He is in high demand for political banquets, corporate functions and funny television commercials.
But national politics can be unpredictable and cruel. Richard Gephardt, whose nonappearance in the 1992 Presidential race Morris greeted with profound relief, could rise again. And the white-bread, no-there-there specter of Dan Quayle in '96 disturbs his sleep.
Overall, the Republicans have been very good to Morris. Eight years of Reagan were an impressionist's dream. At this point, Morris does not even have to open his mouth to get the character across. At Stand-Up NY, he begins his act simply by going through the full panoply of Reagan expressions, his favorite being the open-mouthed look of surprisewhen a thought flies right out of the Gipper's leftear. In his full-length solo show, Morris routinely scores big with a silent-film-style vignetteof Reagan rising and preparing for the day.
Bush has been a piece of cake. Morris got him down pat back in 1980, when Bush's chances for the Presidency looked fairly good. It's safe to say that today he pretty much owns the Bush franchise. Dana Carvey, who does Bush on "Saturday Night Live" and worked as a comedian in San Franciso at the same time Morris did in the early 80's, has tried to worm the secret out of him, to no avail.
But Bush faded, as Vice Presidents are wont to do, so Morris had to put him on the back shelf for eight years and concentrate on Ronald Reagan. Both men now loom large in his stand-up act, in which he draws on the day's headlines and reworks them in the voices of the major political players, as well as broadcasters like Ted Koppel, Sam Donaldson, Dan Rather and Tom Brokaw. If Clinton should prove victorious, Morris says, he will phase out Bush slowly. Perot will probably exit more quickly -- stage left, arms waving.
Like many other Americans, Morris was floored when he found out that Bill Clinton didn't inhale. It was a turning point in the campaign, the moment when an absolutely critical piece of information brought the candidate's character into focus.
To demonstrate, Morris lapses into Clinton-speak. "Folks, Ah feel yur pain, Ah know what yur goin' through." The voice starts out strong but quickly softens to a raspy whisper, an insinuating, intimate delivery, with just a hint of sob. A normal person would have taken a breath to power the second half of the sentence. But Clinton doesn't inhale.
"I discovered that if I just breathe out, I can still get the nasal quality and the hoarseness," Morris says. He also throws in a few of the Clinton mannerisms. First, there's the back-and-forth head wag -- "there's a little cockiness there," Morris points out. He also bites his lower lip when rounding off a phrase, a movement that pulls his eyebrows down to project extra sincerity and compassion. But the breathing is the subtle touch that finishes off the impression. "That's the whole sexual thing," says Morris. "I think he's really got something there."
MORRIS STARTED SMALL, WORKING UP impressions of his parents and relatives in Boston. In his junior year of high school he successfully ran for class president. For his campaign, he stood before the assembled classmates and offered up endorsements of himself in the voices of the school's teachers. He was elected to two terms.
Morris took a few stabs at college, then lit out for Europe. He returned about a year later, just as the comedy-club scene began taking off in Boston.
What happened next is almost too good to be true. A friend asked Morris to come with him to a club called Comedy Connection in 1978. Throughout the evening, Morris pestered the club owner to allow him onstage. At the end of the night, he got his wish.
"I just got up there, and all this stuff that had been pent up for years came pouring out of me," he says. He did impresions of local and state politicians, and threw in Julia Child for a bonus. "I brought the house down. I've worked ever since."
Although Morris retains not a trace of a Massachusetts accent, he has made a minor specialty of Boston politicians, including former Gov. Ed King and former Mayor Kevin White. He also does Senator Ted Kennedy, Michael Dukakis and Paul Tsongas. On one occasion, he used the voice of White to fix two restaurant reservations for himself and a friend at Durgin Park, but he says "that's about as far as I've gone in abusing my talent."
His Tsongas impression is so good -- it's a ballet of bizarre upper-lip movements -- that he has kept the erstwhile candidate in his act. A sure-fire laugh comes when Tsongas says, "I dropped out of the campaign for lack of racehorses." Morris explains that the word is what the rest of us know as "resources."
Morris left Boston for San Francisco in 1980, where he worked comedy clubs and, over a period of about four months, developed a Reagan impression that was good enough to build a business around, called Rent-a-Reagan.
In 1982, Morris moved to Washington. "I decided Reagan was not giving enough press conferences, and I thought, 'Why don't I go to Washington and give them myself?' " he says.
In fact, Morris came no closer to Reagan than watching him pass by in a motorcade down Pennsylvania Avenue. But he has served up the full Bush impression to the President on three occasions. In 1989, he was invited to the White House correspondents dinner, a Washington power occasion that the President usually attends. This was red meat toMorris. "It was like starting in the All-Star Game," he says. "I could say I did an impression of the President to his face and retained my citizenship."
The stakes were high, as Morris realized when he left the dais to visit the men's room and found himself surrounded by three Secret Service agents. He returned, took the microphone and simply became George Bush.
"As soon as I opened my mouth, I was the one who had the power, I was the President," says Morris. Giddy with his newfound sense of Presidential privilege, he pressed his advantage. He began pointing to Cabinet members in the audience and calling them by their first names. Then he leaned over and addressed the President:
"This imposter sitting on my right thinks he's the President. Well, I have news for him. Read my lips. I know the President, and I am that man."
Bush loved it. Morris asked Barbara Bush if she minded his making fun of her husband. Not at all, it turned out. "She said, 'Yes, you're making fun of him, but you're not cruel. You don't do it in a mean way.' " Most comedians would have taken this as a compliment. Not Morris. "I was hurt," he says. "My mission is to make these people look as foolish as possible."
MORRIS BUILDS HIS IMPRESSIONS SLOWLY and painstakingly. He begins with a perception of character that allows him, as he puts it, to "hook into" a personality. Take Michael Dukakis, whose candidacy Morris dreaded, because it meant having to inhabit the soul of the man.
"I'm no authority on how he feels; only he knows that," Morris says. "But I have to feel certain things. I saw arrogance, a dour, scowling manner, as though he was thinking: 'Why do I have to deal with this problem? I don't see why I have to campaign this way. I know best.' " For Dan Rather, the hook was intensity. The key to Bush, whose voice and mannerisms Morris describes as a cross between John Wayne, Jack Nicholson and Liberace, lies in the President's acute sense of discomfort when forced outside the confines of his social class.
"He's a guy who really doesn't want to have to mix with the common folk, answer questions and press the flesh," Morris says. "There's this tension in his face. Sometimes he clenches his teeth when he smiles, so he gets that crooked grin. It's a fissure in the facade, and that's an opening for me."
Once he has established a hook, Morris begins the careful work of assembling videotapes of his subject, replaying them over and over, and compiling a repertory of sounds, which he then puts together to make a word, a phrase and finally a sentence. In difficult cases, he draws a chart with vocal sounds and makes annotations.
"A good impressionist," he says, "will point out certain foibles, quirks or mannerisms the audience never knew the person had, but once they see it, they say, 'Oh yeah.' " Morris noticed thatatnews conferences Bush has a habit of parking his tongue between his teeth on the left side of his face when waiting for a question. So he used that.
"For Ted Koppel, I found the key to the impression was holding my head absolutely still," he says. Morris always includes a bit in which, as Koppel, he recites "Light My Fire" by the Doors. It is funny for reasons neither the audience nor Morris understands.
The work never ends. Morris constantly tinkers, refines and fusses. As he travels, he carries a Sony Watchman so he can tape news broadcasts and press conferences. He also carries his own study tapes. On stage, he makes slight adjustments and corrections as he speaks.
He writes his own material, drawing on the daily newspapers, magazines, network news, C-Span and CNN to keep the material current. Some of Morris's best bits begin with a quote from a candidate. "Once there were three policemen for every crime," he says, borrowing Clinton's line. "Now there are three crimes for every policeman. In Surf City, U.S.A., there used to be two girls for every boy, according to Beach Boys statistics. You can see how badly things have gone awry under the Bush Administration."
Morris likes the news-conference format, with questions thrown out by the audience. He has an acute sense of the political language that allows him to answer -- and evade -- with the slickest of them.
When an audience member asks an uncomfortable personal question of Bush -- "Are you having an affair?" seems to pop up fairly often -- Morris is ready: "I'll repeat that question for those of you who may not have heard it. The question was, 'Are you a good President?' And the answer is, 'Yes, I am a good President.' "
For tough questions on the economy, Morris has a bipartisan answer that he can use either as Bush or Clinton. Generally, it's triggered when someone asks what he intends to do about the deficit.
"Well, that's a very good question, and I think the answer to that question is that what we need to do for the economy is to see to it that whatever it is that needs to get done gets done, so that one day we'll be able to look back and tell our kids andtell our grandkids and tell our grandkids' kids that when it came to doing something about the economy, we did whatever it was we thought we had to do to try to see to it that whatever it was that needed to get done got done."
When Morris's Clinton delivers this, it is genuinely impassioned -- and quite moving. "I'm in overdrive on Clinton right now, trying to pick up everything I can," Morris says. "I like it when he gets all weepy. When he's sincere. He's very good when he clasps his hands together, sort of a Southern church thing, like he's going to heal the nation."
The prospect of a Democratic victory in November bothers him not in the least. The comic possibilities look very, very good -- and the motivation never changes.
"It's always fun when someone's in the hot seat to make them suffer a little more."

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 20; Column 1; Education Life Supplement

LENGTH: 1490 words

HEADLINE: Battling British Tradition

BYLINE: By Susan Chira

 BODY:
TWO young student guides raced through a tour of their school, clearly at home but still a bit in awe at the riches within: computers everywhere, inside classrooms and out. Breakfast for everybody, offered in a sleek, modern space with wide tables, where students serve themselves. A library where books are checked out like groceries, with a bar code.
This is the Kingshurst City Technology College, an alternative inner-city high school in Solihull, England, near the industrial city of Birmingham, that is challenging traditional notions of what school should be. 
 Kingshurst is actually an incorporated company, founded with donations from British businesses. The business link is important: Kingshurst emphasizes math, science and technology, and it was corporate money that outfitted the school with high-technology equipment, including one computer for every four students. Many of the technological specialists, mathematicians and scientists on staff were hired from companies, not out of education schools. And many of the students take advantage of the workplace experience that Kingshurst, with its business ties, can offer.
There are other innovative practices at Kingshurst. Teachers, for example, are paid according to performance, while students attend classes an hour longer each day and 15 days more each year than is usual for their age and grade. The school offers day care for children of employees and older students.
Many of these ideas are exactly what President Bush had in mind when he called for "New American Schools" -- a rethinking of how schools can best serve children, families and employers in the late 20th century. Like the framers of an ambitious school reform effort now under way in Britain, President Bush believes that such institutions could serve as a model and goad to schools still clinging to the old ways.
They haven't yet in Britain, and Mr. Bush's critics are skeptical about model schools changing the vast majority of schools in the United States.
So far, Kingshurst and the 12 other city technology colleges now open in Britain appear to have inspired more resentment than imitators. Nor have businesses anted up as much money to found new schools as government leaders had expected.
 
Passionate Allegiance
 But the schools have the passionate allegiance of students, parents, teachers and administrators, who believe they are charting a course that will convince the doubters. "In this country, we are only successful with the top 10 or 20 percent," said Valerie Bragg, Kings hurst's principal. "I want to prove to this country that all children are talented." That is a particularly important task in Britain, where only 20 percent of students go on to higher education, and in the area around Birmingham, where only about 20 percent of students stay in school through age 18.
City technology colleges try to reverse these trends by combining academic and vocational training, which in Britain are usually separated. They are supposed to serve inner-city students and, among those who apply, must accept youngsters with a wide range of abilities. Mrs. Bragg was otherwise free to create any school she wanted, using ideas she had garnered from a long career as a principal of conventional schools.
Mrs. Bragg recruited more than 70 corporate sponsors, who paid 20 percent of the $19 million cost of building Kings hurst. While the Government gives Kingshurst the same yearly allotment as other schools, the sponsors have donated about $950,000 a year to pay for such things as computers, software and field trips.
With this money, Mrs. Bragg designed a building defined by space and light -- with a curving roof of glass like a greenhouse, walls of windows and classrooms shaped like hexagons instead of squares.
Students use technology in every aspect of their work, from writing papers to designing lighting for the school stage. Their courses have a heavy dose of business, including food and textile technology, information processing, simulations of stock markets. And students have much more freedom than they usually get in British schools -- to learn at their own pace, use computers scattered at will or stay inside when most schools chase students out for recess or after hours.
Four years after Kingshurst opened in 1988, Mrs. Bragg says she has students who are not only motivated, but also aggressive about making sure they learn. "I am convinced what learning is about is getting children to enjoy learning," she said. "If you show them how to learn, those skills can be used for all sorts of things."
As one example, Mrs. Bragg encourages every member of the school, including the custodian, to teach "enrichment" courses, ranging from pottery to kite-making to Italian, which students take several times a year during the school day.
Her students love the school -- and these are children from poor and working-class backgrounds who are usually shunted onto vocational tracks and whatever low-level jobs exist. Nearly a third of the students' families are unemployed, 40 percent live in single-parent homes and 35 percent have such low family incomes that they qualify for free meals.
 
'Allowed to Think'
 "You're treated differently here," said Aimee Weir, 12 years old, who started her second year at Kingshurst this fall. "You're allowed to think. In my primary school, the teachers gave you a book and taught. Here, you've got to find your own way."
A quick tour of Kingshurst conducted by Aimee showed a purposeful, lavishly equipped school. In one room a student sat alone, practicing on a tuba. In a religious studies class, students who had examined the character of Henry VIII were writing autobiographies.
Few outsiders dispute that Kingshurst has captured the imagination and allegiance of students who often hate school by this stage. But scholars and Government education inspectors charge that it has not lived up to its billing, primarily because it has not served as a catalyst for change.
Two scholars from Aston University, in Birmingham, studied Kingshurst and concluded in a book published last year that the school is cut off from other schools, parents and community leaders and has not prompted changes elsewhere. They and other scholars say that many schools resent Kingshurst, accuse it of creaming off the most motivated students and believe it does better because it has better facilities.
"City technology colleges have been a policy failure," said Geoff J. Whitty, a professor of education policy and management at London University's Goldsmiths College, who has also examined these schools. "There is no real mechanism for networking. Local schools just say the city technology colleges have much better budgets."
These are precisely the objections that critics have made to President Bush's idea of New American Schools. Model school projects in the past, they say, have created a handful of wonderful schools that remained isolated enclaves.
While most scholars praised the quality of education at Kingshurst, a report last year by Her Majesty's Inspectorate, a Government school inspection team, said the school offered good information technology but faulted its training in design technology and languages. Mrs. Bragg said the criticism was unjust. The book was based on Kingshurst's first year, she said, and the inspectors came on a day when several language teachers were out sick. She believes that Kingshurst's approach is indeed swaying other schools, particularly in its decision to offer several alternatives to the traditional "A" levels, the examinations that lead to college entrance in Britain.
 
'International' Degree
 Instead, students may study for an "International Baccalaureate" that qualifies them to enter both British and foreign universities, or a business diploma that includes work experience and job placements that Kings hurst helps to arrange.
Mrs. Bragg and her students clearly feel the strain of being a closely watched, highly politicized national experiment. But students say the pressure makes them more determined to prove their school works. "Because we're given so much responsibility, we don't want to muck around," said Chantal Jackson, a 13-year-old in her third year there.
Still others say Kingshurst has invited criticism by grandiose claims. "It's partly because of the boasts made -- letterheads saying, 'The future of education has arrived,' " said Martin Dobson, an 18-year-old studying for the International Baccalaureate.
The future of such schools is not clear in Britain. The victory of the Conservative Party in last spring's elections insures that the Government will have the power to continue the market-oriented changes it believes will transform British education. But in the meantime, the successes and failures of the city technology colleges may offer lessons for Americans as this country begins to move down a similar path.

HEADLINE: The Apprentices' Youthful Tale

BYLINE: By John Holusha

 BODY:
CHRISTOPHER BARTO was "extremely bored" with the academic program at Hughesville High School, near Williamsport, Pa., after his sophomore year. Most of the teaching and reading, he said, involved "just letters and numbers; a lot of things not related to the real world."
So he decided to do something other than slog his way through the remaining two years or drop out. When a guidance counselor described a new program designed to combine schooling with a factory job, he decided, in his words, "to go for it." 
 Now he attends a specially tailored education program during the school year and works part time at Tempella Power Corporation in Williamsport, a producer of industrial boilers. If he stays with the program for four years, he will wind up with an associate's degree from a junior college, a certificate of mastery of industrial technology from the state and, almost certainly, a job as an operator of computerized design and manufacturing equipment.
The Pennsylvania Youth Apprenticeship Program is one of a handful of efforts around the nation to prepare young people not planning to attend a four-year college for the high-technology, self-directed workplace of the future. It is both an attempt to prepare youths for high-skill, higher-paying jobs and to persuade them of the relevance of the academic subjects they are studying.
Worker training has become an issue in the current Presidential campaign. The Democratic candidate, Gov. Bill Clinton, promoted apprentice programs in his home state of Arkansas and advocates a national apprentice system as part of a broader worker-training program. President Bush has been less vocal, but has included apprentice demonstration projects in efforts intended to ease the school-to-work transition.
Proponents of apprenticeship programs say they provide high-status alternatives to traditional academic curriculums, which are taught by college graduates who stress college preparation to the exclusion of other tracks. "Our system is very elite-oriented," said Anne Heald, a program officer with the German Marshall Fund, a foundation that has underwritten apprentice programs. "There is no strong path for the mainstream of youth." Ms. Heald noted that only about half of high school graduates go on to college and not all of those complete their studies.
 
The 'Forgotten Half'
 Indeed, educators often refer to the noncollege bound as the "forgotten half" of the school population. Most have trouble finding jobs that pay well, because a high school diploma is not highly regarded by most employers and the skills students acquire at part-time work during school do not prepare them for jobs offering a decent income. "Flipping hamburgers does not prepare young people for jobs with a future," said Stephen F. Hamilton, chairman of the Department of Human Development at Cornell University. "They lack the technical knowledge, social skills and work attitude necessary to succeed."
The new types of youth apprentice programs, chiefly involving modern industrial technology, differ from traditional union-based apprenticeships, such as in plumbing or tool making. For one thing, they are aimed at a younger population. According to Esther Whitten, a spokeswoman of the National Tooling and Machining Association, the average age of people in traditional programs is 27.
The new programs, typically financed and organized by some combination of state governments and foundations, are aimed at easing the transition from school to work by focusing on young people in their middle years of high school. Supporters of the programs say that working in an industrial setting, where understanding and applying highly technical specifications is essential, usually supplies the answer to students' age-old question, "Why do I have to learn this stuff?"
Most of the new plans are modeled on apprentice programs in Germany and elsewhere in Europe that train a majority of youngsters for employment. "In Germany, two-thirds of the kids go through apprentice programs," Ms. Heald said. "Most economies cannot employ much more than 25 percent of the work force as college graduates. We need an alternate that gives people self-respect, as well as economic success."
In the United States there are as many as 40 such apprentice programs enrolling about 1,000 young people, said Hillary Pennington, president of Jobs for the Future, a foundation-supported organization that promotes the development of apprenticeships. "Our objective in 10 to 20 years is to have apprenticeship as a viable option for 15 to 25 percent of the school population."
 
How Program Works
 In the Lycoming County, Pennsylvania, apprentice program, based in Williamsport, students enroll after 10th grade for four years. They sign contracts with employers and spend about half their time on the job and the rest in a specially designed curriculum taught at the Pennsylvania College of Technology in Williamsport. They are paid stipends of $80 a week for their efforts.
The curriculum is designed to give apprentices the necessary technical and verbal skills, but without the trappings of a standard high school that most of them resented. "There are no bells," said Tom Paternostro, one of the teachers in the program. "They are expected to do their work without somebody standing guard and watching them. And most of them have."
Instruction in different subjects is carefully linked to demonstrate its relevance. One day a history teacher talked about Revolutionary War and Civil War battles that had been fought in the area. The math teacher followed with a discussion of how to calculate the trajectories of cannon balls. Then another teacher helped students construct a small catapult and fire a golf ball across the room. The students then collected data on where the ball landed, using the same statistical control charts found in factory operations.
"They ended up doing history, English, math and physics, and probably did not realize it," said Robert Vandine, director of the local Industrial Modernization Center, which helped organize the program. Mr. Vandine said the purpose of these apprenticeships is as much to preserve the manufacturing base in the area as to provide jobs for young people.
"The current high school system produces people suited for the old, low-skill manufacturing system," he said. "But now to be competitive in the world, manufacturers need people with better technical skills and the ability to work in groups without a lot of supervision."
Greater skills also command higher pay. Professor Hamilton, who is involved in an apprentice program in the Binghamton, N.Y., area, said a technician capable of repairing and maintaining complex biotechnology and life-support equipment represents "real value" to a hospital. That technician, he said, "would make $40,000 a year on a full-time basis."
Christopher Barto said that a year as an apprentice at Tempella Power, had already broadened his options. "I started out in welding and general manufacturing," he said. Then he was taught how to operate a computer-controlled metalworking machine.
When he completes the apprenticeship program he will have even more opportunities. "I could go to a four-year college," he said, "or finish up at Penn Tech. Or I can go to work."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Christopher Barto says his apprenticeship has broadened his options. (Guy Cali for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ON LANGUAGE;
Retronym Watch

BYLINE: By William Safire

 BODY:
THe story is told of a modern mother laying a guilt trip on her grown-up son: "You never call, you never write, you never fax. . . ."
If he sends her a fax in response, we have a name for what she receives: fax mail. And if he leaves a message on her answering machine, that is becoming known as voice mail. But what of the stuff that comes in a paper envelope along with the greeting cards, bills, catalogues, charity solicitations and junk mail? 
 We can no longer call that plain mail. "Recently I received a fax message," writes Gary Muldoon of Rochester, "with the words 'land mail to follow.' Mail is now land mail." But that locution, evoking the days of the Pony Express, won't fly; so much domestic mail is sent by air that we no longer specify airmail, and land mail would be a misnomer.
This question has also puzzled John W. Nason of Jericho, L.I.: "Mail used to be what the postman (now letter carrier) deposited in your mailbox. Now that there's voice mail and E-mail, I wonder what all those bills and other stuff that come through the U.S. Postal Service will be called in the future. Real mail?"
Nope -- real mail doesn't eat quiche. Post is a possibility, from the Italian posta, "a station along the way," from its Latin root, meaning "place"; it came to mean a series of places in a system of communication. As a verb, it gained a meaning of "to send," as in Hamlet's condemnation of Queen Gertrude for her willingness "to post with such dexterity to incestuous sheets" (don't fax that to your mother). The post is now British usage for "the mail," and might serve Americans well to signify old-fashioned mail.
But it lacks the quality of a ret ronym. We have two-word names now for many things that have been overtaken by events. The classic was acoustic guitar, which replaced guitar when the electric guitar came along; this change quickly led to analog watch, which showed its face when the digital watch threatened its existence. Recently, with the introduction of the laser printer, the plain old printer that used to stand next to your creaky old 286 computer became an impact printer. Now that fancy restaurants are advertising free-range chicken, I don't know how to order the other kind. Domesticated chicken?)
The idea of a retronym is to downdate: to modify a familiar term in a way that calls attention to its not being the updated version. As Andrew Pollack wrote in The New York Times a few years ago, "Voice mail users now talk about two kinds of telephone communications -- voice mail, which is communicating by message, and 'real-time' communications, once known as conversation, in which both parties are on the line at the same time." To use retro nyms in a sentence: "The female nurse went to a day game and ordered health food." (Don't look up downdate: I can't wait for the dictionaries.)
In some of these retronyms, the modifier mocks the noun: Tom Pribek of the University of Wisconsin at La Crosse notes the redundancy in religious holiday and handwritten manuscript.
Back to the handwritten, or hand-typed, or impact-printed mail. The emergent idea plays on the traditional contrast between hard and soft. In politics, hard-liner led to soft-liner; in computer lingo, hardware spawned software; contrariwise, the old hard money, meaning "specie" or "an anti-inflationary policy," led to the new soft money, meaning "contributions not counted against a candidate's limits in a campaign." In newsrooms, hard copy was printed out and available to be held in the hand as if to be read, while the newscaster read the soft copy on the prompter screen.
The solution: voice mail and its accompanying voicephone number to print on your business cards; fax mail (two words destined to become one) and its companion fax number, and the unreal-time communication that enlivens and enriches this column, hard mail.
 
THE NEW OMICS
 REALPOLITIK -- PRONOUNCED ray-ahl-pol-ih-TEEK, so as not to confuse it with "real politics" -- was coined by Ludwig von Rochau in 1853 to describe Bismarck's hardheaded policies in the years leading to German unification. In American political usage, it means "international diplomacy based on strength rather than appeals to morality and world opinion" and -- with Tony Lake, a key Clinton adviser, apparently on the way in -- it may be on the way out (the policy, not the word).
A coinage based on realpolitik is likely to be used in think tanks and academic seminars if the Clinton-Gore ticket wins. That term is real economik, set forth by Susan and Martin Tolchin in a book that a new Administration's insiders would be reading, "Selling Our Security: The Erosion of America's Assets" (Knopf). The approach rejects the "Nations have no friends, only interests" summation of Viscount Palmerston's remark; instead, they write, "The U.S. needs a new vision, a 'real economik' that addresses its need to regain economic ground; otherwise, its role as a world leader will surely diminish over time."
The popularity of another coinage will be inevitable in a Clinton Administration: Clintonomics. For the omics suffix to work, the President's name must end in an n. This all began when some of us in 1969 began pushing Nixonomics. (Although Johnsonomics would have been an effective neologism, it was not used, suggesting that Nixonomics was the form's first Presidential use.) Although there was some straining for Fordonomics and Carternomics, neither got off the ground because of the lack of the concluding n.
With Reagan came, of course, Reaganomics. In 1992, Democrats wishing to criticize George Bush's economic policies did not want to evoke the popular former President's name, and there was no Bush onomics; they had to settle for trickle-down economics, a coinage probably used first by Democrats in the 1932 campaign against Herbert Hoover. (The theory under attack was also expressed then as "feeding the sparrows by feeding the horses.")
Now we are likely to have Clinton omics, described breathlessly at first as a new approach, and hailed when the economy turns upward; then, when the business cycle pushes the pendulum back the other way, Republicans will seize Clinton omics as their term of attack. Some linguistic trends are predictable.

HEADLINE: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;
Chairs That Aren't for Sitting, and Other Fantasy Furniture

BYLINE: By RITA REIF

 BODY:
Throughout history, the most outrageous and romantic forms of fantasy furniture have flourished when the economy sagged and dreams flourished. In the late 1930's, for example, Helena Rubinstein acquired a flamboyant suite of shell-shaped furniture for her New York apartment. And in 1938 Jean-Michel Frank, the French decorator, commissioned Salvador Dali to design a sofa shaped like the mouth of Mae West for the showroom of Schiaparelli, the Paris couturiere.
"Fantasy furniture is more popular now than it's ever been," said Bruce M. Newman, a New York dealer and collector of such exotica. He and his wife, Judith, have written a book on the subject, "Fantasy Furniture," and they have recently donated 16 exuberantly embellished pieces to the Brooklyn Museum, where they are now on permanent exhibition. 
 The collection includes five types of fantasy furniture from the 19th century. The Venetian grotto style is represented by a curvaceous shell chair and a table with a dolphin-shaped base. The Black Forest style -- surprisingly all such furniture is Swiss, not German -- is typified by a bench flanked by two robustly carved bears. From Germany comes a lethal-looking smoking stand in the horn-and-antler style. Also from Germany there is a table designed for calling cards, on which a leering beast appears to be chewing up the top; the piece is an example of the mythological style.
The most romantic objects from the collection are a pair of nymph-embellished Art Nouveau chairs, carved in France at the turn of the century in the Belle Epoque style. The silvered wood seats simulate lily pads, the backs large leaves and the legs thick clusters of sturdy vines. "These chairs are so sinuous they seem alive," Mr. Newman said.
Also from the Belle Epoque period is a far more restrained French plant stand, with a wrought-iron frame that suggests vivid red and green branches, leaves and flowers.
A carved mahogany dragon chair is a tour de force of undulation. The dragon's tail forms a headrest, its exposed spine the back and its grinning face the footrest. "The creature is smirking," Mr. Newman said. "When you look at that chair, you feel decadent. If you sat on it, you'd hurt yourself. It was never meant for sitting. Some British lord with a sense of humor may have commissioned it to stand in the corner of his library -- daring someone to try it."
Peacocks probably inspired the Florentine craftsman Andrea Baccetti to carve the splendid feather-surfaced chair and table on view and to paint them red, silver and peacock blue. After completing the table, which has a treelike base, he added a pair of peacocks to the top, carved so that their tails and beaks are joined. The chair is shaped like a peacock, too, its wings spread to form the seat, its tail feathers the fanlike back and its long legs the feet.
Mr. Newman said that he first realized how witty and enchanting fantasy furniture can be during a visit in 1950 to the Royal Pavilion in Brighton, the country mansion built and extravagantly furnished by the man who later became George IV of England. "I thought it was the surrealist land of Oz," he said. "The Prince Regent, who built the place, certainly had a sense of humor."
And presumably so did Ludwig II, the Bavarian aristocrat with a taste for the bizarre in palaces and furnishings. "These two men gave people in the 19th century a license to live a fantasy life," Mr. Newman said.
According to Kevin Stayton, the museum's curator of decorative arts, the ambiguity of fantasy furniture is part of its charm. Among the exhibition's images open to interpretation is the layered detailing on the legs of a silvered Austrian chair. Mr. Stayton sees them as feathers, Mr. Newman as leaves.
Mr. Stayton is also unsure as to what is depicted on the vigorously carved calling-card stand. "The gargoyle figure may be an insect, beast or dragon," he said. "Not knowing exactly what the image is blurs its reality and increases its attraction."
His favorite piece in the collection is a late-19th-century Japanese desk with a three-dimensional rendering of mountains, pavilions and a bridge in cinnabar lacquer. "By replacing the desk's superstructure with a dream landscape," Mr. Stayton said, "something new and mysterious was created."
The collection represents a delightful addition to the Brooklyn Museum's holdings. "We had lots of technologically innovative pieces from the period but nothing as engaging as these pieces," Mr. Stayton said. "Most people view the 19th century as straitlaced and somber. This collection is chock full of whimsy, which helps us understand that the Victorians were human, too."
And it appeals to people of all ages, even the very young. "My 7-year-old nephew saw the show's brochure," Mr. Stayton said, "and asked me to buy some of it for him for Christmas."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Above, a French plant stand, in the Belle Epoque style. At left, a German fruitwood table, circa 1890, at the Brooklyn Museum. Above, a detail of a table by the Florentine craftsman Andrea Baccetti that features peacocks joined at the beak. (Photographs by Newel Art Gallery)

HEADLINE: Trading Low-Income Housing for Bonuses

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
EARTHMOVING equipment is shifting tons of material on a full block near Lincoln Center for the Lincoln Square project, a $234-million complex that will be 20 percent larger than normal zoning would allow because of low-income housing built on 104th and 107th Streets.
On West End Avenue, a few blocks from Lincoln Square, a $180-million complex is planned to include 1,000 rental apartments. Because 20 percent of the apartments in the development, which is called Manhattan West, are to be rented to low-income tenants, the project's owners will pay no city property taxes on their building for its first 10 years and will not be taxed on the basis on its full value for 20 years. 
 Both complexes are reflections of the city's attempt to find ways to provide low-income housing through bonuses and benefits to market-rate developers at a time when traditional funding sources for housing programs have all but dried up and commercial development has slowed to a standstill. While some city planners cite the incentives as examples of government innovations in an especially difficult time, others criticize them as unnecessarily generous to developers.
The Lincoln Square project, which will combine apartments, offices and retail space and a movie complex, will have a total of 666,000 square feet of space above ground -- 111,000 more than could have been built without the bonus for what is called inclusionary housing. Lincoln Square is the largest project to date to benefit from the city's five-year-old inclusionary housing zoning bonus.
Manhattan West, on a site just to the west of West End Avenue between 61st and 64th Streets, is to be a mixed-use complex that will have 1,000 rental apartments, 38,000 square feet of retail space and a 350-space parking garage. Twenty percent of the apartments in the $180 million complex will be rented to low-income tenants in exchange for a 20-year city property-tax abatement on the project.
The developers of the site, the Brodsky Organization, decided to go ahead with Manhattan West after the State Legislature last July approved the city's initiative to extend a part of the 421a tax benefit from 10 to 20 years. The 421a tax abatement program has been used by the city to stimulate the development of housing for all income levels.
"The zoning bonuses and tax abatements now in place," said Philip E. Aarons, a principal with Christopher M. Jeffries in Millenium Partners, the developers of Lincoln Square, "are the best programs so far to stimulate the development of low-income housing." Such housing, he said, can be "built without a direct government subsidy because the revenue from the sale of the credits pays for most of the building costs. The risk as to whether these certificates are used is the developer's, not the city's."
As president of the real estate division of General Atlantic Corporation, Mr. Aarons was the first developer in the city to build low-income housing for tax and zoning bonus credits. Millenium Partners is using credits bought from General Atlantic and other developers in the bonus for Lincoln Square.
Despite the enthusiasm expressed for the incentive programs by Mr. Aarons, a former president of the city's Public Development Corporation, and others, questions remain as to how programs that depend on new development can be viable in a city where construction has slowed to a trickle. Moreover, some planners question whether the impact of the bonus is too great in the neighborhoods where these large projects rise.
"There is no doubt that the city needs more housing," said Norman Marcus, former counsel to the City Planning Commission and now in private practice with the firm of Bachner, Tally, Polvoy & Misher. "But if as-of-right development does not permit the bulk for these projects, then the 20 percent bonus is allowing overbuilding to pay for amenities, like legitimate theaters, improved subway stations, plazas and low-income housing, that the city otherwise would not be able to afford. And the 20 percent extra bulk is one more indigestible element in the stew."
But Robert Flahive, director of the Manhattan office of the Department of Planning, said that currently there were no plans to alter the inclusionary housing zoning bonus.
So far, according the the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, the inclusionary zoning bonus has led to the construction of 140 units of low-income housing, resulting in 646,228 square feet of zoning bonus space. Of the bonus space generated, 455,811 square feet have been transferred to market-rate developments. Among them are the rental apartment buildings at 350 East 79th Street and 200 East 87th Street.
According to Roz Post, a spokeswoman for the city's housing agency, there are currently few low-income housing projects in the pipeline that would generate zoning bonuses. Among them is a plan by the Y.M.C.A. of Greater New York to expand its building at 5 West 63d Street. The Y expects to get a modest zoning bonus for the 65 units of permanent low-income units it will include in its redevelopment plan.
ELIGIBILITY for low-income housing is set by the city under a compex formula involving a percentage of the mean income for the area. Current eligibility for a two-bedroom apartment for a family of three, for example, is limited to those with a household income below $29,592.
Both the inclusionary housing bonus and the 421a tax-abatement program were born of the realization by public officials that without incentives or substantial government subsidies the cost of development in New York City made it less and less likely that even the most basic type of housing could be produced by the private sector. As Federal housing funds shrank in the 80's, the city struggled for ways to fill the gap between what the city could afford and what was needed.
In July 1987, the city added inclusionary housing to its list of zoning bonus incentives. The new zoning code provided a menu of options and a sliding scale of bonuses for on-site and off-site new construction and rehabilitation. Each square foot of low-income housing developed or rehabilitated generated a prescribed amount of bonus space.
A developer could add four feet of space, up to 20 percent of the maximum allowed by the zoning rules, for every square foot of new low-income housing built on a privately owned site. The rehabilitation of publicly owned housing produced a 2.2 bonus, which allowed 2.2 square feet of additional space for every square foot of rehabilitated space.
On a site where the zoning called for an FAR, or floor-to-area-ratio, of 10, the inclusionary housing bonus could bring it up to a maximum of 12 FAR. In the FAR zoning equation, 10 square feet of building is permitted for every square foot of land.
To make the incentive more palatable to developers, the zoning resolution allowed the low-income housing to be built or rehabilitated at a location other than the new development site as long as it was in the same community board jurisdiction or within a half mile of it. Moreover, a developer using the bonus would not have to put up the low-income housing himself, but could buy certificates for housing already completed.
A requirement that the low-income housing be completed and approved before the developer could get a certificate of occupancy for his market-rate project was the safeguard that insured that the low-income housing was completed to the city's satisfaction.
In the Lincoln Square project, for example, the inclusionary housing bonus will add 111,000 square feet of space to the 555,000 permitted for its 10 FAR zone.
The zoning bonus credits come from two new low-income residences. One is the 17-story, 29-unit building at 171 West 107th Street, completed in 1990, with the facade of a Consolidated Edison substation that stood on the midblock site. The building, which has mostly two- and three bedroom apartments, is managed by the West Side Federation for Senior Housing. The other is the 10-story, 56-unit residence at 123 West 104th Street. The building, completed earlier this year, was developed in partnership with Grace United Methodist Church next door, which was also rebuilt as part of the project.
In addition, Lincoln Square received 421a tax-abatement certificates as a result of the development of Gerard Gardens, a 120-unit low-income complex near Yankee Stadium built by General Atlantic in partnership with the Related Housing Companies.
Mr. Aarons said that he had left General Atlantic not because the market for low-income housing credits had dried up, but to pursue other development opportunities. But Mr. Aarons said that after he left, General Atlantic decided to close its real estate development division in New York City.
DANIEL BRODSKY, who is developing Manhattan West, said the project would have been too risky without the 10-year extension of the 421a tax benefit program approved last summer.
"Even with the drop in interest rates," he said, "which helped bring down development costs, the project's financial viability would have been questionable without the extension of the tax benefit."
One factor, Mr. Brodsky said, is that rents, even for luxury buildings, are not increasing at the same rate they did in the 1980's.
"With the old 421a formula," he said, "a developer could expect that by the time the full tax on the building had phased in, tenants would be paying rents that were high enough to cover the higher tax bill. But we cannot assume that will be the case in the near future. Rents have even come down a bit in the past few years."
The city has long used 421a tax incentives to encourage developers to build housing. But in response to critics who charged that in some areas 421a was a giveaway to real estate developers who could benefit from it even in luxury developments, in 1985 the City Council altered the program. The incentive was withdrawn for developments between 14th and 96th Streets in Manhattan. But the amendments allowed builders of market-rate housing to take advantage of the 421a tax break if they agreed to make low-income housing 20 percent of their projects. The low-income units could be part of their developments or built elsewhere. It enriched the value of the 421a tax break the developers are getting.
With the enriched 421a, Manhattan West will benefit from 10 years of full property-tax abatement on the buildings, starting when the project gets its certificate of occupancy. The full abatement under the previous 421a program was for two years. In the 11th year, assessments will start to be phased in gradually until full assessment is reached in the 20th year. While the building itself will not be taxed for 10 years, and not fully taxed for 20, the owner will be assessed for taxes on the value of the land. The current tax on the Manhattan West property is about $837,650.
New York is not alone in its effort to use private development to generate housing for its middle- and low-income residents.
In New Jersey, for example, the State Supreme Court's Mount Laurel decisions require communities to provide the opportunity for a certain proportion of low- and moderate-income housing. Under the policy, communities are allowed to pay for construction of up to half of their required quota of such housing in other areas; frequently, for example, funds from a development in the suburbs will be used to construct low-income housing in an urban area.
"The weak economy has slowed the production of low- and moderate-income units," said Sidna Mitchell, a spokesman for the Council on Affordable Housing in Trenton, "but we think that Mount Laurel and the Fair Housing Act have been successful in that exclusionary zoning has been broken down."
In Boston, where the concept of private developers' participating in creating low-income housing is known as linkage, commercial developers have put $75 million into a housing development fund since 1985. It has come from a $6-a-square-foot linkage fee on all commercial projects over 100,000 square feet.
"ONE rationale in this initiative," said Peter Dreier, director of housing for the Boston Redevelopment Authority, "is that any new development puts pressure on the housing situation. So developers share some of the responsibility in mitigating the impact of their new projects.
"They also are beginning to understand," Mr. Dreier continued, "that in order to have a healthy business climate, the city must have housing for a broad range of incomes; not just executive but salesmen but secretaries and stock clerks as well."
In another component of linkage in Boston, the city awards the linkage fund deposits to institutions most active in low-income neighborhoods.
While the current sour economic climate is not the best atmosphere in which to judge New York City's low-income housing incentives, some observers are confident that when development picks up, builders will embrace them.
Mr. Brodsky says another reason the low-income housing bonus will be used is that banks are more reluctant to give full financing to real estate projects.
"Banks have pulled way back on their real estate lending," he said, "so government programs will be more important."
Michael Parley, an urban planner and consultant to many of the city's largest development companies, also believes the market for tax and zoning benefits generated by low-income housing will pick up when the recession ends.
"Developers will want them," said Mr. Parley, "if for no other reason than the fact that they will need them. The list of zoning bonus options, for example, has been whittled down to the point where low-income housing nearly stands alone. The plaza bonus is not completely gone, but its use has been limited and there are fewer and fewer sites large enough for it to be used effectively."

HEADLINE: Senate Choice: Mr. Inside or Mr. Outside

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON

 BODY:
THE first question in the televised debate between the state's United States Senate candidates last Monday was about converting Connecticut's military industries to peacetime uses, but Brook Johnson began his response with two statements: he has lived in Greenwich since 1978, and he has never shipped an American job overseas.
The moment was awkward for Mr. Johnson, the Republican candidate, a businessman who had spent $1.6 million of his own money on television advertisements to make himself known. Because of attack ads by his Democratic opponent, Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Mr. Johnson seemed compelled to begin by defending his legitimacy as a resident of the state and as a pro-American businessman. 
 Mr. Johnson and Mr. Dodd are spending a total of $5 million on their Senate race, much of it on television, and the war of the airwaves has shown once again how television can cut two ways, especially for a candidate like Mr. Johnson, a newcomer to politics relying on it to establish his identity and to make his case against Mr. Dodd. In a recent Quinnipiac College poll, 94 percent of those surveyed had heard of Mr. Johnson, compared with only 60 percent seven weeks earlier, before he won the Republican primary against State Representative Christopher Burnham. But as Connecticut residents were learning about Mr. Johnson, their perceptions were being shaped not only by his own advertisements, but also by Mr. Dodd's. Between Oct. 16 and 26, as Dodd commercials accused Mr. Johnson of living in Florida until May and attacked his record as a textile executive, the Republican's unfavorable rating in Quinnipiac polls rose to 35.8 percent, from 25 percent, nearly equaling the 36.9 percent who viewed him favorably.
Mr. Dodd, seeking his third six-year term in the Senate, was also feeling the effects of Johnson commercials attacking him as a big-spending career politician who cared more about his salary than about his recession-stricken state. But Mr. Dodd was maintaining a nearly 20-point lead in polls as he campaigned on his record of fighting successfully for Connecticut interests like the Seawolf submarine, widening eligibility for financial aid for college students from middle-class families and pushing legislation for child care and family leave programs. This year challengers across the country based their hopes on a supposed anti-incumbent fever to sweep officeholders out of Congress, but in Connecticut the voters appear to be putting a premium on experience. Both parties say the incumbents in the House of Representatives appear to be safe, unless the volatility of the Presidential election spills over to other contests on the ballot.
At stake on Tuesday, in addition to the Senate and House offices, will be both houses of the General Assembly, two proposed amendments to the state Constitution and a scattering of local questions. The polls will be open from 6 A.M. to 8 P.M.
The main unknown, for Connecticut politicians, is how Ross Perot voters will complete their ballots on Tuesday, giving or denying Democrats in the state a landslide.
In the General Assembly, the Republican State Chairman, Richard Foley, is predicting Republican gains in both houses, where Democrats now hold majorities of 88 to 63 in the House and 20 to 16 in the Senate. The state income tax, he said, is one factor, but Mr. Perot is another.
"No one knows where the Perot vote will go," Mr. Foley said. "I think it will tend to vote Republican, because we are closer to Perot than the Democrats are."
The Democratic State Chairman, Edward Marcus, predicted only that his party would maintain its majorities in the legislature. With 100,000 new Democratic voters registered in the last five months, he is counting on a big Clinton vote.
"I do not see the race tightening," Mr. Marcus said. "I see people leaving Perot for Clinton, and leaving Bush for Perot."
He discounted the impact of lingering anger over the income tax, which Republicans had hoped might lead to a revolt against Democrats like that in New Jersey in 1991. Instead, he said, the 90 Democrats who are also listed as candidates of A Connecticut Party may well gain from that association.
"Connecticut's economy has been so decimated, and people accept as a fact that it's the result of the actions or lack of action of the Bush Administration, that the issue has totally overwhelmed any other in this state," he said.
In the United States Senate race, experience is the clearest distinction between Mr. Dodd and Mr. Johnson, who substantially agree on many issues, from the need to address the Federal deficit to the right of women to seek abortions.
Mr. Johnson, who takes pains to criticize evenhandedly Democrats and Republicans in Congress, and Gov. Bill Clinton and President Bush, has attributed the Federal deficit to special interest groups that have a firm grip on Washington insiders like Mr. Dodd, who has served in the House and Senate for 18 years. In closing the debate, Mr. Johnson stated the choice simply:
"I am definitely an outsider with no political background and no political experience. Chris is definitely a political insider with a lot of political background and political experience. I am a businessman with a background in creating jobs, building factories, creating products, and trying to invest in America and internationally. One thing that we must determine is what is the expertise we need in America today to stop the growing deficit."
 
Familiarity With Congress
 Mr. Dodd, however, has sought to use his experience to great advantage. Widely recognized in Washington as a Senator who can build coalitions across party lines, he points to the coming battle over military spending and suggests his contacts and reputation on Capitol Hill will be a great asset in defending Connecticut's defense-related jobs.
While Mr. Johnson, in three debates between the candidates, focused on reducing the deficit through devices like a balanced-budget amendment to the Constitution, caps on the growth in Federal spending, and term limits for Congress, Mr. Dodd displayed a rich familiarity with the actual work of Congress.
That characteristic of Mr. Dodd could also work against him, though, reinforcing the politician image that Mr. Johnson was polishing for him.
At one point on Monday, after one lengthy Dodd response, Mr. Johnson succeeded in putting him on the defensive by saying, "It's a great disadvantage for a businessman who's used to saying yes or no being in one of these timed debates."

HEADLINE: Hartford's Cityscape Keeps Artist Inspired

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN

 BODY:
FOR three decades Richard Welling has been sketching the buildings of downtown Hartford, the old ones that have come down and the new ones that have gone up.
In one respect he is the darling of the business establishment. A great many of his intricate line drawings are commissioned works that hang in boardrooms and banks and lawyers' offices throughout downtown. When the city's biggest hotel, the Hartford Sheraton, opened a decade and a half ago, each of its rooms contained not one but two Wellings. The drawings have provided his living. His prices start at $500 for the original drawing and $200 for limited-edition copies. 
 In a larger sense, though, Mr. Welling has been the unofficial artist-historian of a city during its greatest period of transition. And in that role, he is sometimes dismayed at what has happened in the name of progress.
One part of a new exhibit of Mr. Welling's work, at a Hartford restaurant, Picasso's, includes a section titled "Lost Hartford." The drawings are of some of the graceful structures that have been destroyed in the last 30 years.
"Don't get me wrong," Mr. Welling said. "I have nothing against skyscrapers. I like tall buildings." He has even learned to enjoy City Place, the modernist structure that deposed the Travelers Tower, which he dearly loves, as the city's tallest building, 535 feet to 527 feet.
And he enjoys radical new architecture. One of his favorite buildings is that of the Phoenix Mutual Life Insurance Company, commonly known as the boat building, because it looks like one and from the air appears ready to slide into the Connecticut River.
But those are exceptions. So many of the modern structures that sprang up during the city's era of redevelopment are really awful in Mr. Welling's judgment.
One of the most awful, he said, is the Travelers Plaza building between Prospect Street and Columbus Boulevard. It looks like a giant radiator cover, he said. Another is 1 Financial Plaza, headquarters for the United Technologies Corporation and commonly known as the Gold Building for its skin of collector panels. He described that as the dullest building in Hartford. A third is the boxlike building he called ugly that was built as an adjunct to the Aetna Life and Casualty Company's old Colonial-style home office.
But the building that has most bothered him of late is a simple one at Main and Asylum streets, the crossroads of the city since Colonial days. It is a farmers' market. "That's like putting up a hot dog stand on Wall Street," Mr. Welling said.
 
City's First Skyscraper
 The farmers' market was created to get rid of a major embarrassment to the city, a great hole in the ground that remained after the landmark known as the Hartford-Aetna Building was imploded on April 1, 1990.
That 11-story building, the city's first skyscraper when it was erected in 1912, was owned in recent years by the Society for Savings, which planned to put up a 45-story office tower on the site. The Greater Hartford Architecture Conservancy put on a spirited campaign to halt the destruction of the old building, assisted by many others like Mr. Welling who felt it was an important structure, architecturally and historically. Their efforts were to no avail.
"I wrote a letter to the paper and said the skyscraper scheduled to replace it was just junk," Mr. Welling said. "I went to see bank officials, and I sent a drawing of the Hartford-Aetna Building to City Council members. I heard from no one. I could have chained myself to the door of the building, but I'm not that crazy."
The skyscraper was not built, however, due to financial problems that developed at the Society for Savings. Hence the farmers' market plan, worked out by the lending institution and the city.
If the city has lost part of its character with the loss of many of its older buildings, it has acquired a real character in Mr. Welling. With his long hair and beard and casual clothes -- his idea of dressing up is to wear a great floppy sweater -- he better fits the image of an artist in Paris than one in Hartford, with its button-down image as an insurance and business center.
 
Changing His Approach
 It was not always thus. Thirty years ago, Mr. Welling was a 36-year-old clean-shaven freelance graphic artist living in suburban Farmington with his wife and four children and commuting daily to a studio in downtown Hartford.
One day he discovered something that fascinated him and in doing so changed his approach to art and work. It was Constitution Plaza, the city's first big redevelopment project.
He did some drawings of the work in progress and realized that it was a lot more fun than working on advertisements or logos back at the studio, he said. He decided to try to sell his drawings, of new buildings going up and the old buildings they were replacing, hoping to find a market for them somewhere. He discovered that developers would sometimes pay for many sketches, occasionally more than 100 of them, of new buildings in various stages of completion. He also discovered that many people were interested in sketches of the older buildings, as reminders of a city that was starting to disappear piece by piece.
He became a familiar sight, the man with the drawing pad on the sidewalk, while pedestrians swirled around him, or perched on a roof, sketching away. He would go almost anywhere to get the best angle for a sketch. One time he felt that the best place to draw a building under construction was from an upper window at the Americana Hotel at Constitution Plaza. The hotel, however, would not let him use a vacant room for a few hours for sketching. So he checked in as a guest.
Over the last couple of years he has not had to worry much about angles for sketching buildings, he said, because there aren't many to sketch in downtown, either going up or coming down, because of the depressed economic climate.
 
Losing Homes to Progress
 "Building is nearly at a standstill," lamented Mr. Welling. Since 1976 he has done a year-end sketch of the Hartford skyline. "But now it doesn't change. Instead of the skyline last year, I did the interior of the State Capitol. This year I don't know what I'll sketch."
The lack of recent redevelopment has, at least, lessened Mr. Welling's concern about a place to live. While the city was almost obsessed with change, he had to move his studio out of four buildings scheduled for demolition. "Everywhere I went, they were knocking down the buildings on me."
In the late 1970's -- he was divorced and his children grown -- he moved from suburbia into the city. His present quarters, a combination of living place and studio, is a loft apartment in an industrial building near the railroad station that was converted to residences.
The apartment would do credit to Montmartre. The motif is Christmas -- complete with decorated tree, cards, even a mask of Ebenezer Scrooge -- year round. Mr. Welling did the decorating for Christmas four years ago, decided he liked what he saw and left it up. "Christmas is a nice season," he said.
