LENGTH: 1037 words

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Defectors: Who and Why?

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
JENNIFER HAUGE of Secaucus is a 32-year-old lawyer and Republican whose roots in the party run deep. Her father was a speech writer for President Dwight D. Eisenhower.
Heidi Ehman, a 27-year-old Hawthorne resident, voted for Ronald Reagan and George Bush. Her parents worked in Barry Goldwater's campaign in 1964. 
 Last July, the two women sat on the podium at Madison Square Garden and heard themselves introduced to the Democratic National Convention as supporters of Gov. Bill Clinton and Senator Al Gore.
"It was a tough decision to do that," Ms. Ehman said. Later, back in New Jersey, she and Mrs. Hauge acknowledged their defection in interviews with local reporters. "The outpouring of support from other Republicans was so moving," Ms. Ehman said, "that we decided to form an organization."
The organization was called New Jersey Republicans for Clinton-Gore, and it has since enlisted about 300 people in its low-key campaign. They do some telephoning, spreading their message to other Republicans, and they organize kaffeeklatsches and parties where they sell campaign pins.
Mainly, though, it is a sort of emotional support group for Republicans who find their party's positions unpalatable but also find it hard to pull the lever for a Democratic candidate for President. Or, as Mrs. Hauge put it, "a haven for those who felt alienated or abandoned by the party."
The impact of the organization is difficult to assess. But its very existence and the personal characteristics of its members offer fresh insights into this remarkable election year. In a state that last voted for a Democratic Presidential candidate in 1964, Mr. Clinton has been enjoying a double-digit lead over Mr. Bush in recent polls.
In the view of Cliff Zukin, a former director of polling at the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University, the increased tendency of Republicans to vote for Mr. Clinton represents a disaffection with Mr. Bush rather than a wholesale defection to the Democrats.
"Statewide, about 6 percent of Republicans say they will vote for Clinton, and 12 percent say they'll vote for Perot," Mr. Zukin said. "Bush gets much less of their allegiance than he did four years ago."
Mr. Zukin said that 1988 polls in New Jersey showed that 90 percent of Republicans supported Mr. Bush; this year, that figure is down to 76 percent.
"He has lost the moderates because of the stress on family values and racial issues," Mr. Zukin said. "These are 'wedge' issues, and President Bush has driven the wedge so hard that he may have cracked his own base."
Like many of the members of Republicans for Clinton-Gore, Allen I. Bildner, former chairman and chief executive officer of Kings Super Markets Inc., was put off by his party's convention this year. Mr. Bildner, a lifelong Republican and former Republican committeeman, attended the 1988 convention and was host of a reception there. But this year's sessions were "disgraceful," he said, citing "the lack of hope and the appeal to divisive elements."
Mr. Bildner cited other reasons for enlisting in Republicans for Clinton-Gore. "I thought our President was exceedingly effective as a leader during the gulf war," he said. "I was hopeful that, with his mandate coming out of that, an 85 percent favorable rating, he and his advisers would turn themselves to the economy, unemployment, the neglected urban areas, drug-related crime, bigotry and discrimination, education -- all of those.
"But I was disappointed and distressed, and I began to conclude that the President, although a decent and concerned human being, he and his advisers either were so far removed from the real problems, or were so convinced that if you kept government away and let the private sector deal with the problems, that would succeed, that they fell into inaction. I became convinced that with four more years of that kind of inaction we would reach a point of no return."
At a meeting in Secaucus on Oct. 14, Mr. Bildner and Albert Camper Jr., chairman and chief executive officer of the CIT Group, were installed as co-chairmen of the Republicans for Clinton group.
Among the other prominent businessmen and lifelong Republicans who declared themselves for Mr. Clinton were Roger Johnson, chairman and chief executive officer of the Western Digital Corporation, and Louis Cabot, former chairman and chief executive officer of the Cabot Corporation.
 
'A Whole Range of Issues'
 "My family thought McKinley was the last best President we had," said Robert Brown, a 69-year-old retired pharmaceutical company executive who was also a Foreign Service officer, as he presented his Republican bona fides. His disaffection with the present Republican party, he said, "runs from A to Z, a whole range of issues."
He expressed one of his concerns in blunt terms: "The neo-fascists have taken over. Pat Buchanan, Pat Robertson, Jerry Falwell. If you disagree with them, you're un-American."
The New Jersey Republicans for Clinton group announced its existence on Aug. 19 at the Republican National Convention in Houston. Both founders were there to protest against the Republican platform position on abortion. They announced their distance from the party physically as well as politically.
"We were at the pro-choice rally across the street," Ms. Ehman said. "I'm sure they didn't want us inside."
 
'A Graphic Illustration'
Mrs. Hauge added: "I had become increasingly concerned about the Republican positions on women. The Anita Hill hearings were a graphic illustration that we need a more active attitude for women."
Gerald Pomper, a professor of polititical science at the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers, who has written a series of books about Presidential campaigns, also attended the Republican convention as part of his research. Mr. Pomper said the New Jersey delegation members, led by former Gov. Thomas H. Kean -- "somewhat genteel, gentlemanly, moderate to liberal" -- were treated as outsiders.
The New Jersey delegation "showed an aversion to the proceedings," he added. "They were unhappy about choice, and also the right-wing character of the convention." There was, he said, "a sense of despair" in the delegation.

HEADLINE: Cracking Down on Cabs at Airport

BYLINE: By TOM TOOLEN

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
MIKE MILNE looked like just another frazzled traveler on a recent Friday night, seeking a cab in the rain outside the Continental Airlines terminal at Newark International Airport. Several empty cabs whizzed past him.
Then a yellow cab with New York plates stopped abruptly. "Where to?" the driver asked. 
 Mr. Milne said he was headed for the Penta Hotel in downtown Manhattan. The driver agreed and got out to put the luggage in the trunk.
"You're under arrest for illegal solicitation," said Mr. Milne, an undercover police officer with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, as he pulled the driver's hands behind his back and snapped on the cuffs.
The driver said that all he was doing was "helping out a person who needed a ride in the rain." But as Mr. Milne informed him, cabs at the airport are registered and drivers must wait in line at a stand to get a fare. Limousines are also not allowed to pick up anyone at the airport unless it has been previously arranged.
 
'Have to Wait for Hours'
 After the driver had been taken to Port Authority police headquarters to be booked, and after his car had been towed, Mr. Milne explained: "At first glance you may have sympathy for the cab or limousine driver who's trying to make an extra buck, but the illegal drivers are taking the food out of the mouths of the legitimate cabdrivers who have to wait for hours in line to get a fare."
The renegade drivers, he said, often do not have insurance or driver's licenses. "These are the guys who often rip off the traveling public," Mr. Milne said.
The sting operation at Newark that night has also been used at Kennedy International and La Guardia Airports. The crackdown, which began on June 22 and was to have ended after Labor Day, has been extended by the Port Authority. It is the brainchild of Stanley Brezenoff, executive director of the Port Authority, who called the airport hustlers one of his "pet peeves" when he took his post two years ago.
The project is budgeted for $1.5 million, with most of it spent on police overtime. But the hiring of about 40 police recruits last month expected to trim that overtime.
"I am delighted with the results of our police effort, but we still have a way to go," Mr. Brezenoff said. "Tourists come from all over the country and the world to our area, and we can't let them experience a rip-off when they arrive at Newark or Kennedy or La Guardia Airports."
 
Tourists Often Overcharged
 Many of the illegal drivers, he added, "grossly overcharge innocent tourists, usually those unfamiliar with the language and the money exchange."
Mr. Brezenoff said the crackdown had made a big dent in the illegal activities. Since the program began, the Port Authority police have arrested or given summonses to 4,000 drivers at the three airports. In addition, the police have impounded 700 cars at the airports, nearly 500 of them at Newark. The drivers must pay a $60 fee to get their cars back.
About three-quarters of the 4,000 cases involve summonses, but arrests are made if the suspect is a repeat offender or has arrest warrants outstanding.
In some cases, Mr. Brezenoff said, the suspects are driving their own cars and have no taxi or livery licenses.
The fine in New York for illegal limousine and cab pick-ups is $100, but if a case goes to a court in Elizabeth -- Newark Airport is in both Newark and Elizabeth -- the fine for repeat offenders can reach $1,000.
 
Many Repeat Offenders
 "We like to think that the stiff fines and even the possibility of spending a night in jail if they are repeat offenders is enough to scare these gypsy cabs and limousines off," said Sgt. Kirk Nelson, who is in charge of the Newark sting operation. But he admits that he sees many of the "same offenders back night after night after night."
"There is a recession out there, and these guys will take any chances they can to make some extra money," he said. "If a limo or cab driver brings a rider from New York to Newark, it's a nice double dip if he can bring a fare back to the city."
Mr. Brezenoff said many foreign tourists, especially the Japanese, were being victimized. He mentioned the case of two Japanese businessmen who were charged $300 to go from Newark Airport to a Morris County office. The fare would normally be about $40. Another cab driver charged a group of Asians $100 to get to Manhattan from Newark and then drove away with the visitors' luggage still in his trunk, Mr. Brezenoff said.
The bulk of the car tows have been in Newark because the responsibility of the police at Newark is broader than that of officers at Kennedy or La Guardia. At Newark, the police can make arrests and order car tows outside the three main passenger terminals, but at Kennedy and La Guardia the individual airlines have responsibility for policing their own outside frontage, using their own security forces.
About 40 officers are involved in the undercover operation at the three airports, and the busiest nights are Thursday and Friday.
 
Pleased With Crackdown
 Legitimate cabbies and limousine companies are pleased with the Port Authority crackdown.
"It's been great," said Frank Barone of Airport Limousine Express in Elizabeth. "I hope they keep it up." Mr. Barone said his business had increased 25 to 30 percent since the crackdown began in June.
John Kampfe, a Port Authority spokesman, said warnings about accepting services from unauthorized people were included in a seven-minute video shown on many incoming flights and on signs posted at the airports.
After the team of undercover officers booked six maverick cabbies that Friday night, they made their way back to the Newark terminals because several international flights were coming in.
"The vultures will be circling and looking for people who look confused about what to do," Mr. Milne said. A few minutes later, he attracted a passing cabdriver who stopped and backed up. After he agreed to take Mr. Milne to Manhattan, he was arrested.
"I recognize him," Mr. Milne said. "He's been through this before." The suspect was smiling broadly.
James Gonzalez, another undercover officer, said: "I like to see that because I have had some of these illegal cabbies cry. One guy got down on his hands and knees and wanted to kiss my shoes if I let him go."

HEADLINE: Hillsdale Journal;
An Uproar Over Police Pay Increases and Garbage Trucks

BYLINE: By ROBERT G. WOLETZ

DATELINE: HILLSDALE

 BODY:
STARTLED by the increasing rumble of 18-wheel garbage trucks through town, alarmed by a proposal to close the police station evenings and weekends, 150 of this Bergen County community's residents packed the Borough Hall a few weeks ago.
There they traded barbs over a yearlong string of decisions by the Borough Council and the Mayor, including a legal challenge to a three-year, 25 percent pay increase for the borough's police, a sudden shutdown of Hillsdale's municipal garbage-hauling operation and an agreement with the owners of a garbage-transfer station whose operations the Council had previously pledged to curtail. 
 At the meeting, several Hillsdale police officers rose to charge that the Council was leading a vendetta against the 19-member Police Department. They expressed concern that the Council was planning to eliminate more positions on a police force that stood at 21 a few years ago.
Other residents protested the proposed police station closings and the rising tide of trucks swinging through the municipality's streets, carrying garbage from other communities to the transfer station in Hillsdale's center. Among the speakers were two residents who are running for Council seats in Tuesday's election on an independent slate.
The embattled Mayor, Robert Elder, charged that the police salary raise was excessive. He also outlined a plan whereby Hillsdale would seek a reordering of its Police Department once Hillsdale could contract with another nearby town to take over the borough's police radio-dispatch responsibilities, now handled by a state-of-the-art dispatching center the borough bought two years ago for $65,000.
The Mayor maintained that the move made sense in light of the state's requirement that regional centers be established by 1993 throughout New Jersey for an enhanced 911 emergency call system. The removal of the dispatching function, he added, would make it unnecessary to keep headquarters open past 4 P.M. on weekdays or on weekends, and desk-bound dispatch officers could be reassigned to street patrols.
 
'What Kind of Message?'
 Donna Sommer, an elementary school teacher, demanded, "What kind of message does it send to the criminal element? I myself have had occasion to use the police station late at night, and I really don't know what I would have done without it. You can't possibly save enough money to justify closing so important a facility."
In fact, whether the Council will move ahead with the station closings is most uncertain, given the public opposition. A week after the Council meeting, the Mayor said that he thought the closings were unlikely and that the decision rested with the Ronald Schramm, the Police Chief.
Money is at the core of Hillsdale's problems. The borough, which has a population of 9,750, has been struggling, like so many others in New Jersey, to find a balance between the growth in the number of state-mandated municipal programs and the caps the Legislature has imposed on municipal spending.
"We have a state-mandated cap on our budget increases," the Mayor said in an interview. "Last year it was no more than 4.5 percent. Now I have to pay that 8 percent of the increase that the cops won this year and then another 8 percent next year, yet I have to stay within the cap legally. So now I have to take something else out of the budget."
Dennis Deutsch is a lawyer and one of the two candidates for Council seats on Tuesday fielded by the newly formed Hillsdale Independent Coalition. He has criticized the borough's failure to establish a legal basis for waging its continuing legal challenge to the police salary award and the proposal to close the police station as evidence of "poor advice and poor judgment."
Hillsdale has an unusually small commercial tax base; more than 90 percent of its taxes are collected from increasingly irate homeowners. The part-time Mayor, a Republican, and the largely Republican Council have sought to trim the growth of municipal service budgets and to generate new revenue.
 
Pact With Private Hauler
 They have divined a certain alchemy in the community's ongoing garbage problems. Last April they closed the municipality's own garbage pickup operations, selling the trucks and equipment and signing a five-year pact with DiBella Sanitation, a private hauler in nearby Park Ridge. The arrangement will save the town $220,000 a year in carting fees, said Mayor Elder,, an International Business Machines salesman by day.
Then, in June, the Borough Council concluded an agreement with Sal-Car Transfer Systems, the local garbage-tranfer station, whereby Sal-Car would begin paying Hillsdale $5 for every ton of Bergen County garbage the company processes. The Mayor estimates that the agreement could yield the borough as much as $1 million a year.
From the company's point of view, the arrangement brings Sal-Car into compliance with a 1988 state law that ordered transfer stations to seek an accommodation with their "host communities," and required that monetary compensation be offered to offset the burden their operations place on the affected towns.
"We are trying to be good neighbors," said James Ribaudo, president of Sal-Car, who said he hoped that the fees would improve the company's relationship with the community.
Mayor Elder said the agreement preserves the borough's right to continue its lawsuit against the company. That suit charges that Sal-Car has been exceeding the limits set in the town permit, which allows the processing of 350 tons of garbage a day.
Mr. Ribaudo said his company was now processing up to 900 tons daily. But he contended that it is the state and not the host community that is empowered to regulate his business.
 
Truck Traffic Called 'Disaster'
 "The residents of this town will tell you we should run out and put a padlock on Sal-Car's operations," said Hillsdale Councilman Joseph J. Tedona, a Democrat running for re-election on Tuesday. "Nothing would make me happier. The truck traffic they've generated is a disaster. But you can't do that."
Mr. Tedona, a plant manager for Star Manufacturing in Little Ferry, voted in favor of signing the agreement with Sal-Car.
Now that a first installment of $382,000 has been received from the transfer station via the Bergen County Utilities Authority, a battle is brewing over how or even whether to spend the money. There have been suggestions that these revenues be set aside in a surplus fund, but Mayor Elder has called upon the Council to use the funds to provide tax relief for homeowners.
One of the most vehement opponents of the Sal-Car agreement is Mr. Deutsch. "I just don't think that it is prudent for the town to base its economic future on its ability to attract more garbage into the community," he said.

HEADLINE: Fall Cleanup Day Draws Hundreds to Playland

BYLINE: By TOM CALLAHAN

DATELINE: RYE

 BODY:
DESPITE the threat of rain, 758 cars pulled into the parking lot at Playland Amusement Park here on Oct. 24. With the park rides closed for the winter, those drivers were there not for entertainment but to get rid of potentially hazardous household chemicals.
Over a seven-hour period on that Saturday, county residents disposed of 4,000 pounds of car batteries, 450 gallons of used motor oil, two Dumpsters full of old tires and 386 drums of household hazardous waste like pesticides and detergents. For the 13th time since 1985, the county's Department of Health and the Department of Environmental Facilities sponsored Household Chemical Cleanup Day. During these events, the county contracts with outside waste-removal firms to dispose of the material collected. The cost of the project is borne by Refuge Disposal District No. 1, which covers all Westchester municipalities except seven in the northern part of the county. 
 Holt Ardrey of Rye was attending his first cleanup day with two crates filled with old containers of antifreeze, enamel paints and pesticides. He was directed to drive to two giant tents set up in a corner of the parking lot. There, 50 employees of the Radiac Research Corporation of Brooklyn, some of them in heavy protective clothing, were working. After assisting Mr. Ardrey in removing the chemicals from his car, the workers separated the chemicals by ingredients and packed them in 55 gallon drums for disposal.
 
Original Containers Required
 Mr. Ardrey found out about the cleanup day from a brochure. "The benefit of this day is, first, that it is an incentive to clean out your basement and, second, it is a way to dispose of this stuff safely," Mr. Ardrey said.
Besides Radiac, the other contractors at Playland included Coletta Recycling of Far Rockaway, for used tires, and County Environmental System of Putnam Valley, for motor oil. All chemicals collected had to be in original labeled containers because no unmarked substances were accepted. Latex paint was also not accepted. County officials said that once it has dried, latex paint may be put out for regular garbage pickup.
"We see a lot of typical household items," said John Tekin, project manager of Radiac, as he went through a box of containers. "One of the most common items we receive is pool cleansers. But they can be a fire hazard if they come in contact with brake fluid. The most unusual item we've seen today is two jars of calcium carbide, given to us by an elderly lady. It had probably been in her basement for years as part of some old chemistry kit. The danger was if it came in contact with water, it would spontaneously ignite."
Mike Ritchie, assistant to the County Executive for Solid Waste Management, said, "Before, this stuff went right down the drain, but now the public consciousness is being raised on how carefully we must think of waste disposal."
 
Three Cleanup Days a Year
 Peggy Peters of Rye drove up in a van with her mother, Margaret Pierce of Katonah. Both women have attend the cleanup day each year and use it as a chance for the family to get together for lunch. "We've been coming to the cleanup days since they started," Mrs. Peters said. "There is no question that they are worthwhile. People have chemicals that they have to use in the home, and this provides a way to dispose of what they don't use."
The county is the host to three cleanup days at different spots during the year. The first this year was in July at the Valhalla Fire Training Center, and the final one of the year will be next Saturday at the Peekskill Waste Treatment Plant. Since they were started in 1985, 4,640 residents have taken part in the events and filled 4,270 drums of chemicals at a disposal cost of $1.11 million to the county.
"The word is spreading that people have to handle their waste in a proper manner," said James J. Hogan, the county's Recycling Director. "Our goal is to keep educating the public and to urge them to participate in events like these."
Marianne S. Gallagher, staff assistant in the Department of Environmental Facilities, said: "By becoming more responsible in how we purchase and dispose of household chemicals, we will be helping the environment as well as being economical. You shouldn't buy any chemical items in excess of what you need. If you have chemicals remaining that you are not going to use, you should give them away or dispose of them safely."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Residents of Rye, above, unloading car containing potentially hazardous household chemicals; A county worker pouring paint into hazardous waste containers at Household Chemical Cleanup Day in Rye (Photographs by Suzanne DeChillo for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New Rochelle in Finals as Site for Unicef

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE

 BODY:
THERE hasn't been this much excitement in town since Thomas Paine, the city's most famous resident, first helped foment a revolution. At deli counters and in small stores operating on half-deserted Main Street, people talk of "The Little Engine That Could" and of David overcoming Goliath.
They are referring to the possibility that their small city could beat out New York City to become the new home of Unicef. Thomas Paine was, after all, the first to propose "a general convention of nations acting as a whole," and residents devoutly hope his dream materializes in their hometown. 
 New Rochelle is one of four sites that the United Nations Children's Fund with 950 employees is considering for its headquarters, having reduced its list of contenders from 34. The agency, which hopes to consolidate its operation in one spot by 1995, has been expanding at a faster rate than expected, said Timothy Boaks, Unicef's director of administration and management, who added that the agency grew 15 percent in the three-year period that ended in 1990. A final decision on the new site is expected by February.
"We are not trying to raid New York City," New Rochelle Mayor Timothy C. Idoni said last week as he prepared to discuss refinements to the city's proposal with a team of lawyers and financial consultants from the international agency. "We were asked to submit a proposal, and we did. We have a wonderful story to tell."
What has attracted the high-profile international agency to this economically battered city 18 miles north of Manhattan is an offer that would reduce its yearly rent from $10 million to $531,156 and provide a new, 575,00-square-foot, designed-to-order 20-story headquarters ready for occupancy in two years.
"If the New Rochelle offer saves us $100 million over 25 years, and it's more than that, New York City must do a lot to match it," said James P. Grant, Executive Director and Under Secretary General of the agency.
"The question is how to measure the cost of our need to stay in New York and near the U.N.," he said. "If Unicef was a free-standing organization, we would have moved to New Rochelle long ago."
What has captured the community's imagination is a comprehensive development plan created by the city with the aid of the Starrett Housing Corporation/H.R.H. Construction Corporation. The proposed new headquarters is the centerpiece of a plan, designed by Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates of Manhattan, to revitalize downtown New Rochelle, a plan in which the United Nations agency would be a partner.
The proposed new headquarters on Huguenot Street would be the focus of a so-called United Nations Community District covering a substantial part of the central business area, much of which is now vacant or underutilized. The district would include four new office buildings with a total of 800,000 square feet, 360 units of market-rate housing, a 1,000-space parking garage and an extensive landscaping and beautification program.
From a new sign on the New England Thruway reading, "Welcome to New Rochelle, Home of Unicef" to a landscaped "U.N. Circle," a traffic circle at the intersection of North Avenue and Garden Street several blocks away, visitors would find a campus-style environment emphasizing the activities of the international agency.
Some of the city's major public buildings are in the same area, and at least one of them, a designated historic landmark next to the New Rochelle Public Library, is being offered to Unicef for use as an international children's library.
These enticements, part of a package that includes tax-exempt financing, reduced parking fees and utility rates, low-cost housing and less expensive hospital care have alarmed New York City officials, who fear they could lose a prized tenant.
In the last six months since the field was narrowed from 34 proposals to 4, the city's Economic Development Office has mounted an aggressive campaign and offered a number of concessions, including rent reductions.
Recently, the Austrian Government alerted Unicef officials that it, too, is preparing to submit a proposal offering space in Vienna before the mid-November deadline. "They are offering totally free accommodations for our New York and Geneva offices," Mr. Boaks said, adding that the agency would pay yearly rent of 1 Austrian schilling. The operating costs, however, would be higher than they are in New York but less than in Geneva, he conceded.
 
Other Sites in Brooklyn and Queens
 For New York City, the stakes are much higher than the potential loss of Unicef. Three other United Nations agencies are considering a proposal to move to Bonn to occupy some of the many Government buildings that will be vacated when the German capital moves back to Berlin. The agencies, the United Nations Development Program, the United Nations Population Fund and the United Nations Development Fund for Women, represent almost 1,300 jobs.
The other sites being considered are one in Brooklyn and two in Queens.
Hoping to assure their place in the outcome of these high-stakes negotiations, New Rochelle's government, educational, business and civic leaders have joined in an unprecedented campaign to convince United Nations officials that the 67,000 men, women and children of New Rochelle want Unicef in the Queen City of the Sound.
"I've never seen a city or its people as united as they are or people as excited as they are," said Sidney P. Mudd, chairman of the New Rochelle for Unicef Committee, an organization of leaders from the city's business, educational and governmental communities. "This has really caught people's attention."
A breakfast at the Greentree Country Club in New Rochelle two weeks ago attracted 160 leaders from around the county who pledged to write letters to United Nations delegates, join the committee supporting the proposal and offer their ideas to city officials.
 
City Hopes to Overcome Setbacks
 The prospect of welcoming the United Nations agency and stimulating the local economy has kept many people in New Rochelle busy thinking of ways to be hospitable. City Hall has been flooded with ideas ranging from one by a doctor who said he would take Unicef employees on a tour of residential neighborhoods to one by a teacher who wants to organize schoolchildren in a letter-writing campaign.
Whatever the outcome, being named to the final four has galvanized New Rochelle, which has had a series of economic setbacks and bitter political battles over the last decade. State aid is down and property taxes are up, and residents have seen retailers depart and witnessed the defeat of such proposals as the $1 billion conversion of Davids Island to luxury housing.
Last spring, Macy's joined the parade of major retailers leaving New Rochelle in recent years. The loss of the only anchor tenant in the city's major shopping mall came two months after the City Council severed a contract that would have given a developer exclusive rights to put housing on Davids Island.
But a new current of optimism pervades City Hall under an administration that says it is determined to work cooperatively with developers. "Now developers believe they can do business with the city," said Joseph G. Madonna, Commissioner of Development. "It's no longer impossible to deal with the city of New Rochelle." Friction among some members of the City Council, former City Manager C. Samuel Kissinger and former Mayor Leonard C. Paduano has been blamed for previous inaction on development programs.
 
10-Year Development Plan
 In the last several months, the city has attracted new tenants who will provide an estimated $4 million a year in sales and property taxes, Mr. Madonna said, as part of a 10-year major development initiative begun in 1991.
The Lillian Vernon Corporation, a mail-order retailer, has agreed to put its corporate headquarters and a 4,000- to 5,000-square-foot retail outlet on Main Street, while the county will move its Department of Environmental Facilities also to Main Street. The Pace Warehouse Club plans to take over the refurbished Joyce Beverage Building, and negotiations are nearly complete with Home Depot, a discount home-improvement retailer, to occupy a 13-acre site in the Weyman Avenue Redevelopment Area.
Although the proposed Unicef headquarters is the catalyst for the redevelopment effort, city officials insist that the renaissance of New Rochelle will continue whether or not the international agency comes to their city.
"We've experienced a 180-degree turn in our view of the future of New Rochelle," Mr. Mudd said. "We have leadership and unanimity on the City Council for the first time in 12 years and an upward surge in the response of the people."
Last week, New Rochelle's leaders continued what they called their "full court press" to convince international officials to move Unicef to New Rochelle with a reception for the 56 United Nations delegates who live in Westchester.
"It is said that New York is the city that never sleeps," Mr. Mudd told the assembled guests. "Well, New Rochelle is the city that never quits."

HEADLINE: World Markets;
A 'No' on Unity, a 'Yes' From Investors

BYLINE: By Clyde H. Farnsworth

DATELINE: TORONTO

 BODY:
In another illustration of unpredictability and perverseness, the markets here have just posted one of the best gains of the year during a week in which voters said "no" to a vaunted constitutional agreement aimed at keeping Canada from breaking up.
Not only did stock and bond prices levitate, but the Canadian dollar rose to nearly 81 United States cents after plummeting during the six-week referendum campaign to just above 79 cents, 5 cents below August's level. 
 What's more, interest rates this week were tumbling. The Bank of Canada dropped its discount rate on Thursday to 6.30 percent from 7.37 percent, the biggest drop since 1987 -- although the rate is well above the 19-year low of 4.93 percent set in early September.
These are far from the gloom-and-doom results that some backers of the Charlottetown agreement, including Prime Minister Brian Mulroney and the Royal Bank of Canada, hinted might follow a "no" victory.
Early in the campaign, the Prime Minister raised the possibility of Canada's dismemberment if "no" won, while the country's biggest bank issued a much-cited report warning of the dire economic consequences of a breakup, including a $4,000 fall in per capita income, a one-third rise in the unemployment rate and emigration of a million Canadians seeking jobs in the United States.
All this came against a backdrop of foreign disinvestment. Figures from Statistics Canada show foreigners dumping a record $4.1 billion of Canadian bonds in August, ending a 26-month trend of inflows. They also sold $1.4 billion of money market paper like Treasury bills and $9 million worth of stocks. (Foreigners have never been big holders of Canadian stocks.)
When released later this year, the figures for September and October are likely to show similar large outflows.
What happened this week, analysts said, was that markets had already built the worst-case scenarios into pricing and then discovered that the actual negative news wasn't as bad as earlier perceptions.
For one thing, an uncertainty became a certainty, and as Michael Holder, senior adviser in foreign exchange at the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, observed: "Even if negative, the emergence of certainty for markets is positive."
Politicians agreed this week that all that had happened was that Canada had returned to the status quo. The fear that Quebec would separate was attenuated by a realization that if it happened at all, it would not be tomorrow or the day after.
Quebec separatists still have to win a provincial election, which the federalist premier, Robert Bourassa, does not have to call for two years, and then a majority of Quebecers would have to vote for independence in a new referendum before any actual divorce.
Most recent polls suggest that even though Quebecers voted against the Charlottetown agreement because they felt it did not give them enough autonomy, a majority still continue to favor union with Canada.
Robert Palombi, economist for MMS International, a Toronto financial information firm, said markets took encouragement from a declaration of Mr. Bourassa that he was still dedicated to "building a strong Quebec within Canada."
This is far different, Mr. Palombi noted, from the premier's reaction after the June 1990 collapse of the Meech Lake agreement, a similar effort at constitutional compromise, when a disappointed Mr. Bourassa, who had also backed that accord, sounded something like a separatist himself.
There was another critical difference between then and now, analysts said. Quebec backed Meech Lake, while two English-speaking provinces, Newfoundland and Manitoba, refused to ratify it. The Charlottetown agreement was rejected not only by Quebec but by five of the other nine English-speaking provinces.
So as Ron Meisels, president of P&C Holdings, an investment advisory firm in Montreal, commented: "It's not a question this time of Quebec versus the rest of the country. A lot of people just didn't like the agreement. It's a clearcut decision of English and French Canada."
Although Canada's unity problems remain under the surface, the political leadership, after Monday's rebuff by the voters, has now promised an indefinite deferral of any attempt at restarting the talks and promised instead to focus efforts on what the Prime Minister called "economic renewal." This, too, analysts said, was what markets wanted to hear.
Paul Ferley, assistant chief economist at the Bank of Montreal, observed that "once assured of no major political fallout from the vote, markets could concentrate on economic fundamentals" in which he noted that an inflation rate of 1.3 percent and a growth rate of 0.7 percent "leaves room" for further declines in interest rates. Although commercial banks on Tuesday cut their prime rate half a point for loans to their best customers, the prime still stands at an unusually high 7 3/4 percent.
In the absence of political uncertainties, Mr. Ferley and other economists see the markets as basically interest-rate-driven.
The Toronto Stock Exchange 300 composite index closed on Friday at 3,336.12, up nearly 200 points, or 6 percent, from the 21-month low of 3,149.27 it hit during trading on Oct. 2. Last Friday's close was 3,246.73.
Canadian analysts said pension and mutual fund investors had been building up cash during the referendum campaign and this week moved heavily into the market.

The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: November 1, 1992

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1791 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/October 25-30

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
At G.M., Shakeups and Promises, Promises 

When the General Motors Corporation's board meets tomorrow in New York, it is expected to name John F. Smith Jr. president and John G. Smale chairman. Mr. Smale would replace Robert C. Stempel, who resigned under pressure last week. Directors are also expected to boot Roger G. Smith, G.M.'s former chairman, off the board. . If the rumors are right, another inside director may also be forced to go. If all that happens, G.M., which lost $752.9 million in the third quarter -- an improvement over its $1.1 billion loss for the same quarter last year -- might finally get an activist board. Such a board, analysts say, would be willing to give G.M.'s new team only six months to a year to turn things around. Still, skepticism abounds. "We have been through the promises of change so many times with G.M., and nothing ever happens," said Joseph S. Phillippi, an analyst with Lehman Brothers.

Bill Cosby Wants NBC
 
Bill Cosby is not only the nation's highest- paid entertainer, he is also the Jell-O man, the host of the syndicated program "You Bet Your Life" and a comedian. But last week he was deadly serious when he said he was trying to buy NBC from the General Electric Company. Mr. Cosby's agent, Norman Brokaw, of the William Morris Agency, told Robert C. Wright, NBC's president, that Mr. Cosby "is definitely interested in buying NBC." Though Mr. Wright said the network -- which has seen its ratings slip -- was not for sale, rumors have been circulating for more than a year that G.E. may put it on the block. If it does, the asking price is likely to be about $4 billion. To do the deal, Mr. Cosby has been working with the New York law firm of Patterson, Belknap, Webb & Tyler, to bring in other investors. "It's not likely Bill will do the whole thing, nor would I consider it prudent that he try to," said Herbert H. Chaice, Mr. Cosby's lawyer.

Paramount's Chief Steps Down
 
Brandon Tartikoff was the whiz kid of network TV. When he was head of NBC Entertainment he gave a generation of couch potatoes hit shows like "Miami Vice," "Hill Street Blues" and "L.A. Law." Then he went to the movies 15 months ago as chairman of Paramount Pictures -- with mixed results. Though "Wayne's World" was boffo at the box office, "1492: Conquest of Paradise," was long on mood-music and jungle vistas but short on box-office receipts. Last week Mr. Tartikoff resigned as head of Paramount. Mr. Tartikoff said it was to spend more time with his family, especially with his daughter who had been injured in an automobile accident last year. But Hollywood insiders say Mr. Tartikoff was also upset by the scrutiny his division was given by its parent company, Paramount Communications Inc. Wall Street thinks Mr. Tartikoff's shoes will be hard to fill. Paramount's stock fell $1.625 to $43.25 on the announcement and closed the week at $42.125.

For Sale: I.B.M.'s Memory Chips
 
In an effort to find revenue wherever it might exist, the International Business Machines Corporation said it would sell its memory chips to other manufacturers. Big Blue is the world's third largest computer chip maker behind NEC of Japan and Toshiba. The strategy follows I.B.M.'s decision to sell other computer components that it manufactures, such as disk drives.

A Fine for Radio's Trouble Maker
 
Howard Stern -- New York radio's bad-boy -- built up a nationwide following for his syndicated talk show by blending celebrity interviews with bathroom jokes. Last week, the Federal Communications Commission announced its intention to impose a $105,000 fine on a Los Angeles radio station, KLSX-FM, for broadcasting Mr. Stern's show during a 12-day period last year. The F.C.C. said Mr. Stern's programs, which went on at length about Pee Wee Herman, the former children's TV performer, were indecent. The new charges follow $6,000 fines against three stations owned by Infinity Broadcasting of New York City, which produces Mr. Stern's show.
 
Continuing Losses for Ford
 
The Ford Motor Company may be highly praised for its strong productivity gains and its Japanese levels of quality, but that hasn't been enough to get the traffic flowing into its showrooms. Last week Ford announced a loss of $158.9 million in the third quarter due largely to a sales slump in North America and Britain. Ford lost $574.4 million in the same quarter last year.

The President's Gifts
 
As President Bush barnstorms around the country in the final days of the campaign, he has been cracking the window of the Presidential limo to hand out gifts to the electorate, mostly in the form of overseas arms sales. Last week Mr. Bush did it again by approving a $1.85 billion contract to the General Dynamics Corporation from the Netherlands, Belgium, Denmark and Norway to upgrade 399 F-16 fighter jets. The work will be divided between General Dynamics's Fort Worth facility and factories in Europe.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Mazda Clips Its Own Wings
 
Detroit is not the only place where auto makers are having trouble. Japan's car companies are having trouble moving their iron as well. Last week, the Mazda Motor Corporation said it was scaling back plans to introduce a high-price luxury-car line under the Amati name. Though it had planned to set up a separate dealer network for the Amati -- a la Toyota's Lexus dealer network -- Mazda will now sell the cars through its existing showrooms. Mazda also canceled plans to tout the new cars in a $60 million to $70 million ad campaign by Lord, Dentsu & Partners. And Mazda said it would bring out only one moderately-priced luxury model, not two, as originally planned. "Mazda is kind of pulling in its horns," said Ben Moyer, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company. "They've extended themselves too far." Mr. Moyer projects Mazda will lose $25 million in the fiscal year ending March 30.

Stow-Away Sushi
 
The restaurateurs at Sushi Boy, a chain in Osaka, planned to get around Japan's import restrictions on rice by bringing in shipments of sushi from California. Japan's customs inspectors seized the first shipment, then allowed it into the country. Last week, after an internal dispute, the masterminds of the import plan -- Fujio Matsumoto, Sushi Boy's president, and Haruhiko Saito, a vice president -- quit the company. As a result, "Sushi Boy itself is without anyone to import sushi," said Jun Nakamura, a spokesman for the company.
 
Spin Doctor Yeltsin?
 
In a statement that sounded more like a news release than a penetrating economic analysis, Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin told a group of American bankers visiting Moscow that "despite the political shouting and hysteria from some groups, the main problems from the reforms are behind us." But according to Russia's State Statistical Committee, inflation could hit 25 percent a month this year -- far in excess of the target set by the International Monetary Fund. Mr. Yeltsin's plans to index pensions to the inflation rate for state workers could drive inflation even higher.

 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
A Little Light in the G.D.P.
 
At last, a little good news for the economy. Gross domestic product grew at an annual rate of 2.7 percent in the third quarter, the Commerce Department said. It was the strongest performance so far during the Bush Administration and because it raised output to levels higher than those before the recession began, technically the economy is now in expansion. But while growth was somewhat brisk, "there was no increase in employment," said Mickey Levy, chief economist at CRT Government Securities in New York.

Silicon Valley's Vote . . .
 
Silicon Valley was Reagan country. It grew strong on tax-sheltered venture-capital money during the go-go 1980's. Then came the tax reform act of 1986, the growth of Japan's semiconductor might and finally the recession. That made this entrepreneurial Eden edgy. Last week, at John Sculley's ranch -- he's the chairman of Apple Computer -- a group of high-level Silicon Valley executives endorsed Gov. Bill Clinton's candidacy and his high-tech policies, which include the national data highways. Among those joining Mr. Sculley to lift their glasses of Chardonnay were John A. Young, president of Hewlett-Packard; Paul A. Allaire, chairman of Xerox, and Jerry K. Pearlman, chairman of Zenith.
Ross Perot also has a following. While he was tossed softballs by admiring callers on "Larry King Live," he got an on-air endorsement call from Cher, who said she approved of his economic plans.

. . . And the Heartland's
 
The brie-and-silicon set may be wild about Gov. Bill Clinton, but President Bush still has his admirers. W. R. Timken Jr., chairman of the Timken Company, which makes roller bearings and specialty steel products in Canton, Ohio, is one of many corporate captains in industrial Ohio who are "overwhelmingly for President Bush," Mr. Timken said. Paul H. O'Neil, chairman of Alcoa Inc., in Pittsburgh, is also in Mr. Bush's camp. And while many of Mr. Bush's critics take him to task for the slumping economy, Robert W. Galvin, chairman of the executive committee of Motorola Inc., in Schaumburg, Ill. doesn't think Mr. Bush has done a bad job at all. "Frankly, I don't think Presidents have all that much to do with how an economy goes," he said.

Big Tickets, Shrinking Orders
 
The economy may be expanding, but tell that to the nation's manufacturers of big-ticket items. Orders of durable goods -- everything from airplanes to dishwashers -- fell in September by 0.4 percent, the Commerce Department said. The largest drop in orders was for military goods -- they were down 15.7 percent. Without the drop in military orders, durable goods orders would have been up by a slim 0.5 percent. "Overall I'd say it's a weak ish report," said Ian Borsook, an economist at Merrill Lynch & Company.

Resisting the USAir Deal
 
British Airways has been trying to acquire 25 percent of USAir's voting stock for $750 million for months. The deal would effectively put USAir under British Airways control. But in the third Presidential debate, Ross Perot said he was against the deal. Let foreign interests buy United States airlines and soon they'll dominate the market for airplanes too, he said. Last week, viewers of "Larry King Live" learned that Gov. Bill Clinton, if elected President, would also oppose the deal. Mr. Clinton said that unless Britain and the United States negotiated an aviation pact that allows United States airlines equal access to the British market, he would not "sign off" on British Airways's investment. President Bush favors the deal.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
To Investors, The Economy Looks Brighter

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
As the election nears, there are clear signs of improvement in the economy, or at least in some parts of it. Perhaps more importantly, it appears that middle-class voters are more optimistic than at any time since early 1990.
Those signs, to be sure, are limited. For every good piece of economic news in recent weeks, there has been a bad one. The surprisingly strong economic growth rate of 2.7 percent in the third quarter, which President Bush trumpeted last week, could easily be revised downward, and in any case is weaker than the first-quarter figure. Those who expect the economy to keep stuttering have plenty of evidence to support their position. 
 "There is a very depressed economy -- commercial real estate, defense, civilian aircraft and the entire state of California," said Ed Yardeni, the chief economist at C.J. Lawrence. "But we have another economy that is performing remarkably well given all the areas of weakness. There are sectors of the manufacturing economy where new orders are at record levels."
Over all, the economy's output of goods and services set a record in the third quarter, exceeding the level hit in the second quarter of 1990. But total employment is down half a million since then.
While consumer confidence figures look dismal, there are surprises hidden in the details. The University of Michigan survey separates out investors, who make up about half the population of consumers. For the last couple of years they have expected their own personal finances to worsen, with income growth running below anticipated inflation.
But the latest Michigan survey, done for Fidelity Investments, shows a turnaround. Investors now think their own family incomes will rise 3 percent over the next year, while they expect inflation to climb 2.5 percent. The last similar margin was in April 1990, before the recession. The Michigan people did not ask for political leanings, but it is a fair bet that a lot of the once-pessimistic investors were Republicans who had decided to abandon President Bush. Their new economic optimism, perhaps, may help to explain the narrowing of the presidential polls.
That investors are beginning to scent a rebound can be seen in the vibrant performance of smaller stocks, as well as in the fact that short-term interest rates have been rising. Since the lows of early October, the Dow Jones industrial average is up just 1.5 percent, but that understates the real action. The Nasdaq composite has leaped 7.1 percent and mutual funds that invest in small growth stocks are seeing the money pour in. Even the bankers seem more optimistic. At long last, they are making more business loans.
Still, it remains hard to believe that such gains will be enough for President Bush to keep his job. In the five Presidential elections since the Conference Board started tracking confidence, the incumbent party has won if the confidence index was above 99, and lost if it was below 88. Now it stands at 53.

But History Favors Clinton," tracks consumer confidence in October of election years, and vote for incumbent party's candidate," 1972-1992.

LENGTH: 2684 words

HEADLINE: A Bank That Lived to Tell the Tale

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
The dark days at the Shawmut Bank started in February 1990, when an army of 170 Federal examiners arrived at the bank's main offices in Massachusetts and Connecticut for what would prove to be a six-week audit of Shawmut's real estate loans.
Shawmut, which had been confident enough to ask the examiners to come a month early, was stunned by the results. The examiners took a much dimmer view of repayment prospects than the bank did. Determined that they would not be accused of the slack supervision that helped topple the savings and loan industry, the regulators forced Shawmut to restate its 1989 results, turning a $202 million profit into a $129 million loss. 
 "We were expecting a rainstorm, but they said we should be ready for a hurricane," said Joel B. Alvord, chairman of Shawmut, the third-largest bank in New England.
Things got worse in January 1991, when the failure of the Bank of New England sent shivers through Shawmut's executive suites here. Like Shawmut, the Bank of New England had been deeply involved in real estate lending and had been hit hard by a massive examination of its loans in the early days of 1990.
"Our customers and other people in the industry looked at us as a twin of Bank of New England, and figured that we were next," said Gunnar S. Overstrom, Shawmut's president.
But Shawmut wasn't next. Today, Shawmut is profitable again, its portfolio of bad loans has shrunk and its prospects have been bright enough to attract new capital.
 
The Banking 'Crisis'
 Shawmut's decline was more extreme than that of most banks, but the way it reversed its slide is representative of what many have done. Among other things, Shawmut began a crash program for dealing with defaulted loans and it tightened its lending standards. It also benefited from a widening spread between the interest rates it pays on deposits and the rates it collects on loans and investments. At Shawmut, that gap now averages 4.16 percent, compared with 3.47 percent two years ago.
Indeed, the rebound at Shawmut and at scores of other once-troubled banks has been strong enough to convince many analysts that the banking industry is not heading for the kind of crisis that crippled the country's savings and loans.
Talk of a banking crisis has been getting louder in the closing weeks of the Presidential campaign, thanks in part to a recent academic study, "Banking on the Brink," which predicted up to 1,000 closings in coming years. Ross Perot cited the study in the final Presidential debate when he suggested that the Bush Administration was waiting for Tuesday's election to be over before closing a large number of banks and handing taxpayers "a $100 billion problem."
But many industry experts say the study is misleading because it relies on 1991 data that do not reflect recent improvements and makes overly pessimistic estimates of losses on bad loans.
At a Senate hearing last week, regulators conceded that some failures will occur after the election because of new rules taking effect Dec. 19 that require weakly capitalized banks to be closed. But the number -- and size -- of the failures will be relatively modest, they said.
Many analysts agree. "The crisis is over," said Lowell Bryan, a banking consultant at McKinsey & Company, quickly adding, however, that "it can come back if the economy weakens further."
And that's the rub. Having proved that they are strong enough to survive, Shawmut and other banks must still show that they can prosper without taking the kind of excessive risks that marked the 80's. Even those banks that avoided the worst mistakes of the 80's admit they need to make fundamental improvements in how they operate.
So far, the favorable spread in interest rates has been providing banks with the revenues they need to write off losses from bad loans and still show a profit.
Shawmut, for example, cut its holdings of troubled loans and foreclosed real estate to $1.07 billion as of Sept. 30, from $1.68 billion in December 1990. The payoff: it started earning small profits in mid-1991. Bad loans have been declining for the banking system as a whole, allowing it to rack up record profits of $15.5 billion in the first half of this year. Recent third-quarter reports indicated that profits are continuing at a record level.
Banks have also raised a record amount of capital by issuing new common and preferred stock, thereby increasing the cushion available to absorb unexpected losses. Shawmut raised $200 million in a stock offering earlier this year.
 
Buying Time
 But the favorable interest-rate spreads are only buying time, Mr. Bryan said. To avoid another crisis, he said, the banks must "wring more profit out of the nuts and bolts of their branch systems, seriously address costs and become better lenders."
Indeed, in the heady days of the 70's and 80's, banks routinely grew faster than the economy, and the growth camouflaged a generation of sloppy lenders.
"The real culprit of bank problems the past few years was the weakness in their credit culture," said George Salem, a banking analyst at Prudential Securities. "Banks need to learn that a good defense is better than a good offense."
For his part, Shawmut's Mr. Alvord says "the pendulum swung too far in both directions," with bankers failing to curb rash lending in the mid-1980's and regulators reacting with overly harsh treatment in 1990.
Mr. Alvord, who is 53, came to the fore during the real estate bust of the mid-1970's, when he was put in charge of Connecticut National Bank's sour loans to real estate investment trusts. His success with those loans helped make him president of Connecticut National in 1978. When the bank merged with Shawmut in 1988, Mr. Alvord was named chairman of the new company.
Yet even with that background, he was unable to avoid the real estate pitfalls of the 1980's.
Although Shawmut and Connecticut National stopped making new lending commitments to real estate developers in 1988, their outstanding real estate loans still accounted for more than 25 percent of their total loans in 1990, or more than twice the average rate for banks their size.
Because Shawmut's most serious problems were the result of bad loans, its lending operation quickly got extra attention. To solve the mistakes of the past, Mr. Alvord assigned about 500 people to do little else but work with troubled borrowers and foreclosed real estate.
To avoid making the same mistakes in the future, Shawmut tightened its lending rules and, last February, hired David L. Eyles, a lending expert with 30 years' experience at Chemical Bank and Mellon Bank, to fill the new position of chief credit officer.
Mr. Eyles is now pushing many business borrowers to provide the bank with audited financial statements, rather than a set of books prepared by the borrower with no outside review. On another tack, he insists that a borrower's internal covenants -- promises it made to the bank about maintaining its financial condition -- should be put in writing and checked periodically.
 
'Infernal' Covenants
 "I know that some of our lenders are talking about Eyles's 'infernal' covenants, but I don't care," Mr. Eyles said. "At least they are talking about credit issues."
A key part of Mr. Eyles's job is to develop uniform standards for measuring loans that coincide with those used by Federal examiners. This would eliminate surprises like the one in 1990, when examiners told the bank it had $1.05 billion of troubled loans, not $535.6 million, as it thought.
With uniform standards, for example, a 5-rated loan (a middle-of-the-road rating for small and medium-sized businesses that are Shawmut's bread and butter) would be reviewed quarterly, while a higher-quality 2-rated loan would be checked only once a year.
The ratings can also point to trends. Mr. Eyles noted, for instance, that loans that drop to 5 from 2 are much more likely to cause a loss than those consistently rated 5.
Such precision is a far cry from the lending practices of the 1980's. "The competitive landscape is much different now, with fewer players and a much more rational market," Mr. Alvord said. The 80's were marked, he said, by "an irrational pattern of pricing and credit standards that went beyond the limits of banking."
But while a few dozen large banks across the country are now far advanced in numerical ratings of loans, much work remains to be done.
In theory, the next step is to use the ratings to set appropriate prices for different customers. For example, a loan to a 2-rated borrower might have a lower interest rate than a loan to a 5-rated borrower.
But only a handful of banks, Shawmut not among them, have made the investment in a system to keep track of all business ties to a customer, and how much profit each produces. A bank that provides a company with cash management and financial advice for mergers could afford to charge a lower rate on a loan than another bank that had no connection to the company except the loan.
While bad lending decisions brought Shawmut to its knees, its consumer business -- operating through 330 branches -- has been a mainstay keeping the company alive. Though third in size overall in New England, Shawmut has the biggest consumer operation in Connecticut and in Massachusetts.
Shawmut has not tried to be a leader in new ventures like banking at home or debit cards. Instead, it has built a solid reputation for its early offering of such humdrum products as consolidated account statements and home-equity loans.
 
Pushing New Services
 Like many other bankers, Mr. Alvord is looking to wring more profit out of the consumer business by offering new services and investments through Shawmut's expensive-to-maintain branch network.
"Joel saw in the mid-1980's that there was money to be made in consumer banking, even though that was not really a big part of tradition at the bank," said Eileen S. Kraus, executive vice president for community banking.
Like many bankers, Ms. Kraus and Mr. Alvord say the nature of consumer banking is changing, with more demand from customers for help in managing their money. The demand for mutual funds and other investment vehicles is more than just a temporary reaction to low rates on deposits, bankers say. As the baby boomers grow older and become middle-aged savers, banks expect slower growth in lending but more growth in money management services.
To take advantage of the situation, Shawmut's trust department, which had revenues last year of about $100 million and managed $12 billion of assets, is accepting smaller accounts and making more use of the bank's connections with owners and managers of local businesses.
"We are blessed with a name that is very well known and a local market that is one of the wealthiest in the country," Mr. Alvord said.
For consumers not wealthy enough to need a trust account, Shawmut is using the trust department as adviser for a new group of mutual funds. Although Shawmut is a late arrival to the mutual fund business, the delay has allowed it to take advantage of a recent ruling by Federal regulators permitting banks to put their names on funds offered to customers.
"We did a lot of comparison shopping, and decided that rather than just jamming someone else's product into our branches using their sales force, we would take the time to develop a product and a distribution system that we would control," said Ms. Kraus.
 
Looking Ahead
 With the strength of Shawmut's branch system still intact, new managers overseeing corporate lending and an improved financial condition, Mr. Alvord says he is not running scared from the two largest New England banking companies, the Bank of Boston, which recently bought a large savings bank in Hartford, and Fleet Financial of Providence, R.I., which bought most of the failed Bank of New England in 1991.
"They want what we have," he said, referring to efforts by both to expand in Shawmut's markets.
The acquisitive drive of other banks may hold the key to Shawmut's future. Plans for a merger with Bank of Boston were far advanced in 1991, but fell apart as Shawmut's health improved and advisers to both sides questioned the fairness of the deal.
But the failure of that deal does not keep many analysts from predicting that another merger lies ahead for Shawmut. Assuming that its loan problems continue to subside, they expect several banks -- including Chase Manhattan and BankAmerica, as well as Bank of Boston and Fleet -- to covet Shawmut's ties to consumers and businesses.
Mr. Alvord isn't tipping his hand. But he is clearly bullish about the future, predicting "dramatic increases" in earnings for the next two years and a 50 percent jump in size -- to $35 billion in assets -- within five. Not bad for a bank whose strategic plan in the last couple of years, according to Mr. Alvord, was simply "to stay alive."
 
 
 
TURNING BRANCHES INTO SALES BOUTIQUES
 With 56,000 bank branches scattered around the country, bankers have a delivery network unmatched in breadth by other financial service companies. It is also unmatched in expense.
While branch closings have become more common lately -- even a consumer-oriented bank like Shawmut has closed 160 in the past four years -- bankers still count on branches as critical to expansion of their consumer business.
In the selling of mutual funds, for example, "the bank's customer relationships and branches can be critical advantages, if there is someone at the bank to sit down with the customer and ask the right questions," said Michael J. Rothmeier, executive vice president at Shawmut and formerly an executive at the Fidelity Group of mutual funds.
Mr. Rothmeier says there is plenty of opportunity for banks since no more than 28 percent of the nearly 70 million households with money available for investments are being served by mutual fund companies.
To make better use of branches as a vehicle for selling and to cut expenses, bankers are eager to reduce the use of branches for ordinary transactions.
Laura Jean Stuart, a bank consultant in Cambridge, Mass., expects that more banks will begin pricing their products to encourage customers to use the high technology on which banks have spent tens of billions of dollars. For example, by charging lower fees to customers whose paychecks are deposited directly by employers or who use automatic teller machines or the telephone, banks would need fewer tellers. That would leave more branch employees free for sales work.

 
THE CREDIT PENDULUM
 As Shawmut and other banks have corrected the lending excesses of the 1980's, they have run into criticism for lending too cautiously, creating a credit crunch that has hurt the economy.
All three Presidential candidates say they want more bank lending. But there are major differences in the way they would accomplish that goal.
President Bush would broaden the banks' powers, allowing them to fully enter the securities business, freely branch across state lines, sell and underwrite insurance and be owned by non-banking companies. Many analysts say the benefits would accrue mostly to a few dozen large banks and take years to appear.
Gov. Bill Clinton would encourage bank lending by ending overly harsh treatment by regulators and through a set of proposals aimed at helping the poorest areas of the country. Using the South Shore Bank of Chicago and other bank-sponsored community development corporations as models, he foresees a network of 100 community development banks. Existing banks would be encouraged to do more lending in poor areas, either directly or indirectly by helping the new development banks.
Ross Perot has pointed out the contradictory policies of regulators, who exhort banks to do more lending and at the same time impose tougher financial standards that have the effect of discouraging lending. Mr. Perot has also warned that many banks, including some of the largest, are weaker than they appear, but he has not said how this weakness should be corrected.

HEADLINE: SoHo Street Therapy

 BODY:
LIKE many good friends, Caroline Johnson, Amy Alkon and Marlowe Minick give one another a lot of advice. One night while trying to help their waiter at the Moon Dance Diner in TriBeCa demystify the meaning of life, they found a way to share their collective wisdom with other people. They became the Advice Ladies and are now a visible and popular part of the SoHo weekend landscape.
On a typical Saturday or Sunday, their modest office -- four chairs and a table at the corner of Broome Street and West Broadway -- is visited by hundreds of people. Most people just stand by and listen, but many sit down and unburden themselves, sharing problems both serious and silly. 
 A large sign reads, "The Advice Ladies Present: Free Advice From a Panel of Experts."
Their expertise extends to love and dating ("also marriage"), color coordination, apartment envy, pet discipline, Paris, recession life style and screenwriting.
In their weekday lives, Ms. Johnson, 37 years old, is an ad account director; Ms. Minick, 35, is a freelance art director, and Ms. Alkon, 28, is a freelance commercial producer.
As Advice Ladies, they say they hear a wildly diverse mix of problems, although most involve "the romance issue" or "the career issue."
On a recent Saturday, an aspiring screenwriter sought advice on dealing with Hollywood, and there were three cases of broken hearts.
"I just want to ask one thing," said Brad Kay, a twentysomething passer-by. "What do women want?"
The Advice Ladies' long list included attention, respect, affection, remembering birthdays and little surprises. "And don't go in for any of that 90's sensitive-man stuff," Ms. Alkon said. "Be aggressive." Ms. Minick added, "But always tell her how you feel."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Advice Ladies: Ms. Johnson, left, Ms. Alkon and Ms. Minick. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
Subaru's Justy, an Endangered Specie

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
AH, the sacrifices one makes.
Dominating the driveway is a lovely Cadillac Brougham, a golden behemoth that has been stretched and redesigned for '93 and that now is the largest production car in the world. It is powerful and it floats. But it has been standing there, quiet and alone, because I have been driving its antithesis, putt-putting in the pursuit of journalism. 
 Said antithesis is a Subaru Justy, a tiny car that would fit into the Cadillac's leather passenger compartment if not into its trunk. The Caddy's keys were on the kitchen counter and I looked longingly at them on the day that professional resolve took hold. But I had to do it. I sighed and picked up the keys for the Subaru.
The Justy is among the cheapest cars around, and it definitely is the least expensive all-wheel-drive automobile sold in the United States. It has cloth upholstery and a three-cylinder engine and manual everything. It also doesn't look like much next to a Cadillac.
But you know what? That little car is pretty neat.
It's odd that more people don't know that and seemingly don't care. And what's really odd, given the sad economy and the state of the car business, is that people are drifting away from vehicles like the Justy and that the trend is toward better-equipped and more expensive machinery.
According to Automotive News, a weekly trade publication that keeps track of such things, the Justy and seven other cars that have base prices of about $7,000 are now selling at less than half their 1988 rate. Things have been so bad, in fact, that Daihatsu, an exporter of inexpensive cars, has pulled out of the American market entirely.
The only success story in the category is the Canadian-built Geo Metro, which along with its twin, the Suzuki Swift, has increased its sales this year.
The manufacturers say the demand for bottom-line models has faded as a result of stabilized gas prices and the growth of baby-boomer families. Safety and emissions requirements also have raised stickers at the same time that production costs have risen in Japan and South Korea, and econocars are being viewed as less of a bargain.
In the first eight months of this year, for example, Subaru's Justy attracted only 2,444 customers, down 50 percent from 1991. And those sales, in turn, were down 75 percent from 1988.
Thus, the Justy is being phased out, although there is some quibbling about that between Subaru of America, which markets the car here, and Fuji Heavy Industries, which makes it in Japan. The word from Subaru's headquarters in Cherry Hill, N.J., is that 1994 will be Justy's last year, and a recent contradiction from Fuji was labeled by a Subaru spokesman as "a mistranslation."
Whatever happens, it means that you have at least another year or so to think about owning what is surely one of the more unusual vehicles on the road and one with a lot to offer.
There is wonderful road feel, for one thing, a result of a stiff but pleasing ride. Air bags are missing, but Subaru has mercifully not resorted to mechanized belts and you can strap yourself in quite comfortably. And, while it lacks power steering, the car weighs only about 2,000 pounds and is easy to handle. It also is only 12 feet long, so it's easy to park.
That small size, accompanied by the buzz of the 73 horsepower engine, gives you the feeling that you are very much a part of your surroundings. But room is as good in front as it is cramped in back. With thin window posts, visibility is excellent, and the short hood allows the driver to look down directly at the road.
For '93, the Justy hatchback can be had with two or four doors and in two levels of trim, base and GL. In the plainest of its stripped modes, it has front-wheel drive and a five-speed manual transmission, but all-wheel drive is available, as is its automatic shifter, the item that makes it truly unique.
The Justy houses America's only constantly variable transmission, known as a CVT -- or, in the electronically controlled Subaru version, as an ECVT. Using no gears, the transmission sends power through a belt that rides on variable-diameter pulleys. The advantages are compact size, few moving parts, low weight and an infinite variety of ratios to perfectly match vehicle loads to engine speeds.
On the highway, that also means smooth shifts and fuel economy of about 31 miles per gallon, slightly better than a similar all-wheel-drive version with a five-speed stick. Unfortunately, the tank holds only 9.2 gallons, so the car's range is limited.
Still, that shouldn't be a problem. Short commutes are the Justy's meat, and it is not a car for cross-country touring. For that, you'll have to excuse me. I think I'll take the Cadillac.
 
 
 
FROM NISSAN, A TOOTHLESS TRANSMISSION
 Subaru's Justy has the only constantly variable transmission sold in America, and it is a neat idea, one that has been experimented with since the late 1800's. The difference between an automatic transmission with gears and a CVT without them is like the difference between a three-way light switch and one with a dimmer control.
The constantly variable transmission uses stepless ratio changes and there is a smooth and uninterrupted flow of power, which improves driveability and fuel economy. As in the Justy, previous designs have transmitted power through a belt, and the strength of the belt has limited CVT's to small cars.
Now, though, Nissan has demonstrated an experimental version for high-output engines that uses two moveable rollers to transmit power between input and output disks. As the positions of the rollers change, so does the transmission ratio.
According to Nissan's engineers, earlier roller designs suffered from high-friction losses and annoying speed changes because of difficulty in controlling the position of the rollers. The new design, they said, reduces the friction and distributes loads more evenly.
They caution that more work needs to be done, but the new transmission is said to be capable of handling 348 horsepower.
