SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 2059 words

HEADLINE: Voting Scared;
Americans Are Sadder and Wiser, But Not Apathetic

BYLINE: By JEFFREY SCHMALZ

 BODY:
THERE was a time when Americans found Presidential elections exhilarating -- bands and bumper-stickers, good guys and bad guys, visions for a brighter tomorrow that had the aura of not just hope but certainty.
But not in 1992. A year of traveling the nation chatting with a thousand voters -- in malls and front yards, in bowling alleys and libraries -- leaves the bland taste of malaise. If the public mood were summed up in a color, it would be gray. People are at once scared and resigned -- scared that the economy has irreparable flaws; scared that the country is adrift; resigned to a visceral feeling that the next President, even if he is their own candidate, will not be able to do much about it. 
 "I feel like we're spinning our wheels," said Elizabeth Hammer, a 30-year-old data processor in St. Louis. "The country isn't going anywhere. I'm not sure that any of the candidates can change that."
Yet remarkable in this campaign is that the malaise has not translated into apathy. Far from it. Even as they voice the lowest of expectations for the next President, Americans, in record numbers in many places, are registering to vote. It is one of the many contradictions in this year when voters sense that the rules of the political game are in flux but can't figure out exactly what they want. They like Ross Perot because he is not a politician, then express reservations about his lack of political experience. They clamor for straight talk, then hover threateningly over every remark about tax increases. They want to throw out the bums throughout the country; they want their own bum kept in.
"You get the feeling things could change. But to what?" asked Angela Hines, a 42-year-old librarian in Albuquerque, N.M. "It's one thing to know something's broke. It's something else to figure out how to fix it."
 
Indecision, Indecision
 Ms. Hines says she has changed since the election season began in February. For one thing, like many other voters around the country, she has switched candidates -- in her case, moving to Gov. Bill Clinton after abandoning President Bush and pausing briefly in between to consider Mr. Perot.
But like many voters, she has changed in other ways, too. It is a sadder but wiser electorate that will enter the booths on Tuesday. In the spring, no interview was complete without cracks about Gennifer Flowers. But that ended abruptly with the Los Angeles riots in April. Suddenly, it all became very serious.
Increasingly, people began to talk about the need for change -- not just in the economy but in health care, the environment, cities. They seemed to realize there would be no quick fixes. And as Mr. Perot gained visibility, it seemed to sink in that all this was going to cost them money, that tax increases were inevitable -- though for whom is another matter.
If Mr. Perot has brought home reality, he has also brought home responsibility. This is your country, he tells voters; fix it. With that has come the rush to voter registration.
But implicit in the Perot comments is that voters are responsible as well for the country's current state. And therein lies one source of uneasiness. The voters toying with the ouster of an incumbent President are the very voters who put him in office in the first place. To repudiate Mr. Bush is to repudiate their own judgment.
Many people who express dissatisfaction with the President nonetheless seem to be groping for reasons to vote for him again, angry at him and at themselves when they don't come up with any.
"I don't understand what happened to him," said Harold Mixner, 52, a Republican in Sherman Oaks, Calif. "I want to shake him."
 
Motivator: the Economy
 This campaign began with the economy and ends with it. But while the theme "the economy" has remained constant, its definition has changed. In February, it meant jobs. By October, it meant jobs and deficit. Ross Perot has sold his message well, burrowing into the voter conscience.
"Perot's right: We have to worry about the future," Nancy Moya, 35, who works in the business department of an Albuquerque television station, said as her lunchmates on Route 66 nodded. "I have a couple of children. It's not fair that we're leaving this for our kids to clean up."
But always, the conversation comes back to jobs.
"I'm making half of what I made two years ago," said Brian Stead, who was lugging plants from one shop to another at the Galleria, a mall in St. Louis, where he fills in at various stores part-time. "You can't get loans to set up your own place. I don't have health insurance. Everything is so tight."
Even people not directly hit hard by the economy are worried. Steady as a drumbeat, they hear bad economic news on television and have family members in a bind.
"My God son is a lawyer and can't get work. A lawyer! Nobody's taking on new people," said Helen Thayer in Miami Beach, Fla. "He's got a family. People are hurting."
To tour the country is to be stunned by the pockets of Rust Belt devastation and the level of blue-collar anger. Entire towns are gone -- plants, main streets, schools. What the candidates seem not to be connecting with is that a way of life and self-respect are disappearing.
"Honest to God, I think the working man gets it between the eyes no matter which way he turns," said David Poole, 38, who for 17 years has worked at G.M.'s Willow Run plant in Michigan, which is scheduled to close. "Nobody cares."
The workers feel betrayed by both parties. They don't want retraining. They don't want to relocate. They want their old lives back. Mr. Perot is the logical heir to the vote they gave Jerry Brown in the primaries. But they seem torn between Mr. Perot and the man they believe will win, Mr. Clinton.
"They're going to have a revolution in this country one day," said Jerry Clifton, 44, vice president of U.A.W. Local 1776 in Ypsilanti, Mich. "People have pride. They want jobs."
 
The Mighty Suburbs
 Forty percent of the country's registered voters live in the suburbs, and it is there where many analysts believe the election will be won and lost. Nothing is magical about the 'burbs, of course. The economic worries of suburbanites are much the same as everyone else's. But the suburbs are the land of families, and with that come worries about education and long-range concerns about problems like the environment. The Bill Clinton-Al Gore message seems to be playing well in the land of vast numbers of middle-income earners likely to vote.
"The problems are so great," said Amy Haskins, 35, picking up her daughter, Jessica, 4, at a day-care center outside Akron, Ohio. "Bush blocked family leave-time. He's done nothing for education."
It is a paradox that the family-values theme of the Republican National Convention seems to have failed to play well in the land of the family, the suburbs. People are more concerned about other matters, like the economy. And they are upset by the convention's attacks on non-traditional families, which seemed to make them fearful that they themselves would be perceived as bigoted if they bought into the presentation.
"I think the country needs to be brought together, not driven apart," said Hank Warren, 36, a data processor, walking with his son, Jamie, in Richmond, Heights, Mo. Mr. Warren, who voted Republican in 1988 and is leaning Democratic this year, then paused and said of the convention, "It was so nasty."
 
The Interest Groups
 Mr. Perot's proposed 50-cent-a-gallon gas tax is, of course, an anathema in the land of the two- and three-car family. Occasionally, but only occasionally, a brave soul said he would pay the tax, but only if -- as Mark Gleason, a lawyer just outside Washington, Iowa, put it -- "it was dedicated to the deficit, guaranteed, no loopholes."
At least a few suburbanites were willing to think about the gas tax. But most elderly people, on the other hand, wouldn't even talk about any tax on social-security benefits.
"Maybe it would be all right, if the income level were high enough," Edgar Jones, 74, announced in Christy's Barber Shop in Newton, Iowa. Mouths dropped open. Barbers stopped barbering.
"No, that's NOT all right!" shot back Wilber Birkenholtz, 63. "I earned it. I should get it. My God, we earned it!"
Mr. Birkenholtz spoke in the Midwest, where voter ambivalence seems as high as in the rest of the country despite all the attention lavished by the candidates and news organizations on this politically pivotal region.
But that is not to say the country is without its pockets of downright enthusiasm. After 12 years of Republican rule, liberal areas like San Francisco and New York's Upper West Side and Greenwich Village can practically taste a Clinton Victory. Some residents predict there will literally be dancing in the streets if Mr. Clinton wins.
San Francisco officials estimate that 95 percent of eligible voters are registered, in large part because of intensive voter-registration drives in gay neighborhoods rattled by the gay-bashing in speeches at the Republican convention.
And the religious right is energized as well, turning out its faithful by taking to radio airwaves to spread the word that Mr. Clinton and Mr. Perot support a woman's right to an abortion.
"I was leaning toward Perot," said Brian Terrell, 24, a duct cleaner, who stood on a ladder painting the side of his house in Grand Rapids, Mich. "But I heard he supported abortion. Now I'll stay with Bush."
But black voters, who might be expected to rally to a Democratic Presidential candidate, are of a mixed mind. Most of those who vote will go for Mr. Clinton. But many say they are inclined to stay home, slighted by Mr. Clinton's reluctance to court them aggressively out of fear of alienating the mainstream voter -- that is, the all-important white suburbanite.
"He's assuming that because we're tired of Bush, we're going to vote for him," said Linda Harris, 35, a store clerk in the primarily black city of Gary, Ind. She plans to vote for Mr. Clinton, but added, "A lot of folks around here say they're not going to vote."
 
Big Turnout, Big Cynicism
 Over all, throughout the country, voter turnout is expected to exceed that of four years ago -- an ominous sign for Mr. Bush since Democrats are outpacing Republicans in voter registrations.
But people's enthusiasm for their candidates does not seem much greater than that of the people of Gary. While the electorate has become sadder and wiser, it has also become jaundiced. Cynicism pervades. Nothing seems genuine.
People see through the photo-ops now in a way they didn't in the years of Ronald Reagan -- a name, by the way, rarely raised by voters in the interviews. Negative campaigning, once the sure-fire way to get ahead, has stirred deep resentment in this campaign, regardless of whether it has helped Mr. Bush in its closing days.
"I was in World War II. Who cares? That was 45 years ago," Leslie Mueller, 75, said after Mr. Bush challenged Mr. Clinton's antiwar activities in the late 1960's. "Who cares what Clinton did 20 years ago as a young man? Let's talk about the homeless and unemployment, Mr. President. What are you going to do about those?" If anything, Mr. Perot, who set out to be the antidote to cynicism, only fueled it more with his abrupt withdrawal in mid-race. And since Mr. Bush reneged on his "read my lips" pledge of 1988 not to raise taxes, voters seem to assume politicians are lying.
"I'm disgusted with all politicians," said Ron Purkhiser, 50, a welder in Akron. "They say one thing, then they go ahead and do the opposite. 'Read my lips: No new taxes.' Yeah, right."
 
None-of-the-Above Syndrome
 In many ways the election is cruel. It has highlighted the country's problems, persuaded voters action must be taken, then left them with candidates they don't think are up to the job.
For truth be told, much of America just doesn't like its three candidates for President. Over and over, the comments are the same: Mr. Bush is out of touch; Mr. Clinton is slick; Mr. Perot is flaky.
Nick Niederlander, 45, the librarian in Richmond Heights, Mo., is voting for Bill Clinton. But in this Presidential election year, he could have been just about any voter talking about the man he will cast his ballot for on Tuesday.
"I want to like him," he said, "more than I like him."

PUB-DATE: November 1, 1992

SECTION: Section 4; Page 6; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1212 words

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Malcolm X, in the Eyes Of Different Beholders

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
"MY whole life has been a chronology of changes," Malcolm X told Alex Haley, his biographer, the year before he was shot to death on Feb. 21, 1965, in the Audubon Ballroom in New York City. His life with its wholesale leaps of faith and thought has led to continual resurrections and numerous reincarnations as the ideological brawl for his legacy continues.
In his 39 years , Malcolm was constantly evolving, complicating the claims of those who seek to be his spiritual heirs and the interpreters of his philosophy. That he was many things to many people is reflected in his range of admirers, who include rap artists like Public Enemy, Justice Clarence Thomas of the Supreme Court, and the filmmaker Spike Lee. Mr. Lee will reveal his version of the black nationalist's life when his already controversial film "Malcolm X" opens this month. 
 Malcolm X was variously a drug dealer and thief and an Islamic family man whose ascetic life forbade drugs and alcohol. As the spokesman for the Black Muslims, he preached the moral inferiority of whites, self defense and black separation from America's political and social mainstream. He later parted with the Black Muslims, repudiated racism and acknowledged that if racism was eradicated, this could be a country where people could lead decent lives.
The question for some scholars is whether the Malcolm X resurrected by black youth hungry for a symbol of their inchoate rage or the Malcolm X resurrected by the star-starved media represents the true Malcolm X. Because he did not leave an extensive body of work, press for a specific political agenda or build a lasting organization, his legacy has been his own persona, open for interpretation. As a result, while praised for his intelligence and bravery, Malcolm X has been criticized for casting the quest for equality as one for black manhood, and for being racist.
"The legacy is a highly contentious one, no doubt about it," said Cornel West, professor of religion at Princeton University and the director of the Afro-American Studies Department. "He has endured because the saliency and visibility of the rage he articulated exists more than before."
Julius Lester, professor of Judaic and Near Eastern Studies at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, has called Malcolm X's legacy a complex and disturbing one that "includes black racism, anti-Semitism and a belief in the inferiority of women." Mr. Lester said he saw the nationalist's extremism as comforting to hopeless black youth.
"There is something in the metaphor of the X that has a romance to it that gives them an identity," Mr. Lester said. "Who Malcolm was that led him to the Nation of Islam -- his despair -- also mirrors their condition. It is a clarity that is illusory. What he left, pretty much, was warmed-over black nationalism. What makes all the difference in the world was that he was assassinated. It made him a deity."
 
Articulated Rage
 Other scholars, and certainly Malcolm X's admirers, reject that assessment. They say Malcolm X challenged blacks not merely to integrate America, but also to change it and to redefine how they saw themselves. He challenged all Americans to come to terms with a nation that preached liberty on one hand yet treated its darker citizens with violence and hatred on the other, they say. Malcolm X also openly articulated an anger among blacks: many had suffocated while hoping that things would change or despairing that they ever would.
"He taught black people what to think about themselves as an African people, culturally and politically," said James H. Cone, a theology professor at Union Theological Seminary who is the author of "Martin and Malcolm and America: A Dream or Nightmare?" "Malcolm began to make a resurgence in the 80's, when Ronald Reagan became President and Malcolm's message about America being a nightmare became symbolized in Ronald Reagan.
"Probably the rap artists come closest to articulating the rage, although they don't always understand the complexity," he said. "People who see the early part of his life as a black nationalist don't always realize the changes. And those who see the changes don't recognize the continuity."
Manning Marable, a professor of history and political science at the University of Colorado at Boulder who is completing a Malcolm X biography, said the renewed interest in the man is symptomatic.
"It's a commentary on black leaders today," Mr. Marable said. "It also speaks to the growing marginality of young African-Americans.
"What young people have done is instinctively gone back into history to elevate a figure who seems to capture the militancy, fiery rhetoric and spiritual commitment which they do desperately desire today."
Others fear that the man and his message will be trivialized by an indiscriminate popular culture.
"Malcolm X has long been popular among black people," said Amiri Baraka, the poet who is a professor of African Studies at the State University of New York at Stony Brook. "What we have now is white people exploiting the image for their own gain. Seeing young people wearing the X- baseball caps is one thing, but seeing Malcolm X in Bloomingdale's boutique is another matter."
Mr. Baraka is among the naysayers who have attacked Spike Lee's film, afraid that it dwells too much on the early Malcolm -- Detroit Red -- who exploited women sexually, straightened his hair and ran numbers. Despite the protests of Mr. Baraka and others, the icon-making machine churns, producing books, magazine articles, baseball caps, shirts and rap records.
Mr. West agreed Malcolm X's latest incarnation is partly a market phenomenon, but he said it also reflects a real rage among the young.
Too often, scholars say, the gains of the civil rights era have bypassed the poor, and violence has been the result. South Central Los Angeles first burned on Aug. 11, 1965, only five days after Congress passed a major voting rights law that would register thousands of disenfranchised black Southerners. Just months ago, South Central Los Angeles ignited again, fueled by much of the same despair and fury. Since 1967, according to the Census Bureau, the proportion of black families living at the lowest income level grew by 50 percent.
Many black intellectuals say few black leaders today can match Malcolm X's ability to reach those at the bottom. His contemporary, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., while revered by many black people, was a child of the middle class whose measured appeals to white morality and whose integrationist blueprint for change could only go so far, they say. What many young people are seeking in Malcolm X is some reflection of themselves and their own experience as quintessential outsiders. So Malcolm X perseveres as a paradigm for the black underclass, capable of transcending economic frustrations and societal dislocations.
Listen to Omar Jerome, a 17-year-old New Yorker who dropped out of school and works in the City Volunteer Corps as he seeks his general equivalency degree.
"Malcolm X is like every black man," Mr. Jerome said. "He's been through things that every black person has been through -- drugs, poverty, going to jail. We love him because he rose above it all and became a leader."

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
New York Tests a Model: Public Works in Private Hands

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
WHAT do Central Park, the Museum of Natural History, the Triborough Bridge, LaGuardia Airport, the Croton Reservoir and Donald J. Trump's proposed Riverside South project have in common? All were initiated during economic panics or recessions.
What is the singular difference between Riverside South and the rest? They were built with government in a dominant role; Mr. Trump's proposal for the largest tract of developable land in Manhattan represents the privatization of public works to an unparalleled degree. Not only did he agree to create a 21-acre public park and to reserve at least 12 percent of the proposed housing for subsidized apartments, but he also pledged $12 million toward the renovation of two nearby subway stations. 
 But can -- or should -- that model be duplicated as a national priority? In the Presidential campaign, Gov. Bill Clinton, in particular, has invoked New Deal and earlier government investment programs to generate jobs. "To build a 21st century economy," Mr. Clinton says, "America must revive a 19th century habit." But with cities strapped for cash and credit and with their construction budgets largely reserved for overdue repairs, they are understandably inclined to encourage private developers to engage in deficit financing to the degree that local government no longer can. In the bargaining over incentives for developers and concessions for the public, one immediate consequence may well be more mega-projects being privately built. But "project" is not only a noun. The verb, to project, suggests the future. And one consequence of a repeated tactical response to economic development could be government abdication of strategic planning.
"The private sector is responding to infrastructure needs in the absence of government capacity," said Richard A. Kahan, an urban planner who is the chairman of Riverside South and engineered a compromise between the developer and civic groups. "It is the wrong context in which to be negotiating public infrastructure. It's also an excuse not to have a strategic approach."
Arguably, though, government's strategy in this case was to palm off the costs of a park, subway improvements and subsidized housing onto Mr. Trump and other private developers. Riverside South, a proposed $3 billion, 56-acre commercial and residential development on derelict railroad yards on the Upper West Side, was approved unanimously last week by the New York City Planning Commission. If built as planned, it would be the largest single private development in the city's history. The scope would be unique, but not the concept. Predecessors, several times removed, to Mr. Trump's own bold vision have tried it and succeeded. Defying convention and accused of folly, the Rockefellers built a mammoth office center in midtown Manhattan in the Depression. Another Rockefeller vision, the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, revitalized the West Side just east of the Trump tract. And when the city was struggling to extricate itself from the depths of its 1970's fiscal crisis, Mr. Trump himself stepped in and, with a major assist from government -- in contrast with the Rockefeller Center projects -- transformed the faded Commodore Hotel on East 42d Street into a glittering Grand Hyatt that began a revival of the area around Grand Central Terminal.
In the 1980's, the city began spending on construction again -- investing largely in neglected repairs to roads and bridges or in less visible though vast projects like a new water tunnel and a sewage treatment plant. The state's Urban Development Corporation built a new convention center on the West Side and the city invested heavily in renovating low-income housing after the Federal government vacated the field. But a public-private partnership to revitalize West 42d Street was delayed by the recession. And the most ambitious of all public works projects -- the roughly 100-acre Westway development along the Hudson River -- suffered an excruciating death from economic, environmental, legal and political causes.
"I sometimes wonder whether our people, so obsessed with the seamy interior of Manhattan, deserve the Hudson," mused Robert Moses, whose own excesses in bulldozer diplomacy all but transformed the term public works into an oxymoron.
As originally proposed, Mr. Trump's blueprint called for the world's tallest building -- one that would cast a shadow on New Jersey. Concessions to politics and economics shrunk the tower. But the project's implications go well beyond New York in the debate over government's role in reviving the economy.
The last hurdle for Riverside South is the City Council, which is likely to one-up Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, and the City Planning Commission by extracting even more concessions for subway station improvements, affordable housing and park maintenance.
Mr. Trump's creditors have let him shepherd the project through the tortuous government approval process, after which he might divide the site among several developers.
"The property is worth more with the approvals than without," said Henry J. Stern, the president of Citizens Union, the nonpartisan civic group. "The question is, though, will it ever be built?"
Another question is whether government, by default or by design, is ceding the planning process to a constructive alliance of developers and civic groups and whether public functions like building affordable housing, parks and subway stations may become dependent on the dividends of massive private investment. As Riverside South inches through the approval process, another version of economic development will be presented Tuesday to New York State voters: an $800 million bond issue that would reap political profits for the state officials who choose the projects to be underwritten as it generates jobs. In their own way, the two different approaches raise still another question, one represented by Mr. Moses's favorite credo: "If the ends don't justify the means, what does?"

It would be the largest single private development in the city's history. Below, a model of the project. (Skyviews; Wolfgang Hoyt)

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Ideology Wanes for Europe, Leaving Politicians Adrift

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
EUROPE, disoriented by lingering recession and the end of its division into rival blocs, is adrift in an ideological void that is threatening the future of traditional parties in several countries and fueling the political emergence of extremist groups.
Indeed, the dearth of ideas is such that the American Presidential race looks like an exciting clash of ideologues compared with the mishmash that passes for political debate in Europe. Where the French used to mock Americans gently for having scant sense of left and right, now it is Europe's political center that seems drably all-encompassing. 
 "It is far easier to distinguish the views of Bush and Clinton on health, education, taxes and the role of the state than it is to tell the difference between the policies of our Socialist administration and a right-wing government," said Olivier Duhamel, a sociologist. "It's depressing."
France's Socialists, after a brief experiment with nationalizing industry between 1981 and 1983, have paid heavily for becoming the standard-bearers of an economic rigor once associated with the right. They have transformed France into a low-inflation country with a credible currency -- where the national habit of stashing gold under the mattress no longer seems justified -- but they have also allowed unemployment to soar and the gap between rich and poor to widen. As a result, said Marie-Noelle Lienemann, a Socialist who is Minister of Housing, "we have run out of convictions, run out of ideas, and we seem to have nothing new to offer."
President Francois Mitterrand's party, which is in a grim mood about parliamentary elections scheduled for next March, is not alone. Throughout the Continent, traditional parties are floundering to find new ideas that can galvanize people and new principles to distinguish them in a world where the clash of Soviet Communism and Western democracy no longer provides clear lines for their positions.
 
Frustrations Feed the Right
 Their attempt, however, has so far been largely unsuccessful. In Italy, the Christian Democrats, deprived of a formidable Communist opposition and paying for years of corrupt government, are losing ground rapidly to the separatist northern Lega movement. The Lega attacks all traditional parties as thieves and its ideologue, Gianfranco Miglio, last month described Hitler's mistakes as "errors of style." Yet recently it won 33.9 percent of the vote in provincial elections in Mantova and polls show it is supported by over 40 percent of voters in many northern cities.
In Germany, frustration with both the governing Christian Democrats and the main opposition, the Social Democrats, is running high as the nation grapples with the unexpectedly high costs of reunification and a flood of eastern European immigrants. The rightist Republicans have gained strongly, just as the National Front has made headway in France.
"This is a dangerous situation because people are fed up with politics generally," said Otto Schiely, a Social Democratic member of Germany's Parliament. "We, in the big parties, seem unable to provide people with a vision, a perspective, an idea that can inspire them. So at a time of stress, people look for quick solutions and scapegoats and that is what the extremist parties offer."
Several factors appear to have contributed to the vacuum of ideas and blurring of party identities.
The most basic is the implosion of the Soviet bloc. Communism, however discredited, offered an alternative model as well as a threat. Now, traditional parties have apparently been left with the uncomfortable feeling that all they can do is fine-tune an accepted democratic and free-market model, an activity that neither thrills nor inspires voters.
 
Out of Steam
 At the same time, the bolder experiments of both left and right appear to have run out of steam. The left's great postwar push to build the welfare state is essentially a completed task in Western Europe, and the great 1980's wave of enthusiasm for unleashing a more unbridled capitalist spirit has petered out.
The plight of Britain's Conservative Prime Minister, John Major, whose apparent lack of coherence or conviction in economic policy has been conspicuous recently, and the economic troubles of the United States have buttressed a feeling that, in the end, a balance between state and private enterprise offers the best hope for vigorous societies that avoid extremes of inequality and hardship.
The problem, however, is that this central political ground is not only unexciting; it is occupied by parties on both the moderate left and the moderate right. "We want to be efficient but also caring -- a direction which, it's true, the Social Democrats share," said Thomas Jansen, general secretary of the European People's Party, a movement of Christian Democratic parties.
Faced with this blurred center, at a time of recession and hardship, people increasingly turn to alternative movements in disgust. "People wonder if parties have anything to say to them," said Pierre Avril, a French political scientist. "We've tried everything and returned to the middle. Socialism has failed for the left, Reaganite liberalism for the right. So what's left, especially for people who are out of work and angry?"
There are some ideas floating around among the old parties, of course. Mrs. Lienemann, the French Housing Minister, sees socialist and ecological forces proposing what she calls "a new culture" -- perhaps named "Ecosocialism" -- that might, she believes, work for innovations like a 32-hour workweek, more democracy at the workplace, and "a greater stress on quality than quantity in everyday life." In Germany too, the Greens and Social Democrats are looking at ways to cooperate.
Others believe that left and right in Europe do remain fundamentally different on questions like immigration, women's rights, the role of the state and military questions. The essential thing, they argue, is to redefine the identities of left and right as rivals.
There is an opposite temptation, however. In France, some talk of a great movement of the center made up of moderates in both the Socialist and right-wing parties. And some argue that a grand coalition of Christian Democrats and Social Democrats is necessary in Germany to confront the nation's crisis.
While traditional parties work on these problems, the danger of returning political demons remains strong. In the worst case, extremist parties will thrive and in more fragile countries like Italy, a fracturing of the nation may be possible. In a less extreme scenario, traditional parties will be forced, for example, to take on anti-immigrant oratory to hold their appeal.
Meanwhile, having long scoffed at the quality of American political debate, there is suddenly a feeling that Europe needs new ideas from America. "Clinton is looked at with such hope because he seems to have something new to propose at a time when we do not," said Mr. Avril, the political scientist.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Behind Vietnam's Candor: A Fear of Being Isolated

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A Vietnamese-speaking Russian named Irina Zisman is now touring the United States to the applause of Vietnamese-Americans and the consternation of Hanoi. Ms. Zisman recently began a prime-time evening broadcast on Radio Moscow that beams pro-democracy messages to Vietnam through the same powerful Siberian transmitters that once relayed programs on the glories of Communism.
Hanoi's stunned officials have branded the broadcasts subversive, but their protests to Moscow have been unavailing. For them, the experience has been a painful illustration of how the world has changed; it also offers a clue to Hanoi's motives in pledging, after 20 years of obfuscation, to finally reveal what it knows about Americans unaccounted for in Indochina since the war. 
 Without weakening in any way its absolute commitment to Communism, Administration officials say, Vietnam is signaling that it realizes there may never be a better chance to win American diplomatic recognition and unlock international economic assistance that Washington has blocked. Withholding information is no longer a workable policy for Vietnam, which remains disastrously underdeveloped by Asian standards and is now running into trouble with both Moscow and Beijing.
There is also some added reason to move fast. For years the Bush Administration has told Vietnam it could obtain normal relations with the United States in return for cooperation in ending the Cambodian civil war and better accounting for American servicemen missing in Indochina. Now, tantalizingly close to the end of that road, Hanoi cannot be sure that a new Congress or perhaps a Democratic Administration will not revise the road map by raising additional issues of political pluralism and human rights. Such a course is advocated by Vietnamese-American organizations and some politicians in both major parties. And if Bill Clinton wins the Presidency it is far from certain that recognizing Vietnam would get high priority in any event.
Internationally, Vietnam has not only lost its political, economic and military lifelines to the former Soviet bloc, but it has also been thrown into renewed confrontation with China, with the latest friction points being conflicting claims to offshore islands in the South China Sea and the activities of smugglers. "Vietnam has become totally isolated strategically," said Robert S. Ross, an assistant professor of political science at Boston College who has recently returned from five months in China. "The Chinese are now trying to extract Vietnamese humility in many ways."
"It was the Soviets who basically allowed the Vietnamese to defy China," said Mr. Ross, referring to the period in the 1970's when Leonid I. Brezhnev supported Vietnam even at the expense of Soviet-Chinese relations. Mikhail S. Gorbachev reversed the policy, and after the Chinese-Soviet summit meeting in 1989 Vietnam was cut adrift. "It had little alternative but to accommodate itself to Chinese authority," Mr. Ross said.
 
Pressure From U.S. Companies
 Dependence on China did not contribute much to Vietnam's economic development beyond some increased trade, however, and now Bush Administration officials are being pressed by American oil companies and other industries eager to do business with Vietnam. Administration analysts think Hanoi would be receptive, and say they don't believe Hanoi wants to trade dependence on China for dominance by Japan in its search for economic partners. Such a message was apparently transmitted between the lines in recent talks between Vietnam's leaders and an American delegation led by President Bush's special envoy, John W. Vessey Jr.
"There is concern about both Japan and China throughout Southeast Asia," said Evelyn Colbert, former Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for the region. But she said some analysts overestimate how much the fear of China is a motive for Vietnam's developing openness with the United States. She said the Vietnamese "woke up and saw that their economic system wasn't functioning" and may simply have come to realize that to improve their economy they would have to change their relationship with the United States. And that, of course, would have to start with a certain amount of candor about the missing servicemen.
"I like to think that Vietnam's cooperation has something to do with those of us who in one form or another have been telling them over and over and over again, you've got to do something about this issue if you want to get normalization," said Ms. Colbert. "They were told by many people, including their friends, that this demand may be unreasonable, but you have this bad public image because of it."
John McAuliff, executive director of the U.S.-Indochina Reconciliation Project, an organization that has been forging private links to Vietnam, says the Bush Administration has also shown a change of approach, "sending a signal to Vietnam that they are serious about solving the problem without recrimination." In addition, the Senate Select Committee on P.O.W.-M.I.A. Affairs and the Pentagon played a part by narrowing the number of cases on which the Vietnamese could reasonably be expected to provide information.
"This is something the Vietnamese can respond to," Mr. McAuliff said, but he added that Washington must seize the moment too. "We would hope that once the election is over," he said, "whoever is elected could use the interregnum period for responding appropriately to the Vietnamese, to the legitimate pressures from American business and to pressure from our allies to cease using trade and the lending organizations as clubs to hit the Vietnamese for political reasons."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
New Heights in Political Low Blows

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
TELEVISION shows win Emmys, plays receive Tonys and songs get Grammys. Should political ads get Meanies?
Compared to the 1988 Presidential campaign, which gave us such memorable images as Willie Horton, Boston Harbor oozing slime and Michael Dukakis driving a tank, the 1992 race has been something of a disappointment. To be sure, the Bush campaign this weekend is running a commercial that depicts Arkansas as a spooky wasteland, like a scene out of "Pet Sematary." But the old trick of making the opponent's state look like the underworld isn't going to win any prizes for originality. 
 Fortunately for connoisseurs of the attack ad, though, a great deal of creative savagery is to be found this year in the "down ticket" races. In Congressional and Senate campaigns from North Carolina to Washington State, candidates have been enthusiastically accusing one another of robbing the taxpayers blind, cheating innocent children and, yes, even helping Teddy Kennedy.
The envelope, please.
 
Best Put-Down of an Historic Achievement: This goes to Michael DeWine, a former Republican Congressman, who is challenging the former astronaut and current Senator from Ohio, John Glenn.
In an ad titled "Astro," the narrator notes that Mr. Glenn, a Democrat, owns an expensive home on a golf course (sound of a club swinging), flies his personal airplane to Vail (sound of a propeller plane taking off) and sails a 53-foot yacht (sound of seagulls and a fog horn.) Then, in an ominous tone, the narrator says that Mr. Glenn still owes $3 million from his 1984 Presidential campaign. Here, a figure of a toy astronaut, modeled closely on the Energizer bunny, bursts through the screen banging a drum. "John Glenn," the narrator says as the astronaut bangs away. "He just keeps owing and owing and owing . . . "
In response, Glenn's ad notes that by Federal law, Mr. Glenn is forbidden from paying the campaign debt with his own money. "So what DeWine is asking Glenn to do is against the law," the narrator intones, "not an unusual request from DeWine, a former Congressman who saw nothing wrong with bouncing thousands of dollars of bad checks at the House bank."

Most Brazen Exploitation of a Mistake: New York's Republican Senator, Alfonse M. D'Amato.
Flustered by heckling from Mr. D'Amato's supporters, his opponent, Bob Abrams, called the Senator a "fascist." Mr. Abrams, the state's Democratic Attorney General, later apologized. But Mr. D'Amato and his ad team had gone right for the archival footage and put together a television ad featuring Mussolini himself.
"There is simply no excuse for Bob Abrams's pandering to religious and ethnic fears and hatreds," the narrator says, while the Italian dictator waves his arms on the screen.

For Putting Women and Children First: Representative Newt Gingrich, and his opponent in Georgia's Sixth Congressional District, Tony Center, tie for this award.
Admittedly, Mr. Gingrich, a seven-term Republican, had the edge for a while when he began broadcasting television commercials that accused Mr. Center, a Democrat and a malpractice attorney, of trying to starve two young children.
"Center actually sued to strip a 4-year-old and a 1-year-old of their child support to pay his own legal fee," the ad says. "He even claimed his fee mattered more than the children's food, medicine and shelter."
But Mr. Center evened the score with a radio ad:
"Newt's running an ad that claims Tony Center thought his legal fees mattered more than children's food," the ad says. "C'mon, look who's talking. It was Newt Gingrich who delivered divorce papers to his wife the day after her cancer operation."

Most Thoughtful Get-Well Wishes: This one goes to Lauch (pronounced LOCK) Faircloth, who is running against Senator Terry Sanford, the 75-year-old Democrat of North Carolina.
After Mr. Sanford went into the hospital to have a heart valve replaced, Mr. Faircloth, a Democrat-recently-turned-Republican, broadcast ads wishing him "a complete recovery" and, in the process, of course, reminding voters of the Senator's ill health.
More recently, Mr. Faircloth has been airing commercials that accuse Mr. Sanford of sanctioning the worst kind of government spending -- that which benefits liberal states like Massachusetts. "Terry Sanford," one ad says, "even voted to spend a billion dollars on Ted Kennedy's Boston Harbor Tunnel!"

For the Kind of Trick Photography Ross Perot Warned You About: To Patty Murray, a Democratic state senator and candidate for U.S. Senate in Washington State.
Three weeks ago, Ms. Murray's opponent, Rod Chandler, a Republican Congressman, began broadcasting an ad that accused her of supporting policies that would cost the state more than 120,000 jobs. "Patty Murray on jobs?" the ad concluded. "Risky."
The figures in the ad may have been exaggerated, but polls showed it was working. To get even, the Murray campaign sent a crew to get film of Mr. Chandler. A cameraman approached Mr. Chandler after a campaign stop and asked if he would pose shaking a voter's hand. The Congressman, not knowing how the cameraman was employed, obliged. Then, using computer video technology, the Murray campaign replaced the voter with a sackful of money.
"What's Rod Chandler done to help Washington's economy?" the narrator of the ad asks as Mr. Chandler reaches for the bag of money. "While job loss rose 38 percent, Rod Chandler was paid 800 grand and passed only one bill in 10 years. How's Rod Chandler done? Good for him; bad for us."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats -- As Presidential Race Nears End, the Attacks Continue;
Clinton Charges Bush Appeals to Prejudice

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BROWN DEER, Wis., Oct. 31

 BODY:
In a last-minute visit to one of the most closely contested regions, Gov. Bill Clinton today challenged President Bush's hold on the South by accusing him of appealing to regional prejudice with a message that changes as the President moves around the country.
"In one state he says I'm too liberal," Mr. Clinton said at a rally in Decatur, Ga. "In another state he says I'm a backwater redneck." 
 Mr. Clinton was helped by several Georgia officials in his attempt to depict Mr. Bush as a man who ridicules residents of the Southeastern states that voted solidly for him in 1988. Mr. Clinton accused his Republican opponent of "trying to perform reverse plastic surgery" by tailoring his portraits of Mr. Clinton and his running mate, Senator Al Gore, to local prejudices.
 
Choosing Regional References
 "Mr. Bush bad-mouths me as being from a small southern state," Mr. Clinton said. "That's only when they're in the North. In the South, when they campaign, they try to convince you that Gore and Clinton are these radical people who have no values like yours and we're going to trample everything Americans hold dear. They're trying to perform reverse plastic surgery in both parts of the country."
He again asserted that Mr. Bush cannot be trusted to salvage the nation's economy, choosing the regional references -- complete with a mention of the Civil War -- that flow so easily when he returns to his native South.
"Now Bush says, 'Trust me to revive the economy.' That's like hiring General Sherman for fire commissioner in Georgia," Mr. Clinton said.
Mr. Bush created the opening for today's riposte by ridiculing Mr. Clinton's state recently as one of the most backward states in the nation, continuing an attack from the the debates, when he termed Arkansas "lowest of the low."
"How dumb does he think we are? " Gov. Zell Miller of Georgia asked.
 
Georgia Is Point of Pride
 Mr. Clinton's aides said they had returned to Georgia today in part because winning the state has become a point of personal pride for the candidate and his strategists. Winning Georgia from George Bush, one Clinton aide said, would be a "straight steal from his base."
The Clinton campaign's biggest fight remains in the North, where he has been spending considerable time working New Jersey, Ohio and Michigan. He is considered to be comfortably ahead in another crucial state, Illinois, and recent polls have shown Mr. Clinton running even with Mr. Bush in crucial states like Texas and Florida.
Dee Dee Myers, the campaign press secretary, said Mr. Clinton had come to Iowa because Republicans had been concentrating some of their negative advertising on the state. And here in Wisconsin, where the President is traveling by train this weekend, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Bush are engaged in the political equivalent of hand-to-hand combat for votes.
Mr. Clinton shook hands in a freezing rain in East Davenport, Iowa, this afternoon, thanking his supporters for withstanding the weather. "Look at it this way," he said. "You've only got two or three more days of trickle-down economics to wait through."
 
'Won't Get Much Sleep'
 Mr. Clinton returns to Ohio and New Jersey tomorrow before undertaking a grueling, 24-hour final campaign day through nine states on the day before the election. Appearing at a rally in the latest of several visits to Michigan late on Friday night, he told supporters that he felt like an Arkansan who had been transplanted to the state.
"Between now and then, I won't get much sleep," Mr. Clinton said cheerfully today, looking forward to Election Day.
Mr. Clinton will stage his largest campaign finale at the Brendan Byrne Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., on Sunday night with a rally televised by satellite. The rally is scheduled to feature appearances by musical guests and supporters, including Bon Jovi and Michael Bolton and the comedian Dana Carvey.
Mr. Clinton's running mate, Senator Al Gore, offered a glimpse of the Democratic campaign's approach in the final days when he spoke in Georgia and Tennessee this morning.
At a rally at the Chattanooga Airport, Mr. Gore promised that if elected the Democrats would create "a government of national unity" to break the deadlock in Washington and get a program enacted quickly. "We are determined to put partisanship aside," he said.
A senior campaign aide said the Democrats would try to attract Republicans and Perot supporters by talking of a broad political coalition to back their proposals. "The idea is, close the sale by appealing to the voters' better sides and by giving them a clearer idea of what they are buying," said one official.
Strolling through a pancake house in Decatur this morning, Mr. Clinton was asked by one patron whether he was getting nervous about the outcome of Tuesday's voting.
"Little bit," Mr. Clinton responded. "But I got to just keep working. My view is that nervousness is a form of energy that I've got to channel and just keep on going."
If Mr. Clinton's nervousness is demonstrated by his frenetic travel schedule, strategists in his Little Rock, Ark., campaign headquarters have been excising excess energy in other ways. On Friday, the campaign's communications director, George Stephanopoulos, called the "Larry King Live" television program to chide President Bush for his statements on his role in trading arms for hostages in 1986.
Mr. Stephanopoulos read a transcript of his televised remarks to Mr. Clinton in a telephone conversation this morning. The Governor laughed, he said.
And this evening, at a "town meeting" in this Milwaukee suburb that was televised statewide in Wisconsin, Mr. Clinton himself pressed the issue, taking the President to task for his role in the arms-for-hostages swap when Mr. Bush was Vice President.
He rejected Mr. Bush's claim that the new indictment of former defense secretary Caspar Weinberger was based on old information that proved nothing new about the President's participation.
"It's very new, and it's very hot," he said.
"Everywhere Bush goes, he is going to get asked about it," said James Carville, a senior Clinton strategist. "The story is big enough to carry on by itself."
Mr. Clinton asserted today that the Republicans' corresponding attacks on his record in Arkansas and his trustworthiness "don't amount to a hill of beans," adding, "The real thing that matters is not our yesterdays, but our tomorrows."
But in answering a question from a member of the studio audience in Wisconsin today, Mr. Clinton conceded that he should have been more forthcoming earlier this year when he was asked to explain efforts he took to avoid the military draft.
"I must say I was shocked and disoriented, and I didn't do a very good job at answering all of those questions about what I did 23 years ago," Mr. Clinton said.

"In one state he says I'm too liberal," the Democratic nominee said to a crowd. "In another state he says I'm a backwater redneck." (Lee Romero/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Five U.S. Nuns Are Shot to Death While Trapped by Liberian War

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
Five American nuns, trapped in the heaviest siege of Liberia's three-year-old civil war, have been shot to death near their convent on the outskirts of Monrovia, the capital's Roman Catholic Archbishop said yesterday. Four Liberian novices were also reported slain.
L'Osservatore Romano, the semiofficial Vatican newspaper, reported the deaths of the novices, but there was no more information about them from Liberia. 
 The nine slayings were by far the worst atrocity involving missionaries in a war that has left tens of thousands of civilians dead and has virtually destroyed the economy and all semblance of normal life in the West African nation of 2.6 million people.
From Washington to the Vatican, outrage was expressed over the killings, which focused international attention on a little-understood war that pits Charles Taylor, a 44-year-old guerrilla whose rebel forces have seized most of the nation, against two rival militias and a consortium of troops from seven West African nations, which are defending their last stronghold in Monrovia.
Civilians trapped in and around the capital have been caught under a rain of missiles, rockets, mortars and shells said the slain nuns' parish priest, who just returned to the United States from Monrovia. Yesterday, he told of dodging bullets, of house-to-house fighting, of guerrillas as young as 11 years old, of atrocities and murders and of his last glimpse of the nuns, whom he has known for years.
 
Worked in Clinics and Schools
 In Monrovia, Archbishop Michael Francis said the American nuns -- who were in their 50's and 60's, worked in clinics and schools and lived in a convent at Gardnersville, on the eastern edge of the capital -- had been stranded and shot to death in an area overrun by Mr. Taylor's National Patriotic Front of Liberia, which began the latest siege of Monrovia on Oct. 15.
Archbishop Francis did not say the nuns had been slain by rebel guerrillas, but he said "only Taylor's men were in the area" when the killings occurred, apparently in the last few days. He said three were shot in front of their convent and two on a nearby road. Some reports yesterday said the bodies still lay where they had fallen because it was too dangerous to recover them.
"The deaths are confirmed -- it is absolutely certain, but it is too dangerous to identify the source," the Archbishop told Reuters and The Associated Press at his home in Monrovia. "Their services were humanitarian, charitable and a complete commitment to the people of Liberia. They paid the supreme sacrifice as their whole work was a symphony of love."
The Archbishop condemned the killers as "people who want power and wealth and will do everything to gain it, even killing innocent people." And referring to the nuns, all members of the Adorers of the Blood of Christ, sometimes called the Order of the Precious Blood, he said, "To see them brutally murdered, one wonders what is the sense in all this killing."
In Washington, the State Department said the United States was "shocked and appalled" and condemned "this cowardly act." It declared, "The fact that these women had no role in Liberia's civil war and were in the country to work with orphaned children and other victims of the conflict makes the killings all the more repugnant."
The State Department, which has urged Americans to leave and defer travel to Liberia since the latest fighting began, expressed deep concern for the safety of expatriates caught in the fighting and said the deaths underscored the need for a cease-fire and negotiations to end the civil war.
Sister Mildred Gross, mother superior of the Adorers of the Blood of Christ Convent in Ruma, Ill., 30 miles southeast of St. Louis, near the Missouri border, identified the five victims, all from Illinois, as Sister Barbara Ann Muttra, 69, of Springfield; Sister Joel Kolmer, 58, of Waterloo; Sister Joel's cousin, Sister Shirley Kolmer, 61, also of Waterloo; Sister Kathleen McGuire, 54, of Ridgeway, and Sister Agnes Mueller, 62, of Bethalto.
 
'Really Dedicated Women'
 "They were really dedicated women," Sister Mildred said of the victims. "We were 246, now we're 241," she said, referring to the convent's membership in an international order that numbers more than 2,300 nuns, most of them in Europe.
In another interview, the Rev. James C. Hickey, an Irish-born missionary who is the parish priest of the slain nuns at St. Anthony's in Gardnersville, said yesterday that he left Monrovia on Oct. 22 as the fighting grew heavy and had just returned to the Tenafly, N.J., headquarters of his order, the Society of Missionaries to Africa.
Father Hickey said the five nuns lived at a convent about a mile from St. Anthony's Church and had been missing for 10 days amid the raging gun battles that have engulfed Monrovia.
He said he last saw Sister Agnes, a nurse who worked at a church-operated clinic next to St. Anthony's and had been in Liberia about four years, and Sister Shirley, the principal of St. Patrick's High School in Monrovia who had been in Liberia for a decade, at a Mass he celebrated on Oct. 21.
He said Sister Kathleen, a teacher, counselor and assistant to Sister Shirley at St. Patrick's High School, had not appeared that day because she had been sick and stayed in the convent.
 
The Day They Disappeared
 He said Sister Barbara Ann, a nurse who had been in Liberia for eight years and operated a clinic in Klay, 15 miles west of Monrovia, and Sister Joel, who went to Liberia in 1986 and was a teacher and manager of St. Michael's Elementary and High School in Gardnersville, went to his home on Oct. 20 to see him, but he was out attending to refugee work, and they left.
"After they left my house, they went down Barnardsville Road, where they were last seen by some Liberian civilians," he said. "They were in their car. They disappeared that day."
In Liberia, where the battle for Monrovia continued to rage yesterday, a spokesman for Mr. Taylor, John Richardson, denied that rebels had killed the nuns. "I can assure you those nuns were never in our area," he told the BBC.
The statement contradicted one made Friday by Mr. Taylor. In response to mounting concern over the fate of the missing nuns, Mr. Taylor denied that they were prisoners of his forces, but he said he believed they were alive and staying with stranded orphans and other refugees in Chocolate City, an eastern suburb of Monrovia that fell under rebel control 10 days ago.
Under a truce worked out by the United States Embassy, United Nations officials and Mr. Taylor, the rebels sent three buses into Gardnersville and Chocolate City to pick up hundreds of orphans trapped in the fighting. Mr. Taylor said he would brave enemy bombardments and personally try to rescue the nuns, but church officials said the assurances were probably given after news of the killings had reached Mr. Taylor's inland headquarters at Gbarnga.
Like other factions in an often-grisly conflict, guerrilla fighters of the National Patriotic Front of Liberia have been accused of appalling atrocities. Civilians, including missionaries and relief workers, have told of beatings, detentions and other harassment, and hundreds of civilians have been killed in crossfires, but there had been no previous reports of civilians' being murdered by combatants.
Liberia, a nation founded by freed American slaves in the early 1800's, was declared a republic in 1847 and its population is largely made up of 16 tribal groups. Its modern history has been marked by pervasive corruption. Master Sgt. Samuel Doe led a coup in 1980, made himself President and pledged to eliminate corruption, but was soon accused of enriching himself.
Mr. Taylor, who attended college near Boston and had helped organize Liberians in the United States against the toppled President, William R. Tolbert Jr., returned to Liberia in 1980 to join Mr. Doe's leadership. But after a falling out with Mr. Doe, he fled to the United States. Liberia sought his extradition on charges that he stole $900,000 in government funds and a Boston court ordered him detained.
In 1985, awaiting extradition, he broke out of jail and vanished for five years. In December 1989, Mr. Taylor and 100 guerrillas invaded northern Liberia from the Ivory Coast. His insurgency gained momentum, even splitting into rival factions. Prince Johnson, the head of one faction, captured, tortured and killed President Doe.
A multinational West African force then intervened, saying the civil war was no longer an internal conflict because thousands of citizens of other countries were trapped in Liberia. As the fighting continued, nearly half of Liberia's people were uprooted, more than 20,000 people have been killed, the economy has all but collapsed and, as the conflict has homed in on Monrovia, chaos has engulfed the capital.
Nearly 95 percent of Liberia is under the control of Mr. Taylor's forces and Monrovia is on its knees. Were it not for the efforts of the United Nations, the Catholic Relief Services and other foreign aid agencies, there would be no electricity, running water or food for its 500,000 residents.

PUB-DATE: November 1, 1992

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1185 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans -- As Presidential Race Nears End, the Attacks Continue;
Bush Calls Rival Untrustworthy and Untried

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OSHKOSH, Wis., Oct. 31

 BODY:
Taking a strategic turn in his campaign's final hours, President Bush today used an attack on his honesty by Gov. Bill Clinton as occasion to mount his sharpest assault yet on his rival's fitness for office.
Before 11,000 backers huddled under dreary skies here, the President denounced Mr. Clinton for accusing him of repeatedly lying about his knowledge of the 1986 Iran arms-for-hostages affair. 
 "He's afraid," Mr. Bush said of Mr. Clinton. "He's afraid for the power that he's lusted for, the political viability that he wrote about when he was demonstrating against this country over in England. And he has basically called me a liar."
 
A Two-Faced Pumpkin
 As the crowd cheered, Mr. Bush added: "You want to talk character, Governor? You and Ozone want to talk character? All right, here we go."
With that, the President unleashed a scorching recital of what he called Mr. Clinton's deceptions and reversals on seven issues, including his draft history, his use of marijuana and his positions on free trade, right-to-work laws and the Persian Gulf war.
"The pumpkin in the Arkansas Governor's mansion has two faces," Mr. Bush said, laughing with evident relish in his attack. "Whatever side you're on, he's right there. You can't do that as President of the United States."
 
Calls Rival Untested
 The President's assault came on the third stop in an 18-car passenger-train junket by his campaign through five rural Wisconsin towns. It was a day-long event intended to project a televised image of confidence and momentum for a re-election bid that still trails Mr. Clinton -- by how much, no one now knows -- with but three days to catch up.
When he paused, in small towns like Burlington, Sussex and Stevens Point, it was to attack Mr. Clinton's economic positions and his character, ending with a Halloween scenario for undecided voters.
Talking about his own role in dealing with the collapse of the Soviet Union and reducing nuclear arms, Mr. Bush suggested that a year from now voters might pick up a newspaper and read of a new crisis, like one set off by a nuclear-armed terrorist.
"Close your eyes and imagine, in a crisis situation, an American leader totally without experience, completely untested, a leader about whom we know very, very little, if you get down to it," he said in Sussex. "And what we do know is a troubling pattern of being on one side and then another, an ingrained habit of trying to lead by misleading and not coming clean. And I don't believe we can take this kind of risk."
Mr. Bush's role in the Iran-contra affair came under renewed focus Friday, when Federal prosecutors released a document suggesting that Mr. Bush has concealed the depth of his knowledge about the arms-for-hostages deals with Iran.
On Friday, Mr. Clinton used the disclosure to try to throw the question of honesty and character, which the President has relentlessly raised about him, back at Mr. Bush. "He has seriously called into question those issues and now has to answer your questions on all," Mr. Clinton said.
Today, Mr. Bush's advisers cast the President's strong counterattack as a strategic victory for the White House, but that was far from clear. By raising the question of his role in the Iran arms-for-hostages deal, even to decry those questions as part of a "Democrat-run" witchhunt, Mr. Bush risked appearing defensive and risked prolonging news coverage of a six-year-old scandal that has already eaten up one of his last four days of campaigning.
"The charges he makes are not new," Mr. Bush said. "I have responded to them repeatedly and under oath, under oath, in numerous investigations in a six-year, Democrat-run political fiasco that has cost the taxpayers $40 million."
 
'Called Ugly by a Frog'
 Mr. Bush called Mr. Clinton's accusations "a desperate attempt to stop his free-fall in the polls," and added: "I welcome this spotlight on character, because it is an essential test of the Presidency."
Whatever the risks of prolonging the issue, Bush aides appear to have concluded that they are better off battling Mr. Clinton on character than on any other ground. They appeared determined to exploit their opening, even at the prospect of making a nasty campaign even more venomous.
The President underscored that in his most pointed remark about Mr. Clinton at the Oshkosh rally.
"Being attacked on character by Governor Clinton," he said, "is like being called ugly by a frog."
Vice President Dan Quayle joined in the attack on Mr. Clinton's character, telling a Bush-Quayle rally in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, today that the Democrat had covered up his attempts to evade military service. The Vice President, nearing the end of a nine-day swing through the West and the Plains states, added a stop in Chicago at the last minute.
Mr. Quayle said there was "new evidence" that Mr. Clinton had some friends remove his Reserve Officer Training Corps file from the University of Arkansas before his first run for public office. "This is just another part of Bill Clinton's pattern of deception in the interests of preserving his political viability in Arkansas and elsewhere," the Vice President said.
 
Counting on Experience
 Some aides said this week that Mr. Bush stands to win in any battle over character, because most of the President's detractors have already quit his camp, while much of Mr. Clinton's support -- a fifth or more, by Bush estimates -- remains weak.
They also believe that their experience in campaign endgames stands them well against Mr. Clinton's advisers.
"He's been in three of these things," Mr. Bush's campaign chairman, Robert M. Teeter, said of his candidate's presidential campaign experience. "This is their first."
 
Quoting Favorite Democrat
 With only 11 electoral votes to offer, Mr. Bush's daylong stop here seemed to defy conventional tactics that place trailing candidates in bigger states. But Mr. Bush's aides appear to feel that the novelty of his train trip guarantees colorful national coverage regardless of the locale.
Mr. Bush's five-town tour traced a path northward along Lake Michigan and then west toward Minneapolis, aiming to recreate the barnstorm aura of a Southern train trip three weeks ago that invigorated Mr. Bush's lagging campaign.
At many stops the President has taken again to quoting Harry S. Truman, the Democratic model for his Republican comeback effort. His aides continue to express confidence that the gap with Mr. Clinton is narrowing, even as some polls suggest that the Democrat's lead has stabilized.
Unlike the Southern swing, launched under bright sun and cheering throngs, today's trip began in subdued, even surreal fashion amid slate-gray skies. And because Wisconsin is nominally Democratic and irascibly independent, unlike the Republican South, the President faced a visibly more skeptical reception here.
Fighting a minor cold, he struggled to rouse a crowd of about 12,000 shivering listeners in Burlington, where he began his trip.
Under a Clinton Presidency, he said, "every day is going to be a Halloween, fright and terror."
