HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Overview;
Polls Say Clinton Keeps Lead Despite Furious G.O.P. Fire

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton and President Bush battled through a final weekend of campaigning with the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll showing that their furious weeklong crossfire had left Mr. Clinton still holding a lead.
The new poll, conducted Tuesday through Friday, also showed that Ross Perot remained a distant third, and that about a third of his supporters said it was possible they would change their minds before Election Day. 
 Despite a fierce Republican assault last week on Mr. Clinton's trustworthiness, his record in Arkansas and his economic policies, Mr. Bush has not succeeded in raising his own support, according to the poll.
The survey showed Mr. Clinton with the backing of 43 percent of the probable electorate, Mr. Bush with 34 percent and Mr. Perot with 15 percent. A week ago, Mr. Clinton stood at 40 percent, Mr. Bush at 35 percent and Mr. Perot at 15 percent.
 
Other Poll Results
 Other polls this weekend showed a far tighter race, with ABC News and USA Today/CNN surveys showing a three-point Clinton margin. Some of the differences in the polls occur because of the way each organization identifies which voters are likely to vote.
The Times/CBS poll showed Mr. Clinton with a strong lead in the Northeast and the West and a smaller edge in the Midwest; separate statewide polls released today in Ohio and Wisconsin reflected an especially tight race there. Mr. Bush gained ground in the South last week, but was still running neck and neck there with Mr. Clinton.
A look at the electoral map suggests that a Bush victory may still be possible, but even his own strategists acknowledge that it would require a wave of last-minute decisions and lucky breaks that would deliver to him a string of states that are now closely contested.
On the other hand, an edge in the popular vote of the kind Mr. CLinton is showing in the latest Times/CBS News poll translates into a daunting advantage in the Electoral College.
The Bush strategy, in these final days, requires a solid South, the restoration of most of the Rocky Mountain West, and then last-minute swings toward the Republicans in a belt of industrial states: Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Ohio, Michigan and Wisconsin.
"If I'm sure of two things in this, it's that we're still going to get a lot of late decision-making, and that people are still very uncomfortable with the idea of Clinton in the White House," said Robert M. Teeter, chairman of the Bush campaign.
But Mr. Clinton's advisers said they were confident that their dominance of the electoral map remained unshaken on this final weekend. "I feel satisfied that we're in a good position," said Mickey Kantor, chairman of the Clinton campaign. "I would not switch places with the other two."
Democratic strategists noted that important parts of Mr. Bush's base in the South, including Georgia, Texas and North Carolina, remained hotly competitive, while Mr. Clinton's base on the West and East Coasts remained secure. Parts of the Midwest, notably Ohio and Wisconsin, are tightening, Clinton strategists acknowledge, but they asserted that the bulk of the region remains solidly in their column.
Mr. Perot, for his part, appears to have paid a considerable price for a week of controversy prompted by his accusations on Sunday that Republicans plotted to disrupt his daughter's wedding and wiretap his office. The proportion of people who view the Texas businessman unfavorably jumped from 32 percent to 41 percent in the last week.
His level of support, after jumping during the Presidential debates and his first wave of television advertising, remains flat, and his supporters are twice as likely as Bush or Clinton supporters to say they might change their minds. The survey also found that 67 percent rejected his assertion that he left the race last July to protect his daughter from Republican dirty tricks.
The normal jitters of a closing Presidential campaign have been intensified by the wide range of poll findings in recent days, with Clinton leads ranging from 10 points to 2. Among the many variables in these final days is the level of turnout, particularly the turnout among young voters, who Clinton strategists say are an important source of their support..
In an interview on Friday, the Rev. Jesse Jackson also predicted a high turnout among minorities. "I think it's going to be very high," said Mr. Jackson, who has been touring the country trying to get out the Democratic vote. "Our objective interests are at stake."
The Times/CBS poll was conducted Tuesday through Friday, and was based on interviews with 1,912 registered voters. The final two days of the polling did hint at some possible tightening; Mr. Clinton's lead in the Thursday and Friday polling was eight points among the probable electorate, and seven points among all registered voters.
The poll also indicated that voters were taking their decision very seriously: 74 percent said they believed this election was more important than previous Presidential elections. And half of them said they believed that there was more discussion of the issues this year than there was in 1988.
Notwithstanding the national polls, the race for the Presidency at this point revolves around one number: 270, the electoral votes necessary to win. Even if Mr. Bush now has the momentum that his advisers claim, he faces a formidable challenge in reaching that number in these final days, based on interviews with political professionals and statewide polls around the country.
 
The South
Many Places Too Close to Call
 Mr. Bush's hopes of assembling an Electoral College majority are based on carrying the South, and thus overcoming the appeal of two favorite sons. By the week's end, many political professionals believed that Mr. Bush had turned a corner in Florida, with 25 electoral votes. But Texas, the other mega-state in the region, was still considered a fiercely competitive contest.
Mr. Bush was scheduled for a final, pre-election appeal to his adopted state at a rally in Houston on Monday night; his advisers acknowledge that there is virtually no way Mr. Bush can prevail without winning this state.
A Mason-Dixon poll released this week, with a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points, showed Mr. Bush at 43 percent, Mr. Clinton at 35 percent and Mr. Perot at 15 percent. But Clinton officials asserted that their private polls in the last few days showed a much closer race, and that Mr. Perot's presence in the race is helping them keep it that way.
Elsewhere in the region, Mr. Bush is thought to be strongest in Mississippi, Alabama and South Carolina. Georgians in both parties say the race in their state is tightening, although the most recent newspaper polls showed a Clinton lead. Polls in North Carolina also show a close race, although with Mr. Clinton retaining a slim lead, and Louisiana is considered a tossup. Whatever the final outcome, Mr. Clinton has forced Mr. Bush to battle for a region that seemed reliably Republican for a generation.
 
The Midwest
Key Region Grows More Competitive
 This is the region, many analysts say, where the election will be decided: in the states of Michigan, Illinois, Wisconsin and Ohio, which account for 72 electoral votes. For most of the fall it was Clinton territory, but the race has grown closer in much of this region in the final days. Clinton strategists see it as the normal tightening of the endgame that will not affect their dominance of the region; Bush strategists contend that it is the beginning of a vast swing toward the President.
Mr. Clinton has kept a strong anchor in Illinois, according to the new Chicago Tribune Poll released this weekend, which showed the Democrat with a 17-point margin in the state. Gary LaPaille, chairman of the Illinois Democratic Party, said party officials were concerned about a week ago because of the resurgence of Mr. Perot, but added, "When Perot unloaded Sunday with the wacky reason about why he got out of the race, his support started to level off."
Mr. Bush's challenge is to break Mr. Clinton's hold on the remaining battleground states in the region; Ohio, with a strong Republican tradition, looks the most promising. "Let's just say we're feeling better and better all the time," said Douglas Preiss, executive director of Ohio's Bush campaign.
A poll for the Akron Beacon-Journal, WJW-TV and WHIO-TV showed a tight race this weekend; with voters leaning toward a candidate included, the poll showed Mr. Clinton with 42 percent, Mr. Bush with 36 percent and Mr. Perot with 18 percent. The sampling error was plus or minus four percentage points.
In Wisconsin, campaign officials for all three candidates agree that the race is increasingly competitive, which explains why both Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton were campaigning there today. A poll this weekend for The Milwaukee Journal showed that the race was a statistical dead heat.
But in Michigan, a Detroit News Poll conducted Monday through Wednesday gave Mr. Clinton a 10-point lead. The Bush campaign's chairman, Mr. Teeter, responded, "Baloney."
 
The East
Bush Needs Gains Here
 The important swing states in this region are Pennsylvania (23 electoral votes) and New Jersey ( 15); again, Mr. Bush's hopes for a comeback depend on whether he can wrest one of these states from the Democrats.
A poll for The Philadelphia Daily News, conducted Saturday through Tuesday, showed Mr. Clinton at 38 percent, Mr. Bush at 28 percent, and Mr. Perot at 15 percent, with a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points. State Senator J. William Lincoln, chairman of the state Democratic Committee, asserted that "Clinton will win this state by 300,000 votes." But his counterpart, Chris Bravacos, executive director of the Republican state committee, asserted that "things have really just caught fire" for Mr. Bush in the last few days.
In New Jersey, a poll by the Eagleton Institute released today showed Mr. Clinton retaining a clear lead. Among registered voters, Mr. Clinton stood at 42 percent, Mr. Bush at 30 percent and Mr. Perot at 18 percent. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points. Both candidates plan a final swing through the state before Election Day, illustrating its importance.
New York, the biggest block of electoral votes in the region, is considered solid for Mr. Clinton.
 
The West
California Stays In Clinton's Camp
 Mr. Clinton retains a solid lead in California, the biggest prize on Election Day, according to the most recent Field Poll. The Rocky Mountain West, ordinarily a Republican stronghold, remained in a state of flux in the last few days, in part because of the tumultuous candidacy of Mr. Perot.
Stan Greenberg, the poll taker for Mr. Clinton, said much of the region was moving toward the Democrats in the last few days. "The West as a whole looks very, very fertile," he said. In Colorado, a new poll for the Denver Post this weekend showed Mr. Clinton with a clear margin there.
Even in Wyoming, which Mr. Bush carried with 61 percent of the vote in 1988, a poll released Friday by the University of Wyoming showed Mr. Clinton and Mr. Bush in a close race.
If Mr. Greenberg is correct -- and Mr. Teeter disputes his analysis -- then Mr. Bush's scenario for 270 electoral votes is in serious trouble.
 
 
 
HOW THE POLL WAS CONDUCTED
 The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Tuesday through Friday with 2,374 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii, of whom 1,912 said they were registered voters.
The samples were organized so that results could be examined for all four days combined, or separately for the first two days and the last two days.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen to insure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the poll.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education. In addition, the results for Tuesday and Wednesday were weighted by party identification because of an unusual imbalance in party identification among respondents interviewed on those two days.
Some findings related to voting are reported in terms of an overall "probable electorate," which uses responses to questions dealing with voter registration, attention paid to the campaign, voting history in past elections, and professed likelihood of voting in 1992 as a measure of the probability of particular respondents' voting next Tuesday. No registered voter's preferences were excluded, but they were given different weights.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than a few percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all adults in the country. For results based on all four days, the potential sampling error is plus or minus two percentage points; for results based on either two-day period separately, it is three percentage points.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for results based on registered voters who called themselves independents during the four days of interviewing it is plus or minus four percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Differences in the wording and order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat varying results.
In a poll conducted just before an election, like this one, there are additional potential difficulties, like dramatic events or campaign appeals made by the candidates between the interviewing and Election Day, unusual patterns of voter turnout, and the ultimate decisions made by those voters who said they were undecided or might change their mind at the time of the poll.

HEADLINE: Ferraro Gets An Apology From Abrams

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD

 BODY:
Ending weeks of behind-the-scenes negotiations with an apology and effusive praise, Robert Abrams said yesterday that he felt "genuine regret" for the tone of the recent Democratic primary battle against Geraldine A. Ferraro, and that "allegations and insinuations" about her links to organized crime "were unfortunate and inaccurate."
Mr. Abrams, who is challenging Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato in Tuesday's election, lauded his former rival Ms. Ferraro as an "outstanding leader" and a "pioneer for women," and he recalled that he was "proud to support her in her quest for the Vice Presidency" in 1984. 
 His dramatic statement came just three days before the election and after seven weeks of intense negotiations over what form of apology Mr. Abrams might provide to win over his still-bitter rival. His comments were released in tandem with a television advertisement featuring his defeated primary opponent announcing her support for Mr. Abrams, the State Attorney General, in the Senate race.
In the 30-second spot, Ms. Ferraro, looking drawn and somber, criticizes Senator D'Amato for working against abortion rights, "even in cases of rape and incest," and for "supporting the Bush economic policies that have devastated New York State."
Facing the camera and speaking in a monotone, she concludes by telling viewers: "I am not in this race any longer, but there's one candidate I support because he is right on the issues. That's Bob Abrams."
The Abrams campaign team was quick to embrace the advertisement as a turning point in the campaign. "It's great," said Ethan Geto, Mr. Abrams's campaign director. "It's a great day. We're happy."
Mr. D'Amato was just as quick to play down the impact of the late endorsement, telling reporters in Albany yesterday that the matter was an intraparty affair. "Geraldine Ferraro is a Democrat," he said, and he described her endorsement as "without enthusiasm" and "at the last minute."
But Mr. Geto said the Abrams campaign was "thrilled and delighted" with the spot and that Ms. Ferraro's stern demeanor "was the tone and tenor that we wanted, and I think Gerry felt the same way."
Ms. Ferraro could not be reached for comment yesterday.
Polls show that Senator D'Amato has picked up about one-third of Ms. Ferraro's former supporters, including Italian-Americans upset with the attacks on Ms. Ferraro during the primary. The difficult peace between Mr. Abrams and Ms. Ferraro was achieved after a final round of prodding from Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and other prominent Democrats and after Ms. Ferraro had faced repeated questions about her reluctance to endorse Mr. Abrams.
Mayor David N. Dinkins, appearing yesterday with the Attorney General at a rally in Washington Heights and at a Bronx luncheon for about 700 Democratic women, said he believes the Ferraro endorsement will give the Abrams campaign a clear lift in the last days of the race. "It'll help him a great deal," he said. "Geraldine Ferraro is very popular, and a tremendous segment of the vote in the state of New York consists of Italian-Americans. I think she'll help a lot."
Not everyone was so convinced. During Mr. Abrams's several stops yesterday, several people said the Ferraro advertisement would not sway their vote at all, and one woman who attended the Bronx luncheon said she had "serious questions" about the campaign and could not back Mr. Abrams. "Ferraro was my favorite," said the woman, who refused to give her name. "Since she's no longer in the race, I'm thinking of voting for D'Amato."
Mr. Abrams's statement yesterday, in a direct reference to Ms. Ferraro's longstanding complaint that the allegations aired in the primary amounted to a broad ethnic slander of Italian-Americans, said he would be working with her after the election to "raise sensitivities about ethnic stereotyping." Ms. Ferraro's statement also said she intends to pursue that issue after Nov. 3, "both with the Democratic National Committee and the new administration."
But lingering tensions between the two seemed clear. They did not meet for the commercial's taping on Friday and have set no specific plans to do so in the coming days.
Since the primary, Ms. Ferraro has criticized the Attorney General for joining Elizabeth Holtzman, the City Comptroller, in aggressive attacks against her background that raised questions about possible ties to organized crime. Mr. Abrams yesterday denied that he ever made such allegations.
"The allegations and insinuations that figured so prominently in the coverage of the primary to the effect that Geraldine Ferraro was somehow linked to organized crime were unfortunate and inaccurate," his statement said. "I hope it is clear that neither I nor my campaign ever engaged in or endorsed these kinds of tactics. It is my firm and sincere belief that Gerry Ferraro has never had a knowing association with any member of organized crime."
But it was not clear yesterday whether even that statement would put to rest the qualms of Ms. Ferraro's backers, especially since it did not entirely match the Attorney General's comments at the height of the bitter primary.
On Aug. 19, he described himself as "gravely disturbed" by an article in The Village Voice headlined "Gerry and the Mob." He then suggested that voters "seriously consider whether Geraldine A. Ferraro's lack of an ethical compass makes her fit to hold a high position of public trust." And on Sept. 11, just days before the primary, he released an advertisement that said, "While Bob Abrams was taking on the mob, Geraldine Ferraro was taking illegal campaign contributions."
In recent weeks, voters across the state have frequently mentioned the ugly tone of the primary as one of their chief reservations about supporting Mr. Abrams.
Senator D'Amato's own campaign team yesterday moved into the last stretch of the race by releasing a new advertisement attacking the Attorney General. Citing reports that Mr. Abrams was late in paying taxes for a Dutchess County country home and filed for excessive deductions for an office space used in his Manhattan apartment, the advertisement warns: "Bob Abrams never met a tax he didn't like -- except his own."
Mr. D'Amato made the same point repeatedly at stops along a barnstorming tour upstate, calling the Attorney General a millionaire and describing him as a man who would tax the poor and middle class while sidestepping responsibilities of his own.
"Working-class families, they've got to pay their taxes, and what does he say?" Senator D'Amato asked reporters gathered in Albany. "He says he was too busy to open his mail."
Mr. Geto countered, as he has in the past, by emphasizing the difference between ethics investigations of Senator D'Amato and the recent revelations about irregularities in the Attorney General's tax record. "The fact that Bob Abrams may have had to pay over the years about $300 in late payments bears no comparison with the hundreds of millions and maybe billions of dollars that Al D'Amato has been responsible for diverting in government payments from where they were supposed to go," he said, charging that the incumbent Republican Senator has "a total lack of an ethical compass."

HEADLINE: Unpredictables: Perot, New Jersey and Connecticut

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, Oct. 30

 BODY:
Although Gov. Bill Clinton appears to be maintaining his overwhelming lead in New York, the strength he showed recently in New Jersey and Connecticut seems less certain in the final days of the Presidential campaign.
And as the spread between Mr. Clinton and President Bush appears to narrow, the cause of this uncertainty could lie as much with the unpredictable Ross Perot candidacy as with Mr. Clinton or the President, poll takers and analysts say. 
 Support for Mr. Perot's independent candidacy, which experienced a nationwide surge after his showing in the Presidential debates, has rated as high as 18 percent in some New Jersey opinion surveys recently. In heavily Democratic New York, Mr. Perot has polled as much as 15 percent, and his rating in Connecticut has been about the same.
But there are indications in the most recent national and local surveys that Mr. Perot's momentum may have stalled, after he charged last week that Republican dirty tricks aimed at his daughter had led him to withdraw from the race in July. If the races in New Jersey and Connecticut continue to tighten, Mr. Perot's rising or falling fortunes could be crucial to the outcome.
 
8 New Jersey Trips for Bush
 With New York's 33 electoral votes all but conceded to the Clinton camp, Mr. Bush has set his sights on New Jersey's 15 votes. By Monday, he will have visited the state eight times in an effort to win back or maintain its large pool of Reagan Democrats and moderate Republicans.
The latest statewide survey of 801 likely voters, conducted by The Star-Ledger/Eagleton Poll Oct. 23 to 29, found Mr. Clinton leading Mr. Bush 42 percent to 30 percent, with 18 percent for Mr. Perot. But there was a distinct shift toward Mr. Bush between the first wave of interviews, from Oct. 23 to 25, and the second wave, from Oct. 25 to 29, with his support rising by 10 percentage points, while Mr. Perot's fell by 8 points. The margin of sampling error for the whole survey was 3.5 percentage points; for the two separate waves of interviews, the margin was 5 percent.
Mr. Bush must also win over Reagan Democrats and moderate Republicans if he is to win the eight electoral votes in Connecticut, which, like New Jersey, has lost hundreds of thousands of manufacturing jobs in the last decade. More recently, jobs in white-collar industries like banking and insurance have disappeared as the economy worsened.
Everett Ladd, a political science professor at the University of Connecticut and director of the Roper Institute of Public Opinion Research, said: "The numbers are inclined to change the closer we get to the election, and doubts about Clinton persist."
In the meantime, he said: "Perot is a convenient parking place for many of these people. He has a core of ardent supporters, but others have moved back and forth. When you get down now to this whole matter, it's just very hard to read."
Neither Connecticut nor New Jersey has supported a Democratic Presidential candidate since the 1960's. And Ester Fuchs, a political science professor at Barnard College who specializes in American political parties and elections, said that Mr. Perot had a potential to be "a spoiler" in traditional Republican states. All the polls indicate there are many disaffected voters out there, she said. "And the disaffected voter is very unhappy with George Bush and not that thrilled with Clinton either."
"Traditional Republicans still have a hard time pulling the Democratic lever on Election Day," she said. "And with Perot, they don't have to vote for Bush or Clinton. These are the higher- or middle-income voters who won't stay home in New Jersey and Connecticut."
But any attempt to gauge the impact of the Perot vote is clouded by uncertainty over whether he can maintain his support.
 
Perot's Loss Is Bush's Gain
 Janice Ballou, polling director for the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University, said the latest Star-Ledger/Eagleton Poll showed that "the increase in the Bush support during the past week is at the expense of Ross Perot."
"George Bush has been more aggressive as a campaigner, and Perot's discussion of additional reasons for withdrawing from the race earlier this year may also have contributed to the changes," she said. "This may be an indicator of increased momentum for Bush in the closing days of the campaign."
Among higher-income groups, she said, sentiment for Mr. Bush was stronger than for either of the two other candidates. And Mr. Perot, she added, is more likely than not to siphon votes away from the Clinton campaign, since both camps can be viewed as a viable haven for anti-Bush sentiment.
Alan Brinkley, a history professor at Columbia University who specializes in the American Presidency, observed that a tighter race -- one in which Mr. Perot's vote-getting ability was a potential liability for either of the other candidates -- might ultimately hurt Mr. Perot's own totals.
"As it becomes clear to people that the major race is a lot closer than people thought it was," Professor Brinkley said, "some Perot voters will decide it's not a free vote anymore."
 
Classic Third-Party Appeal
 He said Mr. Perot's candidacy had classic third-party appeal that would attract a certain percentage of voters no matter what.
"Perot seems to have attracted a kind of personal following in a way that other candidates haven't," Professor Brinkley said. "Diehard supporters look at him as a political messiah." There were true believers, he said, who stayed with him even after July, when he dropped out of the race temporarily. "Some people just never gave up."
But Professor Ladd cautioned that the Perot phenomenon could fizzle.
"In the final analysis," he said, "a lot of people come to vote their second choice. If you believe on Election Day that your candidate really doesn't have any chance, might you shift? A bunch will say yes."

HEADLINE: Court Curtails the Use of Co-ops as Bed-and-Breakfasts

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
Over the last few years, hundreds of co-op owners in New York City have furtively turned their spare bedrooms and vacant apartments into bed-and-breakfasts, helping them keep up with the cost of property that many cannot resell, and offering tourists a homey, inexpensive alternative to the city's hotels.
But now, overturning a judge's ruling that had given some legitimacy to these hosts, a state appeals court has held that a co-op's board of directors has the right to prohibit a shareholder from operating a bed-and-breakfast in his apartment. 
 The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan ruled on Thursday that Peter Hoffman, who for five years has rented his co-op apartment on East 73d Street to tourists, had violated the co-op's proprietary lease and ordered him to stop.
"Having chosen the cooperative form of ownership," the four-member panel wrote in a broad decision, "plaintiff is bound to abide by the rules and regulations governing its operation."
 
Growing Trend Threatened
 The court's decision could threaten hundreds of bed-and-breakfasts that have proliferated in all sorts of apartments across Manhattan and, to a lesser extent, in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx, because the vast majority operate without permission from co-op boards, and around city and state laws.
A bed-and-breakfast costs anywhere from $50 for a single to more than $100 for a double -- compared with about $125 for an average hotel room. The New York State Hospitality and Tourism Association estimates there are more than 1,200 in New York City, many of them co-ops but also privately owned and rented apartments.
Mr. Hoffman turned his two-bedroom, 10th-floor apartment in the Diplomat, a 140-unit co-op between First and Second Avenues, into a bed-and-breakfast in 1987, renting out either one room or the whole apartment for a night or more at a time. He listed it with a number of reservation agencies that help match hosts and guests.
In 1990, after noticing a stream of visitors lugging suitcases up the elevators (including one who asked for a bellhop), the co-op's directors notified Mr. Hoffman that he was violating the rules, which prohibit unapproved guests and commercial activity.
 
Appeal Is Planned
 Arguing that the co-op's directors and employees had harassed his guests, Mr. Hoffman sued, and in September 1991, Justice Irma V. Santaella of State Supreme Court ruled in his favor. Citing a 1938 ruling that permitted "the occasional sharing of a home with others," she ordered the co-op board to leave his bed-and-breakfast alone.
But the appellate judges -- E. Leo Milonas, Ernst H. Rosenberger, Betty Wienberg Ellerin and Israel Rubin -- disagreed, saying that Justice Santaella's interpretation of the 1938 ruling was "misplaced" and did not apply to co-op apartments, which are governed by proprietary leases that all shareholders sign.
Neal Stearns, the executive vice-president of the Diplomat's co-op board, said Mr. Hoffman had never sought the board's permission to operate a bed-and-breakfast. "A co-op is just what it says it is," he said, "a group of people living together cooperatively."
Mr. Hoffman said he would appeal the court's decision. He said he had come to rely on the income from his bed-and-breakfast, which he insists falls in a legal gray area. He said that none of his guests, which have included a Congressman and a foreign ambassador, had ever troubled anyone in the co-op.
 
Discreete Businesses
 "The thing is I'm not running an opium den," Mr. Hoffman said. "I'm having guests."
The decision, like several other state court rulings, reaffirms the ability of co-ops to decide who or what they will accept. And it could pose serious problems for others like Mr. Hoffman whose thriving cottage industry has grown steadily, especially as co-op owners have struggled to cope with the real-estate slump.
"This will probably stop it in its tracks," Morton H. Rosen, the co-op's lawyer, said, "and it will certainly reassure many shareholders in this city who were concerned about security and the devaluation of their property by the potential for their building to be used as a hotel."
But Mary McAulay, who runs Urban Ventures, the city's largest and oldest bed-and-breakfast reservation agency, said she doubted that the ruling would profoundly affect business. She said most hosts operate furtively anyway and, in today's tough economy, some co-ops welcome the idea -- as long as shareholders pay their bills.
"I don't think it's going to have much impact," Ms. McAulay said, "because most people do it very discreetly."

HEADLINE: Calls for Change Mark Congressional Races

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
The calls for political change that have resounded through the nation this year are echoing loud and clear in Congressional races across New York, New Jersey and Connecticut -- perhaps most strikingly in New York, where at least 10 familiar faces will be gone from the House delegation in January.
In tough radio commercials around the region, the themes of the Presidential campaign buzz night and day: anti-incumbency, disgust with Congress, fights over abortion rights. But local political feuds also loom large, as in an open district in central New Jersey where the former Republican state chairman has styled his campaign as a referendum on the tax policies of the Democratic Governor, Jim Florio -- in military sound bites that evoke the Persian Gulf war. 
 Despite upheavals over reapportionment, and complex efforts to create new districts that would increase the chances of minority representation, only two of the 50 House seats at stake in the three states on Tuesday will be newly filled by members of minorities -- both by Hispanic candidates virtually assured of victory after winning primaries on overwhelmingly Democratic turf. And Gary Franks, Connecticut's only black Congressman and the only black Republican in the House, is facing a challenge in a three-way race.
 
Incumbents Highly Favored
 In nearly three-quarters of the seats in the region, incumbents are considered either safe or favored to win, slightly higher than the national average, according to data compiled by Congressional Quarterly.
Still, there will be real changes, and nowhere more pronounced than in New York, which lost three of its 34 seats in redistricting due to population shifts -- more than any other state. Eight incumbents retired, one died on the eve of his primary victory, and another lost a primary forced on him by redistricting.
By contrast, Connecticut lost none of its six seats, all of its incumbents are running for re-election, and most of them are either heavily favored or have a solid chance of winning. Yet a Republican State Senator named Edward W. Munster -- who has built name recognition by having a campaign worker walk around in a Herman Munster mask -- has emerged a surprisingly strong challenger to a six-term Democratic incumbent, Samuel Gejdenson, in the eastern part of the state.
New Jersey is a mixed bag, having lost one of its 14 seats to redistricting and four incumbents to retirement. Its current ratio of 8 to 6 in favor of the Democrats may well shift to 7 to 6 for the Republicans.
Many of the most dramatic shifts in the local landscape actually occurred months ago, as the House bank overdraft scandal, redistricting and disillusion with 12 years of deadlock between Congress and the White House prompted a quarter of the New York delegation to quit, helping assure what promises to be the largest turnover in Congress since World War II.
"It already is a sea change, and you don't even need an election to know it," said John A. Marino, chairman of the New York State Democratic Party. "It's just been an amazing year, and there may be more surprises. Everybody's ready to write the story that despite the calls for change, a lot of incumbents will be re-elected. I think some of that may have to be rewritten on Tuesday night."
 
Hoping for Coattails
 With polls showing Bill Clinton holding a double-digit lead over President Bush in New York, leading in Connecticut and in a close race in New Jersey, Democrats in all three states are hoping his coattails can help.
Matthew F. McHugh, the Ithaca Democrat who was swept into office as part of the "Watergate class" of 1974 and announced his retirement in frustration last spring, said he had no regrets, but that if had known then what he does now about prospects for a Democratic victory, "I might have made a different decision."
But Republicans, too, are optimistic, arguing that anti-incumbency feelings may well lead to Republican gains, whatever happens to the top of their party's ticket.
"I think people are finally focusing on the need for change in America, and some of that they place on Congress," said William D. Powers, the New York state Republican chairman. "The Democrats have controlled Congress longer than Fidel Castro's controlled Cuba, and that type of message is getting out."
Here is a summary of some of the contested races in the region:
 
New York
 In Eastern Long Island, George J. Hochbrueckner, a three-term Democratic incumbent, faces a tough rematch against the Republican Suffolk County clerk, Edward P. Romaine, in a district with a decidedly Republican cast. Mr. Romaine has tried to paint Mr. Hochbrueckner as a tax-and-spend liberal while also criticizing Mr. Bush for his slow reaction to the recession, and both parties say the race is close.
Next door, Representative Thomas J. Downey, the 43-year-old Democratic veteran seeking his 10th term, is trying to fend off a stiff challenge from Rick A. Lazio, a moderate Republican Suffolk County legislator. Wounded by a national television news report that used a hidden camera to capture him riding a Jet Ski on a junket in Barbados, and by 151 overdrafts at the House bank, Mr. Downey is spending more than $1 million, four times as much as his challenger, in a race state Democratic officials fear could be close.
In a newly drawn district that stretches from eastern Queens to Suffolk County, Gary L. Ackerman, a Democrat elected in 1983, is on the defensive against another Republican Suffolk County legislator, Allan E. Binder, who received some prominent endorsements and has needled Mr. Ackerman for his 111 overdrafts. Mr. Ackerman remains favored.
In New York City, Representative Bill Green, the Upper East Side liberal Republican, is facing City Councilwoman Carolyn B. Maloney, while Susan Molinari, representing the third generation of a Staten Island Republican dynasty, is going up against City Councilman Sal F. Albanese, a maverick Brooklyn Democrat. Both Mr. Albanese and Ms. Maloney have uphill climbs.
Meantime, in Westchester County, Nita M. Lowey faces a rematch against the man she defeated in 1988, Joseph J. DioGuardi, a Republican who is broadcasting ads deriding her as "too liberal, even for New York." And Hamilton Fish Jr., a 12-term Republican incumbent who opposes abortion rights, is facing an unexpectedly lively challenge from Neil McCarthy, a lawyer who is running ads urging voters to dump the "Bush-Fish" team.
 
New Jersey
 "The main story about New Jersey is that no matter who we elect, we lose a great deal of power," said Cliff Zukin, a political science professor at the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers, noting the retirements of such senior members of the delegation as Robert A. Roe, a ranking Democrat on several committees who has served since 1969.
The surprise retirement two months ago of Matthew J. Rinaldo, a moderate Republican who had represented the central part of the state since 1972, set off some of the biggest sparks and paved the way for a heated last-minute fight between the former Republican state chairman, Bob Franks, and Leonard R. Sendelsky, a builder who had been dismissed out of the gate.
Mr. Franks's radio ads open with the sound of an explosion, and a narrator intoning: 'It hit New Jersey like a bomb -- Jim Florio's $3 billion tax hike and record-setting spending plan," and then adding, "To Bob Franks, it was a declaration of war." It ends, "Now Bob Franks has declared war on Congress, to fix the economy and create jobs."
Perhaps the tightest race is to succeed Mr. Roe, in a district that covers Paterson and Passaic. It pits Joseph L. Bubba, a conservative Republican state senator, against Herbert C. Klein, a national Democratic Party fund-raiser and former state legislator. Mr. Bubba makes a point of telling audiences that he is both Sicilian and Calabrese, supports the death penalty and strongly opposes gun control and tax increases. A strong Democratic turnout in a state that both national parties regard as pivotal could bolster Mr. Klein's chances.
 
Connecticut
 One of this state's liveliest races had been the fight of Gary Franks, a freshman, to retain his seat. He has been besieged by staff turnover and controversies over his personal finances, and Democrats targeted his seat. But the Democrats split after Lynn H. Taborsak, a plumber and state representative, barely lost a primary to James Lawlor, a probate judge from Waterbury.
Ms. Taborsak has pursued an independent campaign under the banner of Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s Connecticut Party, and recent polls show her and Mr. Lawlor splitting the opposition and Mr. Franks with a clear plurality, if not a majority.
In recent days, a lively battle has emerged between Mr. Gejdenson and Mr. Munster, who won a scrappy Republican primary against Glenn T. Carberry, who used billboards reading "Bounce Sam" to denounce Mr. Gejdenson's 51 overdrafts at the House bank.
"Sam's had very high unfavorability ratings the last year and a half," said Richard Foley, the state Republican chairman, who says this race is virtually even. "Incumbency is still a net disadvantage, and if that's a problem, high visibility and name recognition's not enough of a solution. Voters now know who to punch."

HEADLINE: Fierce Fighting in Angolan Capital Leaves Many Dead

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LUANDA, Angola, Oct. 31

 BODY:
Rebels and Government forces fought a fierce battle in this capital today, heightening fears that they would revive their all-out civil war. The state radio said many people had been killed.
Machine-gun fire and explosions echoed through Luanda, and a Portuguese radio report said several rebel soldiers lay dead in front of a hotel in central Luanda that they use as a base. 
 Edmund De Jarnette, the head of the United States liaison office in Luanda, said the fighting started shortly after the two sides halted a round of negotiations seeking a political solution to their standoff over election results and other issues.
"There is substantial fire in several areas," he said by telephone.
Tension has been mounting in Angola since the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, which is led by former rebels, lost national elections on Sept. 29 and 30. to the governing Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola. The opposition leader, Jonas Savimbi, accused the Government of rigging the vote and threatened to fight rather than accept the election defeat.
The United Nations, which brokered the May 1991 peace accords that paved the way for the elections, says the balloting generally was free and fair.
Angola's 16-year civil war began almost immediately after it gained independence from Portugal in 1975. Cuba and the Soviet Union armed the Government, and the United States and South Africa backed the rebels.
The heaviest shooting today appeared to be around the Hotel Turismo, which is used as a base by the rebel group, known as Unita for its acronym in Portuguese. The Portuguese radio station T.S.F. reported that the hotel and a nearby police station were in flames.
Witnesses said machine guns, mortars, rocket-propelled grenades and heavier weapons were being used. They said mortar shells fired from the Miramar district, where the rebels have a garrison, were falling onto the city center and into Luanda Bay.
 
Roadblocks Set Up
 Hours earlier, the state radio broadcast appeals for people to stay home and keep children off the streets. Heavily armed police officers patrolled the city and set up roadblocks.
Fighting was reported to have claimed dozens of lives on Thursday and Friday in Luanda and in Huambo, which is Angola's second-largest city and the rebels' stronghold.
News reports in Lisbon said the Portuguese Government had sent frigate carrying 200 marines to the West African coast to prepare a possible evacuation of the some 40,000 Portuguese citizens in Angola.
The British Government told its nationals on Friday to leave Angola, and other countries have evacuated nonessential staff from their embassies.
The United Nations Security Council demanded an end to the clashes on Friday night and said any government imposed by force would not be recognized. Western diplomats said economic sanctions would be imposed if the rebels seized the Government.
[Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali issued a statement appealing to President Jose Eduardo dos Santos and Mr. Savimbi "to withdraw immediately their forces and to return them to the barracks." He also urged a resumption of the talks. ]
The governing party of Mr. dos Santos began moving away from Communism as the cold war came to an end in the late 1980's. In April 1990 the Government opened peace talks with the rebels.
The Cubans began pulling out in January 1989, and South Africa agreed to stop aiding the rebels.
After years of rivalry over the oil- and mineral-rich nation, the Soviet Union and United States joined with Portugal in mediating the talks that led to the peace accords signed by Mr. dos Santos and Mr. Savimbi in May 1991. rule

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
U.S. ORDERS DEPARTURES
 WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (Special to The New York Times) -- The State Department ordered all its nonessential employees to leave Angola today because of the fighting there.
The department also urged American citizens to avoid traveling to Angola and advised those who were already there to leave as soon as possible.
The department said slightly fewer than 300 Americans were in Angola at the end of last month, when the country held its elections. It said it did not know how many Americans had since left, and it declined to say how many department employees were there.

HEADLINE: D'Amato and Abrams: Blitzes on the Final Days

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY

 BODY:
Misanthropes who dread an uplifting finish to the mean-spirited Senate race can relax. Neither Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato nor Robert Abrams plans to waste much time or money on inspirational messages.
With so little time left and with so many New Yorkers saying they are still undecided, the candidates are out not to seduce voters, but to scare them. Mr. Abrams says the Republican Senator wants to ban abortion. Mr. D'Amato says the Democrat wants to raise taxes. 
 Their combat has been ruthless, but Mr. D'Amato and his Democratic challenger, Mr. Abrams, are actually fighting extremely different battles.
Mr. D'Amato, a conservative Republican, is running against a political tide, trying to hold onto his 1980 coalition of Reagan Democrats and the party faithful when the economy and the issue of abortion rights appear to be cutting into portions of his Republican base.
This time, it is Mr. Abrams who seems favored by fortune. Unlike Mr. D'Amato, he basks in the glow of a strong Presidential candidate at the top his ticket, and he's relying heavily on Gov. Bill Clinton to pull him to victory. In New York, where Democrats outnumber Republicans by almost 3 to 2, most voters say they agree with Mr. Abrams on his central issues, universal health care and abortion rights. He is even blessed with an opponent whose popularity has been weakened by allegations of ethical misconduct.
If Mr. Abrams loses, despite all his advantages, he will have his own haplessness to blame. If Mr. D'Amato wins, he will have done so through pit-bull tenacity and tough, brash campaign tactics, and money, vast amounts of it.
 
Abrams's Struggles
 Mr. Abrams has been struggling to recover from the ill will he engendered among many Italian-Americans and women when he defeated Geraldine A. Ferraro in the primary by attacking her ethics. Yesterday his campaign released a television ad featuring his long-awaited endorsement from Ms. Ferraro. Looking as stiff and unsmiling as a hostage in a ransom videotape, Ms. Ferraro spoke directly at the camera, explaining it was "critically important" to defeat Mr. D'Amato because of his positions on abortion, and said she supported Mr. Abrams "because he is right on the issues."
Also yesterday, Mr. D'Amato unveiled his latest television ad, which accused "Millionaire Bob Abrams" of cheating on his own taxes, a last gut punch intended to neutralize the ethics issue. "Bob Abrams never met a tax he didn't like," the ad says, "except his own."
Throughout the state, the D'Amato and Abrams campaigns are flooding the airwaves with 30-second commercials suggesting that whatever their candidate's failings, the other guy is even worse.
The Abrams campaign, which has not had enough money to match Mr. D'Amato's barrage of negative ads, always said it would save its resources for a final media blitz. Jan Crawford, a media buyer working for the Abrams campaign, said she expected to spend $1.4 million for the last week. The D'Amato campaign would not divulge what it was spending, but one aide, who did not wish to be identified, said the two camps were roughly competitive.
The Attorney General, who has raised far less money and has proven more accident prone than his opponent, is relying on Mr. Clinton to energize traditional Democratic voters. Mr. Abrams is a little like a mousy debutante who clings to the side of the prettiest girl at the ball, trusting that some of the suitors will fall her way.
 
New Ad Is Scrapped
 Last Thursday, Mr. Abrams tried to add a new, closing television ad selling himself as the third member of a holy Democratic trinity: "Clinton-Gore-Abrams." Ethan Geto, Mr. Abrams's campaign director, excitedly called the ad "the centerpiece" of the final week of media strategy. But the Abrams campaign was thwarted at the last minute by a legal glitch his staff had not foreseen that forced them to scrap the commercial.
When the ad was reviewed by lawyers to make sure it complied with federal regulations, Mr. Geto said that he was informed that the ad would be considered as a promotional spot for Mr. Clinton as well, and that it would be illegal unless Mr. Clinton paid half the cost of producing and broadcasting it. That would cost Mr. Clinton "several hundreds of thousands of dollars."
The contretemps was all too typical of the Abrams campaign's logistical disarray. It also underscored the downside of Mr. Clinton's big lead in New York. As Mr. Geto noted dispiritedly, "I won't even ask if they are willing," Mr. Geto said. "New York is not a place where Clinton wants to spend his money."
The candidates both campaigned upstate yesterday, before returning to New York City to prepare for their debate today, but both planned to go back upstate on Monday. Mr. Abrams has a four-city tour planned, returning to Manhattan for a rally at Harlem hospital with a union local. Mr. D'Amato plans to visit seven cities in upstate New York, hopscotching from airport to airport and media market to media market.
 
The Power of TV
 Television is paramount. The intent of some programming choices is obvious. Mr. Abrams, who is counting heavily on liberal women voters, has placed an ad on the New York affiliate carrying the hit CBS sitcom "Murphy Brown" on Monday night. Mr. D'Amato, who calls his constituency "the working middle class," chose the showcase of Monday Night Football via ABC's New York affiliate. Mr. Abrams favors programs on Lifetime cable. Mr. D'Amato's ads can also be found on such shows as "America's Most Wanted" and reruns of "All in the Family."
But both are buying ads in virtually every market in the state. "They're both pumping in a ton of money," said Tim Busch, a sales manager for WGRZ, the NBC affiliate in Buffalo. Mr. Busch was struggling Friday to put together his station's weekend advertising schedule. "I feel like I'm being picked over by vultures," he said. "They're coming in and eating up every bit of inventory I've got."
In New York City, advertising costs are higher, but the pace is just as fast. Mr. Abrams's largest spending block at one station, WABC, Channel 7, was for the period from Tuesday through tomorrow, during which he spent $203,575 on 49 spots. Mr. D'Amato's largest spending at WABC was for Wednesday through tomorrow, during which he spent $140,505 on 37 spots. Mr. D'Amato has outspent Mr. Abrams at other stations, however. At Fox TV, D'Amato spent $50,851 on 32 30-second ads and 17 10-second ads for Wednesday through Election Day. There is no record of any ads by Mr. Abrams for this period.
 
Radio Ads Too
 Mr. D'Amato has also been buying radio ads throughout the campaign. Mr. Abrams, citing limited money, has focused exclusively on television until the final week. Mr. Geto said the campaign was using radio mostly for its base, with ads on black radio, Hispanic radio and Hispanic cable television. Mr. D'Amato, who is using his endorsement by The Amsterdam News to make overtures to black voters, particularly in Queens, has also run ads on black radio stations.

HEADLINE: Bucking Trends, Dodd Uses Incumbency to Hold His Edge

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 31

 BODY:
After spending 18 years in Congress making his name known to Connecticut voters, Senator Christopher J. Dodd began working a few weeks ago on the name recognition of his Republican opponent, Brook Johnson, a businessman new to politics.
Mr. Johnson, who continues to trail, is not likely to thank Mr. Dodd for his help. In a Senate race that reveals the perils of trying a Ross Perot-style campaign at the state level, Mr. Johnson is now known to voters, but in many cases through Mr. Dodd's commercials, not his own. 
 "Where have the candidates been during our economic crunches?" asks one Dodd ad. "Chris Dodd was fighting for Connecticut, the Seawolf, family leave. Brook Johnson was paying himself millions in salary, laying off workers at his factories, selling his only American plant, moving jobs overseas, and then moving himself to Florida."
That one commercial laid out Mr. Dodd's full campaign, stressing what he sees as the state's main concern, jobs and the economy; identifying him with the state; noting his triumph in saving a Seawolf submarine and its jobs, and reminding voters that his pet subject, helping children, helps them, all while comparing this caring politician to a businessman with few ties to Connecticut and little loyalty except to himself.
 
Ads Bite Both Ways
 It is little wonder that Mr. Johnson, whose appeals to the public have largely been through television, now tells audiences: "My advice is to tune out on the advertising. It's just there to influence you."
Both Mr. Johnson, a 46-year-old textile executive, and Mr. Dodd, who at 48 has served three terms in the House and two in the Senate, began the campaign with clear strategies.
Mr. Johnson announced his candidacy in May. He was drawn, he said, by his concern over the national debt, which he attributed to career politicians spending tax money at the behest of the special-interest groups that financed their campaigns.
Mr. Johnson, like Ross Perot, presented himself as a bottom-line businessman whose financial success proved his competence. And, like Mr. Perot, he said he would pay for much of his own campaign.
 
Attacking 'Career Politicians'
 His spokesman, Mark Rivers, said their strategy from the beginning of the campaign was to win enough delegates at the Republican convention to force a primary, then to win the primary in September, and all the while to build recognition across the state.
Mr. Johnson's concern about the deficit defined his opponent, who had been in Washington for 18 years, as part of the problem.
"Is there a law that U.S. Senators have to be career politicians?" he asked in an early television ads. "No. Politics shouldn't be a career."
As an outsider, Mr. Johnson was racing for recognition, even within his own party. Much of his effort was spent in heavily Republican Fairfield County. As late as Sept. 26, 11 percent of those surveyed in a Quinnipiac College poll had not heard of him, and 34 percent had no opinion of him.
 
At First, the High Road
 Many politicians, hearing his prediction that he would spend $4 million, a huge sum for Connecticut, had expected him to attack Mr. Dodd with waves of negative ads. But Mr. Dodd was viewed as too popular for a blunt assault. Instead, in October, Mr. Johnson appeared in ads in shirtsleeves, saying: "My opponent is not a bad guy. We just have different views about spending your tax money."
Then he accused Mr. Dodd of voting to raise his own pay 51 percent, being the second-biggest spender in the Senate, and voting to raise taxes "dozens of times."
A year before, Mr. Dodd had appeared vulnerable. His popularity was down; he was perceived as falling out of touch with the state, and anti-incumbent fever was high because of the state's new income tax.
 
Focusing on Home
 But Mr. Dodd played an important role in saving the Seawolf contract and thousands of defense jobs at Electric Boat this spring, and he tended his home fences. His spokesman, Marvin Fast, said Mr. Dodd approached the campaign focusing on the public's main concerns, jobs and the economy. And he stayed in Washington, pushing his family-leave bill.
"Dodd said it would be offensive to voters for him to be out going door-to-door then," Mr. Fast said. "They're not concerned about what you're doing about your job. They want to know what you're doing about their job."
Mr. Dodd's ads talked about jobs and how he had helped people. They offered testimonials. They looked to the future. "Look, some people want to sit around and blame each other for our problems," he said in one. "I believe we must work together to put people back to work."
As Congress adjourned and Mr. Dodd came home to campaign, he broadcast ads comparing his record in Congress to Mr. Johnson's in business. Mr. Johnson had told reporters his business affairs were private.
Mr. Johnson prides himself on working his way to the top, and in person he has the regular-guy manner of the salesman he once was. But not being born to the manor, like the Connecticut patricians George Bush and Lowell P. Weicker Jr., he did not wear as well his badges of wealth: his millionaire status, a Greenwich address and a passion for polo.
The Dodd ads portrayed Mr. Johnson as an uncaring businessman while he was still trying to define himself to the public. In the next two weeks Mr. Johnson attained 93 percent recognition in Quinnipiac's polls, but the proportion of people viewing him favorably leveled off, while those viewing him unfavorably shot up.
Mr. Dodd's first important decision was to raise a big war chest, and the $3 million he amassed is a record for a Senate race in Connecticut. Only half is being spent on radio and television; the rest is for mailings, leaflets and other efforts by 2,000 volunteers.
Mr. Johnson is spending $2 million to $2.5 million, which is less than once predicted, and includes his spending on the primary. He is spending as much as Mr. Dodd on advertising, but it is much more of his budget.
 
Limits of an Outsider's Appeal
 To people watching the race, Mr. Johnson's struggle is evidence that the anti-politician appeal of businessmen like Mr. Perot has sharp limits if not supported by political skill.
This month the Institute of Social Inquiry at the University of Connecticut asked people who they thought could best address the nation's problems: a successful businessman with no political experience, or an experienced politician with no experience outside government. Fifty percent said the politician, and only 27 percent the businessman.
The challenge for a candidate like Mr. Johnson is compounded, said Dr. Renny Fulco, a professor of political science at Trinity College, when the opponent is well regarded.
"I don't think Chris Dodd is viewed as someone who doesn't work for Connecticut, so trying to make that case against him was not persuasive," she said. "If an incumbent has a good reputation, coming in and saying 'vote for me because I'm not a politician' doesn't work."

HEADLINE: An Old Shadow Dims Major's Path to Europe

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
As Prime Minister John Major digs in for what some describe as possibly his last stand, staking his political survival and the future of his Government on seeing the treaty on European union through Parliament this fall, a familiar shadow has fallen across Mr. Major's path.
It belongs to Margaret Thatcher, his predecessor as Prime Minister. Now Lady Thatcher, a Baroness and member of the House of Lords, she is an ardent skeptic of European union and, by common acclaim, the spiritual leader of the Tory rebels who are determined to block the ratification of Mr. Major's treaty at all costs. 
 In recent weeks Lady Thatcher has kept a relatively low profile while it seems nearly everyone else in Britain, including many members of Mr. Major's Conservative Party, have piled on the Prime Minister and his Government for its stumbling on the economy and the coal industry.
Critics of Mr. Major are bracing for a showdown over Europe next week. The Prime Minister is personally urging rebels within his own Conservative Party not to desert the Government in a motion in the House of Commons on Wednesday, which would commit Britain to a "leading role" in the development of the European Community.
With only a 21-seat majority in Parliament, Mr. Major must keep Tory waverers in line. The opposition Labor Party has already declared it will vote against the motion, asserting that it is a debate over confidence in the Prime Minister rather than Europe.
Aides at Downing Street suggest that Tory rebels loyal to Lady Thatcher are now as determined to weaken and thwart Mr. Major, as more moderate members of the Conservative Party were eager to force Mrs. Thatcher out as Prime Minister two years ago.
A week ago Downing Street went so far as to accuse opponents of European union as being the source of a specious article that appeared in The Times of London, describing the Prime Minister as a man riven by indecision, isolated from friends, surviving on junk food and dyeing his hair to disguise his wan appearance.
Then, last weekend, other reports began to appear suggesting that Mrs. Thatcher herself was waiting in the wings, poised to take center stage again if Mr. Major should stumble over Europe. The Sunday Times, in a front-page article, quoted unidentified friends and political allies of Lady Thatcher as saying she is ready and eager to return to Downing Street.
According to the article, supporters of Lady Thatcher are studying how to overcome any constitutional or legal barrier to her resuming office, since as a life peer and a member of the House of Lords she would be ineligible to head her party in the House of Commons.
Officials at Downing Street said they do not take such stories seriously, and neither do Lady Thatcher's own aides. "I would take all of this with a huge grain of salt," said Sir Charles Powell, her former national security adviser.
Lady Thatcher was unavailable for an interview but a spokeswoman for her was even more adamant than Sir Charles. "It's rubbish," she said. "There is absolutely no question of such a thing happening. She regards Downing Street as a closed chapter."
More important, there is a strong denial that Lady Thatcher herself is behind any mischief directed at Mr. Major. "A lot of people around her are trying to use her for their own purposes," an aide said. "She has no belief in a comeback, or delusions. She is being used a weapon against John Major by some of those in the Tory Party, but it is not her choosing and it is not something she is encouraging."
But there are suggestions that Lady Thatcher may be playing a more covert role. Last month, in the middle of the Tory Party conference in Brighton, she published an article in Paris repeating her concerns that the treaty on European union would compromise British sovereignty on the same day Mr. Major was to preside over a debate on the issue.
Instead of plotting a return to government, aides say, Lady Thatcher is hard at work on her memoirs and keeping up a busy travel and speaking schedule. She spent 10 days in the United States in September, and recently returned from a similar trip to Japan.

HEADLINE: On Sunday;
Fever Pitch: Democracy At Work

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP

 BODY:
FROM the Roman Catholic chapel in the Bergen Mall in Paramus, N.J., to O'Malley's Pub in Queens, from the bathrooms at Star Multicare Services in downtown (Democratic) Brooklyn, to the counter at the Sweet Shop in (Republican) Oyster Bay, L.I., there is a fever about this election, a mix of fear, excitement and tension unmatched in years.
"I hear it from the guy in the urinal next to me, in the subway, in deli lines," says Stephen Sternbach, president of Star Multicare. "Even my 6-year-old, there's so much bombardment on TV, he says, 'Dad, who's best for us?' " 
 This one feels big. If you ask when was the last time an election seemed this important, people often refer back to their youth, when Presidents strode the earth. "The last one that felt like this?" said William Puskas, age 66, who was heading in to pray at the chapel in the mall. "I was just a kid. Roosevelt's first."
"The last time I remember such tension, I was a kid," said Mr. Sternbach, 38. "When I went to bed, Nixon was ahead and when I woke up Kennedy had won. It felt like magic."
"Big? Yeah, you're going to see something happen," said Demo Scutakes, owner of the Sweet Shop in Oyster Bay. ("Democrats?" asked a waitress there. "I don't know any Democrats.") Mr. Scutakes pointed past a cup of black coffee. "The counter philosophers all believe this is a big one. At breakfast they sit around talking about stuff like term limits. Really. In the 40 years I've been here, I don't remember anything like it. Even when Carter beat Ford, I don't think they were stirred up like this." When a woman leaned over to her friend and whispered, "He wouldn't even allow abortions for someone raped," the waitress poked her head in: "Who? Who's that?"
No one could complain there wasn't enough information. "Last night I watched Larry King," said Martin Errick, owner of Oyster Bay Books. "I thought Clinton looked good. But this morning I had on a talk show with Bill Mazur and they were saying ----"
"I usually wake up and get the traffic report first," Mr. Sternbach said. "Now I'm flipping the morning shows, looking for the latest poll." At the start of the election it seemed undignified for a President to go on the "Today" program and by the end, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato was calling for the abolition of the Federal Communications Commission on the Howard Stern program.
The passionate feelings spring from many sources: Democrats have hope in their hearts for the first time in four national elections; Republicans are rallying to a serious threat; there's that merry quipster, Ross Perot, and deep fears about the economy. President Bush keeps saying the economy isn't that bad, but in this region, at least, even his supporters don't seem to agree. Harold Ellsworth, 24, who lives upstate in North Creek, says he would move to Canada if Bill Clinton won. But he also says, "Anyone who doesn't think the economy's bad isn't paying attention." After working many low paying jobs, he will enter the Air Force in January. "I enlisted mainly because of the economy. Maybe it'll be better when I get out, in four years."
Oyster Bay is one of the richer towns on Long Island, but Mr. Scutakes says Sweet Shop business is down 30 percent in a year. Mr. Errick, the bookstore owner across the street, says, "We had three people in yesterday asking if we buy books. I said I want to, but we have to sell some first." Confidence is shaken. Mr. Puskas, who lives in prosperous Bergen County, N.J., said: "I'm fortunate. I haven't lost my job. But my daughter did."
People are talking it out. "I don't know if I should say this," Mr. Sternbach said, "but for the first time, my wife and I are having intelligent conversations about something beside shopping."
At O'Malley's Pub on Queens Boulevard, the bartender, Pat O'Dea, just had to say, "I'm voting for Bush," and Pat Keating, at the end of the bar, attacked: "Why not give Clinton a chance?"
"This Clinton's a bad one for Social Security, Pat," said Mr. O'Dea.
"Who said that, Pat? said Mr. Keating.
"He's going to cut it back, Pat," said Mr. O'Dea.
"No he isn't, Pat."
"Yes he is, Pat."
"Pat, I saw it in the papers," said Mr. O'Dea.
"Do you believe everything you read in the papers?" said Mr. Keating.
"Hey, this guy writes for the paper," said Mr. O'Dea.
"I don't give a ----" said Mr. Keating. "You could write for the paper, Pat. Would you believe what you wrote?"
"Bush believes in God," said Pat O'Dea.
"Whose God?" said Pat Keating.

HEADLINE: Pumping Along Till the Bubble Bursts

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Regarding "Just as in '87, a Split in Opinion" (Oct. 18), there must be a megaburst of cosmic rays in the fall equinox that shocks market players out of their manic state and into the real world. Or so it seemed in 1720 when the South Sea Bubble burst; also in 1929 as the roaring 20's climaxed, and again in 1987 as Merrill's bull, certified immortal by its handlers, dropped dead in living color on TV. 
 What turns a rational person into a Sisyphus doomed to push prices ever higher until they crash? One academic argues it's generational amnesia; another, crowd dementia, and Wall Street wits insist it's free-lunch hypochondria.
Little did Alan Greenspan know, as he reduced interest rates, that he wouldn't revive the economy but stampede Florida retirees out of certificates of deposit and into mutual funds. So now brokers earn big profits and thrifts are seized by the Government. That's by no means the only threat to this 1992 bull run. Here are a few more: the Fed's triple-bounce soft landing -- or worse. Deflating real estate. Ballooning deficits. Shaky dollars.
Yet, these caveats notwithstanding, who is to say the Dow can't jump over the moon? I certainly won't!
 
HENRY FOGEL
Lexington, Mass., Oct. 18, 1992

HEADLINE: About Those A.I.D. Charges . . .

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "How Washington Exports U.S. Jobs" (Forum, Oct. 18), Jack Sheinkman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union, alleges that "A.I.D. programs are contributing to the deindustrialization of the American economy while preying on, and compounding the misery of, the people of the Caribbean." That charge is just plain wrong. 
 United States exports to the Central American region have grown from $30 billion in 1986 to a projected $80 billion this year, supporting more than one million United States jobs. With regard to the apparel industry specifically, United States exports to El Salvador have soared from $6 million in 1987 to $120 million this year. Exports to Honduras rose from $23 million in 1987 to more than $185 million this year.
The past 12 months have seen a net increase of 22,000 jobs in the United States apparel industry.
 
STEPHEN D. HAYES
Washington, Oct. 19
 
Stephen D. Hayes is director of the office of external affairs for the United States Agency for Intrnational Development.

HEADLINE: Things to Think About on Election Day

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "The Beauty of Indexing Capital Gains" (Viewpoints, Oct. 25), Theodore J. Forstmann, national co-chairman of the Bush-Quayle re-election campaign, reveals the Republicans' true economic agenda: to feather the nests of the wealthiest Americans. How else can you explain his clarion call to save America by indexing capital gains retroactively? 
 A good argument can indeed be made for prospective indexing; I've made it myself. Part of the argument is based on fairness, but the more powerful part is based on incentives: by not taxing the inflation component of capital gains, you raise the incentive to invest.
But no incentive can rewrite history. Past investments were made by rational investors in full knowledge of the tax laws prevailing at the time. By forgiving tax liabilities that have already accrued, but have not yet been paid, we would not make past investment any higher. But we would waste hundreds of billions of dollars of badly needed Government revenue. As a general principle, retroactive giveaways are a bad idea. But if we are to have them, why stuff the largesse into the deepest pockets rather than give it to the people who really need it?
Mr. Forstmann's example of the family grocery is valid, but disingenuous. Most of the $7 trillion in unrealized capital gains that he cites belongs to much richer folks. Voters should ponder this when they pull the lever on Tuesday.
 
ALAN S. BLINDER
Princeton, N.J., Oct. 26
 
The writer is a professor of economics at Princeton University.
