HEADLINE: U.S. SENATE RACE IN NEW YORK;
Simple Assertion, Complicated Realities

BYLINE: By TODD PURDUM

 BODY:
The race between State Attorney General Robert Abrams and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato held the prospect of offering voters a choice between two starkly different visions of government.
But the race has often turned on character attacks and half-stated truths, . and its most symbolic interchange may have been the one in which an exasperated Mr. Abrams labeled Mr. D'Amato a "fascist," and Mr. D'Amato responded with tears and commercials featuring an image of Benito Mussolini. A narrator in one ad said Mr. Abrams's reputation had been "stained and dishonored forever." 
 According to Edwin Diamond, author of "The Spot -- The Rise of Political Advertising on Television," Mr. D'Amato's vulnerable position in the polls drove his actions. "When you're behind, you make the decision to go early and often to negative," he said. "When you have an opponent who is somewhat of a blank slate like Abrams, you go on the attack to fill in the picture."
Yet Theodore J. Lowi, professor of government at Cornell University and a past president of the American Political Science Association, said it was Mr. Abrams, coming out of a Democratic primary filled with rough campaigning, who bore the larger share of the blame for getting the campaign off track.
The distortions and side issues have surfaced in several different forms, including the use of code words, from Mr. D'Amato's sneering references to his rival as "hopelessly liberal" and "a sissy" who "deserted his people" to Mr. Abrams's calling Mr. D'Amato a "bully" and likening his campaign tactics to the Nazi "big lie" technique. As they recur, such words and images take on a life of their own. The candidates have also relied on the unholy trinity once summed up by Mark Twain as "lies, damned lies and statistics."
 
ADDING IT UP: TAXES AND HEALTH INSURANCE
 
Claim: Mr. D'Amato contends that Mr. Abrams's support for a national health insurance system would increase Federal spending $570 billion a year, or 30 percent. He says this would require raising many taxes, including the personal income tax, which he says would "wipe out two million jobs in the first year." He says it would force the elderly to pay $278 more a year in Medicare premiums, and would "increase the taxable portion of Social Security benefits for millions of elderly people from 50 percent to 85 percent."
 
Facts: The assertions about taxes and spending are based on calculations by the staff of Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, in analyzing the health insurance plan proposed by Representative Marty Russo of Illinois, which Mr. Abrams supports. The estimate of lost jobs is a calculation by the Congressional Research Service, based on a 6 percentage point increase in the payroll tax, and assumes no other changes in economic policy. The problem is that Mr. Abrams does not back Mr. Russo's financing plan, and any estimate of the effects of a particular economic policy on employment is speculative.
 
Distortion: Mr. D'Amato repeatedly accuses Mr. Abrams of planning to raise taxes, without specifying the purpose, leaving it to Mr. Abrams to respond that money would be for health insurance. Mr. Abrams insists he would not raise personal income taxes but would rely on a 6.75 percentage point increase in the payroll tax (in lieu of the private insurance premiums now paid by employers). He would quadruple Federal taxes on cigarettes, to $1 a pack, and double them on hard liquor, to $8 a fifth (though not, as Mr. D'Amato claims, on beer or wine). He would raise the top corporate tax rate to 38 percent, from 34 percent.
 
Goal: Polls have repeatedly shown that Americans worry greatly about how to pay for health care. It has been a powerful issue in several races around the country and Mr. Abrams chose to make it a centerpiece of his campaign. Mr. D'Amato's tactic here is to block that appeal by scaring the daylights out of New Yorkers, especially the elderly, who make up a disproportionate share of the electorate. This attack has the advantage of being partly true -- Mr. Abrams does favor raising some taxes -- and partly unrebuttable, since no one can gauge for certain what the economy will do.
 
ARTFUL EXTRAPOLATION: JOBS AND MILITARY SPENDING
 
Claim: Mr. D'Amato says that Mr. Abrams's support for cutting military spending in half over the next five years would eliminate every defense-related job in the state, throwing 400,000 New Yorkers out of work and crippling the economy in many areas.
 
Facts: Mr. Abrams wants to cut military spending by $280 billion; Mr. D'Amato favors $85 billion in cuts. The D'Amato camp says its estimate of 400,000 jobs comes from combining an estimate from Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's office that there are 173,000 jobs in the state involving primary defense contracts, and a Defense Department estimate of 237,000 jobs among subcontractors and suppliers.
 
Distortion: The Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, counting only those companies with at least 50 percent of their output related to the military, calculates that there are only 47,000 defense-related jobs in the state. Moreover, Mr. Abrams favors tax credits of up to 20 percent for businesses that invest in plant modernization or conversion to civilian use.
 
Goal: Again, Mr. D'Amato seeks to frighten voters -- especially middle-class and blue-collar workers like those on his home turf on Long Island -- and persuade them that Mr. Abrams will hurt them. The attack also tars Mr. Abrams as soft on defense.
 
MUDDYING THE WATERS: FUND-RAISING AND PERSONAL ETHICS
 
Claim: The day after Mr. Abrams won the Democratic primary, Mr. D'Amato began harsh attacks on the Attorney General's integrity, claiming that he was guilty of a "fund-raising shakedown" and referring to a "shocking report" of the State Commission on Government Integrity, which he said faulted Mr. Abrams's fund-raising efforts as "implicitly coercive."
 
Facts: The commission did criticize Mr. Abrams in 1989 -- along with every other top state official -- for taking campaign contributions from people who had business pending with his office, and it said that his doing so created an appearance of conflict of interest. But none of his practices broke any laws, and he later voluntarily restricted some of them.
 
Distortion: Mr. D'Amato has implied that Mr. Abrams was singled out for criticism, when in fact the commission faulted the Governor and State Comptroller as well. One of the commission's members has since said that it would have criticized Mr. D'Amato most harshly of all, but did not have the authority to review the conduct of Federal officials.
 
Goal: Mr. D'Amato has faced years of investigations into his ethical conduct. In his attacks on Mr. Abrams, he tries to create the impression that Mr. Abrams is not without sin. But while Mr. D'Amato has repeatedly been accused of doing political favors for friends, relatives or contributors, no such direct allegations have been made against Mr. Abrams.
 
OBSCURING THE SOURCE: A QUESTION OF CREDIBILITY
 
Claim: In his latest television commercial, Mr. Abrams uses highly charged language and a picture of a banging gavel to accuse Mr. D'Amato of "another scandal" with phrases like "suspected perjury" and "serious allegations that Al D'Amato tried to obstruct a Federal grand jury, coaching a witness to lie."
 
Facts: This attack is based on recent news accounts that Federal prosecutors are looking into whether Mr. D'Amato tried to influence the testimony of a former Federal housing official in an investigation several years ago into Mr. D'Amato's role in awarding Federal housing contracts.
 
Distortion: Descriptions of the investigation are basically accurate, but fail to note that the source of the allegations is Arnold I. Biegen, a former fund-raiser for Mayor David N. Dinkins who recently pleaded guilty to fraud, embezzlement and tax evasion charges, and whose credibility has been questioned by investigators.
 
Goal: This charge resonates because Mr. D'Amato has been accused of various improprieties for years. After weeks of a cautious campaign strategy of stressing his own stands on the issues -- while also noting criticisms of the Senator -- this is Mr. Abrams's first all-out attack on Mr. D'Amato, reflecting the apparent closeness of the race.

HEADLINE: A Referendum on New York's Debt

 BODY:
On Tuesday, New Yorkers will be asked to authorize $800 million in borrowing to pay for 390 construction projects around the state. Supporters say this measure would create jobs. In any case, the proposal proceeds from a sound premise. The state is starved for infrastructure spending.
The measure is open to question, however, for reasons of procedure. The list of recommended projects is long, and it was published only 10 days ago. That leaves too much to judge in too little time. 
 More than theory is at stake. New York State already has $21 billion in tax-supported debt. The standards for going even deeper into debt should be strict. Borrowing an additional $800 million would be responsible if the money went into worthwhile capital projects that stood a good chance of improving the economy.
Constructing a parking garage here or a street extension there would obviously create some temporary jobs. But unless the projects produced permanent jobs, the borrowing could backfire. The state would have to pay back more than it borrowed, because of interest. That would probably mean higher taxes, which in turn could hurt the state's economy by making it less competitive.
That's why the precise nature of the projects is so important. Regrettably, with so little time, they can't be examined with care. Nor is there much reason for voters to trust the way the project list was drawn up. Because Gov. Mario Cuomo needed the Legislature's approval to get his initiative on the ballot, lawmakers could exchange their votes for inclusion of their pet projects. Some horse-trading is inevitable, but it's impossible in the short time available to assess how many of the projects are legitimate capital needs.
Vincent Tese, the state's Director of Economic Development, describes the delay as unavoidable. The Legislature didn't give its O.K. until the summer, and then, say state officials, it took them until Oct. 23 to select from more than 1,000 applications. Mr. Tese and other officials strongly defend their choices and insist, though they have done only preliminary appraisals, that these projects will add permanent jobs. Perhaps so, but careful reviews aren't even scheduled to start until January.
To approve the bond measure now, voters would have to take on faith that the projects are economically feasible and that going further into debt represents the best way to finance them. Some voters, worried about the sagging economy, thus might support Proposal One. Regretfully, that's not a decision we can conscientiously recommend.

HEADLINE: Specifically, Bill Clinton;
The Campaign, Issue by Issue

 BODY:
The forest: Last Sunday we weighed President Bush's sensible stewardship of foreign affairs against domestic leadership so limp it has prompted the title President Noodle. Likewise, we weighed Gov. Bill Clinton's lack of national experience and a tendency to evasiveness against his program for growth and his devotion to civil rights and social harmony. In our judgment, the scales tip decisively in favor of Bill Clinton.
The trees: Such an overall assessment scants individual issues that also bear heavily on the choice for President. Here is an evaluation of the two candidates regarding such issues. Ross Perot will be appraised separately tomorrow.
 
Murderers, Age 12 and Under
 The horror mounts; ever-younger and ever-more volatile children commit murder with guns. A Northeastern University study reports that arrests of boys 12 and under for murder doubled between 1985 and 1991. What kind of society shrugs at such an evolving epidemic? 
 Mr. Bush, fearful of offending the gun lobby, resists even modest attempts to control handguns. Governor Clinton forthrightly endorses the Brady Bill, a measure to impose a national waiting period for handgun purchases and to ban assault weapons. That suggests he's receptive to still stronger reform, like universal gun registration and licensing.
 
Cities as Poorhouses
 Cities, magnets of opportunity, continue to socialize and educate poor migrants and immigrants -- serving in effect as poorhouses for the whole population. Washington has long recognized some duty to help -- if not for people in distress then at least for places in distress.
President Bush, having failed to recognize any such duty, now belatedly presses, in the wake of the Los Angeles riots, for tax breaks to urban enterprise zones and for other untargeted tax breaks. The zones deserve trial; the untargeted tax breaks deserve only scorn.
Governor Clinton, by contrast, would promote community development groups and development banks. More encouraging, he is committed to helping people in distress -- for instance by expanding Head Start for all disadvantaged children.
 
The Children Left Behind
 On the hottest educational issue of the day, school choice, the two candidates differ dramatically. Mr. Bush promotes choice, free-market style, at taxpayer expense. He would give lower-income families vouchers to spend at public, private or parochial schools. Mr. Clinton supports the idea of choice -- within public schools. That maintains public responsibility for the children from the most troubled homes who need attention most.
 
Energy for the Environment
 Mr. Bush, self-styled environment President, did far better his first two years. After winning a strong Clean Air Act, for instance, he lapsed into infuriating opportunism. He came close to reneging on his pledge that there be no net loss of wetlands, and may yet do so. His minions have undercut the Clean Air Act in the regulatory process. And his attitude toward the Rio conference was governed by short-term political fears that trashed what could have been a public-relations success.
It's hard, nonetheless, to make a strong environmental case for Mr. Clinton, whose Arkansas record is mixed. He opposes drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge that Mr. Bush supports. Mr. Clinton's position conforms to the wise course, to seek energy through efficiency and conservation.
 
Right to Life: Whose?
 The Bush Administration's opposition to abortion rights has had profound indirect consequences, for the seriously ill and for women all over the world. Fetal tissue, for instance, can play a vital role in facilitating research on Parkinson's disease, Huntington's chorea, childhood diabetes, even Alzheimer's disease and cancer.
But the Bush Administration has banned the use of Federal funds for such research. And Congress, frustrated by Administration opposition, was impelled to strip a provision to give $20 million to the U.N. Population Fund.
 
Investment in Growth: Whose?
 In this increasingly global economy, U.S. living standards will rise in the 21st century only to the extent that America trains unskilled workers to use advanced equipment. The President and Governor Clinton both know that most such equipment must come from private investment.
But Mr. Clinton goes two visionary steps further. He proposes an immense $20 billion a year in public investment on infrastructure projects as a way to make private capital more productive. And he would spend heavily to train workers, and not just the dislocated and unemployed.
If the election is to turn on a single issue, this is the right one -- training and public investment. As President, Bill Clinton might end up doing only a fraction of what he promises. But what he promises is plausible, challenging and even inspirational.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
George, Bill and Millie

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Reaching new heights of eloquence in describing Bill Clinton and Al Gore, President Bush declared that "my dog Millie knows more about foreign affairs than these two bozos." Whether Millie's command of Mr. Bush's specialty surpasses that of the two Democratic contenders remains to be seen. Their record is yet too slender to render a final bozo balance sheet. Mr. Bush's record, however, is ample.
Now, one does not lightly go about calling Presidents bozos. But by slapping the bozo label onto a man who might be elected President in two days, Mr. Bush has broken the bozo barrier -- and has invited measurement by that same exacting standard. 
 Unquestionably, Mr. Bush skillfully supported Mikhail Gorbachev in the dissolution of the Soviet empire and Helmut Kohl in forging German unification. He beautifully corralled Arabs and Israelis into direct negotiations and pushed for freer trade agreements. Above all, he brilliantly stitched together the alliance against Saddam Hussein.
These represent considerable statecraft. Most of his other actions abroad approach or cross the line into bozocraft.
Mr. Bush's denials notwithstanding, there is substantial evidence that he knew -- and approved of -- President Reagan's efforts to trade arms to Iran for the release of American hostages. In other words, Vice President Bush thought it made sense to let Teheran know that it could acquire more U.S. weapons simply by kidnapping more Americans in Lebanon. Was this a mere mistake or bozocraft?
President Bush provided billions of dollars in credits and technology with military uses to Saddam until only months before the invasion of Kuwait. He did so despite knowing that Saddam had employed poison gas against the Kurds, still backed terrorists and was pushing ahead with secret programs to develop nuclear weapons. Was this a reasonable policy to bring Saddam "into the family of nations" or bozocraft?
In late August 1990, Saddam deployed more than 100,000 troops to the Kuwait border. Never once in that time did Mr. Bush tell Saddam -- or even hint to him -- that the U.S. would react to an Iraqi attack with U.S. force. Never once. Indeed, on the day before the invasion, the White House opposed legislation to stop further credits for Iraq. Was Mr. Bush understandably blinded by Arab assessments of Saddam's peaceful intentions or was he caught in the web of his own bozocraft?
In July 1989, only weeks after Chinese dictators had democratic dissidents shot down in Tiananmen Square, Mr. Bush secretly dispatched Brent Scowcroft, his national security adviser, to Beijing. The idea was to reassure Beijing's leaders of the President's affections despite the harsh American words about that unfortunate event. Was that trip a clever display of realpolitik or totally insensitive bozocraft?
More than a year ago, Mr. Bush told leaders of an imploding Yugoslavia that the U.S. wanted to keep that country whole. Serb leaders took this as license to use force against breakaway republics. An excusable miscalculation or bozocraft?
Serbs and Croats have been massacring Bosnian Muslims for almost a year. Mr. Bush and his Eurofriends have been feeding the dying victims, but reject even the most limited military steps to defend them, like arming them. Prudent restraint on Mr. Bush's part to avoid another Vietnam -- or phony excuses from bozos who fail to understand the elemental need for humanitarian intervention in any new world order?
After an inexplicably long delay, Mr. Bush offered a hastily drawn plan to assist reform in the ex-Soviet republics. Then, as seems to be his pattern, he ignored the situation -- as the Russian economy collapsed and dangerous right-wingers gained the upper hand on Boris Yeltsin and the reformers, imperiling the dismantling of thousands of nuclear weapons. The distractions of campaigning or a bozo-like carelessness about the centrality of a peaceful Russia in a new world order?
These and other policy flops raise profound doubts about Mr. Bush's reputation for masterly statecraft. They suggest, rather, an arrogant disregard for complexities, a blindness toward new world politics, a bozocraftiness. Now, Mr. Bush says he wants to bring those same attributes to the solution of America's problems at home. Watch your wallet, Millie.

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
Out of the Kitchen

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

 BODY:
In the beginning was the word on the street, and the word was that people were hungry. That was 10 years ago. Holy Apostles Soup Kitchen in New York City served 35 lunches the first day. By the end of the week, it was 60. And when it recently commemorated -- not celebrated, never celebrated -- its 10th anniversary, it was preparing to serve its two millionth meal.
Most days a thousand hungry men, women and children rotate through 69 seats in a small, bright room in the church annex. About eight minutes chow time per person. "Eat It and Beat It" is the diners' motto. 
 This endless Presidential campaign has focused on the middle class, the disappointments of people who feel the rungs of the upward-mobility ladder splintering beneath their feet. While President Bush continues to beat his economic recovery drum, there is this bit of bitter poetic justice from the capital: If Bill Clinton wins, Bush Administration functionaries are expected to have a tough time finding private-sector jobs because the market is so bad.
The forgotten middle class, we say, but the truth is that it's the poor who get overlooked. They have been shadows in this race: the hungry, the homeless, the hopeless. The Census Bureau says that last year 7.7 million families were living below the poverty threshold, which is defined as a family of four getting by on something under $14,000 a year. Almost 36 million people in all. New York City times five.
That's a big number. But it's the small programs that do the most good. Individual. Community based. Government should cut the red tape, hand over the money and stand back. Someone like Jimmy Novack, who stood on bread lines during the Depression, worked for Con Edison for 35 years before his retirement, and now works as chief volunteer at the Holy Apostles Soup Kitchen, has the human touch. Nothing beats it.
The guests are younger than they were when the kitchen first opened, more 35 than 55. Quite a few are H.I.V. positive. Some get in line for lunch at 8 A.M. They don't like beets or prunes, a clear indicator that they're not crazy. For most, what they eat at the church is their only real meal of the day. Drawn on a graph, their numbers look like the Matterhorn: 390 a day in 1983, 560 in 1984, 890 in 1988. Up and up and up through the Reagan-Bush years.
I could talk about polls and strategy today, but in a week none of it will mean anything. The election will be over and the soup kitchen will still be serving a thousand people fish cakes and carrots. I don't know who will win Tuesday. But I can tell you that he needs to wage a new war on poverty.
A weary middle class may not want to hear that. But middle-class Americans will never be truly secure otherwise. The cities in which they work will still be choked with the homeless and the trains on which they ride pocked with panhandlers. Crime will continue to rise and neighborhoods disintegrate. When they pass a line like the one that curls round Holy Apostles each morning, they know that something is wrong with their country.
But, as important, they have come to believe in their hearts that something is wrong with them. You can feel in this election a thirst for something to elevate us, to make us feel like good people again. The next great President of this country will be the one who slakes that thirst, who makes people believe that it's what you can do for your country, and not the other way around.
"This nation has to tap into people's willingness to stretch beyond themselves," the Rev. William A. Greenlaw, rector at Holy Apostles, said at the soup kitchen's anniversary. That's what the volunteers there have done. While we bemoan the loss of small towns and extended families, they have created both in this unwieldy city, among their fellow volunteers and the people they serve. They are part of the solution, and it has fed their souls.
Ten years from now Holy Apostles wants to be out of business. The people who run the soup kitchen never thought they'd be around this long. The Berlin wall fell. The Soviet Union broke up. The President who can say that the soup kitchens and the shelters closed for lack of need during his stewardship will have to his credit a great accomplishment. If he does this for the neediest of our brethren, he will have done it for all of us.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Mass Mailings;
Fliers: Stealth Messages Zero In on Their Targets

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
To citizens who think they have steeled themselves against political assaults from their televisions, beware the reinforcements approaching on another front: their mailboxes.
In Ohio, the state Republican Party is blanketing households with a flier that warns: "What 'Clintonomics' will do to Ohio: Total Ohio Jobs Lost: 384,170. Ohio Can't Afford Bill Clinton." The leaflet contends that 282,636 of those jobs would fall victim to a "Clinton carbon tax." But the premise is false because Mr. Clinton has never proposed a carbon tax, though Senator Al Gore advocated one in his book "Earth in the Balance." 
 In New York, the state Democratic Party is sending out a flier that features not its own slate but photos of President Bush, Vice President Dan Quayle and Senator Alfonse D'Amato with the bold headline, "There's only one thing more frightening than these men controlling the Government." Inside it continues, "These men controlling your body." The flier goes on to say that the Democratic ticket favors abortion rights.
The messages from ideological groups, usually conservative ones, are more sinister. In one letter, the Conservative Campaign Fund warns in page after page that Hillary Clinton is "a radical feminist who has little use for traditional values or even the family unit." It also plays on racial differences, saying that if Governor Clinton wins, Jesse Jackson will claim that "black voters provided the margin of victory."
 
Mail Besieges Voters
 In the days before they vote, millions of Americans are being besieged by leaflets, mailgrams and urgent pleas giving them reasons to vote, or more often, not to vote, for particular Presidential and local candidates.
It is called "persuasion mail," but these messages sometimes stray from the truth and often are intended more as conduits of fear than constructive argument.
In 11th-hour appeals this weekend, the messages are popping up with most frequency in the most contested states. Prime targets are so-called Reagan Democrats who are torn about who to vote for this year.
Mailings are far less costly than television commercials and allow campaigns to tailor their messages to a precise voting group, often down to the zip code or age group. And the mails are well-suited for stealth political warfare: unlike television ads, the opponents and the press often never find out about mailings. Or, if they do, it is too late to rebut them.
 
'Like a Water Moccasin'
 "Direct mail is like a water moccasin," said Roger Carver, a Democratic direct-mail specialist. "It's silent and it's deadly and you only see it after the fact."
In most elections, there is a mix of persuasion mail, to urge fence-sitting voters to favor a particular candidate, and mail designed to simply get people to the polls. But both Republicans and Democrats say there is a more emphasis on persuasion mail this year because the electorate has been so volatile, with many voters still undecided.
Although the Democrats' mail campaigns are more aggressive this year than in the past, the Republicans still seem to be the masters at painting menacing portraits of their opponents.
Voters in Georgia, for instance, are getting leaflets that feature a military uniform and these not-so-subtle words that play on Mr. Clinton's draft history: "Bill Clinton has finally decided he'd like to serve his country."
 
'Sin Against God'
And in one of the harshest attacks, a coalition of Christian conservatives is warning voters around the country that "to vote for Bill Clinton is to sin against God."
Mailings, like radio ads, can carry particularly sinister messages but can be hard to trace. But mail campaigns can select their recipients with more precision than radio and inundate them with information.
Karl Rove, a Republican consultant in Austin, Tex., working for the Bush campaign, said he is sending fliers that emphasize agriculture to South Dakota and Iowa, and fliers that deal more with the military and the economy to states like New Mexico and Illinois.
"People are so skeptical about any negative attack that if we do a negative piece in the mail we can footnote it, we can cite the sources," said Hal Malchow, a consultant here who works for the Democrats. "So it's a more credible form of negative campaigning."

HEADLINE: 6 Months After Riots, Los Angeles Still Bleeds

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 31

 BODY:
Six months after the burning and looting that swept Los Angeles last spring, Joe Chiu has still not rebuilt his gutted meat market in Koreatown or his grocery in Long Beach. The Federal Small Business Administration has approved his $500,000 loan, but his contractors have been turned down for building permits at least three times because city building rules are much stricter now than when he opened 27 years ago.
"They won't meet you halfway," said Mr. Chiu, who is president of an association for Chinese-American riot victims. "The money is there, but there's been no real effort." 
 He is not alone in his frustration over the recovery. A few days after the fires died, President Bush stepped through the burned rubble, offered an "action agenda" on urban needs and told local black youths that the government had "an absolute responsibility to solve these problems." From the Democrats, there were pledges of bipartisan support.
Half a year later, that promise is already lost. Mr. Bush plans to veto the bill that includes two major elements of his plan, enterprise zones to entice new industry to impoverished neighborhoods like South-Central Los Angeles, and $38 million in tax credits to encourage low-income housing. He complained that Congress had loaded down the bill with new taxes and other measures that made it unacceptable.
The veto will be another disappointment to those who hoped the national outpouring of concern over the days of arson, looting and killing would finally bring official attention to neglected areas like South-Central Los Angeles, something more than the trail of forgotten vows left after the Watts riots a generation ago.
 
Momentum Gained, Then Squandered
 Six months after the eruption that left 51 dead and $1 billion in damage, government agencies have moved with varying degrees of success to help individual victims of the violence. But no leader has been able to harness the outpouring of goodwill and community energy that followed the riots and articulate a long-range strategy to solve the problems that produced them.
"We clearly had the attention of government and political leaders," said Denise G. Fairchild, a community organizer who is director of the local office of the Local Initiatives Support Corporation, a nonprofit group that seeks to encourage private investment in low-income housing. "One after another they came marching through the city, including Presidential candidates, and talked about urban aid packages. All of that is lost. What we've seen is a flagrant disregard for the lives of people in the inner city."
The urgency has been underscored in recent days by racial confrontations that have threatened to explode into violence at North Hollywood, Hamilton and other high schools in recent days.
Against this backdrop of economic and social disorder, the region has been plunged into a leadership limbo. Mayor Tom Bradley has announced his retirement, but his successor will not be elected for another year; a new district attorney will be elected Tuesday, along with two new county supervisors. There is a new Police Chief and new Superintendent of Schools. Rebuild L.A., the private entity designated by Mr. Bradley to lead the economic recovery, says that 500 companies will invest $1 billion in the affected areas over the next two years, but it remains hobbled by factionalism and uncertainty of purpose.
"The leadership we need has yet to emerge," said Oscar Wright, a native of South-Central Los Angeles who is regional administrator of the Federal Small Business Administration. "Mayor Bradley has done all that he can, and his absence will create even more of a void. He provided the glue that held this city together. But demographics have changed, so we'll need a mayor who will not just rebuild L.A. but redefine it. There's gloom and desperation out there so thick you can cut it with a knife."
 
What $1.35 Billion Means in Reality
 This is not to say that nothing has been done. Voters have approved a measure limiting the Police Chief's term and bringing the office under tighter control of the Mayor and City Council. The new Chief, Willie Williams, has begun imposing "community based" policing to help erase the department's image as remote and racist. On Tuesday residents will vote on two measures to raise money for 1,000 new officers and to modernize police communications.
The Federal Government has allotted $1.35 billion to Los Angeles riot recovery. So far $251 million has been distributed for a wide array of programs -- from 9,000 extra summer jobs for teen-agers to housing assistance for 2,096 victims to the beginnings of the "weed and seed" program, meant to rid neighborhoods of crime and to establish medical and school programs aimed at the young.
But the Federal impact on recovery is not as great as the figures suggest. Of $300 million for the Federal Emergency Management Agency, or F.E.M.A., more than two-thirds ($218 million) is going to the state and county to help pay for National Guard, state police, debris removal and other immediate riot-control expenses. That leaves only $82 million to help families with rent and temporary housing, and only $19 million of that has actually been spent.
Of the $1.35 billion total, nearly half ($600 million) is in low-interest loans made available to banks by the Federal Home Loan Bank system to finance low-income housing and commercial development. Deputy Mayor Linda Griego says it is not clear how this money can be obtained. Only $23 million has so far been used.
"These things are out there," said David J. Beightol, executive director of the Presidential Task Force on Los Angeles Recovery, who was designated by the White House to coordinate Federal efforts. "People have to take advantage of it. That's the way these government services work."
 
Why the Promises Are Hard to Keep
 Out of this has come considerable frustration. "It would be very, very difficult to find any program that was delivered on," said Roger Cardinal Mahony, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Los Angeles. "All these high-profile promises of the first week were either not deliverable or translatable to people on the street."
And the failure of legislation in both Washington and Sacramento, the state capital, has frustrated Peter V. Ueberroth, the businessman selected by Mayor Bradley to lead Rebuild L.A. "The Federal Government legislatively will not have done one thing since the riot in April," he told the organization's 80-member board on Wednesday, adding that there would have been far more corporate commitments if Federal incentives had been in place. State government has not helped much either, he complained, saying, "There have been a lot of hearings, a lot of people arguing about territory, but nothing happened."
But it is not clear just how much government can do in this economic climate. "With a recession verging on depression in Southern California, what is it reasonable to expect of government?" asked Jane Pisano, dean of the School of Public Administration at the University of Southern California and former president of L.A. 2000, appointed by Mayor Bradley several years ago to develop a strategic plan for the city.
She added that it was reasonable to expect a "clearly articulated" vision to mobilize people and an effort to minimize bureaucratic obstacles. "Government is going about the maintenance task, the hundred and one itty-bitty things, without saying: 'Wait a second -- we have limited resources. We must think in fundamentally new ways of how we spend our time,' " she said.
 
Trying to Sort Out Real From Phony
 On the individual level, the recovery efforts have been hampered by a clash of cultures -- Asian, black, Hispanic, white -- in which inner-city residents and business people take part in an underground economy that often skirts tax laws and other regulations. It does not fit easily into the framework of rules imposed by Washington.
Fewer than half the applications for F.E.M.A. help have been approved, and there have been conflicts between owners of burned-out businesses and the Small Business Administration. The applicants say the agencies have been slow and unresponsive, unwilling or unable to bend rules to accommodate the circumstances.
"We are completely disgusted with the dismal record of F.E.M.A.," said Paul E. Lee, litigation director at the Legal Aid Foundation of Los Angeles. "It is not clear if any actual assistance has been given to the people who need it the most."
Federal officials reply that they have been plagued by dubious or fraudulent claims. There was the real-estate broker in Beverly Hills who wanted F.E.M.A. to pay her $11,000-a-month mortgage on the ground that the riots scared away clients, and the owner of a video dating service who had sold his business before the riots but nevertheless claimed that he lost customers.
In some cases, said Mr. Beightol of the Presidential Task Force, applicants have applied both to F.E.M.A. claiming poverty (to qualify for rent grants) and to the S.B.A. claiming considerable resources (to qualify for business loans). Often, there are no tax records, since taxes were never paid. "If you are not paying taxes, it is pretty hard to come back and ask the system to support you," Mr. Beightol said.
F.E.M.A. has denied 3,703 of 6,667 applications, or 55 percent. Lorri L. Jean, the agency's deputy regional director, conceded that such a denial rate looked bad but added, "We're doing our best, but these advocacy groups won't be happy unless F.E.M.A. workers stand on street corners handing out money based on nothing more than people's word."
Los Angeles is also an early laboratory for the Government's new "weed and seed" program, which plans to spend $19 million here, though some local agencies have refused to take part because it requires them to submit to oversight from the Justice Department.
The Watts Health Foundation has taken a share to send a medical van to the new Paradise Market at Broadway and 52d Street, where a large, bright-green tent festooned with flags sits atop rows of orange and yellow stalls selling Nigerian blouses, Mexican skirts, food, drink and toys.
"We're involved in the seed portion," said Dr. Clyde W. Oden, president of the foundation, which provides free health care in the market five days a week. "We've developed the concept of mobile medical technology for the past five years. But prior to the rebellion, we did not have these kinds of resources available. What we envisaged was to take a physician's office and put it on wheels."
But if government has spawned such efforts, it has failed to mobilize the larger community, to bring together a city that is often defeated by a vast geography that separates people and cultures. "What has fallen away is the engagement of folks outside the community," said Terri Jones of the California Community Foundation, which supports local cultural and community activities. "Corporate and suburban L.A. is going back to business as usual and leaving South-Central to take care of its own problems. Maybe expectations were too high to begin with."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Looking Ahead;
Clinton Could Claim a Mandate, but It Might Be Hard to Define

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
 If Bill Clinton is elected President on Tuesday, he will doubtless claim a mandate from the voters. But in this season of voter discontent, what exactly would that mean?
"There will be a mandate to act," said Sandy Maisel, a political scientist at Colby College in Maine. "It is not clear what action. Just action. There is this pent-up desire simply to do something." 
 There is no consensus that such a mandate would be enough to win approval of the bold policies that Mr. Clinton has promised in job creation, universal health insurance, taxes, public works spending and student aid.
Many authorities side with Joel H. Silbey, a historian at Cornell University, who holds that Presidents create their own mandates independent of their election campaigns. "Once you're elected, you're President," Professor Silbey said. "Successful Presidents are those who read that the fact that they won is enough to do everything they want."
 
Desire in Congress
 That was certainly true of Abraham Lincoln and Franklin D. Roosevelt. Lincoln won less than 40 percent of the vote in a four-way race in 1860, and Roosevelt gave little indication in the 1932 campaign of the New Deal policies he pursued immediately on taking office.
And Mr. Clinton's position would be strengthened by the apparent desire of Democrats in Congress to work with a Democratic President.
Mr. Clinton himself has carefully avoided talking about what his mandate might be. His staff said he does not want to appear overconfident.
But the prevailing view now is that Mr. Clinton, if he wins, will have a harder time rallying Congress and the public than would be the case if he had been more specific in the campaign about what he wanted to do as President.
His campaign themes have often been contradictory. He favors stimulating the economy and cutting the budget deficit. He wants to provide universal health insurance and lower the Government's medical bills. He wants the United States to be the leader in world affairs, but he proposes reducing the American military presence abroad. He advocates protecting American jobs, but he says he also supports free trade and strict environmental regulations.
 
Call for a Plan Early
 "There's a mandate for change, but not a mandate for a program," said Harry C. McPherson Jr., who was White House counsel under President Lyndon B. Johnson. Mr. Clinton, Mr. McPherson said, "has got to put together a program pretty quickly that will win the assent of the American people."
In the last 30 years or so, the most successful chief executives in attaining their goals, Johnson and Ronald Reagan, were also the ones who had been most specific in their campaigns about what they hoped to accomplish in the White House.
"If you voted for Johnson," Mr. McPherson said, "you knew you were going to get a civil rights law, Medicare, aid to education. You knew you were going to get what came to be called the Great Society."
Similarly, Mr. Reagan left no doubt that he intended to cut taxes, trim the welfare state and beef up the military.
Both had their greatest successes in the first year after their elections, when their campaigns and their sizable electoral majorities were fixed in the minds of Congress and the public.
On the other hand, Presidents like George Bush and Jimmy Carter, who ran less programmatic campaigns, were less successful in getting their policies adopted after they were elected. Mr. Carter's principal theme, in the aftermath of Watergate, was that he would run an honest Government. Mr. Bush's main precept four years ago was that he would continue on Mr. Reagan's course.
In this respect, Mr. Clinton's campaign has been more like the Bush and Carter campaigns than like the Johnson and Reagan ones. But the campaign it resembles most is John F. Kennedy's.
Like Mr. Clinton, Kennedy's main argument in 1960 was that the country needed a more active President after years of rather passive Republican rule. But for all the changes in tone and style he brought to Washington, Kennedy actually accomplished relatively little of substance in his nearly three years in office.
"Kennedy had very little leverage," wrote Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., the historian and Kennedy biographer. He had been elected "by the slimmest of margins; no one could possibly claim his victory as a mandate for change."
In the same vein, Stuart E. Eizenstat, a top policy adviser in the Carter White House, said Mr. Carter's lack of a clear mandate was a drawback. "Mandates do make a big difference," Mr. Eizenstat said. "They give you the only real legitimacy you have to try to impose your priorities on Congress and your own executive branch."
 
Congress on His Side
 Despite the nature of his campaign, Mr. Clinton would have an advantage in the White House that Presidents Kennedy, Carter and Bush did not enjoy: Congress should be enthusiastically on his side.
Congress in the Kennedy and Carter years, though controlled by Democrats, was antagonistic toward the President. In the case of Kennedy, it was because the Southern Democrats who dominated Congress had little use for the Administration's programs. In the case of Carter, it was a combination of the arrogance of Congressional leaders and the contempt the White House showed toward the lawmakers. Mr. Bush faced the largest opposition in Congress of any new President ever elected.
But now, after 12 years of Republican rule, Democrats are expected to control the Senate and House with strong majorities, and these lawmakers say they are dying to follow the lead of a Democratic President.
"We very much want a Democrat to succeed," said Senator Jim Sasser of Tennessee. "The mind set is that we've got to move forward while we can and prove that a Democratic Congress can succeed."
Representative Robert T. Matsui of California said that Democrats shaken by the anti-incumbent fever that seemed to sweep the country early this year would be determined, if re-elected, to prove to the voters that they could be productive.
"It is in our own self-interest to make this Democratic President look good," Mr. Matsui said. It did not go unnoticed on Capitol Hill, he added, that Mr. Clinton spent time and money recently campaigning in states like California, Washington and Oregon, where he seems to have insurmountable leads but where Democratic candidates for the House and Senate are in close races and can benefit by his appearances.
Still, the success of Presidents is generally measured by their actions, not their ideas, and lawmakers and scholars alike agree that Mr. Clinton would have to move swiftly to develop specific legislative solutions to the country's economic and social problems that he maintains have festered under Mr. Bush.
"Clinton must stop just saying, 'I'm not George Bush,' and begin defining exactly what the future is," said Donald F. Kettl, a political scientist at the University of Wisconsin.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Ronald Reagan;
Vintage Reagan Stumps in South

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SMYRNA, Ga., Oct. 31

 BODY:
Speaking shortly before Bill Clinton held a rally on the other side of Atlanta, Ronald Reagan offered an artful blend of nostalgia, theater and politics as he campaigned on behalf of President Bush in this Southern battleground state today.
"I know today is Halloween, a time for ghosts and goblins and other scary things," Mr. Reagan told a small but adoring crowd of perhaps 1,500 people at a suburban amphiteater just outside Atlanta. "But this year be on the lookout for a couple of tricksters who have been on the prowl for months. They may have the best costumes we've seen in in a while, but under those masks are a couple of tax-and-spenders who will scare the daylights out of your pocketbooks." 
 Reprising many of the themes he offered at the Republican National Convention in Houston, the former President defended the achievements of 12 years of Republican control of the White House and attacked Mr. Clinton in remarks that left Mr. Reagan wrapped not only in the American flag, but also in the banner of the popular Atlanta Braves. The trip here was part of a weekend of campaigning by the former President on behalf of his successor.
Mr. Reagan's spirited but relatively genial remarks followed several more heated ones reflecting the anything-goes, white-hot attacks on Mr. Clinton's character, particularly in the conservative South.
 
The Press vs. the Bible
 Daniel Becker, a Republican candidate for Congress in Georgia's Ninth Congressional District, contrasted the press with the Bible in his attacks on Mr. Clinton. While the mainstream news media are touting the Arkansas Governor as the next President, Mr. Becker said, "What my journal calls him" is "a rebellious, philandering, fornicating, adulterating liar."
He added, to loud applause, "My publication doesn't say he's going to the White House, it says he's going to hell."
Mr. Reagan spoke after an airplane circled overhead with the message, "Win One For The Gipper," and after Newt Gingrich, the House Republican whip, introduced him as "the man who changed history."
Seizing on a Commerce Department report on Tuesday showing that the economy grew at a rate of 2.7 percent in the third quarter, Mr. Reagan derided what he described as the Democrats' overly gloomy economic outlook.
"Today we hear the despairing voice of the Doomsday Democrats who gave us the turmoil of the 1960's and the malaise of the 1970's," he said. "To hear the Democratic politicians, things are so bad that down at McDonald's even the Happy Meals are depressed."
 
Reagan-Bush Era Praised
 Much of the speech was a defense of what he said happened "on our watch." He cited a revitalized military, lower inflation and interest rates and the end of the cold war as part of an effort to cast support for the President in the broad sweep of the Reagan-Bush era.
And, in terms less harsh than the earlier speakers and Mr. Bush himself, he cast Mr. Clinton as an unacceptable alternative. "We simply can't afford to put an inexperienced fellow in the White House, particularly one with a dismal track record as a small-state Governor," he said.
In the end, Mr. Reagan stood in front of an American flag backdrop with Francisco Cabrera, whose pinch-hit single put the Atlanta Braves into the World Series. The Braves' unlikely hero gave Mr. Reagan a bat. The former President signed a baseball for him, and the flag-waving crowd did the Braves' tomahawk chop in a made-for-television finale.
Despite, the modest turnout, most of those on hand clearly still view Mr. Reagan with awe. "He's been my idol since I've been 5 years old," said Adam Cathey, an 18-year-old from nearby Powder Springs, who said he planned to cast his first vote for Mr. Bush.
Republicans said they hoped Mr. Reagan's appearance would provide a lift to Mr. Bush in this fiercely contested state. At the least, it gave the Republicans an attractive offering to local television stations to compete with Mr. Clinton, whose Brave-for-the-day was the home run king Hank Aaron.
"It was vintage Reagan," said an admiring Paul Coverdell, the Republican Senate candidate who is running against the Democratic incumbent, Wyche Fowler Jr.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Voters;
A Handful of Midwest Fence-Sitters Climb Down to Say, 'Oh, O.K., Him'

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 31

 BODY:
They watched the debates and the "info-mercials," heard the zingers and sound bites and have had enough of Iraqgate, family values and the character question.
For undecided voters looking for a prince but finding they must settle for a politician, the choice has come down to a patrician President whom they see as out of touch, a smooth-talking Governor who they fear is promising more than he can deliver, and a likable but somewhat paranoid businessman who they think could be a dictator. 
 (Translation: President Bush, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas and Ross Perot of Texas.)
A group of Midwestern voters who were undecided when they were interviewed by The New York Times earlier in the campaign were revisited in the last two days. Many are people who have flirted with and spurned all three candidates over the months, and now there is yearning in their voices.
 
Warts on Them All
 "None of them have impressed me," said Jerry Dunn, a sales representative in Rockford, Ill. "None of them have pinpointed what they are going to do. Bush doesn't seem like he will cooperate with Congress. Clinton says he's going to do a lot but doesn't realize all there is to do. Ross Perot lost credibility when he dropped out."
Mr. Dunn was not finished. He had not come to the part about the candidates' proposals, which he does not like any more than he likes the candidates.
"Those plans are junk," he said. "They have no idea what they're talking about. They're not in the trenches. They're not out here to see us getting laid off and people getting divorced because they're not making money. They are out of touch with reality. If you put them in a gunny sack and shook them up, they'd all be the same."
It seems as true in politics as it is in romance that you always want what you cannot have. Mr. Dunn still wants Paul E. Tsongas, the former Massachusetts Senator.
Many voters who have remained undecided are Democrats who were lured out of their party by Ronald Reagan, then stayed with George Bush in 1988. Now these Reagan Democrats are looking homeward, not so much out of party devotion but because they feel the Republicans have let them down.
They started out torn between Mr. Clinton, Mr. Tsongas and the other politicians seeking the Democratic nomination. They were riven by the "character" questions hurled at Mr. Clinton, thought they had found a savior in Mr. Perot until he quit the race, looked again to President Bush, and have Ping-Ponged between the three ever since.
 
Going to Clinton, With Doubts
 Now many of them say with reservations and a sigh that they are going with Mr. Clinton. In the next breath, they talk about Mr. Bush and how things could have been different. Some are even more wistful about Mr. Perot.
"I don't really want to, but I have to go with Clinton," said Terri Bowler, a homemaker in the heart of Reagan Democrat country -- Macomb County, Mich. "President Bush has been acting like a baby, whining about Congress."
Edward Habecker, a Peoria lawyer who voted for President Bush, said he'd been alienated by the Bush campaign's attacks on Mr. Clinton and its late-offered proposals to improve the economy.
"I agree that character is an issue, but it's George Bush's character I question," Mr. Habecker said. "The cynicism has worn me down. He just realized within the last month or two that we had to do something about health care. He had four years to get busy with this. I don't think his heart is in it."
 
'Bush Is Inaccessible'
 The Rose Garden mentality has turned off Nancy Jeffrey, a nurse in suburban Hometown, Ill., outside Chicago. "I feel George Bush is inaccessible," Mrs. Jeffrey said. "There are homeless people right in front of the White House. I think he is aware of the problem, but I don't think he has a clue."
She is also weary of the family values mantra. "I think Bush really blew that out of proportion with his entire family on stage," Mrs. Jeffrey said of the Republican National Convention. "O.K., everybody has a family. I don't think we need the Bush family show. It was a little bit of overkill. I hate that."
But Thomas Russell, a computer consultant in Peoria, is looking at retirement in a couple of years and does not want any surprises. That is why he is sticking with President Bush.
"The problems with the economy are not so much a result of what Bush has done or not done," Mr. Russell said. "The recession is worldwide. I'd rather go with Bush and the status quo than to give a blank check to Clinton. I don't expect any great improvement with Bush. I just don't want it to get worse."
Patrick Mantel, a factory worker in Springfield, Ill., said he wished he could vote for the man he really wants to see in the White House.
"My gut's telling me to vote Ross Perot," Mr. Mantel said. "He talks so that people like me can understand him. He really makes a lot of sense. It's killing me. I got enough common sense to see the man won't get elected. I know that if I vote for him, Bush will get back in. What would be the use of it? If he'd have stayed in ---- " His voice trailed off.
"So I figure," Mr. Mantel said, "why not get it over with and vote for Clinton?"
"Being a working man," he said, I'm going to get it either way.
 
Down on Politicians
 He likes Mr. Perot for not being a politician and is skeptical of Mr. Clinton because is so very much one. "I think Clinton bends both sides of the fence," Mr. Mantel said. "He tells it like he sees it at the place he's at. The man wants to get elected. That's a politician for you."
While these people like Mr. Perot, they see him as a somewhat paranoid authoritarian who sees plots around every corner and who would not be able to work in the system. "He would have been good back in the days of the kings," said Sally McQuellon, a legal secretary in Peoria. "You've got to love him. It's too bad the government is not a business."
One reason many of these voters are turning to Mr. Clinton is that they are resigned to higher taxes, rejecting one of the Republicans' primary arguments.
"I think taxes are going up no matter who gets in," said James Szalkie, an automobile worker in River Rouge, Mich., who said he had voted for the winner in every election since John F. Kennedy and is supporting Mr. Clinton this time.
There was not much evidence in the second round of interviews that many Reagan-Bush Democrats were accepting the Republican line that Mr. Clinton cannot be trusted. But they were quick to say that they are prepared to vote Mr. Clinton out in a minute.
"I don't think it's a leap into the unknown," Mr. Habecker said. "He's a middle-of-the-road politician who may be a little left of center. He's not an idiot. He wants to be re-elected. I don't expect him to turn the apple cart upside down. If he fails he's gone."
Mr. Dunn is not so sure. This late in the game he still cannot decide. "I don't know who I'm going to vote for," Mr. Dunn said. "I was leaning toward Clinton. Now I'm leaning toward Bush. I just don't know. I am turning them off because they are turning me off. I'm vacillating more on this one than I ever have. What I'm looking for ain't there."

HEADLINE: Texas Banks Closed; Bailout May Cost $500 Million

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
Federal banking authorities said they have closed the First City Bancorporation of Houston, one of the largest banks in Texas, after finding that its two largest subsidiaries were insolvent.
Officials of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said Friday night that the Government would have to put up about $500 million to protect depositors in First City and its 20 bank subsidiaries, which had total assets of $8.8 billion, and prepare the bank for sale to private interests. 
 Regulators said the $500 million bank bailout would be the 10th-largest ever.
This is the second time in four years that the Government has been forced to spend heavily to deal with First City's troubles. In 1988, the F.D.I.C. contributed an emergency infusion of $900 million toward a bailout plan in which a new owner took control of the bank.
 
104th Closing This Year
 The closing of First City highlights the continued problems of many banks even as the industry as a whole is enjoying record profits because of low interest rates. Friday night's move by the F.D.I.C. brought the number of banks closed so far this year to 104, with combined assets of $36.6 billion.
Federal regulators said all offices of the 20 banking subsidiaries of First City would be open Monday, but as bridge banks under F.D.I.C. control. Federal regulators said they hoped to sell the subsidiaries to private owners within three months.
Analysts said that the Chemical Banking Corporation, which already owns the Houston-based Texas Commerce Bank, had expressed interest in acquiring all or part of First City.
Andrew C. Hove Jr., acting chairman of the F.D.I.C., said depositors in the 16 First City subsidiaries that had adequate capital would be fully protected, even the 5,700 accounts in excess of the $100,000 insurance limits.
But it will be a different story for depositors in First City's four subsidiaries in Houston, Dallas, Austin and San Antonio that did not have sufficient capital. While deposits of less than $100,000 will be fully protected, depositors with accounts in excess of $100,000 will receive just 80 percent of their uninsured amount. Those 5,000 accounts with a combined $260 million might receive more than that if sales of the bank's assets exceed expectations.
Stephen R. Steinbrink, the acting Comptroller of the Currency, said his office moved to close First City after an examination of the First City Bank of Houston, the holding company's largest subsidiary, found that a management-led plan to revive the bank was inadequate.
His office found that First City of Houston, with $2.6 billion in assets, needed to make additional provisions for its reserve to cover potential loan losses. But because the bank had just $15 million in capital, Federal regulators deemed the bank insolvent.
To explain why the F.D.I.C. took this delicate move now, just four days before Election Day and in President Bush's home state, Mr. Steinbrink said, "Once we clearly identify that a bank is insolvent, we must act."
He said First City had submitted a plan to raise more capital by selling 13 subsidiary banks, but added that regulators found the plan would not do enough to shore up First City's capital.
Also Friday, the Texas Banking Commissioner, Catherine A. Ghiglieri, closed First City's subsidiary in Dallas after finding it insolvent.
First City has been an object of concern among regulators for years. Four years ago, the bank received the infusion of more than $900 million from the F.D.I.C. as part of a bailout plan that made A. Robert Abboud, the former chairman of the First Chicago Corporation, First City's chairman with a mandate to turn the bank's fortunes around. But the real estate slump and an aggressive foray into foreign lending continued to generate losses and prompted criticism of the chairman's free-wheeling style.
 
Merger Abandoned
 In August, First City gave up on its search for a merger partner and announced a plan to raise capital to meet regulatory standards without Federal intervention.
Federal regulators said they had ousted First City's top two executives and had named Edward G. Harshfield, a longtime banker, to head the bank.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Survey Cited to Assail Bush on Overseas Jobs

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS

 BODY:
A Democratic Congressman made public yesterday a study of an American foreign aid program, saying it demonstrated how financing provided by the Reagan and Bush Administrations was used to subsidize the movement of manufacturing jobs to Central America from the United States.
The survey, by the Price Waterhouse accounting concern, was of 25 companies, foreign as well as American, that opened plants in Costa Rica from 1986 to 1990. It found that 20 of the concerns had decided to do so as a result of efforts by a Costa Rican trade group that receives funds from the Agency for International Development. 
 At least 10 of the companies said they had not considered manufacturing in a less developed country until they were approached by the group, the Costa Rican Coalition of Development Initiatives.
Results of the survey were made public by Representative George E. Brown Jr. of California, who said more than a dozen American companies had been interviewed. The study gave no precise number. Nor were the responses of the American concerns separated from those of foreign manufacturers.
The survey was commissioned by A.I.D. as part of an audit of the Costa Rican group. The study did not examine how many American jobs might have been lost as a result of the companies' decisions to manufacture in Costa Rica.
The United States agency's support for Central American economies has come under criticism as the creation of jobs has grown as an issue in the Presidential campaign.
President Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle have denied that the Administration has subsidized the relocation of manufacturing jobs to Central America and the Caribbean. Rather, Bush Administration officials say, the foreign aid program is meant to recruit American companies that are already planning to expand overseas, steering them toward Central America and the Caribbean instead of the Far East.
 
Policy Defended
 "The trade groups we work with recruit United States companies which have decided to go into production offshore," said Kelly J. Presta, a spokesman for the international development agency. "We're only interested in working with companies that already made that decision, not in soliciting companies to leave. Anything that contradicts that would not be in concert with our policies."
Mr. Brown, who is chairman of the House Science, Space and Technology Committee, said in an interview he is planning hearings next year on the foreign aid program. Earlier this month, Congress ordered an investigation of the program and passed legislation ordering the agency not to finance any more programs that could result in the loss of American jobs.

HEADLINE: Vote on the Issues, and May the Best Man Win;
He Led Us to Peace

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Within days we elect the next President of the United States. As I watched the debates and read the commentaries in newspapers and news magazines, I reflected on a precedent that might repeat itself. 
 I recall that Britain, in the election immediately following the defeat of Germany in World War II, but before the surrender of Japan, voted Sir Winston Churchill out as Prime Minister and Clement Attlee in. Within six years Britain again summoned its greatest statesman and wartime leader, Winston Churchill, back to serve as Prime Minister.
As the father of three draft-age sons and two daughters who are now able to plan their lives without taking into consideration military service or the dangers that haunted this nation during the cold war, I find it difficult to believe that the American people have reduced the nation's highly successful foreign policy of the last 12 years to an insignificant consideration in their selection of leadership for the next four years.
I recently visited the three Scandinavian countries. Like the rest of the world, they are experiencing economic recession. Many individuals with whom I spoke, however, seemed amazed at the vitality of the United States in resisting the worldwide slowdown. Our free enterprise system has experienced recessions, no matter who occupied the White House. Anyone older than 30 can recall one or more recessions from which the country bounced back.
We should think twice before we punish the architects of victory in the cold war. The promises of short-term economic gains or of change for the sake of change appear to come from those who are without the wisdom of experience. Britain made that mistake -- let us learn from its experience.
 
GEORGE P. MC ANDREWS
Barrington, Ill., Oct. 23, 1992

HEADLINE: Talking: Closing Costs;
Lenders And Sellers Helping

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
BECAUSE the depressed economy is making it difficult for borrowers to come up with the cash to pay mortgage loan closing costs, lenders and sellers are being forced to do more to help.
"Nobody has any cash anymore," said Michael Sovereign, manager of the Buffalo office of Norwest Mortgage Inc., a national lender. "And even if they do, they're afraid to use it." 
 The borrower traditionally needed the cash to cover mortgage origination charges and costs for inspection, appraisal, title insurance, legal services and recording fees. The charges, averaging about 5 percent of the loan amount, or about $5,000 on a $100,000 loan, customarily applied whether the borrower was actually buying the home or refinancing a mortgage.
Programs being offered include those that pay some or all of those costs in exchange for a slightly higher rate of interest on the loan. Others offer similar waivers without the added interest charges. However, these offers are normally limited to moderate-income or first-time buyers.
Still other lenders will make the concession, but only if the buyer actually asks for it, warned Paul Havemann, vice president of HSH Associates of Butler, N.J., a mortgage advisory service.
Sellers have also begun picking up such costs to help make their homes more salable. At the very least, they can be persuaded to do so in exchange for a slightly higher purchase price, said Phyllis Bixon, a regional vice president with Weichert Realty.
Consider what happened to Mohan Menon, a vice president at the CIT group, a financial services company with headquarters in Livingston, N.J. He owns a contemporary-style home in Denville, N.J., which he had been eager to refinance. He wanted to exchange his $146,000, 9.25 percent, fixed-rate loan for a newer one with a rate of 7.125 percent.
However, since he was in the financial world he was aware that even the best offer is often negotiable if you ask. So when he walked into the office of Globe Mortgage in Hackensack, N.J., earlier this fall, he quickly discovered that all his closing expenses could be folded into the loan if he was prepared to add $4,000 to the loan amount.
It was well worthwhile, he concluded, because even though he would be borrowing a little extra, he would still be paying $200 less each month than under the old mortgage because of the lower interest rate. Moreover, he didn't have to use up precious cash.
Vicky Papson, a loan officer with Columbia Equities, which lends in the metropolitan area, said borrowers in New York State could further reduce their closing costs by finding ways to eliminate or lower the state's hefty mortgage recording tax.
Different in size, depending on the county or city, it is currently 1.75 percent in New York City and Nassau County (an amount that translates into $1,750 on a $100,000 loan) and around three-quarters of one percent in many other parts of the state.
Tim Walters, vice president and counsel at Globe Mortgage, explained that borrowers could do so by asking their lender or the seller, whichever is applicable, to arrange for the old loan to be assigned to the new lender. When this is done, he said, the borrower is responsible for paying tax only on the difference between the old and new amount. Only in a handful of instances should it not be possible because of restrictions in the old loan's documents.
Chemical Bank of New York began its "Low Closing Cost" program in September. It saves a typical borrower about $2,000 by waiving or paying, on the borrower's behalf, the points (origination) charges, the document preparation fee, the bank attorney's fee, the appraisal fee and title insurance costs. It is available only to residents of New York City who qualify as first-time buyers with a household income below $60,750. And it may not be extended beyond this fall.
However, New York City buyers who fall into this category should find similar, albeit slightly less generous, reductions, at Republic Bank and Manhattan Savings Bank, among others.
THE 18-month-old "Ninety" program from Norwest Mortgage Inc., of Des Moines, Iowa, handles the issue slightly differently. If the borrower is willing to make a down payment of at least 10 percent, Norwest, which lends in most states, will pay almost all closing costs and origination charges in exchange for adding about three-quarters of a percentage point to the interest rate.
The Fleet Mortgage Group, headquartered in Columbia, S.C., is offering a similar deal under its "Cost Cutter Program." So is American Residential Mortgage, headquartered in La Jolla, Calif., under its "no fee" program.
Peter J. Wissinger, Norwest's senior vice president, estimates that the total value of the Norwest offer is around $5,100 on a $100,000 purchase, enough to let any borrower who had been expecting to make a $5,000 down payment raise that to $10,000 if the borrower had been holding back extra cash to meet closing costs.
Monthly payments would not be any larger, even with the higher interest rate, he said, because the loan would be smaller. Moreover, the borrower would have twice as much equity in the home instead of consuming the money in fees.
But a word of warning. Borrowers will probably still have to come up with the cash needed to establish an escrow account equal to a year's worth of real estate taxes. They must also pay for their own lawyer, if they use one, and the first year's premium on a homeowner's insurance policy. Norwest also charges $90 to register for the program.
It may therefore pay to negotiate with the sellers as well, since they may be willing to cover these extras, too.
Working with a seller can also augment any program offered by the lender. That was the strategy chosen, for example, by Michele Smith, an administrative secretary in a vocational high school in Kingston, N.Y.
Although she had signed on for a low-cost closing program from her lender, she asked the sellers to provide a further $1,500 toward incidentals not covered by the program. In exchange, she offered them the full asking price of $48,800 for their two-bedroom ranch-style house. "Without the extra money I couldn't have closed," she said.
Anyone eager to negotiate with a seller should ask the agent to include closing costs in the initial offer, said Harriet Haffner, president of Haffner Realty of Norwalk, Conn. This way it becomes part of the overall negotiations and will be included in the contract as a condition of sale.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 8, 1992, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
The Talking column last Sunday, about closing costs, misstated the mortgage recording tax on loans for homes in Nassau County. It is 0.75 percent, less $25.
