HEADLINE: WINTER IN THE SUN;
Carribean Resorts: The High Points

BYLINE: By STANLEY CARR

 BODY:
PEOPLE in the Caribbean, a region very vulnerable to problems that affect tourism, think they deserve a break. The last winter that was termed good for the volume of North American visitors was 1988-89. Since then tourism has been hurt by Hurricane Hugo, the Persian Gulf war and the North American recession.
In the first four months of 1992, visitors increased by 4 percent over last year, according to figures supplied by the islands, with the rise coming largely from Canadians and Europeans. The number of visitors from the United States remained flat. Furthermore, the figures were not enough to overcome the 9 percent drop in the first four months of 1991, during the gulf war. With a few exceptions, the lodging industry has resisted raising rates in view of the recession. 
 Many islands have also been frustrated by the demise last year of Eastern and Pan American, with the Bahamas, Barbados and Jamaica among those affected. The collapse of Pan American last December, says a spokeswoman for the Caribbean Tourism Organization, has been as big a factor for tourism in the region as the recession. For the most part other airlines have not filled the gap, she says, although American has increased its flights to the San Juan hub and in some cases onward from there. There are now generally fewer flights, and vacationers should make airline reservations early.
One island group that was especially hurt by the loss of Pan Am was the Turks and Caicos. American plans to start daily jet service between Miami and Providenciales in the Turks and Caicos on Dec. 18. BWIA International Airways plans to introduce nonstop flights today between Miami and St. Kitts three days a week and St. Lucia four days a week, with continuing service to Trinidad.
Despite the problems, hotel investors continue to refurbish and expand resorts and occasionally build properties. A cottage complex called Le Toiny has just opened on St. Barthelemy, and a Club Med is scheduled to open on San Salvador, the Bahamas, next month. Like St. Martin, St. Lucia has direct air service from the United States, and has two new hotels, the Jalousie Plantation and the Wyndham Morgan Bay Resort.
All-inclusive resorts, those that offer meals, drinks, sports and other services under one price, continue to grow. Sandals, the Jamaica-based all-inclusive operation, has taken over two Cunard hotels, La Toque in St. Lucia and the Paradise Beach in Barbados, and plans to convert them to one-price resorts next year. The company also plans to build its seventh all-inclusive in Jamaica. Superclubs, another all-inclusive operation, says it wants to build a hotel in Grenada.
The following review of Caribbean islands and the Bahamas offers a selection of hotels noted for a particular quality: being situated on one of the best local beaches or enjoying an exceptional setting, offering good sports facilities or fine food in its restaurant, or serving as a haven for visitors who want to avoid resort bustle. In this category, headed Tranquillity, choices range from the Peach and Quiet on the shore in Inch Marlow, Barbados ($69 a day for a room) and the Calabash on Prickly Bay in Grenada (from $295, including breakfast dinner and afternoon tea) to a quiet in-town mansion, the San Jose in Old San Juan (from $160).
Rates listed are, unless otherwise stated, for a room for two per day during the winter season, which generally runs from Dec. 15 to mid-April. This month and in early December, rates are about 60 percent of high-season prices. Many places also have M.A.P. (modified American plan), providing breakfast and dinner at an additional daily rate. Some, including the all-inclusive resorts, offer a full meal plan; all-inclusives also include taxes and service in their prices. Government taxes on hotel rooms range from 7 to 15 percent and are added to guests' bills. Many hotels also add a service charge, usually 10 percent. Travelers should ask about tax and service charges when they make reservations.
 
Anguilla
 
NGUILLA TOURIST INFORMATION OFFICE
271 MAIN STREET, NORTHPORT, N.Y. 11768
(800) 553-4939 and (212) 869-0402
Sports Facilities
Several of Anguilla's hotels are well situated and equipped for sports; among them is the Mariners, a cluster of gingerbread cottages amid sea grape trees at Sandy Ground. The cottages have hand-crafted lattice and carved trim, wooden shutters, high ceilings with fans and shaded verandas. Use of the Mariners' water sports equipment, including Sunfish sailboats and wind surfing boards, is included in the all-inclusive rate, which also covers tennis, all meals, afternoon tea, wine and other drinks and boat excursions. Rooms and suites start at $210 a day on the all-inclusive program. A diving program with all meals and a two-tank dive or night dive daily, is also available. (809) 497-2671.
Cap Juluca, a resort with 85 rooms and 13 suites on a beach stretching for more than a mile at Maunday's Bay -- the longer Cove Beach is nearby -- is also equipped for sports. It has three tennis courts, two lighted for night play, and a tennis professional gives lessons. The use of Sunfish boats, snorkel gear, wind surfers and Hobie cats is free to guests. Good snorkeling can be done at Cap Juluca's beach, and deep-sea fishing, water sports instruction, scuba and day sailing can be arranged. The 1,800-square-foot fresh water pool has private tanning areas nearby.
Rooms in winter are from $390 to $475; suites are from $600. Rates include Continental breakfast. (809) 497-6779 or (800) 323-0139.
Natural Setting
 The striking Moorish-style Malliouhana has a clifftop position overlooking Meads Bay. Tall arches, tiled roofs, open-air salons and balustrades decked with flowers accent the gleaming white buildings. Inside there are white tiled floors, beds on rattan platforms and louvered doors opening onto terraces overlooking the sea. White bougainvillea blooms around a series of terraced swimming pools.
Enclosed by three stretches of beach, the hotel is strong on water sports facilities and has tennis courts, too. There are 55 rooms, with rates starting at $500 a day -- without meals -- this winter. (809) 497-6111.
Fine Food
 The Palm Court at the Cinnamon Reef was voted top hotel restaurant in a culinary competition on the island last year. At this open-air restaurant with sea views from every table, the chefs, Didier Rochat and Vernon Hughes, serve what they call new Caribbean cuisine. Among entrees are charcoal grilled yellowfin tuna with cinnamon tomato sauce and swordfish steak with passion fruit salsa. The average bill is around $75 a couple, not including wine.
The Cinnamon Reef, on the beach at Little Harbour, is scheduled to reopen today after refurbishing that began last June and included repainting of all 22 villa suites. Each unit has split level bedroom-living room and private patio facing the Caribbean. Daily rates are from from $250, Continental breakfast included. (809) 497-2727 or (800) 223-1108.
 
Antigua
 
ANTIGUA DEPARTMENT OF TOURISM
610 FIFTH AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10020
(212) 541-4117
Great Beach
 Jumby Bay is on its own island, the 300-acre Long Island off Antigua's north coast. It is reached by taking a 10-minute taxi ride from V. C. Bird International Airport to a private dock, where a launch picks up passengers for the 15-minute crossing. The 38 suites, with ceiling fans, all overlook the ocean and beaches. The resort serves meals in its beach pavilion or in the restored 200-year-old Estate House. Facilities for guests' use at no extra charge range from three tennis courts, two lighted at night, to water skiing and instruction, snorkeling, sailboats, bicycles and laundry service. Rate: $895 a night, for two, including all meals, drinks and afternoon tea. (809) 462-6000 or (800) 421-9016.
On another fine beach, at Dickenson Bay at the island's northwest tip, is the Halcyon Cove Beach Resort. There are four restaurants, a pool, tennis courts, all water sports and entertainment. The Halcyon Cove is a 15-minute taxi ride from St. John's, the capital.
The 129 rooms and suites have air-conditioning and telephones. Room rates range from $200 to $370, double. (809) 462-0256 or (800) 255-5859.
St. James's Club is on a peninsula jutting into Mamora Bay at the southeast corner of the island near English Harbour and Nelson's Dockyard. Tennis, horseback riding, water sports, four pools, an exercise room, a croquet court, four restaurants and a small casino are the diversions here. The accommodations consist of 73 two-bedroom villas, 20 suites and 85 rooms, all with ocean views. Breakfast and dinner are included in rates ranging from $500 to $950 a night, double. (809) 460-5000 or (212) 486-2575.
Fine Food
 Elaine Murphy's Guesthouse serves some of the island's best food at the Dolphin, the restaurant she operates in conjunction with her seven-bedroom guesthouse. The restaurant, next door, specializes in local variations of conch, lobster, cod, duckna (sweet potatoes and coconut wrapped in banana leaves and cooked like a patty), eggplant, creole and curried chicken and rice. The coconut meringue pie is a favorite dessert. Dinner costs on average about $20 a person, not including drinks.
At the guesthouse, ceiling fans have been installed and rooms redecorated recently. The guesthouse and the restaurant are on All Saints Road in the residential outskirts of St. John's, a 10-minute walk from town and on a bus route. The room rate of $55 a night for two includes breakfast. (809) 461-1183.
Natural Setting
 The Inn at English Harbour has a hilltop position on 10 acres of national park along Freeman's Bay. There are views of the harbor from many of the 28 rooms and from the Terrace Restaurant and Bar. Below the hotel is a beach where water sports are available. Entertainment is offered three nights a week in winter. The inn is a few minutes from Nelson's Dockyard, named for Britain's Adm. Horatio Nelson, who commanded the Leeward Islands Fleet from this outpost. Winter rates $325 to $400 for two; breakfast and dinner are an additional $42 a person a day. (809) 460-1014 or (800) 223-6510
 
Aruba
 
ARUBA TOURISM AUTHORITY
1000 HARBOR BOULEVARD, WEEHAWKEN, N.J. 07087
(201) 330-0800 and (800) 862-7822
Great Beach
Holiday Inn Aruba Beach Resort, 230 L. G. Smith Boulevard, has 602 rooms. On an island noted for its white sand beaches, this hotel has the longest and widest one, affording both group activities and privacy for those who wish it. The hotel has many shops and restaurants, some on the beach itself, and its Grand Holiday Casino is large and often busy. There are six lighted tennis courts, pool, and sailboats and wind surfing and snorkeling equipment. Rates, without meals, $108 a night single or double. (2978) 23600 or, in the United States, (800) 465-4329.
Natural Setting
The 500-room Aruba Concorde Hotel-Casino, Juan Enrique Irausquin Boulevard, is an 18-story hotel on a coastal point offering commanding views. There are 11 shops, 4 restaurants, lighted tennis courts, pool, beach and casino. Rates, without meals, $160 a night single or double. (2978) 24466, or (800) 428-9933,
Fine Food
Valentino's Restaurant at the Caribbean Palm Village, 45E Palm Beach Road -- its cluster of white two-story buildings resemble a small village -- is considered the island's finest eating place by many Arubans. The Italian chef's creations cover every region of Italy, with veal specialties, for example, extending from Piemonte style to Sicilian veal scallops. A full-course dinner with wine for two runs from about $100.
There are 170 rooms and suites in this resort on landscaped grounds at Noord, a village a mile from the beach. It has a pool and two restaurants. Rates, without meals, $150 a night single or double.(2978) 62700 or, in the United States, (305) 411-7996.
Tranquillity
The Vistalmar, at 28 Bucutiweg, (2978) 28579, consists of eight fully furnished apartments. All have sun decks with sea view. The complex stands on a bluff on an out-of-the-way bay about three miles south of the capital, Oranjestad, but does not have a beach. Guests swim from the Vistalmar's dock. Each apartment's refrigerator is stocked with complimentary food the first night. Rates, without meals, $90 a night single or double; no service charge.
Sports Facilities
Tamarijn Beach Resort, 91 L. G. Smith Boulevard, (2978) 24150 or (800) 223-6725, has more sports activity than any other resort on the island. The full sports program includes swimming, snorkeling and scuba diving (with instruction if required), wind surfing, Sunfish and catamaran sailing, yacht cruises, tennis, shuffleboard, table tennis and, by arrangement with an outside company, riding. The resort is on a large beach, and the two-story buildings containing the 238 rooms are set among palm trees. Its indoor-outdoor restaurant is called the Palms. Rates, without meals, are $225 a night single or double.
 
The Bahamas
 
BAHAMAS TOURIST OFFICE
150 EAST 52D STREET, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10022
(212) 758-2777
Great Beach
 On the island of San Salvador, which has serene white sand beaches, Club Med-Columbus Isle is scheduled to open Dec. 12. (Club Med says the property was not damaged by Hurricane Andrew, which ripped across the Bahamas last August. Most serious damage was confined to some of the Family Islands. Nassau, on New Providence, and Freeport, Grand Bahama, the two major vacation centers, escaped with minor damage, as did many of the other 40 inhabited islands.)
The new resort will be strong on water sports, including diving with wall and wreck dives.
All-inclusive rates, with all meals, accompanying wine and beer, and all sports activities, are $140 to $245 a person a day. For seven nights, the rates are $1,200 to $1,380 a person (higher at Christmas and New Year's), including air fare from New York. Reservations: (800) 258-2633.
Fine Food
Resorts International's Cafe Martinique, at Paradise Island, across the harbor from Nassau, is a waterfront cafe with wall-to-wall etched glass windows, private alcoves, candlelighted terraces, music and a full French menu. Among the choices are an appetizer of shrimps baked in a creamy garlic and herb sauce breast of chicken and large shrimps in a lemon sauce and, among several souffles for dessert, souffle au chocolat. A four-course dinner costs on average $57 a person, including gratuity. The Cafe Martinique is a five-minute walk from the Paradise Island Resort and Casino complex (1,200 rooms) which also includes the Paradise Towers and Britannia Towers. The complex is on a two-mile powder white beach on Paradise Island. Daily rates are $165 to $225. (809) 363-3000 or (800) 321-3000.
Natural Setting
 The Stella Maris Inn is near the northern tip of Long Island in the southeastern Bahamas, about an hour by light plane from Nassau. It was built on an old plantation estate with limestone from the surrounding hills. Guests follow winding pathways from the inn's garden to small sandy strips of beach in coves on the Atlantic shore. There are no locks on doors here, and no hotel keys. Maximum occupancy is 90. The resort is known for diving and underwater photography. Winter rates: $119 for a standard room with double bed and single bed; $139 for one-bedroom suite, and from $240 for a two-bedroom villa for two, and $30 extra for each additional person. (800) 426-0466.
Marriott's Paradise Island Beach Club, Nassau, is close to the tip of Paradise Island and overlooks a long beach with coconut trees. There are 44 two-bedroom, two-bath units, all with fully equipped kitchens. Golf and tennis privileges are available. The club has a poolside snack bar, a variety of restaurants are within walking distance, and the atmosphere is good for families. Rate for a two-bedroom unit, $375. (809) 363-2814.
Sports Facilities
 Paradise Paradise is the most outdoors oriented of the resorts on Paradise Island -- the others being the Paradise Island Resort and Casino complex and the Ocean Club Golf and Tennis Resort. This one- and two-story hotel, with terrace, on a good beach, has complimentary sailing, snorkeling, water skiing, wind surfing, day and night tennis, aerobics, bicycling and volleyball. There are 100 rooms at $125 for two, but Paradise Paradise, where water sports are now included, is scheduled to be converted into an all-inclusive -- with meals all under one price -- on Dec. 26, and the all-inclusive rates have yet to be announced. (800) 321-3000.
Ramada South Ocean Golf and Beach Resort, formerly the Divi South Ocean, near Nassau, has an on-site dive operation, including a photo laboratory, an 18-hole P.G.A.-rated par-72 golf course and two tennis courts. Work is now in progress on adding rooms, which are expected to be up to 250 from 150 by mid-December. The resort is a 25-minute drive from the city center and has a low-key atmosphere. Winter rate for a standard room overlooking gardens or pool or golf course, $160; overlooking beach, $215. (809) 362-4391.
Tranquillity
 Le Meridien Royal Bahamian, Nassau, has 173 rooms either in a manor house or in villas tucked away on Cable Beach, 10 minutes from downtown Nassau. Glass doors open onto balconies with views of sea and gardens. There are three restaurants. The hotel's health facility schedules aerobics clases, mud baths and massage, and there are tennis courts, a pool and billiards room. Water sports rentals are noton the property but adjoin it. Accommodations are from $205 to $400 a day. (800) 543-4300.
The Bluff House Club and Marina, Green Turtle Cay, Abaco, has rooms, suites and villas perched on the highest bluff in the Abacos chain with fine views of surrounding waters. This is for travelers looking for good food and beaches and no connections via telephone or television to the outside world. Rooms from $80 to $125. (809) 365-4247.
 
Barbados
 
BARBADOS BOARD OF TOURISM
800 SECOND AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017
(212) 986-6516 and (800) 221-9831)
Great Beach
 Paradise Village and Beach Club in St. Michael has its own half-mile of powdery white sand on an uninterrupted stretch of beach extending for miles. Sandals, the all-inclusive resort company, purchased the resort from Cunard last month. It will remain open until Jan. 31 when it will close for renovation and some additions planned by Sandals, which says it hopes to reopen the resort as the all-inclusive, couples-only Sandals Barbados in late April.
For now, the informal 13-acre village offers some complimentary features like water sports, tennis and a health club, and it has restaurants, boutiques and other attractions. There are 178 rooms and suites with garden or ocean views. Winter rates range from $150 to $285. (809) 424-0888.
Fine Food
 The chef at the Treasure Beach in St. James, Graham Newbould, is a former personal chef to Prince Charles and the Princess of Wales, and the restaurant offers a selection of Mr. Newbould's Continental and Caribbean specialties. On a recent menu, first courses included spinach tortellini with ricotta cheese filling and a light pesto sauce. Among the entrees was grilled tournedos of beef glazed with Roquefort cheese and served with port wine sauce, and a baked fillet of red snapper topped by a fish mousse, with a champagne and chive sauce. A three-course dinner at Treasure Beach will cost about $37, not including wine.
The resort stands in tropical gardens surrounding a freshwater swimming pool and extending to the edge of the beach. There are 25 suites with ocean, pool or garden views. Rates with breakfast range from $325 to $440. (809) 432-1346.
Another resort in St. James with a good restaurant is the Tamarind Cove Hotel. Set on four acres of gardens on a palm-fringed beach, it has two restaurants, the flagship being the Neptunes. It serves seafood and other specialties in an underwater atmosphere created by an aquarium. Entrees on a recent evening included a fillet of dorado cooked en papillote with chives and brandy; roast duck plantation style; filet mignon, and three lobster dishes. A three-course dinner costs $40 or $50 (more for lobster), not including wine.
The hotel has 117 rooms and three pools. Rates, including breakfast and dinner and the use of water sports equipment, range from $290 to $505. (809) 432-1332.
Sports Facilities
 The Sandy Lane Hotel and Golf Club, St. James, one ofthe island's most elegant resorts, has an 18-hole championship course, tennis courts (lighted for night play) and extensive water sports facilities. The hotel reopened last winter after a major, six-month restoration that brought in marble floors and new fabrics and enlarged many of the rooms.
It is set on a crescent-shaped beach amid a 380-acre estate. Unlimited tennis and water sports and greens fees on the golf course are included in the rates, along with breakfast and dinner. There are 121 rooms and suites with garden or ocean views costing from $720 for rooms to $1,800 for suites. (809) 432-1311.
Tranquillity
 Peach and Quiet, with its adobe-style buildings clustered in four acres of gardens in Christ Church on the breezy south shore, has earned a reputation as a good oceanfront hideaway. It has a restaurant, rock pool and freshwater pool with swim-up bar. The beach at this modest but comfortable and well-run resort is tiny, but a wider one is within walking distance. There are 22 suites (bedroom, sitting room and bathroom) with garden or ocean views. Rooms are $69 (gratuities optional). (809) 428-5682.
 
Bonaire
 
BONAIRE GOVERNMENT TOURIST OFFICE
201 1/2 EAST 29TH STREET, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10016
 (212) 779-0242 and (800) 826-6247
Sports Facilities
 As with other hotels on the island, sports at Captain Don's Habitat are mainly of the water variety. But there are many: pool and ocean swimming, wind surfing, deep-sea fishing, parasailing (soaring with a parachute over the water), and scuba diving (with instruction if desired) to shipwrecks and coral reefs. Habitat also has night diving and classes in day and night underwater photography. Diving tours are available for beginners up through various stages of competence to accredited certification in master scuba diving, drift diving, underwater navigation, and search and rescue diving.
Captain Don's Habitat, 137 Kaya Gobernador Debrot, Kralendijk, has 59 rooms in white buildings with orange-tiled roofs along a low cliff over the shore. The units are set around a pool, garden and restaurant and dive center. Rates, without meals, $145 a night single or double. (5997) 8290 or (800) 327-6709.
Tranquillity
 The Black Durgon Inn, 145 Kaya Gobernador Debrot, Kato, Kralendijk, is at a quiet spot near a coral ledge, and the accommodations stand among palm, almond and kenepa trees north of town. Five of the 11 units are oceanfront, four overlook a garden and there are two small apartments nearby. All have air-conditioning and cable TV. There is no restaurant, although breakfast is served. There is an outdoor area with cooking equipment that is shared by guests. Rates, $95 a night single or double (third person pays $10 a day). (5997) 8978.
The newly built Coral Regency Resort, 90 Kaya Gobernador Debrot, Kralendijk, (5997) 5580 or (800) 327-8150), is set at the edge of town in an isolated area near but not on the ocean. The 31 one-and two-bedroom suites all have ocean views from patio or balcony, cable TV, refrigerator, stove, microwave oven, coffeemaker, blender, juicer, and cooking and dining utensils. There is no restaurant. Rates, without meals, $170 a night single or double. (5997) 0978.
Fine Food
 The Chibi-Chibi Restaurant (named for a tiny bird) at the Divi Flamingo Beach Hotel is built out over the water, affording views of marine life. Entrees include shrimp and chicken kebabs Divi, tenderloin Dijon and grilled wahoo (fish) steaks. Dinner for two, with wine, averages $90 to $100. The 145-room hotel is on the capital's main street but also faces the sea and beach. Water sports and tennis are available. The Divi Flamingo is on J. E. Abraham Boulevard, Kralendijk, (5997) 8825 or (800) 367-3484. The accommodations, from rooms perched over the sea to poolside quarters, cost around $125 a night single or double, not including meals.
 
Cayman Islands
 
CAYMAN ISLANDS TOURIST BOARD
420 LEXINGTON AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10170
(212) 682-5582
Great Beach
 Grand Cayman, the major island in the group, has attractive housekeeping options, particularly in the condominiums along Seven Mile Beach and in the private homes and villas rented through Cayman Villas, (809) 947-4144, a company that also has rentals on Cayman Brac and on Little Cayman.
Morritt's Tortuga Club, Colliers, East End, Grand Cayman, is a 55-unit beachfront enclave on Grand Cayman's quiet East End. The pink and white buildings are on an expanse of otherwise undeveloped reef-protected beach. Each of the one- and two-bedroom apartments has a full kitchen. Morritt's also has a restaurant, David's, free-form freshwater pool with swim-up bar, and water sports; the Tortuga Divers dive shop is on the premises. The wind surfing is good because, although the club is on the normally windward side, the offshore waters are protected by a barrier reef.
Rates begin at $180 for a one-bedroom poolside unit. (809) 947-7449 or (800) 447-0390.
One of the several condo properties on Seven Mile Beach is Lacovia. This property, with 45 one- to three-bedroom units, offers a garden setting with a tennis court across from the Hyatt Regency complex. Each unit has full kitchen, including coffee-makers and microwaves, and satellite TV. Freshwater pool, Jacuzzi bath and clubhouse for events are on the premises. Rates begin at $235 for a one-bedroom condo. (809) 949-7599.
Tranquillity
 Also on Seven Mile Beach, but in a quiet spot in the northern section, is Victoria House. There are 25 units, from studio to three-bedroom penthouse, and tennis courts. Rates begin at $155 for a studio; $195 for one bedroom. (809) 947-4233.
Sports Facilities
 Pirates Point, Little Cayman, is a very casual and secluded eight-unit beachfront property that attracts divers and naturalists to Little Cayman's Preston Bay. The on-site dive operation offers excursions and instruction. There is good snorkeling immediately off-shore. The buildings are of wood and native stone, on a beach shaded by almond trees.
Rates include three meals and a two-tank dive daily: $180 a person in double occupancy. For non-divers, rates are $140 a person. (809) 948-4210.
Natural Setting
 The Hyatt Regency-Britannia, on Grand Cayman, is a complex consisting of a 236-room hotel, Britannia Golf Club and Britannia Villas, with a beach club, Red Sail Watersports and Hemingway's restaurant. The setting is not strictly natural, but the 90 acres of tropical landscaping, including an avenue of palms and pools and small waterfalls accenting the foliage, is striking. The architectural style is "Cayman colonial" in powder blue and white; 35 one- and two-bedroom villas overlook the fairway.
Rates at the hotel begin at $260 for two. Villas begin at $465. (809) 949-1234.
 
Curacao
 
CURACAO TOURIST BOARD
 400 MADISON AVENUE, SUITE 311, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017
 (212) 751-8266 and (800) 332-8266
Great Beach
 The Holiday Beach Hotel and Casino, on Pater Euwensweg, Willemstad, stands on a large private beach a mile from the center of the capital. It has 200 rooms, each with a balcony. There's tennis (on lighted courts), pool, dive shop and transportation into town. The restaurant opens onto the beach. Rates are $70 a night single or double. (5999) 625-400.
Sports Facilities
 Lions Dive Resort, Bapor Kibra, Willemstad, is on the shore -- but a minute's walk from the beach -- near the Seaquarium and the Curacao Underwater Park. All water sports are available, including day and night diving from boats, snorkeling, wind surfing and Sunfish sailing. The resort's health club is equipped with weight room, exercise and aerobics room, and a cardio-fitness section. Classes are available in karate, aikido and slimming. Each of the 72 rooms has two queen-sized beds. Rates, without meals, $100 a night single or double. (5999) 618-100.
Princess Beach Resort and Casino, Dr. Martin Luther King Boulevard, Willemstad, has 340 rooms on its own beach near the Seaquarium, five miles from downtown. There are two pools, a dive shop, all water sports except wind surfing and water skiing, bicycling, riding and, nearby but not on the premises, tennis and minigolf.
Rates, without meals, are $180 a night single or double. (5999) 614-944 or (800) 327-3286.
Tranquillity
 The Trupial Inn, 5 Groot Davelaarweg, Willemstad, is a modest place with air-conditioned rooms in bungalow-style buildings shaded by trees in a quiet residential neighborhood, within walking distance of supermarket and shopping center. It has a lobby and pool (the Trupial is not on a beach). There is a free shuttle bus to downtown, the Seaquarium and beach. The hotel has a restaurant (featuring local dishes but not exclusively) and one tennis court on premises. Rates for the 74 rooms are $60 a night single or double. (5999) 378-200.
 
Dominica
 
 CARIBBEAN TOURISM ORGANIZATION
 20 EAST 46TH STREET, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017
 (212) 682-0435
Sports Facilities
 Several lodges offer good sports and other outdoor facilities, but the atmosphere is casual and visitors should not expect the more modern equipment available on busier islands.
Picard Beach Cottage Resort is on a beach near Portsmouth, Fort Shirley and Cabrits National Park in the northwest, and shares facilities with the Portsmouth Beach Hotel. Water sports available at the Picard resort include scuba diving and boat tours, and there is a swimming pool and beachfront restaurant with local and Continental fare. The resort has 18 wooden cottages built and furnished in 18th-century Dominican style. Each one has bedroom, bathroom, sitting and dining area, kitchen unit, front veranda, phone and ceiling fans. A beach-view cottage is $120 a night double; beachfront, $140. (809) 445-5130 and Robert Reid Associates (800) 223-6510.
Anchorage Hotel, a mile south of the capital, Roseau, has 32 air-conditioned rooms with balconies and most have ocean views. Water sports include snorkeling, scuba diving, sailing and wind surfing, and there's a squash court as well as freshwater pool. The hotel also has motorboat tours, cable TV in the rooms and a restaurant. A standard double room is $80 a night; superior, $100. (809) 448-2638.
The Castaways Beach Hotel, 11 miles north of Roseau, is on a black sand beach a mile long. This small casual resort has a new water sports facility with a diving center. All 27 rooms are beachfront. The Terrace restaurant serves local specialties including fresh seafood and vegetables; facilities include a bar, a TV lounge and a boutique. A double room is $120 a day. (809) 449-6244 or I.T.R., (212) 251-1800.
 
Dominican Republic
 
DOMINICAN REPUBLIC TOURIST INFORMATION CENTER
1 TIMES SQUARE PLAZA, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10036
(212) 768-2481
Sports Facilities
 Casa de Campo stands on 7,000 acres with 950 rooms and villas at La Romana on the southeast coast. Among its many facilities are two public Pete Dye golf courses, both 18 holes. On one of them, the Teeth of the Dog, eight holes overlook the Caribbean. The resort has a fitness center with gym, squash and racquetball courts, massage room, and 13 clay-surface tennis courts, 10 lighted for night play. On the man-made sand beach guests may use Hobie and Sunfish craft, and wind surf and snorkel. Casa de Campo has a shooting center with sporting clays, trap, skeet, and flyer shooting, and an equestrian center.
Rooms, called casitas, in two-story buildings and with two double beds or a king-size bed, cost $270 a night. Villas: two bedrooms, $465; three bedrooms, $710; four bedrooms, $820. With an all-inclusive package, a double room at $265 a person includes three meals, unlimited drinks, horseback riding, tennis, water sports and use of fitness center, airport transfers, taxes and gratuities. Reservations: Premier Resorts, (800) 877-3643 or (305) 856-5405.
A 23 percent tax and service charge is added to all hotel prices in the republic, except all-inclusive packages.
Fine Food
 El Alcazar, the restaurant at Hotel Santo Domingo, in downtown Santo Domingo, the capital, serves buffet lunch, a la carte and buffet dinner and Sunday brunch. One of the Dominican specialties offered is sancocho, a thick soup in which chicken, beef and green bananas are among the ingredients, and several dishes feature rice and beans. Paella is also served. The lunchtime buffet changes each day. Another fine restaurant featuring Italian food is Piazzetta at the Hotel Hispaniola, the sister hotel in the same location as the Santo Domingo. The Hotel Santo Domingo has 220 rooms and suites, a pool, a fitness room, three clay tennis courts and a sauna. Double room per night, $155; one-bedroom suite, $250. (809) 221-1511 or, through Premier Resorts, (800) 877-3643.
Natural Setting
 Heavens, at Puerto Plata, in the Playa Dorado hotel area, has a relaxed tropical setting in which guests walk beside a landscaped lagoon to reach the beach. The hotel has a freshwater pool, boutique, fitness center, disco and a snack bar on the beach. This is an all-inclusive resort (but rates do not include drinks or transfers) with 150 rooms and suites. A standard double is $230 a night; one-bedroom suite, $290. (Suites have a separate bedroom, two double beds, balcony and a small living area.) I.T.R., (212) 251-1800.
 
 
Grenada
 
GRENADA BOARD OF TOURISM
 820 SECOND AVENUE, SUITE 900D, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017
 (212) 687-9554)
Great Beach
Coyaba Beach Resort is on the celebrated Grand Anse Beach, a mile and a half long. The 40 rooms are in four wood and stucco buildings that vaguely resemble the dwellings built by the Amerindians. It is 10 minutes from Point Salines International Airport and about the same distance from St. George's, the capital. All rooms are air-conditioned and there are two restaurants and a pool. $165 double per night. (809) 444-4129.
Fine Food
La Belle Creole restaurant at the Blue Horizons Cottage Hotel is noted for its creative creole cuisine. Specialties include breadnut soup, lobster a la Creole and farina pudding for dessert. The fixed-price dinner is about $30. Blue Horizons is on six acres with gardens, has 32 rooms and a pool and is five minutes' walk from Grand Anse Beach. Double rooms are $130 to $160. (809) 444-4316-4592.
Natural Setting
 The Victoria Hotel, in the fishing village of Victoria on the west coast, 13 miles north of St. George's, is on the beach where the fishing seines are pulled in. This 10-room modest hotel has a view of Mount St. Catherine, the island's highest peak (2,749 feet). A room for two with private shower is $40. (809) 444-9367.
 Sports Facilities
Spice Island Inn on Grand Anse, which has 56 rooms, offers a plan that includes, among other facilities, the use for one hour a day of Sunfish and snorkel equipment, and use of tennis courts, fitness center and bicycles. At extra charge, arrangements can be made for golf, water skiing and diving trips.
All-inclusive rates for suites of $560 (with private pool) and $430 (with whirlpool bath) include, in addition to the sports facilities, all meals, free bar and house wines, a stocked minibar in the room and a tour of the Botanical Gardens. Without some of the extras but with breakfast and dinner, the suites can also be had for $450 and $320. (809) 444-4258.
Tranquillity
 The Calabash is the only hotel on Prickly Bay on the south coast, and the 28 rooms are scattered over eight acres overlooking the Caribbean. It's a quiet spot some distance from a main road and 15 minutes from St. George's. Room rates for two with breakfast, afternoon tea and dinner are $295; suite with Jacuzzi, $350; suite with pool, $450. (809) 444-4334.
 
Guadeloupe
 
FRENCH WEST INDIES TOURIST BOARD
610 FIFTH AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10020
(900) 420-2003; 50 cents a minute
Great Beach
 With a few exceptions, the best beaches are on the Grande-Terre half of this butterfly-shaped island. One is at Ste.-Anne, where the Caravelle-Club Med, with 310 rooms, is situated -- a wide crescent-shaped expanse of white sand nearly one mile long, framed with coconut palms and sea-grape trees. $990-$1,550 a week per person in double occupancy, with all meals. (800) 258-2633.
On the northwest coast of Basse-Terre sits the 194-room Fort Royal Touring Club, which covers a promontory set between two long sand beaches facing the Caribbean. South of here is Pigeon Island, an underwater sanctuary long favored by scuba divers of coral formations, tropical fish and shells. $152 to $170, with Continental breakfast (prices calculated at five francs to the dollar). (590) 25500.
Fine Food
 One of Guadeloupe's best restaurants is L'Habitation, at the Canella Beach Hotel in the Gosier resort area. The restaurant is owned by Francis Delage, a chef and cooking show host on French television and the author of an encyclopedia of creole cuisine. L'Habitation has extensive menus at lunch and dinner, with such delicacies as mousse of fresh crabmeat, locally smoked marlin, bisque of local lobster served with crayfish ravioli, homemade pate de foie gras and imported caviar. About $60 to $65 a person for dinner, without wine. The Canella's 148 rooms cost $143 to $153 a day. (800) 223-9815.
Plantation Ste.-Marthe, entering its first full season, has the Vallee d'Or restaurant, whose cuisine, light and contemporary, is more French than creole. The dessert menu lists many French cheeses and there is a selection of French wines. About $60 to $65 a person, without wine. The resort, which has 120 rooms, is in the countryside above St. Francois. (800) 223-9815. Rates are $125 to $200.
Sports Facilities
 The Marissol-Novotel Complex, twinned hotels at Bas du Fort, has its own fitness center. Among the water sports the hotels offer are wind surfing and jet skiing, with facilities available for deep-sea fishing, scuba diving and boating. There is tennis at both hotels. Marissol PLM Azur: 200 rooms, $160 to $204; Fleur d'Epee Novotel: 191 rooms, $160. (800) 221-4542.
Tranquillity
 Relais du Moulin has 20 bungalows and 20 one-room apartments (10 with kitchenette) surrounding an old sugar mill, off the beaten track in a pastoral setting at Chateaubrun between Ste. Anne and St. Francois. Run by two sisters, it has a pool, dining room and 40 rooms. $145-$178, with Continental breakfast. (800) 366-1510.
 
Jamaica
 
JAMAICA TOURIST BOARD
801 SECOND AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017
(212) 688-7650
Great Beach
 Silver Sands Villa Resort, 30 miles east of Montego Bay, has more than 1,000 feet of coral sand and low-key water sports. There is a modest clubhouse with restaurant and bar and a small commissary.
Hillside accommodations above the beach are in one- and two-bedroom cottages or three- to five-bedroom villas, some with private pools. Rates per night: from $220 for a one-bedroom cottage to $500 for a four-bedroom villa with pool, including maid service and cook. Two-night minimum stay. There are a few economy motel rooms at $40 a night for two. (800) 445-2690 or (212) 953-7910.
Fine Food
 The all-inclusive Grand Lido, a spacious beachfront enclave for couples or singles (over 16 years), offers three restaurants: Piacere's varied menus are inspired by nouvelle cuisine; the open-air Cafe Lido offers international fare, and La Pasta features pasta dishes prepared in front of you. Around-the-clock snacking is possible with 24-hour room service and at three clubhouses offering improvisations such as "bubbly burgers" served with champagne. To counteract the calories Grand Lido has extensive sports and fitness facilities: tennis, squash, gymnasium, water sports, saunas, Jacuzzis and nightly disco dancing.
All-inclusive rates cover sports, services and all you can eat or drink. Per person, in double occupancy, for three nights: $845 to $983. For seven nights: $1,695 to $1,995. (809) 957-4010-9.
Sandals Royal Caribbean, a couples-only all-inclusive beachfront hotel, offers Indonesian dining at its new Bali Hai restaurant on Kokomo, a tiny offshore inlet. The Bali-born chef, Roy Heuvel, presides over the rijstafel -- a 15-dish main course plus appetizer, soup and dessert. International cuisine and Jamaican specialties are available in the Regency Dining Room, the Pavillion restaurant and Courtyard Grill.
The resort's policy allows guests to eat at other Sandals establishments -- Japanese at Tokyo Joe's (Sandals Montego Bay) or Caribbean, Polynesian or Italian fare at the three restaurants at Sandals Dunns River. Sandals Royal has sports and fitness facilities, and offers complimentary golf at Ironshore Golf Club. All-inclusive rates per couple (everything included): three nights from $1,315 to $1,835; seven nights from $2,665 to $3,725. (809) 953-2231.
Natural Setting
 The Enchanted Garden stands on 20 acres of gardens, with streams and waterfalls, above the bustle of Ocho Rios. There is a free shuttle to a private white sand beach at nearby Mammee Bay. Forty of the 120 hillside suites have private plunge pools overlooking the bay and gardens, and guests can make use of a hammock garden, grotto sauna, waterfall Jacuzzi, and complimentary aromatherapy massage and facials. Other facilities include a pool with a swim-up bar, tennis courts, piano bar, nightclub and four restaurants. All-inclusive rates per person per week, in double occupancy, from $1,100 to $1,500. (809) 974-1400.
Sports Facilities
 Swept Away in Negril is a health and fitness oriented all-inclusive resort for couples, with 134 suites on the beach and a choice of restaurants and bars and nightly entertainment. The fitness complex has 10 tennis courts (all lighted), tennis lessons and clinics, air-conditioned squash and racquetball courts, gymnasium with professional staff, aerobics room, a half-mile jogging track, basketball court, saunas, steamrooms and lap pool. It also offers bicycle tours and yoga classes. Water sports include Mistral wind surfers, reef snorkeling, two scuba dives a day, sailing, kayaking and an Olympic-size swimming pool.
Rates (all-inclusive) for a couple for three nights from $1,200 to $1,410; seven nights, $2,700 to $3,150. (809) 957-4061.
Tranquillity
 Negril Cabins on the outskirts of Negril is . a small property in a rain-forest garden with royal palms and indigenous plants like butti thatch and pink poui. The 12 rustic two-bedroom cottages with private bathrooms are popular with bird watchers and other ecotourists. The complex has a freshwater swimming pool, tennis court, restaurant, bar, laundry facilities. There is ocean swimming a short walk across the road from a sand beach at Bloody Bay, which got its name from the 19th-century whaling trade. Room rates of $96 a night include tax and service charge. (809) 957-4350.
 
Martinique
 
FRENCH WEST INDIES TOURIST BOARD
610 FIFTH AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10020
(900) 420-2003; 50 cents a minute
Great Beach
 One of the island's best beaches is in the south at Ste. Anne, and Buccaneer's Creek-Club Med is right on it. Nearby is another great beach, called Les Salines, but there are no hotels there. The Buccaneer has 300 rooms and rates are $800 to $1,450 a week, per person, in double occupancy, with all meals. (800) 258-2633.
The modest Madras, a small hotel with 14 rooms, is set on a small beach off the beaten track, at Tartane, in the middle of the Caravelle Peninsula facing the Atlantic. With little vegetation and few shade trees, the beach is perfect for anyone wanting lots of sun and swimming in the quiet cove of Tartane. Rates are $70 to $90 a day, with private bath and Continental breakfast. (596) 583395.
Fine Food
 One of the most luxurious hotels on the island, the Bakoua, completely renovated last year, prides itself on Le Chateaubriand, its main restaurant, which serves both French and creole cuisine. It has a view across the bay to Fort-de-France, Martinique's capital. An average dinner is $55 a person, not including wine. On Friday night there is a dinner performance by the Grands Ballets de la Martinique. The Bakoua has 140 rooms, $208 to $300. (800) 221-4542
 Martinique Cottages, a little hideaway in the Pays Mele section of Lamentin, has a restaurant, La Plantation, that was selected in 1992 for a Gault Millau golden key award for creating a nouvelle cuisine creole, blending African, Indian, European and Caribbean flavors. The eight modern rooms in a tropical setting are priced at about $75. (596) 501608.
Natural Setting
 Habitation Lagrange, the newest Martinique hotel -- it was opened last winter -- is set on 7.5 acres of tropical gardens between the villages of Marigot and Lorrain on the northeast coast. Lagrange has 17 guest rooms, some in the restored 18th-century mansion that serves as the hotel's centerpiece, others in three cottages. $250-$300, with full breakfast.
In the rain-forested mountainous north of the island lies Leyritz Plantation, originally an 18th-century Bordelais chateau and now a country inn with 50 rooms. Near Basse-Pointe, Leyritz is surrounded by a 25-acre working pineapple and banana plantation. About $146, with Continental breakfast. (800) 633-7411.
Sports Facilities
The Meridien, in Pointe du Bout, across the bay from Fort-de-France, has a water sports complex offering wind surfing, snorkeling and deep-sea fishing.
 Crewed and bareboat sailing are available. Two tennis courts are lighted for night play, and there is golf at an 18-hole Robert Trent Jones course nearby. Espace Loisirs, a fitness center near the Meridien and the Bakoua, has squash, tennis, gymnastics and weight training. The Meridien has 295 rooms. $283-$417, with Continental breakfast. (800) 543-4300.
Tranquillity
 St. Aubin, perched on a hill two miles from Trinite on the Atlantic coast, was built of pink stone in the 1920's by a French planter. There are wraparound verandas on both floors, steeply pitched roofs and filigreed gables. Simply furnished, the 15-room St. Aubin has a pool in an almond grove, formal gardens and a dining room for guests only. About $112, with Continental breakfast. (800) 223-9815
 
Montserrat
 
MONTSERRAT TOURIST BOARD
c/o PACE ADVERTISING, 485 FIFTH AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017
(212) 818-0100
Natural Setting
 Twelve miles long and 7 wide, the island has only a handful of accommodations, mostly small clusters of cottages and villas. There are almost a hundred villas, most with good views and many with private pools. Although Montserrat was the island hardest hit by Hurricane Hugo in 1987, suffering severe damage to buildings, the number of guest rooms today is slightly higher than it was before the storm.
The Vue Pointe Hotel overlooks the most popular of the black sand beaches, Old Roads Beach, where there is scuba diving, snorkeling, deep sea fishing, wind surfing, paddle boating, sunfish sailing, surfing -- and right on the beach there are tennis courts. The atmosphere is informal. Individual cottages set in gardens of croton and oleander serve as hotel rooms. Rates for the 28 units vary from $126 to $166 for two in the winter season. An optional plan for breakfast and dinner costs $35 a person a day. (809) 491-5210 or (800) 235-0709.
The other main hotel, the Montserrat Springs, offers a choice of rooms or one- and two-bedroom efficiency suites, about 50 units altogether. The hotel gardens go down to the beach and to the mineral water baths there, next to the Las' Call beach bar. In season, rates are from $140 to $210. Optional plan for breakfast and dinner is $35 a person a day. (809) 491-2481 or (800) 253-2134.
The Belham Valley Hotel (actually three cottages with kitchens and a restaurant) has a view from the dining room as good as any on the island. A two-bedroom cottage costs $525 for six nights. A studio apartment is $350 for six nights. At the restaurant, dinner comes to about $29, not including drinks. (809) 491-5553.
 
Puerto Rico
 
COMMONWEALTH OF PUERTO RICO TOURISM COMPANY
575 FIFTH AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10017
(212) 599-6262
Great Beach
 The Hyatt Dorado Beach offers a resort setting slightly removed from the bustle of San Juan. Known for its 18-hole Robert Trent Jones golf course, it has 298 guest rooms and casitas along a two-mile crescent beach. Between golf and sunning, there's tennis, dining, casino gambling and entertainment. Two people can spend the night for anywhere from $145 to $315 during the season. The newer, slightly less elegant Hyatt Regency Cerromar shares the same spectacular beach, and a pool with nooks, crannies and waterfalls. All 504 rooms have ocean views. Rates for two vary from $140 to $265. For either Hyatt, (800) 233-1234.
For another fine beach closer to town, the Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza at Isla Verde has a view of sea and sand that is uninterrupted by other buildings. There's also a large pool and outdoor Jacuzzi bath. This hotel near the airport has a new casino. Winter rates for the 254 rooms are $180.50 a night. (800) 465-4329.
Sports Facilities
 For wide open spaces, and the best sports package on the island, visitors drive to the southeast coast at Humacao to the Palmas del Mar resort. This 2,750-acre spread has a 20-court tennis center, an 18-hole Gary Player championship golf course, bike and jogging trails, tropical forest and wildlife preserve, a half-mile beach, scuba diving, wind surfing, kayaking and deep-sea fishing from a full service marina. There are both French and seafood restaurants. Palmas Inn and Casino and the Candelero Hotel have a total of 278 rooms, with nightly rates from $110 to $160 double occupancy. (809) 852-6000 or (800) 468-3331.
Fine Food
 For more French cuisine, visitors may cross the island to the Horned Dorset Primavera, a country retreat near Rincon on the western shore. This oasis has a restaurant and 22 separate little white villas with red roofs overlooking the Caribbean along the Mona Passage. The restaurant serves a fixed-price six-course dinner for $40 a person, not including wine. The menu changes daily; a typical meal might include soup, medallions of fresh lobster, grilled yellowfin tuna, or a veal dish, tamarind sorbet, French cheeses and salad, dessert and coffee. A room for two costs from $325 to $345, not including meals. (809) 823-4030 or 4050.
Natural Setting
 The Hacienda Gripinas, a restored coffee plantation in the mountain town of Jayuya, has been an inn since 1975. There are 19 shuttered rooms. A double costs $60 a night. A special honeymoon package for is $175 a couple for two nights and three days and includes welcome cocktails, two breakfasts and two dinners with wine. (809) 721-2884 or (809) 828-1717 or (800) 443-0266. .
Tranquillity
 Two intimate havens are the Sand and the Sea Inn in Cayey, and the Hotel San Jose in Old San Juan. The former, nestled in the mountains about an hour from San Juan, has antique quilts, a broad veranda and an ocean view. There are only four rooms, of which two are suites, one with a fireplace. The rooms cost $55 and $65, and the suites, $75, all including full breakfast. (809) 738-9086 or (809) 789-3620.
For a bit more colonial sophistication, the Hotel San Jose, a four-story mansion near City Hall in the old capital city, has 10 rooms. There's a central atrium, foliage, fountains and winding staircases. A 45-foot living room for afternoon tea and cocktails has books, a grand piano and comfortable sofas. Some of the rooms have marble tubs. The hotel serves breakfast only, but restaurants abound nearby. Double rates run from $160 to $200, suites from $270 to $500. Rates include Continental breakfast and evening cocktails. No children under 12. (809) 723-1212.
 
Saba
 
SABA TOURIST INFORMATION OFFICE
271 MAIN STREET, NORTHPORT, N.Y. 11768
(516) 261-7474
Natural Setting
 Most accommodations are situated on the higher altitudes of the mountain, insuring an attractive spot with views, mountain breezes and cool nights. Juliana's is the standout here; in addition to the attributes mentioned, it is family owned and operated. The 10-room inn has dive package deals are available on request with the Saba Deep and Sea Saba centers. A double room is $95 and a single $75 through April 15. Telephone, (599) 46-2269.
Captain's Quarters, next door to Juliana's, is the grand old lady of Saba's inns. Quiet and charming, it consists of several restored buildings in which there are 10 guest rooms, many with antique four-poster beds as well as balconies offering sweeping views of the surrounding sea, hills and valleys.
The Victorian main building was built around 1900 by Capt. Henry Hassell, a captain of one of the many clipper ships that used put in to Saba. Daily rates, including Continental breakfast, are $125 double and $95 single. A third or fourth person pays $35 a day. Telephone, (599) 46-2201.
 
 St. Barthelemy
 
FRENCH WEST INDIES TOURIST BOARD
610 FIFTH AVENUE, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10020
(900) 420-2003; 50 cents a minute
Great Beach
 The Hotel Isle de France at Baie des Flamands is on one of the island's best beaches, a stretch of white sand fringed with lantana trees. The 28-room hotel is equipped with two swimming pools, tennis, an air-conditioned squash court and a fitness center. Rates are $300 to $515 a night for a double, with Continental breakfast. (800) 628-8929.
The 30-room Filao Beach Hotel is on the Plage de St.-Jean, which is protected by reefs and offers all kinds of water sports -- wind surfing, Sunfish sailing, water skiing, boat charters, swimming -- as well as some of the best seaside dining on the island. (For scuba, Dive With Dan is next door at the Hotel Emeraude Plage.) Accommodations are in bungalows set along paths in a garden setting. From about $320 a night for a double room with full breakfast. (800) 422-1323.
Fine Food
 La Toque Lyonnaise is a small restaurant in El Sereno Beach Hotel at Grand Cul de Sac. Among the specialties in the candlelighted poolside restaurant are lobster raviolis with shredded leeks, sauteed salmon scallopines, foie gras and sweetbreads with fresh pasta, and banana flambe in a crust. A three-course menu at dinner costs about $48. During the day, there is informal dining at the Lagon Bleu, the 29-room hotel's beachside bistro. Rates: $265-$340. (800) 528-1234.
The Sapora di Mare, formerly the Castelets, is now very Italian, with a menu of "coastal cuisine" created by the New York restaurateur Pino Luongo and his partner, Cesare Dell'Aguzzo. Calamari alla griglia, fresh squid, breaded and grilled, topped with tomatoes, and cacciucco alla toscana, a spicy seafood stew, are among the offerings. Dinner is from $50 to $65 a person, without wine. The hotel has 10 rooms, $100-$255 a night, with Continental breakfast. (212) 319-7488.
Sports Facilities
 Guanahani, St. Barts' first major hotel, has added new rooms and expanded its roster of sports, notably an on-site scuba operation. The 76-room hotel, situated on a lagoon near Grand Cul de Sac, has a pool overlooking the beach, and many of the rooms come equipped with small private pools and Jacuzzi baths. There are two lighted tennis courts, and a wind surfing school around the cove. $400-$500 for a double room, with Continental breakfast. (212) 838-3110.
The 52-room Manapany, a hillside on the north shoreat Anse des Cayes, offers a fitness center, a tennis court for day or night play, a pool, a Jacuzzi bath and petanque, the French version of lawn bowling. Arrangements for scuba, deep-sea fishing and sailing excursions can be made through the front desk. $355-$390 for a double room, with full American breakfast. (212) 719-5750.
Tranquillity
 Off at the eastern end of the island is Le Toiny, which opened quietly in August but plans to celebrate its official debut today. Le Toiny is not only removed from the general activity of St. Barts but also allows for true privacy with individual pools, 10 by 20 feet, for each of its 12 one-bedroom cottages. Additionally, there is a pool that serves all the hotel guests. $650 a night for the cottage, including Continental breakfast. (800) 932-3222.
 
St. Croix
 
U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS DIVISION OF TOURISM
1270 AVENUE OF THE AMERICAS, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10020
(212) 582-4520
Tranquillity
 The Waves at Cane Bay is on the north shore about 10 miles west of Christiansted and overlooks Cane Bay Beach. Good snorkeling and scuba diving are available at the beach, which abounds in coral gardens, and Cane Bay Wall -- a precipitous drop -- just beyond. Waves has 12 studio rooms with kitchenettes, cable TV and ceiling fans; some rooms have air-conditoning and all have sea views. Rates, double, $115 to $175 a night, with minimum three-night stay. (809) 778-1805.
Next door to the Waves is Cane Bay Reef Club, with nine suites and kitchenettes very close to the water, and a 40-foot swimming pool. Water sports are available. The adjacent No Name Bar & Grill serves such Caribbean specialties as conch and lobster. Room rates, double, $110 to $150. (809) 778-2966.
Sports Facilities
 The 150-room Buccaneer, St. Croix's biggest and oldest resort, covers 240 acres and lies two and a half miles east of Christiansted. It has a beach, 18-hole golf course, eight tennis courts, swimming pool, health club, snorkeling and scuba diving as well as day sailing trips to nearby Buck Island National Park. Four restaurants, nightly entertainment and shopping mall. All rooms have air-conditioning and ceiling fans. Rooms range from $184 to $325. (809) 773-2100.
Natural Setting
 Hilty House is a five-suite Mediterranean-style villa built on the ruins of a late 18th-century rum distillery in mid-island about two miles south of Christiansted. This out-of-the-way hillside retreat is surrounded by other forested slopes and has views of both the north and south shores, although not of the sea. Guests can also see the outskirts of Christiansted. Hand-painted tiles from Italy and Spain decorate floors and walls. There is a large swimming pool. There is no restaurant, but the rates of $90 a night for two include Continental breakfast, usually with fruit and home-baked muffins. Three cottages, with kitchens, on the two-and-a-half-acre grounds each sleep two and rent for a minimum of seven nights at $115 a night, not including breakfast. (809) 773-2594.
 
St. Eustatius
 
ST. EUSTATIUS TOURIST INFORMATION OFFICE
 271 MAIN STREET, NORTHPORT, NEW YORK, N.Y. 11768
 (516) 261-7474
Tranquillity
 The Old Gin House is a faithful reconstruction of an 18th-century building that once housed a cotton gin. In keeping with the island's peaceful atmosphere, the hotel has no locks on the doors of its 20 guestrooms. It is on the beach and has a restaurant and pool. No children under age 10.
Rates are $150 double, $110 single, $180 triple. Telephone, (599) 38-2319.
Another hotel with a quiet, unhurried atmosphere, and also on the beach, is the Golden Era, named for Statia's celebrated historical period, in the 17th and 18th centuries. The hotel has 20 rooms, all air-conditioned, with telephone and cable television. There is an outdoor bar and a swimming pool. Children accepted.
Rates are $70 single, $88 double, $104 triple. Telephone, (599) 38-2345.
 
St. John
 
U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS DIVISION OF TOURISM
1270 AVENUE OF THE AMERICAS, NEW YORK, N.Y. 10020
(212) 582-4520
Natural Setting
 Caneel Bay has seven beaches stretching along a 170-acre peninsula within the Virgin Islands National Park and has been a resort emphasizing casual elegance and privacy for 36 years. The 171 rooms are in secluded cottages -- no phones, no TV, no air-conditioning, only ceiling fans. There are three restaurants, bar and lounge, 11 tennis courts, water sports including fishing. Children under age 8 not permitted. Winter rates double, including meals, $325 to $535 a night. (809) 776-6111.
Sports Facilities
 The Hyatt Regency St. John, opened six years ago, is on a white sand beach and offers six lighted tennis courts, all water sports and a quarter-acre swimming pool. Scuba and snorkel gear and sailboats are available. There are 285 air-conditioned rooms and three restaurants. The Hyatt is only a mile from Cruz Bay but a nearby hill gives a feeling of seclusion. Daily rates, double, range from $325 to $475, including meals. (809) 776-7171.
Tranquillity
 Maho Bay Camps, set on 14 acres in the national park, has 113 "tent cottages" that include cooking facilities, ceiling fans, screened dining area, linens and utensils. Bathhouses have toilets, sinks and showers. This luxury camp, renovated in 1990, lies just behind a sandy beach and has an outdoor restaurant and food mart. Winter rates, double, $75 a night. (809) 776-6226.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
'Death of a Salesman': Power Undimmed

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

DATELINE: RUTHERFORD

 BODY:
AFTER the miscellaneous theater companies that meant to set up residence at the William Carlos Williams Center for the Arts and failed, a new group, hopefully calling itself the Williams Center Repertory Theater, has turned up.
And this time there's no reason to disbelieve intentions. Last weekend's gripping opening night of "Death of a Salesman" signals promise and intelligence. Such encumbrances as a make-do look, one unfortunate performance and a few avoidable technical gaffes were surmounted by a perceptive and passionate grasp of a contemporary classic. 
 In the searching portrayal of Howard Wesson, Willy Loman is realized as the eternal low man, a tremulous wreck. No longer sustained by illusions, still floundering at the age of 63 and groping for the secret of the success that has eluded him, Mr. Wesson illuminates Willy's awareness of his own foolishness and mediocrity. Willy's final moment of acknowledgment, almost as if in redemption of his life, that his son Biff is his finest success, is heartbreakingly captured by Mr. Wesson.
Darian Sartain, the company's artistic director, plays Biff with a sense of anguish, complexity and ambivalence of an ostensible loser who wants to follow his own opposite dream. Mr. Sartain gets Biff's conflicted perception of his father as a blowhard and ultimately eulogizes him as "a fine troubled prince." Gino DiIorio's Happy has the makings of the slick plastic star of Willy's inflated dreams.
With a single exception, the rest of the cast is strong, notably Don Carter as an eerie, emcee-like Ben, a note of expressionism in an otherwise naturalistically conceived production. A whiny wrong note is struck by Joan Saporta, a Linda Loman to whom attention must not be paid.
Jack Banning's staging makes a clear distinction between the real memories and the pipe dreams; the happy times when Willy horsed around with Biff and Happy and the trumped-up ones, filled with his illusory claims of productivity.
Mr. Banning catches the usually underplayed aspects of Arthur Miller's work -- Willy's quest to track down his past; to connect with his own father, who made flutes; the encouragement of deviousness (disguised as fearlessness) in his sons.
Even the "what happened in Boston?" scene, which can seem a farfetched motivational device for Biff's defeatism, has a sudden dramatic validity here. The director smooths the transitions as the play maneuvers through the causeways of Willy's drifting mind, before he crashes.
The realistic details of Jared Saltzman's setting -- a drab kitchen, a bedroom with a chenille bedspread -- are offset by the surreal jagged wooden wall of Biff and Happy's room that represents the crackup of a whole family, not just one hapless man.
In 1949, Mr. Miller wrote of built-in obsolescence, boxed-in neighborhoods and the squeezing out of the common man for whom no one composes a fanfare. More than 40 years later, society's value system that he held accountable for the individual's moral and spiritual disintegration is even more reliant on grandiosity and bombast.
The economic problems foreshadowed here are more severe; attitudes toward aging, more pitiless, and the importance of appearances, more pronounced. At the center, the play's lasting hold goes beyond an ideologically driven vision.
Besides prophetic power, "Death of a Salesman" has dramatic glory. Both, astonishingly, are magnified by time. On the evidence of the Williams Center company's debut, there's no doubt about it.
"Death of a Salesman," by Arthur Miller, produced by the William Carlos Williams Center for the Arts, Park Avenue at Williams Plaza in Rutherford. Remaining performances are today and next Sunday at 3 P.M., Friday at 8 P.M. and Saturday at 2 and 8 P.M. Box office: (201) 939-2323.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gino DiIorio, left, as Happy, with Howard Wesson, center, in the role of Willy Loman, and Darian Sartain as Biff, in a scene from "Death of a Salesman" in Rutherford. (William Neumann Photography)

HEADLINE: Singles Pioneer Signs Up No. 300,000

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

DATELINE: RYE

 BODY:
EMPLOYING the dictum it takes one to know one, Richard Lowenstein started a tour company exclusively aimed at single people who want to travel.
The company, Singleworld, with headquarters here, marked its 35th anniversary this year by taking its 300,000th single passenger on a cruise this fall. 
 "Today, everyone is aware of the buying power of the singles market," Mr. Lowenstein said, "but in 1957, when I ran my first singles travel event, a Christmas and New Year's cruise to Europe, pairing two singles was a revolutionary concept."
 
Nine Countries in Five Months
 Mr. Lowenstein, who is a young and energetic 72-year-old, said his interest in the travel business was ignited when he was 32 and traveling through Europe alone.
"I was unemployed," he said. "I had just left a job with a shoe manufacturer. Before that I had been with a food brokerage company. I'm an accountant by profession, but at that point I was thinking about a career change. I always longed to go to Europe, and I had a little money saved up at the time. I remember I budgeted the trip at $1,200, and with that I was able to go to nine countries in five months before my money ran out. The last place I visited then was Capri, where you could stay for $25 a week back in 1953."
 
'There Was a Big Market'
 The European experience decided Mr. Lowenstein on a career in the travel industry.
"But in order to learn the business I went to work for a travel agent for nothing more than gaining hands-on experience," he said. "The first year I earned an average of $25 a week in commissions. By the second year I felt competent enough to run a student tour. But I lost money on it, because I underpriced it. However, from the response I got I immediately realized that there was a big market out there for unattached travelers."
With an investment of $3,000 from personal savings, Mr. Lowenstein started Gramercy Travel Company in Manhattan in 1956. A few months later, on April 1, he hired his first employee, Rita Kaplan, a travel agent and consultant. A year later, almost to the day, they were married. Today, Mrs. Lowenstein runs the parent company, Gramercy Travel, now in Rye.
Mr. Lowenstein's first singles event, an 18-day Christmas-New Year's trans-Atlantic crossing and European tour, called Bachelor Party at Sea, cost less than $1,000 a person in luxury accommodations for the 37 single men and women who signed up for it.
"The concept of singles traveling together was successful from the beginning," Mr. Lowenstein said. "From the first year of operation the business was profitable. Of course, we did a lot of advertising and Bachelor Party, which later became Singleworld, got a lot of publicity because of the novelty of it, and that certainly helped. But I think we were filling a basic need by making it easier for people to travel by themselves and not be alone. I find most people can manage fine during the day, but evenings in a foreign city are something else, especially for women 35 years ago. It was a big selling point for us to be able to tell them that we'd take them out in a group and see the sights after dark."
In those days, about the only people who traveled were wealthy. To make single travel more affordable, Mr. Lowenstein said he pushed the idea of shared accommodations.
"It was pretty bold then to suggest that two strangers who had never met share a room or a cabin on a ship," he said. "But the savings were so attractive that a lot of people were willing to give it a try. Although we have clients who prefer to pay for a single supplement for their own accommodations, most people these days do share. Some cruises have accommodations for four people in a stateroom, which brings the individual cost for a cruise way, way down."
Singleworld's concentration on cruises, which now represents four-fifths of its overall business, began when fly-cruise packages made more options available.
 
Three Age Groups Predominate
 As cruising became more popular, the average age of passengers on cruises started dropping, Mr. Lowenstein said. "It used to be that only older people took cruises," he said. "Now we book three age groups: 20- to 33-year-olds, 29- to 40-year-olds and a third group is an all-ages group."
The company doesn't run its own ships; it uses such major cruise lines as Carnival Cruise Lines, Norwegian Cruise Line and Royal Caribbean Cruise Line.
"Almost 100 percent of our business comes from 6,000 travel agents nationwide who book their single clients with us," Mr. Lowenstein said.
Passengers are accompanied by one of Singleworld's 14 cruise directors, said Randall Russell, the company's managing director, who added that they spend an average of eight weeks at a time at sea.
 
On Call 24 Hours a Day
 "Our cruise directors are men and women who are good with people," Mr. Russell said. "Cruise director on a ship sounds like a dream job, and in many ways it is, but our people work hard. They are literally on call 24 hours a day to help passengers with any problems they might have."
Mr. and Mrs. Lowenstein's daughter, Wendy, now a vice president of the company, came up through the ranks and is a former cruise director.
"The cruise director makes table arrangements so that all singles sit with singles and hold special events solely for the group on board and also takes charge of shore arrangements," Ms. Lowenstein said.
Mr. Russell added: "We also provide the activities that give singles a chance to meet other singles, which otherwise can be difficult on a large ship. Granted, we start with a happy product.
"For most people, going on a cruise is a dream come true, but it's the responsibility of the cruise director to see that everyone, and I mean everyone, has a good time."
The rewards for such diligence come in the form of repeat business. Some clients, Mr. Lowenstein said, take as many as 10 cruises a year with Singleworld.
"Most of those who repeat that often are retirees for whom cruising has become a way of life," he explained.
"A cruise ship is a self-contained world. It's very attractive having meals, entertainment and companionship readily available."
Women passengers still outnumber men, but only slightly, Mr. Lowenstein said. "Years back, there were many more women than men, but the gap has narrowed."
And there are Singleworld imitators to contend with. Other tour operators, recognizing the buying capacity of the single market, have tried to duplicate Mr. Lowenstein's operation.
"To my mind the most flattering one was Club Med, Mr. Lowenstein said. "They shined the spotlight on the entire singles market. I was very pleased that before they began their operation they asked me for advice. Of course, there are other tour operators for singles these days, but none of them are on our scale. I feel I was lucky to have found my niche when the costs for important things like marketing and advertising were reasonable and do-able. I couldn't handle it today."
Despite the current recession, Mr. Lowenstein said, every week so far this year about 15 groups of about 16 travelers, totaling about 12,000 a year, have gone cruising with Singleworld.
"Thankfully, we will end up in the black this year, but we had to work hard to produce more volume in order to do so."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard Lowenstein, at rear, the founder of Singleworld, a travel agency specializing in cruises for single people, at the company's Rye office with Randall Russell, the company's managing director, and Aimee Rinaldi, operations manager. (Alan Zale for The New York Times)
