HEADLINE: County Would Get $26.3 Million From Bond Act Approval

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
FOR the village of Dobbs Ferry, passage of a referendum going before voters on Tuesday could provide $750,000 for a two-tier parking lot in a downtown shopping area that has been hit hard by the recession. For Mount Vernon, a city that is struggling economically, it could mean $6 million for an urban-renewal project to build a multiservice transportation center.
For 15 Westchester communities and the county, passage of the New York State Jobs Bond Act on Election Day would mean that $26.3 million in state aid will be available for projects designed to help local economies and generate jobs in the private sector. 
 The money would be Westchester's share of $800 million the act would make available. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo says the proposed act -- also known as the Jobs for the New, New York Bond Act -- is necessary to jump-start the state's economy.
On a state and local level, the bond act presents voters with a decision that reflects many of the issues being debated by the Presidential candidates.
"It's the same basic dilemma," said Noreen L. Preston, an economist with the County Office of Commerce and Economic Development. "On the one hand, there is the recognition of an already high level of indebtedness. And on the other, there is a need to create jobs and income."
The fate of the controversial borrowing plan, which will appear as Proposal One on the ballot, "will depend on what voters think is the prescription to improve the health of the local economy," Ms. Preston said.
Opponents of the plan, including the president of the Westchester County Chamber of Commerce, called it "just a lot of fiscal gimmickry" and said the state should not take on more debt but should do some vigorous "financial housekeeping."
Those in favor of the jobs bond act, including a trade union president, said the proposal offered the only hope for creating jobs and "getting the local economy moving again." And a spokeswoman for the State Office of Economic Development said: "The Governor's proposal more than pays for itself. The critics are wrong."
Governor Cuomo's plan is to create 24,000 construction jobs and 106,000 permanent private-sector jobs statewide by financing construction of roads, bridges, parking lots and sewer systems.
 
390 Projects in the State
 For Westchester, passage of the referendum could mean 3,744 new construction jobs and as many 8,535 new jobs in the business sector once the improvements are in place, according to estimates made by the municipalities that applied for funds.
Statewide, 390 projects were approved from 1,100 applications. In the county, 24 projects of 47 applications were approved.
The act would authorize the state to borrow $800 million in general obligation bonds, with yearly interest and principal payments of $65 million over 25 years.
Based on state projections, up to $155 million would be generated yearly in additional revenues by the infusion of money into local economies statewide -- in terms of new jobs and business development, said Mardi J. Massaroni, the spokeswoman for the Office of Economic Development. Over 25 years, she said, the state estimates that new revenues generated by the improvements would total $3.1 billion, while the debt service on the bond for that period would be $1.7 billion.
The current bond proposal differs from previous ones -- the Transportation Bond Acts of 1983 and 1986, for example -- in that the highway and other projects are designed to help existing businesses expand and to attract new ones.
"What sets this bond act apart from others is that it's not just for highways, bridges or mass transit. It is designed to stimulate jobs in the private sector once the improvements are made," said George Drapeau, director of communications for the Construction Industry Council of Westchester and the Hudson Valley, a trade association that supports the measure and represents 550 contractors, suppliers and service firms in the region.
"It's not just a make-work proposal," Mr. Drapeau said.
With the county's unemployment rate for August at 5.8 percent, the highest jobless rate for the month in 14 years, many government leaders are eager for voter approval on the referendum.
 
Flood Problem in Peekskill
 In Mount Vernon, where Constance G. Post, Commissioner of Planning and Community Development, said, "The hard economic times have really hit home," the city stands to receive $6 million. The state money would match Federal grants for building a railroad transportation center in a commercial and light-industrial area. Officials there estimate that the project would provide 100 construction jobs and 50 permanent private-sector jobs.
In Peekskill, the city would get $1.9 million to correct a flooding problem in a light-industrial area and another $750,000 to rebuild roads in an industrial park. Deborah Post-Stern, deputy director for planning and development, estimated that more than 50 construction jobs and about 800 business-sector jobs would be generated within the next five years. She said that it was necessary to create local jobs in a city where the unemployment rate has averaged 7.9 percent in the last two years, which is higher than the 4.9 percent average for the county during the period from May 1990 to April this year.
And in Dobbs Ferry, where a two-tier parking lot would be built, the Village Administrator, Margaret Slavin, estimated that 125 construction jobs and about 50 jobs in businesses would provide a "shot in the arm" for the Hudson River community.
"We tried the typical things to revitalize the central business district -- new sidewalks, street festivals," she said. "But in this economy, we have a lot of empty stores. And every time we try to attract a new business here, they tell us the big drawback is the lack of parking."
 
Called 'Poor Economic Planning'
 But while many are touting the borrowing plan as "laying a foundation for a better future," as Frank M. Surdey, regional economist for the State Department of Labor, described it, one county business organization opposed it as "poor economic planning" and "a matter of asking the voters to write a blank check without enough specifics." Other business organizations were at best ambivalent.
"The plan lacks credibility," said Harold E. Vogt, president of the 3,000-member Westchester County Chamber of Commerce. "It seems to be just a lot of marketing hype."
Mr. Vogt, who said the proposal was not specific enough, also said that the state should reduce spending and focus its efforts on "financial housekeeping" rather than borrow more money. He said local municipalities and the county -- not the state -- should take the initiative to make needed infrastructure improvements.
In Yonkers, where three projects have been approved for $3 million in state financing under the act, the city's 900-member Chamber of Commerce recently voted "no position" on the bond issue, reported its president, Thomas J. Caramadre.
 
Belt Tightening Proposed
 "The state has spent millions of dollars in the past few years on projects designed to secure jobs and create a better business climate," Mr. Caramadre said. "Yet in that same period, New York lost 400,000 jobs."
"Our vote," he said, "reflects a lack of confidence in the bond act. The hard part is that Yonkers stands to get a lot of money."
Like Mr. Vogt, the Yonkers chamber president suggested that local officials "do some belt tightening" and not rely on money from outside.
Similarly, the Westchester County Association, a business-based civic group with 800 member organizations, voted "down the middle" on the proposed jobs bond act and as a result took no position on the matter, said the association's vice president, Richard D. Schaab.
 
Unions Give Firm Support
 But on a state level the Business Council of New York State, which represents 4,000 member businesses, chambers of commerce and regional associations, approved the proposal.
Labor unions are firmly behind the Governor's plan. The construction industry, which had 19,100 jobs in the county in August, has lost 8,000 jobs -- a drop of 30 percent -- since 1988.
"When construction is going good, that's when the economy really starts to boom," said Edward Doyle, president of the 5,000-member teamsters union, Local 456, which represents teamsters and chauffeurs. "This could mean jobs for us, good-paying, prevailing-wage jobs," he said.
 
Detailed Applications Required
 "Some people say that another bond act is only going to mean that our children and grandchildren will have to pay the taxes on this," said Mr. Doyle, who is also president of the Westchester-Putnam Building and Construction Trades Council, which represents 50,000 workers -- among them plumbers, electricians, painters and carpenters.
"But I say that if we don't get this economy rolling, we won't be able to afford to have children, much less grandchildren," he added.
Under the bond act, most projects are eligible for up to 60 percent in state financing. If a project is in an economic development zone -- an area previously identified as having high unemployment and poverty rates, for example -- it may be eligible for up to 80 percent in financing.
Before funds are awarded, each eligible municipality and county must present a detailed application that spells out how the rest of the project will be financed -- from other grants or from local budget allotments, for example.
 
 
 
APPROVED PROJECTS
THE following is a list of Westchester projects that have been approved for financing under the proposed New York State jobs bond act, which will appear as Proposal 1 on Tuesday's ballot. The amounts approved for most projects represent 60 percent of the total cost. If a project is in what has been previously identified as an economic development zone -- where there are high unemployment and poverty rates, for example -- or as a distressed area, financing under the act could be as high as 80 percent. HEADLINE: THE 1992 FOLLIES

BYLINE: By Russell Baker; Russell Baker is a columnist for The New York Times.

 BODY:
Many an eerie sight have I seen since covering my first Presidential election 36 years ago. I have seen Adlai Stevenson shake hands with a department store mannequin, and I have seen Barry Goldwater embraced by Col. Harlan Sanders in his white Kentucky Fried Chicken suit.
I have seen squadrons of nuns leaping in shamelessly uninhibited ecstasy as young Jack Kennedy sped through Cleveland in an open car. 
 Estes Kefauver have I seen in a coonskin cap, running on straight Scotch whisky and faith that he could cover up a telltale breath with Sen-Sen.
I have seen Richard Nixon let a practically certain victory drip away in sweat, and I have seen Nelson Rockefeller on national television give the finger to an entire Republican National Convention.
And what of the night Lyndon Johnson, flying across the country, so high on certainty of a landslide victory that he couldn't stop talking to reporters, described President Charles de Gaulle as "just an old man who went to South America and fell on his ass"?
I run on and on in the Ancient Mariner vein only to demonstrate the point: I know what I'm talking about when I say that for pure gaudy, obscene, hilarious, unnatural, shameful and silly politicking, the present campaign beats them all, hands down. Connoisseurs and political junkies -- I guarantee it -- will someday look back on Bush versus Clinton versus Perot as one of the great ones, the way old-timers now look back on 1960 as one of the best.
What made 1960 historic was the triumph of television. No words out of Nixon could have jolted a nation of TV addicts the way it was jolted by that perspiration pouring down Nixon's chin. This wasn't Grandpa's dull, old, wordy, Eisenhowerish politics. This was modern, pulse-pounding TV melodrama. A couple of gunslingers about to shoot it out, winner to be President of the United States, and one of them was -- "My God, Clarissa, the man is -- "
Sweating!
That night, image replaced the printed word as the natural language of politics.
Which brings us to 1992 and the Age of Larry King, world's greatest late-night book salesman, right after this brief pause for the 1980's:
In the 1980's, politicians stood tall, whatever that meant. The image mechanics who operated the politicians would have been alarmed to learn it meant anything at all.
It wasn't supposed to mean anything. It was supposed to sound good, make you think of John Wayne, or basketball players, or make you stop thinking of anything at all, just shut down the boring old brain so you could feel good, unhindered by contact with reality. Making you feel was what images were supposed to do, not think.
In the 1980's, imagery ran politics so completely you could elect an actor whose best off-the-cuff lines were filched from old movies. To win by a landslide you didn't even need a speech, just some knockout TV pictures -- fruited plains, amber waves of grain, purple-mountained majesty -- and a pear-toned baritone voice-over saying, "It's morning in America."
Fast-forward to 1992. It's been 32 years since Nixon's historic TV sweat. Half the present population wasn't even born in 1960. Now everything's different. Everything. Elvis is dead. Hair has come and gone. Sex has come and gone. The good old American gunslingers have turned into kids with handguns shooting each other on street corners -- and you too if you break cover at the wrong time. Americans now go to the movies to hiss the cowboys.
Nobody foresaw the amazing change that Presidential politics has undergone. Only a wizard with a taste for the macabre could have predicted that the great age of image politics would end with the Presidential campaign turning into a TV talk show.
Jonathan Yardley of The Washington Post thought it degrading for candidates to be "reduced to the level customarily occupied by authors hustling their books, faded movie stars grasping for one last jolt of celebrity and transvestites telling their pathetic tales." H. L. Mencken, on the other hand, would surely have declared it no more degrading than the customary obscenities associated with Presidential campaigns, and had a marvelous time ridiculing the men who stooped so low to conquer.
Hark back to the time of the absolutely unbeatable George Bush. See him hailed as the greatest statesman since Caesar Augustus. That was only yesterday. March 1991. The Persian Gulf war had the country unnaturally happy with the state of the world, and Bush's approval in the polls stood at 88 percent.
An 88 percent approval rating is as close to unanimous support as a politician can get without the Gestapo doing his polling door to door. Politicians believe in polls. They tell you they believe in God, flag and mother, and maybe they do, sometimes, but three things they really believe in are polls, polls and polls. This faith in polls was about to be fatal to the Presidential ambitions of several Democratic heavyweights.
Aware of polls suggesting George Bush could probably beat George Washington if the Founder were rash enough to challenge him, big Democratic mules like Sam Nunn, Bill Bradley, Mario Cuomo -- and yes, Albert Gore -- declared themselves uninterested in being President, at least any time soon. Gore's later decision to run for Vice President suggests a boyhood spent dreaming of presiding over the Senate.
Those mighty polls undid Bush too. They concentrated his mind on war glory, distracting him from a recession that threatened to settle in like a long-lost relative who had sent for his trunk. Instead of attending to it, Bush endorsed his economists' incessant forecasts that recovery was just around the corner and traveled around basking in hero's receptions and, presumably, piling up film for "morning in America" commercials for the campaign.
Haven't seen any films like that this fall, have we?
It's hard to realize now that the only Democrat nervy enough to tackle Bush back there when he looked like Godzilla was Paul Tsongas. Everybody laughed about Tsongas. Even Tsongas smiled about Tsongas. "A Greek . . . from Massachusetts," he said. Smiling.
His earnestness was funny, of course, because it was so obviously sincere. It's O.K. for media-age candidates to look earnest as long as they don't look sincere about it. For the longest time, it looked as if sincere Tsongas, with his detailed program for fixing the economy, might be Bush's only opponent.
Media people dogged Cuomo. Would nobody save them from this Greek dullness with Italian fire? Cuomo pondered, philosophized, hesitated, consulted his conscience, dithered. And no wonder.
He was at the mercy of Republicans in Albany, a hometown Catholic cardinal trying to make him toe the Pope's line on abortion and a famously devastating Republican well-poisoning squad that had been itching for years to do its Bible Belt number on a New York liberal with a Mediterranean name.
Enter Clinton. Also Kerrey, Harkin, Brown and maybe two or three more we've forgotten. It was the march of the Millard Fillmores.
Say this for them, though: no faint hearts in that bunch of scrubs. Unlike the varsity, which folded before Bush's mighty polls, this gang had nothing to lose. If you are youngish and would like to be President someday, you run once, maybe twice, to get the feel of it, get some name recognition, but not expecting to score first time out.
Clinton fit the profile. He also fit the press's profile of what makes a plausible candidate, which is to say he was orthodox, somebody reporters could call "a pragmatist," meaning "won't let ideology get in the way of doing what's got to be done to get elected."
For a few weeks early in election years, a few political reporters briefly exercise great power. Before and after the silly New Hampshire primary, they make the odds on the candidates, determine what will constitute a victory and afterward decide who won, no matter what the arithmetic says. Among these connoisseurs and kingmakers, Clinton was the choicest of a dim field.
In the cruel shorthand of political journalism, Brown was a flake, Harkin was an outdated liberal, Kerrey lacked fire in the belly and Tsongas was dull, dull, dull. If you were used to deciphering these media guys, you could tell well before the New Hampshire vote that Clinton would have to get caught at something extravagantly unforgiveable to stop the press from anointing him as "front runner."
Enter Gennifer Flowers. Astonishing people were breaking out all over: Pat Buchanan, Tsongas with his accursed dullness and, waiting in the wings, Larry King, Ross Perot, Murphy Brown, the late Harry Truman, Marilyn Quayle and the Texas Richelieu, a.k.a. James A. Baker 3d.
In a production like this, it was inevitable that Ms. Flowers would become known as "Gennifer with a G." Inevitably, she led to demands for a televised soul-baring. Woe to the modern candidate who refuses a televised soul-baring when accused of sin. Look what happened to Gary Hart in 1988 when he failed to seek absolution in the TV confessional. Clinton did his baring on "60 Minutes," with Mrs. Clinton at his side.
It sufficed, though it lacked the magnificently mawkish insincerity of Nixon's great 1952 soul-barer, the "Checkers speech," because of Clinton's congenital inability to tell the whole darned world absolutely everything about his lapses into human folly. (Yes, he once tried a joint, but didn't inhale. Well, how many times did the press want him to explain that complicated draft situation?)
As if to reassure America that he had the right stuff to handle Presidential soul-baring, he larded his convention speech with real-life story values that had nothing to do with curing superpower blues but everything to do with tugging America's heartstrings. So did Gore. What they meant to do about the health-care nightmare may have been vague, but one thing was clear: These fellows had heart.
Meanwhile, Gennifer with a G got lost in the confusion. In a human stew this rich, even 15 minutes of fame was more than a mere Gennifer with a love story could survive.
Because, look, the Republicans were carrying on in full suicidal fig: Pat Buchanan stalking Bush with political murder in his heart and Bush up in New England sounding as nutty as a kid on jolly pills. How's your health, Mr. President? "Don't cry for me, Argentina." What about these charges that you're insensitive to the country's economic pain? "Message: I care."
How better capture the burlesque into which the Republican party had fallen than to note that Buchanan was a newspaper columnist. A newspaper columnist is somebody who's paid to be provocative at breakfast and, for that purpose, is licensed to be as irresponsible as whim dictates. Imagine the party of Abraham Lincoln flirting with the idea of making a newspaper columnist President of the United States.
Urged on by right-wingers who had long wanted to put the boot into Bush, Buchanan slashed into his target with the exquisite cruelty of a devastating phrase-maker. Here was a right-winger's dream of Paradise. Bush had remade himself to please them, had reversed himself on abortion, come out against government, gone to the flag factory, bought the whole right-wing agenda -- and they despised him for it. Despised him for trying to con them.
They knew that deep down Bush had never been one of them, never would be. They weren't fooled by the pork-rind act and efforts to plug himself into the yahooism of darkest Texas. To keep them happy, he had kept Dan Quayle on the ticket though everybody knew Quayle was a klutz, even by Vice Presidential standards.
Bush's gluttony for abuse seemed inexhaustible. What was Buchanan's punishment for savaging his President? Assignment to one of the convention's best prime-time speech slots with permission to turn American politics into religious warfare. The last time a sitting President was treated this rudely by a rump group, Mayor Daley let the Chicago police tattoo their obstreperous skulls with blunt objects.
Convention over, aficionados of high nonsense were treated to President's Bush's announcement that he would run as Harry Truman, though actually, now that you ask, he voted against Truman in 1948. Still, Truman ran against Congress and Bush too would run against Congress.
Many Americans must have happily cried, "At last!" Clinton's convention had boomed with fatuous talk about the great improvements to come under Clinton triumphant, but there had been an absolute dearth of talk about how any improving at all can possibly get done as long as Congress remains in the pay of the special interests.
Alas, that didn't interest Bush either, and he soon quit running as Truman, except for blaming Congress for everything short of warts and acne. After that, he ran under so many identities it was hard to keep track of who he was from day to day.
Are we forgetting Ross Perot? No sirreee. When you see a Ross Perot, it stays with you. This one was straight out of "Alice in Wonderland." Remember the smile of the Cheshire Cat? It lingered on, nothing but a smile hanging in the air, after the cat itself had vanished. That was Ross Perot. He didn't look a bit feline, of course. He had a face like a Toby jug and a voice like Frank Perdue. Put them together announcing plans to spend $100 million of private capital on a Presidential race, and you had Ross Perot.
And then, of course, you didn't have Ross Perot. He had vanished like the Cheshire Cat, leaving the memory of that face, that voice, that $100 million campaign lingering in the air until -- presto! -- back again. A genuine nonparty Cheshire candidate spending barrels of his own billionaire's money.
What was even more wondrous about Perot, however, was this: In an age when professional image-makers had persuaded politicians that image was everything and frivolity was best, Perot kept talking about the deficit, which no real candidate would have wanted to talk about because it was terribly serious and might be terribly painful to get rid of.
Yet -- mirabile dictu -- millions of people did want to hear about the deficit and how to get rid of it. Toward the end, Perot wore out the somber novelty of his bad-news message by turning cute. In the TV debates he went to cute-as-a-bug-in-a-rug style, joking about his ears, using his salesman's Texas vernacular, plugging his future TV commercials.
Maybe Perot will be remembered in history as the father of the talk-show campaign. He announced his first candidacy on CNN, the "Larry King Live" program. After that, Larry King often seemed to be master of ceremonies to the campaign. Clinton, Bush, Perot again. . . . "Larry King Live" was where you went to get your candidacy validated.
Suddenly you could run for President without TV's big three networks. A new television world had sprung up just as the networks' new bean-counting owners were gutting their once-splendid news departments. Now there were CNN, C-Span, dozens of new cable outlets, all of them desperate for something, anything, anything to fill time.
The pols, enslaved for years to the networks by the theory of image politics, suddenly discovered a new television world that needed them just as desperately as they needed it. Ross Perot and Larry King started a revolution. Yes, revolution: Phil Donahue waving his awesome microphone at Presidential timber. Larry King, America's greatest late-night radio book salesman, examining Presidents, billionaires, ambitious Arkansans. George Bush having the CBS breakfast-show hosts for a morning chat in the Rose Garden. Bill Clinton blowing the sax for Arsenio Hall. . . .
Yes, revolution: after all those years of burning up energy and paying through the nose for precious network exposure, these image-crazy guys were suddenly getting exposure galore, and it was free, and the talk shows let them run on and on and on and on and. . . .
Oh, what a magic year it was: the greatest democracy there ever was staging this astonishing production in self-government up there on the biggest stage in the world right in front of every last one of us. What a show, folks! What a show!
Remember Larry King bringing us George Bush that hair-raising night George stumbled into that antique Joe McCarthy persona. And it was for you -- yes you, Smart Cool Young America -- that Arsenio presented Saxophone Bill Clinton and his really happening shades.
Phil Donahue, stand up. Up, Phil baby. You were terrific in those interviews. And you, Marilyn, it was beautiful the way you slid the stiletto into Hillary Clinton that night in Houston.
Dan, Danny Quayle, you were absolutely unbelievable, sweetheart. America will never forget your wow performance as the first member of a Presidential ticket ever to lose to a fictional opponent.
You were tremendous, gang. Every one of you. Absolutely tremendous. And now, ladies and gentlemen, as the company departs please stare very hard into the expanding emptiness . . . very, very hard . . . no blinking now . . . if you don't blink you may be able to see . . . lingering up there in the void . . . just the faintest remnant of an evanesced cat . . . smile.

PUB-DATE: November 1, 1992

SECTION: Section 5; Page 14; Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 2540 words

HEADLINE: WINTER IN THE SUN;
Guadeloupe's Sleepy Satellites

BYLINE: By BARRY GIFFORD; BARRY GIFFORD has traveled extensively in the Caribbean.

 BODY:
IN 1962, when I was 15, my Uncle Buck, who had been a commander in the United States Navy, suggested that it might be interesting for me to work for the summer on a freighter. We were in Tampa, Fla. -- then a smallish cigar-manufacturing town and phosphate port -- and there were plenty of ships in the harbor, so we went down to the docks and looked them over. Buck struck up a conversation with the captain of a Norwegian cargo boat. We repaired to a bar, where the two men drank whisky and I had a root beer. Buck tried to convince the skipper to take me on as a cabin boy, but since I had no seaman's papers he couldn't do it. His boat was heading down through the Caribbean; its only definite destinations at that point were Pointe-a-Pitre, in Guadeloupe, and Fort-de-France, in Martinique. I don't remember much of what the captain said, but I still recall his remarking on the extraordinary skills of his Colombian crewmen who played soccer on the deck and never once kicked the ball overboard. It was also the first time I had ever heard of Pointe-a-Pitre.
It was many years before I made it to Pointe-a-Pitre, on a different kind of adventure. That port is the jumping-off point for the Iles des Saintes and Marie-Galante, islands in the Guadeloupe archipelago in the French West Indies. 
 Though there are regularly scheduled flights via Air Guadeloupe to Terre-de-Haut, one of the eight Iles des Saintes, I always prefer to approach a destination by boat when possible. I like the feeling of the waves, of knowing the distance at sea level the way the first people to arrive at the place did. In the case of Terre-de-Haut, where my wife, Mary Lou, and I would be staying for the next four days, we were following in the wake of the Arawaks, then the Caribs, and of Christopher Columbus. He came upon this archipelago on Nov. 4, 1493, three days after the Feast of All Saints, and named the islands Los Santos. It was not until Oct. 18, 1648, that Charles Houel, the Governor of Guadeloupe, seized them in the name of the crown. It was Houel who supervised the extermination of the Carib Indians, and established a government in 1659. Slavery was introduced on the more fertile of the two inhabited islands, Terre-de-Bas, where the sugar cane plantations were located. Men were shanghaied in France and brought to settle both islands, and women were paid to come over to provide them with sexual services.
Due to their strategic position in the Caribbean, and the marvelous anchorage, many naval battles between the British and the Frence were fought for control of Les Saintes. In 1782, for example, the Royal Navy, under Admiral Rodney, routed the French under Admiral de Grasse; so the British took over for a short spell, and it was not until 1815 that Les Saintes -- as the Iles des Saintes are familiarly known -- again became French territory.
Terre-de-Haut was settled mostly by whites, the families that came as part of the French military presence established at Fort Napoleon -- begun in 1781, completed in 1867 -- which still stands, immaculately preserved, on a promontory on the north side of the island. The residents of both Terre-de-Bas and Marie-Galante are mainly descendants of the slaves brought there to work the coffee plantations and sugar cane fields.
The boat trip from Pointe-a-Pitre to Terre-de-Haut takes about an hour and a half, and our ride was calm -- unusually so, said a fellow passenger who had made the crossing often. The entrance to Terre-de-Haut is spectacularly beautiful, signaled by a baby version of Le Pain du Sucre (sugarloaf) in Rio de Janeiro, and Le Chameau (the camel), its highest peak (1,014 feet). Our base would be Le Village Creole, a hotel comprising 22 duplexes overlooking the bay at Pointe Coquelet.
"This is what St. Barts was 20 years ago," said Ghyslain Laps, the owner of our hotel and the secretary of the local department of tourism. "People don't really know about Les Saintes." In fact, the archipelago of Les Saintes comprises eight islands altogether, and only Terre-de-Haut is equipped to accommodate tourists. There are a half-dozen hotels on the island, several of which cater to English-speaking guests; all offer the kinds of conveniences modern-day travelers appreciate.
The island is roughly the same size as Key West, three by two miles, and has the feel of the Lower Keys, but the Keys of the 1920's. There are only 1,500 people on Terre-de-Haut. There is no crime here, no need to lock doors or worry about pickpockets.
Other than tourism, which accounts for about 50 percent of the local economy, the main industry is fishing. The island boats are 20-foot dinghies with outboard motors. The men, most of whom begin their profession at 18, wear flat bamboo hats called salakos, whose design is said to have originated in Saigon, where the hats were worn by the police; nobody is certain how or when this Far Eastern wrinkle came to Les Saintes. Using blue nets strung with bright orange buoys, the fishermen haul in tuna, kingfish and daurade (dolphin, or mahi-mahi). They also trap rock lobster and crab, and conch is a local delicacy.
The ferrys from Guadeloupe dock at Bourg, the largest of the island's towns. Rental cars are not available on Terre-de-Haut, nor are they necessary: residents and visitors get around on foot or on scooters. The hotels have vans to transport guests, and minibuses, called Taxis de l'Ile, are available for two-hour tours. But with the exception of the climb up Le Chameau or to Fort Napoleon, the best way to get around the island is to walk, the winding streets and roads providing often breathtaking views of the sea and other islands.
Guadeloupe is only seven and a half miles away, and at night the lights of Pointe-a-Pitre are blazingly visible. During the day you can see the dormant Soufriere volcano on Basse-Terre -- all of these islands are volcanic -- its peak cloaked by cumulus clouds drifting across its sleeping head. Flowers grow everywhere, including yucca, purple granadilla, dragon bone tree, Turk's cap, prickly poppy and crown-of-thorns. Pelicans conceal themselves in the thickets, goats clamber all over, bleating and scavenging for food, and iguanas abound on the beaches.
And there are, of course, many beaches. The most perfect, perhaps, is on the northeast side of the island at the Baie de Pompiere, an idyllic cove protected from the harsher waves by Les Roches Percees, hills that form a narrow inlet. Pompiere was a fabled refuge for pirates, and there are those who believe treasure remains buried along the white sand beach. At Anse Crawen, on the northern side, there is a nude beach; Grand Anse is a long stretch on the eastern side of the island, where because of a decided undertow and rough waves, swimming is not recommended, but it is lovely to walk along. At Marigot Bay, on the northern part of the island, is a good swimming beach, also the site of the Union des Centres de Plein Air. The center is the place for intensive wind surfing and sailing; they offer weeklong packages that include lodging, meals, lessons and unlimited use of sailboards and Hobie Cat catamarans. The Club Nautique des Saintes rents tanks and gear for diving and also provides instruction. There are no sharks around Les Saintes; they stay farther north, near the Gulf Stream.
Terre-de-Haut is something of a paradise for those who do not crave casinos and heavy-duty night life. The one disco, next to the airport landing strip, is open only on Saturday night for three hours. At night the church outside the Hotel Santoise is illuminated by neon lights.
Since there is very little fresh water on Terre-de-Haut, there is a desalinization plant that provides most of the drinking and washing water. This, of course, is very expensive, and tourists use a great deal of water.
FOR this reason, the intention of the hoteliers, like Mr. Laps, is to limit the numbers of tourists who come to Les Saintes. The ideal, says Mr. Laps, who seems to speak for the other hoteliers, is to allow no more than 250 rooms for visitors.
"After all," he told me, "this place is not for everybody. Sure, for you and I, it's paradise. But for people who need more to do, it doesn't work -- at least not for very long."
Mary Lou and I reluctantly left Les Saintes, taking the ferry back to Pointe-a-Pitre, where we spent a couple of hours waiting for another boat to take us to Marie-Galante. Aboard the Trans-Antilles Express ferry, which sped us to Grand Bourg on Marie-Galante in less than an hour, I read up on our destination. Marie-Galante, 25 miles south of Guadeloupe, covers 59 square miles -- the largest island in the Guadeloupe chain. Columbus named it Maria Graciosa in 1493, the nickname of his ship, the Santa Maria. The French occupied it in 1648, though the British battled them for it for awhile. The French reclaimed it for good in 1816. Most of the island, which has 13,500 residents, is still covered with sugar cane fields, and sugar and rum are its chief products. We were met at the dock at sunset by Philippe Bavarday, who operates a tour bus and taxi service, serves as the unofficial director of tourism and, in general, is the man to see for just about anything. He drove us to a nearby gas station to pick up our rental car, a Fiat; (unlike on Terre-de-Haut, a car, or at least a motor scooter, is necessary here). Following him to his guest house, we knew right away how different an experience this would be. The fields and hills we passed were lush, unlike the rocky, desert-like terrain of Les Saintes -- in fact, it had just rained. And there was evidence of extreme poverty.
Mr. Bavarday led us to our Spartan room: a wooden table, two wooden chairs, two slender wooden beds, a small refrigerator, sink, bathroom, wardrobe closet, bare bulb suspended from the ceiling -- a marked contrast to Le Village Creole, where we had every modern convenience, including a phone. Now we were in the middle of a large, strange island, without much of a clue as to where to go even to get something to eat.
We took off in our little Fiat toward Grand Bourg -- the largest of three "major" towns on Marie-Galante, including St. Louis and Capesterre -- where we found a little restaurant called Raissa. We ordered the only thing on the menu that night, the fish called daurade. We were the only customers.
It turned out that the restaurant's proprietor was one of Philippe Bavarday's brothers, and he served us a superb meal, the grilled fish seasoned perfectly with hot pepper and lime. Afterward, he brought out a bottle of eight-year-old Bielle dark rum, distilled locally. It was the beginning of a magnificent four days; if our time in Les Saintes was magical, this was to be meaningful: this was not an island designed to entertain tourists. Marie-Galante, it became apparent, was a place for travelers; conventional expectations had to be left behind.
During our stay, we discovered that not only was the food wonderful -- another waterfront restaurant, Le Corail, serves superb langouste grillade (grilled lobster) -- but the beaches, especially at Capesterre, about five and a half miles from Grand Bourg, are among the best in the Caribbean. The Chateau Murat, once a grand plantation, is now a well-maintained museum, displaying the history of the island; and the rum distilleries -- we visited Bielle -- welcome visitors. The daily market on the Rue d'Eglise, in front of the church, offers all types of goods; and on various street corners fishermen sell their daily catch. Almost everything is available on Marie-Galante except luxury accommodations, which is why 90 percent of its visitors are day-trippers.
They are missing a lot. Although limited, there are a few small hotels on the island, including Le Quartier Latin, the Auberge and the Belvedere, as well as Mr. Bavarday's guest house and a number of villas available for rent. It is necessary to speak some French (or Creole), and to be able to fend for yourself, but the people are very open and friendly and -- as in Les Saintes -- there is no crime.
As for night life, there are actually three clubs on the island: Touloulou in Capesterre on the beachand El Sombrero and El Rancho in Grand Bourg. The bands play zouk, a kind of world beat music with lots of percussion. There are a couple of good cafes, La Brioche and Le Salon de The; the latter is open late at night and serves liquor. Le Salon is where the fishing guides hang out, and it's a perfect spot from which to observe the goings-on at the port.
Before we left Marie-Galante, Philippe Bavarday asked us how the island might draw more North American tourists. One obvious way, we agreed, was by adding at least one or two first-class hotels. But my wife and I found that we liked Marie-Galante just as it is: a kind of no-frills idyll that provides a fine counterpoint to Terre-de-Haut. While I'm old enough now to know that nothing stays the same for long, it will surely be a while before Mr. Bavarday and the others have their way. And until then, Marie-Galante can be considered one of the secret treasures of the Caribbean.
 
 
 
FROM RESTAURANTS TO SCOOTERS
Getting There
 A working knowledge of French is useful and, at times, essential for visiting Terre-de-Haut and Marie-Galante. The office of tourism is on the waterfront in Pointe-a-Pitre, Guadeloupe; telephone 82.09.30.
Air Guadeloupe (83.06.61) has two flights a day from Pointe-a-Pitre to Terre-de-Haut; the round-trip fare is $70. There are two Antilles Trans Express ferries a day from Point-a-Pitre: the trip lasts 75 minutes and costs $31 round trip. Three ferries a day leave from Trois-Rivieres and Basse-Terre, making the 30-minute trip for $15.
Air Guadeloupe has three round-trip flights a day from Pointe-a-Pitre to Marie-Galante for $70.
 
Places to Stay
 Among the half-dozen hotels on Terre-de-Haut, the Village Creole at Pointe Coquelet, (590) 99.53.83, has 22 duplexes on the water, each with a kitchen and patio. Winter rates are $156 waterfront, $124 on the garden side. One of the proprietors speaks English.
Also on Terre-de-Haut, the Bois Joli, (590) 99.50.38, at Anse a Cointe, is on a hill above a beach with 21 rooms and eight bungalows, a restaurant and pool. Doubles from $158.
On Marie-Galante, accommodations are very simple. Philippe Bavarday has four rooms in his home in Grand-Bourg, all with kitchenettes; (590) 97.83.94. A room is $47 a night in winter for two. L'Arbre a Pain, also in Grand-Bourg (97.73.69), is another simple inn, with seven rooms and a restaurant. A double is $46.
 
Dining
 Terre-de-Haut restaurants serve mostly seafood and creole fare at modest prices. A more ambitious option is Le Relais des Iles (99.53.04) with 10 tables in a private home; reservations required. About $35 a person.
On Marie-Galante we had wonderful lobster at Le Corail at 40 Rue de la Marine ($35 for two).
 
Getting Around
 Bicycles on Terre-de-Haut cost about $15 a day, motor scooters about $27.
Cars can be rented on Marie-Galante at Canevas (97.97.76) for $48 a day. Scooters ($29 a day) and bicycles ($13 a day) can be rented at Dingo Passion, Grand Bourg (97.76.58).

PUB-DATE: November 1, 1992

SECTION: Section 10; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1323 words

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living in: Park Slope

BYLINE: By BRET SENFT

 BODY:
PARK SLOPE is families everywhere and brownstones, street after street of them. Far enough from Manhattan for a neighborhood feel, it maintains, in its multiracial population and cultural institutions, what many residents call an urban sophistication.
"A very small-town community with a cosmopolitan attitude," said George Etchison, a 20-year resident and owner of the Brownstone Gallery on Seventh Avenue, the Slope's main street. The gallery's current exhibition, "Made in Brooklyn," features local artists and memorabilia from the borough's heyday. 
 The "small town" was still a sparsely populated rural area in 1857, when the railroad financier Edwin C. Litchfield built an Italianate villa overlooking his vast property sloping down to the Gowanus Canal.
By 1874, the 526-acre Prospect Park was completed, designed by Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux to encompass the villa, which now houses park offices. The designers, regretting the traverses of Central Park, their earlier commission, created a separate entity, Institute Park, for the main branch of the Brooklyn Public Library, the Brooklyn Museum and a 50-acre Botanic Garden, north of Flatbush Avenue.
Grand Army Plaza, the main entrance to the park, was patterned after the traffic circle around Paris's Arc de Triomphe; Victory in her chariot pulled by four horses rides atop the massive Soldiers' and Sailors' Memorial arch.
In the 1880's, mansions and brownstones for the English and German upper class, with stained-glass windows, carved oak paneling and high-relief plasterwork, were built along the park and adjacent blocks. Along Eighth Avenue off the Plaza are Romanesque Revival mansions built in 1888 by Thomas Adams Jr., creator of Chiclets chewing gum, and in 1891 by George P. Tangeman, the baking powder magnate. The Venetian Gothic palazzo built in 1891 for the private Montauk Club has a terra-cotta exterior and friezes depicting its eponymous tribe. The Park Slope Civic Council holds an annual neighborhood house tour in May.
As the area developed, distance from the park was measured economically, with more modest brownstones built in the central and south Slope for Irish and Italian immigrants working as servants for the gentry, on the waterfront or in factories.
In the 1950's, with middle-class flight to the suburbs and social deterioration, one-family brownstones were converted to rooming houses. In the 60's, so-called Brownstone Pioneers -- young professionals, along with artists and teachers -- reclaimed the rowhouses, buying cheap and embarking on long-term renovations.
"We called it 'the schoolteacher's coup' -- buying an Upper East Side-quality brownstone on schoolteachers' pay," said Everett H. Ortner, writer, historian and co-founder in 1968 of the Brownstone Revival Committee. (His wife, Evelyn, a longtime community activist, led the seven-year effort that culminated in 1973 in the designation of a historic district bordering the park and Plaza.)
In those "coup" days, a brownstone cost less than $25,000. Today, they cost $360,000 to $500,000, says Roberta L. Faulstick of William B. May Company, although "many handyman specials in the South Slope" average $250,000.
Most prevalent, however, is "the resegmentation of the housing stock into luxury co-ops," said Clem Labine, a 25-year resident and publisher of Traditional Building, a magazine for professional restorers. Two-bedroom co-ops in brownstones run $125,000 to $250,000, said Ms. Faulstick.
Rentals range from $700 for a studio to $1,600 for a three-bedroom duplex, higher if there is a garden, terrace or roof deck.
ON a recent Sunday at the park boathouse, David Kaplan and his family enjoyed the Touch of Autumn fair organized by park rangers. Mr. Kaplan, a vice-president with Citibank, held his son Isaac, 2 years old, while Bonnie Quint Kaplan and their daughter Nadine, 5, toured the nature exhibits that were in the boathouse that weekend.
"This is a very relaxed place to live compared to Manhattan," said Ms. Kaplan, unwrapping a sandwich for Nadine. The family lives in a seven-room co-op in a tall luxury building at 35 Prospect Park West, offering, Ms. Kaplan said, "a Fifth Avenue feeling, since we're right across from the park, in a building we couldn't possibly afford if it were in Manhattan."
Among the amenities are the park, with its carrousel, which was renovated by the Prospect Park Alliance, and the zoo, which is to reopen next year after a $36 million renovation; a half-dozen day-care centers; the Pinch Sitters Agency, for last-minute babysitters; a farmers' market in Grand Army Plaza each Saturday; the 3,850-member Park Slope Food Co-op in two converted carriage houses on Union Street; the Brooklyn Conservatory of Music, offering concerts and recitals, and, in warm weather, frequent brownstone stoop sales, the counterpart to suburban garage sales.
Inside the park bordering the neighborhood is the 11th Street playground, the nearby Bandshell and, across West Drive, seven ball fields for a thriving Little League population.
For the hungry, there's a wide choice on Seventh Avenue, including New Prospect at Home (at St. John's Place; take-out entrees, salads and pastries), the New Purity Restaurant (Union Street; since 1929); Inaka Sushi House (at Fourth Street) and the kid-friendly Two Boots Pizza (off Seventh at Second Street).
At Seventh Street, John J. Cortese runs the grocery his grandfather founded 77 years ago. His stock-in-trade, besides dry goods, fruits and vegetables, is children. As commissioner of the Park Slope Baseball League, he oversees 34 sandlot teams and coordinates umpires for 140 Little League teams in the spring.
"On Saturdays and Sundays, it's a beautiful thing to see: wall-to-wall kids in Prospect Park," he said.
A downside is the progressive neighborhood's inability to reach consensus on social problems. Illegal street vendors clog the Seventh Avenue sidewalks on weekends and the homeless beg for change at several automatic teller machines. Does this bespeak urban blight or personal initiative? Neighborhood reaction is split 50-50, according to Craig R. Hammerman, assistant district manager for Community Board 6.
"THIS is a place where a marketplace of ideas are freely bantered about," he said. "Thus, not merely the debate but the appearance of inaction can be frustrating."
There are six elementary schools, with P.S. 321 on Seventh Avenue getting high marks for its heavy parental involvement. The Brooklyn New School, an alternative created by the district in 1987, with emphasis on individual hands-on learning, adjoins I.S. 88 (one of two junior high schools).
The once-troubled John Jay High School, with 4,000 students, got a $3 million Federal grant in 1989 to upgrade and introduce new curriculum, such as the law and justice program, with its model courtroom and forensic laboratory and a computerized library research system. The school has been divided into Houses (such as Law and Justice, Humanities and Computer), with corporate partnerships with I.B.M., which provided networked computer labs throughout the school, and Chemical Bank, which provided funds for special projects.
As for private schools, the Woodward Park School, created in 1978 in a merger with the Brooklyn Ethical Culture School, uses progressive Bank Street methods of experiential learning for its 160 students from nursery to grade 8. Tuition is $7,000 to $9,000 a year.
Founded in 1886, the Berkeley Carroll School, with 640 pre-k-12 students, emphasizes math, science and foreign language and has computer instruction starting in kindergarten. The Beyond Berkeley Carroll program has students volunteering in soup kitchens, geriatric centers and environmental projects throughout the neighborhood. Summer programs include a day camp, Young Scientists Institute and the well-known Creative Arts program. Tuition is $4,500 to $10,800 a year.

HEADLINE: An Era Ends. Silently.

BYLINE: By Alan Ehrenhalt; Alan Ehrenhalt, executive editor of Governing magazine, is author of "The United States of Ambition: Politicians, Power, and the Pursuit of Office."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
We expect eras to end with a big noise in Presidential politics: with the sound of a cannon, as in 1861, when the Democrats lost everything; with the collapse of a boom into outright depression, as in 1933, when the Republicans' world fell apart.
We aren't trained to expect cataclysmic change from an election year as petty and mundane as this one has been. But an era is ending, and in the weeks to come we should finally begin to see this clearly. 
 It was an era in which Presidential elections, for all their seeming complexity, were decided more than anything else on one issue -- the belief of the middle class that the Democratic Party intended to take their money away and give it to a disorderly, undeserving and often violent minority. This issue elected Richard Nixon in 1968. And it permitted George Bush to triumph over Michael Dukakis 20 years later.
Ronald Reagan was not, as so many Republicans hoped he would be, the symbol of a new day in American politics. The day was half over as he arrived. When Mr. Reagan took the oath of office in 1980, it was not just noon on the Inauguration Day clock, it was also noon for the Republican era in late 20th century politics.
And 1992 is dusk. Certainly, it remains possible that on Tuesday the peculiar three-cornered contest will allow George Bush to win re-election with a vote no larger than the 38 percent Barry Goldwater received in 1964. But even if that happens, the evidence is overwhelming that 1992 represents something new in politics.
In every Presidential election since 1968, the middle class concerns of race and crime have been at the center of campaign debate. This year, they have scarcely been discussed. In every election since 1968, it has been a disadvantage to be associated too closely with legalized abortion, gay rights and similar challenges to social orthodoxy. This year, it has been a disadvantage to be on the orthodox side of these issues. In every election since 1968, it has been possible to raise fears about the Democrats' ability to cope with the Communist threat. This year, there are hardly any Communists to be threatened by.
Taxes remain a touchy subject. But during the last month of the campaign Ross Perot rose dramatically in the polls at a time when his only specific proposal for reviving the economy was a 50 cent gasoline tax. No candidate could have done that with impunity in 1988, 1984 or 1980.
This year's campaign has been a game played on a new board with a whole new set of rules. The first new rule is hard times. It is a remarkable fact that, while the decline of U.S. economic strength, real wages and living standards goes back to the early 1970's, only one Presidential election in the past 25 years -- 1980 -- has been held in what might legitimately be described as a climate of austerity. In each of the other campaigns, the economy was merely an issue. It was not, for most of America, the subject of terror in the night.
In the 1992 electorate, it is easy to camouflage the depth of economic fear behind the statistical facts of low inflation, low interest rates and less than alarming unemployment. When these economic statistics were run through computer models that had accurately predicted past elections, the result was a comfortable victory for George Bush. But those models are wrong because the economic reality of 1992 renders such conventional statistics obsolete.
The reality is this: breadwinners all over the country have been forced out of well-paid manufacturing jobs into low-wage work they regard as beneath their dignity and living standard. Families of four struggle to survive on two $15,000 incomes, sacrificing virtually all of their free time together. Middle-aged Americans, born into relative affluence in 1955 or 1960, believe not only that they have failed to achieve the comfort they expected in life but that they are never going to achieve it. What the economic models do not detect and what most experts took forever to realize is that for many of these people, 1992 is the political equivalent of 1932.
One can carry this too far, of course. Unemployment is not 25 percent, there are no shantytowns in Washington. But 1932 is worth thinking about for a variety of reasons.
Herbert Hoover, the incumbent President, a man of dignity and personal accomplishment, appeared painfully unable to understand what was happening to the country. "There seems to be a condition of hysteria," Mr. Hoover observed in 1931, in a tone of genuine befuddlement. "If someone could get off a good joke every 10 days, I think our troubles would be over."
That suggests one way to test for the close of an era in American politics: look for an elected leader who seems addled by the changes that have taken place around him. Eras end in the sentence fragments of Presidents who seem unsure about why they are there and what they are supposed to do.
Eras also end, it is reasonable to expect, with a considerable change of faces at all levels of the political system. That will happen this year, no matter whom we elect President. The 1932 election ushered 166 new members into the House of Representatives -- nearly 40 percent of the membership. While it is hard to imagine as many newcomers this time, it is certain that there will be many more than 100 new Representatives. It also appears that more than a third of the country's state legislators will be freshmen, roughly twice the usual number. In several states, such as Kansas, there will not even be enough returning legislators to run all the important committees.
Something is missing here: the prospect of huge partisan upheaval. In the past, any big turnover in Congress has meant a reversal of party control as well. Republicans lost more than 100 House seats in 1932. But this year we are facing an astonishing political event -- a wholesale exchange of bodies in which the balance of power between the two parties may remain largely unaffected. When the smoke clears, Democrats are likely to keep roughly the majorities they have now.
But all those new faces will mark the end of an era in Congress, even if the partisan and ideological balance stays just about the same. The 1932 election swept out dozens of elderly men whose memories were of post-Civil War America. It replaced them with people reared in this century and shaped by World War I and the 1920's.
Something a little like that is going to happen this year. We are going to trade in a large chunk of the World War II political generation for children of the 1950's and 1960's, creatures of early postwar affluence and, more recently, generational self-doubt and disappointment. That is the making of a new era and a new government, whether the partisan breakdown changes very much or not.
When it comes to finding turning points in American political history, journalists carry the burden of having cried wolf once or twice too often. It helps, if one has to spend all year buried in the minutiae of the campaign, to see it as a giant fork in the road. Usually it is nothing of the sort. The election passes and we all muddle on just about as before. The leaders change, the policies may change, but the essential political rules remain the same. Nobody has to bother learning a new vocabulary to understand what is going on. That was true in 1988, despite a year's worth of rhetoric to the contrary. It was even true in 1980. It is not true this time.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
BUSH AND CLINTON GO NONSTOP IN BATTLING FOR CRUCIAL STATES

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STRATFORD, Conn., Nov. 1

 BODY:
Raspy-voiced but outwardly ebullient, President Bush ended the weekend as he began it, banging away at Bill Clinton during a last-shot sweep of states he must win if he is to be re-elected.
In blustery Michigan, before cameras aboard Air Force One and on the airport tarmac in Connecticut, the President leveled new accusations about Mr. Clinton's position on taxes and his handling of questions about his efforts to avoid military service. 
 Mr. Bush tried to rebut the clear impression that he is descending into a catch-up strategy of deeply negative campaigning in the race's final hours.
"We didn't invite that term, 'Slick Willie. We didn't invite it," he said at a rally of about 6,000 party workers at a professional basketball arena in the Detroit suburb of Auburn Hills. "It's come in from Arkansas; it was all through the Democratic primary. We are not going after his character; we're doing what Harry Truman is: We tell the truth, and they think it's hell. So be it."
 
Tough and Getting Tougher
 But Bush aides acknowledged that the final hours were only likely to get more bitter and that Mr. Bush intended to place Mr. Clinton's character at the core of every speech.
"There isn't any campaign that's this close and this tough that won't be even tougher in the last couple days," Mr. Bush's campaign chairman, Robert M. Teeter, said in an interview.
Mr. Bush's day started on a sour note in Wisconsin, where an unfavorable poll and a tough television interview seemed to leave him in a dour mood. But tonight, when Mr. Bush landed by helicoptor just outside Bridgeport, the President was as cocky as he has been in this campaign.
 
Tireless on the Attack
 "It's not the pollsters, it's not the pundits, it's not the talking heads on television who tell you how to vote," he shouted to the Connecticut crowd of about 8,000. "The American people make up their minds on Election Day.
"I love a good fight, and we're going to take it right to 'em," he concluded. "Right around the American media."
Away from the campaign rallies, the President spent hours before local and national television cameras, making twin attacks on what his aides view as Mr. Clinton's weakest spots: his tax proposals, and his character.
In interviews in Detroit and aboard Air Force One, Mr. Bush raised new questions about Mr. Clinton's stated intentions to revive the economy by making a $220 billion "investment" in new roads, advanced technology and other basic needs.
Today, the President asserted that Mr. Clinton was concealing a different agenda. He cited a 1988 Newsweek magazine article in which Mr. Clinton was quoted as saying that "investment" was a term that could be used to make a tax increase more palatable.
 
'His Own Words'
 "Let me read you his own words," Mr. Bush said tonight before some 8,000 people at an airport rally in Stratford. "He said, 'There's a lot of evidence you can sell people on tax increases if they think its an investment.' His own words reveal this duplicity. We're talking about investment, and he means tax increases."
 
Raising the Draft Issue
 In the Detroit suburb of Auburn Hills, as campaign aides handed out copies of a sworn statement to reporters, Mr. Bush said there was evidence that "friends" tried to advance Mr. Clinton's political career in the 1970's by demanding University of Arkansas records on his efforts to avoid military service during the Vietnam war.
"Even today we have new evidence, an affidavit that when Governor Clinton first ran for office, his friends used special connections to seize his R.O.T.C. file and destroy all others," Mr. Bush said. "He's got to level with the American people on this one."
In the affidavit, a retired Army colonel, Donald R. Cake, said that while he worked at the university's R.O.T.C. unit in 1973 or 1974, he was told that "representatives of Bill Clinton" had approached the unit's records clerk and demanded all documents in Mr. Clinton's file.
Later, Mr. Cake swore, he and others in an R.O.T.C. staff meeting were told by the unit's commander, Col. Guy Tutwiler, that the clerk's account was accurate and that the R.O.T.C.'s regional headquarters had deferred a decision on whether to comply with the request. University officials had advised him to release the records, Mr. Cake swore.
Mr. Cake stated in the affidavit that he had decided to make his account public because Clinton aides had called reports of the incident "hogwash."
For weeks, Mr. Bush has called on Mr. Clinton to make good on a promise made last April to release all records relating to his military service. "He has never done that to this day," Mr. Bush said. "He's waffling, and ducking."
 
Withdrew From Unit
 At the time the R.O.T.C. events took place, Mr. Clinton was mounting his first political campaign, for the House of Representatives. Four years earlier, in 1969, he had enrolled in the unit in an attempt to avoid the draft. He withdrew from the unit several months later, when his risk of being drafted had declined.
As grist for his accusations, Mr. Bush was relying in part on an accusation in Saturday's Washington Times, a conservative newspaper that has attacked Mr. Clinton.
But in an interview before the Washington Times account appeared, James Davis, a retired Army colonel who ran the R.O.T.C. program at Arkansas from mid-1974 to 1980, said neither Mr. Clinton nor anyone else approached him for records.
In Wisconsin early today for a television interview, Mr. Bush appeared subdued and a bit nettled after being told that one new poll, by CNN, showed him falling further behind Mr. Clinton. Mr. Teeter later challenged the poll, saying that other surveys and the campaign's own data show otherwise.
By the time he arrived in rainy, windy Detroit to stump at a rally in the Detroit Pistons' new arena, the Palace, Mr. Bush had regained his smile.
"There's been a little panic in Little Rock, because I think the goal that Bill Clinton has seen ever since he was studying away in Oxford might be slipping away from them," he said. "He's begun attacking my character, and I'd love to fight this one out."
Responding to a shout from the crowd, Mr. Bush laughed then and said, "Yeah, he is a character."
On Monday, his last day on the road, Mr. Bush will race through New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Kentucky and Louisiana on his way to an election eve reception in Houston, where he will await the returns on Tuesday.
Those states, with Michigan and Connecticut, are seen as Mr. Bush's best remaining shots in a struggle for the Midwest and East that holds the balance of Mr. Bush's hopes.

LENGTH: 1585 words

HEADLINE: D'Amato Matching Blows With Abrams In Campaign Flurry

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
After trading invectives in their final televised debate of the United States Senate race yesterday, Robert Abrams and Alfonse M. D'Amato plunged into the pivotal New York City suburbs in the final hours before an election that may depend less on either candidate's performance than on Gov. Bill Clinton's projected margin of victory in the state.
The national and local campaigns have generated hundreds of thousands of newly registered voters in New York who could jeopardize the Republican majority in New York's State Senate and threaten other incumbents, Mr. D'Amato included. He has spent more in this campaign than any other candidate for United States Senate in the nation -- in excess of $10 million -- to overcome political handicaps that might have discouraged a less tenacious candidate and which a bolder challenger might have exploited more. 
 In yesterday's debate, Mr. Abrams, the State Attorney General and Democratic nominee, nudged and Mr. D'Amato gently elbowed in a nonetheless bruising, capsulized replay of their rancorous campaign.
For every thrust Mr. Abrams intoned in his earnest sing-song, Mr. D'Amato countered with a strategic parry delivered in an uncharacteristically subdued chirp. He even transformed an exchange over national health care -- the political magic bullet that has helped defeat Republican candidates elsewhere -- into a fusillade against tax increases that Mr. Abrams has proposed or that Mr. D'Amato insisted would be a consequence of the Democrat's agenda.
Largely ignoring Mr. D'Amato's effort to equate their ethical and financial lapses, Mr. Abrams instead drew a distinction between their positions on abortion, the economy and other political touchstones.
The debate was defined, in part, by what the candidates said they were not.
"I'm not a diplomat," Senator D'Amato said, maintaining that he would prefer to be characterized as a "fighter."
"I am not a visionary," said Mr. Abrams, suggesting, rather, that versions of his national health-care proposal have already been adopted in other industrialized countries and that he would fight for his version here.
 
Taking to the Skies
 Both candidates plan campaign fly-arounds, the airborne equivalent of the whistle-stop, in upstate New York today.
Mr. Abrams left New York for several hours last evening to join Mr. Clinton and his running mate, Senator Al Gore, for a Democratic campaign extravaganza at the Meadowlands in suburban New Jersey, which is beyond the borders of Mr. Abrams's constituency but well within the New York media market.
And during the debate, which competed for viewers with the New York City Marathon, Mr. D'Amato invoked Mr. Clinton's name repeatedly and never disparagingly.
The Senator mentioned President Bush by name only twice -- Mr. Abrams did nine times. But Mr. D'Amato recalled twice that he had opposed the President's decision to break his "read my lips" pledge and support the 1990 Federal tax increase.
Mr. D'Amato also sought to identify himself with an emerging political totem, Norman Rosenbaum, whose brother Yankel, a rabbinical student, was killed during disturbances last year in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn. Mr. Abrams visited there Saturday night and Mr. D'Amato returned there yesterday for a rally protesting the acquittal of the teen-ager who had been accused of the slaying.
The Senator was introduced by Norman Rosenbaum, who said, "When so many others were silent, I was fortunate enough to have a politician and a friend in Al D'Amato."
Mr. D'Amato declared, in Hebrew: "Justice must be pursued."
 
Support for Death Penalty
 In the course of the debate, Mr. D'Amato reiterated his support for the death penalty -- even if it meant that an innocent person might be executed. "We're having tens of thousands of people being executed on a daily basis throughout this country," the Senator noted hyperbolically, then added: "I know Yankel Rosenbaum's family. I have met with Norman many, many times. I want to know what Bob Abrams is going to do when he looks him in the eye and says, 'No I'm opposed to justice in this case.' "
To which Mr. Abrams, recalling that he favors life imprisonment without parole for murderers, replied:
"I looked Yankel Rosenbaum's brother in the eye last night for two hours. I spent two hours with Norman Rosenbaum and with the leadership of the Crown Heights community in Crown Heights, where we talked about what has to be done to make sure that that terrible, terrible misdeed, which is yet to be prosecuted, that we have to seek justice and go out and do something about it."
Mr. D'Amato was slightly behind but statistically tied with Mr. Abrams in several polls last week after struggling in his first Senate race against a single opponent.
 
Scars From Primary Race
 Mr. Abrams emerged from the Democratic primary campaign hobbled both by a scarcity of money and by the enmity generated by what Mr. D'Amato described as "tag team" attacks on one candidate, former Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, by Mr. Abrams and by a third contender for the Democratic nomination, New York City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman. After Mr. Abrams apologized for the tone and inferences of the campaign, Ms. Ferraro finally endorsed him over the weekend.
"We've got everything coming together," Mr. Abrams buoyantly declared yesterday at the beginning of the hourlong debate on WNBC-TV, which was carried simultaneously on C-Span.
During the debate, Mr. D'Amato sought to "level the playing field," as his strategists put it, by suggesting that the Attorney General, in paying taxes late on a country home upstate, deducting from income taxes the cost of one room in his Manhattan apartment, and having taken campaign contributions from lawyers with business before his agency, was just as culpable for ethical violations as Mr. D'Amato has been accused of being.
The Senator couched his criticism in sorrow rather than anger, though, saying that Mr. Abrams "should be ashamed of himself" and that New Yorkers were "disappointed" in how he had handled his personal finances and his campaign.
 
Photographic Family Values
 Mr. Abrams and Mr. D'Amato shook hands perfunctorily before and after the debate and barely looked at each other in between. As it ended, Mr. Abrams's children and Mr. D'Amato's grandchildren, who were watching in the studio, were all but catapulted toward the set for the obligatory photographs celebrating family values.
Yesterday, the Senator pursued a sustained assault that, in the final days of the campaign, he has leavened with chuckles when Mr. Abrams was defending himself or attacking, and pained expressions when he was criticizing Mr. Abrams.
More than 25,000 other people were running in the New York City Marathon yesterday, but Mr. Abrams and Mr. D'Amato were the only two who repeatedly veered into each other. The candidates agreed in the debate only on two things: that New York State had lost hundreds of thousands of jobs, though they apportioned blame for the loss differently, and that the tone of the campaign had not been constructive.
 
A New Wrinkle
 One new wrinkle emerged when Mr. D'Amato insisted that on three occasions before the Democratic primary, he had appealed to Mr. Abrams not to engage in personal attacks but to stick to substantive issues. But Mr. Abrams recalled, through a spokesman, Timothy Gilles, that Mr. D'Amato had threatened to "ruin" Mr. Abrams if he referred to Mr. D'Amato's ethical lapses.
"It's preposterous," the Senator said when asked whether the conversations constituted threats rather than appeals.
When asked during the debate whether Mr. D'Amato was corrupt, Mr. Abrams said, "That's going to be left for criminal prosecutors."
Their most sustained exchange was over health care and how to pay for it.
Mr. Abrams insisted that additional taxes would not be necessary. To which Mr. D'Amato countered: "Bob Abrams is running for the wrong office, because if he really has this plan where you can increase spending by $570 billion and not raise any taxes," then "he should be running for President."
Mr. Abrams often returned to abortion, labeling Mr. D'Amato as the candidate of the "extremist Right to Life Party."
Mr. D'Amato, who opposes abortion except in cases of rape or incest, pressed for a parental-consent requirement.
Mr. Abrams said: "I've got a teen-age daughter who's with me here in the studio. I love her very much. I believe in parental communication. I think it's got to be encouraged. But can the government -- a law -- enforce it? Of course not."
After the debate, Mr. Abrams attended a rally with local Democrats in Port Jefferson, L.I.
He ended the day at the Meadowlands, where leading New Jersey and New York Democrats shared the stage with Mr. Clinton, who asked for a special round of applause for Mr. Abrams and who pleaded with New York voters to send the Democrat to the Senate.
 
A Victory Prediction
 Mr. D'Amato campaigned at a Republican rally in Oceanside, L.I., where he predicted that he would win the election by 5 percentage points. He also complained about unfair treatment by the press, bringing cheers from the audience.
"If I, Al D'Amato, was late on my taxes 8 times out of 10 and called my bedroom an office," he said, "it would be a page 1 expose."
Assessing his debate opponent, Mr. D'Amato said, "I've dealt with tougher people who used to come to town board meetings than the Attorney General."
