HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Behind The Scenes;
On the Trail, the Contradictory Sides of Bush

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LA CROSSE, Wis., Nov. 1

 BODY:
In the blue caboose where he was sipping tea to soothe his worsening cold, the President was somber.
It was Saturday morning at the start of a scenic train trip through Wisconsin. Barbara Bush was talking to two grandchildren, Sam and Ellie, and looking at presents from supporters. And Mr. Bush was speaking to Ron Kaufman, an aide who had come back to give him new poll numbers indicating that his surge was flattening after a day of news reports suggesting that he was more in the loop on the Iran-contra scandal than he had yet allowed. 
 Apparently oblivious to the news photographer in the room who later described the scene, Mr. Bush did not hide his vexation. He took off his baseball cap and tossed it on the table, and he and Mrs. Bush quizzed Mr. Kaufman about what the numbers meant.
 
Going Into Campaign Mode
 But whenever he stepped out to the back of the train for rallies in Wisconsin farming towns, the President went into the campaign mode his friends call "jet propulsion."
The words tumbled out in a bracing, breathless aria of insults: "The Waffle Man, moving away from it all." "Governor Taxes and the Ozone Man." "Governor Clinton, over the last 24 hours, has been frantically flopping around like a bass on the side of the Arkansas River." "He smokes a little but he didn't inhale. Sure. Who believes that?" "A couple of yuppies dressed as moderates -- watch your wallet." "Tell all those Washington -- those kind of salon leaders." "These deadly talking heads." "When these instant replay guys come on the television, it doesn't matter what they say."
While Barbara Bush was on the train, Mr. Bush tried to exercise some restraint. But as soon as she dropped off at dusk, the President began calling people "bozos" again.
"A new Congress is coming in," he told the crowd at his last stop in Chippewa Falls, his voice cracking as the words cascaded faster than ever, "so a lot of these bozos are going to be gone -- excuse the expression."
Racing to finish, Mr. Bush truncated his litany of complaints about Bill Clinton's record in Arkansas and simply barked, "And on and on and on."
In his final days on the campaign trail, it has been possible to see, in kaleidoscopic array, all the contradictory sides of George Bush: the endearing screwball charm; the cool determination to use whatever line of attack will work, even if Presidential dignity and factual accuracy are sometimes sacrificed; his desire to be seen as a decent man and his puzzlement when his rhetoric of resentment is taken too seriously; his elation at bashing critics and rivals, and his fatigue and frustration at having to justify his actions as President -- and now as Vice President -- when he feels he has done a good job and is far the superior candidate.
Mr. Bush treats his political persona with a certain good humor and theatrical distance, much like his grandchildren treated the Halloween costumes they wore as they cavorted through the train on Saturday evening. (Sam was a mouse and Ellie was a movie star who grandly assured reporters, as she held out her trick-or-treat bag, "Money is fine.")
It is as though the Bush campaign mask is an exaggerated behavior to put on in the right season to scare people into giving you what you want and what think you deserve.
The President offered a telling response last week, when he was quizzed in an "Ask George Bush" session in Columbus, Ohio, about his repeated warnings that Mr. Clinton's position on fuel economy levels would cost every Ohio auto worker his job. With a frankness disarming or alarming depending on your point of view, Mr. Bush replied: "I hope I didn't say all the auto workers. Maybe in a hyperbole or an exaggeration for a campaign I did."
As he opens a scare-attack on Mr. Clinton's character, he usually gives a little laugh, a self-conscious signal to the audience that he is not as harsh a person as his ice-pick prose might suggest. He often grins his way through the worst of what he says. And in the midst of ranting against Mr. Clinton and Congressional leaders and the press, he sometimes throws in a congenial word about how he really likes them, except when they get in the way of his keeping his job.
His manner in his speeches is often strangely at odds with the blistering words.
"I believe that you've got to close your eyes, imagine in that dangerous situation an American leader without any experience, completely untested, a leader about whom literally we know very, very little," he ominously told a rally in Burlington, Wis., on Saturday. "And what we do know is this troubling pattern that I mentioned -- this pattern of being on one side, pattern of indecisiveness."
Mr. Bush does not let assertions that he has prevaricated on taxes and the Iran-contra affair slow him down. As he told Larry King on a call-in television show in Racine, Wis., on Friday night, when Mr. King asked if he had ever lied to the public: "I don't believe so. I've said things that didn't work out to be true. I've meant things at the time that didn't work out."
 
Who? Me?
 The President frequently seems taken aback if people judge him by or act on the words he says on the campaign trail. When some network cameramen ran into President Bush and his chief of staff, James A. Baker 3d, having dinner at a restaurant in Billings, Mont., a week ago, they told Mr. Bush that his press-bashing at rallies had incited some ugly incidents. They had been yelled at, yanked at, poked at and spit at by Bush supporters.
The President assured the "photo-dogs," as he likes to call them, that he had not meant anything personal. Characteristically, Mr. Bush did not fully appreciate the link between words and action, between his "red meat" lines and the resentful reaction of his supporters.
The next day, he began inserting a line, when he started railing against the media, that the members of the press traveling with him should get "amnesty."
"Don't take it out on the cameramen," he told an audience in Michigan. "Some people get so excited there, they were jabbing the American flag into the back of these poor guys. These are the good guys."
Because it is just campaign "hyperbole," the President does not have to acknowledge the contradiction in making punching bags of some groups -- Congressional leaders, lobbyists and the press -- that he had once assiduously courted, inviting them for barbecues, movies and state dinners.
And he sees no contradiction in complaining that this has been the ugliest campaign he has ever seen and in making own contribution to that: an endgame that focuses on zinging on character and trust rather than laying out a substantive plan for the future.
As he began one more day racing around the country, Mr. Bush sounded listless and sour in a CNN interview this morning, saying that the press coverage of this campaign had been the worst ever and refusing to explain why his account of his role in the Iran-contra affair was at such variance with the contemporaneous notes of Caspar W. Weinberger, the former Secretary of Defense.
His aides were equally snappish. One Bush aide confronted a New York Times photographer and said of the Sunday paper: "Two Perot pictures. Two Clinton pictures. One Bush picture. Don't think we're not watching."
 
Two Sides of Baker
 Although Mr. Baker, the man expected to work another political miracle this year, was spotted at moments on Saturday's train trip grimly staring out at the passing farms and autumn foliage, he was his usual debonair, unflappable self when he ventured out in public to watch the President's speeches.
At one point, waiting inside before a rally, Mr. Bush peered out of his train window and saw his old friend and talking to a cluster of reporters.
Mr. Bush grinned and moved his fingers in a pantomime of a chattering mouth.
Mr. Baker grinned back and went over to stand underneath the President's window. The chief of staff did his own pantomime back to the President, of a man bailing water out of a leaky boat. "He thinks I'm leaking," Mr. Baker laughingly told a reporter when he returned.
Asked if he would like a little more time in the campaign -- a common lament among Bush staffers -- Mr. Baker looked straight at the questioner and replied, "No."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Independent;
Perot Assails Rivals as Unfit to Run a Small Business

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONG BEACH, Calif., Nov. 1

 BODY:
In his most stridently negative attacks on his Presidential rivals since he re-entered the campaign, Ross Perot lambasted President Bush and Bill Clinton, suggesting that he would not hire either man to run a small business. He also seemed to question the Democratic nominee's morals because of past use of marijuana.
Speaking before a crowd of supporters at a rally in the Long Beach Arena, Mr. Perot seemed to go out of his way to criticize and ridicule Mr. Clinton. At the beginning of his speech Mr. Perot turned toward the Dixieland combo that had playing to warm up the crowd and referred to the Arkansas Governor's ability to play the saxophone. 
 "You guys call area code 501 first thing Wednesday morning," he said, "you might get him real cheap." That is the area code for Arkansas.
 
Attack on Two Flanks
 Mr. Perot's quip set the tone for his speech, which assailed Mr. Clinton in language that had previously been absent in the independent candidate's campaigning. In past appearances, including those in Florida and Missouri on Saturday, Mr. Perot directed most of his fire toward the President, and seemed to mention Mr. Clinton only in passing. Today both the Republican and Democratic candidates came under withering attacks.
In a later rally, Mr. Perot was somewhat more muted in an address to more than 5,000 people in Santa Clara.
Mr. Perot's comments reflected a new 30-minute commercial broadcast tonight, after the rally, that attacked Mr. Bush's record as President and Mr. Clinton's stewardship of Arkansas. In addressing the crowd of about 11,000 he made several references to the ad and asked people to invite 10 friends to their homes to watch it.
"When you look tonight, as you're sitting there watching all this stuff, say, If I ran a small business, if I had a small business, would I hire either one of these guys to run it?"
 
Enthusiastic Crowd
 The crowd -- which was similar to the audiences at virtually all Mr. Perot's rallies in that it included people of all ages, but virtually no blacks or other minorities, roared back, "No!"
At one point, Mr. Perot asked the crowd, "Do you think that the President of the United States should be good role models for your children?" When they crowd cheered, Mr. Perot went on to ask, "Do you believe that it's appropriate to have senior Government officials who have used drugs?
"It's up to you; it's up to you.
"But I'm just a college kid and if it seems like everybody at the top can do anything they want to, any time they want to, violate all the rules and just wipe us out -- everything that I've been taught at home and in church and in Boy Scouts, then that's going to change my moral and ethical standards."
At a brief and typically testy news conference after the Santa Clara event, Mr. Perot refused to say whether he was referring to Mr. Clinton when he spoke earlier in the day about government officials who use drugs.
"I'll let you all figure that out," he said. "It's your job to report the news."
Mr. Perot cut off the session after five minutes. "Does anybody have a significant question or is this going to the usual mindless press conference?" he asked. "If it is I'm going to bed."
Of the candidates, only Mr. Clinton and his running mate, Al Gore, admitted past use of marijuana.
In tonight's ad, Mr. Perot took a leaf from the President's play book and disparaged Mr. Clinton's claim of creating on average more jobs in his state than were created in the nation. Mr. Perot asserted that many of the new jobs in Arkansas were low-wage jobs in the state's chicken industry.
 
Quick Clinton Response
 "One out of five jobs in the last 12 years created in Arkansas has been created in the poultry business," Mr. Perot said on the show. "Now this is not an industry of tomorrow. This is honest work. It is hard work. The people who do it are world-class people, but if we decide to take this level of business creativity nationwide, we'll all be plucking chickens for a living."
In neither the ad, nor the speech today, did Mr. Perot mention his proposals, like those for tax increases, spending cuts and tax incentives for some businesses, which he sees as the solution to the nation's economic ills.
The Clinton campaign, which until recently paid scant attention to Mr. Perot, responded quickly to the candidate's charges, releasing a rebuttal to the Texan's claims that Arkansas had not improved under Governor Clinton. "Ross Perot has claimed for months that he's tired of politics as usual, but his latest infomercial is exactly that -- politics as usual," the Clinton campaign said in its statement. "His 11th hour attack on Bill Clinton and the people of Arkansas is nothing but a multimillion-dollar smoke screen designed to distort the record of the only candidate who can bring real change."
Today's rally had all the trappings of the political convention Mr. Perot had hinted he would have last Spring before he abruptly quit the campaign. The crowd was festooned in various Perot T-shirts and many wore plastic imitations of straw hats. As is often the case, many in the crowd criticized the news media, and indeed, at one point the chant went up, "Mind Over Media!"
Still smarting from the skepticism that greeted Mr. Perot's explanation that he quit the Presidential race in July because of fears of a Republican plot to embarrass his daughter and disrupt her wedding, the campaign gave reporters copies of the personal diary Sybil Stockdale, wife of his Vice-Presidential nominee, James B. Stockdale, for the week of July 12.
In the diary, the entry for July 16, the day Mr. Perot quit, stated: "Ross called at 8:30 a.m. and told us he'll announce withdrawing in 30 min. at t.v. He said it's really because because Press will expose dirt on his daughter who'll be married in Aug., but that's confidential."

Behind him were his wife, Margot, right, James B. Stockdale, his running mate, and Mr. Stockdale's wife, Sybil. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Pulse -- Ohio;
Bush Surges in Ohio, His Big Battleground State

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CLEVELAND, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Ohio is one place where George Bush's surge is real. In the crucial belt of states stretching from New Jersey to Michigan, where his fate and that of Bill Clinton may well be decided on Tuesday, this is the President's best hope.
The struggle for Ohio's 21 electoral votes is very, very close. It often is. Harry S. Truman carried the Buckeye State by only 7,500 votes in 1948, and Jimmy Carter won by just 11,000 in 1976. The state has been closely balanced politically since the Civil War, which is why so many Presidential candidates have come from here. 
 In the superheated 1992 Presidential campaign, Ohio has truly been, as its auto license plates proclaim, "the heart of it all." By the time the voting begins on Tuesday, Mr. Clinton and his running mate, Senator Al Gore, and their wives will have made 45 visits to the state; President Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle and their wives will have made 28 trips here.
"Jump ball," said Gerald Austin, a leading Democratic campaign consultant here, when asked on Friday to pick a winner.
 
Clinton's Lead Shrinks
 This morning's final round of state polls showed Mr. Clinton with a slight advantage, considerably smaller than a week ago or two weeks ago, and not big enough to be statistically significant.
Both The Akron Beacon Journal's phone survey and The Columbus Dispatch's mail poll, whose methodology is unorthodox but whose track record is peerless, concluded on Saturday. The Beacon Journal put the Arkansas Governor up by six percentage points, 42 percent to 36, with Ross Perot at 18 percent and 4 percent undecided. The Dispatch put Mr. Clinton at 41.1 percent, Mr. Bush at 39.6, Mr. Perot at 19.3.
The margin of sampling error in the Beacon Journal poll, which covered 833 registered voters, was plus or minus four percentage points. In the Dispatch poll, to which 1,980 people responded, it was three percentage points.
"There has been a lot of flirtation with Clinton, a lot of dissatisfaction with Bush, but eventually flirtation has to end," said Mike Curtin, the political director of the Columbus Dispatch. "As the election gets closer, people are second-guessing themselves, wondering whether Clinton's offering the kind of change they want."
 
'A Spent Bullet'
 "It shifted last weekend and early this week," said Prof. Alfred Tuchfarber, a political scientist at the University of Cincinnati. "In effect, the Clinton message on the economy has become a spent bullet. It has done all the damage that it can do. Bush's message about Clinton's character is not as compelling, but it started later and it still seems to be working, at least in Ohio."
The change has to do with focus, Professor Tuchfarber argued.
"Voters know they're choosing the most important person on earth when they vote for President," he said. "They don't spend much time on it in June or August or September. But come late October, they look into the candidates' eyes and hearts and judge."
The President said all along that the last week to 10 days would prove decisive. For weeks and months, Ohio Republicans were wringing their hands as Mr. Clinton piled up a substantial lead. Only two weeks ago, Gov. George V. Voinovich, a Republican, told a visiting correspondent that his party would lose the state "unless George Bush can do a better job between now and Election Day to define who Bill Clinton is in terms of his experience."
 
Bush Move Is Late
 That, of course, is what the President has sought to do, in his radio and television advertising and his stump speeches, since the final debate two weeks ago. The question is, did he start too late? And if so, why did an experienced politician make such a blunder?
Representative Willis D. Gradison, a Republican from Cincinnati who was a classmate of the President at Yale, said he did not entirely understand Mr. Bush's actions.
"He's found his voice, but it certainly took him a while," Mr. Gradison said. "I've known him a long time, and I sense that, like me, he enjoys government more than politics. That may be part of the explanation for all this."
Robert Bennett, the state Republican chairman, said: "We're tighter than a drum, but we think Clinton peaked out a week or so ago. People started to realize that Arkansas is no bigger than greater Cleveland, and they're worried whether he knows what he's doing. We're picking up Perot voters, and I think he'll lose half his people by Election Day, with the bulk coming to Bush-Quayle."
The dimensions of Mr. Bush's surge, and his new-found vigor and optimism, were on display last week at an ebullient rally in Cleveland, where the President's campaign had been becalmed, and other events in Dayton and Columbus.
Senator Howard Metzenbaum, a Cleveland Democrat, said that Mr. Bush had looked "limp and wan and whiny" until the final debate, but that now "he's hitting Clinton hard and often, and, frankly, he's scoring."
The Senator agreed with Mr. Austin and Mr. Bennett that Mr. Perot was cutting into Governor Clinton's vote. He said he had urged the Democratic high command to put "some believable surrogate" on television -- he mentioned Paul Newman, the actor -- to appeal directly to Perot voters in the final hours to switch to Mr. Clinton.
"I have felt the Perot people would switch off him," Mr. Metzenbaum added, "but now I have my doubts, unless we really pound away at him. All those millions on television give him credibility."
 
Continued Belief in Clinton
 James Ruvolo of Toledo, a Democratic National Committee member, said he continued to believe, like Mr. Metzenbaum, that Mr. Clinton would eke out a victory here. That would have a certain historical symmetry: of the three Democratic Presidential nominees to carry Ohio since World War II, two were Southerners like Mr. Clinton -- Mr. Carter and Lyndon B. Johnson -- and the other, Truman, came from the Southern-influenced part of Missouri, a border state.
Since 1964, the state has been an unusually reliable mirror of American voting, varying from the national pattern by not more than a percentage point or two.
This time, Mr. Ruvolo argued, Mr. Clinton will prevail almost entirely because of hard times in northern and eastern Ohio, in the arc of industrialized large and small cities stretching from Toledo through Cleveland to Ashtabula, then down to Youngstown and Steubenville. His main worry, the Democratic leader said, is Mr. Bush's big edge in spending on television here, combined with what he termed Mr. Clinton's "misguided" decision to seek votes in the Rocky Mountain states last week rather than concentrating on the Midwest.
The television spending in this state is awesome. In Cincinnati alone, candidates for all offices will have spent $3.7 million on the three major stations between Sept. 1 and Nov. 3, and that does not count the network commercials bought by the Presidential campaigns.
 
Republican Tradition
 One reason Mr. Bush is in better shape here than in neighboring states like Michigan and Pennsylvania lies in Ohio's Republican tradition, which has reasserted itself at the last minute in many a close contest. John F. Kennedy often said that this state broke his heart, turning out to cheer him but not to vote for him.
Another reason is the economy. While Akron and Youngstown and other cities in the industrial north and east may have suffered, things have been much better in Cincinnati and especially in Columbus, a white-collar town, headquarters of the Limited clothing chain and of the fast-growing Banc One, that has become the state's largest city.
If the race is as close as it seems, the religious right could hold the key here. Prof. John Green, the director of the Ray C. Bliss Institute of Applied Politics at the University of Akron, estimated that the Christian Coalition, the political organization of Pat Robertson, had raised $13 million nationwide, and he said that it might prove especially effective in southern and central Ohio this year.
"Their target is three-quarters of a million voters in this state," he said, "and everyone they can get to the polls will vote a straight Republican ticket. With the defection of a lot of the Reagan Democrats back to Clinton, those are votes Bush desperately needs."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Split Down the Middle"
 
With Democrats dominating tghe industrial north and east and Republicans predominant in the rest of the state, Ohio has a fluid balance of power that in recent years has edged toward the conservative. The Governor and most of the House delegatgion are Republicans; both Senators are Democrats. But Senator John Glenn, facing dissatisfaction with incumbents and a strong challenge from Lieut. Gov. Michael DeWine, is considered vulnerable on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Almanac;
Clinton Edges Further Ahead

 BODY:
Three new nationwide polls have found Gov. Bill Clinton still leading President George Bush, with Ross Perot in third place.
When the three polls are averaged, Mr. Clinton leads with 43 percent, Mr. Bush has 37 percent and Mr. Perot has 17 percent. 
 The Harris Poll, conducted with 1,675 likely voters Friday through Sunday, found Mr. Clinton ahead by five points.
The CNN/USA Today poll by Gallup with 1,579 likely voters conducted Friday and Saturday showed Mr. Clinton with a seven point lead over Mr. Bush, an increase of four points in his lead since the last Gallup poll release a day earlier. The ABC News poll of 1,369 likely voters taken Thursday through Saturday had Mr. Clinton ahead by five points, two points more than their previous release.
All three polls have a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
A tracking poll involves interviewing with fresh samples daily over an extended period of time with results combined and released two or three days at a time.
A Star Ledger/Eagelton Poll of New Jersey conducted Oct. 23 to 29 with 801 likely voters found Mr. Clinton with 42 percent of the vote to Mr. Bush's 30 percent and Mr. Perot's 18 percent. The poll has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three to four percentage points.
Mr. Clinton is also leading in a Michigan poll of 500 likely voters. Mr. Clinton received 41 percent, Mr. Bush 32 percent and Mr. Perot 18 percent in the poll conducted Wednesday through Friday by Market Strategies Inc. for The Oakland Press, WDIV-TV and WJR Radio. The poll has a potential sampling error of plus or minus five percentage points.

HEADLINE: Israel and Jordan Agree They Want Formal Treaty

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Israel and Jordan have agreed in writing for the first time that their goal is a formal peace treaty within the framework of a comprehensive Israeli-Arab settlement.
Israeli Cabinet ministers described the agreement today as a breakthrough. Some officials, providing details of a draft accord reached last week by the two countries' negotiators, said they hoped that it would serve as a model for discussions with others at the Middle East peace talks, especially Syria and the Palestinians. 
 The officials also said that their chief negotiator with Syria, Itamar Rabinovich, would be named Israeli Ambassador to the United States, replacing Zalman Shoval, who has held the position for two years. An Israeli newspaper reported that the change would occur this month, but officials said it would take longer and that in any event Mr. Rabinovich, who is rector of Tel Aviv University, would remain in charge of the Syrian talks.
 
Two Big Words
 For the Israelis, it was significant that after more than four decades of a technical state of war, Jordan had unambiguously accepted the words "peace treaty" in defining objectives.
For its part, Israel agreed to discuss water and land claims, the intricate problem of Palestinian refugees and arms control, including the destruction of unconventional weapons. A press report here today said that the two countries are talking as well about a "Dead-Red Canal" that would run from the Dead Sea to the Red Sea and would be used to control water levels and promote tourism.
 
Only an Agenda
 In Jordan, officials also praised the tentative agreement, reached four days ago in Washington and focused on an agenda that will guide further Arab-Israeli negotiations, which entered a second year this weekend. "I think it's a very important step forward," an unidentified senior official told Reuters in Amman.
Israeli commentators said it was significant that Jordan had published details of the draft agreement this weekend in the official press.
But for all the optimistic appraisals, senior officials in both countries cautioned that an agenda is no more than that: a list of the items that will be discussed when the talks resume next week. The road to an actual treaty remains long, they said, and nothing has changed in the position of the Arab delegations that an Israeli deal with any one of them must be accompanied by agreements with all.
Still, an official close to Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin said that the draft agenda, whose approval by King Hussein is considered a formality, could provide the momentum to nudge all the negotiations forward.
The talks, being held in Washington, were recessed on all fronts until after the American Presidential election.
Both President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton say they are committed to Mideast peace, but it might take awhile before the winner is able to devote the attention that many in this region feel is required from the United States to push the talks along.
 
The Uncharted Future
 Mr. Bush's point man was former Secretary of States James A. Baker 3d, whom the President says will coordinate domestic economic planning if he is re-elected. And if Mr. Clinton wins, he will will be preoccupied with putting together a Government.
So the Israeli-Jordanian agreement on an agenda was widely seen as timely help for the negotiations.
There is little good news on the Israeli-Palestinian track, which has made scant progress toward an immediate goal of Palestinian self-rule in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. If anything, Palestinian delegates find themselves increasingly besieged by religious and left-wing factions demanding that they withdraw from the talks.
Syria, after making headway with Israel two months ago, is seen as less cooperative these days.
 
Model for Others?
 And Lebanon, where fighting erupted once again last week between Israeli forces and the pro-Iranian Party of God, is unlikely to agree to anything without Syria's blessing.
The tentative agreement with Jordan came as a surprise, even though Israeli experts have long maintained that the two countries, if left to themselves, could have come to terms years ago, for the issues between them are relatively painless.
"The Jordanians are now ready to talk about peace and Israel is ready to negotiate territory," said Akiva Eldar, diplomatic correspondent for the newspaper Haaretz.
"It is very balanced, and I think that this will be a model for the talks with the Syrians. The Jordanians cleared the floor for the Syrians to offer a peace treaty in return for the Golan Heights."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Radio Advertising;
Ads, Late and Nasty, Rule the Waves

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

 BODY:
As bleary-eyed Americans hit their alarms yesterday morning, other alarms went off: Gov. Bill Clinton will steal your job. President Bush is a liar. The Democrats will tamper with Social Security. The Republicans are fanatics.
Even the most facile flip jockeys could not escape the fear and oratory dished out across the radio dial this weekend. By waiting until the last possible moments to broadcast their nastiest ads, the campaigns could distort the truth while running little risk of getting caught until after Election Day. 
 More than on television, radio messages can be tailored to demographic and geographic markets, as they were yesterday. On several black-oriented radio stations, for example, the Bush campaign is running an ad warning listeners that a vote for Mr. Clinton would "be turning the clock back." In Arkansas, the announcer says, "blacks are poorer, less educated and more likely to be unemployed than African-Americans elsewhere in the country."
Instead of directly assaulting his opponents, the ever unpredictable Ross Perot went for something different: he blanketed radio markets with ads promoting his 30-minute paid political program that ran last night on ABC and NBC, against the CBS News program "60 Minutes."
 
'Watch the Feathers Fly'
 "You won't believe what Ross Perot has to say Sunday night," an announcer says. "Tune in and watch the feathers fly." Needless to say, Mr. Perot's television commercial needles Mr. Clinton about the chicken processing industry in Arkansas.
Radio stations across the country reported heavy election-weekend time buys from the Presidential and local campaigns, which in many cases bought up every available second of ad space.
Listeners could punch all the buttons or hit search and scan, but they could not escape the onslaught.
Listen to a Bush radio commercial in Raleigh, N.C. "President Bush wants to protect and sustain the family," the announcer says, while Mr. Clinton would "undermine the family structure."
 
'Something Frightening?'
 Listen to a Democratic Party advertisement in San Francisco. "Want to hear something frightening?" the announcer asks. "It's the Republican platform on abortion. They want to make abortion illegal, even if a woman is raped, even if she's a victim of incest, even if her life is in danger. Sound extreme? That's because right-wing fanatics like Pat Robertson helped write it."
Radio is much more accommodating than television for last-minute time purchases, and the campaigns took full advantage for a barrage of attacks and counterattacks. WWDB-FM in Philadelphia is so loaded with political ads in the closing days, said Dan Sullivan, the sales manager, that "our regular advertisers are screaming because they can't buy any time."
In several markets, the Bush campaign used local examples to try to scare listeners into thinking that a Clinton Presidency would cost them jobs. "Bill Clinton talks a lot about Arkansas jobs," the announcer says in an ad being broadcast in Cleveland. Then, as the volume rises on a foreboding soundtrack, he adds: "Clinton doesn't say he's been stealing jobs from other states. Ohio is one. Spicer Transmission in Toledo closed down, fired its workers and moved to Arkansas."
The ad quotes a Clinton adviser saying that the Governor will "do whatever it takes to attract companies to Arkansas." But the point of the ad was somewhat confusing because, presumably, people would want a President who knew how to attract jobs.
 
Distortion Alleged
 Greg Haas, director of the Democratic campaign in Ohio, lashed out at the Bush ads in the state, saying, "They misstate, misquote and misuse the facts of Bill Clinton's record and economic plan."
That has not stopped the Bush campaign from running variations around the country. Here's an ad in Chicago that cites a study with which Democrats take issue: "Based on a University of New Mexico study, Clinton's massive defense cuts will cost over 31,000 Illinois jobs. So remember Governor Clinton stole jobs from Acme Frame Products. President Clinton could take a whole lot more."
The Republican National Committee hit the airwaves in several cities with ads that, because of Federal election restrictions, do not mention candidates directly but said voting Democratic would be a mistake.
"You don't always get straight talk from a political ad -- this one is different," says a Republican commercial in Greenville, S.C. "The Democrats will raise your taxes by $150 billion and increase spending $220 billion," the announcer says with certainty, even though the Democrats dispute those figures.
 
'Who Will We Trust?'
 Not content to stop with taxes and spending, the ad warns that while the Democrats would fiddle with entitlements, "The Republicans will never touch Social Security."
In Kansas City, Mo., listeners to another Republican Party ad are asked, "Who will we trust?"
A Bush ad heard in Philadelphia is more direct as it seeks to convince listeners in a tri-state market. "You can't trust Bill Clinton," the announcer says. "He's wrong for you and wrong for Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Delaware." The announcer also accuses Mr. Clinton of promoting "radical environmental regulations."
The Clinton campaign bought airtime to respond to such harsh accusations with harsh accusations of its own. An announcer breathlessly decries to listeners in Philadelphia, "George Bush's radio ads are full of lies." To counter the Republicans' accusations about lost jobs, one ad accuses Mr. Bush of encouraging American companies to "move jobs to Central America."
It is not all charges and countercharges. Mr. Perot has saturated radio markets with ads that feature the Texas businessman appealing for votes: "You've got to stop letting these folks telling you you're throwing your vote away. You've got to start using your head."
But mostly, the election-eve ads prove one thing to radio listeners. No matter how fickle the finger, there is no escaping fate: nasty political messages are unavoidable.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Almanac;
Countdown to Election Day

 BODY:

GEORGE BUSH
President Bush continued to fire away at Bill Clinton's character, as aides said the oratory on both sides was likely to get even uglier in the final two days of the campaign. His voice was weakened but Mr. Bush appeared upbeat as he swept through a string of states he must win if he is to return to office. While his language was tougher than usual, he tried to blunt the impression he has dropped into a last-ditch, fiercely negative campaign. At a rally in Michigan, the President told 5,700 party workers that the name "Slick Willie" was not his invention. "We tell the truth, and they think it's hell," he said. "So be it."
 
BILL CLINTON
 Suffering from laryngitis, Gov. Bill Clinton could barely speak as he began a two-day press into Ohio, Pennsylvania and New Jersey, as part of a strategy to strike at President Bush in Republican areas of critical industrial states. His voice was so weak that his attacks on Mr. Bush had to be severely curtailed. The Governor's wife, Hillary, did most of the speaking throughout the day, and at one stop Mr. Clinton managed to talk only 21 seconds. But at an airport in northern Pennsylvania, he warned a crowd about the Republican assaults to his character and promised to restore economic optimism and fairness to the Presidency.
 
ROSS PEROT
 Ross Perot launched the most blistering attacks of his campaign, turning the main force of his fire from President Bush to Mr. Clinton. At a rally in California, Mr. Perot seemed to go out of his way to criticize Mr. Clinton, questioning his morals because of his experimentation with marijuana, ridiculing his record in Arkansas and even dismissing his ability to play the saxaphone. Mr. Perot did not entirely halt his attacks on the President. "As you're sitting there watching all this stuff," Mr. Perot said, "say, If I ran a small business, if I had a small business, would I hire either one of these guys to run it?"

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

METRO DIGEST
 
ABRAMS AND D'AMATO NEAR END OF RACE
In the final hours before tomorrow's election for United States Senate, Robert Abrams and Alfonse M. D'Amato engaged in their last televised debate and plunged into the New York City suburbs to campaign. Mr. Abrams, the State Attorney General and Democratic nominee, and Mr. D'Amato, the Republican incumbent Senator, replayed elements of their rancorous campaign, arguing over health care, taxes and the economy. But the outcome of the election may depend less on either candidate's performance than on Gov. Bill Clinton's projected margin of victory in the state. A1.
 
Pointed contrasts in a final debate. B7.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
ANTI-THEFT OR PRO-THEFT BAR?
Usually carjackers use guns or knives to force motorists to relinquish their cars. But the weapon used in a carjacking in midtown Manhattan was actually meant to prevent cars from being stolen. The police said a 27-year-old Brooklyn man jumped into a stopped 1992 Lincoln, grabbed a metal anti-theft bar lying on the front seat and brandished it to force the driver from his car. The suspect then nearly ran down several officers as he tried to escape, the police said. B2.
 
RANGE OF EMOTIONS IN DANIELS CASE
The case of Randy Daniels, whom Mayor Dinkins had appointed as Deputy Mayor and who resigned last week, has provoked and reinforced a range of emotions among men and women. Some men fear that women now have a new weapon, the allegation of harassment, which they will wield indiscriminately, leaving ruined careers in their wake. And some women still think men do not get it. B3.
 
REGION
 
JOHNSON AND DODD NEAR THE END
Senator Christopher J. Dodd and his opponent, Brook Johnson, reached out to widely differing constituencies in the final weekend of campaigning, as Mr. Dodd visited the low-income residents in this city and Mr. Johnson toured the state's more affluent towns. Mr. Dodd, a Democrat seeking a third term, met people whose concerns ranged from violence and drugs to unemployment and lack of educational opportunities. Mr. Johnson attended rallies in Stamford, Greenwich, Norwalk and Fairfield, where his supporters wanted to hear about how the Republican would revive the state's ailing economy. B6.
 
INCOME TAX? OH, THAT INCOME TAX
This was to be the year the voters would get even. But despite the passion of Connecticut residents a year ago, the income tax has not become a major issue in most legislative races. Most supporters of the tax seem unaffected by the threatened backlash. People still talk about the tax and many still hate it, but politicians and residents in communities across the state say the rage over the tax has become another victim of Connecticut's deepened recession. B6.

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
If Pollsters Would Visit a Welfare Center

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
THE Waverly Income Maintenance Center on West 14th Street in Manhattan was not on any Presidential candidate's campaign itinerary. Nor do pollsters or pundits regularly go there to take the electorate's pulse. But just one visit to the second floor, where people wait to apply for welfare in an office that suggests the apprehension and pain of a hospital emergency room, would explain why Gov. Bill Clinton will win tomorrow -- at least in New York.
Particularly if Michael Mathew, Brian Pierce or John Riley were there, as they were the other day. Waiting with scores of others for some form of benefits, they defied two fundamental stereotypes about welfare. They had never applied before or even envisioned themselves needing public assistance; they are white. 
 Mr. Pierce, a 30-year-old unemployed hairdresser, needed $2,500 to avoid eviction from the Manhattan apartment he shares with his girlfriend, who is also unemployed.
Mr. Riley, 47, a consulting engineer who emigrated from England 30 years ago, was burned out of his apartment and needed help while he replaced documents that would enable him to resume work.
Mr. Mathew, 34, a costume-jewelry maker, was looking for a loan while he looks for another job after the company for which he worked had laid off two of its five employees.
"A couple of years ago we had so many orders we could have worked seven days a week," Mr. Mathew said. "Now, they just don't need us. It's a luxury business, and when the economy slows down this is the first thing to go."
As a result President Bush may be next.
The number of people on welfare in New York City, more than one million, is the highest in nearly two decades. The proportion may be the largest ever. Many have lost their jobs, are afraid they might or know someone who has during an Administration that may be just starting to jump-start the economy. Measured by that experience, change may seem preferable. Against that backdrop of fear, welfare has not emerged as the political hot potato that many people figured it would. In the New York Senate debate yesterday between Attorney General Robert Abrams and Alfonse M. D'Amato, welfare was not even mentioned.
"A big reason Bill Clinton is still leading George Bush in the polls is that welfare has not, contrary to what I expected, become the 'Willie Horton' of 1992," Lawrence M. Mead, a professor of political science at New York University, wrote. "But welfare has hardly been an issue in the campaign. The chief reason, of course, is that the country's economic problems have commanded center stage."
The country's economic problems have placed some people who might ordinarily be susceptible to the welfare-as-Willie Horton appeal perilously close to welfare themselves.
Staking claim to the political center in early primaries, Mr. Clinton said even last spring that he would favor New Jersey's request for a Federal waiver that would enable the state to freeze payments to women on welfare who have more children -- an experiment that even Mr. D'Amato, the Republican-Conservative, is embracing very tentatively. Mr. D'Amato, his spokeswoman said, "supports the concept of responsibility, but it's too soon to judge the effectiveness" of the New Jersey rule.
More intelligent judgments about welfare in general might some day be rendered under Section 1381 of the tax bill that Congress is about to send to the President. Drafted by Senator Daniel P. Moynihan, the provision invokes the Employment Act of 1946, which required an annual economic report to the President and the calculation of unemployment rates. Section 1381 provides for an annual report on welfare dependency, annual goals for recipients and expenditures and sets an interim goal of reducing dependency, from 13 percent to 10 percent for families with children.
The development of the unemployment rate, Mr. Moynihan recalled, "changed the debate concerning this central dilemma of industrialization."
In 1990 twice as many households were receiving Aid to Families With Dependent Children as the number of households and individuals' collecting unemployment compensation. Just a relatively small proportion can ever be weaned from welfare with work. And even that number depends on the availability of jobs.
At so-called income-maintenance centers grim applicants study an eight-page handbook of instructions on how to complete the five-page form for public assistance. The form blandly asks whether the applicant has "a burial space," among other resources.
"I never thought I'd be here," Mr. Mathew said as he awaited an interview at the Waverly center. "But I paid taxes all my life, and it's only fair for the Government to help me now that I need it."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
General Motors' directors are to meet this morning and are expected to entrust Jack Smith with the task of quickly halting the financial bleeding of North American operations. Whether Mr. Smith can succeed at that daunting task may depend on whether the board sets reasonable goals and whether he moves quickly and decisively to change the way G.M. operates. [Page D1.] 
 Banking analysts say as many as five banking companies may consider a bid for First City of Houston, which was seized by regulators Friday night. Chemical seems the early favorite. [D2.]
 
The Economy
For years, the Defense Department has denounced the V-22 Osprey, an aircraft that takes off like a helicopter but flies like a plane, as impractical and unaffordable. But the department continues to finance the plane, and both President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton, along with members of Congress, have committed themselves to building it -- illustrating how maddeningly difficult it is for the nation to cut military spending. [A1.]
Governor Clinton and Alan Greenspan have been circling each other warily, and if the Democratic nominee becomes the President-elect, they could start wrestling. On the other hand, the Fed chief resembles the candidate in a crucial way: each much prefers consensus to confrontation. [D1.]
 
International
Importers of wines and spirits are stockpiling goods, fearful that they may be the first victims if the U.S. makes good on threats to impose steep tariffs on European products. [D1.]
Mexico's President cautiously endorsed the sort of broad political changes demanded by his opposition. But Carlos Salinas de Gortari seemed to signal an end to the dizzying changes he has engineered in the economy and society over four years. [A3.]
 
The Media Business
The Presidential race will not be decided until tomorrow, but among the networks vying for political ads, the returns are already in. For most, they are good news. Bill Carter: Television. [D1.]

HEADLINE: STRICTLY BUSINESS;
A Venture Capitalist and His Politics

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
The receding New York involves things like egg creams and memories of organ grinders. The new city -- the one that could as easily be Zurich or Tokyo -- is a world financial center defined only by the lightning-fast movement of money and ideas.
Alan Patricof grew up playing stickball on the streets of the Upper West Side and selling The Saturday Evening Post in the subway. He remembers organ grinders. 
 Today, he is a major venture capitalist, with headquarters on Park Avenue and offices in eight European cities. Using ultrasophisticated techniques, he prowls the business forest in search of nascent enterprises with profit-making potential.
Using investors' millions and a dollop of his own, he invests in dreams at a time when entrepreneurs' relatives and friends may have run out of money or faith. Many rounds of infusions are usually needed -- each giving him a bigger stake in a company doing nothing but losing money. It can go on for a decade with no payback. Mr. Patricof loses about half the time, but on occasion has seen an investment soar more than 50 times.
 
Perpetually on the Lookout
 His office is telling. It is festooned with hard hats, model airplanes and sundry other souvenirs from companies that he bet on when they were little more than somebody's bright idea and a sketchy business plan. He hopes that the peculiar little tree in the plastic bag -- miniature forestry? -- will hit big.
The walls sparkle with works by artists who were largely unknown, but full of promise, when he purchased them. A plaque honors his service as a board member of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, whose annual Next Wave festival is an avant-garde New York event.
This 57-year-old nurse of the new is subsumed with one question: "What's next?"
A new President, if the marathon runner has his druthers. The chairman of Entrepreneurs for Clinton waxed euphoric about how superbly he thinks the talkative man he met while jogging had debated. "He actually stopped to think," exuded a man who barely stops to sleep.
Such ardor is expected. But his support comes at a cost. The one-time Reagan enthusiast still has shares of some companies that have jumped fantastically in value from as long ago as 20 years. If President Bush's program to cut capital-gains taxes is adopted, it would be a windfall. In addition, Mr. Patricof said he would be hurt by Mr. Clinton's proposal to increase the highest individual tax rate, to 36 from 31 percent.
Mr. Patricof will not estimate what all that adds up to. "That's ostentatious," he said.
The point, he insists, is the future.
 
Confronting the Risk
 On his desk was a foot-high stack of financing proposals. They included a solicitation by an inventor of a car battery, a method to clear out nasal passages and a "noise cancellation system." None was as outlandish as the farmer who once asked him to invest in a horse.
Mr. Patricof was looking for the kind of jackpot deal that he terms "a meteor." He longs to replicate his early stake in Apple Computer to financing a company that became the second-largest recycler of automobile batteries. He was chairman of New York magazine after he had found investors for its startup, having fun as well as making money.
Such help is appreciated.
"This was venture capital in the purest form," said George Blumenthal, chairman of Cellular Communications Inc., an early cellular company that received seed money from Mr. Patricof.
Mr. Patricof has also bought lemons. One of his earliest investments as a young man was in a company in Queens dedicated to developing a strain of laboratory mice. The fast-multiplying rodents turned out to be valueless.
Trouble looms. Mr. Patricof says the venture-capital industry has become less venturesome. Participants, he says, are favoring investment at later stages in a company's growth. The individual investors who once dominated the game drifted toward junk bonds and other greener fields. The pension funds that replaced them want safer, quicker returns.
 
'Short-Term Oriented' Society
 That means that even though the industry's resources have grown to $30 billion from $4 billion in the mid-80's, there is less cash for companies' most critical periods, birth and babyhood. Mr. Patricof says just a fifth of his United States venture-capital fund is invested in early stage companies, compared with more than half of a fund raised in 1984.
The upshot, he argues, is that the response to the broad assistance that Japan and Germany give fledgling enterprises has become inadequate. "Our whole society has become very short-term oriented," Mr. Patricof said. "There have to be more startups that employ people."
New York City, he says, particularly needs new commercial and industrial flowers to bloom. "We probably don't need any more law firms or ad agencies," he said with the slightest of smiles. "But at the moment, I guess we'd take anything."
He said entrepreneurial development was a key to the woes of reviving the city whose past he loves to evoke. He recalls sledding in Central Park as a boy and the strangely compelling chant of a wandering dealer in used garments.
Mr. Patricof, son of a stockbroker, finished Ohio State University in three years while working at a part-time jobs. He earned an M.B.A. from Columbia University while working full-time as an analyst for an investment firm.
The intensity is still apparent. He looks at his watch frequently and emphasizes points with staggering detail. His background includes a series of positions with investment firms, one of which helped manage a pulp-and-paper fortune. Bored with the heavings of the stock market, he found himself devoting more of his time to fun new ventures.
He founded Patricof Company Ventures in 1969. Later he founded a separate investment banking company specializing in entrepreneurial companies. An international arm, Apax Partners, was founded in 1977 and now has eight European offices. In total his firm manages $1.5 billion in more than 130 companies. If an investment is made, the work has only begun. Mr. Patricof or one of his 30 partners will almost always take a seat on the company's board. He is aggressive in pushing his views, a stance that he says represents corporate democracy in action.
Is that appreciated? "They don't have to like us," he said.
These days the father of three sons is neck-deep in the Clinton campaign. His job is not raising money, but finding businessmen to go public with support. "That's harder," he said, noting that even some of the entrepreneurs in whom he had invested millions had turned him down.
His personal support developed from conversations that he had with the Arkansas Governor after being introduced by a friend in East Hampton four years ago. Mr. Clinton was interested in using venture-capital techniques to try to emulate the South Shore Development Bank in Chicago, an institution that makes loans to poorer neighborhoods.
Mr. Patricof said he was not a big campaign contributor. He also claims no interest in a Washington job. But he would appreciate the ear of a Clinton White House.
"I hope I'm not going to drop off the face of the earth," Mr. Patricof said of his political future. "I've put a lot of energy into this."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alan Patricof, a venture capitalist, says entrepreneurial development is a key to reviving the New York that was part of his childhood. (Edward Keating/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Dodd and Johnson Reach Out in Very Different Directions

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 1

 BODY:
Wrapping up the final weekend of campaigning, Senator Christopher J. Dodd and his opponent, Brook Johnson, reached out to widely differing constituencies, as Mr. Dodd visited the low-income residents in this city and Mr. Johnson toured the state's more affluent towns.
Attending morning services at black churches in Bridgeport's East End, Mr. Dodd met people whose concerns ranged from violence and drugs to unemployment and lack of educational opportunities. His schedule also included lunch with Democrats in Norwalk and rallies with supporters in Ansonia, Middletown and Hartford. 
 During the day, Mr. Johnson, trailing by as much as 20 points in recent polls, attended rallies in Stamford, Greenwich, Norwalk and Fairfield, where his supporters wanted to hear about how the Republican would revive the state's ailing economy. He continued his attacks on Mr. Dodd, a Democrat seeking a third term, calling him fiscally irresponsible.
Along the way, Mr. Johnson, a businessman who has never held political office, stressed the need to bring "new blood" into politics and to undo the economic problems of "tax and spend" liberals.
And last night, at a rally attended by President Bush at the Igor Sikorsky Memorial Airport in Stratford, he stressed his experience in creating jobs. "Chris Dodd, let me tell you something," he told the estimated 10,000 supporters at the rally, "if it comes to jobs being an issue in this state, buddy, you lose."
 
'Politics of Division'
 Mr. Dodd, speaking earlier to more than 90 churchgoers at the Russell Temple C.M.E. Church, criticized the "politics of division" that he said has pit the poor and the wealthy against each other in recent years.
Though he made no specific commitments on any particular social agenda, Mr. Dodd's words were received with nods of approval and soft utterances of "Yes, sir." He promised to "try and bring this country back together again."
Holding a microphone at the altar, Mr. Dodd said, "If someone lacks housing, a job, or decent health care or an education, we all suffer."
Mr. Dodd did not appeal for votes directly, but urged the churchgoers to turn out on Election Day. "Your abstinence from the process will make a difference," he said, warning the congregation that those who disagreed with him would indeed vote.
 
Concern for Cities
 After the service at the Russell Temple and the East End Baptist Tabernacle Church, where Mr. Dodd also visited, people said that they felt the problems of cities had been neglected this election year, but that they were reassured by his visit.
"It was about time he came," said Belinda Young, a 28-year-old member of the Russell Temple who said she had been laid off from three jobs since 1989. "I have a house and two kids. It's rough. My husband has a stable job, but it's still tight."
Standing on the church steps, Theodore McCray announced: "We're going to give him another shot. Don't worry about that. We need to turn this world around. The way it's heading, it's not going to amount to nothing with all the drugs and violence."
Kecia Frazier said she felt that Mr. Dodd's message was relevant to her life. She said she began thinking about her godson, Rakim Tucker, 2, while Mr. Dodd spoke.
Holding the child's hand, Ms. Frazier said: "Right now, all the young people are killing each other. I don't want him to be in the middle of that. I want him to get an education.
"The problem is the youth of today are trying to stake their claim by killing each other. The youth don't feel they have a chance otherwise. Their self-esteem is down."
Yet not all were won over by the visit. People like Margarine Hardy, 49, dismissed Mr. Dodd's appearance.
"It's politics time," she said as she walked out of the East End Tabernacle Church. "That's the only time you see them."
 
'Ready for an Upset?'
 As Mr. Johnson traveled from one town to another, his supporters voiced enthusiasm, dismissing polls and comparing him to John F. Kennedy. "It's important to follow him because he'll be President one day," said Emil Judge, 69, who waited for Mr. Johnson to arrive in Fairfield.
Once there, Mr. Johnson was encircled by supporters who offered handshakes and hugs. "Ready for an upset?" he asked people gathered at the Republican Town Committee headquarters, a white colonial house at the center of town.
He amused the crowd by deriding Bill Clinton and Mr. Dodd as "Slick Willy and Deficit Dodd." Stressing his business background, he said it was time to do away with "career politicians."
"I didn't get into this race because I thought it would be a fun thing to do," Mr. Johnson told supporters in Fairfield. "But we need people who haven't been career politicians."
As he has done before, his message focused on managing the country's slumping economy. He called for the passage of a balanced-budget amendment, term limits for Congress and reduction of the Federal deficit.
Along his daylong tour, people talked about how the state had lost jobs and how there was a need for an "outsider" like Mr. Johnson to "shake things up."
He indulged his supporters with talk of having to run his political campaign like a business, playfully barking orders to the members of his convoy to move out of Fairfield on time.
Appealing to middle-class voters, Mr. Johnson stressed his blue-collar background, saying he understood the needs of the working class. Talking about jobs to a group in Norwalk, he said, "I was working at them," while Mr. Dodd "was talking about them."
He also called on supporters to push harder than ever now that the campaign was winding down. "Momentum is much more important at the end than the beginning," he said.

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1528 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: House Races;
G.O.P., Hopeful of Big Gains, Sees Its Chances Fade

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Nov. 1

 BODY:
A historic partisan shift toward the Republicans might have come from this year's House elections. But no serious challenge to 38 years of Democratic control has developed, and no state offers better examples of why not than Georgia does.
Not only are Republicans failing to gain as much as they hoped from redistricting, the war in the Persian Gulf and the general anti-incumbency mood. But this state also displays the unforeseen Democratic advantages that affect House contests nationally. 
 Three Democratic women could win by arguing that they represent change. Three or four very conservative Republicans may squander districts that the G.O.P. could have won with moderates. And the economy and a long, flabby Presidential campaign depress all Republican efforts.
Georgia also reflects the nation in nonpartisan ways that are likely to change Congress as much as any partisan shifts. At least 6 of the 11 Representatives elected Tuesday will be freshmen, joining as many as 125 others. Not since 1948 have there been so many new members. And Georgians will contribute to the striking increases in the number of women and blacks in the House.
 
Great Expectations
 Nationally, it once seemed plausible that Republicans, who now hold 166 House seats out of 435, could gain 35 to 40 and assert ideological control over the House by allying themselves with with conservative Democrats, much as they did in 1981. Now gains of 15 to 20 seats seem more likely, with only trivial impact on the House.
Similarly, Georgia Republicans hoped to go from 1 seat out of 10 in the 102d Congress to 5 or 6 of the 11 in the 103d. Now it seems improbable they will have more than three, and none of their candidates are safe.
While national polling cannot measure individual House races, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll offers general encouragement to Democrats. Forty-five percent of the 1,912 registered voters polled by telephone from Tuesday to Friday said they would vote for a Democrat for the House; 35 percent preferred a Republican.
But the rise in Democratic hopes generally is far from reassuring to individual members. From coast to coast, incumbents are attacked for voting themselves a pay raise, for overdrafts at the House bank and for travel abroad. And if they have committed few or none of those particular sins, members like Representative Richard Ray in west-central Georgia find themselves attacked for not preventing them.
 
Many Incumbents Worry
 All over the country, House members are finding it hard to know if they have successfully countered attacks. Powerful incumbents of both parties are clearly at risk. Democrats like Representatives Les Aspin of Wisconsin, chairman of the Armed Services Committee; Vic Fazio of California, head of the party's campaign committee, and Steny Hoyer of Maryland, chairman of the caucus, all have real reasons to worry.
So do Republicans like Representatives Bill Goodling of Pennsylvania, the senior minority member of the Education and Labor Committee; Don Young of Alaska, the top Republican on the Interior Committee, and, right here, the No. 2 Republican in the House leadership, Newt Gingrich. Mr. Gingrich, attacked over checks and the car he gave up months ago, is taking more hits over incumbency than anyone else in the delegation.
Lesser-known lawmakers are at least as vulnerable, and dozens feel threatened. Their fear has often led them to use the first negative advertisements, and, if they follow most consultants' advice, not to try to explain that the 1990 pay raise was justified or that no taxpayers' money was lost at the bank. "You respond by attacking your opponent on another issue," said Neil Newhouse, a Republican consultant, who said the pay raise was deserved -- but politically "indefensible."
 
Party, Not Individuals, Survived
 There are no political vaccines that guarantee an individual protection against anti-incumbency. But Georgia offers a prime example of how a party can be protected.
Two vulnerable Democrats, Representatives Ben Jones and Charles Hatcher were defeated in primaries. Sanford Bishop, a black former state legislator in the Americus area who defeated Mr. Hatcher, a Representative with 819 overdrafts, and Don Johnson, who defeated Mr. Jones in Athens and the Augusta suburbs, are clear favorites on Tuesday.
Nationally, a postwar record of 19 incumbents were defeated in primaries. At least nine Democrats and two Republicans in that group would have had a hard time winning the general election. Another 53 House members retired or sought other offices. Many of those who stayed on anyhow are in jeopardy, like two Ohioans whose problems seemed over when they won their primaries, Representatives Bob McEwen, a Republican, and Mary Rose Oakar, a Democrat.
Reapportionment, the process of reallocating House seats because of population changes, and redistricting, the actual drawing of the new maps, both promised Republican gains. Georgia went from 10 to 11 seats, and the Justice Department blocked two plans until the state created a second and third black-majority district.
 
G.O.P. Benefit Foreseen
 Republicans hoped that packing black, Democratic voters into districts of their own would drain other Democrats of black support. On the surface, that approach seemed to work here, certainly better than it did where skillful political cartography in Texas and North Carolina seemed to keep other Democrats safe.
Redistricting brought Republicans their biggest gains in California, where a remarkably unfair pro-Democratic map of the 80's was replaced with a neutral one, and in Illinois, where six Democratic incumbents were squeezed into three districts.
But the party was not ready to capitalize here, nominating several candidates favored by the Christian right who seemed too extreme to be able to carry the new districts. The clearest case is Daniel Becker in North Georgia. He runs television advertisements showing body parts from aborted fetuses and assails homosexuality as "depravity and perversity."
The same pattern can be found in other states from California to Michigan. Democrats in 1992 were much more successful in picking candidates who could seize the political middle.
 
War Advantage Ebbs
 Another early Republican hope was the popularity of the war in the Persian Gulf, and the opportunity to label both individuals and the Democratic Party as insufficiently supportive of American troops. The issue has no vitality today, here or anywhere else.
Instead the underlying issue is the lagging economy. Its impact is less severe here than in the Northeast. But candidates like Barbara Christmas in the Savannah area or Cathey Steinberg here are getting somewhere with promises to work to create jobs. Nationally, Spencer Abraham, the co-chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, concedes, "Because of the economy, we've had to play defense to a larger extent than we'd have liked."
This is also plainly a state where renewed enthusiasm for the Democratic Presidential ticket and Republican doubts about President Bush have given the Democrats a clear advantage. In the last week, Republicans have been much readier to be seen as Mr. Bush's allies. But that narrows, rather than erases, the energy gap.
Women are the other dramatic measure of how Georgia strikingly reflects improved Democratic chances. Cynthia McKinney, a black state legislator, beat a field of men to win the nomination in an almost-safe black district that winds through rural Georgia from the Atlanta suburbs to Savannah. Ms. Christmas, a school principal, is a classic example of how women come across as outsiders this year.
 
A Democratic Chance
 Ms. Steinberg, a State Senator from Atlanta, may defeat John Linder, a very conservative former lawmaker, by emphasizing abortion rights in an upper-income, strongly Republican district where the Republican convention played badly to many women.
A near-doubling of the current total of 28 women in the House seems likely, with most of the newcomers Democrats.
The biggest imponderable in this election remains the strength of anti-incumbency. Ross Perot's Presidential candidacy fanned an already strong flame of anti-Washington sentiment. Thomas E. Mann, director of governmental studies at the Brookings Institution, called Mr. Perot's backers "contrarian and susceptible to the worst conspiracy theories about government," natural enemies of incumbents.
The would-be freshmen are often decently financed. Thirty-one challengers had raised at last $200,000 by Sept. 30. And with incumbency a less valuable commodity than it once was, the foes of incumbents may not need as much money. As Alan Secrest, a Democratic consultant, put it, "A little negative for a challenger goes a lot further than it has in the past."
But it is mood, more than money, that seems to matter. A New York Times/CBS News Poll found in late October that only 22 percent of Americans said they could "trust the government in Washington to do what is right" always or most of the time. That is the lowest percentage ever measured by the Times and CBS News.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Newt Gingrich, the No. 2 Republican in the House leadership, has been attacked over checks and the car he gave up months ago and is taking more hits over incumbency than anyone else in the delegation. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "The House: 5 Races to Watch"
 
Races that typify some patterns in a year of change.
 
CALIFORNIA: District 52
 Representative Duncan Hunter (R), a 44-year-old six-term incumbent, is facing an unexpectedly tough challenge in a very Republican district. His Democratic opponent, Janet M. Gastil, is a schoolteacher with little political experience, but 399 overdrafts on the House bank are a problem for Mr. Hunter.
 
GEORGIA: District 4
 Abortion is a key issue in this Republican-majority district in the Atlanta suburbs, where no incumbent is running. Cathey Steinberg (D), 50, has campaigned for abortion rights and labeled her Republican opponent, John Linder, 50, an extremist. He calls her a liberal.
 
IOWA: District 2
 Iowa lost a seat through reapportionment and two incumbents were thrown together. Representatives Dave Nagle (D), 49, and Jim Nussle (R), 32, are fighting about Congress itself. Mr. Nussle wore a paper bag over his head to protest the bank scandal; Mr. Nagle is an effective insider and proud of it.
 
NORTH CAROLINA: District 1
 This is one of 17 new districts drawn to insure election of minority candidates. Eva M. Clayton (D), 58, is heavily favored to defeat Ted Tyler (R), 57, and become the state's first black in Congress since 1901.
 
WISCONSIN: District 1
Les Aspin, the 54-year-old Democrat who heads the Armed Services Committee, is facing a tough anti-incumbent campaign as he seeks a twelfth term. Mark Neumann (R), 38, a builder, has surpised him with lavish spending.
