HEADLINE: Fast Action Called Key For G.M. Board Meets Today To Name New Chief

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

 BODY:
When the board of the General Motors Corporation meets this morning in New York, directors are expected to entrust John G. (Jack) Smith Jr. with the task of quickly halting the financial bleeding of the auto giant's North American operations. Whether Mr. Smith can succeed at that daunting task may well depend on whether the board sets reasonable goals for the company's reorganization and whether he moves decisively to change the way G.M. operates.
Mr. Smith, who has been G.M.'s president since April, is expected to be named chief executive, replacing Robert C. Stempel, who announced last Monday his plans to resign. Mr. Stempel's other title -- chairman -- is likely to be assumed by a director, John G. Smale, who is a retired chairman of Procter & Gamble. 
 Mr. Smith, a G.M. employee for 31 years, is credited with turning around the company's European operations, for which he was previously responsible, along with its other overseas operations.
Another executive who may receive increased power and responsibilities from the board is William E. Hoglund, the chief financial officer. Some analysts suggest that Mr. Hoglund, who has international and domestic experience, would complement Mr. Smith in his efforts to reorganize G.M.'s North American automotive operations.
Mr. Smith faces a difficult task. Not since Lee A. Iacocca helped to stave off bankruptcy at the Chrysler Corporation in the early 1980's has so much rested on a single executive.
During Mr. Stempel's 27 months at the helm of the company, G.M. reported two years of losses, including a $4.45 billion loss for 1991, the largest loss ever for an American company. On Thursday, it announced a $752.9 million loss for the third quarter of this year. Its share of the American vehicle market has dropped to 35 percent from 45 percent in 1980.
 
 
Crucial First Months
 But many experts in academia and business said that if Mr. Smith was given a clear mandate from the board, and if he moved quickly to assert his control, he could stop the financial hemorrhaging that would lead to a wholesale disaster if left unchanged. But to accomplish his aim, they said, he must take a range of actions -- from wholesale dismissals of employees to renegotiating labor contracts on an emergency basis to spending more time in the field and less in his office.
Like a new President's first 100 days in Washington, Mr. Smith's first months in office will be crucial. It will be a period of intense scrutiny, during which he must vividly demonstrate whether he can inspire the fundamental revamping that virtually every expert believes G.M. must undergo. Otherwise, he may have a short honeymoon with the United Automobile Workers union, white-collar workers, parts suppliers and, most important, the board itself.
"You want to use this crisis as an important moment of reassessment, to make changes you can't make normally," said Harry Katz, a professor of labor relations at Cornell University. Mr. Katz suggested that Mr. Smith reopen G.M.'s contract with the U.A.W. and propose that workers in G.M.'s component plants agree to more flexible conditions than those governing workers in assembly plants.
Because G.M.'s costs are higher than those of its competitors, Mr. Smith must almost certainly close plants, eliminate tens of thousands of jobs and revamp its plans for future vehicles -- without delay. Simultaneously, he must move to raise the morale of remaining workers and foster consistent production and quality from the plants that remain after cutbacks are made.
 
 
Economic Fallout
 Although G.M.'s financial condition is not as serious as Chrysler's was, its loss of market share, ebbing financial strength and enormous appetite for capital suggest an industrial failure waiting to happen. And because G.M. is almost three times the size of Chrysler, the potential fallout on the American auto industry -- and on the United States economy -- would be far greater.
Gerald C. Myers, former chairman of the American Motors Corporation and an expert in crisis management, said he thought G.M.'s vulnerability might be overstated "because it has two assets it can sell if it's in trouble: E.D.S. and Hughes Aircraft."
Still, the situation is serious, so directors may keep Mr. Smith on a very short leash. Mr. Myers suggested that to gain some freedom of movement, Mr. Smith should develop quite specific goals in agreement with directors. "As he meets the goals, one by one, the board will get off his back," Mr. Myers said.
Another former auto executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity, estimated that G.M. must slice 45,000 to 50,000 jobs from its 90,000 white-collar jobs in North America -- far beyond the 20,000 it announced last December that it was trying to eliminate. G.M. had also announced at the same time that it planned to cut 54,000 blue-collar jobs and close 21 plants over the course of several years.
"Smith should concentrate on cash rather than profit, eliminate the dividend, sell E.D.S., sell Hughes if he can get a good price for a defense business, ignore stock price and rebuild from there," this former executive said.
He added that Mr. Smith should purge as many senior executives as possible. "People who are associated with a failure, no matter how bright they are, can't stop trying to justify why the failure wasn't their fault," he said.
 
 
Resignations Expected
 People familiar with the thinking of the G.M. board said that several senior company executives -- Lloyd E. Reuss, executive vice president, and F. Alan Smith, executive vice president, and others -- are expected to resign the day Mr. Smith takes office. The departures of Mr. Reuss and Mr. Smith would be largely symbolic, since they have been out of key operating roles for some time.
James Harbour, a manufacturing consultant based in Troy, Mich., was a 50-year-old Chrysler engineer in 1980 when Mr. Iacocca abruptly dismissed him and thousands of others. "It was cruel," Mr. Harbour said. "But unless you do it right away, everyone else is sitting around doing nothing, waiting to see who goes and who stays." Within months, Chrysler trimmed white-collar employment by a third, to 18,000 jobs, he said.
Simply cutting jobs will not be enough, though, to turn the huge company around. Vehicle development teams at G.M. are large, complex and heavily bureaucratic. Their leaders change frequently, and the teams do not have the freedom to pursue their vision of what the entire vehicle should be.
Some experts suggest that Mr. Smith should copy G.M.'s domestic and Japanese competitors by organizing vehicle development into small teams that include engineering, marketing and design specialists headed by young, charismatic leaders who could better take advantage of G.M.'s brightest people. Kim Clark, a professor of business administration at Harvard University, said, "I have always been impressed that when you get into the guts of G.M., the people seated at drawing boards and design tubes, there is a tremendous base of talent."
Mr. Clark added, "G.M. must empower what I call a heavyweight team of people with absolute freedom," like the Ford Motor Company team that developed the Taurus and Sable, or the Chrysler team that designed the new and highly praised line of L/H midsize sedans.
Perhaps no single problem looms larger before Mr. Smith than G.M.'s relationship with the U.A.W. All of the Big Three auto makers have the same union contract for their assembly plants, but Ford, Chrysler and the Japanese companies with American plants buy a majority of components from outside suppliers, some that use nonunion labor. G.M., on the other hand, buys 70 percent of its parts from factories run by the company with higher-wage U.A.W. workers.
Mr. Katz, the labor relations expert from Cornell, said that either the company had "to work out a separate agreement for G.M. parts operations" that make them competitive with outside suppliers, or it had "to get rid of sizable pieces of G.M.'s parts subsidiaries."
Mr. Katz continued: "Mr. Smith must open the contract and deal with this as Chrysler did when it was in trouble. He has to convince the union he's really in trouble, and so they've got to find the solution together."
Tough prescriptions for G.M.'s survival would have sounded strange during its halcyon years in the 1950's and 1960's, when executives feared that the company's mammoth size and success would prompt the Government to order it broken up. But Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate and longtime G.M. critic, said he thought such a breakup may be the answer to G.M.'s troubles. He suggested that the company be carved into "four independent auto companies so there will be more competition, less bureaucracy, more creative energy and more shareholder value." He postulated one small-car company, two mid-size car companies and a large-car company.
 
 
Expectation of Action
 If Mr. Smith decides bold action is the answer, G.M.'s hidebound organization may finally be ready for it, Jeffrey Sonnenfeld, a professor of leadership studies at Emory University, said. "His predecessor's failure has been identified by all as caused by inaction, so there is an expectation now that rapid action will take place."
Yet Mr. Sonnenfeld counseled Mr. Smith not to immediately dismiss thousands of workers. "To start, what would be seen as sadistic cost-cutting would cause a revolt," he said. "He needs first to do something symbolic, like reorganize his own team. Later he can execute on a larger scale, with more confidence and justice."

HEADLINE: Anger Over Income Tax Subsides

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Oct. 30

 BODY:
One year ago this month, 40,000 screaming Connecticut residents were drawn to the State Capitol to protest the state's new income tax, and many of them, in oaths and speeches, repeated a single simple line: 1992.
This was to be the year the voters would get even. 
 But despite the passion of a year ago, the income tax has not become a major issue in most legislative races. Most supporters of the tax seem unaffected by the threatened backlash.
People still talk about the tax and many still hate it, but politicians and residents in communities across the state say that the rage over the tax has become another victim of Connecticut's deepened recession.
 
Budget Surplus Helps
 "Anger has been supplanted by fear," said Senator John B. Larson, a Democrat from East Hartford who led the opposition to the income tax last year in the State Senate. He has told his constituents that the battle is over and that he would now oppose getting rid of the 4.5 percent tax because of the economic disruption it would cause. "The focus in state races is the economic slump," Mr. Larson said.
Politicians in both parties say that a riveting Presidential race also stole much of the spotlight from the tax issue, with Ross Perot in particular hammering away at the same themes that Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. did when he proposed changing Connecticut's tax law last year: the irresponsibility of running a budget on borrowing and red ink. Meanwhile, Connecticut ended its fiscal year on July 1 -- the first year with the income tax -- with its first budget surplus in five years.
Democrats, who controlled the Legislature during the tax fight and became most closely identified with the new law in the bitterest moments of the protests last year, now expect to retain control of both the state House and Senate.
The tax bill passed the House by a vote of 75 to 73 and passed the Senate by 19 to 18.
Party leaders said that Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democratic Presidential nominee who leads in the polls here, will attract more voters to the Democrat line than in past Presidential elections, and that they believe the tax issue, as a vehicle for Republican hopes, has fizzled.
 
Weicker's Popularity Up
 "The notion of an income tax was frightening, but the reality is only irritating," said Rep. Jonathan Pelto, a Democrat from Storrs and a deputy minority leader in the House of Representatives. "People do not like the income tax, but they've come to accept it."
In the most recent opinion poll on the tax, conducted in April by the University of Connecticut, 52 percent of residents said they either wanted the wage tax kept as it is or modified in some way.
Mr. Weicker, who proposed the tax and became its lightning rod, has also seen his popularity rebound, with 47 percent of residents rating his performance as good or excellent in the most recent poll in late August and early September, compared with 22 percent a year ago.
Certainly, there are races where the tax is a major issue, and there are still candidates who say the tax -- which generates about one-quarter of Connecticut's $8.2 billion budget -- can be repealed immediately, by slashing state spending. The State Republican Party chairman, Richard Foley Jr., also said he believed that the income tax was still the "No. 2 or 3 issue statewide," and that many tax-repeal candidates would be elected.
 
Opposition Has Splintered
 But other Republicans say the more revealing fact is that the anti-tax movement has splintered into varying shades of opposition that did not exist in the more black-or-white days after the law was passed.
Hard-liners want immediate repeal, while the more moderate position favors a phased-out repeal tied to spending cuts over three or four years. Some candidates say they would try repealing the tax, and if that failed would try to get the rate reduced for middle-class families.
In some races, the debate never materialized at all. Representative Paul J. Knierim, for example, a Republican from the Hartford suburb of Simsbury, opposed the tax and then helped in the unsuccessful effort to repeal it at the end of last year.
Six months ago, however, at the beginning of his race against two candidates who support the tax -- one Democrat and one member of a Connecticut Party, Mr. Weicker's fledgling third party -- Mr. Knierim said that repeal had become an impossible goal and that he would now vote to keep the law intact if the question ever came before him again.
"People see the income tax as the thing that put the budget in the black," Mr. Knierim said.
 
'A Growing Reasonableness'
 Other leaders of the anti-tax movement have dropped the language of repeal almost entirely and have run instead on promises to cut state spending and so perhaps eventually make the income tax smaller or more dispensable.
"There's a growing reasonableness," said Chris Powell, a Republican candidate for the Senate from Manchester, who opposed the tax last year, but also harshly criticized his own party for what he called the "fraudulent" alternatives to income tax that were put forward at the time. "I don't think too many candidates that I've seen have been absolutist -- repeal it now no matter how high the cost," he said.
Even ranking how much voters care about the tax has become problematic in some races. In Meriden, for example, the race for the local state House seat is another three-way affair, with two candidates for the tax and one against. "The income tax is still important," said the repeal candidate, James A. Tavegia, a Republican. "But it's sixth or seventh in priority."

HEADLINE: Would Clinton Have to Fight Greenspan Over a Stimulus?

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton and Alan Greenspan have been circling each other warily for weeks now. If the Democratic nominee becomes the President-elect, they might start wrestling.
Then again, they might not.
Many people who make it their business to parse the Fed's every move see inevitable conflict between a Clinton drive to turbocharge the economy and the central bank's mandate to keep inflation in check. 
 They predict an interest rate increase soon after Inauguration Day. Pressures on a Democratic President for a stimulus package are expected to be intense, and Mr. Greenspan said as long ago as January, when President Bush proposed a modest collection of growth measures, that he thought such steps would do more harm than good.
But people familiar with the way both men operate find another sequence of events equally plausible.
Yes, a Clinton Administration would undoubtedly want to burst, not crawl, out of the starting blocks as far as economic growth is concerned. And yes, the Fed fears that the deficit spending that a short-term stimulus package would undoubtedly entail would drive up long-term interest rates, pushing down capital investment.
But Mr. Greenspan resembles Mr. Clinton in one crucial way: he much prefers consensus to confrontation. And so he might balk at raising rates soon after Inauguration Day, partly to avoid sparking a fight early on.
"On one hand, it will be a new Administration, and the Fed will feel fairly edgy, but on the other hand, they are all Republican appointees," said David A. Wyss, chief financial economist for DRI/McGraw-Hill, an economics consulting firm.
Another reason the Fed might forgo a winter increase is lethargic economic growth. Many analysts said the 2.7 percent increase in the gross domestic product reported last week could not be sustained. Some even say the central bank remains so worried about the economy's lackluster performance that it will cut rates one more time soon after Election Day, no matter who wins.
 
Arguments for Aiding Growth
 Indeed, the Fed's governors are known to believe that the economy remains weak in many areas, that inflation will remain subdued for two to three years and that households are still struggling to reduce their debt burdens.
Another consideration is that not cutting could backfire. "The longer the Fed waits to use monetary policy, the more it invites a greater fiscal response later on," said Henry Kaufman, who heads his own economics consulting firm in New York.
Mr. Kaufman argues that further cuts are needed to strengthen growth. And if the Fed lowered short-term rates today, that could help housing starts and tug downward on long-term rates.
But then again, forgoing a cut in rates now might make it easier for the governors to avoid raising them early next year.
One thing is certain: if Mr. Clinton is elected, monetary policy will no longer be the only economic policy-making game in town.
Another sure thing is that Mr. Greenspan, who was confirmed to a new four-year term as chairman as well as a full 14-year term on the Fed's seven-member board in March, will raise rates faster if a Clinton Administration enthusiastically embraces fiscal stimulus. The Fed, like the bond market, would have a stronger reaction to a $75 billion program than to a $35 billion one.
"I think the Fed will be treading water during the first six months of 1993," said David M. Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company. "But in the second half, when the effects of fiscal stimulus will begin to show up, then the prospect would be likely that they'll tighten."
 
Trying to Influence the Fed
 To keep the Fed from stepping on the monetary brakes, Mr. Clinton and his lieutenants would doubtless be working overtime in their first few months in office to persuade the Fed not to fret about stimulus because the economy is so lackluster. And if the governors dug in, then the Clinton Administration would probably borrow a page from President Bush's playbook and put pressure on them behind the scenes.
"An aggressive Administration, eager to get the economy going, normally puts pressure on the Fed to do their bidding," said Scott E. Pardee, a former Fed official who is chairman of Yamaichi International America.
For now, the Arkansas Governor and the Fed have both been paying close attention to the markets -- the politician because he wants to reassure them and the central bankers because they look closely at inflationary expectations to help determine how to jigger interest rates. And recently the prices of long bonds have fallen, partly because investors believe that Mr. Clinton will win and adopt more expansionary policies than President Bush.
Allan Meltzer, an economics professor at Carnegie-Mellon University, argues that the Fed should not hesitate to roll out the heavy artillery if it sees price stability under assault. Professor Meltzer, a well-known inflation hawk, said, "It would be the height of folly for the Fed, having paid the heavy cost of bringing inflation down, to run the risk that inflation be allowed to creep upward again."
Perhaps fearful of criticism that he is not serious about cutting the deficit, Governor Clinton has shied away from embracing fiscal stimulus. But his aides admit that if the economy is weak early next year, he may back stimulus, insisting that this would be tied to a stringent, long-term plan to cut the deficit.
The one high-profile statement Mr. Clinton has made about the central bank pleased Fed officials. During the first Presidential debate, on Oct. 11, he said, "Their policies so far, it seems to me, are pretty sound."
Noting that the Federal Reserve has cut rates two dozen times, Gene Sperling, economic issues coordinator for the Clinton campaign, said, Mr. Clinton "thinks there haven't been major problems with Federal Reserve policy."
"He feels the Fed is not at the heart of our economic problems," Mr. Sperling said.
Whether Mr. Clinton will still feel that way a year or two into a Presidential term is another question.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Hometowns Try To Help Airlines

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell

 BODY:
WHEN America West Airlines received $16 million in loans and other financial incentives from a group of private companies and public agencies in Arizona during August, that provided the green light for foreign investors to provide an additional $45 million in loans. The foreign investors had wanted to see signs of community support before opening their own wallets.
By the time the financial package was finally in place, America West, which has been in Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings since June 1991, had a cash balance of about $40 million and was spending almost $100 million a month. 
 The bulk of the aid, $35 million, was pledged by GPA Group of Ireland, from which the carrier leases many aircraft, while Ansett, the Australian carrier that owns a small stake in America West, provided $10 million. But the $16 million that paved the way for the foreign investors was put together by a combination that included three Arizona banks, the state's professional football and basketball teams, Phoenix Newspapers Inc., the Dial Corporation and Phelps Dodge, plus the State of Arizona.
Together they lent the carrier $8 million, including $1 million from proceeds of Arizona's instant lottery game. In addition, several companies, including Motorola, the state's biggest employer, bought $8 million in prepaid tickets and said they would replenish the amount as it was used up.
While public and community help for airlines has not been uncommon, it has become much more visible in recent years -- probably because communities have increasingly felt the economic impact of one airline after another liquidating or being swallowed by bigger rivals.
Kiwi International Airlines, for example, which is based in Newark and started flying in September, received a $1.5 million loan guarantee from the New Jersey Economic Development Authority.
Northwest Airlines, with headquarters in Minnesota, provides its home state with some 18,000 jobs and $2 billion in wages, benefits and taxes. That economic impact helps explain why the carrier has received more than $800 million in cash and tax credits from Minnesota agencies.
When United Airlines decided a couple of years ago to build a $1 billion maintenance base, more than 90 communities vied to be chosen, a couple with incentive packages worth hundreds of millions of dollars. The winner was Indianapolis, which together with the State of Indiana offered $270 million in cash grants, said Dennis Rosebrough, director of public affairs for the Indianapolis Airport Authority. In return, he said, United agreed to provide 6,300 jobs.
The $1 million state loan to America West was granted by the Arizona Commerce and Economic Development Commission, established in 1989 to offer low-interest loans to new or expanding businesses.
"States go out of their way to chase smokestack industries, and we think it's more important to keep existing industries," said Bruce Sankey, director of communications and research for the Arizona Department of Commerce. "America West is crucial to Arizona's economic competitiveness because it supports 7,000 jobs directly, and businesses relocate here because of the wonderful, low-cost airline service."
A study published earlier this year by the Arizona State University college of business estimated that America West, with headquarters in Tempe, was responsible for a $3.4 billion infusion, direct and indirect, into the Arizona economy in 1990. It is responsible for about $100 million in purchases in Phoenix alone, said Shirley Richard, chairman of the Phoenix Chamber of Commerce. And it is the biggest employer based in Arizona. (Motorola has about 20,000 employees in Arizona, Mr. Sankey said, but its headquarters are in Schaumburg, Ill.)
The Phoenix Chamber, along with its counterparts in Tempe and Glendale, ruffled the feathers of some America West competitors with its campaign urging member companies to "Frequent Our Hometown Flier." As a result, USAir, Alaska Airlines and Trans World Airlines resigned from the chamber. An official of one of those carriers, who asked not to be identified, said, "There's a big difference between support for a hometown airline and all-out championing its cause."
Alphonse E. Frei, America West's chief financial officer, said the airline had recently negotiated a $72 million, two-year reduction in airplane rentals and leases and also negotiated $50 million in deferred payments for aircraft. Its cost-cutting plan involving the work force, fleet size and routes will save another $73 million, he said, adding, "We now have the financing in place to make it reasonably sure we'll make it through 1993."
Mr. Frei said the company was also considering an alliance with another carrier.
"Logic says that with four contestants for Continental, there's only going to be one winner," he said. "Since there's a clear desire on the part of international carriers to feed their points of entry into the United States, that leaves only T.W.A. and America West as merger possibilities. And with our financing, we expect to be in the better shape."
The most likely partner is Aeromexico, which is a bidder for Continental and with which America West already has some arrangements on marketing, code sharing and ground handling.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Traders Wary of Growth Signals

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
There has been enough new economic data recently to suggest that it is time to wonder just how weak the economy is and how long it will stay that way. If these straws in the wind do portend some growth, then there may be trouble in the bond market.
"There is some anecdotal evidence to say there is some growth," one bond trader remarked last week. But the economy, he added, "is the last thing on the minds of investors right now, so that is why that could surprise them." 
 Referring to the October employment data to be released on Friday, the trader said, "if the number is strong this market will be blown away."
 
Rate Drop Assumed
 The conventional wisdom is that regardless of who is elected President tomorrow, the economic fundamentals of slow growth and low inflation will underpin the bond market for the immediate future. This means that even though interest rates have backed up in the last month, they will begin to come down again. The drop should be quicker after a victory for President Bush, but given the economy, the fall should be inevitable even with the uncertainty that would accompany a victory by Gov. Bill Clinton. There is no Perot victory in this forecast.
"I hate it, but I think there is some logic to the conventional wisdom," said Nicholas Sargen, the chief investment officer at Prudential's Global Fixed Income Advisers.
But some contrarian economic signals could mean enough change at the margin to shake the confidence in the certainty of the pro-bond, pro-lower- interest-rate outlook.
A sense of what might happen came Friday, when the market was surprised by the September report on new single-family home sales. Instead of rising to around 582,000 sales at an annual rate, as had been expected, they jumped to 617,000. But with a big revision, to 623,000, in the initially reported August rate of 570,000, the September figure was officially reported as a decrease.
But the market saw through the statistical quirk. Bond and note prices were down for the day, with the price of the 30-year bond falling 17/32 while the yield jumped to 7.62 percent.
 
Signs of Economic Growth
 Among other growth signals are these: an end of the decline in bank lending, which has been a central villain in the downturn; the leveling off of initial jobless claims to their lowest point in two years; talk of better-than-expected Christmas retail sales; a recent upturn in inventories, and the stronger-than-expected 2.7 percent growth in the nation's third-quarter gross domestic product.
Of the bank lending, some data show commercial and industrial loans up $7 billion in the last three weeks after falling $40 billion in the last two years. "There are a lot of indications this could have, including a firming of the economy," said Ken Safian, the president of Safian Investment Research in White Plains.
Initial unemployment claims rose by 8,000 in the week ending Oct. 17 to 375,000. But on the basis of a four-week moving average, claims are at their lowest level in two years.
Richard B. Hoey, chief economist at the Dreyfus Corporation, said retail stores could do well at Christmas. And he was not ready to dismiss the G.D.P.'s quarterly 2.7 percent growth as a one-time shot. "Domestically the economy is better off than it was two months ago," he said. But at the same time, the slowdown in Europe and elsewhere has cut into the American export sales which have been supporting the economy for some time.
Edward Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence, said that if the upturn in inventories was voluntary it would produce a rise in credit demand.
When summed up, this list of little signals has pushed Mr. Yardeni and his colleagues at C. J. Lawrence to shift their outlook for the economy. "We still see little if any growth in the current quarter," he said in the firm's weekly newsletter. "But we no longer believe that all the risks are on the downside. We are willing to consider the possibility that economic activity might surprise us on the upside next year."
James S. Fralick, principal senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company, sees another factor that could bolster the economy if Mr. Clinton wins.
"My sense is that after the first of the year the press is going to be more positive for Clinton and that we will have a pop in consumer confidence," he said. "With that pop there will be a spill over into production so I am expecting a pickup in activity."
And, he concluded, "I think that the pickup in activity together with the focus on the effect of the Clinton program on the budget deficit will push interest rates higher earlier next year."
 
Obstacles to Swift Recovery
 Not everyone supports this outlook. Elliott Platt, director of economic research at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, argued that the economy faces too many obstacles to grow beyond a range of 2 to 2.5 percent next year.
Among the problems he cited are the high vacancy rate in commercial real estate, which is bad for the construction industry; the continued decline in military spending; the low level of consumer confidence, which is hurting, among other things, auto sales; the spending restraints on state and local governments, and the slowdown of the economies in Europe and the rest of the world.
"I don't see that we are on a major move to a buoyant economy," he said.
But the bond market can be very sensitive to the slightest change, especially when it goes against expectations. So it would only take a few out-of-line economic reports -- not a thundering recovery -- to jar the market.
"Bond markets are vigilantes, and it is our role to be ahead of things," said Theresa Havel, director of fixed income at Neuberger & Berman, meaning that any unexpected development will be seized upon by traders and dealers. The paradox is that stronger-than-expected growth could eliminate the need for and worry about a Clinton stimulus program but still spook the bond market to higher interest rates.

HEADLINE: NEW YORK CITY MARATHON;
Given His Chance, And Lucky Charms, South African Wins

BYLINE: By ROBIN FINN

 BODY:
Willie Mtolo, a 28-year-old Zulu who works for a bank in Durban, South Africa, when he's not winning marathons, had his birthright carved onto his face with a tribal knife when he was only a year old. The scars still show, and he is proud of them.
But for so many years, Mtolo, who ran away with the New York City Marathon yesterday once he reached the hilly terrain of Central Park, was a victim of apartheid because of his heritage, and also because of the international sanctions against South Africa. 
 Mtolo, already stunted by the economics of apartheid, was born in a thatched hut in Natal, lived there with eight siblings, and ran to school each day because his father, a farmer, couldn't afford a bicycle.
He then found his running career jeopardized by that system's political fallout. Because of sanctions, Mtolo was barred from entering any marathon that did not take place within his country. The ban took a toll on his ambition and, assuming he'd never get a chance to prove himself against an elite international field, he all but retired in 1989.
 
'I Ran to Win'
 "I went down after that," Mtolo said. "I ran to win, but I wasn't running for the time." He had raced locally for $35 to $200 winner's checks in 120-degree heat, a setting that failed to incite him to challenge the record books. A letter he wrote to his sport's federation begging for an end to South Africa's exclusion from international marathons before he grew too old to win one went unanswered.
In 1992, with the end of South Africa's 32-year Olympic absence and 21-year ostracism from international meets, Mtolo began training for the Olympics, but the death of his father and a bout of flu during the trials kept him off the national team. So he refocused his 80 mile-per-week training runs on New York.
Mtolo entered this marathon field with the fastest time of any runner, but it was an old time: 2 hours 8 minutes 15 seconds for a second-place finish in the 1986 South African Championships. For that race, Mtolo wore a cache of local charms, a white necklace strung with ostrich-shells, and he was still wearing it yesterday when he ran and won his very first major international marathon. Mtolo said he intended to run New York in a maximum of 2:10 and to finish among the top five, but his 2:09:29 effort surpassed his expectations and earned him his seventh marathon victory in his last nine starts.
"When I catch the guy running in front, I couldn't believe it," he said.
 
A Victory and a Gift
 Mtolo won his first marathon outside of South Africa last June in the Netherlands, and bought for his family's potato farm a new tractor with his $2,500 winnings. Yesterday's victory, he said, probably changed his life, and his family's fortunes, forever. It was something he'd dreamed of, and plotted for, since the sanctions began loosening last year.
"But we didn't have enough time to prepare right for the Olympics this year," said Mtolo, who hopes to represent his country in the 1996 Games. So far, he said, he has noticed very little improvement in the training programs for South Africa's black athletes.
For the New York City Marathon, Mtolo trained himself, with a little strategic assistance from his manager, Ray deVries, and moral and culinary support from his fiancee.
 
At Home in the Hills
 He made his first visit to New York exactly a year ago. With the sanctions against South African runners still in effect, Mtolo scouted the course from a photography van. What he remembered most was the way the course escaped from the Upper East Side concrete into the swirling hills of Central Park. Mtolo, who scaled similar heights to finish second in the 55-mile Comrades Ultramarathon in South Africa in 1989, smiled at the sight of such hills smack in the middle of the biggest city he'd ever seen.
Central Park's terrain reminded him of home, and it was right there, as he and the front-runner, Andres Espinosa of Mexico, entered the park, that he surged ahead at the 23-mile mark.
"I told myself that I'm very strong on the hills, that no one else can go with me," said Mtolo. Earlier he had allowed Espinosa, the 1991 and 1992 runner-up, and Lameck Aguta of Kenya, like him a New York neophyte, to chug up First Avenue without him. "I knew the hills were coming, so I saved my energy for them, and when I get there and pass him I thought, 'Oh, the race is mine.' "
The runner's emotions veered from terror, as the race began and he faced a caliber of athletes who "scared" him, to an almost surreal calm by the time he was halfway home. "After halfway I thought maybe I can win, or if not first, I must be second," he said.
Just before Mtolo made the move that left Espinosa behind for good, he dug into his blue sweatband, grabbed a handful of his favorite glucose boosters, Leppin, and chewed one with relish.
He called them "magic," and that's how they worked. But the runner had also ingested another of his magic supplements the night before the race.
 
The New Diet for Runners
 Mtolo is Zulu to the core, so steadfast in his customs that he couldn't run the marathon on Sunday morning unless he'd eaten a traditional meal of phutu on Saturday night. This secret corn meal-based repast fueled the victory that earned Mtolo $20,000 for first place, a $30,000 bonus, and a $36,000 Mercedes, but it wasn't concocted without high drama.
"He almost burned the hotel down," said deVries. "But he can't run without his phutu."
Mtolo smuggled the corn meal, and a hot plate, into his suite at the Hilton. His cooking promptly set off the hotel's smoke detectors. Mtolo and his fiancee, Fikile Mhlungu, used towels to fan the smoke out the windows, unhitched the detectors, waited for the firefighters to leave, and then finished their meal in peace.
"It was worth it," he said.

HEADLINE: Major Races to Watch in Tomorrow's Elections in New York State

 BODY:

U.S. Senate
 
The Candidates
 
ROBERT ABRAMS, 54. Lawyer, State Attorney General since 1979. Elected Bronx Borough President, 1969. First won office as Assemblyman from the Bronx, 1965. Had raised about $5.4 million as of Oct. 15 and will spend all that and more.
 
ALFONSE M. D'AMATO, 55. Lawyer, United States Senator since 1981. Presiding Supervisor, Town of Hempstead, L.I., 1977-80; Supervisor, 1971-77; Receiver of Taxes, 1969-71. First office, Nassau County Public Administrator, 1965. Had raised $9.4 million as of Oct. 15 and will spend it all.
 
The Issues
The candidates have sharp differences on almost every important topic. Mr. D'Amato opposes abortion; Mr. Abrams is a longtime supporter of abortion rights. Mr. D'Amato supports the death penalty; Mr. Abrams opposes it. Mr. Abrams wants to cut $280 billion from the military budget over the next five years; Mr. D'Amato wants to cut $80 billion. Mr. D'Amato opposes national health insurance or any higher taxes; Mr. Abrams favors ending all private health insurance in favor of a Government plan backed by higher payroll and corporate taxes, and higher taxes on liquor and cigarettes.
 
Analysis:
Recent statewide polls have shown Mr. Abrams holding an edge, with a lead ranging from 3 to 11 points. But one-quarter or more of voters were undecided as of last week, so the race remains volatile. Mr. Abrams, a popular vote getter for years, should have a strong natural advantage, since registered Democrats outnumber Republicans about 3 to 2 in the state, Bill Clinton has a double-digit lead over President Bush and Mr. D'Amato's reputation has been tarnished by years of official inquiries into his ethical conduct in office. But Mr. D'Amato has shrewdly promoted his reputation as a "Senator Pothole" who gets things done, a rancorous Democratic primary left Mr. Abrams wounded and struggling to raise money and polls show much of the public unhappy with both candidates.
 
U.S. House of Representatives
 
3d DISTRICT: NASSAU COUNTY
 
The Candidates
 
PETER KING, 48, Republican. Served as Hempstead Councilman from 1978 to 1981 and has been Nassau County Comptroller since then. The public has long identified him as an opponent of abortion. He has taken part in demonstrations against abortion organized by the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre.
 
STEPHEN A. ORLINS, 42, Democrat. A newcomer to the district making his first run for public office. He has spent the last two decades building a brokerage business, which he sold to Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. in 1985. He is now a consultant to American Express.
 
The District
The redrawn District has a population of 580,337, 91.7 percent white, with 150,000 registered Republicans, 87,000 Democrats 60,000 independents and a small percentage of voters divided between the Right to Life and Liberal parties. It stretches along the South Shore from East Rockaway through Long Beach, Merrick, Bellmore, Seaford, Massapequa, Farmingdale, Hicksville and north through Locust Valley, Brookville, Glen Cove and Glenwood Landing on the North Shore.
 
The Issues
Mr. Orlins, who strongly supports a woman's right to abortion, describes Mr. King as a zealot and extreme opponent of abortion. Mr. King describes Mr. Orlins as a carpetbagger who has lived in Manhattan for the last several years and rented a house in Manhasset this summer to run for Congress. Mr. Orlins says he grew up in the district and had his basic values formed there. Both candidates insist that the economy is the major issue. Mr. King says he blew the whistle on Nassau County's fiscal crisis. Mr. Orlins says Mr. King, as Comptroller, was part of the fiscal problem rather than part of the solution.
 
Analysis
While Republicans have held the district for the last 20 years with the repeated election of Representative Norman Lent, who decided not run again this year, the Democrats, riding a wave of anti-incumbency sentiment, have a strong chance. Although it is Mr. King's first race for Congress, he is seen by many voters in the district as part of the Republican establishment that has governed the county for several decades. Two other candidates are in the race and are expected to draw about equal votes from Mr. King and Mr. Orlins. Louis P. Roccanova, 27, is running on the Right to Life ticket, while Ben-Zion J. Heyman, 59, is on the Liberal Party line.
 
4TH DISTRICT: NASSAU COUNTY
 
The Candidates
 
DAVID A. LEVY, 38, Republican. A lawyer and former radio reporter, he is a member of the Hempstead Town Board and is also a staff political strategist and spokesman for the Nassau County Republican Committee.
 
PHIL SCHILIRO, 36, Democrat. A lawyer, he has spent more than 10 years in Washington as a staff aide to Democratic members of Congress. He is on leave from his job as chief aide to Representative Henry Waxman, a California Democrat and chairman of the House Health and Environment Subcommittee.
 
The District
The Fourth District was enlarged earlier this year to include most of what had been the Fifth Congressional District, and Raymond J. McGrath, a Republican who had represented the Fifth District for five terms, decided not to seek re-election in the new district.
The Fourth District covers roughly the southwestern two-thirds of Nassau County. Nearly 76 percent of its 580,338 residents are white, 14.3 percent are black and 7 percent are Hispanic. The district is wealthy, with a median household income of $52,000, compared with $32,965 for New York State. Registered Republicans outnumber Democrats, 147,000 to 87,000, with 52,000 Independents.
 
The Issues
Both candidates' positions conform roughly to those of their parties but reflect the moderate views on some social issues of a wealthy, well-educated and religiously diverse constituency. Mr. Levy, who opposes the use of Federal Medicaid funds for abortion, nonetheless rejects the official Republican Party position and supports a woman's right to an abortion during the first trimester of pregnancy. Mr. Schiliro describes himself as ardently "pro-choice," supports the use of Medicaid funds for abortion and is seeking to appeal to women by offering greater Federal involvement to combat the high incidence of breast cancer on Long Island. On economic issues, Mr. Levy favors a cut in capital-gains taxes and an income-tax credit for first-time home buyers. Mr. Schiliro supports more Federal funds for rebuilding the nation's infrastructure and for education.
 
Analysis:
No polls have been taken, but the race appears close. Both candidates are seeking national office for the first time, and voters must decide between professional politicians with sharply different backgrounds. Mr. Levy brings strong support from within the Nassau County Republican organization and years of experience dealing directly with voters in the Town of Hempstead. But his allegiance to the county's Republican establishment is criticized by many here -- including Mr. Schiliro -- who say Nassau has been dominated and hurt by its Republican machine.
Mr. Schiliro brings a decade of experience in Congress, where he has analyzed national policy on health and the environment. His campaign has raised much more money than Mr. Levy's, much of it from political-action committees outside Nassau. But Mr. Schiliro may be vulnerable because he has spent all of his adult life outside the district he hopes to represent, residing mainly in Washington and its suburbs, and returned to his family's home in Baldwin only last spring, when his campaign began.
 
13TH DISTRICT: BROOKLYN, STATEN ISLAND
 
The Candidates
 
SAL F. ALBANESE, 43, Democrat. City Councilman since 1982 representing a Brooklyn district that covers some of the most conservative neighborhoods in the city, including Bensonhurst, Dyker Heights and Bay Ridge, where he lives. Former public-school teacher whose family immigrated to Brooklyn from Italy when he was a child.
 
SUSAN MOLINARI, 34, REPUBLICAN. Former City Councilwoman and third generation of a well-known Staten Island political family. In 1990 she was elected to the seat that had been held by her father, Guy V. Molinari, now Staten Island Borough President. Known for her support of abortion rights. Lives in New Dorp, Staten Island.
 
The District
 The redrawn 13th District covers all of Staten Island and then zig-zags through southwest Brooklyn. The population is mostly white and nearly 1 in 3 voters are Republicans, making this district one of the most conservative in the city. Two-thirds of the electorate live in Staten Island, the rest in the mostly Italian, Irish and Greek neighborhoods of Brooklyn, including Bay Ridge, Bensonhurst, Fort Hamilton and Dyker Heights.
 
The Issues
 The candidates differ on who would best address voters' concerns about reducing the $5 toll on cars crossing the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge from Brooklyn to Staten Island, the Fresh Kills landfill, health care and the environment. They both support a woman's right to an abortion.
 
Analysis
 Ms. Molinari's Staten Island roots and her name recognition have afforded her the clear advantage in this race. But her strong ties to the Bush Administration and her status as an incumbent may pose problems. She faces stiff competition from Mr. Albanese, who has based his campaign on his record as a maverick on the City Council and his reputation for strong constituent service.
 A third-party candidate, Kathleen Murphy, 53, a lawyer running on the Right to Life line, describes herself as the "only true conservative" in the race and is expected to draw some voters from Ms. Molinari.

14TH DISTRICT: MANHATTAN, BROOKLYN, QUEENS
 
The Candidates
 
CAROLYN MALONEY, 44, Democrat. Worked as a public-school teacher, an administrator for the City Board of Education and an aide in the State Assembly and the State Senate before being elected to the City Council in 1982. Has served as chairwoman of the Contracts Committee for the last year.
 
BILL GREEN, 63, Republican. Former administrator of Region 2 of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development before being elected to the House of Representatives in 1978. Serves on the House Appropriations Committee and is one of the wealthiest members of the House.
 
The District
District 14 is known as the Silk Stocking District because it comprises some of the richest areas in Manhattan. It takes in a good chunk of the East Side, stretching from Grand Street north to 106th Street and also zigzags into the West Side. The lines were redrawn this year so that the district now includes the West Side from 89th to 103d Streets; Greenpoint, Brooklyn; Astoria, Queens, and Roosevelt Island. These areas tend to be heavily Democratic, and Democrats outnumber Republicans in the district 3 to 1.
 
The Issues
Mr. Green has a well-established reputation as a progressive Republican in the Jacob Javits mold, a persona perfectly suited to this area of monied Democrats, and in Congress he has tended to vote against the Administration more often than not. He and Ms. Maloney agree on most social issues, including abortion -- both support a woman's right to choose -- and gay rights, and both describe themselves as champions of the environment. Mr. Green disparages the City Council's work, saying that the Council has not been particularly effective, while Ms. Maloney has sought to cast her opponent as a big-spending tool of special interests who has sided with the Administration on economic matters harmful to the city.
 
Analysis
Mr. Green is extraordinarily popular in the district and has staved off heavyweight challenges in the past from the likes of Bella Abzug, Andrew J. Stein and Carter Burden. He is also outspending Ms. Maloney more than 3 to 1 in this race. But he faces several problems this year: a possible landslide by Gov. Bill Clinton in the district; Ms. Maloney's anti-incumbency, year-of-the-woman campaign, and new district lines that have added heavily Democratic neighborhoods, where Mr. Green has little name recognition, to the district.
 
18TH DISTRICT: WESTCHESTER COUNTY, BRONX, QUEENS
 
The Candidates
 
NITA M. LOWEY, 55, Democrat. A volunteer community advocate in such organizations as the Parent-Teacher Association until 1975, when she became an official of the New York State Department of State. Served as the state's Assistant Secretary of State from 1985 to 1987. First elected to Congress in 1988 when she unseated her current opponent, Joseph J. DioGuardi, a conservative Republican who served two terms in Congress, winning election in 1984 and 1986.
 
JOSEPH J. DIOGUARDI, 52, a certified public accountant and a former partner of Arthur Andersen and Company. Served two terms in Congress. Besides the Republican line, Mr. DioGuardi has the Conservative and Right to Life designations.
 
The District
Snaking through central Queens, parts of the Bronx and southern Westchester County, 43 percent of the voters in the 18th Congressional District are registered as Democrats and 32 percent as Republicans.
 
The Issues
The race, a classic battle between a liberal Democrat and a conservative Republican, has been portrayed by some as one of the sharpest ideological conflicts anywhere in the country this year.
Mrs. Lowey has described her opponent as a "far-right, radical, former failed member of Congress" and said that his stance against abortion made abortion rights "a defining issue" in the race.
Mr. DioGuardi portrayed Mrs. Lowey as a "100 percent certified public liberal," who has been anti-business and weak in her support of Israel.
 
Analysis
In the final days, the campaign, which had been marked throughout by harsh attacks by both candidates, became extremely bitter with each side accusing the other of ethics and campaign-finance violations. Although Mr. DioGuardi has said he doesn't expect Mrs. Lowey to benefit from the Democrats' enrollment edge, new lines for the district have brought in areas of the Bronx and Queens that traditionally have heavy Democratic turnouts.
 
New York State Senate
The elections for the 61 seats in the New York State Senate, where Republicans have been in the majority for the last 27 years, are marked by two overarching questions: Will the Democrats pick up the five seats they need to take control of the chamber? And even if they fail, will Ralph J. Marino, the majority leader and most powerful Republican in state government, be returning to Albany?
The odds would appear to favor the Republicans in each case, in part because they controlled the Senate redistricting this year and in part because the G.O.P. is way ahead in fund raising for the Senate races. But in a state where Democrats outnumber Republicans nearly 3 to 2 and where the Presidential ticket may draw a huge Democratic turnout, the sheer force of numbers could yield some upsets.
Mr. Marino is locked in a tough race in his Nassau-Suffolk district with James F. Gaughran, a Democrat whose campaign has been aided by a fierce anti-Marino advertising blitz by a conservative anti-tax group. Mr. Marino has poured money and campaign workers into the race, and his party holds a clear edge in registration in the district. But the race is still considered up in the air, in part because a large turnout for the Clinton-Gore ticket could give Mr. Gaughran a major boost.
Another race that could be especially close is in Queens, where redistricting has pitted two popular incumbents, Jeremy S. Weinstein, a Democrat, and Frank Padavan, a Republican, against each other, .
The Democrats are concentrating on several other districts where they say their challengers have a real shot at unseating Republican incumbents. Among the major challenges to Republican incumbents in the metropolitan region are:
-- District 6, Nassau County, where the incumbent, Kemp Hannon, is running against Barbara I. Amster, the Democratic challenger, a college professor.
-- District 7, Nassau County, where Senator Michael J. Tully Jr., faces Michael J. Siris, a lawyer.
-- District 38, Rockland and Orange counties, where Senator Joseph R. Holland is running against Diana Hess, a former utility executive.
 
The Ballot Question
 
Proposal 1: The Jobs for the New New York Bond Act
Voters in New York State will be asked whether they want to support the proposed jobs bond act, under which the state would borrow $800 million to invest in infrastructure projects like roads and sewer hookups, to create jobs and to attract businesses to the state.
 
Analysis
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo says the proposal would create more than 35,000 immediate jobs, mostly in construction, and result in 122,000 permanent ones when businesses were attracted to the state. His administration has released a list of more than 350 projects around the state that would be eligible for funding if the bond act passed.
Opponents of the plan say that with the state already carrying $24 billion in tax-supported debt, it can ill afford to take on $1.7 billion more (the cost of the bond issue plus interest). And they question its usefulness in creating long-term jobs.

HEADLINE: Essay;
To Remember After E-Day

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Are you ready for the first pre-post-mortem of the '92 election? Here are some of the late hits and last-minute maneuvers that we can do without next time around.
1. Polling switches. The Gallup organization crossed the line from reporting to manipulating when it suddenly changed its methodology in the campaign's final week. Overnight, "likely voters" rather than "registered voters" became the basis for the closely watched percentages, instantly changing a six-point differential to a two-point gap. 
 If the Gallup organization, polling for CNN and USA Today, turns out to be right, other pollsters will henceforth weight their results on similar guesstimates of degrees of likelihood of respondents' actually voting. But the final-week switch in weighting misled a great many people into thinking the raw data was radically changed and a Bush bandwagon was rolling.
People who take and publish polls have an obligation to compare apples to apples, or to make a big, public point of it when switching the comparison to yesterday's oranges.
2. Campaign finance reform. Using the loose change in his own fortune, Ross Perot outspent the publicly financed candidates on television at the end by three or four to one. Not illegal; the Supreme Court has held it would infringe free speech to limit anybody's private spending. But it's not fair for any one candidate to use a huge financial advantage to dominate the airwaves and cables in the final stage of the campaign.
How to remove the inequity without limiting free speech? Require all candidates to file their spending plans 30 days in advance; then the Federal Election Commission could raise the publicly financed candidates' subsidy to match the private spenders. A billionaire would be restrained if he knew the others would charge him with forcing higher public spending.
3. F.B.I. dirty trick. After hearing the tall tales of Mr. Perot and his conspiracy consultant, the F.B.I. in Texas launched a "sting" to induce the head of George Bush's campaign in Texas -- a man who had shown no predisposition to wiretap, bug or dirty-trick anyone -- to commit a crime.
Incredibly, this entrapment was approved by the Director of the F.B.I., William Sessions, in Washington. He hotly defends his wrongful intrusion into political campaigns and threatens his readiness to tempt an honest official again when the next conspiracist points a finger.
Sunshine civil libertarians who shyly looked the other way when the F.B.I. used a sex lure to entrap the District of Columbia's mayor must now face the music: in the name of crime-prevention, the F.B.I. is in the business of crime-creation. With Mr. Bush's Attorney General in a personal war with Director Sessions, nobody can take the corrupt custodians into custody. Where is Senate Judiciary? Who will rid us of this power-abusive presumption of guilt?
4. Government statistics watch. A Hallowe'en "October surprise" to benefit the President was predicted here last summer; I suspected a strike at Saddam Hussein, with the bombers knocking over Qaddafi and Castro on the return home.
Instead, with the economy, stupid, the paramount issue, the final week of the campaign saw a surprisingly rosy estimate of the economy's third-quarter growth from Mr. Bush's Commerce Department. This provided some desperately needed ammunition to fire off a declaration that there won't be a triple dip.
In a month or so, we'll get the revised figures. If G.D.P. growth is 2.7 percent or higher, I will express chagrin at my lack of faith in the bureaucracy; if it's 2.2 percent or less, and Mr. Bush has won, suspicious souls will reach down there and demand an accounting of the projections.
5. Independent counsel restraint. In handing up his second indictment of Cap Weinberger, Judge Walsh supplied more evidence that blew away Bush protestations of having been out of the arms-for-hostages "loop."
Was Vice President Bush in the Casey-Poindexter ransom camp? Yes; his denials ring ever more false. Was the independent counsel right to drop this bombshell four days before the election? No; the indictment should have been handed up weeks earlier, or sealed -- special prosecutors should stay outside politics.
Those are for Wednesday. Meanwhile, there's Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Foul Words and False

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
My father was in the textile business. When I was perhaps 12 years old, he came home from the office one night looking stunned. He told my mother this story, and I listened.
Another man in the industry had made a bargain with him. That day my father discovered that the man had not carried out his promise. My father telephoned and asked him what had happened. He said: "So I lied." 
 It was not anger that I heard in my father's voice; it was bewilderment. He was an upright man, and it was beyond his understanding that someone would have no shame. "So I lied."
That childhood episode came back to me during the last days of President Bush's campaign. More than any incumbent President in memory he has been a candidate without shame. Lies, hate, vulgarity: Nothing has been too shameful for George Bush.
He referred to Bill Clinton and Al Gore as "these two bozos." Attacking Senator Gore's views on the environment, Mr. Bush called him "ozone man" and then just "ozone."
It is the name-calling of a child, a playground bully. Listening to such talk from the President of the United States, a young person said: "It makes me feel sad for America."
And the lies. I was in a New York taxi the other day when on a radio news broadcast there was Mr. Bush attacking something that he said Governor Clinton had proposed on increasing AIDS research. The taxi driver, amazed, exclaimed: "That isn't what Clinton said." I was not amazed. No one could be who has followed Mr. Bush's falsehoods in this campaign.
The lies are so shameless that they have buffaloed the press. Generally, campaign coverage has improved. The press has done more this year to watch out for deception, especially in political advertising. But reporters still have trouble confronting the President of the United States when he is untruthful.
Sam Donaldson of ABC News is not a shy person. But the other night, interviewing President Bush, he asked how Mr. Bush could blame Congress for spending too much when his own budget proposals over the years would have produced about the same spending levels. The President said that was not so. But it was exactly so. And Mr. Donaldson let him get away.
The big lie that has now been definitively exposed is Mr. Bush's repeated statement that as Vice President he did not know we were sending arms to Iran in exchange for hostages.
Several official sources, American and Israeli, had said that Mr. Bush was thoroughly informed -- indeed was a participant. Then came last week's clincher: the contemporaneous notes of Caspar Weinberger, then Secretary of Defense, showing that Mr. Bush favored the deal when a crucial White House meeting on Jan. 7, 1986, considered a proposal to sell 4,000 TOW missiles to Iran in return for the release of five American hostages.
(The Weinberger notes were disclosed in a court filing by the independent counsel on Iran-contra, Lawrence E. Walsh. It was a powerful example of the need for an independent counsel on such politically charged matters. No one would expect candid conduct of the case if Attorney General William Barr, who is busy covering up the Iraqgate scandal, were in charge of Iran-contra.)
George Bush's falsehoods have none of the justifications sometimes offered for lying. They are not white lies, to save hurt feelings. They are not lies to serve some great cause. They are only lies, small and large, to serve George Bush's ambition.
The foul words and falsehoods that have spewed from Mr. Bush in the last days of the campaign show us a man in a frenzy for something -- anything -- that might work. They show us a man without the inner values that restrain human conduct: a man without a core.
These last days have degraded the most important office in the country. They have made the Presidency a symbol of hate and division instead of unity and dignity.
The strange thing about the 1992 campaign is that the challenger has acted more like a President. Win or lose, Bill Clinton has campaigned with respect for the office. That may be why The Economist of London, a conservative magazine, concluded its lead editorial last week by saying that Mr. Clinton as President could "bring Americans, black and white, rich and poor, closer together. Despite the risks, the possibilities are worth pursuing. Our choice falls on him."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Pop and Jazz in Review

BYLINE: By ANN POWERS

 BODY:
Velocity Girl
CBGB
Lower East Side
The youngest school of tadpoles to start swimming up the alternative music scene is characterized by shyness and some fear of individuation. Produced in the bedrooms and basements of undergraduate white America, this gentle form of rock is typified by whispering vocals and sleepy rhythms. Call it rainy music, because it seems to dissolve the outside world and demand a moment of revery. Velocity Girl, from Washington, is an emerging talent on this scene, and in a C.M.J. showcase on Saturday night, the band demonstrated the streaks and limitations of this appealing musical style. 
 Weaving a chord of sonorous guitar and bass lines above the steady beat of drums, Velocity Girl jumped to its own amiable sound. Sarah Shannon, the singer, murmured difficult-to-decipher lyrics about longing and self-doubt in honey-soft tones popular among rainy-music vocals. A few of the songs moved to a more emphatic peak of guitar noise, but most stayed on the smooth ground of melancholy repetition. "It doesn't matter much if we live and die," she sang, but the message resonated not as despairing but as ethereal, as if Velocity Girl were more likely to simply float into the cloudy sky at any moment.
When she tried to sing with more power, her voice came off as strained, and the band's stabs at heavy noise seemed misdirected. Velocity Girl's strength is in tapping the seductive strain of music that also produces lullabies, aiming for sounds that charm. For a young generation already weary from an adulthood starting in a recession, Velocity Girl's rainy music is a comfortable haven, leaving room for wistful imagining without too many demands.

TYPE: Review

HEADLINE: European Suppliers of Iraq Were Known to Pentagon

BYLINE: By DEAN BAQUET with ELAINE SCIOLINO

 BODY:
Four months before President Bush signed a secret order encouraging closer relations with Iraq, the Defense Intelligence Agency provided rich details of the network of European companies President Saddam Hussein used to buy technology that could upset the balance of military power in the Mideast.
 A classified 1989 document illustrates how much information about Mr. Hussein's military ambitions and methods was available as the Administration was embarking on its policy of courting Iraq. It shows that United States intelligence knew that British tool-maker Matrix Churchill Corp., which had a branch in Solon, Ohio, played a major role in Iraq's weapons-buying program, yet did nothing to stop its operations. 
Mr. Hussein used the company to buy seemingly innocent technology and equipment, then converted it for use in building a homegrown weapons industry, law enforcement officials said.
 
Did One Agency Tell Another
 The existence and timing of the report raise the question of whether Mr. Hussein's arms-buying spree was aided by a lack of communication between United States intelligence agencies on the one hand, and export agencies and policy makers on the other.
 It is not clear whether this June 1989 report, written more than one year before Iraq invaded Kuwait, made its way to top policy makers within the Administration, or the agencies that control exports. One Pentagon official familiar with the report, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said it was the kind of document that would be widely circulated among senior Pentagon officials.
 If the report was passed on, it raises yet another question: In its pursuit of a closer relationship with Iraq, did Washington allow Iraqi-owned companies in the West to freely acquire weapons technology?
 Parts of the June 1989 report, as well as a classified Nov. 6, 1989, report by the C.I.A., were described in broad terms in a floor statement last summer by Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat, as evidence that the Government had information about Mr. Hussein's arms network.
 But other Administration and Government officials familiar with the report provided additional information about it, including the warnings about Mr. Hussein's growing power and aggressiveness.
 The Administration has repeatedly asserted that it did nothing to encourage Mr. Hussein's military buildup, and that Iraq acquired Western arms technology by lying about the purpose of equipment it bought.
 
An Intelligence Source
 But last week, documents made public in a trial in London revealed that the British Government knowingly allowed Matrix Churchill to buy arms-making equipment because two of the company's British executives were secretly informing it about Iraq's arms buildup. Rather than lose this source of intelligence, the British let the company buy equipment known to be destined to help Mr. Hussein build weapons.
 Following disclosure of the documents in London, the Senate Intelligence Committee asked Robert M. Gates, Director of Central Intelligence, what Washington intelligence agencies knew about the relationship between Matrix Churchill and the British Government. Among other things, the committee wanted to know whether American intelligence also allowed the company to buy equipment for Iraq.
 The report's warnings about Mr. Hussein mirror the criticism Democrats have leveled at the Bush Administration's policy toward Iraq. Though it is not known if the report was widely circulated, other evidence about Mr. Hussein's arms buildup was presented to President Bush and senior policy makers during a 1989 National Security Council meeting called to discuss whether economic and political incentives could be used to change Mr. Hussein's behavior.
 Richard J. Kerr, former Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, recalled that he told policy makers that Mr. Hussein had maintained his million-man army after the Iran-Iraq war and was already meddling with other countries in the region.
 "I tried to give the sense that this guy was dangerous, that he had not changed his spots," Mr. Kerr recalled in a recent interview. "I also said that he had ambitions and that he was going to be dangerous. I don't think his military buildup was ever an issue. No one ever disagreed that he was involved in these weapons programs."
 The report described more than a dozen companies in Western Europe as owned or controlled by Iraq. It said that during the latter part of the 1980-1988 war between Iran and Iraq, Matrix Churchill sold Iraq computerized lathes that were used to produce weapons, despite the company's assertion to British export authorities that they were machine tools intended for peaceful purposes. The report also linked the company's Ohio subsidiary to Mr. Hussein's arms network.
 The report said secret procurement networks could help developing countries such as Iraq acquire chemical and biological weapons and ballistic missiles. It added that such weapons in the hands of Iraq could pose a major threat to United States forces in the Middle East, and disrupt the balance of power in the region. It predicted that such secret networks would become more complex, hampering Western efforts to stop or limit the spread of military technology.
 In the months after the reports were written, Matrix Churchill continued to buy Western arms-building technology. Pentagon officials now acknowledge that its Ohio-based subsidiary helped Iraq purchase parts to make howitzers through a Virginia-based supply company.
 In addition to Matrix Churchill's Ohio operation, the report also portrayed at least one other United States-based businessman, Anees Mansour Wadi, an Iraqi national with a mansion in Beverly Hills, Calif., as integral to Mr. Hussein's arms-buying network in the West.
 The June 1989 document identified Mr. Wadi as head of a British company the report said was buying ballistic missile technology for Iraq. The report said Iraq gained control of the firm between late 1987 and late 1988 and identified its ultimate master as Hussein Kamel al-Majid, Mr. Hussein's son-in-law and the man charged with supervising Iraq's arms buying network.
 The Treasury Department seized the assets of Mr. Wadi's United States company, called Bay Industries, Inc., after Iraq's August 1990 invasion of Kuwait. Nonetheless, the Government has given Mr. Wadi permission to draw up to $12,000 a month from his assets for living expenses.
 Mr. Wadi's lawyers have said he is innocent of any crime, and has been financially devastated by the Government action.

HEADLINE: Slovaks Finish Much-Criticized Dam on Danube

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 31

 BODY:
Bucking a storm of criticism and threats from several nations, the Slovak republic is digging in to defend its nationalistic energy policy -- a policy that has diverted the Danube River and has apparently preserved two large nuclear reactors that many Western experts say should be dismantled.
As Hungary reviles Slovakia in terms that once might have started a war, Slovak officials stand firm. 
 Julius Binder, director of the Slovak water enterprise that has just completed a vast dam on the Danube at Gabcikovo, is particularly harried.
"I've had phone calls from five government ministers this morning, and we're trying to deal with a case of sabotage that happened two days ago," he said. "And it's not even 9 A.M. yet.
"Right is on our side, and we intend to stand fast."
 
Problem No. 1
 Slovakia is not yet sovereign; representatives of the Czech and Slovak republics have agreed that the federation will split on Jan. 1. But the republics' governments in Prague and Bratislava are already rushing to complete the details of their divorce.
Perhaps the thorniest international problem that Slovakia faces stems from its determination to generate as much electricity as possible, both for domestic industry and to export to Western Europe. Much poorer than the Czech republic in almost all ways, Slovakia faces an uphill battle for economic survival, and the sale of electricity is crucial.
More than half of Slovakia's electricity is generated by its huge nuclear complex at Jaslovske Bohunice, where four Soviet-designed plants turn out 440 megawatts each. The Gabcikovo dam, which sent its first brief jolt of power into Slovakia's grid in October, will generate some 720 megawatts.
 
The Criticism
 Hungary is determined to fight the dam tooth and claw, despite the fact that when the project began in 1977, Hungary was an equal partner.
When opponents of Hungary's former Communist Government came to power in 1989, they announced plans to end the Gabcikovo project, which many Hungarians had come to regard as a symbol of high-handed Communist rule and Soviet domination.
Since 1989, Hungary has been joined by several international environmental groups that say the dam will destroy wildlife, flood valuable land and damage one of Europe's largest underground water supplies. Nations downstream worry that a reduction in the flow of the Danube will disrupt river transport.
Many Western nations take an equally dim view of Slovakia's nuclear power program.
Two of the plants at Bohunice are relatively new and are regarded by Western experts as fairly safe, despite their lack of sealed enclosures capable of confining radioactive material during an accident. But the other two, one of which began operating two decades ago, lack even a substitute for such containment and have many other deficiencies.
Ivan Selin, director of the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission, has visited Bohunice, and he said in a recent interview: "The old reactors really look Stalinist, old-fashioned and dirty. It's a sloppy place."
Experts of the European Community generally agree with Dr. Selin, and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development has made credit to Slovakia conditional on closing down the old reactors, known as VVER-440/230's.
But Bohunice's director, Robert Gunis, said in an interview that Slovakia not only intended to continue operating the old pressurized-water reactors, but was also seeking Western expertise and credits to modernize them.
"Several companies are bidding for the job," said Dobroslav Dobak, the assistant plant manager, "but frankly the Westinghouse Company looks rather good to us. They're putting together a plan that would not make closing down those reactors a condition, and we like that."
 
Focus on Security
 An extensive tour of Bohunice disclosed antiquated video monitors and worn computer keyboards (with Cyrillic letters) in the main control room, a bank of old-fashioned Soviet electrical relays in the fire-control station and other aging equipment. But the turbine and reactor halls looked much like their Western counterparts (except for the absence of containments), and elaborate safeguards to protect the 2,800 workers from radioactive contamination.
A new double apron of electrified fence was being installed, and soldiers with submachine guns patrolled the plant's perimeter, alert against nuclear terrorists or other threats.
The importance of security was shown in late October at the Gabcikovo dam: as the finishing touches were put on the huge project, someone broke into the electronic system controlling the brand-new locks and destroyed two vital circuit boards, Mr. Binder, the water-resources director, said.
 
Who Was the Saboteur?
 "Temporarily, we were unable to operate the locks, and because the water was rising, we had to turn on one of the dam's turbines for a while, although we had agreed not to run the turbines until November, after concluding the international discussions," Mr. Binder said.
"But despite the sabotage, we were able to control the locks manually, and we shut down the turbine after just a brief run," he said. Mr. Binder declined to speculate who the saboteur might have been.
Whatever assaults it may face, the giant dam is finished, and ships traveling from the mouth of the Rhine at Rotterdam will soon move through its two locks on the way to the Black Sea. A huge new lake is spreading behind the dam.
Hungarian insistence on demolishing the dam notwithstanding, it would take a nuclear bomb to remove it, and the filthy, olive-drab Danube is already flowing through its new channel.
