HEADLINE: Major Races to Watch in Today's Election in New Jersey

 BODY:
U.S. House of Representatives
 
2D DISTRICT: ATLANTIC, BURLINGTON, CAPE MAY, CUMBERLAND, GLOUCESTER, SALEM
 
The Candidates
 
WILLIAM J. HUGHES, 60, a Democrat. The incumbent, he has represented the district for 18 years. Was an assistant prosecutor in Cape May County for a decade before that.
 
FRANK LoBIONDO, 46, a Republican. Elected as State Assemblyman in 1987. Had been a Cumberland County Freeholder for 3 years. Operations manager for a family-owned trucking business.
 
The District
 The Second is the state's largest congressional district, sprawling over six counties, from the Delaware River to the Atlantic Ocean. The vast majority of residents are white, and among voters, Republicans outnumber Democrats, 82,000 to 65,000. But the largest group of voters -- more than 138,000 -- are unaffiliated.
 
The Issues
 Gun control has become a significant issue in the race because the two men have very different views. Mr. Hughes, a gun-control advocate who has written several major anti-crime bills as chairman of the Judiciary subcommittee on crime -- he has since switched to the subcommittee on courts, intellectual property and judicial administration -- has emphasized Mr. LoBiondo's support from the National Rifle Association, which despises Mr. Hughes and applauds Mr. LoBiondo for his sponsorship of a measure to repeal Gov. Jim Florio's ban on assault weapons in the Legislature.
Mr. LoBiondo has assailed Mr. Hughes for votes against the balanced budget amendment to the Constitution and in favor of the Congressional pay raise, as well as his acceptance of such Congressional perks as a taxpayer- provided automobile.
 
Analysis
 Mr. Hughes's self-effacing popularity and attention to the district -- he has spent few weekends in Washington during his long tenure -- have made him all but unbeatable. Despite Mr. LoBiondo's aggressive campaign, the incumbent's roots in the district give him the edge.
 
6TH DISTRICT: MONMOUTH, MIDDLESEX
 
The Candidates
 
FRANK PALLONE JR., 40, Democrat. Lawyer and former Long Branch City Councilman and state legislator. Elected to Congress in 1988.
 
JOSEPH M. KYRILLOS JR., 32, Republican. A State Senator and former member of the General Assembly. Manager of business standards and ethics for the Mid-Atlantic Health Group, a hospital management company in Rumson.
 
The District
The new Sixth District is an amalgam of two areas: the northern half of Mr. Pallone's old Third District along the Jersey Shore, and southern and central Middlesex County from the old Sixth District, which was represented for the last 12 years by Bernard J. Dwyer, who has retired. The southern end of the district begins in Sea Girt, an affluent oceanfront town, and heads north and then west into industrial Middlesex County, which makes up 58 percent of the district and gives it a blue-collar and Democratic cast.
 
The Issues
Mr. Kyrillos has been basing his campaign on voter frustration over the economy and the resulting anti-incumbency mood. He said he recognized that much of the anger was aimed at President Bush, whom he supports, but that voters should remember the role of Congress. He characterizes Mr. Pallone, who attracts many large donations from political action committees, as "the ultimate insider."
Mr. Pallone calls himself a "maverick" and repeats that he was the only member of the New Jersey delegation to vote against the last Congressional pay raise in 1989. He has won the support of national and state environmental organizations for his sponsorship of clean-water legislation in the State Legislature and Congress.
Both men support abortion rights, although Mr. Pallone was a strong opponent of abortion before changing his position three years ago.
 
Analysis
Mr. Pallone has raised five times more money over the last two years than Mr. Kyrillos, who entered the race only last spring. The edge in financing and the strong showing of Gov. Bill Clinton in the Presidential race have helped install Mr. Pallone as the favorite. With Mr. Bush closing the gap in recent days, Mr. Kyrillos has been attracting new support and exhibiting increased enthusiasm as the race ends. Still, a Kyrillos victory would be considered an upset.
 
7TH DISTRICT: ESSEX, MIDDLESES, SOMERSET, UNION
 
The Candidates
ROBERT D. FRANKS, 41, Republican. A member of the Assembly since 1979. Twice served as chairman of the New Jersey Republican State Committee.
 
LEONARD R. SENDELSKY, 58, Democrat. A house builder who founded his own company in 1958. Has never run for office. One of the state's major fund-raisers for Democratic candidates.
 
The District
The newly redrawn district, for 20 years the fief of Representative Matthew J. Rinaldo, a Republican, stretches across northern New Jersey and is one of the most ethnically diverse in the state.
 
The Issues
Neither candidate has found a specific issue to exploit. Instead each has focused on portraying himself as a Washington outsider intent on reforming Congress, while painting his opponent as a political insider.
 
Analysis
Representative Rinaldo surprised everyone when he announced his retirement just days before the filing deadline for the election. With no incumbent and a new district, this is one of the most unpredictable races in the state. After winning the Democratic nomination, Mr. Sendelsky spent much of his effort compiling material for a race against Mr. Rinaldo. Nearly all of it became useless. Mr. Franks's campaign had a late start. Each candidate has claimed to hold a slight edge, while worrying about the outcome.
 
8TH DISTRICT: ESSEX, PASSAIC
 
The Candidates
 
JOSEPH L. BUBBA, 54, Republican. He was elected to the State Senate in 1981. He also served as Passaic County Freeholder and Passaic County Republican chairman in the mid 1970's and early 80's.
 
HERBERT C. KLEIN, 62, Democrat. A lawyer, he served in the State Assembly from 1971 to 1976 when he was defeated in his bid for a third term. As executive director of the Passaic County Democratic Committee, he has remained politically active. He is also one of the biggest fund-raisers for Democratic candidates and causes in the state.
 
The District
With the voting-age population almost equally divided between urban and areas, blue-collar bedroom communities and wealthy mountainside suburbs, the 8th is one of the most varied political districts in the state. Democrats outnumber Republicans, 92,000 to nearly 55,000. But in recent national and statewide elections, an unaffiliated bloc of voters, now numbering about 125,000, have given the edge to Republican candidates. About 70 percent of residents are white, with large blocs of second-generation immigrants. Blacks make up about 15 percent of residents, with most concentrated in two cities, Paterson and Passaic.
 
The Issues
Mr. Bubba, a conservative who prides himself on never having voted for a tax increase in 11 years in Trenton, has attacked Mr. Klein for voting for the state income tax when he was a member of the Assembly in 1976. Mr. Bubba also highlights his tough stance in the Legislature against crime.
Mr. Klein argues that he is "not a career politician who has lost touch with ordinary people." He also assails Mr. Bubba for accepting contributions from the National Rifle Association and supporting the overturn of the state's ban on assault firearms.
 
Analysis
 When Robert A. Roe, a very popular Republican, announced he would not run again after 22 years in Congress, the district turned into a battleground for the first time in two decades. Mr. Bubba has the edge in name recognition, and is thus favored, but the race at this point is considered too close to call.
 
13TH DISTRICT: HUDSON, ESSEX, MIDDLESEX, UNION
 
The Candidates
 
ROBERT MENENDEZ, 38. Mayor of Union City since 1986. Was serving his second term in the State Assembly when selected to fill a vacant State Senate seat in February 1991; was elected to a two-year term in the Senate in November.
 
FRED G. THEEMLING JR., 48. Lawyer and former assistant Hudson County prosecutor. Tried unsucessfully to unseat the retiring incumbent Congressman, Frank Guarini, in 1988 and 1990.
 
The District
The 13th was drawn after the 1990 Census, when New Jersey lost one seat, and comprises working-class, urban areas. Was drawn to maximize Hispanic voter strength; about 43 percent of the district is Hispanic.
 
The Issues
Both candidates have focused on jobs, the economy, health-care costs and crime. Mr. Menendez's "urban agenda" would focus on tax incentives for new development and job-training in urban areas. Both candidates favor urban enterprise zones; Mr. Theemling would also grant tax breaks to companies that hire new workers and raise taxes on businesses that lay off workers to make a profit.
 
Analysis
Mr. Menendez, the Democrat, is the heavy favorite in a district where Democrats far outnumber Republicans. Besides outspending Mr. Theemling by more than 15 to one, he has received all the major endorsements. He is a Cuban-American and many Cuban-American voters in the district, who tend to vote Republican, are expected to support him. He would become New Jersey's first Hispanic representative in Congress.
Mr. Theemling's hope is that the anti-politician, anti-incumbency sentiment in the district will work in his favor.

HEADLINE: Senate Candidates Barnstorm Around New York Last Times;
In Party Unity Effort, Abrams Sees 'New Era'

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD

 BODY:
Robert Abrams bumped across a relentlessly gray upstate landscape through intermittent rain, sleet and snow yesterday in a final appeal in areas where polls show a tight race for the United States Senate, then raced back to heavily Democratic Manhattan to stir enthusiasm at a union rally in Harlem and at a handshaking stop on the Upper West Side.
 Sounding a theme of party unity and pounding away at the need for change in Washington, the Attorney General spoke repeatedly of a "new era" in American politics and stressed that Bill Clinton, if elected, will need another vote on the Senate floor if he is to overcome Washington gridlock. He also contended that Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, his Republican opponent, had joined with two Republican administrations to draw jobs and money away from the state. 
Speaking again and again of the hope of a Clinton administration, Mr. Abrams told small gatherings at airports in Buffalo, Rochester, Syracuse and Albany that he wanted to have a place in a revitalized Washington.
 "I want to be part of that," he told a group of party faithful and union leaders while standing in a penetratingly cold hangar in Syracuse and urging them to get out the vote. "I want to be at the table."
 
Rain and Rainbows
 By dusk, he was at a rally at the Bethel A.M.E. Church in Harlem, where he was greeted with a standing ovation by about 300 members of the New York City Hospital Employees' Union Local 420 and introduced with the promise that "we are going to wake up in the morning and we are going to go out to the polls because after the rain, comes the rainbow."
 The union rally, which brought together Mayor David N. Dinkins; Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President; Representative Charles B. Rangel, and other city leaders, used the rhetoric of revolution and promised "the end of the dark night" of 12 years of a Republican White House, in the words of one speaker. But it was perhaps most notable for the presence of the Rev. Al Sharpton, whom Mr. Abrams defeated in the bitter primary, and who has consistently refused to formally endorse Mr. Abrams's candidacy.
 Mayor Dinkins called for a Democratic sweep and urged everyone to vote. "We have the franchise," he said to enthusiastic applause. "And we ought not to waste it, because if we do, it's shame on us."
 Mr. Abrams, who sat grinning and relaxed as one speaker after another rose to take the podium, repeated his familiar litany of complaints about New York's economy and the drain of money to Washington. "You know," he said to applause and shouts of approval, "George Bush is shivering in his boots. People are gathering like this all over the state and all over the country and tomorrow they are going to send George Bush out of the White House and Al D'Amato to the dog house. For 12 years, they have been punishing the people of New York."
 Hitting away at Senator D'Amato in one of his most sustained attacks of the campaign, Mr. Abrams told the crowd: "You know, voting for Al D'Amato is like playing the Lotto. One wins. And millions lose. I want to go to the Senate to be your advocate,"
Earlier, in back-to-back stops across upstate New York, the Attorney General wheeled through his last full day of campaigning, repeating his appeal for votes.
 Between stops he chatted with his traveling companion, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who was so confident that he suggested to Mr. Abrams that he seek a seat on the Senate Appropriations Committee, as if the election were already decided.
 "All the signs are going your way now," Senator Moynihan said.
 Clearly, the agenda for the day was to highlight what Mr. Abrams called "the coming together of the campaign," from Bill Clinton's hoarse endorsement at a rally in the Meadowlands Sunday night to Geraldine A. Ferraro's somewhat strained endorsement Saturday.

HEADLINE: Many Teachers, Required to Make Do With Less, Are Giving Less in Return

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
Upset by Spartan pay increases and the effect of budget cuts on schools, many teachers are venting their frustrations in a way that has angered students and parents: They are refusing to write letters of recommendation for college-bound students, to tutor after school or to perform other duties not specified by their contracts.
The tactic, called "work to the rule," is being used in growing numbers of school districts across the country to underscore teacher disenchantment over the management of public schools. At a time when teachers are under mounting pressure to produce better students, recession-induced budget cuts have meant teacher layoffs and larger class sizes, making teaching more difficult. New contracts have provided small raises, if any; in some cases teachers have been asked to take pay cuts. 
 Although teachers said striking is normally a more effective tool, it is increasingly viewed by educators as a poor weapon in economic times that are tough for everyone. Moreover, teachers strikes are illegal in 22 states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. As a result, work-to-the-rule tactics are being used widely for the first time in a decade to illustrate the extent to which teachers are disaffected.
 
'Tearing Communities Apart'
 "There's absolutely no question that this is happening more often," said Arnold Fege, director of government relations for the National Parent-Teacher Association in Washington. He said his office had been inundated with calls from parents across the country wondering what they can do. "The last time I saw this happening at this level was in the early 1980's," he said. "This is tearing communities apart."
Many students and parents do not sympathize with the teachers. While there are no definitive statistics on the number of school systems in which teachers have adopted work-to-the-rule stances, anecdotal evidence from Virginia to Michigan to California suggests that the practice is widespread.
In Los Angeles, teachers scuttled the usual back-to-school nights for parents or held them during the day, and most will take parents' calls only during school hours. Teachers in Dearborn Heights, Mich., will not sponsor clubs whose meetings are held after regularly scheduled classes. And at Madison High School in Fairfax County, Va., many teachers have refused to write recommendation letters for college-bound students or complete students' scholarship recommendation forms.
 
Scholarship in Jeopardy
 William Mathews, a 17-year-old senior at Madison who applied for a scholarship in the Navy Reserve Officers Training Corps, asked his mathematics teacher to complete a questionnaire about his academic and leadership abilities. She refused.
"What upset me most was that she didn't even have to write a recommendation," said Mr. Mathews, who is not sure he will get the scholarship now because he submitted an incomplete application. "There were 10 questions, and all she had to do was fill in a bubble on a form. I was upset."
At Woodrow Wilson High School in the District of Columbia, a controversy arose in September when teachers agreed to write college letters of recommendation only if the students' parents first wrote three letters -- to the school board, to the City Council and to the school superintendent -- protesting low pay for teachers and teacher furloughs.
While work-to-the-rule tactics have succeeded in getting the attention of school boards and parents, the approach has a price: parents are angry, and the teachers' actions have created even greater rifts between teachers and school boards, which are faced with tough decisions on where to trim budgets because of declining state aid to schools.
 
Teachers' Actions Criticized
 "Teacher unions have no concern about resources," said Thomas A. Shannon, executive director of the National Schools Board Association, an umbrella group for the nation's 15,350 local school boards. "School boards can't print money, and they are constrained by law in the resources that they can raise."
Many teachers themselves say they find work-to-the-rule actions distasteful, and recognize that their truncated workday undermines their students' education.
"It hurts education on two levels," said David Tokofsky, a teacher at Marshall High School in Los Angeles who has stopped coaching the school's academic decathalon and mock trial teams after school. "Teachers come to the profession because of their idealism, and that has been put on hold. And students aren't getting all the extras that we can give them after school."
Nonetheless, many teachers like Mr. Tokofsky are firm in their support of the work-to-the-rule strategy, and pay is the principal reason. Mr. Tokofsky, 32, has taught for nine years and now earns $43,000 a year. But this year his salary is being cut by 9 percent by the Los Angeles Unified School District, whose board voted to reduce salaries rather than lay off teachers. That is in addition to a 3 percent pay cut last year.
 
Decline in State Aid
 In many ways Los Angeles exemplifies other districts across the country, which have seen sharp declines in state aid because of the recession. The Los Angeles school district, whose 640,000 students make it the nation's second largest after New York City's, cut $400 million from this year's budget, leaving it at $3.9 billion. But teachers opposed the 9 percent pay cut, and voted to use the work-to-the-rule tactic.
"I've liked what I've done for the last nine years," said Mr. Tokofsky, who coached his school's academic decathalon team to two national championships in the 1980's, often staying late on school nights. "Now I'm asking myself, 'Why are they doing this to me?' "
Mr. Tokofsky, who teaches American history and Spanish, said he enjoyed the after-school activities because they gave him the chance to work with only 10 to 15 students, instead of the 35 to 45 he usually has in his classes.
But now, given the district's budget problem and its effect on teacher salaries, Mr. Tokofksy said he is thinking about getting out of teaching.
Budget cuts and their effect on the quality of public schools have prompted teachers in other school systems this fall to eliminate duties for which they are not paid. In Fairfax County, a Washington suburb where teachers have been fuming over the district's decline in the amount of money it spends per student, the district is now ranked fifth in spending out of five school systems in the Washington area.
"We need to take control of our professional lives," said Karen Beasley, a Madison High School teacher of students with learning disabilities. "We can't do more and more with less and less." But because Virginia law prohibits strikes by public employees, teachers chose the work-to-the-rule tactic to call attention to what they view as a dismantling of public education.
Fairfax teachers are now boycotting meetings scheduled at night and on weekends. And they will not help students or take telephone calls from parents after 2:45 P.M., the end of the teachers' contract workday.
Teachers at Madison High will co-sign letters of recommendations for college-bound students written by others, but have refused to write the letters.
"I asked one teacher to write me a letter, and she refused," said Benjamin Boykin, a Madison student and president of the senior class. "I was surprised, but I knew where she was coming from."
 
Teachers 'Take a Hit'
 "None of us like doing this," Ms. Beasley said. "The hardest part of it is the confliction all the teachers feel. But we understand that when we take an action like this, we take a hit from the public."
The teachers have, in fact, been widely criticized by parents and the community. "That's not influencing anyone," said Kenton Pattie, president of the Fairfax County Council of Parent Teacher Student Associations, referring to the teachers' refusal to help students with letters of recommendation. "It's repugnant to our sense of decency and fairness."
In other school systems where teachers have followed a work-to-the-rule policy, parents and some administrators have filled the breach by serving as club sponsors and chaperones so that students are not cheated out of extracurricular activities.
"We need teachers who are completely committed," said Annie Costanzo, president of the Parent Teacher Association at Melrose Avenue Elementary School in Los Angeles. Mrs. Costanza said teachers at that school had opposed the teachers union's work-to-the-rule tactic; teachers in other schools had agreed to the work slowdown.
"I'm certainly upset about the budget cuts to education," she added. "I understand the teachers' outrage. But their priority should be the kids."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Some teachers are expressing discontent over budget cuts with a tactic known as "work to the rule," or performing only the duties specified in their contracts. "I asked one teacher to write me a letter, and she refused," said Benjamin Boykin, senior class president at Madison High School in Vienna, Va., who talked with Karen Beasley, a teacher. "I was surprised, but I knew where she was coming from." (Michael Geissinger for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1818 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: CELEBRATION
Man in the News: Albert Arnold Gore Jr.;
A Focused Leader on an Uneven Climb

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

 BODY:
When the subject of Al Gore Jr. is raised, inevitably the phrase "born to lead" -- spoken with either admiration or sarcasm -- somehow seeps into the conversation.
Still, if it was preordained for this child of a former Senator and native son of Washington to reach the heights of power, his rise to the Vice Presidency has been accomplished through fits and starts. 
 Indeed, after his disastrous 1988 run for the Democratic Presidential nomination -- an effort that thrust him onto the national stage but also saw him alienate large blocks of traditional Democratic voters -- he is as surprised as anyone else to be in the position he's in now.
"I certainly had not given up the thought of running for President," Mr. Gore said when asked about his feelings after his defeat four years ago. "I made no bones about the fact that I wanted to be President and would run again when I had the opportunity.
"But if somebody had told me in 1988 that come January '93 you'll be inaugurated as Vice President of the United States, I would have said, 'You're nuts.' "
 
Once Disparaged Office
 Mr. Gore's astonishment to be Vice President-elect stems both from having won an office he had disparaged in the past and his feeling that he had removed himself from consideration for national office when he said in August 1991 that he would not run in 1992. At the time, he said he wanted to devote more time to his family and young son, who was nearly killed when he was struck by a car two years earlier.
But in what Mr. Gore feels is a sweet irony, the banking of the fire of his ambition moved him closer to his goal of national power rather that farther away from it.
"I think that sometimes in life -- and I'm neither old enough, nor wise enough to put this in proper words -- when you care about something a lot and you give it up for the right reasons, it will come back to you in a different form with a deeper meaning," said Mr. Gore, who once attended divinity school.
"That's what this feels like," he said. "I gave up my ambition to be President in the 1992 cycle for the right reasons, because of my family's healing process, and stayed completely out of it and really enjoyed not running for President. And then a place on the national ticket came back to me, unsolicited, unsought, in a different form and with a deeper meaning because the element of personal ambition had been in significant measure drained out of it."
 
Driven to Achieve
 Albert Arnold Gore Jr. was born March 31, 1948, in Washington, the son of Albert A. Gore Sr., a Democratic Representative, and later Senator from Tennessee, and Pauline La Fon Gore, a graduate of the Vanderbilt law school.
From childhood throughout much of his adult life, Mr. Gore seemed to be driven to achieve. He was the least rebellious of his parents' two children; an honors student and captain of the football team at St. Albans School for Boys, an exclusive preparatory school in the capital; a cum laude graduate from Harvard; a diligent Congressman, and an expert on arms control and the environment.
In 1988 he wanted to be the youngest President in the country's history.
In all his successes, and even in his failures, friends say, Mr. Gore made his mark more through doggedness than flash. "He was a very hard-working player," said James Bailey, a friend from Harvard who played alongside Mr. Gore on the freshman basketball team. "There were other players who were more talented, but nobody worked harder."
But his diligence and discipline can border on bland and boring. In 1988, after a political consultant suggested that because few voters could identify him Mr. Gore should not vary his wardrobe too much, Mr. Gore drove the patience of his staff to the wall by refusing to appear in anything but a blue suit, light blue shirt and red tie.
 
Opponent of Vietnam War
 Like many of his classmates at Harvard, Mr. Gore opposed United States involvement in the Vietnam War. But classmates say he was not an active participant in the anit-war movement.
Vietnam was to confront Mr. Gore with his own moral quandary after his graduation from Harvard in 1969. At the time, his father, an outspoken opponent of war, was locked in a bitter and close re-election battle for his Senate seat in which his opponent, Bill Brock, was making an issue over the Senator's anti-war stand.
Mr. Gore considered leaving the country to avoid the draft -- a move his parents say they would have supported -- but he knew that that would have doomed his father's chances. In the end, he enlisted in the Army. He was motivated, he says, by his desire to help his father and because if he had avoided the draft someone else from his small town of Carthage, Tenn., would have had to go. His decision, however, made little difference to his father's re-election bid. The Senator lost by 46,000 votes.
His military career was undistinguished. In Vietnam, he served as a reporter for the newspaper of the 20th Engineering Battalion, stationed outside Saigon, and never saw combat.
But his father's loss, the war and the Watergate scandal a few years later soured him on politics. "When I was a little kid, I remember thinking, maybe I would like to do what my father did," Mr. Gore said. "But I completely abandoned that notion, especially after coming back from Vietnam, going through the Watergate years and becoming so disillusioned with government and politics."
Returning home in 1971, he went to work as a reporter for The Tennessean, a newspaper in Nashville, attended the Vanderbilt Graduate School of Religion and tried his hand as a home builder and a livestock and tobacco farmer. While writing about politics and government for the newspaper he began to feel, he said, as if he "could handle some of the decisions I was writing about more creatively than some of the people I was covering."
In 1974, when the local Congressman abruptly announced he was retiring, Mr. Gore said he made a "snap decision" to run for the office. After squeezing out a victory in the Democratic primary, he won going away in the general election.
Recalling that his father's defeat in 1969 stemmed in part from accusations that he had lost touch with his constituents, Mr. Gore made sure he kept in contact with the people back home. In his eight years as a Congressman he attended more than 1,300 town meetings in his district, spending an average of three weekends a month away from his family in order to do so. Mr. Gore is married to the former Mary Elizabeth (Tipper) Aitcheson, and they have four children: Karenna, Kristin, Sarah and Albert 3d.
Attending a state convention of a civic club for high school girls in 1981, Mr. Gore was stunned when told that a number of the participants felt that nuclear war was inevitable in their lifetimes. The experience, Mr. Gore said, led him to seize on arms control as a cause.
For a year, Mr. Gore buried himself in the study of arcane disarmament issues, spending hours in weekly study sessions on the subject. He emerged with a novel approach to the arms race that emphasized replacing multiwarhead missiles, which he felt promoted fears of a catastrophic first strike, with single-warhead missiles.
After Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, the Republican leader in the Senate, announced in 1983 that he would not seek re-election, Mr. Gore sought his seat the next year and won it easily.
But 1984 was a bittersweet year for Mr. Gore. His elation over his victory was tempered by the death of his older sister, Nancy Gore Hunger, from lung cancer.
In 1988, when he sought the Presidency, Mr. Gore was responding to a request by a group of centrist Democratic fund-raisers. But he entered the race late and his main messages -- arms control, a need for a strong national defense and protection of the environment -- never connected with voters. Although he won five Southern and border states in the Super Tuesday primary, Mr. Gore's campaign foundered above the Mason-Dixon line.
He ended the race with an embarrassing showing in the New York primary, where his most prominent supporter, Mayor Edward I. Koch, so angered black voters with repeated attacks on the Rev. Jesse Jackson that Mr. Gore was forced to march in a New York City parade on a sunny Sunday wearing a bullet-proof trench coat after receiving death threats.
Yet, if Mr. Gore's badly run 1988 effort in the primaries left him in need of any political rehabilitation by his party's left wing, in many ways it was the prototype for the successful campaign waged this year by Gov. Bill Clinton.
Many of Mr. Gore's themes -- focusing on the economic needs of "the average working family," for example, or standing up to the icons of Democratic liberalism like Mr. Jackson -- found their way into Mr. Clinton's oratory.
 
Senator's 'World Changed'
 Disappointed after his loss and saddled with a $2.3 million campaign debt, Mr. Gore set about refurbishing his image and preparing the ground to run again. He paid off his debts in a remarkable 10 weeks, as much to rid himself of the financial burden as to show his continued political viability. He once again buried himself in weekly seminars, this time on economic issues, which he felt would be central to the next election.
But in April 1989 "the world changed" for the Senator, said his longtime aide, Peter Knight. That moment came when Mr. Gore's youngest child, Albert, was struck down by an automobile after the family had attended a Baltimore Orioles baseball game. The near-fatal accident and the child's monthslong rehabilitation brought about a transformation in his father, the Senator's friends say.
"Basically, a lot of people can be pretty calculating," said Carter Eskew, a political consultant and a longtime friend. "They're always looking at the next move. The chess game never stops. Well, with Al, all of sudden the chess game stopped."
As a kind of therapy, Mr. Gore threw himself into writing a book, "Earth in the Balance," in which he compared his son's medical emergency with what he considered the planet's tenuous condition and called for a radical program to halt ecological degradation.
Before the accident, Mr. Gore says, he was convinced that he could win the Democratic nomination in 1992 and that President Bush, despite his stratospheric voter-approval ratings, could be beaten. But in August 1991 Mr. Gore announced he would not run. Family considerations, he said, were paramount. As he put it:
"What I finally came to terms with was that the real cause of my conflict about running was that so long as my son's healing process and my family's healing process was still under way, I could not throw my whole heart and soul into a race for President, because I would feel terrible not being able to devote the time and attention and emotional energy that healing process still required of me."

HEADLINE: Tide of Migrant Labor Tells of a Law's Failure

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CONKLIN, Mich.

 BODY:
At dusk, the migrant workers trudge in from the orchards to the dusty courtyard of the farmer's labor camp, where they live in aged, rust-pocked trailers. From straps on their shoulders, they carry galvanized buckets with canvas bottoms so the apples they pick will not bruise. The workers get 50 cents each time they fill a bucket.
Every year, an estimated 45,000 of these men and women, nearly all originally from Mexico, spend one to six months in western Michigan. With its wide variety of fruit and vegetable crops, including asparagus in the spring and apples in the fall, the region is one of the nation's leading employers of migrant labor. 
 But it is harder than ever for workers to find a job here or, having found one, to make a living. This year, like last, farmers report that they have been turning people away. A sign on the packing shed of one farmer, Fritz E. Umlor, says "No help wanted" in foot-high letters. Mr. Umlor said that most of his 12 workers returned year after year and that he had to turn away three carloads of job seekers during one week in October.
The Government once thought it could prevent an overflow of such job seekers. Six years ago, Congress passed the Immigration Reform and Control Act, under which three million illegal immigrants, including one million migrant farm workers, were granted amnesty and permitted to remain in the United States. The law tried to prevent any further illegal immigration by imposing sanctions on employers who hired subsequent arrivals.
By making it harder for illegal immigrants to come here and work, the law was intended to alter the economics of migrant labor. Employers, having to compete harder to lure a stable or shrinking supply of legal workers, would improve workers' wages and working conditions.
But this month, the Commission on Agriculture Workers, which Congress created with the immigration act to assess the effects of the law, disclosed that illegal immigration continues largely unchecked. An overabundance of farmworkers is crowding the job market and holding down wages. State officials say the average migrant family of four in Michigan, legal and illegal, made $7,200 last year, just over half the $13,924 the Government says the family needed to escape poverty. The $7,200 salary represents no real improvement in a decade, farmworker advocates say.
The law's impotence is easily seen here: Among the people coming in from the orchard are a 25-year-old man whose wife and two children are in Mexico, and another man, 45, with a wife and six children there. About 3,300 agents of the Immigration and Naturalization Service patrol the 2,000-mile border between Mexico and the United States, 100 more agents than six years ago, but the two farmworkers here got past the authorities and into Brownsville, Tex., uneventfully.
"We just crossed the bridge when it was busy," said the older man, who along with the 25-year-old man spoke on the condition that they not be identified for fear of deportation.
From Texas they caught a ride to Florida. In Tampa, they said, they each paid $900 for phony identification documents -- a Social Security card and a resident alien card -- and hitched a ride to the Midwest.
 
Passing Boss's Scrutiny
 The younger man took out his papers. His resident alien card is a copy of a new, ostensibly fraud-resistant version. It is plastic-coated, with personal data, a fingerprint and his picture in profile; all like the real thing except that the picture is blurry. He said his papers readily passed the boss's scrutiny.
He also said he believed the cards looked good enough to let him cross the border at will. "Soon the winter will come," he said. "There's no work, so no money to pay for rent and food. I will go back to Mexico then."
No one knows how many of the farmworkers in Michigan are illegal. Rick Kessler, a lawyer in Grand Rapids who specializes in migrant worker cases, gives an estimate of 30 percent. Mr. Kessler said the total number of workers does not change much here, despite the apparent rise in illegal immigration. He said many who come looking for work find none, so they go back to their bases in Florida and Texas.
Because of the threat of sanctions, employers ask for two pieces of identification. But no one expects employers to be forensic technicians; if the documents look authentic, the employer is off the hook. The authorities say the law has given rise to a growing counterfeit-document industry.
Still, the people working illegally in the fields and orchards here might have been apprehended if not for another failing of the law. To raid farms of illegal workers, Congress required that the immigration service get search warrants specifying a cause for a search, the fields where the immigrants would be working and the identity of the landowner. Because the workers move from field to field day to day, the information is hard to get, Duke Austin, a spokesman for the service said. "That dramatically deterred our ability to do enforcement," he said.
 
More Legalized Workers
 In western Michigan, Manuel Gonzalez, head of the Governor's Interagency Migrant Services Committee, said the immigration law did seem to be contributing to a slow improvement in working conditions. With help from advocates like Mr. Kessler and the Michigan Migrant Legal Assistance Project in Grand Rapids, he said workers can demand more of farmers.
But Mr. Gonzalez also said the law was paradoxically encouraging more immigration. The reason is that more workers sought amnesty than expected, partly because many were able to qualify with falsified documents. More legalized workers meant more legalized spouses, who could also work.
Under its immigration policies, the Government tries not to split up families. So if the wife and children of a newly legalized worker could show that they were in the country before the law was enacted, the immigration service permitted them to stay.
Michael C. Hyde, a lawyer with the legal assistance project, said workers' living conditions were improving somewhat in the state, but not because farmers had to compete harder to attract workers. The state has enacted new laws requiring that farmers provide drinking water and portable toilets in their fields and better housing.
 
11 People Live in One Room
 Yet enforcement of these requirements is lax, because of budget cuts in Federal and state agencies. Mr. Gonzalez, who coordinates state services to migrant workers, said his office had been reduced from six workers to one -- himself. He said a state program that subsidizes farmers who build better housing had been sharply cut, from $600,000 three years ago to $75,000, a minuscule amount in a state with 900 labor camps on its farms.
The state public health agency, which licenses the camps, has just nine inspectors. Marvin Johansen, chief of the agency's migrant labor housing office, said inspectors get to most of the camps before they open in the spring and make random checks later.
But the later checks are so rare that farmers do not seem compelled to maintain the camps through the summer. At one camp here, a large old barn had been converted to a three-story apartment house. In one ground-level, one-room apartment, four children, aged 8 to 16, cooked an early supper while their parents and older relatives worked.
The room is quite large, about 600 square feet, with a concrete floor. The children say 11 people live in it. It is midday, but the room is dark. One side of the room has been sliced from the rest by a barrier of sheets. The sheets hide a row of double beds, aligned side by side, mattress to mattress.
The 8-year-old, a boy, proposes a tour of the camp. "Want to see the bathroom?" he says. There are no toilets in the barn, so the farmer provides separate cinder-block community outhouses for men and women. The men's outhouse is dark and dank and layered with mildew and scum. It is acrid.
A narrow aisle, about two feet wide, separates five toilet stalls that face five shower stalls. State law requires provisions for privacy. But hardly anything remains of the plastic curtains the farmer has hung in front of the stalls. Visits to five camps in and around Conklin suggest that the condition of the outhouse is not unusual.
 
Few Regulators Seen
 Federal regulators are not often seen on the farms. The wage and hour division of the Federal Department of Labor enforces regulations governing child labor and the $4.25-an-hour minimum wage. Over 15 years, its investigative staff in Michigan has been cut from about 50 to 20, in line with cuts in other states.
So, rather than seek out abuses, the Labor Department can only react to complaints, and a department official said it had a backlog of them in Michigan. As a result, farmworker advocates say violations of the child labor laws are common.
With enforcement lax, conditions on the farms here depend largely on the attitudes of the farmer. Bill Rasch, probably the biggest apple grower in the area, has a well-ordered, well-swept camp close to his home. Mr. Rasch, father of 14 children, says his workers are based in Florida and that each winter he visits them there.
Much of Mr. Rasch's camp, though tidy, is old and worn, and Mr. Johansen says his office has urged Mr. Rasch to replace the housing. Still, Mr. Rasch's community outhouse is, relatively speaking, a model of comfort and hygiene. It is clean, dry, well lighted and freshly painted white. There are plywood doors enclosing the toilets and new curtains for the showers.
"They are human beings," Mr. Rash said of the workers. "They are proud people. And we need them."

Mares, above, are recruited from Florida yearly and have well-maintained housing. (Deb Kik for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTION: NEW YORK STATE -- D'AMATO;
Senator Proclaims Comeback, and Victory

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY

 BODY:
Shortly after 1 o'clock this morning, after a long night of suspense, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato joined hundreds of cheering supporters in a ballroom at the New York Hilton and claimed victory over Attorney General Robert Abrams.
Looking happy but subdued, surrounded by former Mayor Edward I. Koch and a crowd of loyalists, he thanked his family, his campaign aides and particularly Jewish leaders for their assistance. Then he embraced Norman Rosenbaum, the brother of the Hasidic scholar slain last year in Crown Heights, and said, "I pledge to you, we will pursue justice" -- a reference to the acquittal of the man accused of killing his brother. 
 The Senator called it a great political comeback, and at the end of a bitter and arduous campaign, the claim seemed to be justified. Mr. D'Amato waged a fierce, ruthless and seamless battle against a lackluster challenger and spent more than any other Senate candidate, close to $10 million. But all along, he was fighting the political tide. The former Hempstead, L.I., presiding supervisor who narrowly won on the coattails of Ronald Reagan in 1980 clung to his office even as Bill Clinton soundly trounced President Bush In New York and across the nation.
 
Highs and Lows
 It was a night of highs and lows and nervous energy and taut suspense. While his supporters sipped cocktails and watched the results on a huge TV screen in the ballroom, booing whenever Mr. Abrams's face came on the screen, the Senator watched the TV results in his suite, surrounded by his parents.
Shortly after 10 P.M., moments after The Associated Press first predicted him the winner, Mr. D'Amato received 100 special supporters to thank them for their support. Dov Hikind, the Brooklyn Assemblyman who helped coordinate Jewish voters on his behalf, said he found Mr. D'Amato emotional, "choked up" and expansive. "I've never been kissed so much in my life," he said.
Mr. D'Amato had always said he was seeking "vindication" in his campaign for a third term, bitter over a two-year Senate Ethics Committee investigation that cleared him of criminal charges but chastised him for misusing his office.
But, cautious to the end, he did not claim victory until he was satisfied that his narrow lead would hold.
 
Highs and Lows
 But downstairs, in a conference room off the main ballroom, his aides quickly moved from stunned relief to rapture at the early predictions of victory.
"It's a miracle," shouted Jeff Weisenfeld, Mr. D"Amato's liaison to the Jewish community. Other staffers strove for more equanimity. "Al D'Amato spent 12 years in the Senate fighting for the people of New York," said his campaign manager, Keiran Mahoney. "In the end, people didn't believe the attacks levied against him."
Mr. D'Amato's brother Armand, whose trial on charges of illegal lobbying on behalf of defense contractors is scheduled to take place after the election, roamed quietly around the ballroom, hugging friends. He said he was surprised by the outcome. "Given the tide," he said, "and all the negative things, I didn't expect it." He said he, too, felt vindicated by the upset victory.
Publicly, Mr. D'Amato had predicted victory until the end, but on election day, before the polls had closed, there were small signs of pessimism within his campaign. Unlike Mr. Abrams, who followed the example of Mr. Clinton and continued to campaign yesterday morning, Mr. D'Amato voted in his hometown of Island Park, carrying a grandchild into the voting booth with him, gave an emotional talk to Republicans at a diner in Oceanside, then spent the day between his parents' home in Island Park and his own house a few streets away.
He had a 6 P.M. dinner at De Grezia, an East Side restaurant, with Mr. Koch, his campaign strategist, Arthur Finkelstein, and three other friends. His dinner of pasta and paillard of chicken was interrupted by periodic calls from his campaign manager, Mr. Mahoney, who called the restaurant with the latest exit polls. Before leaving, he instructed Mr. Finkelstein to prepare two speeches, one for victory and another for a concession. As if bracing himself for defeat, he asked Mr. Koch to stay close to his mother in his hotel suite, "if things don't go right."
 
Money Leads the Way
 Mr. D'Amato outspent his opponent, bested him in debates, and outmaneuvered him time and again. Mr. D'Amato, who at the beginning of the year seemed almost certainly doomed to defeat, bogged down by multiple allegations of ethical misconduct and a slumped economy, punched, kicked and spent his way back into an even contest.
He was relentless until the very end, returning to the message of class resentment that helped him win in 1980, casting himself as an ordinary Joe battling a millionaire opponent who drives "limousines" and lives in a "fancy" Upper East Side Avenue apartment.
And with his nasal Long Island accent, he spoke directly to New Yorkers' fear of rising crime and higher taxes. Those were his themes in 1980, and he repeated them in 1986 and again this year.
"The message won," said Tony Russo, who produced Mr. D'Amato's campaign commercials. "We drew the comparison between D'Amato and Abrams on taxes and jobs, the issues New Yorkers care about."
But it was the Senator's mother, Antoinette D'Amato, who stood at the podium this morning and tried to get the last word. "Everybody used to call him the pothole Senator. Please, he's not a pothole Senator, he's a people Senator."
But it was Mr. Koch who go in the final rejoinder: "Mama D'Amato, it was the potholes that elected him."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTION: NEW YORK STATE -- NEWS ANALYSIS;
'Senator Pothole,' and Money, Win

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
Alfonse M. D'Amato, the scrappy Long Island Republican who reveled in his nickname of "Senator Pothole," proved the political adage last night that all politics is local, withstanding Gov. Bill Clinton's 16-point landslide in New York State to win a third term in the United States Senate.
It was a race that the 55-year-old incumbent would have lost if New Yorkers had voted by issues and party line and logic. 
 It was, after all, his opponent, Robert Abrams, the State Attorney General for four terms, who stood squarely with New Yorkers on the issues that they most cared about, according to surveys of voters leaving the polls. Mr. Abrams was a critic of the 12 years of Republican management of the economy and far better positioned than Mr. D'Amato on such such issues as abortion rights and health care.
 
Running as Underdog
 And even if New Yorkers did value Mr. D'Amato for his ability to bring home money and projects to New York, they had to ask if he would be as successful with a Democrat in the White House.
But in a tactically brilliant campaign, Mr. D'Amato skillfully undermined his lackluster opponent and painted himself as an underdog defender of local interests, a little guy who looked out for the people like him.
"I'm not a diplomat," he said during his acceptance speech early this morning, adding in his distinctive nasal tones: "I'm your advocate. I'm your fighter and I'm going to continue to fight."
And a fighter he was. From first to last, Mr. Abrams, who had rarely faced a tough opponent in his 26 years in public office, simply seemed shocked by the ferocity of Mr. D'Amato's charge against him. And he remained stunned and frustrated as Mr. D'Amato brazenly and pre-emptively attacked Mr. Abrams's ethics although the Senate Select Committee on Ethics had criticized the Senator for running his office in an "improper and inappropriate manner."
"He totally had Abrams on the defensive for the entire campaign," said William D. Powers, the Republican state chairman.
Democrats, who rallied to Mr. Abrams's side, tried to put the best face on his bumbling campaign, saying the Attorney General had come out of a close, divisive primary, which had muddled his message and left him without funds to match Mr. D'Amato's formidable treasury of nearly $10 million.
"He wasn't given the chance to use his best political instincts -- to be progressive, be constructive, because of the unfortunate way in which the primary left him vulnerable and left him broke," said Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who turned his own personal fund-raising list over to his fellow Democrat, although the two had had their own differences in the past.
"Senator D'Amato, by his negative advertising so big and so early, had an effect on the campaign," said Kevin Thurm, state director of the New York Clinton-Gore campaign. "It took a while for Abrams to recover."
Still, Mr. D'Amato's campaign tactics should not have come as a surprise to any politician who remembered his Republican Senate primary victory in 1980 when he savaged the incumbent, Jacob K. Javits, for his age and failing health, defeating a man who was considered a New York institution.
He played just as hard in his bid for a third term. He immediately assailed Mr. Abrams as "hopelessly liberal," more liberal than the Democratic standard-bearer, Mr. Clinton. And he went further, unabashedly staking out positions that he should not have been able to get away with if his Democratic opponent had been more aggressive. He portrayed himself -- a conservative Republican opposed to abortion rights -- as close to Mr. Clinton.
Democrats had hoped that repeated official inquiries into Mr. D'Amato's conduct in office would be the Senator's great vulnerability: he had faced charges of using his office to seek special favors for relatives, friends and contributors. His brother, Armand, who goes to trial early next year on mail fraud charges, was said by the Senate ethics committee to have used the Senator's office to help win a client a defense contract.
But Mr. D'Amato fought Mr. Abrams to a draw on ethics issues, equating his own lapses with Mr. Abrams's late payment of taxes on a country house and with Mr. Abrams's campaign fund-raising techniques. Despite Mr. Abrams's efforts to take the high ground and stick to issues, both men ended up sullied by the charge and countercharge. More voters questioned in surveys by Voter Research & Surveys, the television polling consortium, thought Mr. Abrams had leveled unfair charges than thought Mr. D'Amato had.
Most importantly, Mr. D'Amato, a fiery campaigner, sought successfully to hold onto the kinds of conservative blue-collar Democrats who supported President Ronald Reagan in 1980 and swung back to the national Democratic ticket last night. He used snide references to Mr. Abrams's "Fifth Avenue" apartment and "51-acre estate" to portray the staid Attorney General as a rich man.
Mr. D'Amato, the child of Italian immigrants, also capitalized on Italian-American resentment over the way Geraldine A. Ferraro had been criticized during the Democratic primary when her opponents raised questions about her family's close contacts with organized-crime figures. And when Mr. Abrams in frustration called Mr. D'Amato a "fascist," Mr. D'Amato deftly portrayed the comment as another anti-Italian slur to solidify his own support among this base.
To draw Democrats, Mr. D'Amato highlighted his endorsement by a Democrat, former Mayor Edward I. Koch of New York City, whose sassy, abrasive qualities still have appeal among white working-class voters. Mr. Koch was at Mr. D'Amato's side at the victory podium this morning, getting an embrace from the Senator.
Mr. Abrams sought to reclaim part of the Italian-American vote with a an endorsement by Ms. Ferraro, who made a television commercial on his behalf. But the endorsement was late and Ms. Ferraro's grim face made it seem half-hearted.
But when the vote came in last night, Mr. D'Amato held strong leads among Catholics and Protestants and among both the Irish- and Italian-American voting blocs. Mr. Abrams was unable to muster huge majorities among any voter categories except blacks and Jews and people whose education included at least a college degree. He also held a small edge among women.
As the race hovered all night in a dead heat, political professionals could only express astonishment.
"I'm surprised," said Ms. Ferraro, who lost to Mr. Abrams in the Democratic primary by one percentage point. "Where's the coattails?"

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTION: NEW YORK STATE -- U.S. HOUSE RACES;
Green and Downey Lose as New York State Delegation Changes Dramatically

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
In the most drastic transformation of the state's Congressional delegation in decades, New York voters yesterday elected at least eight new members, with at least two longtime incumbents headed for defeat.
With the defeat of Thomas J. Downey, a Suffolk County Democrat with 18 years in the House, and of Bill Green, a liberal Manhattan Republican with 14 years of service, New York will be missing at least 12 incumbents, and much of its seniority, in a delegation already diminished by reapportionment. 
 Mr. Downey, who was first swept into office as a grass-roots outsider in the wake of the Watergate scandal, was defeated in a bitter negative campaign by Rick A. Lazio, a Suffolk County legislator and former assistant district attorney, who lambasted Mr. Downey as a Washington insider who had lost touch with his struggling, recession-scarred district.
Representative Green, among the most liberal Republicans, who worked to disassociate himself from President Bush in the closing days of the campaign, apparently lost in a close race to Carolyn B. Maloney, a popular Manhattan City Council member, in the overwhelmingly Democratic Silk Stocking District.
 
A Loss of Seniority
 Ms. Maloney declared victory just after midnight. Mr. Green said that the race might not be decided until the absentee votes were counted -- and offered no public concession last night.
"I've had a wonderful decade and a half and maybe I'll have another two years, but we'd better wait," Mr. Green said.
The defeats mean that New York will lose members with considerable seniority on both the Ways and Means Committee (Mr. Downey) and the Appropriations Committee (Mr. Green) and other key committee assignments that have been used to protect the state's interests in Washington.
In Staten Island, Susan Molinari, who was being challenged by a well-known Democratic city councilman, Sal F. Albanese, declared victory shortly before 11 P.M. "It's going to be a different time in our political history," she said. "The message was sent out that business as usual is going to change."
 
Battles in Nassau
 Nassau County, where Democrats hoped to make inroads in a long-entrenched Republican party, was a battleground with several close races. David A. Levy, a local Republican strategist and member of the Hempstead Town Board, defeated Philip Schiliro, a Democratic congressional aide.
Late last night, Peter King, the Nassau County Comptroller, appeared before a Republican Party gathering and said that he appeared to have won a very close race, against Stephen A. Orlins, a wealthy businessman.
In a third race, a Democratic incumbent, Gary L. Ackerman, running in a new district, that runs across Nassau into Suffolk, narrowly defeated Allan E. Binder, a Suffolk County legislator.
In Westchester County, Representative Nita M. Lowey was re-elected, defeating Joseph J. DioGuardi, a conservative Republican, who had served two terms in the mid-1980's.
In New York City, longtime incumbents such as Charles B. Rangel, and Charles E. Schumer, Edolphus Towns and Major R. Owens were swept into office with overwhelming margins, as were Republicans farther upstate like Amo Houghton Jr. and Gerald B. Solomon.
In a sign that things remain the same even as they change, nearly all of the newly elected Congressmen -- from Jerrold Nadler, an eight-term Democratic Assemblyman from Manhattan, to John M. McHugh, a four-term state Senator from Watertown -- come from the ranks of experienced legislators in Albany or in local governments around the state.
Perhaps no other Congressional delegation is changing as much as is New York State's. It has lost more incumbents and more seniority than any other state. It will be less white, less male, and younger -- with the average age of the new members perhaps 15 years than the 55-year average age of New York's incumbents.
The transformation has far more to do with the perils of redistricting than with the popular mood.
In the redistricting following the 1990 Census, New York lost seats in Congress -- as it has in each redistricting since 1950. This time it was three seats out of 34, more than any other state.
Of the 34 members of the last Congressional delegation, 8 retired. For some the problem was redistricting; for others, personal dissatisfaction with Congress. One incumbent, Ted Weiss of Manhattan, died. And another, Stephen J. Solarz, lost in the primary, unable to hold on in a district redrawn to elect a Hispanic representative.
Even in this year of change this loss of perhaps 12 members is striking. In all, the state will lose more than 200 years of combined seniority or an average of 17 years of seniority for each departing representative.
"We have the biggest turnover problem," said Representative Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat. "It presents a problem -- you don't have enough seniority -- and an opportunity -- you get new energy and new blood."
The last time there was such upheaval in New York's delegation was in 1974, following the Watergate scandal, when 11 new representatives were sent to Congress, out of 39 seats. That year all the newcomers were Democrats, including five who defeated incumbent Republicans.
Though New York has about 1 in 13 representatives in the House, it accounts for one in eight retirements this year, according to Michael J. Malbin, a researcher with the Rockefeller Institute. And among those stepping down were New Yorkers who were well placed on important committees, giving rise to to concerns that the state delegation will lose some of its ability to save military bases and bring the state a hefty share of any new Federal spending.
In the place of the veterans will be a collection of newcomers, such as Mr. Nadler and Nydia M. Velazquez, who served a short interim appointment to the New York City Council.
"New blood is good," said Ms. Velazquez yesterday. She said that she hoped to work with other new members, blacks, Hispanics and progressive whites, to put together "the kind of agenda that will address the issues of the inner cities."
Mr. Nadler said that he was pressing to get committee assignments in public works and transportation as a way of paying attention to "fundamental economics."
"We are going to have a new beginning and a 20-year backlog of pent-up progressive legislation," he said.
During the state's redistricting, a second Hispanic district was created across three boroughs. It is there that Ms. Velazquez defeated Mr. Solarz in the Democratic primary. The seats of New York City's four black representatives were protected.
Other incumbents were not so lucky. Representative Ackerman, after nine years representing a Queens district, was forced to run in a district that stretched far into Suffolk County, including less than 10 percent of his old district.

GRAPHIC: Photos: On the day when New York's Congressional delegation underwent major change with at least eight new members, Nydia M. Velazquez celebrated at her campaign headquarters in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. (Photographs by Monica Almeida/The New York Times)
 
 
New In Congress: New faces in New York's Congressional delegation.
 
2d District; RICK A. LAZIO , 34, Republican. A lawyer and member of the Suffolk County Legislature since 1989, he upset longtime Representative Thomas J. Downey. His district covers western Suffolk County.
 
4th District: DAVID A. LEVY , 38, Republican. A lawyer and former radio reporter, he is a member of the Hempstead Town Board. He replaces Raymond J. McGrath, a Republican who retired after redistricting. The district covers southwestern Nassau County.
 
8th District; JERROLD NADLER , 45, Democrat. A State Assemblyman since 1976, he won his seat when chosen by party leaders to replace the late Ted Weiss on the ballot. He will represent a heavily Democratic and liberal district, which includes Manhattan's West Side and parts of Brooklyn.
 
12th District: NYDIA M. VELAZQUEZ , 39, Democrat. Formerly a cabinet-level representative of the Governor of Puerto Rico, she essentially won her seat in the Democratic primary, defeating an incumbent, Steven J. Solarz, and four Hispanic candidates. Her district was created especially to include Hispanic neighborhoods in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens.
 
14th District: CAROLYN B. MALONEY , 44, Democrat. A New York City Councilwoman since 1982, she has worked as a teacher, an administrator for the Board of Education and an aide in the State Assembly and State Senate. She defeated a longtime incumbent, Bill Green, and will represent some of the wealthiest areas in Manhattan.
 
24th District: JOHN M. McHUGH , 44, Republican. A member of the State Senate since 1985, he replaces David O'B. Martin, who retired after serving six terms. He will represent an overwhelmingly Republican district, which includes his hometown, Watertown, and Oswego and Plattsburgh.
 
26th District: MAURICE D. HINCHEY , 54, Democrat. A member of the State Assembly since 1974, he fills the seat left vacant by the retirement of Matthew F. McHugh. In the Legislature he earned a reputation for environmental and consumer activism. His district includes Binghamton, Kingston and Newburgh.
 
30th District: JACK QUINN , 41, Republican. A teacher and a four-term town supervisor in Hamburg, he fills the seat left vacant by the retirement of Henry J. Nowak. His district includes most of Buffalo and Erie County suburbs.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTION: NEW YORK STATE -- THE NEW YORK LEGISLATURE;
Once Again, Republicans Maintain Control of the Senate

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK

 BODY:
After spending more for a state legislative seat than any other candidate in New York history, the majority leader of the State Senate, Ralph J. Marino, last night comfortably fended off a vigorous challenge that had threatened his standing as the most powerful Republican in state government.
At the same time, several Republican colleagues of Mr. Marino in the Senate also appeared to have beaten back Democratic challengers and thus preserved the G.O.P.'s 27-year grip on the Senate, but with the strong possibility that the party's majority would be diminished. 
 As of 12:45 A.M. today, Republicans, who now hold a 35-to-26 edge in the chamber, were ahead in at least 32 races and seemed likely to win at least one other.
Overall, Democratic hopes of riding the Clinton-Gore coattails to victory in the local State Senate races were, in most cases, crushed.
In one bitterly contested race in Queens pitting two incumbents against each other, a Republican Senator, Frank Padavan, defeated his Democratic opponent, Jeremy S. Weinstein. With 77 percent of the precincts counted, Mr. Padavan had 60 percent of the vote.
In another hotly contested race, in the Hudson Valley, with 90 percent of the precincts counted, a Republican incumbent, Joseph R. Holland, led a Democrat, Diana Hess, a former utility-company executive and soap-opera star, by 56 percent to 44 percent.
In the conservative southwestern corner of the state, a surprisingly close race emerged as Nancy Gay Bargar, the Democratic challenger, was leading by a single percentage point over the Republican incumbent, Jess Present, with about 90 percent of the precincts counted. Mr. Present was hurt as 9 percent of the voters turned to John W. Hasper, a Republican Assemblyman whose name appeared on the Conservative line even though he had endorsed Mr. Present after losing the Republican primary.
Democrats also were on the verge of winning an open seat in the Rochester area.
 
Marino Talks Tough
 A fiery Mr. Marino declared victory around 11 P.M. at his headquarters in Jericho, L.I., and offered a blunt retort to two conservative anti-tax groups that had also spent heavily to denigrate his record in Albany. "To hell with Pack-Up, to hell with Change-NY," he said, referring to the groups by name. And he pledged to lead an effort to revitalize his party as it approaches the 1994 gubernatorial election.
At 12:45 A.M. today, with 34 percent of the precincts reporting, Mr. Marino had captured 60 percent of the vote in his race against James F. Gaughran,
a Suffolk County legislator. Mr. Gaughran had conceded after early returns showed him losing even in precincts of his hometown of Huntington.
In the Assembly races, while final totals were not available, Democrats appeared assured of winning at least 88 of the 95 seats they hold now, and probably several more.
 
High-Visibility Race
 The race involving Mr. Marino was clearly the most watched among the contests for the 211 seats in the State Legislature -- 150 in the State Assembly and 61 in the Senate.
As the majority leader of the Senate, which has been in G.O.P. hands since 1965, Mr. Marino is the most powerful Republican in state government.
It is extremely rare for a legislative leader to face any serious opposition in a re-election bid, and indeed the last time one actually lost was in 1978 when the Assembly Speaker, Stanley Steingut of Brooklyn, was upended in a Democratic primary by an insurgent, Murray Weinstein.
As of Oct. 19, which was the most recent mandatory filing at the State Board of Elections, Mr. Marino had spent $560,000 and Mr. Gaughran $80,000, with both men expected to add tens of thousands of dollars to those totals by the end of the campaign.
On top of that, Mr. Gaughran benefited from the $185,000 spent in a highly unusual campaign, an effort against Marino led by an anti-tax conservative group that calls itself Pack-Up, for the Political Action Committee to Kick Out Unproductive Politicians. The campaign, listed in elections filings as an "educational effort on Ralph Marino's record," consisted of a flood of radio commercials excoriating Mr. Marino for approving billions of dollars in tax increase and deferred tax cuts during his tenure in Albany.
The drama over Mr. Marino's plight played against the backdrop of Democratic hopes that the Clinton landslide in New York state would help the party do what it had failed to do for almost three decades: take back the Senate from the Republicans.
But history, and the realpolitik of incumbency-protection politics in Albany, suggested all along that the Democrats' battle would be very much an uphill one.
The Democrats needed to pick up 5 seats to take control.
But the G.O.P., which controlled the reapportionment process in the Senate this year, drew new district lines to maximize their advantages. That made it even tougher for the Democrats to win new seats than in 1990, when a similar push for a Democratic victory failed miserably, and the Republicans actually picked up a seat.
And because the laws of political gravity in Albany push money toward expected winners, the Republicans held an overwhelming advantage in fund raising as well this year. The New York State Republican Senate Campaign Committee, the chief funnel to G.O.P. candidates, has received about $1.2 million in contributions for this campaign, almost 10 times what the Democrats got.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, consumed with campaign work on behalf of the Clinton-Gore ticket and for the economic-development bond act that he proposed, had little time for specific campaigning for Democratic Senate candidates.
But Mr. Cuomo, angrily dismissing suggestions that he doesn't mind having the Republican-led Senate around as a whipping boy, urged voters in general to back Democratic candidates for the Senate.
With the Democrats in firm control of the Assembly, Mr. Cuomo and Democratic lawmakers repeatedly pledged that if the Democrats won the Senate, New Yorkers would quickly see passage of a range of legislation routinely blocked by the G.O.P.: stiffer environmental protections, a ban on assault weapons, changes in allocation of school aid and an overhaul of New York's infamously arcane election laws.
In the Assembly, while there were a handful of close races, and reapportionment virtually guaranteed the election of several new black and Hispanic lawmakers, there was virtually no suspense about the overall outcome: the Democrats, who now have a 95-to-55 edge and controlled redistricting in their house, all along were expected to maintain their overwhelming majority.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTION: NEW YORK STATE -- THE REGION'S VOTERS;
Finally, the Economy Was What Mattered Most

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
Mabel Gates calls herself a "registered Republican, life-long, family, forever." But when the moment of electoral truth came yesterday in a voting booth in White Plains, she cast tradition aside and voted for Gov. Bill Clinton.
"Bush and Reagan have had their chance, finito! I call it trickle-down poverty," said the 73-year-old retired physical-education teacher. 
Jeff Hearn, 30, also voted for change. "I spent my entire adult life living in the Reagan era," said the Brooklyn Heights computer consultant, who opted for a straight Democratic ticket. "All of my friends and acquaintances get worse and worse and worse off," he said. He was thinking particularly, he said, of three friends who had been forced to declare bankruptcy.
With anger and angst about the state of the nation, with fears that the country was growing ever more polarized, with last-minute qualms about whether a vote for Ross Perot was a gesture of useless protest, voters across the New York City region surged to the polls yesterday to take part in an election many viewed as a turning point for their country.
"I think it's a watershed election," said Brian Barrett, 49, waiting in line at the State Supreme Court building in downtown Brooklyn to support Governor Clinton. "I get the sense there's a generational change. There has to be a refocusing on what we think are the most important social issues, such things as abortion, public education, all the economic issues."
Turnout was heavy in the metropolitan region. Myriad issues ran through people's minds as they stood in unusually long lines to vote: health care, education, interest rates, abortion, foreign policy. But from Harlem to Brooklyn Heights, from leafy Westchester County suburbs to the old industrial city of Paterson, N.J., the economy was uppermost.
Christy Caridi, a comptroller from Manhattan's East Side, conceded that foreign policy was significant, but "that's not what matters now."
"The real global problem is the economy," she said, after voting at the Sutton Place Synagogue on East 51st Street, where people were waiting outside through drizzle and downpour. "We're not going to have World War III in the near future. We're going to have an economic war, and we need to learn how to fight it."
Her view was shared widely. In New York State and New Jersey, more than two-fifths of the voters selected the economy and jobs as one of the two most important issues that affected their voting decision, according to surveys of voters leaving the polls conducted yesterday by Voter Research and Surveys. And Mr. Clinton received more than half of those people's votes.
Time and again, people said they had been swayed by their personal financial situations.
"If Bush gets in again, I'm leaving the country," said Karen Shockness, 36, a social worker at P.S. 7 in East Harlem. "The economy is going down the tubes, especially for the poor and the middle income. I'm middle income, and I'm always living paycheck to paycheck. I've had my master's degree since 1980 from Temple University, and all I had to show for it is a damn piece of paper."
By contrast, 56-year-old Linda Lempit of White Plains voted for President Bush. She said she lives off investments, earning up to $100,000 annually. Of the President, she said, "It isn't that I like him so much, but I am afraid of Mr. Clinton. I'm afraid he has plans for higher taxes and for distribution of wealth to people that I don't want to distribute my wealth to." Only about a fifth of the voters in the three states said their financial situation was better than it was four years ago, and more than half of them voted for Mr. Bush.
Asked to describe the national economy, about half the voters in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut said it was not so good. And more than a third of the voters in the three states described economic conditions as poor.
 
Health Care Is No. 2
 Health care was the second most important issue on voters' minds in New York and New Jersey, selected by almost 3 in 10 of those asked as one of the two issues that mattered most. In New York, more than 7 in 10 of these voters cast their ballots for Mr. Clinton, as did more than 3 in 5 in New Jersey.
"Every time I go to the doctor his fees go up and so does the cost of medicines," said Blanche Kratz, 79, a retired saleswoman and registered Republican, who crossed party lines in Hacksensack, N.J., to support Governor Clinton.
The divisive abortion issue was cited as one of the most important by more than one in 10 voters asked in New York and New Jersey, with almost two-fifths of New York and New Jersey voters saying abortion should always be legal and 3 in 10 saying it should be legal in most cases.
Asked how she was voting, Diana Barrett, 32, held up a yellow campaign flier for Governor Clinton and the Democratic ticket. "I like the way he feels on abortion," said the Brooklyn Heights mother of three.
But for Louis Chanza, 53, of White Plains, it was Governor Clinton's support for the right to abortion that caused him to switch to Ross Perot. "I used to be a Democrat, but I do not like Mr. Clinton's position on abortion," he said. "It bothered me. I believe abortion is very wrong."
With a sense that somehow this year and this election were different, some voters agonized until the moment they stepped into the voting booth, pulled one way by an issue like the economy but another way by opposition to abortion, or else wondering whether they could really vote for Mr. Perot.
There were people like John Porter in White Plains who at age 32 had never cast a vote in a Presidential election. "There was just never anybody I wanted to vote for before," he said. But this time he voted -- for Ross Perot.
In Red Bank, N.J., Joan Krevsky, 39, also came very close to voting for Mr. Perot. But in the end, she flinched, saying she knew he couldn't be elected, and she wanted to avoid "business as usual." With her two pre-school sons in tow, she voted for Governor Clinton.
In Brooklyn, all weekend long, Steven Nitzberg, 31, of Cobble Hill, argued over the phone with a relative in the Midwest, trying to persuade him to vote for Governor Clinton. He thought he couldn't budge the man who called himself a "clothespin Republican, because he was going to hold his nose and vote for Mr. Bush."
But yesterday morning, Mr. Nitzberg received an unexpected call from his political sparring partner. "He said when he got into the voting booth he just couldn't do it," Mr. Nitzberg said. His relative voted for Governor Clinton and Republican all the way through the rest of the ticket.
Elsewhere in Brooklyn, John Garra, 64, paused on his way out of the State Supreme Court building yesterday morning and spoke ruefully of what the nation had become during 12 years of Republican rule.
"We've had a kind of selfish attitude: get what you can and to hell with the guy who's falling behind," said the retired social worker, who spends some of his days now teaching English to Russian immigrants in Brighton Beach. "I think we've got to change if we're going to be one nation. We've got to come together as one people. If we don't, we will have riots in Los Angeles and New York. It's inevitable."
