HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
Trade negotiators failed to break the impasse over farm subsidies, and no new talks are scheduled. The United States Agriculture Secretary, Edward R. Madigan, said he would recommend to President Bush that the United States impose prohibitive duties on certain European goods. The European Community is likely to retaliate. [Page D1.]
OPEC's crude oil output rose in October to 25.15 million barrels a day, a 12-year high, according to a Reuters survey. [D7.]
 
The Economy
The Government's index of leading indicators fell three-tenths of 1 percent in September to produce the first back-to-back declines since 1991. The monthly Commerce Department report offered more evidence that the economic expansion is likely to remain feeble in coming months. [D1.] 
 The climate is warming for small businesses in America. While the nation's economy limps along, there are signs that the worst may be over for the small-business sector. This is the first step in the economic food chain of job creation. [D1.]
 
Companies
Caldor made a bid to acquire and reopen 6 of 11 Alexander's department stores in the New York metropolitan area. The offer puts Caldor in competition with Bradlees Inc., another leading discount chain. The bid follows a remarkable rise in the price of Alexander's since it declared bankruptcy in May. [D1.]
Travelers had a loss of $358 million, which was higher than expected, in its third quarter. The big insurer said it would cut an additional 1,500 jobs as part of a restructuring that would reduce the work force by 5,000. [D4.]
CalFed reported a loss of $42.2 million in the third quarter and announced a restructuring deal with bondholders that would allow it to forgo a $158 million debt payment. [D4.]
Air Canada scrapped a merger with Canadian Airlines, ending a proposed deal that would have created a national airline monopoly. Air Canada's board objected to details in the plan. [D4.]
A defunct Kaiser Steel steel mill will be broken down and shipped to China for reassembly, 20-story building and all. [D4.]
Fukutake Publishing of Japan asked to renegotiate its deal to merge with Berlitz International because of weak financial results at the language service business. [D5.]
Jack W. Simpson resigned unexpectedly as president of Mead Data Central Inc., a leader in electronic publishing. [D5.]
Pearl Stewart was named editor of The Oakland Tribune by the newspaper's new owner, the Alameda Newspaper Group. [D20.]
Hachette is acquiring Metropolitan Home magazine from Meredith. No terms of the deal were disclosed. [D20.]
 
Markets
The Treasury will sell $11.25 billion in current 10-year notes next week to eliminate a serious shortage of the security. The Treasury has never before used its authority to sell additional securities of an issue to combat shortages. [D1.] Yields were mixed on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit. [D17.]

Cotton futures prices surged after the American agricultural attache lowered his estimate of China's cotton crop. [D17.] The dollar fell overseas and ended mixed in domestic trading. [D17.]

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTION: NEW YORK STATE;
Voters Reject $800 Million Plan For Projects in New York State

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

 BODY:
Showing that they were more concerned about the state's already-high level of debt than its high unemployment, New Yorkers yesterday rejected Proposal One, which asked them to give the state permission to issue $800 million worth of bonds to finance public works projects.
With the votes of 68 percent of the state's precincts counted, 54 percent voted against the bond issue, dealing a blow to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. 
 The bond issue was the centerpiece of the Governor's program to stimulate the depressed economy of the state, which has lost some 550,000 jobs since June 1989. The $800 million would have been spent on projects like sewage and water systems, roads, sidewalks, ports and waterfront revitalization, business parks, and parking garages.
The proposal had the backing of the State Legislature, labor groups and several large business organizations. The state alone spent $150,000 to $200,000 distributing information on the proposal, which some critics charged was an illegal use of state funds for promotional purposes.
Mr. Cuomo contended that the bond issue would more than pay for itself by generating economic activity that would produce $2 in taxes for every $1 borrowed and invested. His experts estimated the total cost of the bond issue, including interest, would be $1.7 billion over 25 years.
At 12:30 A.M. today, Mr. Cuomo still had made no comment.
Opponents of the bond issue included conservative organizations advocating a smaller, more efficient government; rural groups generally opposed to state borrowing; environmentalists who argued the projects would harm wetlands and would increase road travel, and Edward V. Regan, the state Comptroller.
Brian Backstrom, vice president of research for Change-NY, a conservative group advocating cuts in taxes and regulation, called the defeat of the bond issue a "rebuke of the Governor's tax-and-spend policies." He added: "Obviously more debt is not the answer to creating jobs."
Mr. Regan tried to use the bond issue to increase pressure on the state to reform the way it borrows money. Specifically, Mr. Regan wants to increase the right of voters to authorize state borrowing, to subject borrowing legislation to greater public scrutiny, and to end the practice of using government authorities to borrow money for things that have nothing to do with them.
In a statement issued at midday, before the result of the vote could be known, Mr. Regan said that whether the bond proposal passed or failed, his campaign had "achieved the desired result." He added: "There is now widespread public attention and support for fiscal reform among political candidates, business and civic groups and individual taxpayers."
As the defeat of the bond proposal began to look likely last night, the Comptroller's press secretary, Marvin G. Nailor, said: "Our position is this is an additional message" for the Governor and Legislature to enact reforms. During the campaign, Mr. Cuomo stressed that he backed many of Mr. Regan's proposals.
Unwilling to comment on a political issue and noting that they had been given little time to study the projects, credit-rating agencies had declined to say whether passage of the $800 million might result in a lowering of the state's rating. Depending on the agency, New York's rating is the lowest or one of the lowest among the 50 states. The reasons are the state's high spending, its tax-supported debt of $24.29 billion, combined with pessimism about the near-term outlook for the state economy, and, as a result, for state revenues.
Economic-development experts in the Cuomo administration had predicted that the spending program would reach at least $1.27 billion when mandatory contributions from local governments were added to the $800 million from the bond issue, and that it would quickly create nearly 35,000 temporary construction-related jobs and, over the long term, would result in more than 122,000 permanent private-sector jobs.
 
Projects Throughout Region
 Local governments had requested more than $2.5 billion for more than 1,000 projects. On Oct. 23, Governor Cuomo and state Legislature leaders chose about 390 projects to receive $558 million of the $800 million.
The defeated bond issue had included nearly $234 million for 70 projects in New York City; $85.1 million for 58 projects in Nassau and Suffolk counties; $26.3 million for 24 in Westchester County and $7.6 million for six in Rockland County.
The larger projects that had been planned for New York City included $18.8 million for Battery Park and the South Street Seaport; $11 million for work on Brooklyn piers for a mixed-used development; $10.4 million for expanding the Hunt's Point Market in the Bronx; $9.2 million for the reconstruction of Main Street and a new parking garage at Flushing Center in Queens, and $8 million for reconstruction of the Brooklyn Navy Yard.
In Nassau and Suffolk, the bond issue would have allocated $8.6 million for a wastewater-treatment plant in Glen Cove; $6.5 million for Wyandanch for sewers and for revitalizing its commercial district, and $5.9 million for converting Roosevelt Raceway to commercial uses. Among the Westchester projects in the proposal were $6 million for Mount Vernon for preparing a site for commercial or light industrial use and for parking and $2.5 million for parking in Ossining.

HEADLINE: Talks Fail; Trade War Is Feared

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Nov. 3

 BODY:
American and European negotiators failed to achieve a breakthrough tonight on an impasse over farm subsidies that has blocked world trade talks, making a trans-Atlantic trade war likely within days.
Agriculture Secretary Edward R. Madigan said he would recommend that President Bush impose prohibitive duties on certain European exports. The European Community is likely to retaliate against American exports. 
 The election of Gov. Bill Clinton makes retaliation even more likely because world trade talks will probably be interrupted for months as Mr. Clinton picks new trade officials and reviews current American negotiating positions.
Ray MacSharry, the European Community's Agriculture Commissioner, said the American side had asked for excessive reductions in subsidized European grain exports and subsidized production of soybeans and other oilseeds. "The demands," he said, "were too much." No further meetings are scheduled, Mr. MacSharry said.
 
The 'High Ground'
 Mr. Madigan said the European Community had refused to take account of reports by two international arbitration panels, which concluded that European oilseed subsidies violate international free trade rules. "We believe that we have the moral high ground, the legal high ground and the intellectual high ground," he said.
Mr. Madigan also said that he and Mr. MacSharry had made some progress today but that Mr. MacSharry had to leave because of appointments on Wednesday in Brussels. Mr. Madigan said that he was willing to hold further talks but that he did not believe the United States had to delay its retaliation.
Steve M. Yoder, president of the American Soybean Association, called for immediate penalties on European exports. "The United States has very little option except to retaliate," he said.
The prohibitive tariffs are likely to fall first on alcoholic beverages from France but may be extended to include wines from the rest of Europe, cut flowers, industrial products and even snails. Wine importers have lobbied heavily against the imposition of punitive import duties.
On June 9, Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, released a list of $2 billion worth of European farm exports and threatened to impose punitive duties on half the list if the oilseeds issue was not resolved. At a White House meeting on Oct. 22, Mrs. Hills, Mr. Madigan and the Acting Secretary of State, Lawrence S. Eagleburger agreed that tariffs would initially be imposed on up to $350 million worth of goods and eventually on up to $1 billion.
Mr. Madigan said the United States would review whether to prepare a supplemental list of exports that would be punished. American officials say the list could include industrial products because Germany has been the main obstacle to an oilseed agreement and Germany exports mostly industrial goods to the United States rather than farm goods.
The dispute about the oilseeds, used as animal-feed supplements and cooking oil, was the most important of the farm subsidy issues that have blocked an agreement in world trade talks for the last two years, European and American officials said today.
European officials had offered to reduce their oilseed acreage, but the Americans wanted a binding commitment that actual production of oilseeds would also fall.
Mr. MacSharry organized a plan last May for reducing European subsidies through cuts in acreage and he criticized the United States tonight for refusing to negotiate on the basis on those cuts.
John S. Gummer, Britain's Farm Minister, flew to Chicago Monday night and conferred with European Community negotiators here.
Prime Minister John Major of Britain insisted on the current round of negotiations and appeared to have the most at stake. The British Parliament is scheduled to vote Wednesday on whether to approve the Maastricht agreement, which is intended to stimulate trade in Europe by creating a single European currency and by eliminating differences in social and economic policies among European Community members.
Political analysts in London have speculated that Mr. Major could be replaced as Prime Minister or could be forced to call general elections if he fails to get his fractious Conservative Party to support the Maastricht pact. Trade frictions with the United States could undermine support in Britain for the pact.
Among the 12 European Community nations, the main opponent of a trade pact has been France.
France is Europe's leading grain exporter, and has steadfastly resisted American demands that the European Community's tonnage of subsidized grain exports be reduced by 24 percent within six or seven years.
A European diplomat who insisted on anonymity said France had little direct interest in the oilseed issue, because Germany is the leading producer of oilseeds. But if Germany had received what it views as an acceptable deal on oilseeds, then it would have put pressure on France to accept limits on grain export subsidies, making an overall deal possible, the diplomat said.

HEADLINE: Economic Indicators Drop by 0.3%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3

 BODY:
The predictive index designed by the Government to plot the economy fell three-tenths of 1 percent in September to produce the first back-to-back declines since 1991, the Commerce Department reported today.
The report offered more evidence that despite some scattered hopeful signs, the economic expansion is likely to remain feeble in coming months, analysts said. 
 "Where we're likely to go is sideways," said Richard D. C. Trainer, chief economist for the Bank of Tokyo in New York. "The economy is still very, very sluggish."
 
G.D.P. Data Questioned
 Relatively few economists expect fourth-quarter growth to match the 2.7 percent pace reported last week for the July-September period, a figure buoyed by consumer spending that was faster than incomes can sustain and by an increase in military spending that was at odds with a well-established trend.
Robert Parker, an associate director of the Commerce Department unit that assembles the figures for gross domestic product, defended the report today after making further investigations of the military and farm components that have come into question.
He said that there had been a $1.1 billion replenishment of a separation-pay fund depleted by the Persian Gulf war but that this had no effect on the G.D.P. results. And he found "nothing peculiar" in another rise in farm inventories, noting that hurricane damage was mostly confined to limes and other fruits that are not stored.
The decline in the index of leading indicators, the third in the last four months after five straight increases, was slightly worse than had been expected but had no discernible effect on prevailing sentiment.
"The economy is weak and will stay weak for the near future," said William C. Dunkelberg, chief economist for the National Federation of Independent Business. "We will continue to downsize, right-size, rationalize and fantasize as we prepare for the next period of stronger growth."
 
Quarterly Results
 For the entire summer quarter, the predictive index edged down one-tenth of 1 percent after gains of 1.1 percent in the spring and 1.6 percent last winter.
Six of 11 components contributed to the September decline, the largest being lower prices for materials that are particularly sensitive to the business cycle and a shorter average workweek.
The other negatives were a decline in backlogs for manufacturers of durable goods, higher first-time claims for unemployment insurance, falling consumer expectations and lower contracts and orders for plant and equipment.
The five rising components were paced by a jump in building permits, followed by slower deliveries by vendors, higher new orders for manufactured consumer goods and advances in the M-2 money supply and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.
The Commerce Department's companion indexes of coincident and lagging indicators also fell three-tenths of 1 percent last month. This was the second straight decline for the coincident index, which would have fallen eight-tenths of 1 percent without the effects of Hurricanes Andrew and Iniki on personal income and on industrial production.
 
Widespread Revisions
 The decline in the lagging index was the 19th in the last 20 months, the exception being the rise of two-tenths of 1 percent for August that was revised from a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent.
Today's report included revisions of all three indexes from January 1987 through August 1992. For the leading index, 53 of the 68 monthly changes were no more than one-tenth of a point. The biggest was five-tenths of a point, chopping a June 1991 gain to one-tenth of 1 percent from six-tenths of 1 percent.
The department also said the weekly jobless claims component had been redefined to include claims made under the emergency unemployment amendments enacted in July.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: CONNECTICUT -- THE CONNECTICUT LEGISLATURE;
Aided by Vote for Clinton, Democrats Retain Control

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Nov. 3

 BODY:
Connecticut Democrats, aided by a large turnout for Gov. Bill Clinton in the Presidential race, retained control of the State Legislature tonight.
Unofficial counts by both parties had the Democrats winning at least 83 seats in the 151-member House, with 3 more seats claimed by Democrats but close enough to require recounts. The Republicans took 65 seats. Democrats won 20 seats in the 36-member Senate to 16 for the Republicans, according to unofficial counts by both parties. 
 Those tallies leave the legislature, known as the General Assembly, all but unchanged in party composition despite a huge turnover of retiring lawmakers and a backdrop of political turmoil over taxes and the recession. Before the election, the Democrats had a 20-to-16 majority in the Senate and an 88-to-63 majority in the House.
 
The Difference a Year Makes
 Only a year ago, Republicans had flatly predicted a sweep that would give them majorities in one or both chambers. Voters were outraged then by the imposition of a state income tax passed in August 1991 by a Democratic-led coalition. But candidates and poll takers said that anger over the income tax cooled during the last six months, dismaying the Republicans who had expected to ride the issue to victory.
In the few races in which Republican candidates campaigned to repeal the income tax, Democrats were returned to office anyway. And at least one hard-line income tax opponent lost his bid for re-election. The former Speaker of the House of Representatives, Richard J. Balducci, a Democrat from Newington and a major proponent of the tax, made the jump from House to Senate, winning a vacant seat.
In a heavy turnout, Connecticut voters also overwhelmingly approved a measure pushed by the state's biggest business organizations, but opposed by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., that could lead to an amendment to the State Constitution limiting the annual growth of state spending. With 76 percent of the precincts reporting, 81 percent of voters had said yes, with 19 percent voting no.
 
Democrats' Confidence
 The Democrats had been confident of retaining the House going into to day's voting, but their hopes for retaining the Senate had slipped recent ly as some districts appeared to swing toward the Republicans.
In the House, in one closely watched race, Representative Reginald L. Jones, a Republican from Darien, defeated Sally Bolster, a Republican running as a Democrat but with Governor Weicker's blessing and thousands of dollars in donations from his independent party. Four Democratic incumbents in the House were defeated and three Republican incumbents lost their seats.
The state Republican Party chairman, Richard Foley Jr., said he felt that his party had done well to hold its own in a year that saw a strong state majority for Mr. Clinton and for United States Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Democrat who won a third term. "They swam against a strong tide," Mr. Foley said of Connecticut's Republicans.
 
2 Variables
 For both Democrats and Republicans, two variables shaped this election. The first was the scramble to fill an unusually large number of seats vacated by lawmakers seeking higher office or retiring. The second was the impact of cross-endorsements by Mr. Weicker's third party, called A Connecticut Party.
In the Senate, 10 of 36 seats were open and up for grabs. Seven of those had been vacated by Democrats and three by Republicans. In the House, incumbents did not seek re-election in 48 of the 151 seats. The seats had been occupied by 28 Democrats and 20 Republicans.
The effects of Mr. Weicker's cross-endorsements were not immediately clear. Cross-endorsed candidates appeared twice on the ballot, once on their own party line and once on the Connecticut Party line. In tallying votes tonight, however, election officials combined the two totals.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: CONNECTICUT -- U.S. SENATE RACE;
Gejdenson Claims Victory, but Recount Is Sought

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 3

 BODY:
Senator Christopher J. Dodd won a third term today, easily defeating Brook Johnson, a Republican businessman who spent millions of his own money trying to make Mr. Dodd's long tenure in Washington an issue.
Mr. Dodd, a Democrat first elected to Congress in 1974 as a member of the House representing eastern Connecticut, had 59 percent of the vote today, to Mr. Johnson's 38 percent, with 53 percent of the state's precincts reporting. 
 Mr. Dodd, who is 48 years old, in a sense ran toward incumbency, rather than away from it, unlike many national and local candidates. He focused on Connecticut's struggling economy, arguing that his experience and contacts in Washington would help him protect military contractors in a state that is among the most heavily dependent on military spending.
He held up his advocacy of child-care and family-leave legislation and his support for expanded Federal aid for middle-class college students as help for hard-pressed families.
 
Resorting to Negativity
 Surveys of voters leaving the polls showed Mr. Dodd running strongly among the 86 percent of voters who said the national economy was poor or not good, and he outpolled Mr. Johnson by a ratio of 2 to 1 among the 13 percent of voters who said they had not voted in the last Presidential election.
"This election was not about the candidates on the ballot," Mr. Dodd told a crowd of screaming supporters in the Sheraton Hotel in downtown Hartford at 9:30 tonight, after Mr. Johnson called him to concede. "This election was about the American people and the people of our state trying to get our economy moving and putting people back to work in America."
Facing a well-financed opponent, however, Mr. Dodd also resorted to negative television and radio advertisements for the first time, portraying Mr. Johnson, a textiles executive new to politics, as a millionaire carpetbagger who shipped jobs overseas and paid himself royally at his employees' expense. Mr. Dodd spent nearly $3.5 million, and Mr. Johnson $2.5 million.
Mr. Johnson, a 46-year-old Greenwich resident, was unknown in Connecticut in May when he announced his entry into the Republican contest to oppose Mr. Dodd, whose popularity had appeared to be eroding in polls taken in 1991.
He won the Republican primary in September after advertising heavily on television, spending mainly his own money. He then continued to rely on television and radio to spread his main message: that the Federal deficit was caused by free-spending career politicians beholden to special interests.
 
A Vow to Stay
 It was time, he told voters, to replace Connecticut's premier career politician, Mr. Dodd, with someone with business experience and business sense. He promised to vote for a Constitutional amendment requiring balanced budgets, a cap on the rate of growth in Federal spending, and term limits for Congress.
"We didn't lose, we just started," Mr. Johnson told supporters tonight in his Cos Cob headquarters, above a supermarket on Route 1. "If you can get that much of the vote in five months, think of what I can do when I get a little more time and a little more money."
He vowed to stay in politics and to help rebuild the Republican Party in Connecticut, and hinted he might consider running for either Governor or the seat of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman.
"All this country talks about is change and difficulty," he said, "but the country doesn't understand we need change in Congress and the Senate."
In this campaign's competing appeals to the negative stereotypes of politicians and businessmen, however, Mr. Dodd had the great advantage of being well known.
The Republican's portrayal of Mr. Dodd as a Washington fatcat doing nothing for his own state ran into the Senator's highly publicized success in saving a Seawolf submarine contract and thousands of defense jobs at Electric Boat in Groton -- an effort for which Mr. Johnson complimented him.
Against Mr. Johnson's charges that he was a big spender, Mr. Dodd offered his record of support for several deficit-fighting measures, as well as his lonely votes against the Reagan Administration's 1981 and 1986 tax cuts, which he had predicted would lead to huge Federal deficits.
Mr. Johnson, in contrast, had never participated in politics, and most of his business experience had been with a textiles maker, Collins & Aikman, based in Tennessee. He refused to discuss his own company, C. S. Brooks, a bath furnishings manufacturer that he had taken private in a leveraged buyout in the 1980's.
So when Mr. Dodd's advertisements began questioning Mr. Johnson's business record and commitment to Connecticut, they were often the first information anyone had had about Mr. Johnson's business. He immediately was put on the defensive.
One of the most devastating commercials pointed out that Mr. Johnson had never created a manufacturing job in Connecticut (C. S. Brooks had no plants in the state), and that he had sold an American plant and invested in ones in Canada.
Mr. Johnson, in his best moments, presented himself as a plain citizen willing to go to Washington, do his duty in helping to straighten out the nation's financial mess, and return home. By spending his own money on his campaign, he said, he would go to Washington "with no strings attached."
But Mr. Dodd's victory may also have demonstrated the value that voters place on the arena of politics, and on the skills of an experienced politician. Far from offering any apology for being a career politician, he argued that his experience and growing seniority in Washington would serve Connecticut well.
According to exit polls today, a majority of voters considered government experience more important than business experience in choosing a Senator, and even among those who favored business experience, Mr. Dodd trailed Mr. Johnson by only 44 percent to 56 percent.
Mr. Johnson, in the last days of the campaign, appeared frustrated by the effect of Mr. Dodd's attacks, which he said distorted his background. "They don't want to talk about the issues," he said. "They don't want to talk about how the country is spending itself into its grave."
But he also talked about another campaign in the future. Sounding like a businessman again, he said: "I'm not going to change the arena. I'm either going to become a good player in it, or I'm not going to be in it."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTION: CONNECTICUT -- U.S. HOUSE RACES;
Incumbents Stave Off Rivals Amid Economic Concerns

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Wednesday,Nov. 4

 BODY:
Defying a wave of anti-incumbency that many in Congress had feared, all six of Connecticut's United States Representatives appeared to have won on Tuesday.
In the Second District, which covers most of eastern Connecticut, the six-term incumbent Democrat, Sam Gejdenson, appeared to have squeezed out a narrow victory over Edward Munster, a Republican State Senator from Haddam. With 86 percent of the vote counted, Mr. Gejdenson appeared to have won, but his opponent refused to concede, saying, "This is no mandate." Early this morning Mr. Gejdenson declared victory, but Mr. Munster said he was entitled to a recount. 
 The incumbents who were re-elected included Barbara B. Kennelly, a five-term Democrat from the First District, centered in Hartford, and Nancy L. Johnson, a Republican who has served as long in the Sixth District, in the state's northwest corner.
In the Third District, a rematch between Rosa DeLauro, the incumbent Democrat, and her Republican challenger, Tom Scott, saw Ms. DeLauro win by 2 to 1. In the Fourth District, dominated by Fairfield County, the Republican incumbent, Christopher Shays, handily defeated a pair of challengers, David Schropfer, a Democrat, and an independent candidate, Al Smith.
In the Fifth District, Gary Franks, a freshman who is the only black Republican in Congress, eked out a victory over a pair of challengers, Lynn Taborsak and Jim Lawlor.
 
Keeping in Touch
 Problems at home, particularly unemployment with at least 185,000 jobs lost since 1989, and perceived problems in Washington, including the House banking scandal and a sense that members of Congress had lost touch with their constituents, influenced voters in House races across Connecticut. In some cases, that may have worked against incumbents; in others, it kept challengers at bay because voters questioned their qualifications.
Leaving a polling place at a high school in Milford, Elizabeth Cappello said she had voted for Ms. DeLauro because "she did very well in her last term, and I like everything she stands for."
Other voters felt that controlling spending and the threat of additional taxes meant that they should support Tom Scott, Ms. DeLauro's Republican opponent. "I know he's against the state income tax and so am I," said Debbie Perillo. "I think he looks out for those of us in the middle class and he'll work for us."
In the Second District, which covers most of eastern Connecticut, many voters interviewed seemed simply to want a change from Mr. Gejdenson.
Bruce Jablonski, a machinist at the Electric Boat shipyard in Groton, said he was angry with Mr. Gejdenson for voting to support a recent Congressional pay raise, when many people, like himself, are worried about layoffs. "I think he cares more about himself than about anyone else," Mr. Jablonski said, after voting for Mr. Munster.
 
'Clear the Incumbents Out'
 There were also people who could not decide how to express their anger, and left that space on the voting machine untouched. "I felt I could not support either of them," said Amy Kennedy, who stood in the rain waiting to vote in Norwich, part of the Second District. She added: "But I would like to see Gejdenson voted out. I'd like to clear the incumbents out of Congress."
Voter turnout was also high, reflecting widespread dissatisfaction with the status quo. "I've never seen anything like this," said George Hajjar, an election worker at the polls at John F. Kennedy High School in Waterbury, where 3,000 of 4,200 registered voters in the city's largest district had voted by 6 P.M. Another 500 were expected by the time the polls closed at 8 P.M., Mr. Hajjar said.
Mr. Lawlor, who won the state Democratic primary in September, continued to be challenged throughout the fall by Ms. Taborsak, who kept on as an independent despite her defeat in the primary. Mr. Lawlor, who conceded defeat about 9:45 P.M., declined to blame Ms. Taborsak entirely for his poor showing but said, "Taborsak had to be a factor." Ms. Taborsak contended that a two-way race in the district would have meant "no choice for a lot of people" and said last night that had Mr. Lawlor not been opposed to abortion, she would have gladly dropped out of the race after the primary.

HEADLINE: Credit Markets;
Treasury to Expand Offering To Stem Shortage of Note

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The Treasury announced yesterday that it would sell $11.25 billion in current 10-year notes next week in an effort to eliminate a serious shortage of the security.
This is the first time the Treasury has used its authority to sell additional securities of the same issue to combat such a shortage, which has sharply driven up the cost for trading in the 10-year note that was auctioned last August and could disrupt the market. 
 In response to the scandal involving Salomon Brothers in the summer of 1991, the Treasury announced in January that it would use this authority when there were severe shortages. The goal was to discourage illegal manipulations of the Treasury market and to help the market function more smoothly when there was a natural shortage.
In the Salomon case, the firm admitted to illegal bidding violations in the Treasury auction to gain control of a particular issue. In addition, investigations are continuing on whether there was any collusion among large dealers to control some securities and force a squeeze, or shortage, that would force some investors and dealers to pay much more than they should for those securities.
The Treasury said yesterday that there was no indication that any improper squeeze was currently taking place.
"We have no indication of any wrongdoing," said Jerome H. Powell, Treasury Under Secretary for Finance. He said the Treasury had decided to issue more of the 10-year notes because "there was an acute and protracted shortage" and that the reopening of the 10-year note first auctioned in August would "contribute to the smooth functioning of the marketplace."
The decision on the 10-year note follows close monitoring of the issue by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
 
A Popular Hedge
 Traders said that one big reason for the shortage was that the 10-year note was in great demand for hedging against losses by dealers who were buying up the recent flood of corporate and other bonds.
Because this is the first use of the Treasury's policy, dealers and investors now have some guidelines on when the Treasury will act. Mr. Powell said one gauge of an acute shortage was the number of instances in which a dealer who had sold the 10-year note could not actually deliver them because they were not available. He said this was the case in a significant number of transactions.
Another measure is demand for this issue in the market in which one investor borrows securities from another. In this market, called the repurchase, or repo, market, one investor borrows the securities. In exchange, he gives the lender cash. The lender usually pays an interest rate close to the current Federal funds rate. The usually small differences between the two give the lender his profit.
But when there is intense demand, the borrower pays a premium by giving the money to the lender at an interest rate well below the current market rate, giving the lender large profits. In the case of the 10-year note, traders said, the interest rate has not been far above zero for several weeks.
The Treasury, in official terms, will reopen the issue of the 6.375 percent 10-year note that is due in August 2002 and sell more with the same coupon and maturity. In this way, the supply of this issue will be increased and that may satisfy the demand and end the shortage. The tax status of the issue will be the same as if the note were bought in the secondary market, the Treasury said.
 
'Facilitating the Industry'
 There are certain to be traders who consider the Treasury's move to be meddling in the market. But several traders and analysts greeted the move positively, saying they were forewarned. "It is almost like facilitating the industry," said Terrence Crowe, a vice president at Nikko Securities Inc.
Acknowledging that some traders might be angry, Louis Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates, said: "It is choosing sides but that is inevitable. Any decision the Treasury makes will help those who bet right and hurt those who bet wrong."
In an analysis last week, Wrightson said that the shortage of the 10-year note was not that severe, falling "between the extreme squeezes that have caused concern in the past and business as usual."
The Treasury decision was announced as part of the regular briefing on the details of the Government's quarterly auction of securities, which is next week. In total, $37 billion in notes and bonds will be auctioned, including $15.5 billion in 3-year notes on Monday; $11.25 billion of the existing 10-year note, which will now be a 9 3/4-year note, on Tuesday, and $10.25 billion of 30-year bonds on Thursday.
The new supply from the auction next week is one reason the market has been nervous and falling lately.
But the news on the reopening of the 10-year note seemed to be favorably greeted because the price of the note finished up 6/32 on the day to yield 6.85 percent, down from 6.87 percent on Monday.
The Treasury also said that its authority for borrowing under the current Federal debt ceiling of $4.145 trillion, will run out in March.
 
Treasury Market
 Bond and note prices were up in the morning than faded some in the afternoon. While the trading was brisker than expected for an Election Day, there was no real trend, traders said. In late secondary trading, the 30-year bond was offered at 9510/32 , up 3/32 , to yield 7.65 percent, unchanged from Monday.
The price of notes was up moderately while yields fell. In the pre-auction, or when-issued, market for next week's Treasury auction, the 30-year bond closed at a yield of 7.63 percent; the reopened 10-year note, which will be a 9 3/4-year note, was at 6.90 percent and the 3-year note ended at 5.05 percent.

HEADLINE: Caldor Bids for Alexander's Stores

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
The Caldor Corporation, a big discount retailer in the Northeast, made a bid yesterday to acquire and reopen 6 of 11 Alexander's department stores in the New York metropolitan area. The bid competes with one by Bradlees Inc., another discount chain, for the properties of the 64-year-old bankrupt retailer.
The size of the Caldor bid was not disclosed in short statements by Caldor and Alexander's Inc. issued after 5 P.M. yesterday. But Alexander's said that the new bid would exceed the Bradlees bid by about $5 million in "present value," as required last month of any future bidder by the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, which is supervising Alexander's affairs. 
 When Bradlees made its bid in September, it said it would spent $82 million to buy or take over the leases of two Alexander's stores in the Bronx, two in Queens, one in Valley Stream, L.I., and one in Yonkers. Executives of Caldor and Alexander's would not comment on yesterday's bid, and a call after business hours to Bradlees headquarters in Braintree, Mass., was not answered.
 
A Remarkable Rise
 Yesterday's proposed transaction follows a remarkable rise in the price of Alexander's stock since it declared bankruptcy in May and closed all of its stores. Its shares have risen almost two and a half times in value in less than six months and are up more than 15 percent in the last month alone. Yesterday, they slipped 75 cents, closing at $31.875 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Some analysts believe that the price will go substantially higher. "I'm assuming that Alexander's can generate cash flow after expenses of $3 to $4 a share," said Samuel Lieber, portfolio manager of the Evergreen Global Real Estate Equity Fund in Purchase, N.Y. "If they create a real estate investment trust out of it, I think we will see a share price of $50 to $60 within 18 months."
Others, particularly those who have sold the stock short, expect a sharp drop in the price of Alexander's once it emerges from bankruptcy, most likely as a real estate company.
After Alexander's presents a debt reorganization plan to the court, "I think the price will plummet," said Michael Murphy, editor of the Overpriced Stock Service in Half Moon Bay, Calif. "The maximum the stock is worth is $20, and I think it will go down to $12."
Alexander's filed for Chapter 11 protection from its creditors on May 15 amid weak sales, intense competition from suburban malls and the recession. Its retail operations have been unprofitable since 1987.
Alexander's made its deal with Bradlees in September, but Caldor, based in Norwalk, Conn., expressed an interest in the same properties within weeks. Bankruptcy Judge Cornelius Blackshear had set a deadline of yesterday for new bids and will select a winner by Nov. 12.
"Alexander's is in a position of strength because it has already done a deal for its least attractive properties," Mr. Lieber said, alluding to the offers from Caldor and Bradlees. Fund and other entities under his control own 6 percent of the company's stock. He added that the other Alexander's properties, like the flagship store on Lexington Avenue in Manhattan and a store in Paramus, N.J., were much better values for other discounters like warehouse stores or home centers.
On the other hand, Allan Roness, a managing director of Fahnestock & Company, a securities concern, called the stock "fully priced at 30." Development of the Manhattan and Paramus properties "is not going to happen tomorrow," he said.
"Why did the stock go up,?" he asked. "I think the shorts are squeezed a little bit."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Legal Strategy Ends in Dismissal

BYLINE: By Kurt Eichenwald

 BODY:
PUBLIC disclosure is a funny thing. While publicly traded companies must inform investors of some plans that might affect earnings, they need not disclose when the strategies are farfetched.
Consider Lifschultz Industries, a New York conglomerate that for five years has been trumpeting a single note in its investment symphony: a $1.8 billion lawsuit pending against three large trucking companies. The suit charged that the group had conspired over 25 years through bribery, fraud and other criminal activities to push Lifschultz out of the trucking business. Company executives hoped the litigation against the Consolidated Freightways Corporation, Yellow Freight System Inc. and Roadway Express Inc. would bring a windfall to holders of Lifschultz stock. 
 The stock's story gained an air of plausibility from myriad celebrities, living and dead, who were somehow connected to the case. The roster of well-known figures -- ranging from Donald Trump to Robert Bork to Jimmy Hoffa -- who played one role or another in the Lifschultz saga gave the company's story the breathless feel of a dime-store detective novel.
Too much so, in fact. Buried among years of hoopla from the company about the litigation was one serious problem: Lifschultz's evidence was painfully thin.
The company offered two witnesses with Mafia ties who testified that Hoffa, the former head of the teamsters' union, had devised the conspiracy to consolidate the trucking industry into a few large unionized carriers. The company also presented an economic analysis it had paid for that was said to detail predatory pricing. And that was the whole case.
So while it made an interesting tale, the Lifschultz lawsuit amounted to little. Last Friday, Federal District Judge Henry M. Herlong, who has been hearing the case in Greenville, S.C., dismissed the suit on a summary judgment motion from the defendants. The reason? Lifschultz did not have enough evidence to convince a rational jury that the defendants had done anything wrong.
"The conspiracy as alleged by Lifschultz is of monstrous proportions," Judge Herlong wrote. Yet "Lifschultz has been unable to product plausible evidence that supports its allegations."
Judge Herlong went on to play down the significance of Lifschultz's analysis of pricing, saying "for the most part, the report is merely a series of unsupported speculations."
This slamming of the company's case has not deterred Lifschultz, which plans to appeal. "I don't believe the judge even read our economic data," said David Lifschultz, chairman.
Investors who were looking to make a play on the Lifschultz litigation would have been hard pressed over the years to find any indication -- outside of the legal filings -- that the case the company was pressing was so weak that it would never even get to a jury. Indeed, throughout the years, Lifschultz would make new disclosures every now and then that may have raised new hope for the sagging lawsuit.
For example, in 1991, Mr. Lifschultz said the company had a deal with Mr. Trump, the developer who owned the land beneath the Lifschultz headquarters in Manhattan. Under the deal, Mr. Trump would take 10 percent of the company in exchange for allowing Lifschultz to sublease the property, a move that would generate revenue for the legal case. Essentially, the agreement allowed Mr. Trump to keep getting his rent while also receiving a free chance to ride the lawsuit.
The deal was proclaimed as evidence of the case's strength. In a news report at the time, Mr. Lifschultz was quoted as saying Mr. Trump would help to influence the defendants to settle -- a statement that surely gave investors comfort. Yesterday, Mr. Lifschultz said he had been misquoted.
Yet Mr. Lifschultz said he had never felt compelled to tell his investors that they might have been misinformed. "I didn't even think about that," he said yesterday. "Nobody advised me I had to do that."
The case gained renewed credibility in June when Lifschultz added Mr. Bork, the unsuccessful nominee for the Supreme Court, and Thomas Puccio, the former special prosecutor for the Abscam bribery case, to its legal team. But naming the two high-profile lawyers almost five years after the case began came far too late.
Even as upbeat news came from the Lifschultz camp, other developments were not played up for investors. A number of investors, including the company's own president and a corporation that was one of the largest holders of its stock, were filing reports to sell the Lifschultz shares -- at a time when the case had not even gone to trial. The stock lost a third of its value yesterday, closing at 6.25 cents a share, down 3.125 cents, in over-the-counter trading.
In the end, few people tied to Lifschultz believe that the quixotic fight will end, although no one is holding their breath for success. "I think David Lifschultz has a lot of moxie and a lot of energy," Mr. Trump said yesterday. "But obviously he didn't have a lot of case."

HEADLINE: Stocks Off a Bit, With the Dow Falling 9.73

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Stock prices fell modestly yesterday after traders deployed computerized sell programs in an Election Day session that was otherwise uneventful.
The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which jumped 35.93 points in the previous session, closed down 9.73 points, to 3,252.48. 
 Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 9 to 8 on the New York Stock Exchange. Big Board volume was active, with 208.1 million shares changing hands, up from 203.3 million in the previous session.
The market's decline came a day after a rally based in part on analysts' speculation that a Bill Clinton Presidency would not be adverse to the financial markets. Alfred Goldman, market strategist for A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis, said market participants expressed relief that a decision was finally at hand in the race among Mr. Clinton, George Bush and Ross Perot.
"If the market knows what devil they have to deal with, then it will be a lot more comfortable," he said.
The market showed little change in early trading, but then prices headed lower after noon after two waves of computer-driven selling hit stocks, said Dennis Jarrett, market analyst for Kidder, Peabody & Company.
Mr. Jarrett said the selling was apparently caused by an attractive spread between stock futures prices in Chicago and cash prices on the New York Stock Exchange. There was no economic news to account for the selling, he said. Jack Solomon, an analyst at Bear Stearns & Company, said the market's decline was smooth and orderly.
Analysts dismissed as old news the Commerce Department report on the index of leading economic indicators, which was released yesterday. The Government's chief economic forecasting gauge fell three-tenths of 1 percent in September, a sign that the economy will remain sluggish for several months.
"The vast majority of market participants are looking beyond old economic news and looking at a Clinton Presidency and some moderate fiscal stimulus," Mr. Goldman said.
Oil stocks took the brunt of the day's selling after several brokerage houses downgraded prominent companies because of weak demand and the recent decline in oil prices. ARCO fell 2 7/8, to 113 1/8; Amoco, down 1 7/8, to 50 1/4; Exxon, down 3/4, tot 59 1/2, and Texaco, off 1 3/8, to 58 3/4.
The Big Board's composite index fell 1.24, to 231.24. On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index rose 0.13, to 382.83.

HEADLINE: Yields Mixed On C.D.'s and Money Funds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields offered on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit were mixed again for the week that ends today, as banks refrained from making sharp adjustments in deposit rates.
Analysts at The Bank Rate Monitor, a Florida-based interest rate publication, said average yields were little changed as money market accounts held firm in the New York market but slipped in a survey of 20 large banks nationwide. For certificates of deposit, yields were thinly mixed in New York, but were moderately higher at the same 20 large banks. 
 At the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills on Monday, average discount rates rose again, reaching their highest levels since late summer. For depositors the interest rate picture is a bit brighter, since the auction is often regarded as the harbinger of how banks could eventually set their deposit rates in the weeks ahead.
According to data released by the Treasury, the average rate at auction for a three-month bill this week rose 8 basis points, to 3.05 percent from 2.97 percent, achieving the highest level since Aug. 31, when the rate was 3.17 percent. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
For the six-month Treasury bill, the average discount rate rose 5 basis points, to 3.27 percent, its highest since Aug. 3, when it was 3.30 percent at auction.
 
Local Money Market Rate: 2.79%
 The combined New York area average for yields in the latest week showed the average money market account unchanged at 2.79 percent, with a three-month certificate of deposit unchanged at 2.85 percent, and the six-month certificate a basis point lower, at 3 percent.
Among commercial banks, yields were unchanged at 2.63 percent for money market accounts, but slipped on C.D.'s, with three-month and six-month certificates each down 2 basis points, to 2.75 percent and 2.89 percent, respectively.
Depositors at savings banks saw money market yields slip a basis point, to 2.95 percent, with a three-month C.D. unchanged at 2.95 percent and a six-month C.D. up a basis point, to 3.12 percent.
The sharpest adjustments made by New York banks this week included Green Point Savings, which lowered its money market account 5 basis points, to 3.05 percent. Key Bank dropped 15 basis points off its three-month C.D., to 2.48 percent, and 30 basis points off the six-month C.D., to 2.84 percent.
Outside the New York market, yields at 20 large banks surveyed were also mixed, with average money market account off 2 basis points, to 2.66 percent, and a six-month C.D. up 2 basis points, to 2.93 percent.

HEADLINE: Proposed Hospital Merger Concerns Medical School

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STONY BROOK, L.I.

 BODY:
The proposed merger of two Long Island hospitals, brought on by the changing economics of health care, is threatening the survival of the State University Hospital at Stony Brook, officials there say.
As Suffolk county's only referral center for specialized care, the 10-year-old hospital at Stony Brook has agreements with more than 50 hospitals on the East End of Long Island to assist patients who would otherwise have to travel more than 100 miles to medical centers in Manhattan. 
 But officials at Stony Brook say the vital income from such patients is now threatened because North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, in Nassau County halfway between here and Manhattan, is seeking to merge with the Community Hospital of Western Suffolk in Smithtown, only seven miles from the State University Hospital.
No money would change hands, but the Smithtown hospital, which has fallen on hard economic times, would agree to become a satellite of North Shore, said Carol Hauptman, a spokeswoman for North Shore.
Tertiary, or highly specialized care, would be provided at the Manhasset hospital, which is affiliated with Cornell University's medical college.
 
Interests of the County
 The merger is part of a plan by North Shore to establish a network of satellite hospitals, with the aim of reducing costs while providing improved care for patients. Such networks are part of a national trend that is now rapidly emerging in Long Island, said Dr. Jordan Cohen, dean of the School of Medicine at the State University of New York at Stony Brook.
"I have no quarrel with North Shore in that they are merely pursuing their self-interest -- but that's the problem," Dr. Cohen said. "Their self-interest is not in the best interest of Suffolk County. By trying to solidify and greatly expand their base of patient referrals from Suffolk, they threaten the development, even the very existence, of the county's only tertiary referral center and Long Island's only medical school," he said.
Ms. Hauptman countered, "There's no such thing as territory in medical care."
The Stony Brook School of Medicine turns out 100 physicians a year, a large percentage of whom remain on Long Island, said Dr. Michael Geheb, associate dean for clinical affairs.
"Consequently," Dr. Geheb said, "a threat to the viability of the medical center at Stony Brook represents a serious threat to the health and welfare of the region."
 
Limits on Competition
 Stony Brook has called on the New York State Department of Health and the Nassau-Suffolk County Health Systems Agency to reject the proposed North Shore merger with Western Suffolk in favor of a proposal under development at Stony Brook, Dan Forbush, a spokesman for Stony Brook, said.
But Ms. Hauptman, noting that the State Board of Health had been encouraging such mergers, said North Shore was expecting a "quick decision."
Dean Cohen met with officials at Western Suffolk on Monday to discuss "possible alternatives." He said the talks were cordial, but, given the constraints on Stony Brook, he was not optimistic about the hospital dropping its merger plans.
Under current state regulations, Dean Cohen said, Stony Brook cannot borrow money, seek mergers or buy property. To survive in the health care environment today, he said, Stony Brook "must be given greater flexibility by the state so as to be able to compete on a level playing field."
Ms. Hauptman said it was "unfortunate that publicly owned hospitals like Stony Brook could not afford to enlarge and increase their scope of operations because they were hampered by slow-moving state regulators."
"But private not-for-profit hospitals like North Shore can and should, especially if they can provide better service at a better price," she said.
She noted that North Shore merged with the Community Hospital of Glen Cove in Nassau County two years ago and that 50 such arrangements had been completed in New York State over the last two years.
"We're free to introduce new ideas and believe the merger will be beneficial to the care of patients throughout Long Island," she said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Travelers' Loss $358 Million; 1,500 More Jobs Will Be Cut

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
The Travelers Corporation announced losses yesterday for its third quarter that were higher than expected and said it would cut an additional 1,500 jobs as part of a restructuring that altogether will reduce the company's work force by 5,000.
About 1,000 of the 1,500 job cuts announced yesterday are expected to be made in Connecticut and most of those in Hartford, where the company has its headquarters. 
 The company's loss of $358 million come during a quarter when Travelers announced a significant reorganization and streamlining of the company, which includes a plan to sell a 27 percent stake to the Primerica Corporation. Travelers also attributed its poor performance to losses caused by Hurricane Andrew that grew to $240 million after taxes.
The third-quarter loss compares with a profit of $65 million, or 60 cents a share, in the corresponding period last year. Revenue dropped 7.7 percent, to $2.6 billion from $2.8 billion.
Travelers stock closed at $23 yesterday, down 12.5 cents on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Losses From Hurricane
 "Our core businesses are sensitive to the protracted weak economy, and therefore we are continuing an intensive process to streamline operations," said Edward H. Budd, Travelers' chairman and chief executive. "Staffing decisions are directly related to the significant efficiencies we must achieve in order to compete in an environment that requires leaner and more competitive companies."
Like other leading insurers, Travelers experienced staggering losses as a result of Hurricane Andrew. These losses continue to grow and are still surprising industry experts months after the storm struck Florida and Louisiana. The company's latest estimate of $240 million in reduced income is an increase from previous estimates of $175 million to $225 million.
Travelers also announced a charge against earnings of $202 million for its restructuring efforts, up from the previously announced cost of $132 million. The additional $70 million is related to the newly announced reduction of 1,500 jobs in corporate staff and administration, the company said. The jobs will be cut over two years.
The company said it expected to begin realizing savings from the reorganization in 1993 and hoped to achieve savings of more than $100 million by mid-1994.
Westin Hicks, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein, said the announcement indicated the company was moving faster in its restructuring efforts than it indicated earlier this fall, at the time Primerica deal was disclosed. Although the pain will be slightly higher now, he said, the moves could speed up savings in the next few years.
"This was going to be a lousy year anyway," said Gloria L. Vogel, an analyst with Lehman Brothers. "I like to see them throwing a lot of these costs in here now."

HEADLINE: Abandoned Newborn Found in Bronx Alley

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
An newborn girl stuffed into a gym bag was abandoned in a cold, damp alley in the Bronx yesterday morning, where her cat-like cries alerted a couple who rescued her.
The child, who did not appear to have suffered any physical injuries, was taken by the police to Lincoln Hospital, where she was listed in good condition, said Detective Joseph McConville, a police spokesman. The mother has not been found. 
 Lorenzo Beltre, the superintendent of an apartment building at 787 Prospect Avenue in the Melrose section, was leaving his basement apartment shortly after 8 A.M. when he heard a noise in the dimly lighted, narrow alley outside his front door, said his wife, Tamares. The noise came from a brown gym bag propped up against a brick wall, yards from a row of garbage cans.
"He thought that perhaps it was a cat," she said. But when he approached the bag and realized a child was inside, breathing through a small opening, he told his wife to call the police.
"I went crazy," she said, "like that child was mine. I cried."
Officers canvassed the building, searching apartments with the residents' permission, but they found no leads, said Sandra Cosme, a resident. She and other residents said none of their neighbors were expecting to give birth. Detective McConville asked anyone with information to call (718) 402-2270.
The baby is emblematic of the neighborhood and its times, lamented Lorraine Montenegro, the executive director of United Bronx Parents, a community agency a few doors away from where the child was found.
She has seen drugs, poverty and unemployment tear at the neighborhood in which she was born. Her agency offers day care, meals, education and even residential drug treatment for expectant mothers.
Roberto Rivera, who lives in a building adjoining where the infant was found, pointed to a teen-age girl who passed by him on the sidewalk and whispered that she, her brother and mother roam the streets scavenging for cans at night because their father has become so ensnarled in his drug addiction that he sold off the appliances in his apartment.

HEADLINE: New York Firefighters Reject Contract, Forcing Arbitration

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
A contract settlement with New York City firefighters that some city officials hoped would be a model for other labor talks has been rejected by the union.
The negotiations will now go to an independent panel for arbitration on Monday, said James F. Hanley, the Commissioner of the city's Department of Labor Relations. 
 The tentative settlement reached in September with leaders of the Uniformed Firefighters Association called for a salary increase of 4.5 percent, nearly all of it retroactive -- an amount that was roughly the same as the police and other municipal unions won in 1990. But the proposed firefighters' contract would have covered 30 months, or twice as long as most of the other city contracts settled in 1990, leading some city officials to describe it as the equivalent of two 15-month deals, the second without a raise.
Leaders of the union, which represents 8,500 firefighters, had argued that improvements in retirement benefits in the proposed contract made up for the relatively small salary increase. But the delegates, who under union bylaws must vote on contract proposals, rejected the deal on Monday by a vote of 339 to 17.
 
Members Called Frustrated
 James J. Boyle, the president of the firefighters union, said his members were frustrated because they have worked without a raise since 1989. But he also defended the proposed contract, saying that it had offered several benefits, including an annuity and changes in pension schedules, that were significant gains in a difficult economic climate.
"Now we are left with an arbitration coming up, and our history with arbitration is not good," Mr. Boyle said.
The city and the firefighters also went to arbitration in 1987, when the union overwhelmingly rejected another proposed contract. That resulted eventually in a major victory for the city, which won the right to have four firefighters on each truck instead of five. The ruling saved the city millions of dollars in salaries and overtime.
Mr. Hanley contended that the rejection of the latest settlement was due, at least in part, to internal union dissension. He noted that the firefighters union has often rejected contracts negotiated by their leaders, and that, indeed, the leaders themselves are often voted out of office. Mr. Boyle is currently being investigated by a union committee on allegations of misusing the union's credit accounts and other questionable spending.
 
Productivity Gains Sought
 Mr. Hanley said he did not expect the contract rejection to have a major impact on the city's many other sets of labor negotiations. The contract was basically retroactive, and thus was part of the last round of city labor talks, nearly all of which have now been completed. Members of most city unions are now working under expired contracts, and few unions have reported much progress in the current round of talks.
When the proposed contract settlement with the firefighters was reached two months ago, many leaders of other municipal unions were quick to reject the assertion by senior mayoral aides that it would set a pattern for other labor negotiations.
The city has maintained for months that it will grant raises for new contracts only if the raises are financed through productivity gains and other concessions. Union leaders have rejected the city's strategy, saying they will discuss concessions only after the city puts some money on the table.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: PRESIDENT -- THE OVERVIEW;
CLINTON CAPTURES PRESIDENCY WITH HUGE ELECTORAL MARGIN; WINS A DEMOCRATIC CONGRESS

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas was elected the 42d President of the United States yesterday, breaking a 12-year Republican hold on the White House.
Mr. Clinton shattered the Republicans' political base with a promise of change to an electorate clearly discontented with President Bush. 
 Ross Perot, the Texas billionaire who roiled this race throughout, finished third, drawing roughly equally from both major party candidates, according to Voter Research & Surveys, the television polling consortium. His share of the popular vote had the potential to exceed any third-party candidate's in more than half a century.
 
Faithful Are Won Back
 The President-elect, capping an astonishing political comeback for the Democrats over the last 18 months, ran strongly in all regions of the country and among many groups that were key to the Republicans' dominance of the 1980's: Catholics, suburbanites, independents, moderates and the Democrats who crossed party lines in the 1980's to vote for Ronald Reagan and Mr. Bush.
The Governor from Arkansas won such big, closely contested states as Michigan, Missouri, Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Illinois. As polls closed across the nation, networks announced projected winners based on voter surveys. It was Ohio that put him over the top shortly before 11 P.M., followed closely by California. Based on those projections, Mr. Bush prevailed in his adopted state of Texas and other pockets of Republican states around the country.
With 83 percent of the nation's precincts reporting by 3 A.M. today, Mr. Clinton had 43 percent to 38 percent for Mr. Bush and 18 percent for Mr. Perot.
A state-by-state breakdown of those returns gave the President-elect more than 345 electoral votes, a commanding victory in the Electoral College, which requires 270 for election. His victory also provided coattails for Democrats running for Congress in the face of tough Republican challenges: Democrats, who control both chambers, appeared likely to gain in the Senate and suffer manageable losses in the House.
 
'With High Hopes'
 In a victory speech to a joyous crowd in Little Rock, Mr. Clinton declared, "On this day, with high hopes and brave hearts, in massive numbers, the American people have voted to make a new beginning."
He described the election as a "clarion call" to deal with a host of domestic problems too long ignored and to "bring our nation together." He paid tribute to the voters he had met along the campaign trail, saying they had simply demanded that "we want our future back." The President-elect, who looked euphoric and seemed to savor every cheer, added, "I intend to give it to you."
He also hailed his longtime rival, Mr. Bush, for "his lifetime of public service" and the "grace with which he conceded this election."
"Not very long ago I received a telephone call from President Bush," the President-elect said. "It was a generous and forthcoming telephone call, of real congratulations and an offer to work with me in keeping our democracy running in an effective and important transition."
The crowd hailed the victor repeatedly with cries of "We love you, Bill," especially when he paid tribute to his home state, the object of Republican ridicule throughout the campaign.
Mr. Clinton credited much of his success to his wife, Hillary, who was also a target of Republican attacks. The Clintons and their daughter, Chelsea, were joined by Vice President-elect Al Gore and his family, creating once again the tableau of youth and generational change that they projected throughout the campaign. Mr. Gore and Mr. Clinton embraced in jubilant bear hug.
 
Bush Gives Concession
 Mr. Bush, looking weary but composed, made his concession speech shortly after 11 P.M. in Houston. "The people have spoken and we respect the majesty of the Democratic system," he said. Mr. Bush congratulated Mr. Clinton, but did not mention Mr. Perot, and promised that his own Administration would "work closely with his team to insure the smooth transition of power."
Vice President Dan Quayle made his concession speech in Indianapolis a few minutes later and like Mr. Bush congratulated Mr. Clinton and hushed the boos. "We must all pull together now. If he runs the country as well as he ran the campaign, we'll be all right."
Congressional leaders said they welcomed the new era beyond divided government. "We welcome the challenge and the responsibility," said Senator George Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader.
There were other signs of change: California elected two women to the Senate, in Representative Barbara Boxer and the former San Francisco Mayor Dianne Feinstein. Illinois also elected a woman, Carol Moseley Braun, to the Senate, as did Washington State, which chose Patty Murray..
Mr. Perot made his concession speech in remarkably good spirits and seemed intent on signaling that he was not leaving the political stage. "This is not the time to get discouraged," he said. "This is the time to redouble our efforts, to make sure we live in alabaster cities undimmed by human tears."
Mr. Clinton's campaign represented the culmination of years of effort by centrist Democrats to redefine their party and reconnect with the middle class. It also represented an extraordinary turnaround for a party that for much of 1991 seemed destined to lose to a President soaring in the approval ratings in the aftermath of the war in the Persian Gulf.
 
Brown Sees 'Watershed'
 "It was a watershed election for America," said Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee. "The case for change was made, and it resonated so much that it broke down traditional political lines. It's a new day." In fact, the voter surveys showed that economic discontent and a hunger for change were two of the engines of the Democratic victory.
Republicans sadly watched Mr. Bush become the third one-term President in 20 years. "He was a good man, he was a good President," said Representative Vin Weber of Minnesota, a co-chairman fo the Bush campaign. "But he thought that if he simply did the right thing, people would understand. Whereas I think Reagan understood the need to communicate your vision."
Lynn Martin, the Secretary of Labor, said of the voters last night, "They understand about world affairs, but they were worried about their own."
But there was also Republican anger; Mary Matalin, deputy manager of the Bush campaign, accused the news media of bias last night in their coverage of the 1992 election. Ahead, many Republicans feared, was a round of soul-searching, finger-pointing and a struggle to recast their party for an era beyond the cold war, an era that seems relentlessly focused on domestic needs.
 
A Grueling Comeback
 The voting capped a grueling campaign in which Mr. Clinton came back from seeming disaster in the New Hampshire primary, where questions were raised about how he avoided the draft in the Vietnam War, setting off a round of attacks from his political opponents on his trustworthiness. Mr. Clinton survived with a remarkably disciplined campaign that stayed focused on the economy and what he often called "the forgotten middle class."
Mr. Bush, at the same time, fell from great heights as the economy continued to falter. He spent much of the year trying to convince the voters that the country was in better shape than they thought. Still, the voter surveys showed that seven in 10 voters considerd the economy either poor or "not so good," and Mr. Clinton ran strongly among them.
Mr. Clinton also ran strongly among young voters, working women and a variety of other groups that showed the strains in the Republican coalition, which had been held together for years by economic growth and a fierce anti-Communism. And his Southern roots, like those of Jimmy Carter in 1976, made him a formidable challenger to the Republicans in the heart of their political base in the South. The big states of Florida and Texas stayed fiercely competitive until the end.
Mr. Clinton, who is 46 years old, becomes the first President born after World War II -- a changing of the guard in American politics.
Mr. Clinton's careful strategy to appeal to suburban residents, independent voters and moderates clearly paid off. Nearly half of the suburban voters backed Mr. Clinton, compared with about a third who were supporting Mr. Bush. Mr. Clinton also carried 4 in 10 of the independent voters, with Mr. Bush splitting the rest with Mr. Perot.
Here, and in several other demographic categories, Mr. Clinton broke into groups that for the past decade were clear parts of the Republican Presidential majority -- the swing voters drawn to the Republicans by the promise of fiscal responsibility and economic growth. In 1980 and 1988, for example, independents went heavily for Mr. Reagan and Mr. Bush.
The President-elect also won more than half of the voters who consider themselves moderates, suggesting that he had succeeded in his goal of recasting the Democratic Party in a more centrist image. Only 3 in 10 of the moderates backed Mr. Bush, who was widely thought to be hurt by the backlash to the "family values" appeal at the Republican National Convention. Again, that was a far poorer showing than Mr. Bush had in 1988.
Mr. Clinton also succeeded in bringing home many of the Democrats who persistently crossed party lines in Presidential elections in the 1980's: More than half of the Democrats who voted for Mr. Bush in 1988 voted for Mr. Clinton this time around.
Mr. Bush essentially ran even with Mr. Clinton among white voters, but the Democratic nominee, as is the case with most recent Democratic nominees, did far better with black voters.
Mr. Bush ran better than Mr. Clinton among white Protestants, but the Democrat carried about half of the Catholic votes and an even bigger majority among Jewish voters.
 
'Way Beyond Abortion'
 Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton fared about the same among men, but Mr. Clinton had an edge among women, particularly among working women. Only 3 in 10 of the working women voted for Mr. Bush, according to the poll.
"It goes way beyond abortion," said Ann F. Lewis, a former Democratic strategist and commentator. "George Bush campaigned four years ago on the promise of a kinder, gentler nation, and women are keenly aware that he provided neither."
There was also a distinct generational cast to this election. Mr. Clinton, who carefully courted MTV viewers, carried half of the 18- to 29-year-olds, after a decade in which Republicans worked hard to cement their political gains by building on the loyalty of the young. Baby-boomers, those aged 30 to 44, broke more like all voters, despite Mr. Clinton's status as a card-carrying boomer.
But Americans aged 60 and over showed a clear bias in favor of Mr. Clinton, according to the poll. He also ran well among other demographic groups, including half of the military veterans, (despite the furor over his draft status during the Vietnam War), half of the first-time voters, and more than half of union members.
From the beginning of this campaign, in the chilly towns of New Hampshire, the economy was the issue that was front and center, and so it was when voters went to the polls yesterday. Jobs and the economy were cited by nearly 4 in 10 voters as the issue that mattered most in their decision. Health care and the deficit, the latter's prominence probably a reflection of the Perot candidacy, were the second-most important issues, each cited by about a quarter of the voters.
The hostility of the political terrain for Mr. Bush this year was underscored by this fact: fewer than one in 10 voters cited foreign policy as the most important issue to them. Abortion was cited as the determining issue by about one in 10.
Not surprisingly, Mr. Bush carried the anti-abortion vote, after a year when he and his party chose to reaffirm their strong opposition to legalized abortion, as codified in their platform. Mr. Clinton, equally unsurprisingly, carried the votes of those who support abortion's being legal in most or all circumstances.
There were also clear regional patterns at work: Mr. Clinton ran strongest in the East and the West, and only slightly less strongly in the Midwest. Mr. Bush's strength was greatest in the South, which was long considered his political "fire wall." But even there, the all-Southern Democratic ticket kept it neck and neck. Mr. Perot's strongest performance was in the West.
The voting ended what had become an epic campaign.
The Clinton forces, who became increasingly convinced that victory was in their grasp over the past week, flew home to Little Rock yesterday morning. There was some weeping, much rejoicing and great weariness on the Clinton plane. James Carville, the strategist who headed the campaign's "war room" in Little Rock, said there was also some weeping Monday night as the group of strategists at the heart of this campaign met for the last time.
"I'm a little overwhelmed," said Mr. Carville, the tightly wound Louisianian who became emblematic of a new, more aggressive Democratic Party. "When you get to the top of the mountain, your first inclination is not to jump for joy, but to look around."
 
How the Polls Were Conducted
 The Election Day exit poll was based on questionnaires completed by voters as they left voting stations throughout the United States. The national poll included 13,471 voters in 300 randomly selected precincts in all states and the District of Columbia.
The polling was conducted by Voter Research & Surveys, an organization created in 1990 by ABC News, CBS News, CNN and NBC News.
In addition, V.R.S. conducted further interviewing throughout the individual states. The New York Times subscribed to 12 of the individual state exit polls. These included from 700 to 1,900 voters per state in 30 to 50 randomly selected precincts per state.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results from such polls should differ by only a few percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking to interview all voters who turned out. The potential sampling error was one percentage point for the nationwide survey and from three to five percentage points in the individual state polls, depending on the number of interviews.
Results based on smaller subgroups have a larger potential sampling error. In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of voter opinion on Election Day, such as the reluctance of some voters to fill out questionnaires, may introduce other sources of error.
