SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 1513 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: NEWS ANALYSIS;
The Economy's Casualty

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

 BODY:
In the end it was the faltering economy, which had bedeviled him all year, that did George Bush in.
From the New Hampshire primary in February, through the party conventions this summer, to the start of the general-election campaign on Labor Day, public opinion held remarkably steady: three-quarters of the American people, according to New York Times/CBS News polls, disapproved of the way the President was handling the economy. 
 Mr. Bush failed to change their minds with his furious closing onslaught against Bill Clinton's character. More than 7 voters in 10 said in interviews as they left their polling places yesterday that they considered the economy not so good or poor, and a big majority opted for giving the Arkansas Governor a chance to turn it around. Though many had doubts about a man untried on the national stage, they had lost faith in Mr. Bush's ability to do the job, and they found Ross Perot too much of a gamble.
Electoral votes piled up in landslide proportions as Mr. Clinton blitzed through some of the most hotly contested terrain in this election: New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Michigan, Ohio, Illinois and Missouri. He swept New England and the West Coast states of California, Oregon and Washington. With that kind of triumph, leading Democrats said, the pressure on Mr. Clinton to produce big economic improvements soon after taking office will be enormous.
 
Competing Imperatives
 Within days of moving into the White House, for example, he will have to find a balance between competing imperatives: getting a start on reducing the deficit and finding some way to jump-start the nation's stalled economic engine. With Democrats firmly in control of the House and Senate once again, the President-elect will have little excuse for inaction or confusion.
If the partisan coloration of the new Congress will be little different, its diversity will be markedly greater, with four more women and an American Indian, the first ever, in the Senate, and at least a dozen new black members in the House.
"There's nothing very profound about this election," a Pennsylvania political scientist, G. Terry Madonna, said more than a week ago. "There's a massive pro-change vote."
Altogether, something approaching two-thirds of the electorate said it wanted to put an end to business as usual. Most of the pro-change vote went to Mr. Clinton, of course, but a sizable segment also went to Mr. Perot. Politicians of both major parties said that meant Mr. Perot would retain a powerful voice in American politics, if he chose to, and that his principal issue, reducing the Federal deficit, would remain prominent.
Conceding defeat at his headquarters in Dallas, Mr. Perot promised his supporters to "keep on going as long as you want us to keep on going."
After months of speculation about whether Perot backers came principally from the Bush camp or the Clinton camp, the exit polls provided an answer of sorts: they came from both sides, with slightly more people saying they would have voted for the Democrat if Mr. Perot had not made his late re-entry.
But Mr. Perot's most important role, in addition to dramatizing the widespread sense of alienation among American voters, may have been as a halfway house. Early this year, when Mr. Clinton seemed so damaged as to be unacceptable to many people, Mr. Perot provided a temporary home for anti-Bush voters; when he pulled out, many of them switched to Mr. Clinton.
If the election was basically a referendum on President Bush's performance on domestic policy, it was also a testament to the Democratic nominee's grit. He decided to run when many people laughed at his pretension and when senior figures in the Democratic establishment in Washington declined to take the risk.
Then, in New Hampshire, Mr. Clinton was almost knocked out of the contest by Gennifer Flowers's charges. As former Gov. James Blanchard of Michigan, a close friend, recalled last night, "A lot of important Democrats pressed him hard to pull out, telling him he couldn't possibly survive, but he staggered on and won the nomination."
Yesterday, Mr. Clinton's powerful performance at the polls was built on strong showings in all sections of the nation and most demographic groups.
It was not just the hard economic statistics that dogged the President, not just the shuttered shops and lost jobs from Alameda, Calif., to Zanesville, Ohio, that cost him dear. It was also a pervasive if less quantifiable sense of economic foreboding, a fear that the United States was losing its manufacturing base and economic leadership to Germany and Japan.
The current recession had an extra political cost that earlier ones did not, because it hit not only manual laborers but also large numbers of white-collar, and highly skilled, highly paid blue-collar workers who suspected that their jobs were gone forever.
If there was a leitmotif to the 1992 campaign, it was the comment heard on a thousand doorsteps and a hundred bar stools: "I'm worried my kids will never have it as good as I do."
Such economic worries easily overcame the social concerns that had dominated most of the last six Presidential elections, all but one of them won by the Republicans. Concern about jobs -- and about the closely allied subjects of health care and education -- trumped racial tensions, fears about crime and even fervent appeals to patriotism.
That was especially true among the urban, socially conservative, largely Catholic Democrats who have been voting for Republican Presidential candidates in recent decades -- a pivotal block this year. Exit polling by Voter Research and Surveys, a consortium of the leading television networks, showed that half the Democrats who voted for Ronald Reagan and half those who backed Mr. Bush four years ago came back to Mr. Clinton in yesterday's balloting.
So George Bush suffered the fate of William Howard Taft and Herbert Hoover and Jimmy Carter, the only other elected Presidents in this century to be turned out of the Oval Office.
In one important sense, his defeat was the most ignominious of all, because he had held such a commanding position, with a stratospheric 88 percent approval rating in March of last year, and allowed it to disintegrate so quickly.
"He was the king of the mountain after the Persian Gulf War," said J. Robinson West, a Republican who served in both the Ford and Reagan Administrations. "He could have achieved almost anything. He was so popular that if he had drawn up a program, gone to Capitol Hill and battled for it, Congress would not have dared defy him. But he didn't do anything at all."
Then Mr. Bush spent much of the last six months arguing that things were not as bad as they seemed, which wasted what little credibility he had left.
Professionals of both parties were openly scornful of the campaign waged by the President and unstinting in their praise of that mounted by Mr. Clinton. Louis Harris, the poll-taker, who has watched Presidential politics closely for four decades, said recently that Mr. Bush's campaign operatives were "the most incompetent lot left to run a national election" that he had ever seen.
The Republican convention in Houston was a fiasco that failed to give Mr. Bush the kind of bounce in the polls that he expected and needed. Women in particular were offended by hard-edged "family values" appeals suggesting that those who failed to follow the prescriptions of Pat Robertson and Patrick J. Buchanan, a pair of right-wing orators given prominent time slots, were somehow not fully American.
Mr. Clinton ran particularly strongly in the suburbs and among people who called themselves independents, according to the exit polls. And among first-time voters, young voters and single parents, the Arkansas Governor rolled up huge majorities.
All of those groups tend to favor abortion rights, adamantly opposed by Mr. Bush, and to recoil from the kind of cultural conservatism espoused by the religious right -- and seemingly tolerated by the President -- at the convention.
"For years the Republican party suffered from Herbert Hoover," said Michael K. Deaver, President Reagan's master of imagery and symbol, who was offended by the prominence of evangelists at the convention. "Reagan tried to repair that, but now Bush has made us the party not only of Herbert Hoover but Billy Sunday."
The late Lee Atwater, who engineered Mr. Bush's victory four years ago, had warned of the dangers of identifying the Republican party too closely with anti-abortion forces. He called for "a big tent" that could accommodate those of differing views.
Mr. Clinton tried hard to steer a moderate course, describing himself and his running mate, Al Gore, as "new Democrats" unbeholden to special interest groups. One of his primary rivals, former Senator Paul E. Tsongas, called him a "pander bear," and Mr. Bush accused him of trying to be all things to all men. But for the first time in years, a Democrat had a real shot at the ideological center, the place where most American elections are won or lost.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1774 words

HEADLINE: Signs of Thaw for Small Business

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
The entrepreneurial urge is stirring again in John Wyatt. The 47-year-old computer expert founded his first business two decades ago, has since worked for a handful of companies large and small and now thinks the time is ripe for another start-up.
So with a promising product, two colleagues and cluttered office space above his garage in Chapel Hill, N.C., he has founded a new computer software company, Easy Entry Software. 
 The nation's economy may still be limping along. But Mr. Wyatt along with others in the high-tech hub of Raleigh, Durham and Chapel Hill, known as the Research Triangle, sense that a steady diet of low interest rates has begun to quicken business activity. "This may be the ideal time to get positioned to ride the next wave," he said.
 
Banks Starting to Lend
 Across the nation, more entrepreneurs are taking the same gamble. And that is an early indication that the climate is at last warming for small business in America, helped by banks that are gradually starting to lend again as interest rates decline and bad-loan problems ease.
Dun & Bradstreet reported on Friday that during the first half of this year the number of new businesses incorporated in the United States rose 7 percent, after declining for five straight years. "That turnaround is a significant development," said Joseph Duncan, chief economist of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation.
The pickup in new business activity is especially encouraging because it is the first step in the economic food chain of job creation. And jobs have been scarce in this sluggish economy, with big companies slashing payrolls and small companies not growing. In fact, the steady trend of cuts by Fortune 500 companies, dropping 3.7 million workers, to under 12 million by the end of last year, seems sure to continue and perhaps accelerate. The place to watch for signs that the American job machine is starting to work again, economists agree, is in the smaller companies. Small businesses -- defined as everything from one-person start-ups to 500-worker companies -- generate two-thirds of all new jobs in America, as well as half the nation's economic output.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics estimates that in August and September new businesses added about 35,000 jobs a month, up steadily from 10,000 jobs a month earlier this year. And in its September survey, the National Federation of Independent Business, a small-business group, found that its 500,000 members had added jobs at the rate of one worker for every five companies, marking the fifth straight monthly survey that recorded net additions in the head count.
No one suggests that this amounts to a grass-roots surge in the economy. The Government estimates of jobs added by new businesses are well below the 100,000-a-month level experienced during the 1980's, and business failures are still increasing, though the rate of increase is slipping fast. And recent surveys of small-business opinion show that uncertainty does persist about the economy, as well as concern about regulation, health care and other issues.
Still, the new signals that the worst may be over for the small-business sector are heartening to economists.
"If this trend continues, we could have a much stronger economy next year," said David Hale, chief economist of Kemper Financial Services in Chicago. "It certainly is a flicker of hope."
The reason smaller entrepreneurial companies create more jobs than big corporations is that they can often move more quickly to exploit new technologies, techniques and market niches. The casualty rate is high because the early stages after a start-up are tenuous and often difficult for a small group to get through. But the ones that make it beyond the incubator phase can be real job engines, sometimes even surging beyond the small-company category.
 
500,000 'Gazelles'
 David Birch, president of Cognetics Inc., a research firm in Cambridge, Mass., has identified 500,000 small- and mid-sized companies that are growing at 20 percent a year or more and adding workers.
These fast-moving innovative companies -- Mr. Birch calls them "gazelles" -- can be found pretty much across the spectrum of industries. "They are not all high-tech companies by any means," Mr. Birch said.
In Dresden, Tenn., the Stetson Boot and Shoe Company would seem an unlikely gazelle. Gus DuPuis, the 59-year-old chief executive, brags that Stetson is in a "dying industry." Stetson is a contract producer of private-label Western-style boots for major discount and department store chains, competing with producers in low-wage places like India, Mexico, South Korea and Taiwan. When Mr. DuPuis and his partner, Ken Moore, bought Stetson in 1989, the company had just one major account, the work force totaled 148 people and the business outlook was bleak.
Today, the Dresden plant is humming, with 328 people turning out 3,000 pairs of boots a day. Stetson now has 50 accounts instead of one, and the business has tripled. In June the company opened a second factory in nearby Waverly, where the payroll of 179 people is scheduled to reach 450 by next year.
"We kind of adopted the Japanese approach to business," Mr. DuPuis explained in a drawl as thick as molasses. After taking over, the two new owners eliminated foremen and formed teams on the factory floor. Piece-work payment was replaced by hourly salaries to help insure quality. They invested heavily in new molds and lasts to expand the product line. In the last 15 months, the Stetson workers have had four pay increases, bringing them to $8.50 an hour. The company has begun offering its rural Tennessee workers reading courses two nights a week, and they are paid to attend. "Better educated workers make you a more productive company," Mr. DuPuis said.
The Nunes Company of Salinas, Calif., is another fast-growing business with sales in the food industry rising 70 percent, to $85 million annually in the last five years and employment doubling to 100 people, mainly marketing and sales staff. Branded lettuce, called Foxy, is the company's brainstorm. And it has invested in specialized refrigeration equipment and sheds to permit a vacuum cooling process that enables Nunes to maintain quality for lengthy shipments to East Coast supermarket chains like Grand Union and Food Emporium, and growing export markets from Hong Kong to Saudi Arabia.
The premium for its brand-name lettuce is $1 to $2 per 24-head carton above the wholesale price for ordinary lettuce. The company also affixes the Foxy name to its cauliflower, broccoli and asparagus. "We're trying to take these products out of the commodity arena and make them value-added packaged consumer goods," said Matt Seeley, the marketing director of Nunes.
 
A Familiar Regimen
 In the North Carolina Research Triangle, entrepreneurs are striving to build companies in computer software and biotechnology. Their ages and experience vary, but the familiar regimen of 70-hour workweeks, scrambling for cash and sleepless nights is common to most of them.
The three-city hub is one of the nation's high-tech hot spots, yet even there banks have been tightfisted. But they have begun to pursue small-business lending more aggressively.
"Regardless of what the banks tell you, there really was a credit crunch," said Scott Daugherty, director of the Small Business and Technology Development Center in Raleigh, N.C., a government-financed agency. "But in the past six months, the banks have opened up here."
Reed Phillips, president of the Knowledge Systems Corporation in Cary, N.C., has certainly noticed the difference. His software development company, founded in 1985, is growing rapidly by working for corporate customers including I.B.M., Hewlett Packard and others. Its work force of programmers and technical specialists, which numbered 25 people a year ago, is up to 40 and Mr. Phillips plans to hire 10 more by January.
Knowledge Systems is not a bricks-and-mortar business, but its need for working capital has grown as the company has expanded. With banks vying for its business, Mr. Phillips has been able to increase his credit line from $120,000 to $300,000 and get his interest charge cut from the prime rate plus two percentage points to prime plus a half a percentage point.
Yet at the outset, entrepreneurial companies are typically backed by personal savings and sweat equity, not bank loans. Down the road in Cary, Burl Software Laboratories Inc. is a classic high-tech start-up, founded by David Babson and Ken Romley, both 27. The two met when they were scholarship students in the graduate computer science program at Cornell University. After Cornell, Mr. Babson joined Bellcore, the research arm of the regional Bell companies, and Mr. Romley went to work for the computer consulting unit of Price Waterhouse & Company.
They did well, but found the big-company setting bureaucratic and confining. So with a grubstake of $40,000 in personal savings, the pair started Burl. "Big companies don't understand the contribution that one innovative person in a field like this can make," said Mr. Babson, who believes that Burl has two such people.
They have one room in an office park in Cary, and three computers. The two desks were purchased for $25 apiece at a flea market. "Ken got the better desk, so I got to be president," Mr. Babson explained.
They work six and a half days a week, have exhausted their savings and are subsidized by their wives, Megan Babson, a computer engineer, and Ditas Romley, a programmer. But they now have a product that is being tested by R. J. Reynolds, Duke Medical Center and Blue Cross-Blue Shield. And the company is now being courted by venture capital firms, intrigued by Burl's potential.
Its product, called Revolve, is a tool for analyzing software code written in Cobol, the traditional language used in large business computers. Revolve provides a kind of graphic map of the software landscape that is being analyzed, and allows programmers to type in questions and move quickly to selected lines of software code to make changes. Corporate America spends perhaps $80 billion a year to maintain existing software, updating and refining it. A tool that makes the chore more efficient could be a winner. "It's an emerging market, and a huge one," Mr. Romley said.
Burl plans to add three people by the end of the year to help start marketing its product. Beyond that, everything depends on whether its offering is a hit.
"We are small, but there's going to be more and more start-up companies like this," Mr. Babson said. "That's where the growth comes from."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Trading in Dollar Is Mixed; Gold Is Lower in New York

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was hit yesterday by profit taking and fell overseas before ending mixed in choppy domestic trading.
Gold prices settled mostly lower. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $337.50 an ounce, down $2.40 from Monday. The Republic National Bank reported a late bid of $337.75 an ounce, down $1.05. 
 Analysts said traders were locking in profits after the dollar's run-up in recent weeks. Trading was choppy because of the Presidential election.
 
Wait and See
 "People want to see what the election results hold," said Randolph Donney, research director at the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J. "Then we can go back where we were, as long as Clinton is elected."
Currency dealers believe that Gov. Bill Clinton would, as President, increase Government spending to get the economy moving, which in turn would raise interest rates and enhance the value of dollar-denominated securities.
Activity was somewhat light, with Japanese financial markets closed yesterday for the Culture Day holiday.
The dollar, which closed at 123.69 yen in Tokyo on Monday, up 0.34 yen, later closed at 122.15 yen in London, down from 123.90 on Monday. In New York, the dollar settled at 122.40 yen, down sharply from 123.60 on Monday.
The dollar lost more than 1.5 cents against the British pound. In London, the pound rose to $1.5510, from $1.5340 late on Monday. In New York, it cost $1.5505 to buy a pound, more expensive than Monday's $1.5340
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday rates, included: 1.5675 German marks, up from 1.5660; 1.3985 Swiss francs, up from 1.3955; 5.3085 French francs, up from 5.3065; 1,337 Italian lire, down from 1,342.50, and 1.2428 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2412.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday, included: 1.5625 German marks, down from 1.5665; 1.3920 Swiss francs, down from 1.3980; 5.2930 French francs, down from 5.3115; 1.7575 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7640; 1,333.38 Italian lire, down from 1,344, and 1.2418 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2418.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $338.75 an ounce, from $340.15 late on Monday. In Zurich, gold fell to $338.65 an ounce from $339.25. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose 64 cents, to $340.43.

HEADLINE: Results Improve at Milacron

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: CINCINNATI, Nov. 3

 BODY:
Cincinnati Milacron Inc. posted third-quarter earnings of $7.3 million, or 26 cents a share, compared with a loss of $93.8 million in the period a year earlier.
Sales advanced 5 percent, to $225.5 million from $213.8 million. Overseas sales increased 37 percent. 
 The machine-tool company's earnings included a special tax benefit of $2 million, or 7 cents a share. The results a year ago included nonrecurring charges of $94 million to relocate operations, shed product lines and reassess the value of a unit for sale.
Earnings before the gain this year were in line with the consensus forecast of 19 cents a share by six analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research. In New York Stock Exchange trading, shares of Cincinnati Milacron fell 12.5 cents, to $15.875.
Separately, the company said it had revised its retiree health care program and reduced its estimated liability for retiree health benefits to about $50 million before tax, which it will record in the first quarter. Last year, the company estimated it would have to take a pretax charge of $90 million to $120 million for the benefits.
The company said new orders rose 7 percent, to $225 million from $210 million.
"While new orders for our plastics machinery and industrial consumable products were encouraging, the biggest boost came from our machine tool group," said Raymond Ross, president and chief operating officer.
Looking ahead, the company said it expects profits to grow in the fourth quarter and in 1993, assuming the economy improves.

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial

 BODY:
THE British, who have no more than a token wine industry of their own, have long been important arbiters in the European wine market. They practically invented port and sherry; they made Bordeaux respectable and Champagne rich and were, for the longest time, far greater enthusiasts for the wines of the Rhine and Mosel than the Germans themselves.
They even gave these wines dreadful English names. Sherry is, of course, Jerez, anglicized; claret is a simple version of clairet, an old French name for Bordeaux wine, and there is that truly execrable name for German wine: hock. 
 But . . . what is this? No less authoritative a taker of the British pulse than The Financial Times seems to be saying this pre-eminance is over.
"Britain's wine market," Philip Rawstorne wrote in that newspaper recently, "seems to have been affected by a touch of Euro-skepticism." The demand for traditional wines, from France, Germany and Italy, is falling, he said, while British consumers are developing a taste for what he called "New World wines."
New World wines, Mr. Rawstorne said, come from Australia and New Zealand, South Africa and California.
He offered figures. The amount of Australian wines entering Britain grew to 18.2 million liters last year, up from 800,000 liters in 1985; volumes for July and August of this year were 88 percent higher than the same two months in 1991. United States wineries shipped 10.5 million liters of wine to Britain in the first six months of 1992, a 25.5 percent increase over the same period in 1991.
The lifting of economic sanctions against South Africa has had a big effect on that country's wine exports to Britain. Shipments in 1991 rose 65 percent above those in 1990, to 2.8 million liters, as against 1.7 million.
New Zealand established an office in London last year with a 12-month goal of selling 1.8 million liters, The Financial Times said. It sold twice that, the newspaper added.
Imports from France were down 7.4 percent in Britain last year; from Italy, down 6 percent, and from Germany, 4.4 percent. Mr. Rawstorne offered several hypotheses. French wines are overpriced, he said, while German wines are poorly promoted. But he suggested that "New World" wines may actually taste better.
For example, he said that South African producers "put a lot of research into discovering what consumers wanted." What they discovered, he said, was that the British did not fancy mean, acidic stuff like Muscadet or -- this idea must have raised an eyebrow or two -- what he called "the leathery taste of a Burgundy." Leathery? Burgundy?
He is talking about what are called "user friendly" wines in this country, although the South Africans and the Australians don't seem to have become as friendly as some bigger California producers. American wine makers don't hesitate to add a bit of sugar to their supposedly dry wines, particularly chardonnay. They know they are trying to appeal to a populace raised on sweet soft drinks.
A closely followed court case in California ended recently with a wine maker's being prohibited from taking the "secret" formula for adding sugar to chardonnay from one winery to his new job at another.
It's no secret that millions of potential wine drinkers are turned away by what they perceive to be "sour" and "bitter" tastes. In fact, the wines are neither sour nor bitter; they just aren't as sweet as Pepsi-Cola or Coke.
There are two ways to make a wine sweeter: add sugar after fermentation or stop the fermentation before all the sugar from the grapes has been converted to alcohol and carbon dioxide. I have seen no evidence that the Australians or South Africans are doing either. But even without sugar, many New World wines are much easier to drink than their European counterparts. The difference is partly a function of warmer climates, partly of wine-making techniques. The result is softer, more rounded wines, without the astringency of many red and white European wines.
Intelligent labeling is an important asset for the New World wines, Mr. Rawstorne suggested. "Just decoding a German wine label, cluttered with Gothic script, or identifying yet another French chateau inhibits many potential customers," he said. Labeling wines with the variety of the grape, like chardonnay or cabernet sauvignon, has made selecting a bottle much easier, he added.
Furthermore, he said, the similarities between an Australian cabernet and one from California would "reassure the drinker that if he has enjoyed one, he will enjoy the other."
European wine makers have made some attempts at varietal wines, which is what Americans call wines that bear the name of the grape they are made from. But it is their very particularity that is the glory of the best European vineyards. All the great red wines from Burgundy are made from pinot noir grapes, but three vineyards less than 100 yards apart will make three different wines.
The Germans are bringing their labels into the 20th century, but slowly, while Italy, which produces literally thousands of different wines, could never truly simplify its labels.
Prices are certainly a factor, probably the biggest one. Prices for European wines got out of hand in the 1980's. Many consumers were driven into the arms of the eager New World producers by outrageous prices for medium-quality European wines. The recent devaluation of the pound certainly won't help the British market.
In this market, there are signs that some of these trends have been reversed. Sales of better European wines did well in the United States in the first half of this year, in spite of a continued drop in overall wine consumption.
British wine drinkers, no more than American wine drinkers, are not about to abandon Europe's great wines; it has been a long and ardent love affair. On the other hand, it's difficult to love someone who charges you $14 for a bottle of Beaujolais.
 
TASTINGS
Chateau Giscours 1989, Margaux, Bordeaux; about $24.
In some recent tastings of Bordeaux wines from the 1988, 1989 and 1990 vintages, it quickly became evident that the 1989's would be the first to mature. It also appeared that although they would not be long-lived wines, during their good years they would be very good, indeed. Some, including this medium-bodied, supple Giscours, are just about ready to drink now. Giscours was a problematic wine in the 1960's and 1970's, when its owners, the Tari family, were waiting for their vineyards to mature and deciding what kind of wine to make. In the 1980's, Giscours came into its own. Even the 1987 vintage, underrated by many critics, was a delightful wine. The 1989, bought now, should continue to develop in the bottle for a year or two and be good to drink for 5 or 10 years after that. Not every Bordeaux has to be spectacular; some should be good, solid workaday wines like this one.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Nuremberg as Seen by Prosecutor

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:
The Anatomy of the Nuremberg Trials
A Personal Memoir
By Telford Taylor
Illustrated. 703 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $35.
As a record of the international trials of Nazi Germany's major war criminals and the personal story of Telford Taylor's role as the chief American prosecutor, "Anatomy of the Nuremberg Trials" is a masterly work of military and judicial history. Mr. Taylor's book marks the apogee of his career as a crusading lawyer and law professor. It is the long-awaited narrative he had to write because of his singular experience. 
 An important theme emerges from these rich and readable pages: the need for international laws and tribunals to hold individuals responsible for war crimes against humanity. And the author sends a subliminal message: if such laws and courts are established and respected, they can be a warning of personal accountability to prevent atrocities in the name of tribalism or nationalism, crimes that are still being committed against civilians.
Mr. Taylor does indeed anatomize Nuremberg, forcefully but fairly praising or criticizing colleagues and allies. The road to the courtroom in Germany was strewn with uncertainty because the Allies were breaking new ground in international law. There were divisions among the American, British, Russian and French leaders and their prosecutorial staffs about what constituted criminality in wartime; about the written and unwritten rules of war themselves; about who should be put in the dock: only the high-level German warmongers and genocidal policy makers or also the big industrialists who supported Hitlerism with armaments and slave labor.
After serving in Army intelligence in wartime Europe, Colonel Taylor (later a brigadier general) joined the staff of Robert H. Jackson, the Associate Justice of the Supreme Court who had been appointed by President Harry S. Truman to represent the United States at an international trial of war criminals. On the ashes of victory in the spring of 1945, the plans for such a four-nation trial were chimerical at best, abrasive at worst.
The author became one of Justice Jackson's principal associates after he wrote an impressive memorandum spelling out the goals of Nuremberg. He emphasized that the trial should make the war valid and meaningful for the people of the Allied nations, who had suffered casualties and destruction, and also be a lesson for people of the Axis nations. Looking to the mechanics of the trial, he saw the need to maintain harmonious relations among the Allied prosecutors to prevent dissension before the eyes of the world.
Among the many revelations in the book is that President Franklin D. Roosevelt himself provided the informal, unpublished instructions that formed the basis of the trial. Roosevelt said that charges against the chief Nazi war criminals should include an indictment for "waging aggressive war" and that these charges be joined in "a conspiracy indictment." Mr. Taylor reminds the reader that President Roosevelt had been a New York lawyer early in his career and that the philosophical spine of the Nuremberg indictments was developed by a group of New York lawyers, including Henry L. Stimson and Samuel Rosenman.
The American prosecutors played the most important role at Nuremberg. The French and Russians only reluctantly agreed to the aggressive war and conspiracy charges. Stalin reportedly had desired quicker justice, suggesting that 50,000 German general staff officers be killed, but Charles Bohlen, the American diplomat who was Roosevelt's interpreter at the Teheran conference, said Stalin had spoken "in semi-jocular fashion" as a jibe against Winston Churchill. Gen. Charles de Gaulle, head of France's provisional government, told Mr. Rosenman that he favored a trial rather than summary execution.
Twenty-four defendants were indicted. There was unanimity about including such Hitler cohorts as Hermann Goring, Rudolf Hess, Joachim von Ribbentrop, Julius Streicher, Robert Ley and Field Marshal Wilhelm Keitel. Initially, the British wanted a quick trial of the dozen worst war criminals, but the Russians and French supported American proposals to add military and big business leaders. The "economic defendants" included Hjalmar Schacht, Fritz Sauckel, Albert Speer and Walter Funk. All had knowingly provided the sinews of war.
In a fascinating account of a mix-up of names by the allies, Mr. Taylor relates that the tribunal indicted the wrong Krupp. Gustav, who was senile, was indicted instead of Alfried, his son, who was the sole owner of the huge munitions company at the height of the war, who had exploited concentration-camp slave labor. He writes that while the Americans were by no means blameless, it was the British, and in particular Sir Hartley Shawcross, Britain's Attorney General, who were primarily responsible for the mistake because Krupp headquarters was in their occupied zone of Germany.
The trial of the defendants is reported with an insider's knowledge in gripping detail, including cold-blooded testimony about the horrors of the Holocaust, activities of the SS and the German high command, and portraits of the individuals in the courtroom: the prosecutors, judges and defendants. Mr. Taylor then deals with the judgment at Nuremberg, what happened to the leading Allied trial personalities, and an assessment of this and other war-crimes trials. Judiciously, he also provides some facts about his personal life in the Nuremberg community.
What chances are there to establish a new "Nuremberg" international tribunal to adjudicate crimes against the peace and, by doing so, possibly help to prevent them in the future?
Mr. Taylor writes: "During the four or five years after the end of World War II there was an effort made at the United Nations to create a permanent International Criminal Court, but Republican Presidents have shown no interest in such a project. Application of international rules of warfare thus remains generally determined by the nations concerned, except in the comparatively rare occasions when the United Nations takes action."
This wise and authoritative book could help to stimulate such action.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE;
WEST

 BODY:
ALASKA
The race between President Bush and Governor Clinton was too close to call here in this state, which had not given its three electoral votes to the Democrats since 1964. This was the case despite Mr. Clinton's opposition to drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, which Alaskans overwhelmingly favor.
Mr. Perot led the polls in early June, but his support faded after his withdrawal and re-entry. 
 In the Senate race, Frank H. Murkowski, the Republican incumbent, went into Election Day with a commanding lead over his Democratic opponent, Tony Smith, who suffered a sharp financial disadvantage.
Representative Don Young, a 19-year Republican incumbent with 57 overdrafts at the House bank, faced a sharp challenge by John Devens, the former Mayor of Valdez.
 
ARIZONA
The only state to have voted Republican in every Presidential election since 1952, Arizona gave the Bush campaign the jitters. Recent polls showed Bill Clinton slightly ahead in the contest for the state's eight electoral votes, largely because of voter dissatisfaction with the President's handling of the economy. The state was devastated by the savings and loan troubles and by plummeting commercial and residential real estate prices. Polls indicated that Mr. Perot was hurting Mr. Bush more in Arizona than in any other state except Texas.
Although Senator John McCain, a war hero and first-term Republican, was tarnished as one of the five Senators who intervened on behalf of Charles Keating, a savings and loan operator, Mr. McCain was sufficiently confident to join his colleagues on a fact-finding visit to Hanoi earlier this fall.
His opponents were Claire Sargent, a Democrat who has been active in civic affairs, and former Gov. Evan Meacham, a Republican best known for his opposition to making the birthday of Martin Luther King Jr. birthday a state holiday.
 
CALIFORNIA...CLINTON
Mr. Clinton's victory in California, with its 54 electoral votes, had been a foregone conclusion.
As interviews with voters led to projections of a Democratic triumph, attention was focused on the unprecedented election of two women to the state's two seats in the United States Senate.
Dianne Feinstein, a former Mayor of San Francisco, was projected the winner by a comfortable margin over the Republican incumbent, John Seymour, who was appointed to the Senate seat vacated when Pete Wilson was elected Governor.
The other female Senate candidate, Representative Barbara Boxer, a Democrat running to replace Alan Cranston, a Democrat who is retiring, was locked in a tight race with Bruce Herschensohn, a conservative Republican and television commentator.
Mr. Bush's decision not to seriously contest California allowed Mr. Perot to sap the President's strength further and post a fairly strong showing.
In a newly drawn district, the 41st, which includes some of Orange County, Republican registration was high, favoring the Republican Jay C. Kim's bid to become the first Korean-American immigrant elected to Congress.
Californians passed a ballot initiative on limiting Congressional terms. Representatives could serve no more than 6 years in an 11-year period, and Senators 12 years out of 17. There was also a measure to allow mentally competent adults who are terminally ill to direct a physician to kill them.

COLORADO
Colorado, with eight electoral votes, was hotly contested by all three candidates. But, despite the strong state economy, Mr. Clinton's efforts to portray himself as the candidate most likely to create jobs appeared to pay off. Surveys of voters leaving the polls projected that he would win.
President Bush pushed hard in Colorado, visiting the state twice and dispatching Barbara Bush to Denver at the 11th hour. In the cattle country of western Colorado, Mr. Bush's radio commercials asserted that Mr. Clinton favored higher fees for grazing on Federal lands and opposed agricultural subsidies.
Although Mr. Perot was backed by almost one in four Colorado voters before he pulled out, he never regained that level of support, statewide polls showed.
In the campaign to replace Senator Tim Wirth, a Democrat who is retiring, State Senator Terry Considine, a Republican, closed a wide gap with Representative Ben Nighthorse Campbell, the pony-tailed, lone American Indian in Congress. But by last night, surveys of voters leaving the polls showed that Mr. Campbell would become the first American Indian in the Senate. In the race's final weeks, as Mr. Campbell broadcast commercials stressing his support for legalized abortion, his lead in the polls had grown.

HAWAII
No one ever doubted that Hawaii, with its formidable Democratic machine, would vote overwhelmingly for Mr. Clinton, giving him its four electoral votes. Projections by a network consortium, based on the polling of voters, gave Mr. Clinton the state's four electoral votes.
The polls similarly showed that Senator Daniel K. Inouye, the incumbent Democrat easily won re-election.

IDAHO...BUSH
The oratory of the Republican convention initially soured many voters and opened the way for Mr. Clinton to make early inroads in this bedrock Republican state. But that surge quickly faded, and, according to surveys of voters leaving the polls, President Bush was winning the state's four electoral votes. Mr. Perot was poised to come in second, in one of his best states.
The race to fill the seat left by Senator Steve Symms, a Republican who is retiring, was hotly contested. Representative Richard Stallings, a conservative Democrat, ran aggressively against Mayor Dirk Kempthorne of Boise, criticizing him for raising taxes. But Mr. Kempthorne gained by backing a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution and promising to cut Government regulations.
Michael D. Carpo, a Republican who is President of the State Senate, was favored to take the House seat Mr. Stallings is vacating.

MONTANA...CLINTON
Montana politics was dominated by a House race featuring two popular incumbents and a hotly contested governor's race that overshadowed the Presidential election.
Mr. Clinton hoped to be the first Democrat in 28 years to win Montana's three electoral votes.
Redistricting this year forced the state's two popular incumbents, a Republican, Ron Marlenee, and a Democrat, Pat Williams, to face each other.
The retirement of Gov. Stan Stephens opened the office to a contest between State Representative Dorothy Bradley, a Democrat, and State Attorney General Marc Racicot, a Republican.

NEBRASKA...BUSH
Nebraska has not embraced a Democrat for President since Lyndon B. Johnson in 1964, and this year Mr. Bush won an easy victory.
With no races for Senate or governor, the hottest electoral contest in the state was for the House in the Second District, anchored in Omaha. Peter Hoagland, a two-term Democratic Representative, faced a spirited challenge from a flamboyant restaurant owner, Ron Staskiewicz. Trying to ride the anti-incumbent wave, Mr. Staskiewicz burnished his outsider image by campaigning in a bus decorated like a Pullman train car. Mr. Staskiewicz based his pitch on "House Rules," a book by Robert Cwiklik characterizing Mr. Hoagland as the consumate insider and an opportunist to boot.
In a referendum, voters decided whether they wanted a statewide lottery to provide money for schools and an environmental trust fund.

NEW MEXICO...CLINTON
Governor Clinton won in New Mexico, long a Republican Presidential stronghold, and where both major Presidential campaigns had made late campaign stops in bids for the state's five electoral votes.
Mr. Clinton made Albuquerque one of his final stops, urging his supporters on in a 3 A.M. rally on Election Day. Former President Ronald Reagan had visited the Southwestern state last week to bolster support for Mr. Bush.
Mr. Perot polled about the same in the state as he did nationally.
The state's delegation in the House of Representatives was firmly ensconced.

 Perot...70,776...17%
 
OREGON
To little surprise, Mr. Clinton took Oregon's seven electoral votes.. Oregon was one of two Western states to go to Michael S. Dukakis in 1988, and it was a sign of the candidates' fatalism about the state that all three relied principally on national advertising to carry their messages there.
Attention in Oregon focused instead on ballot measures and on a fierce Senate race between the four-term Republican incumbent, Bob Packwood, and Representative Les AuCoin, a nine-term Congressman.
One initiative this year, Ballot Measure 9, which would permit discrimination against homosexuals, touched off a sharp increase in violence and vandalism this fall by both its opponents and supporters.

 AuCoin (D)...200,049...47%
 
UTAH
During Mr. Bush's down-and-up national campaign, Utah, with five electoral votes, never wavered in its loyalty to the Republicans, according to statewide polls that also showed Mr. Perot narrowly trailing Mr. Clinton with about a quarter of the vote.
In the race to replace Senator Jake Garn, a Republican who is retiring, Representative Wayne Owens, a Democrat, appeared to trail Bob Bennett, a Republican businessman. Both are Mormons, but Mr. Bennett claimed that Mr. Owens, who had overdrawn 87 checks at the House bank, had been the most liberal of the Utah delegation. Mr. Owens sought to connect Mr. Bennett to the Watergate scandal for having employed one of the burglars, E. Howard Hunt, at his public relations firm.
In a first for Utah, two women competed to represent Mr. Owens's district, which includes Salt Lake City. Karen Shepherd, a Democratic State Senator, faced Enid Greene, the chairwoman of the Young Republican National Federation.
In the Governor's race, Michael Leavitt, a Republican insurance executive, appeared likely to beat the Democrat, Stewart Hanson, a former state trial judge.
 
WASHINGTON
Mr. Clinton took Washington, according to network surveys of voters leaving polls, but the Senate race in Washington State was not nearly as easy to call.
State Senator Patty Murray, who called herself "just a mom in tennis shoes," was one of a handful of women nationwide who appeared to have a good chance of breaking into the male-dominated Senate. But recent polls showed her lead considerably reduced against Representative Rod Chandler, a five-term Republican Congressman. The two competed for the seat vacated by Senator Brock Adams, a Democrat who is retiring.
If Mr. Clinton did as well as expected and won the state's 11 electoral votes, he could help Democrats, including Representative Thomas S. Foley, into eight of the state's nine House seats.
About a month ago, State Attorney General Ken Eikenberry, a Republican, was thought to be certain to replace the retiring Governor, Booth Gardner, a Democrat. But few wanted to discount the chances of Mike Lowry, a Democratic former Congressman.
Voters also considered term limits.
 
WYOMING
Although Lyndon B. Johnson was the last Democratic Presidential candidate to carry Wyoming, Mr. Bush could not take the state's three electoral votes for granted. Voter discontent with the President's handling of the economy and support for stronger measures to protect the environment, were the most important issues.
A week before Election Day, a poll for The Casper Star-Tribune showed the President and Mr. Clinton virtually neck-and-neck. Ross Perot was making one of his strongest showings. But last night the network consortium, surveying voters leaving the polls, called the state for President Bush.
The state's lone member of the House, Craig Thomas, a Republican seeking his second full term, was opposed by John Herschler, an eye surgeon. Mr. Herschler enjoyed good name recognition, but is not related to the late Gov. Ed Herschler.
Voters also considered term limitations.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: STATES BY STATE;
Northeast

 BODY:
CONNECTICUT...Clinton
 Gov. Bill Clinton took this state of disaffected voters, which had not supported a Democratic Presidential candidate since 1968.
President Bush apparently failed to win over the ranks of Reagan Democrats and moderate Republicans he needed to help him take the eight electoral votes in Connecticut. 
 Like much of the Northeast, the state lost hundreds of thousands of manufacturing jobs in the last decade. More recently, as the economy worsened, jobs in white-collar industries like banking and insurance also disappeared.
In the race for the Senate, two-term Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Democrat, defeated a millionaire businessman, Brook Johnson.
Early on, Mr. Dodd seemed in danger of being washed away by the anti-incumbent tide, but he managed to leap far ahead of Mr. Johnson, a political novice, by campaigning constantly and mostly on one issue -- jobs.
Mr. Johnson ran as an outsider, labeling Mr. Dodd a big spender who voted to raise his own salary and catered to special-interest groups.
But Mr. Dodd countered that his experience saved the Seawolf submarine contract for Electric Boat, eastern Connecticut's largest employer, over the Administration's opposition.

DELAWARE...CLINTON
Mr. Clinton won Delaware and its three electoral votes, despite efforts by Mr. Bush to portray the Democrat's policies as dangerous to the state's chemical, banking and automobile industries.
Gov. Michael N. Castle, taking mandatory retirement after two terms in the statehouse, was well ahead of former Lieut. Gov. S. B. Woo, a Democrat, in the race for the state's sole House seat.
In the governor's race, Representative Tom Carper, a five-term Democrat, defeated B. Gary Scott, a retired real estate executive.

MAINE
With half of the precincts reporting, Mr. Clinton held an 11 percentage point lead over Mr. Bush in the state where the President and his family have long spent their summers. Mr. Perot was falling only one percentage point short of sending the President into a third-place finish in Maine, where four electoral votes were at stake.
Mr. Bush's support fell even in Kennebunkport, his family's summer home, as the weekly newspaper endorsed Mr. Clinton.
In a rematch of their 1990 contest Representative Olympia J. Snowe led Democrat Patrick K. McGowan,who was set back by the Green Party candidate, who won 8 percent of the vote.
Early returns also showed Thomas H. Andrews, a Democrat, crushing Linda Bean, a Republican and heiress to the L. L. Bean fortune. She spent over $1 million -- including $900,000 of her own money -- on the race.

MARYLAND...CLINTON
Mr. Clinton scored an easy victory in a state where Democrats outnumber Republicans by a margin of more than 2 to 1. Expecting as much, President Bush put little energy into the state, which carries 10 electoral votes.
Mr. Perot finished a distant third.
Maryland voters affirmed a law guaranteeing abortion rights. The law, passed by the Legislature and signed by the Governor last year, guaranteed the right even if the United States Supreme Court overturns Roe v. Wade, which established abortion as a Constitutional right.
An anti-abortion group, the Vote Know Coalition, had collected enough signatures to keep the law from taking effect until it was put to a popular vote.
Senator Barbara A. Mikulski, a Democrat, won easily over Alan Keyes, a black Republican who had accused the party of racial bias, saying it had not funneled enough money to his campaign.

MASSACHUSETTS...CLINTON
Mr. Clinton was not beloved by Massachusetts Democrats. He came in third in the Massachusetts Democratic primary, behind both a native son, Paul E. Tsongas, and Edmund G. Brown Jr., and he failed to win a single delegate. But this state is a Democratic stronghold, where only 14 percent of the voters consider themselves Republicans and 45 percent prize their independence.
Anti-Bush feeling was so strong that the state that had twice supported Ronald Reagan before voting for Michael S. Dukakis, another native son, gave Mr. Clinton its 12 electoral votes.
Reapportionment increased the political problems of two Congressional veterans. Representative Joseph D. Early, a nine-term Democrat who had written 140 overdrafts on his House bank account, had to cope with a district in which half the voters were new. He faced State Senator Peter Blute, a conservative Republican.
Representative Nicholas Mavroules, a seven-term Democrat indicted on charges of racketeering, bribery and tax evasion, was considered the underdog against State Representative Peter Torkildsen.

 Bush...344,844...29%

NEW HAMPSHIRE
Governor Clinton took this most Republican of states, according to surveys of voters by a consortium of networks. With their state's economy in a shambles, New Hampshire voters appeared in the mood for change, and Mr. Bush never seemed to recover from the pounding he took in the February primary from Patrick J. Buchanan, his conservative challenger..
Gov. Judd Gregg, a Republican, sought the seat of Warren B. Rudman, who is retiring, against John Rauh, a businessman who challenged his opponent on the national deficit, the economy and jobs. Mr. Gregg warned that his opponent's suggestion to cut military spending by 50 percent over five years would put thousands of local shipyard workers out of work.
Competing for governor were State Representative Deborah (Arnie) Arnesen, a Democrat who proposed a 6 percent income tax on those earning more than $30,000, and Steve Merrill, a former attorney general who promised not to raise taxes but to make state government leaner.
The state's two House members, Bill Zeliff, a Republican, and Dick Swett, a Democrat, faced strong challenges, but were expected to survive.
 
NEW JERSEY
In surveys of voters leaving the polls, Governor Clinton was projected by early evening to be the winner in New Jersey after a bruising campaign there.
With 15 electoral votes and more independent voters than Democrats or Republicans, New Jersey had loomed as a crucial prize for the Republicans, who sought to link Mr. Clinton to Gov. James J. Florio, a Democrat badly wounded by tax increases. In the closing days of the race, Mr. Bush's advertising hit hard on Mr. Clinton's record in Arkansas on the environment, welfare reform and children's issues.
Mr. Clinton visited the state six times after his party's convention. As part of a huge advertising campaign that included big purchases in New York City and Philadelphia, the Democrats broadcast a commercial touting the low tax burden in Arkansas. He and Senator Gore repeatedly claimed that 218,000 residents of New Jersey had been thrown out of work under President Bush.
According to state polls, support for Mr. Perot, which topped 20 percent after he re-entered the race, faded after his allegations of Republican dirty tricks.
Many of the 13 Congressional races were also ferocious, with redistricting and the retirement of four incumbents raising the possibility that Republicans could outnumber Democrats in the state's Congressional delegation for the first time since 1964.
In a district drawn to increase Hispanic representation, New Jersey elected its first Hispanic Congressman, Robert Menendez, a Cuban-American who is a Democratic State Senator and Mayor of Union City.

NEW YORK...CLINTON
From the moment the campaign began in earnest, Mr. Clinton seemed a certain winner in New York, with its 33 electoral votes. As the polls closed, Mr. Clinton was declared the winner by a large margin over Mr. Bush.
And so the main show was the Senate race. And what a show it was with Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato eking out a narrow victory over his Democratic challenger, Robert F. Abrams, the State Attorney General. Despite Mr. Clinton's commanding lead at the top of the ticket, Mr. Abrams was unable to prevail in a blistering campaign that may have been the nation's nastiest campaign. Mr. D'Amato made it clear that he did not want to be identified with Mr. Bush, often speaking more favorably of Mr. Clinton's programs than those of Mr. Bush.
The two candidates differed on almost all the issues: Mr. D'Amato opposed abortion under most circumstances; Mr. Abrams staunchly supported the right to obtain an abortion. Mr. D'Amato supported the death penalty, and Mr. Abrams opposed it.
Yet the campaign was fought mostly on other grounds, notably attacks and counterattacks about ethics. Although Mr. D'Amato has been the subject of years of ethics inquiries, he moved deftly to pre-empt Mr. Abrams, accusing him of being slippery about his own tax payments and campaign donations.
In the House races, Representative Bill Green, a Republican who represents what is left of Manhattan's Silk Stocking District, also worried that a Democratic landslide could give the seat to Carolyn B. Maloney, a Democratic City Councilwoman.
Democrats hoped that a Clinton victory might also help them win control of the State Senate for the first time in 28 years.

PENNSYLVANIA...CLINTON
Mr. Clinton won Pennsylvania's 23 electoral votes, taking a state that was narrowly in President Bush's column in 1988. Fears about the economy had eroded Mr. Bush's support among coal miners, steel workers and other Reagan Democrats this year, despite the President's efforts to paint the Democrats as overzealous on gun control and environmental regulation.
Mr. Clinton successfully echoed the 1991 campaign themes of Senator Harris Wofford, whose surprise victory last year over former Attorney General Dick Thornburgh had been orchestrated by James Carville, Mr. Clinton's chief strategist. Mr. Perot drew support from blue-collar Democrats and moderate Republicans, but not enough to hurt Mr. Clinton.
In a closely watched Senate race, Senator Arlen Specter, a Republican considered vulnerable after his questioning of Anita Hill at the Clarence Thomas confirmation hearings last year, narrowly defeated Lynn Yeakel, the Democrat..
In an expensive campaign with a nasty personal edge that gained momentum in the final days, Ms. Yeakel attacked Mr. Specter for humiliating Ms. Hill. Mr. Specter responded with advertisements calling Ms. Yeakel a one-issue candidate, emphasizing his support for women's issues and attacking her for having failed to pay her Philadelphia income tax until a day before announcing her candidacy.

RHODE ISLAND
Gov. Michael S. Dukakis took this state in 1988, and Rhode Island once again handed its four electoral votes to the Democratic Presidential candidate, according to network projections, even though the candidates paid scant attention to the nation's tiniest state.
While Mr. Bush was not expected to do well here, Mr. Perot, the independent, was counting on doing better in the Ocean State than in the rest of the Northeast.
In the governor's race, Elizabeth Ann Leonard, a Republican car dealer, tried to use the recession and the state's banking crisis to unseat Gov. Bruce Sundlun, a Democrat. In this year of anti-incumbent sentiments, Ms. Leonard was called the "perfect outsider" by the Republican Governors' Association.
Representative Ronald K. Machtley, a Republican who unseated a 28-year Democratic Congressman in 1988, faced a tough re-election bid against State Senator David R. Carlin Jr. Representative John F. Reed, a Democrat, was expected to win handily over his Republican challenger, James W. Bell, a building contractor.
 
VERMONT...CLINTON
Mr. Clinton took Vermont and its three electoral votes, the first time a Democrat won the state since 1964.
Gov. Howard Dean a medical doctor, also beat out State Senator John McClaughry, a Republican. Mr. McClaughry is a former White House aide under Ronald Reagan.
Bernard Sanders, a socialist who ran as an independent, was seeking re-election for the state's only House seat against Lewis E. Young, a Democrat, and Tim Philbin, a Republican.
Senator Patrick J. Leahy, a Democrat, won re-election, over Secretary of State Jim Douglas, a Republican.
 
PRESIDENT - 43% reporting
 Bush...31,496...30%
 Clinton...51,982...49%
 Perot...22,752...21%
 
SENATE - 40% reporting
 Douglas (R)...41,364...42%
 Leahy (D)...57,114...58%
 
WEST VIRGINIA...CLINTON
 With twice as many registered Democrats as Republicans, and with Democratic control of the Statehouse and a monopoly over representation in Congress, West Virginia was expected to provide Mr. Clinton its five electoral votes, and did so. Having had severe economic problems for the last decade, the state viewed the rest of the nation simply as catching up.
West Virginia voted for Richard M. Nixon in 1972 and Ronald Reagan in 1984, but those votes proved aberrations.
Gov. Gaston Caperton, a Democrat, won re-election yesterday. He won election four years ago by campaigning against new taxes. But once elected, he shepherded a tax bill through the Legislature, alienating many voters.
His Republican opponent was Cleve Benedict, the state's Agriculture Commissioner. Charlotte Pritt, a Democrat, , waged a write-in campaign.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE;

 BODY:
ALABAMA...BUSH
President Bush captured Alabama in part by attacking Mr. Clinton on social issues. At an anti-Clinton rally last week parents said their children would be exposed to homosexual scout masters if the Democrat won.
With nine electoral votes, Alabama last went Democratic in 1976. 
 Senator Richard C. Shelby, a Democrat, won an easy re-election campaign against Richard Sellers, a Republican business consultant. And State Senator Earl F. Hilliard, a Democrat, became the first black Alabaman in Congress since Reconstruction, running in a new black majority district.
George Wallace Jr., the Democratic State Treasurer, carried his famous name into a Congressional battle for an open seat previously held by the Republicans. He faced Terry Everett, a newspaper executive who spent more than $600,000 to win the primary.
Representative Ben Erdreich, a five-term Democratic incumbent, faced a tough fight in a redrawn Birmingham district, now overwhelmingly Republican.
 
PRESIDENT - 84% reporting
 Bush...710,055...48%
 Clinton...620,250...42%
 Perot...161,072...11%
 
SENATE - 84% reporting
 Shelby (D)...921,735...67%
 Sellers (R)...459,642...33%
 
ARKANSAS...CLINTON
Mr. Clinton easily landed his home state's six electoral votes, marking the first time Arkansas had voted Democratic for President since 1976. Mr. Perot and Mr. Bush, after writing off the state, even went so far as to ridicule it.
Senator Dale Bumpers, the three-term incumbent, defeated his Republican challenger, Mike Huckabee. In the heavily Democratic Congressional district in the northeastern corner of Arkansas, Blanche Lambert, the Democrat who beat her former boss, Bill Alexander, in the primary, defeated the Republican challenger, Terry Hayes.
John R. VanWinkle, the Democratic underdog in the northwestern section of the state, was hoping to hitch a ride on Mr. Clinton's victory train to upset State Representative Tim Hutchinson, a Baptist minister favored in the historically Republican district.
Voters were also expected to approve a measure to limit the terms of state and Federal officials.
 
PRESIDENT - 80% reporting
 Bush...250,466...36%
 Clinton...370,011...53%
 Perot...76,478...11%
 
SENATE - 70% reporting
 Bumpers (D)...364,714...59%
 Huckabee (R)...251,014...41%
 
FLORIDA
Florida came to epitomize Mr. Bush's difficulties. Four years ago, he won the state by nearly a million votes. But late last night, with 70 percent of the vote counted, the race in this former Republican stronghold remained too close to call.
Mr. Perot, meanwhile, was enjoying one of his best showings. He had made one of his few campaign appearances here, in Tampa, where he drew a packed house.
Governor Clinton had been benefiting from the economic fears of Floridians, unaccustomed to the downturn in their boom economy. The Democratic National Committee ran television advertisements that courted the elderly by asserting that the Republicans would cut the Medicare program.
The Republicans countered with their familiar charges that Mr. Clinton lacked character and fiscal restraint.
Senator Bob Graham, a Democrat won an easy re-election race against Bill Grant, a business consultant and ex-Congressman.
Mr. Graham, the state's most popular politician, did not extend more than perfunctory support to Mr. Clinton.
The state's Congressional delegation is expanding by four seats, to 23, at a time when six members of its delegation are retiring. It is now split between 10 Republicans and 9 Democrats, a ratio that could be reversed.
A referendum that would impose an eight-year term limit on state legislators, and members of the state executive branch and of Congress seemed likely to pass easily.

GEORGIA
 Georgia gave George Bush an overwhelming margin four years ago, but the Southern-grown Democratic ticket of Bill Clinton and Al Gore was declared the victor by the network consortium that surveyed voters leaving the polls. The same consortium projected that Wyche Fowler Jr., the one-term Democratic Senator, would defeat Paul Coverdell, a former state chairman of the Republican Party.
Mr. Coverdell had boasted of his association with President Bush, whom he once pronounced "one of the strongest Presidential personalities in history." As Mr. Bush's popularity plummetted, Mr. Coverdell mentioned him less frequently.
Democrats tried hard to insure Mr. Fowler's re-election, seeing that he campaigned with Georgia's senior Senator, Sam Nunn, an enormously popular figure.
Most gripping among several interesting House contests was Representative Newt Gingrich's bid for re-election from a newly drawn district. Democrats salivated at the prospect of forcing the retirement of Mr. Gingrich, a slashing partisan fighter. His Democratic opponent, Tony Center, is a trial lawyer.

 Fowler (D)...595,010...51%
 
KENTUCKY...CLINTON
After a hard-fought race in which both candidates made last-minute campaign visits, Mr. Clinton defeated Mr. Bush to take Kentucky's eight electoral votes. Mr. Bush, who won Kentucky handily in 1988, attacked Mr. Clinton's policies as dangerous to local industries like automobile manufacturing and coal mining.
But in his visits, Mr. Clinton emphasized his experience as Governor of a Southern state, a tactic that also worked well for Jimmy Carter in 1976, the last time Kentucky voted Democratic.
In the Senate race, the Democratic incumbent, Wendell H. Ford, the majority whip, easily defeated David Williams, a Republican State Senator.

 Clinton...659,706...45%
 Perot...202,739...14%

LOUISIANA...CLINTON
Mr. Clinton won Louisiana from the Republicans for the first time the Democrats have taken the state since 1976. He enjoyed strong support from two leading Democrats, Senator John B. Breaux and Representative William J. Jefferson, who backed the Governor before he was the presumptive nominee. Mr. Bush won easily in 1988, in part by portraying himself as an oil man who would help the state's troubled chief industry. But oil remains depressed.
The Republicans ran commercials that featured comments made by Mr. Gore calling for a ban on offshore drilling in all coastal waters. The Democrats responded that Mr. Clinton had not called for a ban.
Mr. Bush made seven visits this year, seeking the state's nine electoral votes, and Mr. Clinton visited five times.
In the state's Congressional races, Mr. Breaux cruised to re-election on Oct. 3 by capturing a majority in an open primary.
The nation's only standoff between two incumbent Republicans, Representatives Clyde Holloway and Richard H. Baker, remained too close to call at midnight.
In another fight between incumbents, Jim McCrery, a conservative Republican, defeated Jerry Huckaby, a Democrat who had 88 overdrafts on the House bank.
 
 PRESIDENT - 99% Reporting
 Bush...719,910...41%
 Clinton...808,069 746,660...47%
 Perot...207,215...12%
 
MISSISSIPPI...BUSH
Despite Republican strength in the state, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore both come from neighboring states, and the Democrats campaigned in Mississippi as they sought unsuccessfully to chip away at the Republican grip over the South.
Among the unknown factors this year was how enthusiastically blacks, who make up 36 percent of the electorate but were not aggressively courted by the Democrats, would turn out for Mr. Clinton and the Democrats.
Mississippi had five Democrats in Congress, all elected the last time around with overwhelming majorities. But Representative Jamie L. Whitten, the dean of the delegation who has spent 50 years bringing back the bacon to his constituents, is now 82 years old and in ill health. Republicans, sensing vulnerability, put up Clyde E. Whitaker, a former Mayor of Tupelo. Mr. Whitten had run unopposed 18 times; Mr. Whitaker said Congressional terms should be limited. For Mr. Whitten, it was one last stand for incumbency.
 
PRESIDENT - 88% reporting
 Bush...411,346...50%
 Clinton...336,952...41%
 Perot...74,142...9%
 
NORTH CAROLINA
North Carolina, with 14 electoral votes, is the third biggest prize in the South after Texas and Florida. As in those states, Mr. Clinton decided to go all out, regularly visiting the state and sending Mr. Gore for a last-minute stop on Monday.
Mr. Clinton sought to become the first Democratic contender to capture the state since 1976.
Senator Terry Sanford was upset by his Republican challenger, Launch Faircloth, a former Sanford ally, after a tight, hotly fought race. Mr. Faircloth, a businessman and farmer, reminded voters of Mr. Sanford's opposition to the Persian Gulf war and made an issue of the Senator's recent heart operation.
In the governor's race, the Democrat, Jim Hunt, beat Jim Gardner, the Republican who had been Lieutenant Governor since 1989.
Two Democrats in House races, Eva Clayton and Mel Watt, won, becoming the first blacks to represent North Carolina in the House since 1901.

OKLAHOMA...BUSH
Oklahoma is about as Republican as any state in Presidential politics, and Mr. Bush was an easy winner.
Steve Lewis, a Democrat who is the former Speaker of the State House, failed to make a strong showing against Senator Don Nickles, the Republican incumbent, in part because he was short of money.
Mr. Lewis made an issue of Mr. Nickles's strong opposition to abortion rights, a novel approach in a Bible Belt state. Mr. Nickles, who was chairman of the Republican platform committee, might have been vulnerable on that issue in other states.
The Democrats were expected to hold their 4-to-2 advantage in House seats. Representative James M. Inhofe, a Republican, once again faced a tough challenge but was expected to slip by.

 Perot...303,404...23%

SOUTH CAROLINA...BUSH
Though South Carolina was one of President Bush's best states in 1988, he had to scurry with an 11th-hour whistle-stop tour to win the state's eight electoral votes.
The close Presidential race gave a boost to Senator Ernest F. Hollings, the veteran Democrat, whom Republicans marked as vulnerable as soon as he had voted against authorizing United States participation in the Persian Gulf war. Mr. Hollings made a number of gaffes, but by early evening he was also projected to win. But his challenger, former Representative Tommy Hartnett, failed to muster enough money and his advertisement that linked Mr. Hollings to gay rights appeared to backfire.
Democrats were expected to keep their 4-to-2 edge over Republicans in the House. Jim Clyburn was expected to win easily and become the first black member of the delegation.

 Hollings (D)...536,656...52%
 
TENNESSEE...CLINTON
Governor Clinton's choice of Senator Gore as his running mate put this state into the Democratic column.
The last Democrat to capture Tennessee's 11 electoral votes was Jimmy Carter of neighboring Georgia in 1976.
Despite polls showing a predictable Democratic lead, Mr. Bush, Mr. Quayle and surrogates, including Lamar Alexander, the state's former Governor and now Education Secretary, had all campaigned there in hopes of taking the state from the Democrats. Mr. Quayle made Tennessee one of his last stops before Election Day.
Mr. Gore, however, got in the last word, since he returned to Tennessee for two rallies yesterday before casting his vote there.
The Democrats counted on Mr. Gore's coattails not only to help Mr. Clinton but also to bolster showings by Democratic members of Tennessee's delegation in the House.
Marilyn Lloyd in the Third Congressional District faced an easier time than in the past, when in order to win re-election she usually had to outperform the Democrat at the head of the ticket by thousands of votes. So did Bart Gordon in the Sixth District.
Even David Davis, a minister, hoped to benefit in the Seventh District from the strength of the Presidential ticket in challenging Don Sundquist, the five-term Republican incumbent.
 
PRESIDENT - 93% reporting
 Bush...750,934...42%
 Clinton...858,095...48%
 Perot...179,733...10%
 
TEXAS...BUSH
On this rock Presidential strategies begin: The candidate must carry his home state. Since World War II, all the winners have done so.
But in 1992, more so than ever, the Republicans saw Texas, Mr. Bush's adopted home state, as crucial to a second term. He won the state's 32 electoral votes, even though it was not enough to win him the election.
It was a measure of the President's woes, as well as a reflection of Mr. Clinton's regional appeal, that Mr. Bush worked so hard in Texas, outspending Mr. Clinton on direct media expenses by more than $3 million.
Mr. Bush won the state by 12.7 percentage points four years ago. Surveys of voters also indicated that Mr. Perot's maverick campaign hurt Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton virtually evenly in the state.
Three veteran Democrats in the House who wrote many overdrafts on House bank accounts were vulnerable to anti-incumbent sentiments. Representative Charles Wilson, a 20-year veteran from East Texas who had 81 overdrafts, overcame a stiff challenge from Donna Peterson, a Republican. A five-term incumbent, Ronald D. Coleman of El Paso who wrote 673 overdrafts, faced Chip Taberski, a popular sportscaster. Representative Albert G. Bustamante of Laredo, under Federal investigation for helping a friend win a bingo contract on an Indian reservation, lost to Henry Bonilla, a Republican television executive.
 
PRESIDENT - 87% reporting
 Bush...2,218,065...41%
 Clinton...2,049,762...38%
 Perot...1,188,907...22%
 
VIRGINIA...BUSH
President Bush won by a sizable margin in Virginia, which had not given its 13 electoral votes to a Democrat since the Lyndon B. Johnson won in a landslide in 1964. Still, the race had been tighter than some had expected, especially after one debate, held in Richmond, hurt Mr. Bush and gave Mr. Clinton momentum.
The state's Congressional districts were extensively redrawn, resulting in sure bets in some House races and in close races elsewhere. But incumbents did not suffer at the hands of the voters; eight of the state's House members were re-elected.
The creation of a district with a 64 percent black population, guaranteed that the winner of the Democratic primary, State Senator Robert C. Scott, would become the first black sent to the House by the state in this century. He won easily.
In another new district, the 11th in the suburbs of Washington, Leslie L. Byrne, a Democrat, became the first woman elected by Virginians to the House. Mr. Bush's coattails proved inadequate for Henry Butler, a Republican economics professor.

 Perot...276,408...14%

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE;
Midwest

 BODY:
ILLINOIS...CLINTON
Illinoians made history by sending Carol Moseley Braun, the 45-year-old Cook County Recorder of Deeds, to the United States Senate. Ms. Braun will be the first black woman, as well as the first black Democrat, ever in the United States Senate.
With nearly two-thirds of the vote counted, Ms. Braun, a former State Senator, had won 56 percent of the vote, with the remainder going to the Republican, Rich Williamson.
Surveys of voters leaving polls showed that Ms. Braun had scored particularly well among women, but won among men by only two points. Ms. Braun won 93 percent of the black vote, but only 49 percent of white votes. 
 The Senate campaign overshadowed the Presidential contest, in which Mr. Clinton won overwhelmingly.
Bobby Rush, a former Black Panther, won a House seat on Chicago's South Side. Another Chicagoan, Luis V. Gutierrez, will become Illinois's first Hispanic House member. Donald Manzullo, a Republican, defeated the Democratic incumbent in the district once held by Secretary of Labor Lynn Martin.
 
PRESIDENT - 62% reporting
 Bush...959,182...34%
 Clinton...1,423,859...50%
 Perot...461,500...16%
 
 SENATE - 64% reporting
 Braun (D)...1,574,755...56%
 Williamson (R)...1,241,356...44%
 
INDIANA...BUSH
Vice President Quayle's home state has gone Democratic in only one election since 1932, that being 1964. Yesterday's voting continued that trend, as Mr. Bush won the state's 12 electoral votes.
The President visited the state just once during the general election campaign, but sent in a steady stream of surrogates, including Mr. Quayle and his wife, Marilyn, and Labor Secretary Lynn Martin. Nevertheless, as state polls showed Mr. Clinton gaining ground in October, the Republicans were forced to invest in local television commercials, even though Mr. Clinton never campaigned or advertised in Indiana.
Other incumbents were also successful in Indiana. Senator Daniel R. Coats, a Republican, fended off a challenge from the Democratic Secretary of State, Joe Hogsett. Mr. Hogsett never recovered from a damaging radio advertising volley from Senator Coats that portrayed Mr. Hogsett as a career politician who had broken a pledge to serve out his term as Secretary of State. .
Gov. Evan Bayh, a Democrat first elected in 1988 at the age of 32, also held onto his job, defeating the Republican, Linley E. Pearson, the State Attorney General.

 Hogsett (D)...766,110...42%

IOWA...CLINTON
Mr. Clinton experienced some surprising difficulties in a state that backed Michael S. Dukakis in 1988, but with more than two-thirds of vote in, he had established a comfortable lead over Mr. Bush.
With Senator Charles E. Grassley, the in-cumbent and a Republican, crushing his Democratic challenger, State Senator Jean Lloyd-Jones, interest in the state's Congressional delegation focused on two House seats affected by redistricting.
In a race between two incumbents, Jim Nussle, a Republican who won fame by wearing a bag over his head on the floor of the chamber to symbolize his disgust over the House banking scandal, held a small lead over Democrat Dave Nagle with 70 percent of the vote counted.
In southern Iowa, Jim Ross Lightfoot, a Republican member of the House Appropriations Committee tarnished by 105 overdrafts at the House bank, established a more comfortable margin over Elaine Baxter, the Iowa Secretary of State.
