HEADLINE: Major Barely Wins Test Vote on European Union

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
Prime Minister John Major narrowly beat back an alliance of Conservative Party rebels and rival Labor Party politicians who came within three votes tonight of dealing the Government's political authority a crippling setback.
In a highly charged showdown in the House of Commons, Mr. Major and his aides managed to cobble together a coalition of some 300 Conservative loyalists and members of the small, pro-European Liberal Democratic Party to pass, 319 to 316, a symbolic motion that pledged his Government "to play a leading role in the development of the European Community." 
 In doing so, Mr. Major managed to pry away just enough waverers from a quarrelsome core of 35 Tory rebels bitterly opposed to Mr. Major's support for the treaty on European union. They had been joined by nearly all 270 members of the opposition Labor Party, whose pro-European leadership had seized on the issue hoping to deal Mr. Major a lethal blow.
The Prime Minister, whose Government has been forced into several embarrassing reversals on economic and monetary policy in recent weeks, had staked his personal and political prestige on winning the motion.
Mr. Major's victory came after hours of intense lobbying among wavering Tory backbenchers, at least one of whom was reduced to tears tonight after a session with party whips.
While Mr. Major narrowly reasserted his authority tonight, the matter of the treaty is not resolved. The House of Commons will now begin to debate it in full, leading toward a final ratification vote, likely early next year.
The ongoing rebellion among Tory backbenchers insures the the 651-seat House of Commons will be the scene of considerable political drama through the winter, since Mr. Major and his Government hold only a 21-seat majority, as a result of their victory in national elections last spring.
Warning that Britain could be left without influence on the fringe of Europe, should it turn its back on European union, Mr. Major declared in an impassioned, 50-minute speech that Britain's "national self-interest" was at stake in the vote.
On the surface, the vote had little procedural impact, merely setting out when the House of Commons was to resume debate on ratification of the treaty, agreed to by Mr. Major and other European leaders last year in the Dutch city of Maastricht.
But the Prime Minister said he wanted the backing of the Commons to strengthen his hand when he gathers with other European leaders at a summit meeting next month in Edinburgh to discuss differences over the future of European political and monetary union, including ways to limit the power of bureaucrats in Brussels.
As European leaders prepared for next month's summit, there are continuing strains within the community over the treaty, which must be ratified by all 12 members state to take effect.
In addition to British wavering, the Danes, who already rejected the agreement once in a nationwide referendum, say they would be willing to put the treaty up for a second vote only if the community agrees to legally binding exemptions from the treaty.
The Danes want to be exempted from joining a single currency, adopting a common defense policy or surrendering sovereignty over judicial and police matters, but some European officials feel the Danish demands go too far, because they might require changes in the text of the treaty.
Before passing its own motion, the British Government's supporters also defeated a Labor amendment to delay debate on the treaty, 319 to 313.
The votes followed seven hours of noisy debate in Commons. Labor backbenchers taunted the Prime Minister with calls of "Goodbye John."
Both sides accused their opponents of political opportunism. During the debate, John Smith, the Labor leader, sharply criticized the Government for turning what was ostensibly a motion on the European treaty into a vote of confidence.
The Conservatives, in turn, attacked Mr. Smith and Labor for betraying their own pro-European agenda, by seeking to delay progress toward ratification of the treaty.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: THE WORLD -- NEWS ANALYSIS;
At Dawn of New Politics, Challenges for Both Parties

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
The Democrats came out of the political wilderness on Tuesday. The Republicans entered it.
The Democrats set aside all the self-doubts, the years of feeling on the wrong side of history, the election nights when the proud party of Roosevelt, Truman and Kennedy seemed consigned to a painful irrelevance. 
 Ahead is the challenge of governing, and the clear accountability that comes with controlling both Congress and the White House. No more political cover for the Democrats, no more room for fingerpointing between Capitol Hill and the White House, no more excuses.
But the Republicans face the hard, brutal struggle of deciding who they are, resolving the tensions between moderates, conservatives, evangelical Christians, country-clubbers, supply-siders, suburbanites -- all the disparate elements held together by Ronald Reagan that collapsed under President Bush.
 
Perot Over the Shoulder
 The task of both parties will be complicated by Ross Perot, who served notice this week that he has no intention of fading away.
He certainly didn't fade in the voting on Tuesday. While he did not win a state, as George Wallace did when he captured five in 1968, Mr. Perot polled 19 percent of the popular vote nationwide, compared with Mr. Wallace's 13.5 percent. And while that showing was certainly stoked with Mr. Perot's money, people in both parties worried that it was also fueled by a disaffection with the parties themselves.
But Democrats were not much given to worries this week. It would be hard to exaggerate their euphoria, especially the generation in its 30's and 40's that spent its adulthood out of power, told again and again that it was "out of the mainstream."
"It was like having been a member of a religious minority in a country with a state religion," said David Dreyer, communications director for Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader.
 
Rethinking a 'Lock'
 Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, gleefully announced that the Republican "electoral lock" on the White House was "broken forever." Allowing for overstatement, the Republicans' aura of invinicibility -- which was very real in the 1980's -- was certainly gone.
Mr. Clinton carried the popular vote in the East, the Midwest and the West, and fought Mr. Bush to a standstill in the popular vote in the South, the region that was the basis of the Republican "electoral lock." He held the party's base, bought home many of the Reagan Democrats and struck deep into the suburbs and the ranks of independents and moderates.
Centrist Democrats viewed the Clinton candidacy as a vindication of their long struggle to push the party to the center, to broaden its base and reconnect with the middle class, to shatter the view that the party was a mere collection of liberal constituent groups. But the Rev. Jesse Jackson, a principal spokesman for the party's left, asserted yesterday that Mr. Clinton's victory was largely a result of broader forces: a bad economy, the votes of blacks energized by black candidacies this year and the mobilization of women by what he calls "the Anita Hill factor."
 
Understanding the Stakes
 Those tensions will remain in the party, and will become more than debating points when Mr. Clinton takes office and begins to make policy on trade, welfare, education, jobs and taxes. Some Republicans took a little quiet pleasure yesterday in predicting the ideological tugs and pulls of a Clinton Presidency, particularly as they will play out in the Administration's relations with Congress.
But Stan Greenberg, Mr. Clinton's poll taker and a principal strategist for his campaign, said both Congressional Democrats and Mr. Clinton understood the stakes and the responsibilities of one-party government.
"Congressional Democrats understand they're on the line, and the Clinton Administration will understand it. There has to be movement," Mr. Greenberg said.
Hanging over both is the memory of the last Democratic Administration, when relations between President Jimmy Carter and the Democratic-controlled Congress were hardly a model of partisan cooperation, for which both paid a price.
 
Clouds Over Republicans
 Republicans, for their part, face a much more fundamental task, as any Democrat who tried to pick up the pieces after 1980, 1984 and 1988 will attest. Their long hegemony in Presidential politics is over, and it did not leave the lasting gains in Congress or below that many Republicans had hoped for. Their political professionals seem sapped by the long, enervating campaign of Mr. Bush, and the exit polls carried chilling news, notably the strength of Mr. Clinton among the young.
The faultlines in the party are clear, beginning with the social agenda of the religious right, including abortion. And ahead lies the challenge of finding a new governing conservatism that can regain the loyalties of voters who seem to demand a new domestic agenda and who simply seemed to lose faith with the Republicans on the economy, as they lost faith with the Democrats 12 years ago. All of this will play out in the early jockeying for 1996.
 
Appeal to Perot
 Many Republicans are expecting a fight as the party enters its wilderness sojourn. "The first verbal assault will come from the right, which will argue that if the Republicans were just purer, they'd be in no trouble," said Representative Jim Leach, a moderate Iowa Republican. "The second assessment, from the more mainstream and the public at large, will be that the party has become too co-opted by narrow groups."
Mr. Leach added, "I personally think a great challenge for the party will be to establish a sense of tolerance."
The battle for control of the party could begin this winter, around the chairmanship of the Republican National Committee.
In the midst of all this is the Perot factor.
If the exit polls showed anything on Tuesday, they showed that Mr. Perot is a force to be reckoned with by both parties; he drew roughly equally from both.
Mr. Clinton clearly recognizes that, making a gesture of outreach Tuesday night to the Perot supporters on the issue of government reform and "reducing the influence of the special interest," one of Mr. Perot's favorite themes. "I will work with him to do that," Mr. Clinton said.
The major parties have long adapted to -- and co-opted -- third forces in politics, many analysts note. But not many third forces have behind them the Perot fortune, which this year proved to give Mr. Perot's movement considerable staying power.
Kevin Phillips, the conservative analyst, suggests that Perot backers could become major players in the struggle for control of Republican parties in some states.
It is all part of the mix of the politics to come.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: VOTERS -- THE POLLS;
Despite Some Puzzling Readings, '92 Polls Came Through at End

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr.

 BODY:
As in most election years, poll takers had their own ups and downs during the 1992 Presidential race.
Most came within two or three percentage points of predicting the margins by which Gov. Bill Clinton would beat President Bush and Ross Perot. In fact, most major poll takers came within one point of Mr. Clinton's percentage of the vote. 
 But earlier in the year there were some total misses by poll takers, as well as some inexplicable readings.
One of the significant misses occurred during the New Hampshire primary in February, when some surveys of voters leaving polling places, the so-called exit polls used by news organizations to predict eventual outcome, indicated that Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative columnist, would run stronger against President Bush than he actually did.
 
Late Surge Questioned
 As for puzzling readings of voter preferences during the year, none stirred more debate than two polls by the Gallup Organization over the weekend of Oct. 28-29, one for Newsweek, the other for CNN and USA Today. They indicated that President Bush was making a late surge and had closed to within one to two points of Mr. Clinton.
Most other polls at that point were showing a spread at least twice that large, and many poll takers questioned the timing of the Gallup sampling and the composition and breadth of its sample. The Gallup Organization insisted it had detected a genuine Bush surge, even if the surge eventually fell back.
Overall, the performance of poll takers this year compared favorably with their projections in 1988, when they also came within two or three points of predicting the winning margin. Their 1992 performance was slightly better than their 1980 performance, when some missed the final spread by as much as seven points, and better still than in 1984, when some missed by as much as eight points.
 
The Year of the Poll
 "This has been a polling year with some bad things but also some good things," said Martin Wattenberg, a political scientist at the University of California at San Diego who specializes in public opinion surveys. "There were too many polls, many of them not carefully done. Early on, they indicated Ross Perot was a real player, when in fact the voters being polled didn't really know anything about him. On the other hand, this was the year that a lot of news organizations finally began to run the results of other polls with the results of their own polls. That provided people with some badly needed context."
In the end, five of six major polls, exhibiting unusual agreement, indicated at the end that Mr. Clinton would win 44 percent of the vote. The sixth predicted 43 percent.
His final margin: 43 percent.
Most polls predicted that Mr. Bush would get from 35 to 38 percent of the final vote. His final figure: 38 percent.
"People like to criticize us, but I think poll takers had a remarkably good year," said Frank Newport, the president of the Gallup Organization.

HEADLINE: Kenya Sets Date for First Open Vote in 3 Decades

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 4

 BODY:
Nearly a year after opening up the political system under foreign and domestic pressure, President Daniel arap Moi has announced that this country's first multiparty elections in nearly three decades will be held on Dec. 7.
The decision on Tuesday comes amid concern about how fair the elections will be. 
 Although this East African country was once regarded as one of the most politically mature in Africa, it has lagged in introducing a multiparty democratic system. The scheduled elections here would follow about 20 other open elections across Africa in the last year.
Mr. Moi, the second President in Kenya's 29 years since independence, has ruled for 14 years.
Until last December, after the World Bank suspended new financial aid because of Kenya's resistance to political liberalization, Mr. Moi ruled over a single-party state with an increasingly authoritarian hand. His Government was regarded by many Kenyans and some major Western donors as blatantly corrupt, a factor that moved donors, including the United States, to reduce aid.
Since the legalization of opposition parties, two new major parties and about eight other minor parties have emerged. One of the two main opposition parties, the Forum for the Restoration of Democracy, went through months of internal bickering and finally split into two parts last month.
The fragmentation within the Forum, led by politicians of the 68-year-old Mr. Moi's generation, disappointed many Kenyans who were looking forward to a strong challenge to the ruling party, the Kenya African National Union, known as KANU.
The current issue of Society, a new magazine that has been unfriendly toward the Government, said this week: "While it is clear Mr. Moi's party has lost its grip in most parts of the country, it is also clear that none of the opposition parties has wide national versatility like KANU. Without forming a united front, there is little doubt KANU will, through hook or crook, hang them."
The Forum split along tribal lines. Jaramogi Oginga Odinga, a Luo from western Kenya and former Vice President, leads one faction. Kenneth Matiba, a Kikuyu and former Cabinet minister, who was detained for almost a year in 1990 by Mr. Moi for urging an end to one-party rule, leads the other.
Another party, the Democratic Party, is led by a former Vice President and Finance Minister, Mwai Kibaki, who is also from the Kikuyu tribe, the largest and wealthiest in Kenya.
Political rallies have been held with frequency in the last few months, but many of them have been marred by violence.
A meeting held by Mr. Moi's party last month at which his vice president, George Saitoti, appeared was interrupted by hecklers. Mr. Saitoti denounced the hecklers by yelling "Burn D.P.," the Democratic Party, "Burn the Devil," and "Burn FORD," the Forum. Stones were then thrown toward Mr. Saitoti.
 
Monitoring of Vote
 Under pressure from Western donors, the Government agreed to delegations of foreign observers for the elections, but not as many or as much in advance as Zambia allowed for its first open elections, which were held last year.
The American Ambassador here, Smith Hempstone, said in a speech last month that while Mr. Moi had pledged free and fair elections, "there's always the 10 percent who don't get the word."
"In this instance, I'm afraid the percentage may be considerably higher," he added.
Mr. Hempstone said his skepticism was caused by the Government's refusal to allow for an effective domestic monitoring system on election day.
He said it was not a good sign that the registration process had been terminated before one million young people, who did not have Government identification cards, had a chance to register. He said he was also disturbed about reports that teachers, civil servants, soldiers and police officers had been "admonished" to vote for Mr. Moi's party.

SECTION: Section B; Page 6; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1359 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: CONGRESS -- THE NEW CONGRESS;
Democrats Promise Quick Action on a Clinton Plan

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

 BODY:
Democrats moved quickly yesterday to commit the 103d Congress to fast action on President-elect Clinton's legislative plans, saying the election results assured him of effective support on Capitol Hill.
Starved for legislative successes against President Bush, they have told each other, Mr. Clinton and reporters that they expect to be able to pass his main proposals, once he tells them what they are, in the first months of his Administration. That is when unity, rather than individual agendas, will matter most politically. 
 Remarkably slim Democratic losses in the House gave force to that promise, as the Democrats ended up with 259 seats, or only nine less than they have now. And the increase in young, black, Hispanic and female members seems likely to leave the new House more liberal and committed to action than the old.
But while Democrats held their own in the Senate against initially difficult odds, they did not make the gains needed to squelch determined opposition, which Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, indicated he would often provide.
 
Filibuster Calculations
 The final tally in the Senate gave Democrats 57 seats, as many as they hold now, and the Republicans 42, or enough to prevent bills from coming to a vote with united opposition. It takes 60 votes to end a filibuster.
One Senate seat will be decided Nov. 24 in a runoff between Senator Wyche Fowler of Georgia and Paul Coverdell, a Republican. Georgia law requires a runoff if no candidate gets more than half the vote, and Mr. Fowler got 49 percent.
The new Congress will have 110 new representatives, the most since the 118 elected in 1948, and 11 to 13 new senators, depending on results in the Fowler-Coverdell runoff and a special election in North Dakota on Dec. 4.
It will have nearly double the numbers of women, blacks and Hispanic lawmakers. There will be six women in the Senate with the elections of Dianne Feinstein and Barbara Boxer in California, Carol Moseley Braun in Illinois and Patty Murray in Washington, and the re-election of Barbara A. Mikulski in Maryland. All are Democrats. There is also one Republican woman, Senator Nancy Kassebaum of Kansas.
 
Increase in Women
 The House will have 47 women, up from 28. Thirty-five will be Democrats, up from 19, and 12 will be Republicans, up from 9.
Along with Ms. Braun, who is black, in the Senate, there will be 38 blacks in the House, an increase of 13, including the first blacks elected in this century from North Carolina, South Carolina, Virginia, Alabama and Florida. All but one are Democrats.
The ranks of Hispanic lawmakers will increase from 10 to 17. Three are Republicans. The first lawmaker of Korean descent, Jay Kim, was elected in California as a Republican, and Representative Ben Nighthorse Campbell, a Colorado Democrat, will be the first American Indian in the Senate in 60 years.
House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said on the NBC News program "Today" that its demographic changes would help make the new Congress more representative of the American people and more in tune "with the message of change and movement."
Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Senate majority leader, said at a news conference that he expected Mr. Clinton to present n agenda for action early next year. "I know President-elect Clinton wants to act," he said. "The American people want to act. And we in the Democratic majority in the Senate and the House want to act."
And Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, said in an interview that control of both the White House and Congress came with heavy responsibilities to solve the problems the nation faces. He also said Mr. Clinton would also "reach out to moderate Republicans" to get his bills passed.
But Senator Dole, while offering to cooperate "where we can," also asserted a Republican duty to "reflect the views of the Republicans, the independents, the Perot supporters who did not vote for Clinton and watch out for more taxes and more spending." He also on appeared "Today."
Mr. Gephardt explained the Democrats' success in holding their House losses in single digits by arguing that his party hd concentrated on the economy while Republicans emphasized subjects of less impact on most voters, like political reform of Congress.
The results seemed to support his assertion and not that of Representative Guy Vander Jagt of Michigan, the chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, that the gain of nine seats was a remarkable achievement.
He justified that description by saying it was the first time in this century that House Republicans had gained seats while their Presidential candidate lost an election. But in fact Republicans hoped as late as yesterday morning to gain as many as two dozen seats. Earlier in the year, they dreamed of controlling the House for the first time since 1953.
In the end, few leading lawmakers were defeated, though many had the toughest race of their careers. Mr. Foley, for example, got only 55 percent of the vote. Perhaps the two most effective legislators to lose were a pair of New Yorkers, Bill Green, a Republican, and Thomas J. Downey, a Democrat.
But there was one clear indication that the nation's anti-incumbent mood was deferred, not destroyed. Voters in 14 states passed initiatives to limit how long lawmakers can serve in Congress. Those measures, which have different specifications and effective dates, are sure to be challenged on the ground that the only the Federal Constitution can establish requirements for holding Federal office.
The results might have been much different if Democrats had not won 21 of the 35 races decided by four percentage points or less.
They also improved, compared with 1990, in holding their own core voters. This time, interviews with 12,875 voters leaving polling places showed that 89 percent of Democrats said they had voted for Democrats for the House. In 1990, a poll by Voter Research and Surveys, the television network polling combine, showed 79 percent staying with the party.
 
Where Republicans Prevailed
 In the Senate contests, victories in close races were crucial to the Republicans' ability to hold their own. In five races won by four percentage points or less, they won four.
In New Hampshire, Gov. Judd Gregg, with 50 percent of the vote, defeated John Rauh, a retired corporate executive, who got 48 percent. They battled to succeed Senator Warren Rudman, who retired.
In New York, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato won a third term with 51 percent of the vote, defeating state Attorney General Robert Abrams, who got 49 percent.
In North Carolina, Lauch Faircloth, a former appointed state official, defeated a one-time friend, Senator Terry Sanford, with 52 percent to 48 percent. Mr. Sanford, a former Governor and president of Duke University, had been in public life for 40 years. But at 75, he was attacked as too old, especially after he interrupted campaigning last month for surgery to replace a heart valve.
In Pennsylvania, Senator Arlen Specter won a third term with a 51-to-49 victory over Lynn H. Yeakel, who began her campaign against him in reaction to his hostile questioning of Prof. Anita F. Hill over her accusations of sexual harassment against Clarence Thomas, the Supreme Court nominee.
 
Close Race Goes Democratic
 The only Democrat to win a race that close was Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina, who got 51 percent to the 49 percent recorded by former Representative Thomas F. Hartnett. Mr. Hollings, who was first elected in 1966, is one of the longest-serving junior senators in history. Strom Thurmond, elected in 1954, is the state's senior senator.
Other Republicans prevailed after races that were closer than expected. Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon won his fifth term with 52.2 percent of the vote to the 47.8 percent recorded by Representative Les AuCoin.
The two Republican incumbents who lost were Senator John Seymour, defeated by Ms. Boxer after being appointed to the seat last year, and Bob Kasten of Wisconsin, beaten by State Senator Russell Feingold.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: THE WORLD -- FOREIGN POLICY;
Clinton Warns U.S. Foes And Reassures Its Friends

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton's declaration today that no foreign nation should "doubt America's resolve" during this transition period was intended to signal adversaries, particularly President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, that they should not try to test the young new American leader, Clinton aides said.
Mr. Clinton's statement also appeared, in part, to be an effort to address any lingering public doubts that his lack of experience in foreign affairs and his efforts to avoid military service during the Vietnam War would in some way diminish his abilities to be an effective Commander in Chief. 
 Mr. Clinton and his foreign policy aides concluded in the weeks leading up to the election that if he won, the leaders of Iraq, Iran or China -- whose elderly statesmen have grandchildren Mr. Clinton's age -- might be tempted to test him when he takes office in January.
Clinton aides were specifically concerned that a foreign leader might try to take advantage of the Arkansas Governor's foreign policy inexperience, recalling that Nikita S. Khrushchev thought he could take advantage of President John F. Kennedy after the botched effort to topple Fidel Castro of Cuba in 1961.
 
Facing Hussein's Glee
 When Mr. Clinton was receiving foreign policy briefings during the campaign, he often asked experts: "Where will I be tested first? What should I say to prevent that?" one adviser recalled.
Clinton aides said today's statement was carefully written with such questions in mind, and it got an extra jolt after the news that President Hussein fired his gun into the air in defiant celebration of President Bush's electoral defeat. As one Clinton adviser put it: "The only world leader who was unreservedly for Bill Clinton is Saddam Hussein, and we have to make sure he regrets that."
It may have seemed odd that Mr. Clinton, who ran a campaign focused on domestic economic concerns, would use his first statement the morning after his election to send a foreign policy message. But the choice reflected the sense among many Clinton foreign policy advisers, as well as senior Bush Administration officials, that while the nation has been focused inward on the campaign and domestic affairs, serious problems have begun brewing abroad and will be inherited by Mr. Clinton.
Hyperinflation and challenges from right-wing extremists are threatening to topple the democratically elected government of President Boris N. Yeltsin in Russia, which has already put on hold the withdrawal of troops from the Baltic republics and is backtracking on some of its agreements with the Bush Administration to destroy nuclear arms. Meanwhile, a series of ethnic wars are flaring up around its borders.
Iran's increasingly aggressive behavior and arms buildup has prompted the United States to augment its naval presence in the Persian Gulf as a counterweight. Other problems, like the prospect of further widespread starvation this winter in Bosnia and Somalia or a potential breakdown of the Arab-Israeli peace talks, could be enough to derail Mr. Clinton's plans to be first and foremost a domestic President.
As Defense Secretary Dick Cheney remarked on the eve of the election, "I would put forward the proposition that the next set of American policy makers will face tougher challenges, more difficult problems than anything we have had to deal with over the course of the last four or five years."
Mr. Clinton's statement today was also intended to be a note of reassurance to longtime allies. When Mr. Clinton said he wanted to "reaffirm the essential continuity of American foreign policy," he did so with the knowledge that certain important American allies, like Saudi Arabia, Japan and some European nations, are extremely uneasy about the passing of the Republican Bush Administration, with which they had worked closely.
King Fahd of Saudi Arabia had a strong personal relationship with Mr. Bush, with whom he planned the gulf war, and the Saudis were quietly rooting for his re-election. The Japanese are very wary of the protectionist instincts within the Democratic Party, as opposed to Mr. Bush's unabashed free-trade instincts, and the Europeans have always been more comfortable with Mr. Bush's unsentimental realpolitik view of the world than traditional liberal democratic instincts.
Mr. Clinton, aides said, wanted to get off on the right foot with all of them by signaling from the outset that there will be much more continuity in American foreign policy than might have been suggested by the heated campaign debates.
With an eye to the problems that he might inherit, and with an effort to put the best face possible on them, Mr. Clinton declared that he looked forward to "working closely with President Bush to insure continuity in global affairs of interest to all Americans, from continued progress in the Mideast peace talks, to completing negotiations on the details of the Start II arms control agreement, to making progress toward a good agreement on our world trade talks, to bolstering Russia's fledgling democracy, to working toward peaceful resolution of the conflict in the republics of the former Yugoslavia, to assisting the victims of famine in Somalia."
Mr. Clinton, aides said, specifically mentioned the Arab-Israeli peace talks because all the various parties are returning to Washington on Monday to resume negotiations, which have been stalled on all fronts save for Israel and Jordan.
The message Mr. Clinton wanted to send to both Arabs and Israelis, say aides, is that progress in their peace talks will be a foreign policy priority. The negotiators, they said, should therefore remain seriously engaged and not withhold concessions just to see what will happen after he takes office. With everything else he will have to worry about, Mr. Clinton does not want to have to worry about reviving these negotiations as well.
While Mr. Clinton indicated his intention to maintain the continuity of American foreign policy in the Persian Gulf, he may not have the resources in the region to do it. At the end of December Turkey is scheduled to decide whether it will continue to let its air bases be used as part of the gulf war military coalition, and in specific for maintaining the no-fly zone over northern Iraq and the relief effort for Iraqi Kurds.
At the moment, political sentiment in Turkey is running strongly against remaining in the coalition. The American military operations in the gulf have from the start been built on three pillars: Saudi Arabian bases, Turkish bases, and American naval power. If Turkey pulls out, it would seriously diminish that triad and the operational effectiveness of American forces in that part of the world.
"If you want to keep Saddam in a box, you need to be able to keep the lid on, and that is not going to be easy without Turkey," said one foreign policy adviser to President-elect Clinton.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: THE STATES -- THE BALLOT ISSUES;
Move to Limit Terms Gathers Steam After Winning in 14 States

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 4

 BODY:
The national movement to impose term limits on members of Congress gathered momentum today following sweeping approval of such limits by voters in 14 states Tuesday.
Leaders of the movement said today that they hoped the vote would pressure Congress to draw up a constitutional amendment imposing uniform national limits on the service of Senators and Representatives. The state measures passed Tuesday all varied somewhat, generally setting limits of 12 years for senators and 6 to 12 years for representatives, depending on the state. 
 "We have a mammoth mandate," said James K. Coyne 3d, a former Congressman from Pennsylvania who founded Americans to Limit Congressional Terms, an advocacy group based in Washington that claims 300,000 members. "We now have a six-year window of opportunity to force, or persuade, Congress to do the right thing and pass it uniformly for the whole country by a Constitutional amendment."
The term-limit votes presented a stark paradox. Even as voters passed them by margins of nearly 2 to 1 or larger, they handily re-elected most veteran incumbents to Congress. Here in California, for example, the initiative passed with the support of 63 percent against 37 percent, but all except one or two of the 36 incumbent Representatives running won re-election. Of the 116 incumbents running in the 14 states voting on term limits, only 6 lost, and only 19 lost nationally.
 
Scores of Ballot Questions
 Proponents of term limits said this added evidence that incumbents were too entrenched and powerful, while opponents said it showed that people were satisfied with their representation and that terms should not be truncated.
The term-limit initiatives were among scores of measures on ballots in 23 states that permit law-making by direct vote. Except for the term-limits trend, few significant patterns emerged.
Here in California, voters soundly defeated a measure to permit doctors to assist terminal patients in ending their lives. Californians also dealt a blow to their Republican Governor, Pete Wilson, rejecting a measure he backed to enhance his power in budget making and cut welfare grants. They also spurned, by more than 2 to 1, a doctor-sponsored measure requiring businesses to provide health insurance to employees.
Colorado rejected a school choice plan to allow parents to take public education dollars to private schools. Arizona, after years of bitter conflict, finally created a paid state holiday for the birthday of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. And Massachusetts residents imposed a new excise tax of 25 cents a pack on cigarettes to subsidize smoking-related health programs, but rejected a measure to require recyclable packaging.
 
Rebellion in Capital
 Maryland voters approved an initiative writing into law the provisions of Roe v. Wade, the 1973 Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion. If a future Court should overturn Roe v. Wade, the new measure would prohibit the state from interfering with a woman's decision to abort a pregnancy before the fetus is viable. It also repealed requirements that women be given information about alternatives to abortion.
And in a vote that touched on local sensitivity over Congressional influence over local affairs in the nation's capital, voters in the District of Columbia overwhelmingly rejected a Congressional initiative establishing the death penalty for murder. The measure was a result of the murder of a Senate aide on Capitol Hill.
The term-limits measures could give members of Congress a predicament. Beginning in January, more than a quarter of the Senate and nearly a third of the House will be serving under a ticking clock, limited in tenure like the President. Colorado passed such limits in 1990.
According to Mr. Coyne, the new Congress will include about 225 members who are under state-imposed limits or who have pledged to support limits.
Speaker Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, considers the measures unconstitutional and expects them to lose on court challenge, according to a spokesman, Jeffrey R. Biggs.
Representative George E. Brown Jr., a 72-year-old California Democrat who has been in Congress since 1963 except for one two-year term and who won yet another term Tuesday, expressed a common view: "I don't like term limits enacted state by state. If adopted as a Constitutional amendment by all states, I wouldn't be enthusiastic, but I could live with it."
If Congress does not make the issue moot with an amendment, the state-passed limits face almost certain challenge from incumbents in the Federal courts on the ground that the Constitution controls eligibility for Federal offices and that it specifies only age, citizenship and residency for members of Congress.
It was unclear just when such a challenge could be brought since no one would be barred from running again before 1998. "My guess is if you were to bring one to court now, the court would not consider it ripe," said one leading Constitutional scholar, Gerald Gunther of Stanford University, adding that the most likely time for such a suit would be after an incumbent wins his last permissible election four years from now, though "it depends on the judge."
He said he considered the state measures unconstitutional. "I personally think it's an abomination to restrict the choice of voters to this extent," he said. "We should allow the public to select anybody they want, subject to the limitations of the Constitution."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: VOTERS -- STATE LEGISLATURES;
Elections Change Face Of Lawmaking Bodies

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS

 BODY:
There will be an enormous transfer of power in state capitals next January as a result of Tuesday's elections, which gave one of every three or four seats in state legislatures to newcomers, many of them female, black or Hispanic, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures.
The turnover, the largest in at least a decade, may shift control of legislative chambers to a new party in as many as 14 states when the ballots are finally tallied. Republicans have already won six of these legislative battles and could well win four more. 
 "When you have so many green legislators, there is a great opportunity to shape new issues, but there is also the possibility of chaos, where nothing much gets done," said Steven D. Gold, director of the Center for the Study of the States at the Rockefeller Institute of Government in Albany.
This year's high turnover may also foreshadow the future, given Tuesday's passage of term limits for legislators in 14 states, said Alan Rosenthal, director of the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University. "We can expect a higher and higher turnover in the membership and leadership of state legislatures, and that means a loss of continuity, institutional memory and, to some extent, expertise," Mr. Rosenthal said. "And that is likely to mean more confrontation and more conflict over the issues."
 
1 in 6 Decide to Retire
 "More than any other single reason, the decision by one in six legislators not to seek re-election created this year's high turnover, according to the conference's surveys. Some legislators sought other offices, and some retired because their districts were redrawn or eliminated after the 1990 census. But many quit out of frustration with the thankless task of balancing budgets during a recession, and others decided to leave before being forced out by term limits.
Bruce Bronzan, for example, announced his plan to resign from the California Assembly last week, just before running unopposed and winning his sixth two-year term on Tuesday. "If you know your legislative career is going to end in four years, you can't wait until the last minute to decide what to do with the rest of your life," Mr. Bronzan, who is 45 years old, said Tuesday.
The Democratic Assemblyman from Fresno said he had accepted an offer to become an associate dean at the University of California School of Medicine. Turnover in the California Assembly, where terms are limited to six years, is expected to exceed 40 percent.
Of the 7,461 legislative seats in state capitols, 6,255 were up for election on Tuesday, and voters filled over 2,000 of those positions with newcomers. Nearly 1,500 races were still undecided on Wednesday, but William T. Pound, executive director of the conference of state legislatures, estimated that the number of women would increase by about two percentage points, or twice the increase in any election during the 1980's. That would mean women's representation in the nation's legislatures will increase to 20 percent in January from 18 percent this year and 12 percent in 1981.
Mr. Pound also said black and Hispanic candidates seemed to have made gains, largely because many legislative districts were redrawn after the 1990 census, to comply with 1982 amendments to the Voting Rights Act, mandating the creation of districts favorable to minority candidates when possible.
Blacks hold 6 percent of the nation's state legislative seats this year, up from 5 percent in 1981. Hispanic legislators hold 2 percent of the seats this year. The conference did not calculate a Hispanic percentage in 1981 because there were so few.
This year's turnover varies greatly by state, ranging from less than 15 percent of the members of the New York Legislature, to 37 percent of the Connecticut Legislature, to 58 percent of the Alaska Legislature, which had the highest turnover this year. New Jersey had a 25 percent turnover in its State Legislature last year, and Republicans gained control of both houses.
There will be so many freshmen legislators in state capitals that they are expected to assume leadership roles quickly. Most committees in the Kansas Senate, for example, will be headed by new members, said Paul B. Burke, the Senate president.
Going into this election, Democrats held a majority in both houses in 29 states and controlled 70 of the nation's 99 chambers. (Nebraska has a unicameral legislature that is nominally nonpartisan.) The Republicans controlled both chambers in 6 states this year, and the parties share legislative leadership in 14 states.
Now, Democrats control both houses in 25 states and 64 chambers; Republicans control both chambers in 9 states, and a total of 30 chambers. Legislative control is shared in 15 states.
The Republicans did the best at the polls on Tuesday, according to the conference of state legislatures. They solidified control of three state legislatures by winning control of a second chamber in Kansas, Arizona and Idaho. Republicans also gained control of one chamber each in Alaska, Illinois, Iowa, Michigan, Montana and Vermont.
Preliminary counts also suggest that Republicans may win control of the Iowa House, the North Dakota Senate, the Oregon House and the Nevada Senate. Republicans gained one seat in the Democratic-led Florida Senate, creating a 20-to-20 split; similarly, Pennsylvania Democrats won enough seats to tie up, but not to control, the Republican-led Senate.
Democrats won control of the South Dakota Senate and the Washington Senate. In three states where Democrats control the legislatures, victories by Democratic candidates for governor will unify party leadership. They are Lieut. Gov. Mel Carnahan in Missouri, Mike Lowry in Washington and former Gov. Jim Hunt in North Carolina.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: DISAPPOINTMENT -- THE TURNOUT;
55% Voting Rate Reverses 30-Year Decline

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

 BODY:
Voter turnout rose substantially this year, reversing a three-decade decline, political scientists said yesterday.
Curtis Gans, director of the Committee for the Study of the American Electorate, said it appeared that 104 million Americans, representing 55 percent of the voting-age population, cast ballots in this year's Presidential election. 
 The turnout rate is probably the highest since 1972, when 55.2 percent of the eligible people voted, he said. He said he was unable to calculate the turnout rate of registered voters because not all states were prompt in accounting for voters who had died or moved away.
Using different techniques, Voter Research & Surveys, the television polling consortium, estimated a turnout rate of 54 percent for the voting-age population.
Mr. Gans and other election experts said anger over the condition of the economy drew many people to the polls. "Recession always tends to focus the mind and increase turnout," he said.
Even more influential, he said, was Ross Perot's specific appeal to people who felt disenfranchised and had not voted in recent elections. He said preliminary data showed that the Democratic share of the eligible vote rose very slightly, while the Republican share declined, suggesting that Mr. Perot caused the overall increase in turnout.
The independent got more than 19 million votes on Tuesday.
Ruy A. Teixeira, a sociologist at the Brookings Institution in Washington, said the candidates' debates and television call-in programs like "Larry King Live" had also increased people's "psychological involvement in politics."
Nationwide, the Census Bureau says, there are 189 million people of voting age, 18 years old and over.
Comparing 1988 and 1992, the turnout rate rose about six percentage points in Connecticut, to 64 percent, according to Voters Research & Surveys. In New York, it stayed about the same, at 48 percent. In New Jersey, the turnout rate rose two percentage points, to 55 percent.
Mr. Gans said many New York residents were apparently put off by the bitter contest for the United States Senate.

HEADLINE: Transcript of Clinton's Remarks on White House Transition

BYLINE: Reuters

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of remarks by President-elect Bill Clinton yesterday in Little Rock, Ark., as recorded by News Transcripts Inc., a private transcription service:
Good afternoon. Ladies and gentlemen, I have just heard a summary of President Bush's recently concluded remarks. I'd like to begin by expressing my appreciation for them. I'd like to read this statement.  
 Today I want to reaffirm the essential continuity of American foreign policy and my desire to seek bipartisan support for our role in the world.
During the transition that is now beginning, I urge America's friends and foes alike to recognize, as I do, that America has only one President at a time, that America's foreign policy remains solely in his hands, that even as America's Administrations change, America's fundamental interests do not, that the greatest gesture of good will any nation can make toward me is to continue their full cooperation during this period with our one President, George Bush, and that the greatest mistake any adversary could make would be to doubt America's resolve during this period of transition.
I look forward to working closely with President Bush to insure continuity in global affairs of interest to all Americans, from continued progress in the Mideast peace talks to completing negotiations on the details of the START II arms control agreement, to making progress toward a good agreement on our world trade talks, to bolstering Russia's fledgling democracy, to working toward peaceful resolution of the conflict in the republics of the former Yugoslavia, to assisting the victims of famine in Somalia.
I also look forward to getting to work on the hard and vital task of restoring our nation's economic strength. Today I say to our financial and business leaders that although change is on the horizon, we understand the need to pursue stability even as we pursue new growth.
The changes I seek will strengthen America's market systems not weaken them.
And to the people of our great nation, for whom we pledge to get up every morning and work hard to bring the economic opportunity that was at the core of the Clinton-Gore campaign, I say that the task has already begun. It will not be easy, but we will spare no effort to restore growth, jobs and incomes to the American people.
Let me also stress the stakes and the opportunities in the months and years that lie ahead. The cold war is won. Now we have a chance to build a new peace. We have entered a global economy. Now we have the opportunity to master its competitive challenges rather than let these changes undermine our strength. We have become a diverse people of many colors and languages and beliefs. Now we have the obligation to insure that our diversity is a source of strength and pride to all of us here at home and around the world.
We've become a nation of 250 million Americans. Now we have the opportunity, the duty and the imperative to see that we do not leave even one of those 250 million behind as we move toward the next century.
We have entered a period of great challenge and extraordinary opportunity for our nation. I am confident we can make it a proud time in our history, proud for the families who are raising this nation's next generation, proud for the workers and businesses who are America's lifeblood, proud for the men and women who wear America's uniforms and proud for the peoples of other nations living today in freedom, or in fear, who draw strength from American ideals, and share our vision of a peaceful and more prosperous world.
America has called upon me to be our next President. But our forebears call on all of us at this moment to honor their efforts, their sacrifices, their ideals and their lives by working hard and working together to improve this good and great nation as much for our children and our children's children as those who preceded us did for us.
They call on us to take our dreams and our hopes and make them real. Thank you, and God bless America.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: NEW YORK STATE -- U.S. HOUSE RACES;
Years of Seniority Are Gone in One Swoop

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
Every year when New York City wanted to make sure it would get its $9 million in Federal help to pay for police protection for the United Nations, Representative Bill Green of Manhattan, a seven-term Republican, was there on the Appropriations Committee to see it through.
And when New York State wanted the Federal Government to pay a greater share of job-training for welfare recipients, Thomas J. Downey of Long Island, a nine-term Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee, shepherded the measure into the tax bill sitting on President Bush's desk. 
 But yesterday, city and state officials were grappling with the knowledge that they may soon be flying without radar in Washington: With the defeat of Mr. Downey and Mr. Green, and the loss, through retirement, defeat in the primary, or death, of 10 other senior Representatives, New York is relinquishing 214 years of combined seniority on Capitol Hill.
The loss, which experts call the worst for any state in decades, is the most extreme example of the down side of the anti-incumbent fervor that swept the nation in this year of scandals, redistricting and search for change.
"It will take us a generation to get back the delegation that vanished yesterday," Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said, as he pored over the Congressional Directory, totaling the losses. "We will never have as little influence as we do now."
 
A Young Delegation
 He said that the loss of seniority and influence in New York was the worst thing to happen to the delegation since he began working for Gov. W. Averell Harriman's office in the 1950's, worse than the gradual loss of 10 seats through redistricting over the last three decades, including three in this year's election.
To be sure, among the nine new representatives are many with decades of government experience, like Peter King, the Nassau County Comptroller, a Republican, or Jerrold Nadler, a seasoned Democratic legislator from Manhattan, who hope to advance rapidly in a Congress that will have more than 100 freshmen next year.
But in the sometimes subtle ways power is wielded in Washington, many longtime Washington hands say it could take years before the huge class of 1993 develops the clout -- seniority, the sophistication, and the relationships with long-serving committee chairmen -- to bring home the goods for New York.
It is a sign of these troubled times that, in a delegation known more for conflict than cooperation, remaining members have begun working with city and state officials to find strategies to help incoming freshmen fill important vacancies -- including the loss of all three New Yorkers on the House Appropriations Committee and two of three on the influential Ways and Means Committee.
"I'm making a special plea to the Speaker to give special attention to the new members of the New York delegation as it relates to committee assignments," said Charles B. Rangel, who emerged as the senior Democrat and as a high-ranking member of the Ways and Means Committee, and one of the few well-placed representatives New York has left.
"It is a tremendous loss," he said. "Let's face it. New people on the block don't have that much influence."
The losses include two ranking minority slots on full committees, six ranking minority slots on subcommittees, four subcommittee chairmen, two acting subcommittee chairmen and one of two New Yorkers on the Armed Services Committee.
While the new Congress will have dropped about a quarter of all incumbents, New York lost 35 percent of its delegation, members with an average of 18 years in the House. "I don't think any state has anything comparable in recent memory," said Michael J. Malbin, a researcher at the Rockefeller Institute who studies Congress.
He said the loss of Mr. Downey and David Martin, an upstate Republican on the Armed Services Committee, could affect the state's ability to defend upstate military installations, like Fort Drum and the air base at Plattsburg, at a time of military retrenchment.
Brad Johnson, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's Washington lobbyist, said it would take years to rebuilt the seniority that was lost this year. He especially noted the loss of Mr. Downey, who only last week was meeting with the Governor on proposals to retool the state's defense industries.
He said there would be an effort by the state's delegation to work out conflicts over committee assignments in private, in order to bolster the state's efforts to regain lost committee seats, particularly on Ways and Means and Appropriations.
Judy Chesser, head of Mayor David N. Dinkins's Washington office, said: "Our hope and goal would be to try to encourage the new members to go on some of these important committees and secure those positions."
Both said that with the loss of influence in the House, they would have to rely more on the state's well-placed senators, and develop new channels in the Clinton Administration.
 
Placing the Blame
 Many incumbents, those who survived and those who did not, today blamed the state Legislature, and its disruptive battles on reapportionment, for the waves of retirements and defeats that routed the stalwarts of the delegation. The Legislature, unable to agree on a plan of its own, eventually passed a plan that was essentially drawn by the courts.
Asked to explain the losses, one legislator said, "Ask the people who screwed up the lines up there and had us twisting in the wind."
Whatever the cause, the effects are clear. Enter, stage left, nine new representatives, still more or less shell-shocked from often bitter elections. The new members will add two women to the delegation, for a total of five, and one new minority member for a total of six.
Carolyn B. Maloney, a Democrat on the New York City Council, defeated Mr. Green, a 14-year Republican veteran in the Silk Stocking district on the East Side of Manhattan.
 
'Better Off With Me'
 Saying she would be a more effective legislator because Mr. Green had supported President Reagan's 1981 tax package, Ms. Maloney said, "The delegation is going to be a lot better off with me because I am not going to vote against the city's interests."
Rick Lazio, a Suffolk County Legislator who defeated Mr. Downey, the acting chairman of the Human Services subcommittee, said his chief goal would be "more employment for Long Island."
Mr. King, another Republican newcomer to Washington, sat back for a moment to savor the change.
"Yesterday I was playing with the Democrats on the Nassau Board of Supervisors; today I get a call from Jack Kemp, to talk about national economic policy."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
A.T.& T. is negotiating to buy a third of McCaw, the nation's largest cellular phone operator, for $3.8 billion. The alliance would take advantage of the research prowess of A.T.& T.'s Bell Laboratories, accelerate the growth of the cellular industry as well as hasten the arrival of personal communications technology. [Page D1.]
Paramount named Sherry Lansing chairwoman of its motion picture group. Ms. Lansing, a former president of 20th Century Fox, replaces Brandon Tartikoff, who resigned last week. [D1.] 
 Union officials are hoping for improved labor relations at G.M. under Jack Smith, the new chief executive. [D1.]
Teledyne was accused in a lawsuit of falsifying test results on electronics equipment it sold to the military and of bribing overseas officials. Federal investigators are said to be investigating. [D4.]
Light truck sales surged, pushing overall sales of domestically built vehicles up 9.7 percent in late October. For all of October, sales of all types of vehicles rose 7.7 percent. [D4.]
Volvo will close two plants and lay off 4,500 workers. The plants to be closed include the Kalmar factory, where Volvo developed its team-assembly approach. [D4.]
The Church's and Popeye's chains emerged from bankruptcy under the ownership of lenders who provided some $400 million in financing for the fried-chicken restaurants. [D5.]
Rockwell International reported a 9 percent decline in its fourth-quarter earnings and a loss for the year. [D5.]
Woolworth had 59 percent increase in quarterly earnings as its store reorganization program continued to produce results. [D5.]
 
International
The United States plans to announce punitive taxes on European imports today because of the breakdown of trade talks on farm subsidies, United States officials said. [D1.]
Spain expects a further realignment of currency rates in the European monetary system to be necessary before the end of the year, according to Finance Minister Carlos Solchaga. [D2.]
 
The Economy
Business and finance leaders show restrained hope as they look to a future under Bill Clinton as President. Some say they approve of his open-mindedness about the economy, while others say they fear Goverment might grow too big. [D1.]
Three post-election reports find the economy lackluster. The reports were issued by the Federal Reserve, the Commerce Department and the United States Chamber of Commerce. [D3.]
President Bush vetoed a $27 billion tax bill that included enterprise zones designed to aid the cities.[A22.]
 
Markets
Blue-chip stocks fell sharply as investors became nervous about Bill Clinton's plans to stimulate the economy. The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 29.44 points at 3,223.04. [D10.]
The Clinton election was good news for investors who own municipal bonds and the dealers who sell them, because higher taxes would effectively increase the securities' yield. [D17.]
Oil prices dropped after it was reported that OPEC nations pumped more oil last month than in a dozen years. [D18.] The dollar settled mostly higher on world currency markets. [D18.]

Some economists say commercial banking is dying and they fear that no efficient system will exist for channeling the nation's savings to the creditworthy. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Biotechnology stocks may be inviting because they have dropped so far, and one analyst has devised methods for measuring the prospects of biotech companies. Market Place. [D10.]

SECTION: Section B; Page 10; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 929 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: THE WORLD -- WORLD VIEW;
Foreigners Hope Clinton Keeps Policy

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 4

 BODY:
After sitting through an American election campaign that largely ignored international affairs, many world leaders expressed hope today that a Clinton Administration will not veer far from President Bush's foreign policies.
Much like the Americans who voted for President-elect Clinton, however, many foreign governments are looking to the new Administration to revive the stagnating domestic economy in the belief that only a United States recovery can lift the global economy out of recession. 
"The revitalization of the American economy is important not only for the United States alone, but also for Japan and for the whole world," Japan's Foreign Minister, Michio Watanabe, said, echoing a widely held view throughout the world.
In Western Europe and Japan, though, many people also fear that Mr. Clinton may favor greater protection of American markets, particularly after the breakdown of global trade liberalization talks on Tuesday raised the specter of a trade war between the United States and the European Community.
 
Anxiety in Mideast
 Elsewhere, there are other reasons for apprehension. In the Middle East, there is anxiety that Arab-Israeli peace talks may lose their momentum. From Moscow, appeals came for continued American support for Russia's economic reforms. China's nervousness over its relations with Mr. Clinton was apparent in the absence of an official reaction.
Yet the generally calm reaction of both financial markets and foreign governments today suggested that no drastic change in American foreign policy is expected after Jan. 20. During the campaign, Mr. Clinton sent emissaries to reassure allies that he offered continuity on important issues, and he repeated that assurance today in Little Rock.
"Even as America's administrations change, America's fundamental interests do not," Mr. Clinton said.
 
Not Well Know Abroad
 The President-elect is still little known abroad, and since he moved ahead in the polls last July, officials from Buenos Aires to Warsaw have been avidly studying his background and occasional pronouncements for indications as to his likely policies.
Significantly, reflecting their preference for continuity, several world leaders went out of their way to praise Mr. Bush for the way he handled the post-cold war transition in Europe, nuclear disarmament, the Persian Gulf War and efforts to bring permanent peace to the Middle East.
In a message to Mr. Clinton, for example, President Francois Mitterrand of France recalled the traditional friendship between his nation and the United States. In a message to Mr. Bush, the French leader spoke of "the excellent cooperation which never failed between us."
Other leaders stressed that, as the sole remaining superpower, the United States had a special role to play in the world and could not opt for isolationism. "I want to say that we are still counting on America's leadership in this period of global instability," Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan told Parliament.
NATO's Secretary-General, Manfred Worner, added that he was sure the Atlantic alliance could still count on strong leadership from Washington. Mr. Clinton has said he favors reducing the American troop strength in Europe from the 150,000 level proposed by Mr. Bush to between 75,000 and 100,000, but this has caused no alarm inside the alliance.
Germany's Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, who congratulated Mr. Clinton in a telephone call early today, stressed that close solidarity with the United States is "even more important as we face new challenges after the end of the East-West conflict.
Many governments, though, viewed the election result through the narrower prism of bilateral relations. Describing Mr. Bush as "an exemplary leader of the Western world," Britain's Prime Minister John Major said he was confident that the special relationship between London and Washington would continue.
But a senior British official said Whitehall was concerned about Mr. Clinton's campaign promise to send an envoy to investigate human-rights abuses in Northern Ireland. "We see the greatest threat to human rights in Ireland as being the I.R.A.," the official said.
 
Addressing Yugoslavia
 European leaders said they are hoping Mr. Clinton will abandon Washington's current hands-off policy towards the Yugoslav crisis and assume a more active role in trying to end the fighting there.
Their most immediate concern, however, is that frustration over the breakdown in global trade talks could lead to an exchange of sanctions between the United States and the European Community even before Mr. Clinton takes office.
Foreign Minister Roland Dumas of France said "it is necessary for the new Administration to take on the issue and to make new proposals to the Europeans."
In a message of congratulation today from Moscow, President Boris N. Yeltsin said he hoped "the new United States Administration will continue active support of Russia's reforms."
In Warsaw, where President Lech Walesa went as far as endorsing Mr. Bush's re-election this summer, there was evident concern that Poland may soon be of little interest to Washington. A spokesman for Mr. Walesa noted that Mr. Clinton's predecessors" had helped bring down the Berlin Wall.
In the Middle East, the responses were mixed. Syrian officials expressed fear that Mr. Clinton would adopt a more pro-Israeli stance. But President Saddam Hussein of Iraq fired a gun in the air to celebrate Mr. Bush's defeat. "Bush fell a long time ago when he decided to bomb Baghdad," Mr. Hussein said.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Impose a Tax On European Imports

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
The United States plans to announce punitive taxes on European imports on Thursday morning, taking another step toward a trans-Atlantic trade war after the breakdown of talks on farm subsidies, American officials said today.
Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, will announce taxes of 100 percent or more on up to $350 million worth of luxury European exports, mainly white wines from France, said two American officials who insisted on anonymity. Rufus Yerxa, a deputy United States trade representative, said the Customs Service would begin collecting the taxes 30 days after an announcement was made.
 
Retaliation Proceeds
 The delay is needed to instruct customs officials on the new taxes, to allow time for the arrival of goods already paid for by American importers and to permit further negotiations. Bureaucratic and legal details were worked out nearly two weeks ago, and the retaliation is now proceeding with relatively little high-level involvement in the wake of President Bush's loss in Tuesday's election. 
 After negotiations broke off Tuesday night, Ray MacSharry, the European Community's Agriculture Commissioner, and Agriculture Secretary Edward R. Madigan said that they were willing to talk further on the issue of agricultural supports but had not scheduled any more meetings. But American officials were not optimistic about the prospects for further talks, having tried for six years to persuade the European Community to reduce its production subsidies for soybeans, rapeseed and sunflower seed, which are used in cooking oil, animal feed and paint.
The European Community issued a thinly veiled threat today to respond with taxes on American exports. An American official said that while the Administration had not reached a final decision, it was very likely that European retaliation would provoke another round of punitive taxes by the United States, covering a broader range of goods.
"It's kind of like World War I," said Harold Malmgren, who was a deputy United States trade representative in the Nixon and Ford Administrations. "Everyone is digging in."
The United States has singled out white wine and possibly truffles for four reasons: They are luxury goods that Americans do not really need. They are high-prestige exports that are sources of national pride in France. They are consumer goods rather than intermediate products like ball bearings, whose loss might shut down an American factory. And wine importers tend not to be large donors to political campaigns, so they have few friends in Congress.
The wine varieties chosen by Mrs. Hills are produced mainly in France, but smaller quantities from Italy and elsewhere in the European Community will also be hit by the taxes.
American officials have become worried in recent weeks that punishing European farm exports may not be enough to secure a deal on soybean subsidies. So they are drafting a supplemental list of industrial products that can also be taxed if necessary.
The United States asked the governing council of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade today to endorse the first stage of the planned American retaliation: the wines and truffles. But Washington was rebuffed when the European Community refused to debate the issue. The council reaches decisions only by consensus, according to a legal tradition that has paralyzed GATT, a world trade body in Geneva that drafts and enforces international free-trade rules.
 
Pressure on GATT Talks
 The current dispute puts renewed pressure on the current round of GATT talks, which began six years ago and which are aimed at reducing world trade barriers. The election of Gov. Bill Clinton on Tuesday further jeopardizes the future of the talks, which have been ailing for some time, by undermining the authority of Bush Administration officials to negotiate for the next two months.
In Little Rock, Ark., Mr. Clinton was quoted by the Reuters news agency as saying today that he would work closely with President Bush on a variety of issues, including "progress toward a good agreement on our world trade talks."
Current American law requires that a deal be completed before March 2 if Congress is to take it up under the so-called fast track procedure, which does not allow amendments.
Gary C. Hufbauer, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics, said that a key signal of whether Mr. Clinton wanted a quick conclusion to the trade talks would be whether he retained Mr. Yerxa and his aides in charge of the negotiations.
Mr. Yerxa is a Democrat and a former aide to Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, which has jurdisdiction over trade issues and would review a new GATT accord. The Bush Administration chose Mr. Yerxa to head the American negotiating team to build Congressional support for an eventual deal.
If Mr. Clinton replaces Mr. Yerxa and his aides, the new officials probably will not be able to finish the talks before March 2, Mr. Hufbauer said. Mr. Clinton would then have to persuade Congress to extend the negotiations, Mr. Hufbauer said.
 
Taxes Often Become Permanent
 Once imposed, punitive taxes often become permanent. The United States imposed a 25 percent tax on truck imports in the 1960's to retaliate for European restrictions on American poultry shipments. The truck tax is still in effect, and American auto makers want it extended to cover Japanese mini-vans.
Punitive taxes usually come with short grace periods before they are actually collected, but Washington trade lawyers could recall only one case that had been settled during a grace period. The United States announced 200 percent duties on imports of European pork and cheeses on Jan. 26, 1987, in retaliation for higher Spanish taxes on American corn and sorghum, but the two sides settled the case within days, said Alan F. Holmer, who was the White House's chief trade lawyer then.
Usually the announcement of taxes so poisons the atmosphere that further talks show little results.
Higher taxes on French wine are unlikely to affect American consumers immediately, because wine importers have already brought in huge inventories. But if the duties become permanent, prices for affected wines could eventually double.
France shipped nearly 50 million bottles of wine to the United States last year. Americans drank about 2 billion bottles of wine last year, most of it produced domestically.
