HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Shareholders Charge Teledyne With Fraud and Bribery

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 4

 BODY:
A shareholder lawsuit was filed today charging that Teledyne Inc., a prominent military contractor here, falsified test results on electronics equipment it sold to the military and that the company bribed officials in Egypt and Saudi Arabia to gain new aerospace business.
Congressional staff members and lawyers involved in the case said the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the House Energy and Commerce Committee and several Defense Department agencies were investigating the fraud and bribery charges, which were made public in an amended shareholder lawsuit filed today. 
 The suit is the latest in a growing tangle of disclosures about questionable practices in Teledyne's military businesses. It accuses Teledyne of falsifying test results on electronic identification systems used in military aircraft and weapon systems to determine whether an approaching target is a friend or enemy. Teledyne is also accused of hiring foreign military officials who are said to have bribed Government officials in Egypt and Saudi Arabia to get business for the company.
 
Fined in Previous Case
 The new charges against Teledyne come just four weeks after the company pleaded guilty to charges that it falsified testing on electronic relay devices and agreed to pay $17.5 million in fines, the largest penalty ever imposed on a military contractor for defrauding the Government.
Teledyne, a secretive contractor that makes aviation and electronics products, has been hit with a flood of lawsuits in recent years, most filed under the Federal False Claims Act, which allows whistle-blowers to share in any settlement or any financial recovery won by the Government.
Critics of Teledyne contend that the latest accusations raise questions about the company's ability to police itself and about Teledyne's financial future, which is being threatened by the deluge of lawsuits.
In addition to the court-imposed criminal fines, some industry analysts and lawyers representing the whistle-blowers have speculated that the company could face more than $1 billion in civil fines and penalties in the relay case alone.
The Pentagon has also suspended the division of the company responsible for doing the relay tests from doing business with the Government until criminal investigations are completed.
There are at least five other lawsuits pending against the company, including one filed by Stephen Reddy, a senior program manager for Teledyne's Middle East division. Mr. Reddy has said he saw a former Egyptian general, who was hired by Teledyne, make cash bribes to Egyptian officials on several occasions.
Mr. Reddy's suit remains under seal while the Justice Department investigates the claim and decides whether to take over prosecution of the case. The case was first reported in The Los Angeles Times last week. Much of the shareholder suit filed today is based on information contained in the Reddy case.
Berkley J. Baker, a Teledyne spokesman, said the company had not yet been served with the shareholder lawsuit and thus could not comment. Teledyne has a reputation of being uncommunicative, so much so that its strategy and operations remain a mystery even to investors.
Teledyne is a widely diversified conglomerate, with about 40 percent of its revenues coming from aircraft parts and electronics, which have been hurt by weakness in military and aerospace spending. The company's specialty metals, industrial and consumer products businesses -- which include shower massagers, water filters and heaters -- have suffered from the recession.
In the third quarter that ended Sept. 30, Teledyne reported a profit but said it could report a loss in a future quarter when Federal fraud charges were settled. Teledyne had net income of $16.3 million, or 29 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $79.8 million in the third quarter of 1991. Revenue dropped 6.5 percent, to $708 million.
 
Embarked On Restructuring
 The company has embarked on a restructuring to eliminate a number of low-profit operations, which some analysts have said should benefit margins in other segments. But that strategy has proved costly. Teledyne took after-tax charges of $68.9 million in 1991 to cover losses to dispose of 24 operations being restructured.
Sidney J. Heller, an analyst for Lehman Brothers, said that Teledyne's earnings had been disappointing and that the lawsuits would have a negative impact on the company's earnings. As a result, Mr. Heller said he had rated the stock neutral.
Howard A. Rubel, an analyst for C. J. Lawrence, said that the growing number of lawsuits against Teledyne was becoming a serious liability for the company. "All I can say at the moment is that it raises a lot of questions as to character, which is disheartening because I don't sense that the management of this company is trying to rip people off," Mr. Rubel said.
The company is taking the position that former employees are trying to take advantage of the Federal False Claims Act.
The shareholder lawsuit is a derivative suit filed on behalf of the company today by Marshall Wolf, an investor, against Teledyne's senior management in Delaware Chancery Court. Corporate officers are usually insured against such suits, and any awards from the suit are paid to the corporation.
 
False Testing Alleged
 According to the shareholder lawsuit, Teledyne's electronics division, in Newberry Park, Calif., engaged in wholesale false testing of "identification friend or foe" systems. Test equipment was said to have been programmed to print out passing results for equipment that had not been tested or failed to pass.
The suit also charges that Teledyne hired Qayed Nadim, a retired major general of the Egyptian Air Force and member of the Egyptian royal family, to funnel money to air force personnel to get new contracts and retain existing business for Teledyne. It similarly charges that Teledyne's Saudi Arabia division paid bribes to Abdullah Khayat, the husband of the sister of a colonel in the Saudi Air Force.

HEADLINE: Executives' Outlook On Clinton Presidency

 BODY:
Although they traditionally favor Republican Presidents and policies, the nation's business, economic and finance leaders look to a future with the Democrat Bill Clinton as President by showing restrained hope if not hats-in-the-air enthusiasm.
In a series of interviews, some expressed the view that the nation's economy may well benefit from what they regard as the open-mindedness of President-elect Clinton in coping with the economy. Others voiced the fear that Government might grow too big again under a Democrat but were now nevertheless optimistic about the nation's chances for long-term economic growth. 
 Among the mildly optimist forecasts for dealing with a problem of concern to all, the growing national budget deficit, was that of the chairman of Chase Manhattan Corporation, Thomas G. Labrecque: "I think Clinton has as good a chance of doing something about the deficit as a Republican administration."
Following are comments from interviews yesterday:
 
M.R. Greenberg
Chairman of American International Group.
 Mr. Greenberg said that economic growth under Mr. Clinton would depend upon the new Administration's understanding that private enterprise creates jobs and that international protectionism can destroy them.
"Avoid protectionism," Mr. Greenberg said, when asked for his first thought for the President-elect. "That is a pox on everybody's house."
Mr. Greenberg, who is regarded as a leading voice of the insurance industry and who had close ties with the Bush Administration, said he would welcome an end to the deadlock between a Republican White House and a Democratic Congress. And Mr. Greenberg said he was optimistic about the prospects for the long-term growth of the American economy.
But as the builder of a company with half its business overseas and new enterprises under way in China and Russia, Mr. Greenberg said the new Administration must give a clear priority to free trade to insure the international economic growth upon which American jobs depend. In particular, he expressed hope that American criticism of human rights violations in China will not cut into trade and, in turn, lend support to hard-liners in Beijing.
"It is important that we not fall into shooting barbs into each other, that we avoid an international trade war," Mr. Greenberg said.
 
James D. Wolfensohn
Investment banker and close adviser to more than 30 chief executives.
 "Clinton appears to have a substantial mandate," Mr. Wolfensohn said. "The people behind him are anxious for economic leadership, and even more than that, the 19 percent who voted for Ross Perot are people who manifestly are saying we have serious economic problems and we're prepared to sacrifice to solve them."
He said he was heartened by the outpouring of support for a more forceful economic leader than Mr. Bush had been.
That consensus, he said, should help Mr. Clinton carry out the ambitious program of simultaneously pumping billions of dollars into the nation's infrastructure and social programs without raising taxes on the middle class.
In Mr. Wolfensohn's opinion, the President-elect is wise to put off taming the budget deficit until he shows some quick results of some symbolic value, like his infrastructure spending program.
Over all, Mr. Wolfensohn thinks Mr. Clinton's plan is reasonable, though he is skeptical that Mr. Clinton can raise $40 billion over four years by taxing foreign corporations. "The President-elect has great support domestically, but internationally we are in a negotiating environment where actions taken by us will be met by actions taken by other sovereign countries."
Asked to respond to rumors that Paul A. Volcker, the former Fed chairman and inflation fighter who is Mr. Wolfensohn's partner, was being considered by the Clinton team as the next Treasury Secretary, Mr. Wolfensohn, said the departure would be a big loss for him but he would nonetheless applaud the appointment. "I have no knowledge" of Mr. Volcker's plans, Mr. Wolfensohn, said, "but he would be a marvelous choice."
 
Thomas T. Labrecque
Chairman of Chase Manhattan.
 Mr. Labrecque said Mr. Clinton's election was not the negative development that some in the financial markets had feared. In the past two months, the prospect of a Clinton victory, and the assumption that it would bring more inflation and more Government borrowing, helped lift the yield of long-term Treasury bonds to 7.68 percent from 7.21 percent.
"I think Clinton has as good a chance of doing something about the deficit as a Republican administration," Mr. Labrecque said. Because of Mr. Clinton's background in state government, where he was obliged to balance the budget, Mr. Labrecque said he was hopeful that as President, Governor Clinton will stand by his campaign promises to eventually reduce the Federal deficit from last year's $290 billion.
To gain support for his budget plans and assure nervous financial markets, Mr. Labrecque said a Clinton Administration might want to appoint a few Republicans to the Cabinet, much the way President Kennedy reached into the Republican ranks in 1960 to name C. Douglas Dillon as Treasury Secretary.
 
Graig O. McCaw
Chairman of McCaw Cellular Communications.
 Mr. McCaw looked favorably on the new Administration on the basis of his company's experience with those who have been associated with Mr. Clinton. "We view Clinton and the change in administration in a positive light because his people are very familiar with telecommunications and are open-minded about new ideas," he said. He noted that Vice President-elect Al Gore, as a Senator, had sponsored a bill, signed into law last year, that promoted research into fiber-optic telecommunications networks.
Mr. McCaw said his company provides cellular telephone service to Little Rock, Ark., and that President-elect Clinton "had in our experience been an advocate of telecommunications."
Mr. McCaw said he had greater enthusiasm for President Reagan than for President Bush. "Under Mr. Reagan, the Government was philosophically probusiness. But under Mr. Bush, it was philosophically pro status quo," tending to favor large, already established businesses.
But Mr. McCaw still has concerns about the President-elect. "A Democratic victory has the potential of making the country go back to the big-government approach and that is my greatest fear."
 
Henry Kaufman
Consultant and former chief economist at Salomon Brothers.
 For Mr. Kaufman, who speaks for the nation's bond markets as much as anyone, President-elect Clinton will be an acceptable chief executive if he adheres to a cautious economic policy. That means some deficit spending, but not enough to frighten bond traders and cause them to drive up interest rates.
"The great issue for Mr. Clinton is whether he can orchestrate a glide path for economic growth that will not disturb the financial markets," he said.
Given the weak economy, the correct glide path would include $20 billion to $30 billion in the next 12 months in public works spending, adding that much to the deficit in the process. That is more or less what Mr. Clinton has advocated but well below the $50 billion in job-creating public spending that some economists say is the minimum needed to bring economic growth to an acceptable level.
"There is some infrastructure spending that he should do modestly," Mr. Kaufman said, putting the emphasis on "modest." The markets would also approve of quick action on another item among Mr. Clinton's proposals: a tax credit that encourages companies to invest in new machinery and equipment -- creating jobs to make the machinery.
"I think there is some leeway to do the investment tax credit without breaking the budget agreement," Mr. Kaufman said, referring to the 1990 deficit reduction law that put limits on spending and tax cuts.
For Mr. Kaufman, the President-elect will have failed if bond traders get nervous that the new Administration is pumping too much new money into the economy. Fearful of inflation, they would drive up interest rates -- just when the weak economy requires lower rates, not higher ones.
"The Federal Reserve should bring down rates by another half percentage point," Mr. Kaufman said. "But the Fed will do this only if there is no danger of higher inflation."
 
Frank Levy
Labor economist at Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
 On the crucial issue of jobs, a Clinton Administration should be helped by two forces: the timing of the economic cycle and demographics. But it must also prod the economy with a stimulus package, Mr. Levy said.
Mr. Clinton needs to bolster the economy quickly so that his longer-range plans to generate jobs through increased investment in education, training and local programs will be working in a buoyant economic environment, Mr. Levy said.
"Clinton's right to emphasize the benefits of education and training, but you need some running room before those programs really pay off," said Mr. Levy, who is the Daniel Rose Professor in Economics at M.I.T.
The new President, Mr. Levy says, should announce his deficit-reduction plans at the same time a stimulus package is rolled out. The deficit-curbing measures would likely take effect later, but they should be spelled out explicitly to ease the fears in financial markets that spending will proceed unchecked.
 
Gary C. Hufbauer
Senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics.
 Mr. Hufbauer said the election of Mr. Clinton heralded a broad philosophical change in American trade policy.
The Bush Administration had a strong ideological preference for free trade. Administration officials have tended to pay little attention to the short-term effects of trade in the belief that the world and the United States would be better off in the long term if each country produces and exports whatever it can make most efficiently and imports the rest. Mr. Hufbauer predicted that a Clinton Administration would probably look more closely at the immediate impact on jobs and economic growth in the United States.
The Bush Administration has also encouraged American companies to set up factories overseas, on the theory that the operations are necessary to winning foreign markets and that the factories will assemble American-made parts or pay royalties on American production processes. A Clinton Administration, in contrast, would encourage companies to produce at home, Mr. Hufbauer said.
The result would be "a somewhat less friendly environment for companies that are trying to expand overseas," he said.
Mr. Clinton's election makes it nearly certain that Congress will eventually approve legislation putting the provisions of the North American Free Trade Agreement into American law, Mr. Hufbauer said.
Mr. Clinton, who has endorsed the need for a pact, said that the agreement negotiated by the Bush Administration fell short in several important areas, including protection of the environment and American workers. But Mr. Hufbauer said Mr. Clinton's concerns were narrow enough to be addressed quickly.
"I think we're talking about a month of negotiations at most," he said.
 
Michael H. Walsh
Chairman of Tenneco
 Mr. Walsh, an early supporter of Mr. Clinton though he predicts that his taxes, like those of many well-to-do executives, will rise, said, "I just decided early on that Clinton was reaching out to a broad constituency of people whose commitment was needed if you were going to get, not just the economy, but the country, moving again."
Mr. Walsh, who knows a thing or two about turnarounds -- having revitalized both the Union Pacific railroad and Tenneco Inc., said, "Whether you're running a company or a country in difficulty, hope is a big part of the program."
One suggestion: "Mr. Clinton's first and foremost job is to decide who's going to be Secretary of the Treasury. He's got to make an appointment at Treasury that unmistakably communicates that while his Administration stands for change, it stands equally strongly for fiscal responsibility."
Though Mr. Walsh refused to name names, he suggested that Mr. Clinton look beyond the Democratic Party for appointees. "You need a healthy dose of people who have wrestled these kinds of alligators to the ground before. This is not a job that can be done strictly by amateurs."
 
William H. Brandon Jr.
President of First National Bank of Phillips County, Helena, Ark.
 Mr. Brandon, who has known Governor Clinton since 1973, said from that vantage point, the Clinton Administration can be good news for bankers. "His policies here have been basically probusiness, and he recognizes that banks are a major vehicle for business growth."
The President-elect's advocacy of community development banks to inject more capital and stimulate the economy in poor parts of the country is not worrisome, Mr. Brandon said, even though bankers tend to groan at the idea of government intervention in lending.
"He wants to use the thousands of banks we already have rather than start something totally new with a lot of direct Federal control," Mr. Brandon said.

HEADLINE: Union Pins Its Hopes on G.M.'s New Management

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 4

 BODY:
With the General Motors Corporation's newly appointed chief executive officer, John F. (Jack) Smith Jr., signaling that he needs labor's help in changing the company, industry analysts and union officials are hoping for a new era of improved labor relations at the nation's largest auto maker.
On Monday, Mr. Smith said he wanted to "find, cultivate and maintain common ground with union leaders" following weeks of rumors and worried speculation that the company's outside board of directors intended to get tough with the United Automobile Workers union. It is still too early, however, to predict what will happen next summer when the company and the union begin negotiating a new contract.
 
'It Looks Promising'
 "The rhetoric certainly goes in the direction of a more cooperative relationship," Harley Shaiken, an industry analyst at the University of California in San Diego, said. "The statement was designed to defuse rumors and to smooth the way for continued negotiations with the U.A.W. It looks promising in the short term. There is a perception that the U.A.W. is spoiling for a fight. The reality is quite different." 
 In recent weeks, Stephen P. Yokich, the U.A.W. vice president who heads the union's G.M. department, has been discussing a number of labor-related issues with Mr. Smith, including the possibility of more attractive early-retirement buyouts as a way of cutting back the work force. The average G.M. worker is about 45 years old and has been on the job some 20 years.
U.A.W. officials have declined to specify the other issues under discussion, though industry analysts say they include bringing back some of the thousands of component and assembly jobs General Motors has transferred to Mexico. Workers here are particularly bitter over their sense that they are competing with workers at General Motors plants across the border who are earning about $1.50 an hour, compared with $17 a hour in the United States plus nearly that same amount in health and other benefits.
In a joint statement Monday, after Mr. Smith's news conference in New York, Mr. Yokich and the U.A.W. president, Owen Bieber, reiterated their willingness to be a part of the solution at G.M. Their brief statement said in part, "We have indeed made some new beginnings with C.E.O. Jack Smith and his team, and look forward to building a constructive problem-solving relationship."
Union officials said they were also encouraged that Mr. Smith made a point of saying that in addition to better relations with the union, he also wants to reconsider whether G.M. needs to sell more than 100 different models and to find ways to consolidate engineering and other car-making activities to become more efficient. Mr. Shaiken and other industry analysts have said that those tasks, along with better-designed cars, will be pivotal to the company's future.
"If this is Smith's attitude, then I think the union will reciprocate," said Douglas Fraser, the retired U.A.W. president, who is a professor of labor relations at Wayne State University here. "This could be the turning point."
Now more than ever, industry analysts say, General Motors needs the support of the union to meet its goals for improved quality, efficiency and productivity while undergoing painful restructuring. They point out that both the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation were turned around in the early 80's with labor's help. Mr. Yokich, the former head of the U.A.W.'s Ford department, played a key role in Ford's turnaround in the 80's.
"It would be easy to stand back and say, 'Labor is in decline; nuke 'em,' " said an executive at one of the other auto companies, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "But that's not true for the auto industry. The U.A.W. is a powerful, well-organized union. G.M. needs the cooperation of labor for orderly downsizing."
The U.A.W. is already playing an important role in G.M.'s transition by helping arrange transfers of thousands of laid-off workers from one G.M. plant to another. But the transfers have created a new class of auto worker -- the so-called G.M. gypsies -- and generated considerable pain for those who are displaced and created political turmoil for union officials.
The company and the union have also been involved in a number of successful joint projects, with the Saturn plant in Spring Hill, Tenn., perhaps the best-known example of innovation on the assembly lines.
 
Dwindling Union Membership
 The U.A.W. may still be one of labor's better organized, more powerful unions. But it has lost nearly 40 per cent of its membership in the last 12 years, dropping to about 850,000 from 1.4 million, largely because of lost jobs in industries such as autos and farm equipment. The union has not organized any of the Japanese auto assembly plants in the United States, and it suffered a national defeat last spring at Caterpiller when striking workers went back to work after management threatened to hire replacements.
At G.M. since 1978, 210,000 hourly jobs have been lost, with thousands more expected over the next several years.
"You cannot get decent production and decent quality if you have everyone on the edge of fear," said Irving Bluestone, a retired U.A.W. vice president who is also a professor of labor relations at Wayne State. And it is not only hourly workers who are afraid of losing their jobs these days, Mr. Bluestone added, but salaried ones, too.
 
'A Very Uneasy Relationship'
 G.M. has alienated thousands of workers in the last several years by a mix of secrecy and overly generous bonuses to executives. The company has also pitted assembly plants against each other to determine which to close, as in the case of the Willow Run plant in Ypsilanti, Mich., which will shut down sometime next year after losing what analysts describe as a bidding war with a plant in Arlington, Tex.
G.M. has repeatedly declined to specify its reasons for choosing Arlington, beyond saying that it needed only one plant to make full-sized, rear-wheel-drive Chevrolets and Buicks. And since last February's announcement of the Willow Run closing, G.M. has refused all requests from news reporters to visit the plant, though they are invited to tour other plants.
"Throughout the 1980's, G.M. has had a very uneasy relationship with workers," Mr. Shaiken said. "They have a disastrous record of symbolic actions that inflamed tensions at just the wrong time. There is a lot of cynicism and distrust -- more than at Ford and Chrysler."
 
Perceived Inequality
 G.M. outraged workers in 1989, for example, by paying top executives bonuses averaging $44,800, while workers' profit-sharing benefits that year amounted to just $50 apiece. That same spring G.M. nearly doubled the pensions of top executives. When Roger B. Smith retired as chairman in 1990, he was awarded an annual pension of $1.1 million. It was later trimmed slightly.
At the same time, with General Motors still racking up record profits in the late 1980's, the U.A.W. negotiated lucrative contracts that keep its members among the highest paid industrial workers in America, with health benefits that are also near the top. Workers at Ford and Chrysler have the same agreement.
Health-care costs are estimated to add more than $600 to the cost of each Big Three vehicle. Still, union officials say that auto workers' current wages of about $17 an hour put them only slightly ahead of inflation, and behind their counterparts in Europe. Auto workers in Japan, who are also unionized, earn only slightly less than American auto workers.
The company announced sizable health-benefit cutbacks for its salaried employees in September and indicated that it might seek similar reductions from hourly workers during next summer's contract negotiations. Mr. Bieber and Mr. Yokich responded by saying they "have no intention of going backward on health-care benefits."
Also under contention may be the $4.1 billion income-security package that the union negotiated with G.M. in 1990. It guarantees that laid-off workers -- under a program labeled the Jobs Bank -- receive nearly their full incomes and benefits, at least until next September. Workers at the other two auto companies have similar income guarantees.
While some Wall Street analysts have suggested that the Jobs Bank is part of G.M.'s cost problems, others disagree. "The Jobs Bank has been painted as a boondoggle that G.M. got shackled with in a moment of excess," Mr. Shaiken said. "It was never designed for the kind of slide G.M. has taken. It bought G.M. labor peace."
Mr. Bieber has said that he won't give up income security next year.
"The Jobs Bank was designed to be a stabilizing force, and I think that it was," said a union spokesman, Frank Joyce. "Why do you carry an umbrella? Because you think it's going to rain. We negotiated an umbrella. Well, it rained. It rained torrentially. It hailed."
And it is going to keep raining on G.M. workers. The company is expected to name seven more of the 21 factories it intends to close by 1995, including more assembly plants. "If anything came out of what happened this week, it is that there is now an opportunity for the company to sit down with the union in a number of key areas," Mr. Shaiken said.
"There's an opening," he continued. "How large that opening is, and how far it will go, nobody knows. It's going to take more than rhetoric."

HEADLINE: Data Show Economy Is Unimproved

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
The first three post-election economic reports did little today to challenge the presumption that President-elect Bill Clinton would inherit a lackluster economy.
The Federal Reserve said today that economic activity was increasing at a slow and uneven rate around the nation. That less-than-stellar picture was reinforced by the Commerce Department's report that while factory orders had picked up in September, business backlogs fell. And the United States Chamber of Commerce said business confidence fell sharply in October. 
 In its most recent economic survey, which includes information collected as recently as last week, the Fed said that the manufacturing sector lost some momentum in October as several regions experienced declining demand or a slower pace of expansion. Manufacturers said they were concerned about the weakness in foreign markets and about anemic consumer confidence.
 
Brighter Retail Sales
 But the central bank's report, known as the Beige Book, painted a brighter picture for retail sales, noting that they grew in most regions although the extent of the gains varied. The Fed also reported an improvement in housing construction and sales in several regions. In California, however, the real estate market suffered from sluggish sales and declining prices.
And in an important index of expansion, the Fed said that several regions reported a slight increase in loan demand in recent weeks, but it noted that mortgage refinancing seemed to have peaked.
The Beige Book is published eight times a year and is based on surveys of regional economic activity made by the Fed's 12 district banks.
In a somewhat more optimistic report, the Commerce Department said that orders for new manufactured goods rose in September after falling the two previous months. The 1.1 percent increase in factory orders, to a seasonally adjusted $239.4 billion, was the largest increase since June, and came after a 2.2 percent decline in August.
But the report also noted that business backlogs had declined for their 13th straight month, dampening hopes that corporations would be adding many new workers.
 
Economists Not Optimistic
 One bright spot in the Commerce Department survey was that an important measure of business investment -- orders of nonmilitary capital goods -- climbed 7.8 percent, after falling by 3.9 percent in August.
In all, economists were not sanguine about today's news, which came a day after the Commerce Department reported that the index of leading economic indictors, a gauge that predicts the economy's future, fell by three-tenths of 1 percent in September, producing the first back-to-back monthly declines since 1991.
"In the fourth quarter, growth will definitely be weaker," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist with Merrill Lynch. "That is pretty much baked in." He predicted slack growth of 1.5 percent in the fourth quarter, down considerably from the Commerce Department's preliminary estimate of 2.7 percent in the third quarter.
Also pointing to more sluggishness, the United States Chamber of Commerce reported today that its business confidence index plunged in October to its lowest level since December. The index fell from 58 in August to 53.3 in October, with 50 or more indicating the prospect for an expanding economy.
 
Possible New Hope
 "Businesses are quite negative about the next six months," said William T. Archey, the chamber's senior vice president for policy.
He said Mr. Clinton's victory might help increase business confidence. "A new Administration always brings new hope, and confidence can't get much worse than it's been," he said.
The Federal Reserve's report said retail sales were up markedly in the Cleveland district, and improved slightly in New England and the Philadelphia region. It added that retail activity remained sluggish in California as defense-related employment cutbacks continued.
In the manufacturing sector, producers of aircraft, military goods, primary metals and rubber and plastic goods said demand had slowed. But producers of building supplies, carpeting and home furnishings reported that demand had picked up, partly because of the post-hurricane rebuilding in the South.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Election Result Favors Municipals

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
For investors who own municipal bonds and the dealers who sell them, the election of Bill Clinton was good news yesterday. The President-elect has promised to raise taxes on higher-income individuals, and that is music to the ear of a trader or owner attuned to the tax-exempt market.
While those who may have their taxes raised will not be happy, the higher rates they pay will also make the tax-exempt municipal bond market a more attractive tax shelter for their money, analysts say. 
 With higher tax rates, several traders noted, the yield on a tax-exempt municipal bond becomes more valuable because the equivalent yield in the taxable market moves higher.
"The market over the last few days has come to realize that a Democratic President with a Democratic Congress could mean higher taxes," said Frank Scaraggi, director of institutional trading for municipal bonds at Lehman Brothers. "And municipals are the only tax shelter."
James J. Cooner, senior vice president at the Bank of New York, added, "Tax-free income received from municipal bonds is worth more in a rising tax environment."
Mr. Cooner said a municipal bond with a 6 percent yield equaled 8.7 percent from a bond that is subject to Federal income tax in the 31 percent tax bracket, currently the top tax rate. But at a rate of 36 percent, the 6 percent yield is equal to a 9.37 percent return on a taxable bond. Mr. Clinton has proposed raising the tax rate to 36 percent on families with incomes over $200,000 a year. The demand yesterday was enough to push the prices of actively traded municipal issues up by 1/8 to 1/4 point, traders said. Some of the more popular issues that are also insured rose as much as 1/2 point, driving yields lower.
The other effect of the election on the municipal market came from local voting. There were a host of issues on the ballots around the nation that would authorize new state or local bond issues or place some kinds of limits on government spending or taxing power. Some large bond issues were approved and when final results are in, voters may have approved more new spending that many analysts had expected.
In California, voters passed a $1.5 billion wastewater improvement bond issue in Los Angeles and a $900 million million state issue to repair public schools. But voters rejected a $1 billion bond authorization, the second-largest issue on the ballots around the country, for California railroads.
In New York, voters easily rejected the $800 million bond issue aimed at creating jobs through spending to improve roads, water and sewer projects and other important public projects. But in New Jersey, voters did approve a $345 million state bond issue for purchasing land for parks and other environmental purposes.
On the issue of limits on govenment spending and taxing, the ballot proposals were important because they could limit a state or local government's ability to issue bonds and could affect the credit rating of those that are issued.
In Michigan, voters defeated proposals that would have cut current property tax levels and limited future increases. Rating agencies had said that the proposals, if approved, could hurt the state's credit rating. In Colorado, voters did pass a plan to limit state spending increases to the rate of inflation. Because the proposal limits state and local government flexibility it could have an impact on credit ratings in the future.
 
Treasury Market
 In the Treasury market, prices moved around but ended little changed on the day, except for the 30-year bond, which was down 9/32 , to yield 7.67 percent, up from 7.65 percent Tuesday.
Several traders said there was no message about the election because prices had already fallen sharply in the last month, in part because of the anticipation of a Clinton victory and the probability of a spending program to stimulate the economy.
Mr. Clinton made a nod to concerns about his programs in his first news conference as President-elect yesterday. "I say to our financial and business leaders that although change is on the horizon, we understand the need to pursue stability even as we pursue new growth," he said.
William Pike, managing director at Chemical Securities Inc., said some of the market's attention would now turn to Mr. Clinton's appointments, especially that of Treasury Secretary. These decisions could move the market because they might indicate how cautious or aggressive the President-elect would be on economic policy and the Federal budget deficit.
One interesting development was that bond prices rose in early trading in Europe well above their closing levels on Tuesday. But most of this was given up by the end of trading in New York.
David Smart, a managing director at Fiduciary Trust International in London, said Europeans seemed to be buying for two reasons. One is that with the dollar rising against Europen currencies, owning American securities could be a good bet for Europeans. And he suggested that European investors might be a little less worried about the impact a Clinton Presidency would have on the bond market because the record American budget deficit would limit his options.
In the junk-bond market, a rumor about a new investment of $500 million by KLM Royal Dutch Airlines into Northwest Airlines, sent the prices of the company's bonds soaring. Traders said that the price of some bonds were up as much as five or six points during the day and finished up about two points, althogh KLM has denied the rumor.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: CONNECTICUT -- U.S. SENATE RACE;
Victorious Dodd to Press for Campaign Limits

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Nov. 4

 BODY:
The day after winning Connecticut's most expensive Senate race, Senator Christopher J. Dodd vowed today to work for legislation to limit the cost and length of campaigns.
"I can't think of anything that would do more to level the playing field and eliminate a lot of the concerns that are reflected by some of the peripheral issues like term limitations," Mr. Dodd said at a news conference at the Goodwin Hotel. "Campaign finance reform is something I am going to push for ardently and immediately." 
 Mr. Dodd, a Democrat from East Haddam, won re-election to a third Senate term on Tuesday with 59.2 percent of the vote, to 38.5 percent for his Republican opponent, Brook Johnson, a Greenwich textiles executive new to politics.
 
Dodd Raised $3.5 Million
 Mr. Johnson contributed almost $2 million to his own campaign, and spent an estimated $2.5 million, but Mr. Dodd raised $3.5 million for his. Mr. Johnson attacked the incumbent for accepting money from political-action committees, accused him of being beholden to special-interest groups and advocated term limits for Congress.
Mr. Dodd, who said during the campaign that he had to seek contributions because he was not wealthy, said today that he would like to see a new campaign-finance law take effect for the 1994 elections.
He said he was excited by the prospect of working with a President of his own party. The election results, he said, were a signal from voters that "they clearly want things done differently in this nation" to restart the economy.
"They want to see the country come together and start working as one," he said. "They're tired of the partisanship. They're tired of the finger-pointing. They want to see a government that takes their interests to heart and works on their problems."
 
Johnson's Plans
 Mr. Johnson spent today relaxing with his campaign staff, but Tuesday night, in his concession call to Mr. Dodd and in his speech to supporters, he vowed to stay involved in Connecticut politics.
"I am in it for one reason," Mr. Johnson said. "You can step forward and make a difference in this town and this country.
"I'm not going to wait four years," he said. "I am going to run again. I don't think I did a bad job. I need to polish a few rough edges."
He would not say what office he might seek next, but the terms of both Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., an independent, and Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, a Democrat, expire in 1994.
Mr. Dodd said today that Mr. Johnson had accepted his invitation to meet in the coming weeks to discuss how to stay involved.
"Brook Johnson said last evening he wanted to stay involved, and I welcome that," Mr. Dodd said. "He plans on staying in the state and being involved in public policy and public life, and I welcome him."
Surveys of voters leaving the polls on Tuesday supported Mr. Dodd's assessment that the economy was the driving issue in the election.
On economic questions, the only voters among whom the Republican won majorities were those who said that their financial situation was better than in 1988, or who said that they earned over $75,000 a year, or that the condition of the national economy was good. Each of those groups was a small minority of the vote.
Connecticut's income tax did not appear to be a factor in the Senate race, although the surveys found that 55 percent of those questioned opposed the tax, compared with 42 percent who supported it. Mr. Dodd won a majority of both groups of voters.
Many voters split their tickets. Mr. Dodd won the ballots of 34 percent of President Bush's voters, as well as 82 percent of those who voted for Gov. Bill Clinton. Among voters who cast ballots for Ross Perot, the survey found that 48 percent voted for Mr. Dodd and 52 percent for Mr. Johnson.
As a Democrat, in fact, Mr. Dodd received fewer votes than Mr. Johnson, according to the unofficial figures available today: 552,821 for Mr. Dodd, to 553,655 for Mr. Johnson.
The Democrat's large margin of victory was provided by the 297,735 people who voted for him on the line of A Connecticut Party, Governor Weicker's independent party, which had endorsed him.
Asked today about the influence of A Connecticut Party, Mr. Dodd was at a loss. He had thanked the party for its endorsement, he said, and thanked Mr. Weicker, but he had never mentioned the party during his campaign.
"I'm a Democrat," he said, "and I ran as a Democrat."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Infiniti Account Is Switched To Chiat From Hill, Holliday

BYLINE: By Kenneth N. Gilpin

 BODY:
CONTINUING the turmoil that has rocked the automotive marketing world for nearly two years, the Nissan Motor Corporation U.S.A. said yesterday that it had pulled its Infiniti division advertising account from Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos Inc. and placed it with Chiat/Day/Mojo Inc.
Chiat has handled the $165 million advertising account for the auto maker's Nissan division since 1987. 
 Nissan, which on Monday reported its first net loss in four decades, said in a statement that the decision was part of an effort to "better focus all communications and image enhancement" in the United States.
As a result of the loss of the $75 million account, Hill, Holliday will shut its office in Marina del Rey, Calif., and dismiss many of its 118 staff members there, Paula Polito, a spokeswoman, said.
At the same time, the account is a coup for the Venice, Calif., office of Chiat, which in the last few months lost the estimated $20 million account of Shearson Lehman Brothers and the $60 million creative portion of the account for the American Express Company's flagship charge card.
Hill, Holliday won both kudos and raspberries for its initial "rocks and trees" ads when the Infiniti campaign began in November 1989. Characterized by some agency executives and analysts as "Zen advertising," the initial spots were criticized because they were seen as not emphasizing the car quickly enough.
"Those ads created an immediate brand awareness for Infiniti, but they became a joke," said George Peterson, president of Auto Pacific Group, an automotive marketing research company in Santa Ana, Calif. "And once Hill, Holliday had determined that rocks and trees had gotten Infiniti into the vocabulary of luxury-car buyers, they didn't have the next step that showed the car."
Hill, Holliday's spokeswoman defended the agency's record with Infiniti, noting that the car's sales grew 30 percent in 1991 and that so far this year sales are up another 18 percent, to 33,654.
"I think we fell victim to the economy," she said. "They told us they wanted to consolidate and give it to Chiat, Day, and that's the end of it."
Don Spetner, a spokesman for Nissan North America, said, "Hill, Holliday helped us launch the division and got us up very quickly to a high level of awareness. But we also have a positive feeling about Chiat, Day and what they have done for Nissan's business."
After criticizing Hill, Holliday, Mr. Peterson noted that Infiniti's managers could have done a better job defining its market niche.
"Infiniti never really told the press what their volume objectives were," he said. "Because of that, they were always destined to be measured against Lexus," Toyota's luxury sedan, which was introduced two months before Infiniti and has been considered a bigger success as it has outsold Infiniti.
"Their objectives were only to sell about half what Lexus sold," he added. "If they had just told folks that, they would be perceived as much more successful than they are today."
Nissan's dismissal of its agency is the latest in a string of similar moves made by nearly a dozen auto makers since February 1991. Just last week, BMW said it had placed its $65 million account under review. Ammirati & Puris, the agency that had held the BMW account for 18 years, decided not to participate in the review.
"A general panic and an intense fight for market share has been going on since 1987" among auto makers, said Martin Puris, president and chief executive of Ammirati & Puris. "And advertising is always at the whip end of the craziness that goes on in business. If computers are having a tough time, the agencies get hit. It's the same for the car business."
Bob Kuperman, president and chief executive of Chiat, said the agency had no immediate plans to alter Infiniti's campaign. "In making the transition, we have to determine what our strategy is from here," he said. He added that it "would be premature to say" if Michael Douglas, the announcer in Infiniti's current ads, would continue in his role.
In addition to the advertising shift, Nissan said it had placed public relations accounts for the Nissan and Infiniti divisions with Bob Thomas & Associates, the public relations subsidiary of Chiat.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Domestic Vehicle Sales Up 9.7% in Late October

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 4

 BODY:
A surge in the sales of light trucks pushed overall sales of domestically built vehicles up 9.7 percent in late October, the nation's auto makers reported yesterday.
Analysts were not able to pinpoint any reasons for the surge, except that the popularity of mini-vans, sport-utility vehicles and light trucks as personal transportation continued to grow unabated. 
 Sales of domestically built cars during the period of Oct. 21-31 fell 1.2 percent, to 225,946; sales of domestically built light trucks, however, rose 28.5 percent, to 170,098.
For all of October, sales of all types of vehicles, domestic and imported, rose 7.7 percent.
 
New Monthly Record
 Joel Pitcoff, sales analyst for the Ford Motor Company, said Ford's light-truck sales for the month established a new record for October.
"The new Mercury Villager mini-van is very hot, and the Ford Explorer sold more than 29,000 for the month, a new monthly record," he said.
Harvey Heinbach, automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch & Company in New York, said: "It's easy to tell you what happened; it's tough to tell you why. We don't have any economic data that provides a rationale."
Whatever the reason, auto executives were delighted that some products were selling amid overall sluggish conditions and the distractions of Presidential politics.
"With the elections over, consumers can go about their purchase decisions and the country can get on with the economic recovery," said Yale Gieszl, executive vice president of the Toyota Motor Corporation's United States sales subsidiary. Toyota's light-truck sales rose 1.3 percent, to 23,613.
Car dealers echoed the sentiments of executives. "Now that the mud-slinging is over, we can get back down to business again," said James Flanigan, operator of Flanigan Chevrolet in North Tonawanda, N.Y. Mr. Flanigan said car and light-truck sales had been slow at his dealership.
The seasonally adjusted annual rate for sales of cars built in the United States, Canada and Mexico was 6.6 million during late October and 6.3 million for the entire month, the same as September.
For the month, domestic and imported vehicle sales totaled 1,112,789. Car sales fell 1 percent, to 699,263, but light-truck sales soared 26.6 percent, to 413,526.
 
General Motors Data
 The General Motors Corporation sold 236,919 cars in October, a decrease of eight-tenths of 1 percent from last year, and 136,842 light trucks, an increase of 26.9 percent. For the month, G.M. sold 226,827 domestically built cars, a decrease of 1.5 percent, and 134,799 domestically built light trucks, an increase of 27.5 percent.
Ford sold 161,805 cars for the month, an increase of 12.3 percent, and 124,561 light trucks, up 34.2 percent. Sales of Ford's domestically built cars were 157,985, an increase of 15.3 percent, and the company's domestic light-truck sales in the month were 124,561, up 34.2 percent
The Chrysler Corporation sold 63,127 cars in the month, a decrease of 9 percent, but light-truck sales rose 30.2 percent, to 92,430. Sales of Chrysler's domestically built cars were 57,529, down 9.5 percent, but domestically built light-truck sales were up 30.3 percent, to 91,848.
The Honda Motor Company sold 62,484 cars in October, a drop of 14.9 percent. Sales of Hondas built in the United States were 37,192, down 14.6 percent.
The Nissan Motor Company sold 35,900 cars for the month, an increase of 12.6 percent, and light-truck sales rose 28.5 percent, to 19,430.
Toyota's car sales fell 15.7 percent, to 56,940. Sales of Toyota's domestically built cars fell 19.8 percent, to 23,243.
The Mazda Motor Corporation and the Mitsubishi Motor Corporation posted car-sales increases of 13 percent and 18.5 percent, respectively, while Subaru, the American brand for Fuji Heavy Industries' cars, posted a 25.1 percent decrease in monthly sales, at 9,090.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Market Fund Yields Are Higher in Latest Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on money market funds moved higher in the week that ended yesterday, according to the latest IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report survey of more than 864 tax-exempt and taxable market funds.
Tax-exempt yields are up for the second consecutive week. But they are still below the levels of early October, when investors seeking tax-exempt paper drove yields lower by pouring money into the money market funds, normally the largest buyers of short-term tax-exempt paper. In the last few weeks, however, there has been a slight runoff of cash from the funds and an increase in supply of tax-exempt paper that is outpacing demand and putting some upward pressure on yields. 
 "In this market, the flow of cash into the tax-exempt money funds is important in determining the direction of yields," said Walter S. Frank, IBC/Donoghue's chief economist.
Assets of tax-exempt money funds fell by $137 million for the week, dropping the total to $96.7 billion, with the average number of days left to maturity of securities held in fund portfolios unchanged at 65, Donoghue's analysts said.
The seven-day average compounded yield rose smartly to 2.35 percent, from 2.18 percent last week, with the simple yield at 2.32 percent, up from 2.16 percent a week ago.
The 30-day average, which still reflects previous yield declines, has the compounded return at 2.27 percent, down from 2.36 percent last week and the simple return at 2.25 percent, down from 2.33 percent.
Not assuming state taxes, the taxable equivalent of the seven-day compounded yield this week for investors in the 28 percent tax bracket is about 3.26 percent, and 3.40 percent for investors in the 31 percent bracket.
Of the surveyed tax-exempt funds with assets greater than $100 million, IBC/Donoghue's said the Dreyfus Basic Municipal Money Market fund was again the best performer with a yield of 3.11 percent, up from 2.90 percent last week.
 
Taxable Yield: 2.79%
 In taxable money market funds, yields bounced slightly higher, as total assets dropped by $8.2 billion, to $483.2 billion. Of that total, institutional money fund assets fell by $5.2 billion, to $165.7 billion, with public funds off $3.1 billion, to a total of about $317.3 billion.
"At this end of the market, yields are expected to move up and down slightly in the near term," Mr. Frank said. "And the only big number that could change that is coming tomorrow in the October employment report."
The average seven-day compounded yield for a taxable money market fund was 2.79 percent, up from 2.78 percent last week, and the simple yield was 2.75 percent, compared with 2.74 percent. For the 30-day period the average compounded yield is 2.81 percent and the simple yield is 2.77 percent, both down 2 basis points from a week ago.
Analysts said the average days left to maturity of securities in portfolios rose by one, to 66, as managers displayed little fear of rates rising dramatically.
Standby Reserve Fund, distributed by Cowen & Company in New York, the top yield producer last week, had the best return this week with a yield of 3.87 percent, up from 3.78 percent. For government-only funds with assets under $100 million, the United Services Government Securities Savings fund, distributed by United Services in San Antonio, was the best as it cracked through 4 percent, to 4.03 percent.
Elsewhere, the average yield on bank money market accounts held at 2.79 percent this week.

HEADLINE: Blue Chips Slide, With Dow Falling 29.44

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks fell sharply yesterday in a post-election response to Bill Clinton's White House victory, with investors nervous about the Democrat's plans to stimulate the economy.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 29.44 points at 3,223.04. Volume totaled 194.4 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange, compared with 208.1 million on Tuesday. Declining issues led advances, 1,011 to 734. 
 The Nasdaq's composite index ended up 0.94 at 605.52, with advancing issues narrowly edging out decliners.
Arnie Owen at Soundview Financial Group said that although the expected post-election rally did not take place, he saw "pockets of strength" in the over-the-counter market.
Analysts said that uncertainties about the outcome of the election have shifted to Mr. Clinton's Cabinet choices and economic growth plans.
Medical and drug stocks were among the weaker issues as investors continued to shun the industries amid expectations that health-care costs would be cut by the incoming Administration.
"A lot of people will want to wait and see who the key players are in the Administration," said Mark Tincher, manager of United States equity investments at the Chase Private Bank. Speaking of the stock market's expected gains under the new Administration, he said: "I think people got a bit ahead of themselves. The reality is that it's not going to happen overnight."
 
Clinton's Late Afternoon Speech
Robert Stovall, president of Stovall/21st Advisers, noted that the market's fall accelerated during Mr. Clinton's televised speech in late afternoon. Mr. Clinton said he would insure that his program to stimulate economic growth would not disrupt financial markets.
"Maybe the market expected him to say something more," Mr. Stovall said. "We're not getting off to a very upbeat start with him."
David Shulman, United States equity strategist at Salomon Brothers, said in a report released yesterday that the sluggish economy and high debt burden "will make it difficult for Bill Clinton to stimulate the economy."
But several analysts said they still saw a positive environment for stocks. "the alternatives are not that attractive," said Tony Kreisel, co-manager of the Putnam Fund for Growth and Income.
Historically, stock gains for the first year after a new Democratic Party administration have been about 4 percent.
Among individual stocks, shares of Compaq Computer slipped 7/8, to 39 1/2. The company said that while a continuing computer component shortage may dampen its fourth-quarter revenues, it still expects results in the period to be its strongest in 1992.
News that A.T.&T. plans to buy a 33 percent stake in McCaw Cellular helped shares of telecomunications stocks. McCaw was up 2 1/8, to 26 3/4, but A.T.&T.'s lost 5/8, to 42 3/4.
Archer Daniels Midland lost 1 1/2, to 25, as investors reacted to the threat of a United States-European Community trade war over an oilseeds dispute.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks fell 2.81, to 417.11. The American Stock Exchange index lost 0.89, to 381.94.
The New York Stock Exchange Composite index of all listed common stocks was off 1.45, to 229.79. The average share lost 21 cents.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher On Muted Response to Vote

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mostly higher on world currency markets yesterday in moderate, post-election trading.
Gold prices fell slightly worldwide. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $337.10 a troy ounce, down 40 cents from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold of $337.30, off 45 cents an ounce. 
 Currency dealers said there was only a muted response to Gov. Bill Clinton's victory in the Presidential race since it had been widely expected and was factored into the price of the dollar.
The dollar's rise was attributed in part to "the perception that a Democratic President and Congress approach will be more toward fiscal stimulus, and therefore there will be higher interest rates," said Kevin Lawrie, a vice president at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. Higher interest rates make dollar-denominated securities more attractive to investors. In Tokyo, where financial markets were closed Tuesday for a national holiday, the dollar settled at 122.90 yen, down 0.79 yen from Monday. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 122.85 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 123.05 yen, up from 122.40 yen on Tuesday.
In London, the British pound was unchanged at $1.5510. In New York, it cost $1.5435 to buy one pound, less expensive than Tuesday's $1.5505.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.5730 German marks, up from 1.5675; 1.4055 Swiss francs, up from 1.3985; 5.3220 French francs, up from 5.3085; 1,335.50 Italian lire, down from 1,337.00, and 1.2467 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2428.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.5690 German marks, up from 1.5625; 1.4015 Swiss francs, up from 1.3920; 5.3065 French francs, up from 5.2930; 1.7649 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7575; 1,335.00 Italian lire, up from 1,333.38, and 1.2461 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2418.

HEADLINE: Wells Fargo Prices Floating-Rate Notes

 BODY:
Wells Fargo & Company yesterday priced $150 million of floating-rate notes due 1994 through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers.
The two-year floating-rate notes were priced at 100 to float quarterly at a full percentage point above the three-month London interbank offered rate, the basic short-term interest rate in the Eurodollar market and the rate to which many Eurodollar loans and deposits are tied. The rate, known as Libor, is similar in concept to the United States prime rate except that it is less subject to individual bank adjustment. 
 Noncallable by the San Francisco bank holding company before they reach maturity, the notes are rated Ba-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A- by Standard & Poor's.
Underwriters said the notes would pay interest quarterly. By late in the day yesterday, the three-month Libor rate was about 3.56 percent.

PUB-DATE: November 5, 1992

SECTION: Section D; Page 2; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 828 words

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Still Banking On Trouble

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
WILL taxpayers, insurers of last resort for bank deposits, once again be left holding the bag? Warnings of humongous bank losses ahead, offered in a new book and splashed around the airwaves by Ross Perot, have been dismissed by Federal regulators in a rare public display of wrath. And the regulators' scorn was only reinforced last week with reports of surging bank earnings.
But there is much more to the new book, "Banking on the Brink" by Roger J. Vaughn and Edward W. Hill (Washington Post Company Briefing Books), than estimates of which banks may be buried under a rubble of bad loans or how much it might cost Uncle Sugar to dig them out. The two economists argue that commercial banking is dying -- at least commercial banking-as-usual. And they see little evidence that the road to a more diverse system for transforming private savings into productive capital has been mapped by Washington. 
 Will there be a Federal takeover of undercapitalized lenders that empties the deposit insurance fund? The experts disagree, as experts are wont to do. And Mr. Vaughn and Mr. Hill are numbered among the pessimists. Surprisingly, though, in light of the bitter responses to the Vaughn-Hill findings, the range of disagreement among independent analysts is not all that great.
If insolvent banks were promptly shuttered, the two authors estimate that the net cost of paying off the insured depositors would run between $45 billion and $60 billion. The Congressional Budget Office puts the number at $43 billion, while Robert Litan, a bank watcher at the Brookings Institution, says $30 billion to $50 billion.
In the less bearish forecasts, deposit insurance premiums, plus funds borrowed under the insurers' established lines of credit, would probably let Washington squeak through the 1990's without tapping taxpayers for more cash. That might not be the case with the Vaughn-Hill scenario; hence Ross Perot's plea to "just tell me now."
The core problem, though, is not the $10 billion to $20 billion in liabilities that might or might not spill over to the United States Treasury. What really upsets Messrs. Vaughn and Hill and many other banking specialists is that delays in downsizing commercial banking could multiply these expected losses many times over, while leaving in place an inefficient system for channeling the nation's savings to the creditworthy.
The wretched performance of many commercial banks, including many of the biggest, in the last decade has been casually attributed to stupidity or venality. But the truth is more complicated.
Deregulation has forced banks to compete with nonbanks at ever-decreasing margins. Fidelity and Vanguard mutual funds have become as attractive places to store cash as, say, Chase or Citibank, while GE Credit and Sears have become highly competitive lenders. Meanwhile blue-chip corporations, long the meal tickets of the big banks, have learned they can borrow direct from the securities markets.
Many banks panicked, responding to harsh realities by rushing into lending businesses where brighter lights feared to tread: third world debt, oil and gas, commercial real estate.
That suicidal urge to make up for lost lending volume is presumably spent. And thanks to the plunge in interest rates on short-term deposits, average bank margins have risen sharply in recent months. But the profit reprieve is surely temporary: Mr. Litan reckons that commercial banking's lending capacity is still a third larger than can be justified by its core business. And in any case, Mr. Vaughn notes, "the sick banks aren't the ones making money." Unless the mortally wounded are put out of their misery promptly, he worries the taxpayers will end up with the hospital bill.
As of Dec. 19, regulators will be, in fact, under Congressional orders to perform this triage, raising minimum capital standards for all banks and closing the ones that cannot make the hurdle. Washington is also taking a cautious stab at discouraging the banks' tendency to plunge by linking deposit insurance premiums to their lending risks.
But Mr. Vaughn notes that measures to sweep away the weak could also drive out the strong. Squeeze much harder and a successful "wholesale" bank like Morgan Guaranty, with little need to raise money through insured deposits, might decide a bank charter is a luxury it need not afford.
Lawrence White of New York University adds, moreover, that it is by no means clear that the bank-busting regulators will chose their targets accurately. Accounting rules still permit banks to value assets at cost rather than market price -- a time bomb when the asset is an office building worth perhaps 40 cents on the dollar.
Almost everyone, it seems, agrees where commercial banks are and where regulators should be pointing them. What is less well understood, though, is that the likeliest path to an efficient, profitable commercial banking industry runs through a mine field.

SECTION: Section C; Page 17; Column 1; Cultural Desk

LENGTH: 1225 words

HEADLINE: Review/Architecture;
6 Visions of a New Ferry Terminal

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP

 BODY:
The world's most famous cheap date will soon be puttin' on the Ritz. If things proceed according to plan, voyagers on the Staten Island Ferry, that cut-rate, late-night ship of love, will no longer await departure in hateful surroundings. Instead, urban romantics, and mere 9-to-5 commuters, will grandly embark from a crystal palace. Or a classical pavilion. Or a soaring, barrel-vaulted terminal crowned with a gigantic illuminated clock. Or whichever of six remarkable designs, by a roster of prominent architects, is chosen today in an architectural competition to find a plan for a new Whitehall Ferry Terminal down at the tip of Manhattan.
As Edna St. Vincent Millay didn't put it, it is all very merry to go back and forth between these six lovely visions of the ferry. These designs, taken together, demonstrate the range of solutions serious architects can bring to the same problem. And the manner in which the design is being chosen proves there is still plenty of life in that venerable device for selecting architects, the competition. 
 
As the competition entries illustrate, architecture can be anything now. It can celebrate history or look afresh at the present. It can be a designer label or a low-profile intervention; an engineering tour de force or an urban shopping mall. The six finalists' designs are an impressive group. Any one of them would raise the art of municipal building by several notches. What the competition has not produced -- yet -- is a focus: the coherent urban vision the sponsoring agency, the City Economic Development Corporation, must have if its desire for good architecture is to be more than a bid for prestige.
The existing terminal building, a banal box, was badly damaged by fire in September of last year. Plans to rebuild the terminal were already under way when the Economic Development Corporation stepped in and decided that the site demanded something more than another utilitarian shed. A commuter portal to Manhattan and a hub for bus and subway lines, the terminal is also a pivotal link in a revitalized Manhattan waterfront. In addition to its spectacular harbor views, the site fronts on Peter Minuit Plaza, a traffic snarl with the potential to become a major public space. Architecture, in the Economic Development Corporation's view, offered a better means than civil engineering to capitalize on these assets.
Two of the proposals are signature designs, bearing the hallmarks of their internationally renowned designers. The Aldo Rossi Studio di Architeturra has produced the most gravely historical of the designs; it employs Mr. Rossi's familiar vocabulary of spare classicism alleviated by bright colors. Columns, cornices and square Roman windows trim a green temple to water transport. No iconic Rossi lighthouses flash this time, which may be why the ship-shaped waiting room bisects the terminal like a boat run aground. Cone-roofed gatehouses flank the entrance to a piazza framed by arcades. The piazza looks exquisitely forlorn: a place to listen for the ghostly blasts of long departed liners.
Venturi, Scott Brown & Associates, in association with Anderson/ Schwartz Architects, have fashioned a trademark "decorated shed." The green exterior of this brash design owes nothing to weathered patina; in a nod to Wall Street, the walls are the color of freshly printed dollar bills. They are engraved with a full-scale rendering of the adjacent Battery Maritime Building. But this cartoon contextualism is but a setting for the design's main feature: a giant clock that faces out to the harbor. Of the six designs, this is the most conspicuous landmark, an architectural billboard impossible to ignore. There's nothing romantic about the message it spells out: Time Is Money.
Where Mr. Rossi and Mr. Venturi and Ms. Scott Brown remain within their customary esthetic bounds, Skidmore, Owings & Merrill has made a bold attempt to break out of its recent Art Deco mold. Alas, the stretch has pulled the firm's scheme to pieces. An industrial shed, a hat-shaped rotunda, and a floating hairpin ramp, slung from what appears to be the superstructure of a Navy destroyer, cover the ground like urban fragments. The separation of elements has one advantage: the scheme makes better use than most of Peter Minuit Plaza. And there are wonderful spaces within. But a project that is supposed to connect people to the water would instead take us miles away.
James Stewart Polshek & Partners claims the opposite extreme on the scale of ambition. Its design is disarmingly modest. A simple canopy opens into a spare pavilion, its walls of glass, its roof molded into a wave-like contour. The design's simplicity grows on you: Whitehall Terminal is for commuter ferries, not the Queen Mary. And Mr. Polshek has surpassed Mr. Rossi and Mr. Venturi and Ms. Scott Brown in distilling an earlier era of public works. His terminal's clean, mid-century modern lines recall a time when Kennedy was called Idlewild and New York looked with faith to its horizons.
Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates sits somewhere in the middle of these divergent roads. Fronted by gabled glass entrance canopies, the design takes its scale and lines from the Battery Maritime Building next door. But the terminal's spiritual cousins are the pseudo-industrial sheds of South Street Seaport. This is a ferry building half wishing it were a festival marketplace: not an unreasonable wish, considering all the train stations lately retrofitted as urban malls. Crystalline interiors sparkle within Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer's market halls. And the firm's desire to create a "people place" needs no defense. But why make people feel that they must buy something to belong there?
If the purpose of the competition was to transfer the terminal's design to architecture from engineering, then Rafael Vinoly deserves a slap on the wrist. His design shows how expressive engineering can be. With a spectacular roof of cantilevered trusses springing from slender supports, the terminal stretches out toward the harbor like a sinewy hand. The design balances more than a roof. It also strikes an equilibrium between shelter and circulation; it is partly a place to gather, partly a conduit to move people through space. A spiral observation tower counterpoints the roof's strong horizontal lines, but redundantly so. On a site surrounded by tall spires, who needs a vertical accent?
The ferry competition is not a beauty contest. It's a disservice to assess these six designs solely on the basis of their visual images. Each has tackled complex requirements for circulation, urban design, public space, transit links, retail concessions, not to mention the mechanics of ferry operations.
Yet it is through visual imagery that each design projects a civic statement: an idea about the city and the terminal's place in it. If Mr. Vinoly's design stands out, that is not because it is physically more striking but because its dynamic form projects a stronger connection to an urban vision. Renewing the city's transportation system is a top priority. Mr. Vinoly's scheme is visually alert to the urgency of the enterprise. Like a taut muscle of urban will, this design looks poised to drive the city forward. It gives symbolic form to forces that could knock the rust off bridges, subways and minds.
